site_title: TDCX reports 22.5% jump in Q1 2023 profit to US$20.5 million
summary: TDCX reported a 22.5% increase in Q1 2023 profit to $20.5 million, driven by an 8.2% rise in revenue to $124.3 million. The company grew its client base by 55% and became less reliant on its top five clients, which accounted for 76% of revenue. CEO Laurent Junique attributed the growth to the company's focus on adding value to clients by solving strategic customer-experience challenges, despite market uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The latest Q4 set of results brings Singapore-based TDCX’s earnings for the full year to S$104.9 million, up a marginal 1.1 per cent from its FY2021 profit of S$103.8 million.

The higher price target on the New York Stock Exchange-listed counter comes after CGS-CIMB raised its FY2023 to FY2024 forecasts for TDCX by 1.3 per cent to 3.1 per cent on stronger growth assumptions.
TDCX said revenue contributions from new economy clients stood at 93 per cent for the first nine months of the year.

site_title: Opec excludes Bloomberg, Reuters and WSJ reporters from meeting
summary: Opec+ is meeting as oil prices slide below $70 a barrel in New York, reversing gains made since a surprise cut in early April. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has excluded reporters from Bloomberg, Reuters, and the Wall Street Journal from covering the meeting, with invitations sent directly to journalists instead. The decision has no precedent in Opec's history and Bloomberg has asked for clarification, but received no response.

site_title: British consortium to invest US$9 billion in Indonesia mining, EV batteries
summary: A British consortium led by mining giant Glencore plans to invest approximately $9 billion in Indonesia's mining and electric vehicle (EV) battery sectors, with a focus on developing downstream industries to produce batteries and vehicles for major electric car manufacturers. The investment will be used to build an industrial park on Sulawesi island powered by wind energy, with a completion target of September.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s IPO market has raised US$1.58 billion as of April this year, second only to China in the Asia-Pacific region excluding Japan.

site_title: Toyota says some customers in Asia, Oceania face risk of data leak
summary: Toyota has revealed that customer information, including names, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, and vehicle registration numbers, may have been publicly accessible in some countries in Asia and Oceania from October 2016 to May 2023. The incident occurred due to human error and affected customers in countries excluding Japan. The company has not specified which countries were affected, but will take steps to address the issue and protect customer data.

images.alt_text: More than 2 million Toyota users face risk of vehicle data leak in Japan

site_title: Sri Lanka’s key inflation rate eases to 25.2% in May
summary: Sri Lanka's inflation rate decreased to 25.2% in May, easing from 35.3% in April, providing some relief to the crisis-hit economy. Food inflation decreased to 21.5% and non-food inflation reached 27%. Experts predict single-digit inflation by September and expect the central bank to keep policy rates unchanged. This easing inflation is also expected to prompt the central bank to maintain benchmark rates steady.

images.alt_text: ADB president Masatsugu Asakawa says the bank is "concerned about the deep crisis in the country and its impact on the people of Sri Lanka, especially the poor and the vulnerable, particularly women".

site_title: US mortgage rates hit near seven-month high during debt impasse
summary: US mortgage rates reached a 7-month high of 6.91% in May, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. The rate increase occurred after a debt-ceiling impasse, stifling demand for home purchases and refinancings. However, Treasury yields have fallen since a deal was reached, suggesting a potential decrease in mortgage rates next week. Home purchase index fell to its lowest level since March, and refinancing activity was the weakest since February.

site_title: The blue economy offers growth amid economic volatility
summary: The blue economy, or ocean economy, presents a promising opportunity for growth and diversified investments despite global economic uncertainties. With over 90% of global trade carried out through the world's oceans, this sector has the potential to double in size from $1.5 trillion to $3 trillion by 2030. However, financing and data gaps persist, hindering the sector's potential. To address this, collaboration between the financial sector and businesses is crucial, with efforts needed to democratize data and technology, and to create new public-private financing approaches.

images.alt_text: French divers Hugo Bischoff, CNRS (National Center for Scientific Research) scientist, and Emmanuel Gouin, doctor and safety diver, take pictures of the sea bed under the water to study the marine forest life, during a two and a half month expedition, as part of the "Under The Pole" mission, on the French island of Guadeloupe, off the coast of Le Moule, on April 16, 2023. (Photo by Olivier MORIN / AFP)

site_title: Mighty dollar can fight off the digital upstarts
summary: The US dollar's dominance in international commerce and fundraising is unlikely to be threatened by de-dollarisation efforts. Despite China's growing economic influence, the greenback's widespread use in global trade and the depth of the dollar-denominated capital market make it difficult for alternative currencies to gain traction. A proposed common currency for the Brics grouping also faces significant hurdles. Analysts suggest that de-dollarisation proponents may be misplacing their hopes in blockchain technology to end the dollar's hegemony. The US dollar is likely to remain a dominant currency in the foreseeable future.

images.alt_text: US currency, dollars, notes

site_title: IMF calls for carbon pricing to aid energy transition
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has called for carbon pricing to aid the global transition to renewable energy. The IMF's First Deputy Managing Director, Gita Gopinath, emphasized that carbon pricing is essential to finance the transition and warned against relying solely on "green" subsidies. She stated that current discussions on the energy transition focus too much on subsidies rather than prices, and that carbon pricing makes a significant difference in terms of fiscal implications. The IMF's call comes as the European Union expands its carbon market, which currently covers around 40% of the continent's emissions.

images.alt_text: A worker walks through the wastewater treatment plant at textiles manufacturer Ghim Li Group's fabric mill.
Joe Green’s Lightweight Green Aggregates (LiGrA) building materials are made from recycled waste.
Gillian Tan, MAS’ Chief Sustainability Officer and Assistant Managing Director (Development & International) at her first interview with the media on Tuesday (May 30, 2023) at the MAS Building.
A recent two-day conference in the Philippines explored the challenges and opportunities of shipping’s decarbonisation, including skills development for seafarers, and a “Maritime Just Transition”.

The Wujing Coal-Electricity Power Station in Shanghai. China's energy sector continues to invest in new coal mines and power plants, but these are now largely intended to act as a backup fuel source as wind and solar power become dominant.

site_title: As Pita seeks green light, Thailand’s economic outlook hinges on its achieving political stability
summary: Thailand's general election results have created uncertainty about the country's future, with the Move Forward Party led by Pita Limjaroenrat holding the most seats but falling short of an overall majority. The Election Commission has up to 60 days to verify the results, and Pita must secure a majority in both the Lower House and Senate to become prime minister. This has led to market instability, with the baht weakening against the US dollar and the stock market experiencing a decline, raising concerns about the country's economic outlook and the strength of democratic institutions.

images.alt_text: CP All, which operates Thailand's largest convenience store chain through the 7-Eleven brand, is a popular "buy" option according to a Bloomberg poll of analysts.
FILE PHOTO: Thailand's central bank is seen at the Bank of Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand April 26, 2016. REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo
XX
Thailand posts a trade deficit of US$1.47 billion in April versus an expected deficit of US$450 million, with imports showing a 7.3 per cent year-on-year contraction.

site_title: Sky-high hedge costs push big Japan insurers to riskier avenues
summary: Japan's major life insurers have increased their use of longer-dated currency hedges to a record to mitigate sky-high costs, with over 11% of overseas securities protected by these contracts. This shift reflects the challenge of managing currency risks in a domestic bond market constrained by the Bank of Japan's yield-control policy. Insurers are also diversifying their hedging methods, with put options more than tripling to 5.9%, and are expected to repatriate into Japan's super-long government bonds, creating yen-buying flows.

images.alt_text: Market players expect new BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda to keep monetary settings ultra-loose at his debut policy meeting but they think a change in the BOJ’s yield curve control, which keeps the benchmark 10-year government bond yield below 0.5 per cent, is likely at the June policy meeting.

site_title: Singapore-headquartered crypto data company Nansen to lay off 30% of staff
summary: Singapore-based crypto data company Nansen is laying off 30% of its staff, citing difficulties in the crypto market. The company, backed by venture capital firms GIC, Accel, and Andreessen Horowitz, is trying to focus on core areas after expanding into non-core business areas. Nansen CEO Alex Svanevik stated that the company's "cost base is too high relative to where the company is today" and has "several years of runway" left. This move comes amid an ongoing rout in cryptocurrency prices and a wave of bankruptcies and layoffs globally.

site_title: Scandal-hit UK business lobby outlines survival plan
summary: The Confederation of British Industry (CBI), UK's largest business lobby group, has outlined a survival plan amid a scandal over sexual harassment allegations, which could potentially lead to its collapse. The organization has announced significant changes, including the departure of its president and non-executive directors, and the creation of a new People & Culture Committee. A vote at an extraordinary general meeting will determine whether remaining members have confidence in the CBI's proposals for reform. The organization aims to refocus and reduce its size to address the challenges posed by the scandal.

images.alt_text: BizUK, an emergency body being created by public affairs firm WPI Strategy after discussions with Conservative and Labour Party officials, will support the representation of business to the main political parties.

site_title: German unemployment rises less than expected in May
summary: Germany's unemployment rate rose less than expected in May, increasing by 9,000 to 2.573 million, with a seasonally adjusted jobless rate of 5.6%. Despite a weak economy, the labour market remains steady overall, according to the Labour Office. Unemployment is 284,000 higher than in May 2022, and job openings decreased by 98,000 compared to the previous year.

site_title: China venture fundraising heading for weakest first half in 8 years
summary: China's venture capital fundraising is heading for its weakest first half in at least eight years, with US dollar funds reaching US$610 million and yuan funds totaling US$1.65 billion, according to Preqin data. A weak business environment, geopolitical tensions, and economic uncertainties are deterring investors, leading to a prolonged fundraising cycle for startups. Only two unicorns have been minted in the world's second-largest economy this year, and declining valuations of publicly listed firms are making it difficult for startups to seek funds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past a screen displaying the Hang Seng stock index outside Hong Kong Exchanges, in Hong Kong, China July 19, 2022. REUTERS/Lam Yik/File Photo

site_title: Makino Asia launches precision cutting machine to mark 50 years in Singapore
summary: Makino Asia, a precision-engineering company, launched a precision metal-cutting machine in Singapore to mark its 50th anniversary. The S50 Vertical Machining Centre boasts digital controls and artificial intelligence, promising to boost efficiency and provide consistent quality. The machine is designed for industries such as aerospace, automotive, and semiconductor, and will start sales in the end of this year. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong praised Makino Asia's significant investment in Singapore, highlighting the company's role in Singapore's industrialisation and its contribution to the country's precision engineering industry.

images.alt_text: Biomedical manufacturing was the worst performing cluster in April, clocking an overall contraction of 11.1 per cent on the year.
Economists are closely scrutinising Chinese economic releases after April’s data widely missed forecasts.

site_title: Global shipping losses at a record low; South China Sea a hotspot: report
summary: Global commercial shipping saw a record-low number of losses in 2022, with 38 vessels lost, a 65% reduction from a decade ago. The South China Sea accounted for 26% of total losses, driven by high trade, congested ports, and extreme weather. The most common causes of losses were foundering or sinking, fire or explosion, and ship-to-ship collisions. Piracy levels declined to near three-decade lows, but incidents remained steady, with the South China Sea remaining a piracy hotspot.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (May 26, 2023).

This undated and unlocated handout picture released by Monjasa shows the Liberian-flagged oil tanker, Monjasa Reformer, owned by Monjasa, and technically managed by Montec Ship Management. - A Danish-owned Liberian-flagged oil tanker was boarded by pirates over the weekend in the Gulf of Guinea, the owner said on March 28, 2023, adding that contact with 16 crew members had been lost.
