site_title: Netherlands steps up China chip spat with probe into Nowi deal
summary: The Dutch government will investigate Nexperia's acquisition of Nowi, a local chipmaker, amid a chip spat with China. The move comes as the Netherlands steps up controls of the industry, following its agreement with the US to restrict exports of chip technology to China. The new legislation allows the government to stop foreign takeovers on national security grounds, and the investigation will also review other acquisitions retroactively. The decision aims to protect sensitive technologies that may be used for military purposes.

site_title: India meets FY2023 fiscal deficit target of 6.4%
summary: India's fiscal deficit for FY2023 reached 17.3 trillion rupees (S$283.3 billion), meeting its target of 6.4% of GDP. Higher tax revenue, despite increased spending, contributed to the achievement. Net tax receipts were 100.5% of the annual revised estimate, while total expenditure was 100% of the goal. The government's capital spending on infrastructure projects increased 24.2% from last year, aiding the economy. The country's budget deficit target for FY2024 is 5.9%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee works inside an engineering goods export unit in the manufacturing hub of Faridabad on the outskirts of New Delhi, India, January 13, 2023. REUTERS/Manoj Kumar/

site_title: India launches electronics repair pilot project to lure manufacturers
summary: India has launched a pilot project, the Electronics Repair Services Outsourcing (ERSO) programme, to establish itself as an electronics repair hub. The three-month-long programme has attracted companies like Lenovo, Flex, CTDI, R-Logic, and Aforeserve, with policy changes expected to include relaxing import-export rules and environmental laws. The government aims to lower approval times for imports and exports to a day, allowing recycling of 5% of imported goods domestically and permitting re-export of electronics goods to countries other than the original one.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Lenovo logo is seen in this illustration photo taken on Jan. 22, 2018. REUTERS/Thomas White/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: North Korea satellite plunges into the sea; more launches expected
summary: North Korea's satellite launch attempt on May 31 ended in failure when the booster and payload crashed into the sea due to engine and fuel system instability. The launch, intended to deploy a military observation satellite, prompted emergency alerts and brief evacuation warnings in parts of South Korea and Japan. South Korea is recovering parts of the launch vehicle, while officials from the US, Japan, and South Korea condemned the launch and vowed to stay vigilant. North Korea plans to investigate the failure and conduct a second launch as soon as possible.

images.alt_text: North Korea, led by Kim Jong Un, is working to launch a military reconnaissance satellite.

site_title: Home prices may slump in eurozone as rates rise, ECB warns
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) warns that home prices in the eurozone may slump due to high mortgage rates making purchases unaffordable for households and unattractive for investors. The ECB attributes this to a strong labor market, reducing the likelihood of people defaulting on mortgages due to unemployment. Rising interest rates, which have been increasing since July, are also affecting the property market, which has boomed over the past decade. This decline is expected to have a negative impact on traditional lenders and shadow banks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European flags are seen in front of the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: North Korea’s Kim Yo Jong promises more spy satellite launches: KCNA
summary: North Korea's Kim Yo Jong has promised to increase military surveillance after her country's failed satellite launch. The launch, which included a military reconnaissance satellite, crashed into the sea due to an accident. Kim stated her country is ready to defend its sovereign rights and interests. The failed launch was criticized by South Korea, Japan, and the US, with UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres calling any future launch using ballistic missile technology a breach of Security Council resolutions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Kim Yo Jong, sister of North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un attends wreath laying ceremony at Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum in Hanoi, Vietnam March 2, 2019. REUTERS/Jorge Silva/Pool/File Photo

site_title: Commodities could pull back more this year as supply outpaces demand growth
summary: Commodities are expected to decline this year due to factors such as the strengthening US dollar, stable supply, and weakening demand. Most precious metals have fallen in price except for gold, which has risen 7.2% this year. Gold's unique fundamentals and diverse demand sources contribute to its low correlation with financial assets. Energy prices are expected to be the weakest performer, with natural gas prices already at pre-Covid lows. Precious metals, particularly gold, are expected to remain supportive, with gold prices potentially breaking the all-time high later this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars are pictured at the plant of gold and silver refiner and bar manufacturer Argor-Heraeus in Mendrisio, Switzerland, July 13, 2022. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse//File Photo
Uma Devi

site_title: US: Stocks end lower ahead of key debt ceiling vote
summary: US stocks ended the day lower, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.4% at 34,908.27, amid anticipation of a key congressional vote to lift the US debt limit. The vote comes after a compromise package was approved by a House committee, increasing optimism that the US can avoid a debt default. China's manufacturing activity shrank for the second consecutive month, and fresh US job opening data raised concerns about interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Traders work the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during the opening bell in New York on May 23, 2023. Stock markets slid on May 23 after fresh talks between President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarty on raising the US debt ceiling ended without an agreement as a crucial deadline approaches. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Europe looks to build bridges beyond Russia
summary: The European Political Community (EPC) summit will take place in Moldova on June 1, bringing together 47 leaders from greater Europe and countries including Israel and Turkey. The event aims to address shared economic and political challenges, with the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine likely to be a key topic. The EPC's purpose and relevance remain uncertain, and its impact on Europe's integration project will be evaluated. President Volodymyr Zelensky may attend, and discussions will focus on the club's mandate and relevance.

images.alt_text: Wind turbines in the North Sea at the London Array offshore wind farm, in the Outer Thames Estuary, UK. One focus of the North Seas Energy Cooperation is facilitating the cost-effective deployment of offshore renewable energy.

French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz at a news conference as part of a Franco-German joint Cabinet meeting, during the celebration of the 60th anniversary of the signing of the Elysee Treaty, at the Elysee Palace in Paris, France, Jan 22, 2023.
The overriding issue to be discussed at the G7 summit in Hiroshima from May 19 to 21 is Ukraine and its ongoing ramifications.

site_title: Seatrium under investigation by CPIB for alleged corruption in Brazil
summary: Seatrium, a Singapore-based offshore and marine company, is under investigation by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) for alleged corruption in Brazil. The CPIB has commenced investigations against Seatrium and individuals from the company, following information received. This comes after Seatrium's wholly-owned subsidiary, Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz, was previously investigated for alleged irregularities linked to Operation Car Wash, a major anti-corruption probe in Brazil. The CPIB has assured that it will investigate without fear or favor and take action against any parties involved in corrupt activities.

images.alt_text: Integration of Vito RPF topside structure with the FPU hull using a pair of 30,000-tonne goliath cranes at Tuas Boulevard Yard.
Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: US bank deposits fall at record pace in Q1 as profits remained steady: FDIC
summary: US banks saw record 2.5% decline in total deposits in Q1, primarily due to uninsured funds, despite insured deposits rising 2.5% amid bank failures. Industry-wide profits remained relatively flat, offset by increased wholesale funding. The FDIC reported a $472 billion deposit outflow, with 43 problem banks totaling $58 billion in assets. Despite this, bank profits rose 16.9% to $79.8 billion, with strong trading revenue and non-interest income contributing to the growth.

site_title: Taiwan central bank sees export momentum picking up in H2
summary: Taiwan's central bank expects the island's economy to grow 2.04% this year, down from an earlier estimate of 2.12%, due to ongoing global inflationary pressure. Exports, which have been sluggish, may pick up in the second half of the year. The central bank emphasized its commitment to maintaining economic stability, citing factors such as tightening monetary policies and geopolitical conflicts. It has raised its policy rate by 12.5 basis points to 1.875% and will hold its next rate-setting meeting on June 15.

site_title: Calls grow from Federal Reserve officials to ‘skip’ a rate hike
summary: Federal Reserve officials are considering skipping a rate hike in June to gather more data on the US economy's health, potentially altering the Fed's decision on additional policy firming. Fed governor Philip Jefferson stated that skipping a rate hike would allow the Committee to see more data before making decisions about the extent of additional policy firming. This move comes as the US central bank has raised interest rates 10 times since last year to bring inflation back down to its long-run target of 2%.

images.alt_text: A shopper caries a Zara clothing retailer bag  past GAP and Coach in Regent Street in London, U.K., on Tuesday, April 17, 2018. Photographer: Luke MacGregor/Bloomberg
Inflation by the Fed’s preferred gauge accelerated to 4.4 per centfrom a year ago, with core prices – a key measure of the trajectory – gaining 4.7 per cent, up from the 4.6 per cent pace in March.

SVB’s collapse on March 10 after taking excessive interest-rate risk led to a snowball effect in the financial markets as concerned investors looked for signs of weakness in the broader banking sector in the US and Europe.

site_title: Elon Musk again world’s richest person as Arnault’s LVMH sinks
summary: Elon Musk has regained the title of the world's wealthiest person, surpassing Bernard Arnault, after Tesla's shares rallied 66% year-to-date and boosted Musk's fortune by over $55.3 billion. Arnault's LVMH shares have fallen 10% since April, wiping $11 billion from his net worth. Musk's fortune now stands at approximately $192.3 billion, while Arnault's is about $186.6 billion. The shift is largely due to Tesla's strong performance amidst slowing economic growth and fading faith in the luxury sector.

site_title: UK regulator makes 'final call' to switch off Libor
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has made a final call to switch off the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor), a widely used interest rate that was fined for rigging. Markets have a month to stop using Libor, with the last remaining dollar quotes ending on June 30. It will be replaced by the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR), considered a more accurate and secure pricing benchmark. The FCA urges firms to transition contracts to robust reference rates, warning that failure to do so may result in significant market disruptions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Financial Conduct Authority's (FCA) logo is seen at their head offices in London, Britain March 10, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Golden Energy and its IFA hit back at criticism of opinion and valuation methodologies
summary: Golden Energy & Resources' independent financial advisor, W Capital, has defended its valuation methodology for the exit offer, citing a more complete picture of the company's value. The methodology used the enterprise value to earnings before interest, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) multiples of comparable companies, resulting in a fair-value range of 3,773 to 4,277 rupiah per share. The company disputed Sias' allegations of over-emphasizing Ebitda, saying it used a blended approach to arrive at its estimated range of values. The IFA also clarified that the distribution and exit offer were not conflated.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Gear's key units, Gems and Stanmore, have plainly observable market prices
David Gerald president of Sias says that the IFA has conflated the two corporate actions to the detriment of minority shareholders.

site_title: Japan PM orders US$26 billion for childcare, tad more than expected
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida instructed his government to allocate around $26 billion in the annual budget for childcare, exceeding the previously estimated $29.1 billion. This move aims to double childcare spending over the next three years to help reverse Japan's dwindling birth rate, which dropped to a record low of 800,000 in 2022. The government plans to expand childcare measures to support higher education, prevent child abuse in poverty, and ensure medical care for handicapped children.

images.alt_text: “I’m not considering imposing new tax burdens, including sales tax hikes, to secure sources of funding childcare support,” Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida says.

site_title: Baidu creates US$140 million fund to back ChatGPT-like startups
summary: Baidu has established a $140 million fund to support Chinese startups developing generative AI, with a focus on projects built on its Ernie AI model. The fund will incubate projects in deployments of up to $10 million yuan each. Venture investors will review pitches from founders, who will then build demo products before receiving seed funding. This move joins a global investment wave in generative AI, following the success of ChatGPT. Baidu aims to integrate AI into its products, rather than just integrating AI, with billionaire founder Robin Li stating that the company will "rework and restructuring" all its products.

images.alt_text: Baidu CEO Robin Li says the company was waiting for government approval before launching its ChatGPT-like Ernie bot.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower ahead of debt ceiling deal vote
summary: The US stock market opened lower on May 31, 2023, ahead of a pivotal vote on a debt ceiling deal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 94.07 points, or 0.28%, to 32,948.71. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened lower, with declines of 14.78 points and 49.05 points, respectively. The declines were attributed to the looming debt ceiling vote and the ongoing impact of higher prices on corporate America.

site_title: More than 1 in 4 American homeowners ‘house poor’
summary: A study by the Chamber of Commerce found that over 1 in 4 American homeowners, or 27.4%, are "house poor", spending more than 30% of their income on housing costs. The top 10 cost-burdened cities are primarily located in California and Florida, with Miami, Los Angeles, and New York City having the highest rates. The study attributes the increase to rising mortgage interest rates, inflation, and stagnant wages, squeezing homeowners and renters alike.

images.alt_text: The housing market has taken the biggest hit from the Federal Reserve’s fastest monetary policy tightening campaign since the 1980s.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble as hardline Republicans threaten US debt deal
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Wednesday, with Hong Kong leading losses of over 2% amid concerns that hardline Republicans may block a US debt deal, potentially triggering a catastrophic default. The US Federal Reserve is expected to increase interest rates next month, further fueling recession worries. China's manufacturing activity contracted in May, exacerbating concerns about the country's economic recovery. Despite House Democratic leader Hakeem Jeffries' confidence in passing the bill, the uncertainty has sent investors shifting out of risk assets, affecting markets in Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, and others.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong markets rose after four days of hefty losses, while there were also gains in Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul and Taipei, though Tokyo, Sydney, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta dropped.

site_title: HP Enterprise shares fall as dull forecast fuels fears of slowing demand
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) shares plummeted over 10% on May 31 as the company's disappointing revenue forecast fueled fears of a slowdown in cloud spending. The company's shares have lost about 3% this year, missing the broader tech sector rebound. Analysts expect economic uncertainty to impact HPE's server and storage systems, with some cutting their price target. Despite concerns, some analysts see potential in the AI boom, citing HPE's leadership in the industry. The company's stock now trades at 7 times Wall Street's average earnings estimates, lower than the tech sector average.

images.alt_text: HP also narrowed its forecast for fiscal-year adjusted profit to US$3.30 to US$3.50 a share, topping analysts’ average estimate.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sets US$12 billion profit goal for wealth unit
summary: Morgan Stanley set a US$12 billion profit goal for its wealth management unit, nearly doubling its current pre-tax earnings. The goal, set by co-president Andy Saperstein, aims to come from asset growth, lending, and expanding markets. In contrast, Saperstein forecast a decline in sales and trading and investment banking operations, citing a slowdown in dealmaking. The bank began eliminating 3,000 jobs this month amid the slowdown.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank and Citi have admitted to involvement in anti-competitive activity, while HSBC, Morgan Stanley and RBC have not admitted any wrongdoing.
Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman says the bank’s board has identified three strong candidates to succeed him.

site_title: 48 semi-detached houses at Eleven@Holland up for mortgagee sale while developer winds up
summary: Forty-eight semi-detached houses at Eleven@Holland in Singapore's District 10 are being put up for sale after the developer Clydesbuilt (Holland Link) went into liquidation. The 99-year leasehold units were valued at S$177 million in 2019, with an average price of S$3.74 million per house. The properties, mortgaged to Hong Leong Finance, will be sold with existing tenancies, offering a gross rental yield of up to 4.8%. The sale follows a High Court judgment ordering Clydesbuilt to pay S$87 million in profits to Innovative Corp, a real estate company.

images.alt_text: Exterior of Eleven @ Holland.
Jessie Lim

site_title: Hong Fok to join MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index
summary: Hong Fok, a Singapore-based property developer, is set to join the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index after the market closes on May 31. The company, which has a market capitalization of S$879.3 million, will be added alongside mining company Golden Energy and Resources and Super Hi International. Hong Fok's shares have gained 6.3% year-to-date, driven by strong net profit growth of 466% to S$220 million in the full year ended Dec 31, 2022.

images.alt_text: Hong Fok said that it expects to continue to recognise revenue from the sales of the residential units in Concourse Skyline (in picture).

site_title: BOJ’s Ueda says era of low global interest rates may be over
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda says the era of low global interest rates may be over due to the impact of massive fiscal and monetary support during the pandemic, which has contributed to high inflation. Ueda notes that global inflationary pressure may not subside and interest rates may not return to pre-pandemic levels. He emphasizes the importance of stabilizing inflation expectations in guiding monetary policy and warns central banks to be more careful in communicating their tools.

images.alt_text: The weakness in domestic production is a potential drag for the Japanese economy, which has recently shown some signs of recovery.
Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the central bank will maintain its ultra-loose monetary.
The 10-year Japanese government bond yield has recently hovered around 0.4 per cent after the BOJ took a range of steps to counter market attacks against the cap.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment’s Quah Ley Hoon joins SPH Media’s board
summary: CapitaLand Investment's Quah Ley Hoon will join SPH Media's board on June 1, bringing her experience spanning both private and public sectors. She previously served as the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore's first woman CEO from 2019 to 2022, overseeing the country's response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Quah also worked at Mediacorp and various government ministries, including the Ministry of Trade and Industry and the Ministry of Finance. Her diverse background will likely contribute to SPH Media's strategic decision-making.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: House set to vote on debt-limit bill amid Republican resistance
summary: The US House of Representatives is set to vote on a debt-limit bill despite Republican resistance. Speaker Kevin McCarthy has secured a deal with President Joe Biden to suspend the debt ceiling and set federal spending limits, but hard-right lawmakers have vowed to derail the bill. The bill has been criticized for not securing deep spending cuts and rollbacks of Biden administration policies, with some lawmakers comparing it to a "foul-tasting sandwich." McCarthy's team predicts they will secure the votes needed for passage, but it's unclear if Democrats will be required to provide support in procedural votes.

images.alt_text: US Representative Thomas Massie wears a pin displaying the amount of the US national debt during a House Committee on Rules hearing about whether to raise the United States' debt ceiling and avoid a catastrophic default, at the US Capitol in Washington, May 30, 2023.

site_title: Chinese graduates lower their ambitions in moribund jobs market
summary: China's youth unemployment rate hit a record 20.4% in April, with 11.58 million university students set to graduate this summer. Highly educated graduates, such as math major Liang Huaxiao, are struggling to find jobs, trading down to manual labor roles. This trend is attributed to China's worst youth job market on record, with many graduates facing difficulties in securing employment, even in their fields of study. The situation is expected to worsen with the upcoming large-scale graduation of university students.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Graduates, including students who could not attend last year due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, attend a graduation ceremony at Central China Normal University in Wuhan, Hubei province, China June 13, 2021. REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo CHINA OUT.

site_title: Bank of Thailand raises key policy rate by 25 bps to 2%
summary: The Bank of Thailand raised its key policy rate by 25 basis points to 2% for a sixth consecutive meeting, aiming to curb inflation risks as the economy recovers from global uncertainties. The unanimous decision aligns with expectations from 17 of 22 economists polled. The central bank maintains its forecast of 2.5% headline inflation this year and 2.4% for 2024, with inflation dropping to a 16-month low of 2.67% in April. The decision is part of a gradual policy normalization to achieve long-term sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: The Asian currency weakened for its third straight week against the dollar, closing at 34.77 on Friday.

site_title: Where are the jobs? India's world-beating growth falls short
summary: India's world-beating 6.5% economic growth has fallen short in providing jobs, with unemployment rates soaring during the Covid-19 pandemic. Urban unemployment has declined to 6.8% but the share of urban workers with full-time jobs has decreased to 48.9%, leaving 73 million without full-time employment. The young population, with 53% under 30, faces a crisis of underemployment and disguised unemployment, with many turning to low-paid casual work or unreliable self-employment. Economists warn that the country's demographic dividend is a "ticking time-bomb" due to the lack of jobs, threatening to create a lost generation.

images.alt_text: Naseem Jaafar Ali Sheikh, 41, a member of an NGO called Apnalaya, that works for the betterment of urban poor, poses for a photograph at a slum area in Mumbai, India, April 20, 2023. REUTERS/Niharika Kulkarni

site_title: Tokyo shares plunge at close on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted on Wednesday, May 31, as investors took profits from recent gains, with the Nikkei index losing 1.41% and the Topix index falling 1.32%. The sell-off was driven by concerns over a potential US debt default and the yen's relative strength. Market players also took advantage of weaker-than-expected Japanese machinery orders data and slowing manufacturing activity in China. Several major Japanese companies, including Nintendo, Fast Retailing, and Toyota, also fell.

images.alt_text:
A man looks at an electric quotation board flashing the Nikkei key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 12, 2017.
Tokyo stocks fell April 12 morning as the yen shot to five-month highs against the dollar over fears about growing tensions on the Korean peninsula and in the Middle East. / AFP PHOTO / Kazuhiro NOGI

site_title: New Zealand’s house-price declines slow as rate hikes set to end
summary: New Zealand's annual house price decline slowed to 10.2% in May, down from 10.3% in April and 10.5% in March, according to CoreLogic New Zealand. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's projection that interest rates are unlikely to rise further is seen as a fillip to the property market, with ANZ Bank predicting prices could recover as early as the third quarter. The RBNZ's comments also provide relief for borrowers facing higher mortgage repayments, but affordability concerns remain, and the rebound's strength is uncertain.

images.alt_text: The nation’s housing market has declined about 16 per cent over the past year and a half.

The RBNZ has warned that a boost in government spending could add to red-hot inflation, which it has aggressively tried to temper by increasing the official cash rate by 500 basis points since October 2021.

site_title: Tesla plans to showcase updated Model 3 with Musk in Shanghai
summary: Tesla plans to unveil its updated Model 3 sedan during CEO Elon Musk's visit to the Shanghai factory, marking the company's first major product refresh in China since 2017. The updated Model 3 features a sleeker interior design and sportier look. Tesla is under pressure to refresh its product line in China, where local manufacturers have gained market share, and has responded with discounts. Musk's visit to China is his first in three years, and the company is seeking to revitalize its sales in the country.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of car manufacturer Tesla is seen at a branch office in Bern, Switzerland October 28, 2020. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Exploring the possibilities of the King of Fruits
summary: Singaporean bakery Ms Durian, founded by Ling Goh and co-owned by Jeslyn Tan, has expanded its offerings beyond traditional durian pastries to include innovative creations such as durian macarons and craquelins. After facing challenges, including a shop closure and lease renewal issues, the business has grown by 30% since relocating to a new 10,000 sq ft space at Jalan Besar. The bakery now also hosts events and workshops, aiming to support the local SME community and promote durian awareness.

images.alt_text: Audrey Chew founded You Tiao Man in 2017, which has been suppling its manufactured products to food service businesses since.
Getting a second Michelin star helped to boost business at Cloudstreet.
What sets this cafe apart is that it not only employs people with disabilities, and those from disadvantaged backgrounds, it also adopts a sustainable approach in the entire supply chain.

site_title: IFC establishes presence in Malaysia, aims to help private firms improve competitiveness
summary: The International Finance Corporation (IFC) has established a presence in Malaysia to support the country's efforts to become more prosperous, inclusive, and sustainable. The IFC aims to help private firms improve competitiveness by offering equity and debt investment, as well as partnering with financial institutions to issue debt securities and launch risk-sharing facilities. Regional Director Kim-See Lim emphasized the need for Malaysia to improve the quality, inclusiveness, and sustainability of economic growth to remain competitive, particularly in addressing inequality and promoting green finance.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara Malaysia Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said: "The economy is no longer in crisis and in fact, continues to gain strenth."

site_title: Ikea stores owner Ingka buys warehouse software firm Made4Net
summary: Ingka Group's investment arm Ingka Investments acquired warehouse software firm Made4Net to improve Ikea's warehouse and logistics operations. This comes as Ikea plans to open eight new stores and nine smaller stores in the US, aiming to grow its online sales and offer next-day or same-day delivery. Made4Net's software analyzes warehouses, worker productivity, and delivery routes to find efficiency gains and cut costs. The deal will allow Made4Net to continue serving existing customers, including H&M, DHL, and Uber.

site_title: ‘The pictures are miracles’: How Judith Joy Ross finds pain and nobility in portraits
summary: Photographer Judith Joy Ross, 76, has created a series of empathetic black-and-white portraits that capture the pain and nobility of everyday people. Ross, who has photographed working-class and lower-middle-class individuals, believes that her subjects fill the space with their own individuality. Her use of a large-format Deardorff camera adds a sense of occasion to the act of being photographed. Ross's work, which includes portraits of Vietnam veterans and teenagers, has been hailed as "miracles" by curator Joshua Chuang. Her approach, which involves surrendering to the moment and downplaying her own skill, has resulted in a unique and powerful body of work.

images.alt_text: Growth in the market came from sales of high end art and from digital art backed by non-fungible tokens (NFTs).

site_title: Singapore sees record clampdown on oil ships as dark fleet grows
summary: Singapore has detained 33 oil and chemicals tankers for failing safety inspections this year, the same number as for the decade through 2019. The city-state's Maritime & Port Authority resumed physical vessel inspections in 2022 and has increased inspection frequency to ensure compliance with regulations. The surge in detentions is part of a regional trend of rising detentions since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which has led to the expansion of an "aging fleet" of tankers sailing under the radar to transport sanctioned oil.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SIA's CEO Goh Choon Phong announced he's grooming next-generation leaders but the decision on his successor lies with the board. SIA is investing to offer free unlimited inflight Wi-Fi to all KrisFlyer members. Condo rental prices rebounded in April, while the HDB market strengthened for the second straight month. Aims Apac Reit plans to launch an equity funding exercise to raise approximately S$100 million. CapitaLand's Quah Ley Hoon joins SPH Media's board, while developers consider deferring new launches or offering discounts due to the ABSD hike.

site_title: Chinese visa applications just 35% of pre-pandemic levels, data show
summary: China's visa applications from Chinese citizens have reached 35% of pre-pandemic levels as of May, according to VFS Global. Despite China's government lifting travel restrictions in January, international flights remain limited, and travel demand has remained gradual. Top destinations for Chinese tourists include Canada, Germany, Italy, Britain, and the US. Analysts attribute the slow recovery to concerns over new outbreaks and limited flights. The number of international flights is expected to be a key indicator of China's travel recovery.

images.alt_text: China's official manufacturing purchasing managers’ index fell to 48.8 from 49.2 in April, according to data from the National Bureau of Statistics, its lowest in five months and below the 50-point mark that separates expansion from contraction.

Concern about the impact of a weak business environment on startups’ prospects and valuations means a turnaround in fundraising may take time as venture funds take longer to evaluate potential deals, investors and advisers say.

site_title: Former VP Pence to announce White House bid next week: media
summary: Former US Vice President Mike Pence plans to announce his 2024 presidential campaign on June 7 in Iowa, challenging Donald Trump for the Republican nomination. Pence, 63, has distanced himself from Trump after a mob of Trump supporters threatened his life during the January 6, 2021, US Capitol assault. Pence's candidacy is seen as a challenge to Trump, who is the frontrunner in the crowded Republican field, which also includes Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and South Carolina Senator Tim Scott.

images.alt_text: Chilean president Gabriel Boric arriving at the South American Presidents' Summit at the Itamaraty Palace in Brasilia, Brazil, May 30, 2023.
US senator Tim Scott hugs his mother Frances as he announces his candidacy for the 2024 Republican presidential race in North Charleston, South Carolina, US, May 22, 2023.

Technologists warn of bad actors exploiting AI to sow chaos at a moment when the political climate is already hyperpolarised in the United States and many voters dispute verified facts including that Trump lost the 2020 election.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis remains in a pitched battle with Walt Disney over the company’s criticism of laws prohibiting the teaching of gender identity concepts in public schools.

site_title: Hong Kong Telco HKBN’s sale stalls again on valuation, sources say
summary: The sale of Hong Kong Telco HKBN has stalled again due to disagreements over valuation among potential buyers and the company's owners. Private equity firm I Squared Capital had expressed interest in acquiring the company for over $1 billion, but discussions have been put on hold as the parties couldn't bridge the differences. This marks the second time sale talks have broken down on similar grounds, with market volatility and valuation concerns cited by potential buyers. No final decision has been made, and HKBN could attract other suitors in the future.

images.alt_text: HKBN offers broadband Internet services to residential and corporate customers in the city. It also provides other enterprise telecom solutions, runs data centres and offers Wi-Fi connectivity.

site_title: Credit Suisse bankers sue over AT1 bonuses wiped out in UBS deal
summary: About 50 Credit Suisse bankers are suing Switzerland's financial regulator for rendering their bond-based bonuses worthless as part of the bank's state-brokered takeover by UBS Group. The bankers claim the regulator unfairly prioritized shareholders over bondholders, wiping out $17 billion in bond values. The employees are seeking compensation for their contingent capital awards, which were tied to Additional Tier-1 bonds. Credit Suisse last week withdrew its appeal over the writedown, citing the terms of the merger agreement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Credit Suisse bank is seen outside its office building in Hong Kong, China March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
Credit Suisse has also been handing out retention bonuses to staff whom UBS sees as critical for the future of the combined bank.
The order affects the top three levels of Credit Suisse management and follows the multi-billion franc state rescue of Switzerland’s second-biggest bank.

site_title: US dollar hits highest since mid-March as European inflation cools
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-month high, reaching 104.63 on the US dollar index, as European inflation cooled quicker than expected and China's economic recovery slowed. The euro fell to its lowest since March 20, while the Chinese yuan hit a low of 7.133 per US dollar. Analysts attributed the US dollar's surge to reduced pressure on the European Central Bank to raise interest rates and the probable resolution of the US debt ceiling standoff.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are displayed in this illustration taken, February 14, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Australia’s house prices rise sharply in May, driven by Sydney
summary: Australia's house prices rose sharply in May, driven by Sydney, with prices in the city increasing 1.8% and major cities rising 1.4% collectively. This follows a third consecutive month of price growth, fueling concerns about inflationary pressures. The Reserve Bank is worried that a renewed rise in property prices will drive a wealth effect, encouraging more household spending and further fueling consumer prices. Money markets now expect a quarter-percentage-point interest rate hike to 4.1% in August to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Houses stand in the suburb of Eastwood in Sydney, Australia, on Saturday, Jan. 11, 2014. Purchases by locally resident Chinese and those from mainland China are inflating housing bubbles in and around Sydney, where prices in some suburbs have surged as much as 27 percent in the past year. Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg

site_title: Lee Foundation-linked company selling two Barker Road bungalows for S$32.2 million
summary: Pulau Properties, linked to the Lee Foundation, is selling two freehold bungalows in Barker Road, Singapore, for S$32.2 million. The 14,123 sq ft land area works out to S$2,280 psf. The bungalows, built about 25 years ago, are being bought by Barker Developments, a Singaporean family member of Indonesian palm oil tycoon Bachtiar Karim. The sale does not require a housing developer's license, as the redevelopment project will have four or fewer residential units.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter (March 21, 2023)

site_title: Bezos, Musk among most used images to  scam: UK bank
summary: Celebrity images of Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk are among the most used to scam customers at NatWest bank in the UK. The bank's annual Celebrity Scam Super League lists Bezos in fourth and Musk in sixth. Scammers use these images in fake investment adverts, with one customer losing £275,000 after seeing a Twitter ad featuring David Attenborough. NatWest urges the public to be cautious of these ads and calls for a cross-industry effort with social media companies to eradicate the problem.

images.alt_text: This illustration photo taken in Los Angeles on April 20, 2023, shows Elon Musk's blue tick next to his name on a smartphone. - And so The Great Sorting has begun. Elon Musk's long promised move to strip un-paid-for Blue Ticks from Twitter users swung into action on April 20, 2023. Like some kind of Bibilical parable in which sheep and goats are separated, hundreds of high profile accounts were put on Elon's left side, while a handful of others were gathered on his right. (Photo by Chris DELMAS / AFP)

Elon Musk said he was “willing to continue to expand its business in China”, according to a foreign ministry readout in which he also reportedly stressed Tesla’s opposition to economic “decoupling” with the United States.
Elon Musk has gained more than US$55.3 billion this year, largely due to Tesla.

site_title: OK Lim ‘is a kind person... although he appears stern’: witness
summary: OK Lim, the former CEO of Hin Leong, a Singapore-based oil trading firm, faces cheating and forgery charges. A former employee described Lim as a "kind person... although he appears stern" and stated he was a good boss. The company collapsed in 2020 due to pandemic-led oil crash and hefty debts. Lim was once an icon in the oil sector but faced fraud allegations, sending shockwaves across the industry.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Lim Oon Kuin, better known as OK Lim, of the failed Hin Leong group faces cheating and forgery charges
Serene Seng, a former long-serving employee of Hin Leong, is Singapore prosecutors' third witness in the trial on cheating and forgery charges against OK Lim at the State Court

site_title: South Korea chip stockpiles swell to record high as demand sputters
summary: South Korea's semiconductor inventory has surged to a record high, increasing by 83% in April from the previous year, according to Statistics Korea. This is the largest increase in seven years, despite a global boom in artificial intelligence development. Factory shipments fell 33% and production was cut 20%, with smartphone and personal computer manufacturers struggling to clear inventory due to weak demand. Executives expect inventories to remain high through the second quarter, with a potential normalization later this year. The technology accounts for 13% of South Korea's total exports.

images.alt_text: The weak economic activity in April follows the country’s slim growth in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: US job openings surge to 10.1 million, exceeding all estimates
summary: US job openings surged to 10.1 million in April, exceeding all estimates. The increase was led by retail trade, health care, and transportation and warehousing, while openings fell in accommodation and food services, business services, and manufacturing. This suggests strong demand for workers despite challenging economic conditions.

images.alt_text: The conference board says its consumer confidence index slips to 102.3 this month from an upwardly revised 103.7 in April.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers approve US$8.9 billion sovereign wealth fund
summary: Philippine lawmakers approved a US$8.9 billion sovereign wealth fund, the "Maharlika Investment Fund", to boost growth and cut poverty. The fund will be primarily funded by the national government, with private financial institutions and corporations allowed to invest. The final version of the bill excludes pension funds from contributing, alleviating concerns about retirement savings. President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. had called for swift passage to finance infrastructure projects. Critics labeled the move a "scam" but Senate President Miguel Zubiri assured the public that safeguards were in place.

images.alt_text: This photo shows a general view of the plenary session at the Senate in Manila on May 31, 2023. Philippine lawmakers approved the creation of an 8.9 billion USD sovereign wealth fund on May 31 to boost growth and cut poverty, but critics insisted it was a "scam" and should be scrapped. (Photo by JAM STA ROSA / AFP)

site_title: Xiaomi adds Indian assembler to revive local smartphone push
summary: Xiaomi is partnering with Indian assembler Dixon Technologies India to revive its local smartphone manufacturing in the country. The move comes after Xiaomi lost its dominant position in India's smartphone market due to regulatory scrutiny and competition. The partnership will see Dixon assemble and export Xiaomi smartphones, as well as explore component manufacturing. This collaboration is seen as a step by Xiaomi to win favor with the Indian government and increase sourcing from the country. Dixon's shares rose 5.1% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past Xiaomi, a Chinese manufacturer of consumer electronics, store in Mumbai, India, May 11, 2022. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares slump amid heavy trading; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) slumped 0.9% to close at 3,158.80, following heavy trading of 2.7 billion securities worth S$2.8 billion. The decline was attributed to disappointing factory activity in China, which negatively impacted sentiment across the region. The Nikkei 225, Hang Seng Index, and Kospi also fell, with DBS being the top decliner, losing 3.3%.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The average fund is 15 percentage points underweight Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon.com, Nvidia, Tesla and Meta Platforms, according to Goldman.
China’s blue-chip CSI300 Index slumped 1.4 per cent at the close, while the Shanghai Composite Index plunged 1.5 per cent.

site_title: India’s economy grows 6.1% in March quarter, topping forecasts
summary: India's economy grew 6.1% in the March quarter, surpassing forecasts of 5% and exceeding the revised 4.5% growth in the previous quarter. The full-year growth estimate was revised to 7.2%, above an earlier estimate of 7%. Private consumption grew 2.8% year-on-year, while capital formation rose 8.9% and government spending increased 2.3%. The economy remains one of the fastest-growing emerging economies, but economists warn of risks from global slowdowns and volatility in financial markets.

images.alt_text: The federal government meets the targeted fiscal deficit of 6.4 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP), helped by higher tax revenue even as spending increases.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks hit by China economy, US debt fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.94% on May 31 due to concerns over China's economy and US Republican threats to default on the debt ceiling. The Hang Seng Index dropped 361.51 points to 18,234.27, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.61%. The decline was attributed to worries about China's economic slowdown and the potential for US debt default.

site_title: Saudi population up by a third since 2010: census
summary: Saudi Arabia's population has grown by 34.2% since 2010, reaching 32.2 million residents, according to the 2022 census. The majority of the population, 58.4%, are Saudi nationals, with 63% under the age of 30. Non-Saudi nationals, mainly from South Asia and the Middle East, account for 13.4 million, with Bangladeshis being the largest group. The census, initially scheduled for 2020, marks the most comprehensive and precise population survey in the kingdom's history.

site_title: Nvidia’s CEO plans trip to meet China executives despite US curbs
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang plans to visit China in June to meet with tech executives, despite US sanctions preventing the sale of advanced AI chipsets to Chinese customers. Huang's trip comes as the company forecasts booming demand for AI chips, pushing its market valuation to $1 trillion. He will meet with companies like Tencent Holdings, ByteDance, and EV makers Li Auto and BYD Auto. Despite concerns about the impact of US sanctions, executives from Chinese customers downplay the risks, citing the potential to make up for lost performance by employing more chips.

images.alt_text: No other company embodies Wall Street’s current obsession with artificial intelligence (AI) more than Nvidia.

site_title: Disappointing returns cool China’s infrastructure Reit craze
summary: China's infrastructure-focused Reits have seen disappointing returns, with the total market capitalization slumping to 90.6 billion yuan (S$17.3 billion) on Apr 27. The CSI Reits Index, which measures the performance of such Reits, plummeted to a historical low of 932.6, losing 13% since its year-high in Feb. The underwhelming performance is a stark contrast to the initial hype, with only 10 of the 27 Reits generating positive returns since listing. Industry insiders see the waning hype as a positive sign, as it indicates a more rational pricing and valuation of the products.

images.alt_text: Passengers at the Hangzhou East train station in China. Around 270 domestic trips were made during the five-day Labor Day holiday that ran from Apr 29 to May 3 this year.
US lawmaker warnings about China e-commerce fashion retailers such as Shein could signal upcoming regulatory action.
Automaker BYD showcases its intelligent body control system at its booth at the Shanghai auto show on April 24
Good gold returns require impeccable market timing — otherwise, long-term pain ensues.

site_title: South Korea April factory output falls, retail sales drop most in 5 months
summary: South Korea's factory production declined 1.2% in April from the previous month, following a 5.3% gain in March, the country's fastest growth since June 2020. Retail sales also dropped, marking the largest decline in 5 months. This weak economic activity follows the country's slim growth in the first quarter, narrowly avoiding a recession. The data suggests another tough quarter for the South Korean economy.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s Samsung and SK Hynix, the world’s top two makers of memory chips, have invested billions of dollars in chip factories in China.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks declined at the opening on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.5% to 3,170.68. The broader market saw losers outnumber gainers 79 to 44, with 42.1 million securities worth S$64.6 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Golden Energy and Resources' BIB mine in South Kalimantan.

site_title: Whisky lifts spirits of inflation-hit investors
summary: Inflation-hit investors are turning to whisky as a lucrative asset class, with the global market expected to reach $100 billion by the end of the decade. Whisky sales have surged in popularity, with prices increasing by 20% annually on average. Investors can purchase casks of whisky, which can double in value within five years and treble over a decade. However, experts caution that the market can be murky, and investors risk being duped if they don't do their homework. Despite this, companies like Annandale Distillery are seeing a boom in demand, with customer enquiries jumping over the past year.

images.alt_text: Tenmile Distillery aspires to produce a whiskey that in its aroma, palate and texture closely approximates single malt scotch.

site_title: Top Global is case study why firms should be made to sell their investment properties before going private
summary: Top Global, a Singaporean property group, is selling two strata units at 15 Scotts Road, a prime location, for S$38.8 million, or around S$6,000 per square foot. The sale comes after the group's delisting from the Singapore Exchange in 2021. The move is seen as a way to unlock value for shareholders, as the group was previously undervalued. Experts argue that property groups should be privatized in a fairer way, by selling investment properties first and returning the proceeds to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

ljoffice24 - 15 Scotts Road is a District 9 freehold nine-storey commercial building located near the Tanglin Club and various hotels.

Credit: Cushman & Wakefield
15 Scotts Road is a District 9 freehold nine-storey commercial building located near the Tanglin Club and various hotels
Listed companies appear to be trying to make use of the compulsory acquisition loophole before it is closed?

site_title: Indonesian copper miner Amman plans 12.94 trillion rupiah IPO by July
summary: Indonesian copper miner Amman Mineral Internasional plans to raise up to 12.94 trillion rupiah (S$1.17 billion) in an initial public offering (IPO) from June 28 to July 3. The IPO will be used to pay off debt and fund projects, including a copper smelter in Sumbawa island. The smelter, valued at US$983 million, will produce 220,000 tonnes of copper cathode annually. The IPO is part of Indonesia's growing IPO market, which has raised US$1.58 billion as of April, second only to China in the Asia-Pacific region excluding Japan.

images.alt_text: Exports of copper, iron ore, lead, zinc and anode mud from copper concentrates will be allowed until smelters, many of which were delayed by the pandemic, are ready to handle the materials, says Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Arifin Tasrif.
Freeport is building a US$3 billion copper smelter in East Java to process 1.7 million tonnes of copper concentrate.

site_title: German inflation slows significantly as ECB rate hikes near end
summary: German inflation slowed significantly to 6.3% in May, down from 7.6% in April, as fuel and heating-oil costs tumbled and a cheap public-transport ticket was introduced. The data suggests interest-rate increases by the European Central Bank may be nearing an end, contradicting some officials' warnings that hikes may continue. The ECB is set to decide on a quarter-point rate hike in two weeks, with some officials predicting borrowing costs may peak after the July meeting.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product (GDP) falls by 0.3 per cent in the first quarter of the year when adjusted for price and calendar effects.

site_title: MAS taps Google Cloud for generative AI tools in regulatory work
summary: MAS has partnered with Google Cloud to utilize generative AI tools for regulatory efforts. The partnership, announced at the Google Cloud Singapore Summit, aims to leverage Google's foundation models for tasks such as risk identification and trend monitoring. The collaboration prioritizes information security and data governance, with the goal of inspiring greater adoption of responsible generative AI in the financial sector. Google Cloud also launched a platform for Singapore's public sector to build and use generative AI applications, with a focus on upskilling government agencies in data science and AI expertise.

images.alt_text: Google has previously tested new search features by introducing them to randomised groups of users.
The partnership between SAP and the cloud unit of the Internet giant will help customers in a range of industries, says Google Cloud chief executive officer Thomas Kurian.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong interacting with an exhibit at the Google for Singapore event
Singapore targets to be a leader in developing and deploying AI solutions in key sectors from health care to finance and education by 2030.

site_title: Foxconn sees AI driving strong server demand, but full year to be flat
summary: Foxconn expects strong server demand driven by artificial intelligence (AI) applications this year, but overall revenue will remain flat due to global economic uncertainty. The company's chairman, Liu Young-way, cited rising interest in AI as a bright spot, predicting a three-digit increase in AI server sales in the second half of the year. Despite this, Foxconn remains cautious about the year ahead due to monetary policy tightening, geopolitical tensions, and inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman carrying an umbrella walks past the logo of Foxconn outside a company's building in Taipei, Taiwan October 31, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Garcia Rawlins/File Photo

site_title: Australia’s central bank warns of inflation risks, pain ahead for households
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, warns of inflation risks and potential pain for households. Governor Philip Lowe says inflation expectations are well anchored, but risks are on the upside, leading to higher interest rates and unemployment. The RBA aims to return headline inflation to its 2-3% target by mid-2025, with services price inflation potentially remaining elevated due to high unit labor costs. Lowe cautions that success is not guaranteed and it will be "painful" for households.

images.alt_text: PricewaterhouseCoopers Australia staff and clients were referenced in a cache of partially redacted emails released amid a scandal over a former partner at PwC who shared confidential information with colleagues on government plans to crack down on tax avoidance by multinational corporations.

site_title: Developers weigh deferring new launches, offering discounts after ABSD hike: NUS poll
summary: About 70% of developers surveyed expect residential property in the Core Central Region to be affected by the new Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) hike. Possible strategies to adjust to the increase include deferring new launches, offering discounts of 3-5%, and building smaller apartments. Luxury non-landed homes are expected to be significantly affected, with residential property in CCR bearing the brunt of the new measures. Developers are also considering redesigning luxury properties into mass-market homes to improve affordability.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
An artist's impression of Klimt Cairnhill, one of eight condominiums observed to have offered discounts in recent months.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH raises PropNex target price to S$1.16
summary: UOB Kay Hian has raised its target price on PropNex to S$1.16 from S$1.07, citing the company's strong position in the residential property segment and its planned entry into the commercial market. Analyst Adrian Loh believes PropNex can maintain and grow its market share, driven by new growth plans and a consultancy arm offering leasing and valuation services. The brokerage maintains its "buy" call on the counter.

site_title: Preserving heritage: Ethiopian quest to recreate ancient manuscripts
summary: In Ethiopia, the Hamere Berhan Institute in Addis Ababa is preserving ancient heritage by replicating centuries-old religious manuscripts and sacred artwork. Priests and lay worshippers work by hand to recreate the parchments, using traditional techniques and materials. The process, which can take months to years, aims to preserve a fading cultural tradition. The institute, which began the project four years ago, receives commissions from individuals and churches to create reproductions of ancient Ethiopian works, including paintings and prayers. The painstaking task is seen as a way to connect with God and bring closer to a spiritual dimension.

images.alt_text: Ethiopian Jews' long wait for life in Israel

site_title: Debate on CPF Ordinary Account interest rate resurfaces as those for Special, MediSave accounts rise
summary: The Singapore government has announced a 0.01 percentage point increase in interest rates for the Special Account (SA) and MediSave Account (MA), bringing them to 4.01% per annum, effective in the third quarter of this year. The Ordinary Account (OA) interest rate remains at 2.5% per annum. Economists argue that the increase is small but significant in symbolism, as it marks the first time the SA and MA rates have exceeded 4% since 2008. The interest rates for these accounts are pegged to the average yield of 10-year Singapore Government Securities (10YSGS) over a 12-month period.

images.alt_text: CPF ST PHOTO: KUA CHEE SIONG

site_title: Credit Suisse aborts China bank plan to avoid regulatory conflict under UBS: sources
summary: Credit Suisse has scrapped plans to establish a locally incorporated bank in China due to a potential regulatory conflict with its merger with UBS. The Swiss bank had invested years in preparing for the venture, aiming to boost its presence in China. However, UBS already has a locally incorporated bank in China, raising concerns about overlapping regulatory requirements. By abandoning the plan, Credit Suisse avoids a potential conflict and maintains its existing operations in the country.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Credit Suisse bank is seen outside its office building in Hong Kong, China March 20, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

The investor claims UBS was unfairly able to snap up the shares for a bargain 0.76 Swiss francs apiece – far below the closing price of 1.86 Swiss francs on Mar 17, the last trading day before the deal was agreed.

Deutsche Bank didn’t beef up its investment banking units as much as many Wall Street peers did during the boom two years ago, partly because it was simply unable to keep up with the enormous pay packages offered at the time, sources said.
Bondholders have argued the writedown was an unfair and disproportionate move that put shareholders before bondholders.

site_title: Oil settles lower on weak China data, stronger US dollar
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Wednesday, pressured by a stronger US dollar and weak data from top oil importer China. Brent crude futures for August delivery fell US$1.11 to US$72.60 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) fell US$1.37 to US$68.09. Weak Chinese manufacturing data and a stronger dollar contributed to the decline, while a bipartisan US debt ceiling bill and cooling European inflation provided support.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled US$3.53, or 4.6 per cent, lower at US$73.54 a barrel on Tuesday

site_title: Condo rental prices, volumes rebound in April; HDB market continues to climb: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's condo rental prices and volumes rebounded in April, with condo rents rising 1% and leasing volumes increasing 13.8% month-on-month to 5,598 units. HDB rental prices also rose 0.8% in April, with overall rents up 26.1% year-on-year. Experts predict condo rents may rise 10-15% in 2023, while HDB rents are expected to increase by 10%. However, further supply additions could moderate the market.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
ULI notes that the median price of Singapore’s private-sector homes now stands at US$1.20 million, compared with Hong Kong at US$1.16 million.
“The rise (in HDB rentals), as opposed to condo rentals, could be reflective of tenants switching to lower rental alternatives in the HDB market,” says 99.co's Luqman Hakim.

site_title: And the winners are... Succession fans who correctly chose the new CEO
summary: A group of friends wagered on who would succeed Logan Roy as CEO of Waystar Royco after watching the series finale of Succession. Tom Wambsgans was the predicted winner, with one fan spending $1,000 on new clothes to celebrate his victory. The show's creators had subtly hinted at Tom's rise to power throughout the series, but many viewers were still surprised by the outcome. The friendly betting pools, which are legal in most states, added a new layer of engagement to the viewing experience.

images.alt_text: The financial world's favourite TV drama Succession is now in its 4th and final season.

site_title: China’s factory activity falls faster than expected as recovery stumbles
summary: China's factory activity contracted faster than expected in May, with the manufacturing PMI falling to 48.8, its lowest in five months and below the 50-point mark. The service sector activity also expanded at the slowest pace in four months. The contraction pushed Asian markets lower and raised concerns about China's economic recovery, with economists warning of a potential K-shaped recovery. Policymakers are under pressure to implement policies to boost demand and sustain growth.

images.alt_text: Companies that have visibly de-emphasised their Chinese identity include online fast-fashion retailer Shein which has made a Singapore firm its de facto holding company.
Tesla sold 267,171 Model Ys in the first quarter of this year, of which 94,469 were sold in China, higher than 83,664 in the United States and 71,114 in Europe.
Shanghai's main shopping belt, March 2023

site_title: Jazzing up the traditional you tiao
summary: You Tiao Man, a Singapore-based food manufacturer, has modernized the traditional you tiao fritter, making it suitable for fine-dining restaurants and supermarkets. Founded by Audrey Chew in 2017, the company started as a supplier to F&B outlets but expanded to new channels and markets, including overseas. With improved recipes and certifications, You Tiao Man has introduced variations such as wholegrain, otah, and charcoal, catering to changing consumer demands. The company has achieved halal certification and exports to Malaysia, with plans to expand to Australia, Indonesia, and the UK.

images.alt_text: Ling Goh (right) founded Ms Durian in 2019 and works closely with Jeslyn Tan (left), co-owner.
Stephanie Chan (right), co-founder of IncuBaker Studio, and Farah Fami, partner at the studio.  Chan warts to help new F&B brands that are starting out to reduce their capital risk.
Batu Lesung Spice Company, founded by Jeremy Nguee, saw its sales spike during the circuit breaker as diners began cooking at home instead.

site_title: How the far left paves the way for the far right
summary: Chile's Constitutional Council election results show a shift in power from the far left to the far right, with a far-right party now in control and the left holding fewer than one-third of the seats. This trend is part of a global phenomenon, where right-wing populists with authoritarian leanings have won elections in the US, India, Hungary, and Turkey. Latin America, known for adopting global trends, has also seen a rise in right-wing populist movements, mirroring the shift in Chile. This shift may be attributed to a combination of factors, including global trends and the influence of right-wing populists.

images.alt_text: Traders in Chile, Brazil and Colombia now price in odds of rate cuts starting in the second half of 2023.
Democracy is the next identity politics

Supporters of Brazil's former President Jair Bolsonaro demonstrate against President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva while security forces operate, outside Brazil’s National Congress in Brasilia, Brazil, Jan 8, 2023.

site_title: AI boom triples valuation of Lightmatter, US startup using light for computing
summary: Lightmatter, a Boston-based startup, raised US$154 million and tripled its valuation, valuing the company at US$454 million. The company uses light for AI computing, reducing power costs and increasing efficiency. Lightmatter's technology, called Passage, will be mass-produced and used in data centers next year. The company's more futuristic product, Envise, will use light instead of electrons for computing and will be tested by customers this year. The funding round included investors GV (Google Ventures) and Fidelity Management & Research Company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman initially said his company could quit Europe over new AI rules but later backtracked.
Baidu will use the pool to incubate projects built atop its Ernie AI model, in deployments as high as 10 million yuan apiece.

site_title: ECB’s inflation fight exposes fragilities in financial system
summary: The European Central Bank's fight against high inflation has exposed fragilities in the financial system, with higher interest rates testing the resilience of households, companies, governments, and property markets. The ECB warns of disorderly adjustments, vulnerable markets, and potential dents in bank profitability. Despite this, officials say the rate hike campaign is not over, with price stability remaining crucial for financial stability. The review highlights potential risks in property markets and commercial real estate, but also notes the resilience of euro-area banks, which should not be taken for granted.

images.alt_text: Households are benefiting from a strong labour market, meaning fewer people are likely to stop paying back their mortgage due to unemployment, says the ECB.

site_title: Young South Koreans drive shift in attitudes to Japan as ties thaw
summary: Young South Koreans, particularly those born after Japan's colonization in 1950, are driving a shift in attitudes towards Japan, viewing it as a cultural and consumer market rather than a historical adversary. This is reflected in a sharp rebound in demand for Japanese products and culture, with 24-year-old office worker Jeong Se Ah citing nostalgia for Japanese animations and music as reasons for her interest. The change in attitude is seen as a positive development, marking a new era of cooperation and mutual appreciation between the two nations.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea starts raising interest rates in August 2021 to tame inflation.
South Korea’s Samsung and SK Hynix, the world’s top two makers of memory chips, have invested billions of dollars in chip factories in China.

site_title: JPMorgan says China growth takes longer, eyes Japan market
summary: JPMorgan Chase announced its China expansion is taking longer than expected, with the bank planning to invest more in Japan and Australia instead. CEO Filippo Gori stated that these countries offer opportunities for growth, while JPMorgan's China chief executive officer Mark Leung said the expansion will be a "longer journey" due to the country's sluggish economy and intense domestic competition. Despite this, JPMorgan remains committed to the Chinese market, citing growth from wealth management fees, and expects a flurry of activity in the second half of 2023.

images.alt_text: First Republic became the largest US bank to fail since 2008 after it was seized by regulators and sold to JPMorgan in early May.
Scientists estimate that the world may need to remove billions of tons of CO2 from the atmosphere annually by mid-century to limit global warming.

site_title: Gold faces monthly fall on debt deal hopes, US Fed policy outlook
summary: Gold prices are expected to fall for the first time in three months due to expectations of higher interest rates and diminished optimism over the US debt deal. Spot gold is down 1.6% for the month, with traders now pricing in a 66.6% chance of a 25-basis-point interest rate hike at the Fed's June meeting. Higher interest rates are seen as dulling the appeal for zero-yield bullion, while Richmond Federal Reserve president Tom Barkin suggests the US economy may support interest rates at a "neutral, normal level" once the current inflation shock passes.

images.alt_text: Gold, which offers no yield of its own, tends to fall out of favour among investors when interest rates rise.

site_title: China was top market for Tesla Model Y, world’s best-selling car in Q1
summary: Tesla sold 267,171 Model Ys in Q1, with 94,469 sold in China, the top market. The Model Y became the world's best-selling car, surpassing the Toyota Corolla. Elon Musk recently visited China, highlighting the importance of the electric market. Analysts expect the Model Y to remain top seller by year-end due to price cuts and increasing EV demand. Tesla's limited model lineup may pose a concern, with some analysts suggesting the need for more models and variants to expand its market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Visitors wearing face masks check a China-made Tesla Model Y sport utility vehicle (SUV) at the electric vehicle maker's showroom in Beijing, China January 5, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Billion Dollar Whale author says 1MDB suspect Jho Low under house arrest in China, not Macau
summary: Author Bradley Hope claims Jho Low, the alleged 1MDB scandal mastermind, is under house arrest in Shanghai, contradicting previous reports that he was in Macau. Low was first charged in absentia in 2018 with eight counts of money laundering. A recent associate, Kee Kok Thiam, died after being questioned by authorities about Low's whereabouts. Malaysian authorities have been trying to repatriate Low, who publicly declared his innocence in 2018.

images.alt_text: Kee Kok Thiam, an associate of fugitive financier Jho Low (pictured), died in a hospital of a “sudden massive stroke” on Monday, Valen, Oh & Partners said in a statement.

Fugitive financier Jho Low.
