DiCaprio met Low at a party and they bonded over several years and on trips.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit two-month low on weak China data, log monthly drop
summary: European stocks hit a two-month low, closing 1.1% lower on Wednesday, due to concerns over a global slowdown fueled by China's weak economic data. China's factory activity shrank faster than expected in May, leading to losses in luxury firms and automakers. The downturn is also linked to uncertainty over the US debt ceiling. Despite easing inflation in some euro zone economies, the Stoxx 600 index fell to its lowest level since March 30.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent lower at 34,908.27 on Wednesday.

site_title: GIC takes minority stake in German gas specialist Messer
summary: Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC has invested a minority stake in German industrial gases company Messer as part of a strategic partnership. The investment will help Messer take full control of its Messer Industries joint venture, financing the acquisition of shares from previous minority shareholder CVC Capital Partners. As a result, Messer will become the sole owner of Messer Industries, bringing all its activities under one roof. The investment proceeds will also support the company's future growth plans.

images.alt_text: Messer Source: Messer SE

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Golden Energy and Resources, Challenger Technologies
summary: Several companies saw new developments affecting trading on May 31. Olam Group's IPO of its agribusiness unit is now unlikely to be completed by H1 2023, and its shares ended down 5.5% on the news. Sias recommended that Golden Energy and Resources' minority shareholders reject the exit offer by its controlling shareholders. Challenger Technologies' majority shareholders made a voluntary cash offer to take the company private. Aims Apac Reit requested a trading halt to raise S$100 million through an equity fundraising exercise.

images.alt_text: Excavators at work in Golden Energy and Resources' BIB mine in South Kalimantan.
Derryn Wong

site_title: US monthly home prices increase in March, surveys show
summary: US single-family home prices increased 0.4% in March, boosted by a persistent shortage of properties on the market, according to the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller national home price index. The inventory of existing homes remains 44% below pre-pandemic levels, driving prices up. Despite a slowdown in house price inflation, challenges from current mortgage rates and economic weakness are expected to remain a headwind for housing prices.

images.alt_text: US Representative Thomas Massie wears a pin displaying the amount of the US national debt during a House Committee on Rules hearing about whether to raise the United States' debt ceiling and avoid a catastrophic default, at the US Capitol in Washington, May 30, 2023.
The conference board says its consumer confidence index slips to 102.3 this month from an upwardly revised 103.7 in April.

site_title: Inflation fears push UK bond market towards crisis levels again
summary: The UK bond market is facing a potential crisis due to high inflation, with 10-year bond yields reaching 4.3% and potentially increasing to over 5% unless inflation declines. This has led to concerns about a recession and higher mortgage rates, affecting households already struggling with food inflation of 19%. The Bank of England and Chancellor Jeremy Hunt are under pressure to address the issue, with some experts suggesting interest rates could reach 6% to control inflation.

images.alt_text: There are signs that inflation is becoming entrenched in the UK and that Brexit has exacerbated the cost-of-living crisis.
Britain has Western Europe’s highest rate of inflation for food, with prices up more than 19 per cent over the past year, the worst such run since the 1970s.

A surge in net migration to 606,000 last year is deepening disquiet in the ruling Conservative Party, which touted “taking back control of our borders” as a dividend of Britain exiting the European Union.
The two-year British swap rate, which underpins many lenders’ own financing costs and mortgage pricing for two-year deals, has shot up around 50 basis points so far this week.

site_title: US debt ceiling bill to cut US$1.5 trillion from deficit over decade
summary: US lawmakers are set to vote on a debt ceiling bill that would cut the US$1.5 trillion from the national deficit over the next decade. The bill, agreed upon by President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, would suspend the debt limit through 2025, cap spending, and speed up energy project permitting. The Congressional Budget Office projects that the bill would reduce interest on public debt by $188 billion and cut mandatory spending by $10 billion. If passed, the bill would prevent the US government from defaulting on its debt.

images.alt_text: Both Democratic President Joe Biden and the top Republican in Congress, House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, have predicted they will get enough votes to pass it into law before Monday.
This week brings a month-end rebalancing of the US Treasury bond index to incorporate large quarterly new issues of 10- and 30-year debt, which may drive demand for those sectors of the market.
Biden says he doesn’t foresee any sticking points that can derail the agreement.

site_title: Ex-aide to 1MDB fugitive Jho Low dies weeks after questioning
summary: Kee Kok Thiam, 56, associate of fugitive financier Jho Low, died from a "sudden massive stroke" in a hospital on Monday. Thiam was questioned by Malaysian authorities on Low's whereabouts after being repatriated from Macau in May, where he allegedly met with other 1MDB fugitives. Thiam's death comes weeks after his questioning and amid ongoing investigations into the 1MDB corruption scandal, in which Low is wanted in at least three countries.

images.alt_text: Fugitive financier Jho Low.

site_title: It may be time for SingPost to hand over some, or all, of its domestic postal obligations to the State
summary: SingPost, Singapore's national postal service provider, reported its first annual loss for the domestic postal business, with an operating loss of S$15.9 million for FY2023. The company expects the post and parcel business to be in the red for the current financial year. As a public postal licensee, SingPost faces conflicting obligations to provide a national utility while delivering shareholder returns. The government may consider taking over the domestic operation, paying SingPost a fee to manage the business, or nationalizing it, to ensure the continued provision of postal services.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Vincent Yik, Group CFO, Singapore Post
The Speedpost standard delivery fee within Singapore will also be revised from S$6 to S$6.10 from Jan 1, 2023, and to S$6.20 from Jan 1, 2024.
Singpost's mail volume weakened 2 per cent y-o-y in H1 FY2023.
The board has declared an interim dividend of S$0.0018 per share for the half-year, which will be paid to shareholders on Nov 30.
SingPost said higher operational costs due to more expensive fuel, labour and utilities hit its post and parcel segment,

site_title: AI leaders warn of ‘risk of extinction’ from the technology
summary: Industry leaders, including DeepMind, OpenAI, and Anthropic CEOs, warn of an "existential risk" from AI, calling for a global priority to mitigate its potential for extinction. Over 350 executives and researchers, including Sam Altman and Demis Hassabis, signed a statement released by the Center for AI Safety. This warning follows a March call for a six-month pause on training powerful AI models by over 1,100 industry leaders. Some skeptics argue that the risks are exaggerated, focusing instead on issues like algorithmic bias and disinformation.

Asus will preload the AFS hardware with its own large language model, called Formosa, which it says is equivalent to ChatGPT 3.5 and trained in traditional Chinese.

site_title: UK business confidence dips in May, inflation pressures persist: Lloyds
summary: UK business confidence dipped to 28% in May, its first decline in three months, despite the economy beating recession forecasts. Consumer price inflation fell to 8.7% in April, less than expected. The decline in business confidence reflects ongoing concerns about the economy, despite some signs of resilience.

images.alt_text: Last October, investors dumped UK government bonds to an extent that scores of pension funds were facing collapse, forcing the Bank of England to intervene.
There are signs that inflation is becoming entrenched in the UK and that Brexit has exacerbated the cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: Elon Musk says he wants to expand China business
summary: Elon Musk announced his willingness to expand Tesla's business in China during a meeting with Foreign Minister Qin Gang in Beijing. The country is the world's largest electric vehicle market, and Tesla has recently announced plans to build a second massive factory in Shanghai. Musk stressed Tesla's opposition to economic "decoupling" with the US, while China committed to creating a favorable business environment for foreign enterprises. The meeting comes after US President Joe Biden expressed scrutiny over Musk's links to foreign countries.

images.alt_text: Chinese State Councillor and Foreign Minister Qin Gang meeting Tesla chief executive officer Elon Musk in Beijing on Tuesday (May 30).
Elon Musk’s private jet was recently over the Yellow Sea, west of South Korea.
Since Twitter was acquired by billionaire Elon Musk for US$44 billion last October, the company has cut thousands of jobs and made numerous changes.
Neuralink is developing a brain implant it hopes will help paralysed people walk again and cure other neurological ailments.

site_title: Citi sees securitisation deals in ESG picking up across emerging markets
summary: Citigroup expects sustainable securitization deals to gain traction in emerging markets, following a deal in Kenya that raised $130 million for off-grid solar energy provider Sun King. The deal uses mobile payment systems to serve low-income households, improving their credit scores and providing affordable financing for renewable power. Citigroup's global head of social finance, Jorge Rubio Nava, sees the model as a viable asset class for private investors seeking commercial returns and social impact.

images.alt_text: Gillian Tan, MAS’ Chief Sustainability Officer and Assistant Managing Director (Development & International) at her first interview with the media on Tuesday (May 30, 2023) at the MAS Building.
nature, earth, sustainability

site_title: Japan’s factory output drops on hit from global slowdown
summary: Japan's factory output declined 0.4% in April, the first drop in three months, due to a global slowdown. This decrease is likely to weigh on the country's recovering economy, which has shown some signs of improvement. The decline was attributed to a slowdown in production machinery, metal work, and automakers' output. Economists had forecast a 1.4% rise in industrial production. The weakness in domestic production is a potential drag on the Japanese economy.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit to launch equity funding exercise to raise around S$100 million
summary: Aims Apac Real Estate Investment Trust (AA Reit) plans to launch an equity funding exercise to raise approximately S$100 million. The exercise includes a private placement of 56-57.7 million new units and a non-renounceable preferential offering of up to 25.4 million new units. The private placement units will be priced between S$1.214 and S$1.249, while the preferential offering units will be priced between S$1.189 and S$1.224. The manager intends to use the funds to fund asset enhancement initiatives, redevelop properties, and reduce debt.

images.alt_text: The real estate investment trust’s (Reit) gross revenue was S$84.2 million, up 9.1 per cent from S$77.1 million the previous year.

site_title: Economists see India’s first rate cut in 2024 for durable growth
summary: India's central bank is expected to hold interest rates this year, with a possible 25 basis point cut in the first quarter of 2024, according to a Bloomberg survey. Policymakers will meet June 6-8 to deliberate, focusing on growth while inflation moderates. Retail inflation is expected to trend lower, with a forecast of 5% for the current fiscal year, and consumer prices may ease to 4.7% in the second quarter. The central bank aims to balance growth with inflation concerns, with a potential rate cut to 6% in the following quarter.

images.alt_text: RBI injected about 468 billion rupees into the banking system on May 19 via a repo auction, the first such injection since March.
FILE PHOTO: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) seal is pictured on a gate outside the RBI headquarters in Mumbai, India, February 2, 2016. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: Chinese tech entrepreneurs keen to ‘de-China’ as tensions with US soar
summary: Chinese tech entrepreneurs are seeking to "de-China" as tensions with the US escalate, making it harder for them to operate in the US. Many are trying to gain permanent residency or citizenship in other countries, such as Hong Kong, Canada, or Singapore, to avoid US government curbs and biases. The US-China trade spats and restrictions on Chinese companies have led to disillusionment with China, with some entrepreneurs even shutting down businesses due to government censorship requests. Despite the challenges, many still aim to expand their businesses in the US, with some exploring options to rebase offshore and de-emphasize their Chinese identity.

images.alt_text: So far this year, China is in the lead with 19 LLMs to US’ 18.

site_title: Elon Musk in Beijing, meets Foreign Minister Qin Gang
summary: Elon Musk met with Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang in Beijing on May 30, marking his return to China after three years. Musk expressed willingness to expand Tesla's business in China and opposed decoupling the US and Chinese economies. The meeting came amid increasing competition from Chinese-made electric vehicles and uncertainty about Tesla's Shanghai plant expansion plans. Musk's trip is the latest return visit by a top US CEO to China since the country reopened its borders and reversed its zero-Covid policy.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk’s private jet was recently over the Yellow Sea, west of South Korea.
In a sign of tough times even for Tesla, the market leader in electric cars, Elon Musk said the company would try to advertise its vehicles, something it has not done before.
Tesla’s move to export to Canada from Shanghai could help it keep vehicles made at its plants in California and Texas for sale in the United States.

site_title: Goldman planning another round of job cuts amid chill in banking
summary: Goldman Sachs is planning another round of job cuts, affecting less than 250 employees, amid a muted dealmaking environment. The investment bank, which has already eliminated several hundred jobs this year, is working on its third round of cuts in under a year. The move comes as the firm seeks to reduce expenses, with a goal of $1 billion in cost savings. The job cuts will include more senior employees, and follow the bank's previous rounds of layoffs, which included 3,200 positions cut in January.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 15, 2010 a plaque for investment banking giant Goldman Sachs reflects attendants at a press conference in Hong Kong. - Goldman Sachs plans to cut 3,200 jobs and could announce this as early as this week, a source close to the issue said on January 8, 2023, confirming press reports. site_title: Tesla, BYD, Li Auto to lead in China’s EV race as country becomes carmakers’ battleground
summary: China has overtaken Japan as the world's top vehicle exporter in the first quarter of 2023, driven by rising demand for electric vehicles. Analysts suggest investors consider Tesla, BYD, and Li Auto shares due to their dominance in the Chinese EV market. BYD's market share has risen steadily, while Tesla cut prices last October, sparking competition among foreign brands. The Chinese market is becoming increasingly crucial for global auto manufacturers, potentially determining their success in the global arena.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Tesla’s move to export to Canada from Shanghai could help it keep vehicles made at its plants in California and Texas for sale in the United States.
Tesla’s Shanghai plant, its largest worldwide, produced about 726,000 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles in 2022, more than half of the automaker’s global sales.
Chery’s mid-size Omoda 5 is selling across Australia for as little as A$32,000 (S$28,789) for the base model.
Tesla has cut prices globally since January, including in the United States, seeking to drive volume, especially for its mass-market cars, the Model Y crossover and the Model 3 sedan.

BYD has unveiled its Seagull electric hatchback at the recent Shanghai car show, stunning visitors with a price from just 78,000 yuan – around half the level of the cheapest new energy vehicles available elsewhere.
BYD sold almost 550,000 cars globally in January-March, more than all of the passenger vehicle registrations in the UK in that period.
Visitors checking out the BYD Seagull car that was on display at the Shanghai Auto Show 2023.

site_title: For Turks, it wasn’t just the economy
summary: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan won re-election despite the country's poor economic performance over the past five years, with a majority of voters deeming the depreciation of the lira worth it. This challenges the conventional wisdom that elections are driven by economic factors, as Erdogan's authoritarian rule and restricting press freedoms were not major concerns for voters. In contrast, Greece, another ancient rival of Turkey, went to the polls and emerged as the largest party, but its economy is now roaring back after a decade of austerity. The contrast highlights that voters are not solely bound by economic considerations.

images.alt_text: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan addressing supporters gathered outside his residence following his victory in Turkish presidential election at Kisikli district in Istanbul, Turkey, May 28, 2023.
Greece’s debt ratio still remains the highest of any in the euro region, while the nation has a way to go to make up for the lost era of its debt crisis.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide on Tuesday amid US debt deal doubts
summary: Europe's main stock indices fell 0.9% on Tuesday, tracking a steepest monthly fall this year, due to uncertainty over the US debt ceiling deal. Despite hitting a one-year high earlier this month, the pan-European Stoxx 600 index declined. Sectors such as real estate and utilities were among the rare bright spots, while packaged food group Nestle and energy majors suffered losses. Investor sentiment was dented by concerns over the US debt deal, with sectors typically favored during economic uncertainty underperforming.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.2 per cent lower at 33,042.78 on Tuesday.

site_title: HP sales decline worse than expected as PC slump continues
summary: HP's Personal Systems segment saw a 29% decline in sales to $8.2 billion, worse than the 24% drop analysts predicted. The company's revenue fell 22% to $12.9 billion, attributed to a slump in consumer PC sales. Despite this, CEO Enrique Lores remains optimistic about the second half, citing reduced inventory and strong back-to-school and holiday seasons. The company affirmed its full-year cash flow forecast and narrowed its adjusted profit estimate.

images.alt_text: Hewlett Packard laptops sit on a table in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Wednesday, August 26, 2009. Kim White/Bloomberg News
HP’s higher mix of commercial PCs initially shielded it from the plunging consumer market, but the weakness has spread.

site_title: Oil slides 4% on worries about US debt ceiling, Opec+ talks
summary: Oil prices fell 4% on Tuesday due to concerns over the US debt ceiling pact, with Brent crude futures settling at $73.54 a barrel. The US Congress' ability to pass the debt ceiling deal has been called into question, with some hard-right Republican lawmakers expressing opposition. Despite this, Democratic President Joe Biden and Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy remain optimistic about the deal passing. The mixed messages from major producers have also clouded the supply outlook ahead of the Opec+ meeting this weekend.

images.alt_text: Crude prices have dropped about 12 per cent this year due to factors such as China’s lacklustre recovery from its Covid-Zero policy and concerns about aggressive monetary policy in the US.

site_title: Eurozone lending hit by higher rates; ECB flags risks from funds running into trouble
summary: The eurozone's top banks face a risk of financial instability if shadow banks withdraw their funds, according to the European Central Bank (ECB). Shadow banks, which provide funding in one form or another, account for 13% of traditional banks' liabilities and could cause significant losses if they lose confidence in banks. This could lead to a chain reaction of financial instability, with potential spillovers to traditional banks and other financial institutions. The ECB has raised interest rates to combat inflation, weakening demand for bank credit and slowing economic growth.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1 per cent lower on Monday, after logging its strongest one-day gain in nearly two months on Friday.

The European Commission, which runs the EU’s powerful anti-trust regulator, said the merger between UBS and Credit Suisse would not significantly reduce competition in the markets where their activities overlap” within the European Economic Area.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as market weighs lower default risk
summary: US stocks finished mixed on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average 0.2% lower at 33,042.78, despite a tentative debt ceiling deal between the White House and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy. Markets weighed the remaining risk of a US debt default, with rising fears that an agreement may not come in time. The S&P 500 was flat, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.3%. Consumer confidence dipped in May, and individual equities saw mixed performances, including a 3.0% gain for chip company Nvidia.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A street sign for Wall Street is seen in the financial district in New York, U.S., November 8, 2021.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: FDIC to release report on bank system health spanning SVB, Signature Bank failures
summary: The FDIC will release a report on the health of the US banking system, focusing on the period when Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and Signature Bank failed. The report, known as the Quarterly Banking Profile, covers the first three months of 2023, a time of significant bank failures. The report will include the number and assets of lenders on the Problem Bank List, as well as information on the government's deposit insurance fund. The release of this report comes as analysts continue to scrutinize the viability of other small and midsize lenders.

site_title: Twitter is now worth just 33% of Elon Musk’s purchase price, Fidelity says
summary: Elon Musk's Twitter is now worth only 33% of its original purchase price of $44 billion, according to Fidelity, which has marked down its equity stake to $8.8 billion. Musk has acknowledged overpaying for the social media platform, which has struggled financially since his takeover, with advertising revenue declining by 50% and failed attempts to recoup revenue through Twitter Blue subscriptions. The markdown erases about $850 million from Musk's fortune, but his wealth remains up $48 billion this year due to a surge in Tesla's share price.

images.alt_text: This illustration photo taken in Los Angeles on April 20, 2023, shows Elon Musk's blue tick next to his name on a smartphone. - And so The Great Sorting has begun. Elon Musk's long promised move to strip un-paid-for Blue Ticks from Twitter users swung into action on April 20, 2023. Like some kind of Bibilical parable in which sheep and goats are separated, hundreds of high profile accounts were put on Elon's left side, while a handful of others were gathered on his right. (Photo by Chris DELMAS / AFP)

site_title: Why are food prices so high in Europe?
summary: Food prices in Europe have surged, with average prices rising 17% in April compared to the previous year, according to the European Union. The main drivers of this inflation are rising commodity prices, particularly wheat and energy, as well as labor costs and profit margins. Companies, including major food producers like Nestle, are accused of profiteering, with some economists estimating that 10-20% of food inflation is due to this. Governments are intervening by capping prices on food essentials, but overall, food prices are unlikely to decline in the near future, with the pace of increases expected to slow later this year.

images.alt_text: A vendor writes out euro prices for his products at a market stall in Patisia district in Athens, Greece, on Monday, May 22, 2023. Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis pummeled his opposition in Sunday’s national election, moving a step closer to getting another four-year term and sending markets higher on the prospect that the premier’s investment-friendly policies will continue. Photographer: Konstantinos Tsakalidis/Bloomberg

epa10649444 A shopper at a supermarket in London, Britain, 24 May 2023. The Office for National Statistics (ONS) has reported a drop in UK inflation to 8.7 percent but food prices still remain close to a forty-year high, as the cost of living crisis continues to hit UK households hard.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Pakistan International Airlines’ jet seized in Malaysia for unpaid dues
summary: Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) had a Boeing 777 jet impounded in Kuala Lumpur due to unpaid charges by a leasing company, AerCap Holdings. The plane was seized on May 29, forcing PIA to send a replacement aircraft to pick up stranded passengers. PIA claims the disputed amount has been paid, and they will seek legal remedies to free the plane. This is the second time in two years a PIA aircraft has been seized in Malaysia, amid the airline's ongoing financial struggles following the European Union's 2020 ban on its flight operations over fake pilot licenses.

site_title: Crypto here to stay, must be regulated: Hong Kong treasury chief
summary: Hong Kong's treasury chief, Christopher Hui, announced that the city will allow retail investors to trade cryptocurrency under its new regulatory regime, citing the "fundamental value" of virtual assets despite potential risks. The move comes as regulators worldwide examine cryptocurrencies following high-profile failures, and Hong Kong aims to become a major digital asset hub. The new rules will require crypto exchanges to assess client risk tolerance and knowledge, and impose risk-exposure limits. The government has received over 80 enquiries from crypto firms and aims to attract more businesses to the city.

images.alt_text: China’s ban on crypto trading in 2021 dulled Hong Kong’s allure as a conduit for mainland cash.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on tentative debt ceiling deal; Nvidia jumps
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, May 30, as lawmakers agreed to raise the nation's debt limit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 10.31 points, or 0.03%, to 33,103.65. Nvidia led a rally among chipmakers and AI-related firms, with shares jumping. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, gaining 21.26 and 133.41 points, respectively.

site_title: The cobra effect on the bottom line
summary: Business leaders are often prone to the "cobra effect," where well-intentioned decisions lead to unintended negative consequences. This phenomenon is commonly seen in sales teams, where inadequate rewards and compensation plans can drive motivation to sell at the expense of customer relationships. A recent example is Wells Fargo, which introduced an aggressive cross-selling reward scheme that led to the opening of millions of unauthorized accounts. To avoid similar pitfalls, companies must adopt a data-led and connected planning approach, incorporating collaboration across revenue operations and using scenario planning to understand the future impact of their decisions.

images.alt_text: Ask sincere questions, check your own biases, have empathy -- some ways to check if your business culture needs improvement.
Apple, the world’s most valuable company, began a belt-tightening effort last July, when galloping inflation and recession fears spurred it to take a more cautious stance.

site_title: US consumer confidence dips in May: survey
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 102.3 in May from 103.7 in April, according to The Conference Board. Despite the decline, more households planned to purchase motor vehicles and big-ticket items, which could support consumer spending. Consumer inflation expectations dropped to 6.1% from 6.2% last month. A notable worsening in consumer outlook among those over 55 years old was observed, while plans to purchase autos and appliances increased slightly.

site_title: Canary Wharf debt downgrade is latest sign of real estate woes
summary: Moody's downgraded Canary Wharf Group's debt to Ba3 from Ba1, citing a difficult operating and funding environment for real estate companies. The company, owner of London's Canary Wharf financial district, has £1.4 billion of debt due in 2024 and 2025, which it may need to refinance or de-leverage through asset sales or shareholder support. The downgrade reflects the challenges facing the UK commercial property market due to rising interest rates and reduced lending.

images.alt_text: Rising interest rates and macro-economic worries have dampened a tentative recovery in the British commercial property sector from pandemic lows, while the office space portfolio has struggled due to an increased shift to remote-working trends.
Canary Wharf in the financial district of the City of London. Commercial real estate has been roiled by the dramatic shift in interest rates over the past year, which has begun to hit pricing.

A crane operates on construction of a new residential apartment building near to a row of terraced residential housing in London, U.K., on Thursday, Nov. 16, 2017. London's housing market is being battered from all sides. A survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors showed a price gauge at its lowest level for seven years, and far below the national average. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
The highest number of super-prime deals took place in the borough of Kensington, with 26 properties sold.

site_title: Challenger majority stakeholders make S$0.56 per share cash offer to privatise company
summary: Majority shareholders of Challenger Technologies, a consumer electronics retailer, have made a voluntary cash offer of S$0.56 per share to take the company private. The offeror, DigiTech Holding, intends to delist the company from the Singapore Exchange once the offer is complete. The offer represents a premium of 3.1% over the volume-weighted average price (VWAP) for the past month, providing shareholders with a "clean cash exit opportunity." The move aims to give the company more flexibility in managing its business and optimizing its resources.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Challenger Technologies requested for a half in trading effective immediately on Monday (May 29).
Creative destruction? Once upon a time, venture capitalists refused to fund anybody who didnt promise to break things.
For the second half of 2022, Challenger’s revenue rose 9 per cent to S$160.4 million, with IT products and services revenue contributing to the increase.

site_title: JE Cleantech takes electrifying journey to cleaner operations
summary: JE Cleantech, a company specializing in custom cleaning machines and dishwashing services, is transitioning to cleaner operations by reducing water consumption and investing in electric vehicles. The company has cut fuel and maintenance costs by 60% since electrifying its fleet, and is also installing solar panels at its facility to offset energy consumption. JE Cleantech aims to expand its centralized dishwashing operations to generate consistent cash flows, driven by growing demand in the food and beverage industry. The company is also exploring other products and services to diversify its revenue streams and innovate its machines and processes.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Singapore precision engineering body to be helmed by woman for first time

site_title: Farm to table: A strategic approach to smart manufacturing in F&B
summary: Singapore aims to produce 30% of its food domestically by 2023, requiring food and beverage (F&B) manufacturers to adopt smart solutions to improve inventory management, reduce labor constraints, and meet industry standards. Automation, digitalization, and information solutions can help manufacturers overcome challenges such as high labor costs, lack of skilled workers, and environmental concerns. Key benefits of smart manufacturing include energy management, food safety, and optimized operations, with a focus on sustainable practices and resource-efficient approaches. A collaborative cyber strategy is also essential for F&B players to effectively manage security risks and bridge information technology and operational technology silos.

images.alt_text: Janice Wong’s innovative dessert concepts have enabled the brand to cultivate a loyal following of customers globally, across different generations.
F&B sector has evolved over the course of 2020

site_title: US debt ceiling deal to face its first test in Congress
summary: US lawmakers are set to vote on a bipartisan deal to raise the US debt ceiling, with President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy predicting they will get enough votes before Monday. The 99-page bill will be considered by the House Rules Committee on Wednesday, and votes are expected in both the Republican-controlled House of Representatives and Democratic-controlled Senate. The US Treasury Department warns that it will run out of money to pay its bills by Monday if the deal is not passed.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong markets rose after four days of hefty losses, while there were also gains in Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul and Taipei, though Tokyo, Sydney, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta dropped.
Brent crude futures settled 12 cents, or 0.2 per cent, higher at US$77.07 a barrel on Monday.
The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, March 23, 2023.    REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Ukraine, IMF reach agreement for US$900 million loan disbursement
summary: Ukraine and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) reached a preliminary agreement for a $900 million loan disbursement, part of a $15.6 billion four-year loan program. The agreement follows talks in Vienna, where the IMF approved Ukraine's performance criteria. The IMF praised Ukraine's resilience in the face of war-related uncertainty and noted a gradual economic recovery, but warned of a risk of a ballooning deficit. In exchange for aid, the Ukrainian government committed to measures such as improved tax collection and shielding the central bank's independence.

site_title: India to lure manufacturers with electronics repair pilot project
summary: India is launching a pilot project to establish itself as an electronics repair hub, relaxing cumbersome import-export rules to attract tech majors like Flex. The move aims to create a $20 billion repair industry in five years, with a total cost advantage of 57% over China and 26% over Malaysia. The pilot phase, involving companies like Lenovo and Cisco, will permit re-export of imported electronics goods and allow for 5% domestic recycling of imported goods. The goal is to draw electronics manufacturers and create resilience in the supply chain.

site_title: UBS sued by Credit Suisse investor arguing price was too low
summary: A Credit Suisse shareholder is suing UBS Group for at least 1.06 million francs, claiming the bank unfairly acquired shares for 0.76 Swiss francs each, significantly below the closing price of 1.86 Swiss francs on March 17. The investor alleges this undervalued offer broke takeover convention and ignores Credit Suisse's broader value. If the complaint succeeds, it could embolden other shareholders to come forward, adding to mounting legal headaches for UBS.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse has also been handing out retention bonuses to staff whom UBS sees as critical for the future of the combined bank.
“I think Credit Suisse is culturally challenged in the investment bank so we have to be very careful about – I use the term culture filter – who we bring in,” UBS Chairman Colm Kelleher says.
The order affects the top three levels of Credit Suisse management and follows the multi-billion franc state rescue of Switzerland’s second-biggest bank.
On May 9, Credit Suisse decided against an appeal and withdrew its application for precautionary measures, according to the court.

site_title: Oil falls amid risk-off mood and doubts of further Opec+ curbs
summary: Brent oil prices have dropped about 12% this year due to factors such as China's economic sluggishness and US monetary policy concerns. The risk-off mood in Asia has led to a decline in oil prices, with the global benchmark trading near $76 a barrel. Opec+ producers Saudi Arabia and Russia have given conflicting signs on production cuts, with Russia stating it is unlikely to take further measures at its June meeting. Oil prices may drop further if economic news worsens, potentially reaching the $65-$70 range.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 12 cents, or 0.2 per cent, higher at US$77.07 a barrel on Monday.
Brent crude futures climbed 39 cents, or 0.5 per cent, to US$77.34 a barrel by 2317 GMT, while US West Texas Intermediate crude was at US$73.12 a barrel, up 45 cents, or 0.6 per cent.
Brent crude settled 69 cents, or 0.9 per cent, higher at US$76.95 a barrel on Friday.

site_title: Top emitter China needs US$38 trillion to hit climate goals early
summary: China, the world's largest greenhouse gas emitter, needs approximately $38 trillion in investment to hit its climate goals of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. To meet this target, China must triple its energy-transition investment to $1.7 trillion annually, focusing on renewable energy, energy storage, and carbon capture technology. The country's energy sector is shifting away from coal, with wind and solar power becoming dominant, and coal consumption is expected to peak this year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 28, 2021 shows a general view of the Wujing Coal-Electricity Power Station in Shanghai. - Asia-Pacific accounts for about three-quarters of global coal consumption -- even as the region struggles with the environmental and public health impacts of global warming, from deadly levels of air pollution in India to extreme heatwaves and wildfires in Australia.  (Photo by Hector RETAMAL / AFP) / TO GO WITH Climate-UN-COP26-Asia-coal,FEATURE by Haeril Halim and Sam Reeves

site_title: Frasers Property announces programme to support inclusivity in malls
summary: Frasers Property Singapore has launched an "Inclusion Champions" programme to create more inclusive spaces and experiences for community members with different needs. The programme, which includes a six-hour training session, will equip mall employees and participating retail tenants with skills to engage persons with dementia or autism. Ten mall retail tenants, including Osim and Cathay Cineplexes, will dedicate space within their outlets to cater to the needs of the neurodivergent and elderly. The initiative aims to enhance inclusivity and sustainability across Frasers Property's properties.

images.alt_text: Having volunteered for a year with DBS, volunteer Reagan Foo says that one of the most common questions posed to him would be “how to create a password”.
From left:  BT Editor Chen Huifen, Standard Chartered Bank, Tan Wei Zhi, Regional Head of Impact & Engagement, Singapore & Asia

site_title: Nearly 7,000 flats launched in May BTO and Sale of Balance Flats exercises
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched its May Build-To-Order (BTO) and Sale of Balance Flats (SBF) exercise, offering 6,995 new public housing flats. The majority of the flats (61%) have been completed, with 5,945 BTO units and 1,500 SBF units available. The launch includes various types of flats, including five-room units in mature estates, which are expected to be popular among families and young couples. Experts predict strong demand for the flats, with prices expected to moderate due to increased supply.

images.alt_text: Parc Meadow @ Tengah will have 15 residential blocks, ranging from 12 to 13 storeys.
The number of households and grant amount given out have increased each year since, in line with more flats being sold.

site_title: Microsoft says UK regulator an ‘outlier’ for blocking Activision deal
summary: Microsoft has appealed the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) decision to block its $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard, calling the regulator an "outlier" for its stance. The CMA vetoed the deal in April, citing potential harm to the UK's cloud gaming market. Microsoft argues that 10 regulators worldwide have already approved the merger, and that the UK's decision creates uncertainty that could derail the deal. The appeal is set to be heard in July, with Microsoft's lawyer stating that speed is of the essence to complete the merger.

images.alt_text: Activision Blizzard headquarters in Santa Monica, California, US, on Monday, May 15, 2023. Microsoft Corp.'s $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard Inc. won European Union approval, putting the bloc at odds with its UK and US counterparts. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg

site_title: Deutsche Bank on M&A hiring spree as deal drought lowers costs
summary: Deutsche Bank is on an M&A hiring spree, signing veterans from Wall Street rivals such as Bank of America, Credit Suisse, and Citigroup. The German bank aims to boost its ranks and regain market share from US rivals, which have been cutting jobs due to a slump in deals. Deutsche Bank has hired over 50 industry-coverage deal makers and product experts since the start of the year, investing in technology and selective hiring to target growth in strategic revenues. The bank's CEO, Christian Sewing, has stated that he will continue to invest in fee-generating areas such as M&A advisory.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Deutsche Bank is seen in Brussels, Belgium, December 6, 2022. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Nvidia surpasses US$1 trillion market valuation in massive AI bet
summary: Nvidia surpassed the $1 trillion market valuation milestone, becoming the world's first chipmaker to reach this mark. The company's stock rose 4.3% in New York trading, following the viral success of ChatGPT and the increasing adoption of AI technology across industries. Nvidia now joins the ranks of five American companies with trillion-dollar valuations, including Alphabet, Amazon.com, Apple, and Microsoft.

images.alt_text: Asus will preload the AFS hardware with its own large language model, called Formosa, which it says is equivalent to ChatGPT 3.5 and trained in traditional Chinese.
“Agile companies will take advantage of AI and boost their position. Companies less so will perish,” the Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang says.

site_title: Thai exports fall more than expected in April, may rebound in Q3
summary: Thailand's exports contracted 7.6% in April, worse than expected, due to global economic uncertainty. The country posted a trade deficit of $1.47 billion, with imports showing a 7.3% year-on-year contraction. Exports of industrial goods fell 11.2%, while agriculture goods rose 24%. Despite this, the commerce ministry expects shipments to rebound in the third quarter, maintaining its target of 1-2% export growth this year.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s economy expanded faster than expected in the first quarter due to a revival in tourism, a mainstay of the economy.

site_title: Sias recommends Golden Energy and Resources shareholders reject exit offer
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association (Sias) is advising Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) minority shareholders to reject the exit offer by the controlling shareholders, citing concerns over the independent financial adviser's (IFA) valuation methodology. The IFA's "fair and reasonable" opinion on the delisting proposal has been questioned by Sias, which claims the IFA conflated the exit offer and the distribution of shares, reducing the value of the Gems distribution by 42%. Sias urges minority shareholders to make their voices heard, with the resolutions requiring 75% approval, and notes that rejecting the exit offer would leave Gear holding onto its valuable stakes.

images.alt_text: David Gerald , Founder, President and CEO of Securities Investors Association (SIAS) speaking at the inaugural SIAS Master Series Investment Conference.
Benjamin Cher

site_title: A life’s work in guitar-making
summary: Freeman Vines, a 80-year-old guitar maker, has spent his life crafting unique instruments using wood from unexpected sources. Starting in 1958, Vines pursued a specific sound that he couldn't replicate on mass-produced guitars, resulting in dozens of one-of-a-kind creations. His guitars, known as "Hanging Tree Guitars," have been featured in exhibitions, including a recent show at the Maria V Howard Arts Center in North Carolina. Despite health issues, Vines continues to work, saying "I'm living now" and that his craft allows him to connect with the wood he uses.

site_title: US dollar set to be stronger for longer
summary: The US dollar is expected to remain stronger for longer due to the pricing out of rate hikes, despite a potential reversal in risk aversion that pushed US bond yields and the dollar higher. The Fed is likely "done" with rate hikes, but the process of unwinding has not yet completed, providing near-term support for the dollar. The yuan, however, is expected to avoid sustained underperformance due to China's recovery in domestic investment activity and trade surplus, as well as improving economic fundamentals and potential easing of US-China tensions.

images.alt_text: John Woods

Stacks of U.S. $100 bills are arranged for a photograph in New York, U.S., on Thursday, Feb. 7, 2013. The U.S. dollar advanced in trading today to the highest in almost three weeks against a basket of major currencies.  BLOOMBERG

Since the  yuan fell below the key 7-level on May 17, the central bank has been setting the fix broadly in line with market estimates, with investors taking it as a sign that the PBOC would tolerate further weakness in the  yuan.

site_title: Chinese organisations launched 79 AI large language models since 2020: report
summary: China has launched 79 large-language models (LLMs) since 2020, surpassing the US in the number of LLMs released this year with 19 to the US' 18. The development of LLMs accelerated in 2020, with 2 LLMs released by Chinese organisations, compared to 11 in the US. The US still leads globally in terms of LLMs, accounting for over 80% of the total, but Chinese tech giants are launching their own versions of chatbots powered by generative AI and LLMs, such as those from Alibaba, Sensetime, and Baidu.

site_title: Indonesia presses Shell to expedite Masela project exit
summary: Indonesia is pressuring Shell to expedite the sale of its 35% stake in the Masela gas project, which has been on the market since 2019. The government has given Shell sufficient time to sell, but the company has been slow to decide. If Shell fails to sell by next year, Indonesia may take back its stake. Petronas, a Malaysian state-run energy company, has expressed interest in buying the stake. The project, held by Inpex, is expected to produce 9.5 million tonnes of LNG per year, boosting Indonesia's natural gas output.

images.alt_text: More than 100 activists interrupt the opening remarks from chief executive Wael Sawan, according to Fossil Free London, while others attempt to occupy the stage.

site_title: Vietnam urges industry to save energy during heatwave
summary: Vietnam is taking measures to conserve power amid a severe heatwave, with temperatures expected to reach 26-38°C this week. The country has turned off street lights and manufacturers are switching to off-peak hours to reduce demand on the national grid. Government offices have been urged to cut power use by 10% as the state utility EVN warned of strain on the grid in coming weeks due to the heatwave, which could persist into June.

images.alt_text: The climate fund is set to be the first to focus specifically on South-east Asia with the launch coming at a time when investors globally are increasingly focusing on investments that can help in the fight against global warming.
Samsung is the biggest single foreign investor in Vietnam, employs 160,000 people and produces half of its smartphones in the country,

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private residential property is now the most expensive in the Asia-Pacific, surpassing Hong Kong, with a median price of US$1.2 million, according to a report by the Urban Land Institute (ULI). The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will launch a consultation on the inclusion of coal phase-out criteria in the Singapore taxonomy. WongPartnership is in talks with over 40 Credit Suisse AT1 bondholders to represent them in a collective action. Condo resale volumes fell 17.9% in April, while prices rose 1.2%, according to SRX and 99.co.

site_title: Potential offeror for ASTI a consortium comprising majority shareholder and Thai-listed company
summary: ASTI Holdings, a semiconductor company, has identified a potential offeror for the company, Prospera Alliance, a consortium comprising Thai-listed Capital Engineering Network Public Company (CEN) and substantial shareholder Heah Theare Haw. The consortium has submitted an application to the Securities Industry Council for approval. ASTI's shares have been suspended since July 2022 due to failing to exit the Singapore Exchange watch list. The company's board of directors aims to secure a fair and reasonable exit offer for shareholders, which must first obtain necessary regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: cpu, chip, semiconductor
Benjamin Cher

site_title: Yen firms on policymaker meeting, US dollar swings after debt deal
summary: The US dollar index surged to a 10-week high against peers and a six-month high against the yen before retreating, influenced by Japanese officials' response to the yen's weakening. The yen strengthened, holding onto gains, while the US dollar fell 0.2% to 140.16 yen. Japanese officials stated they will closely monitor currency market moves and respond "appropriately" as needed.

site_title: Toyota’s April global sales rise on stronger demand in Japan, China
summary: Toyota reported a 4.9% increase in global sales in April to 800,863 vehicles, driven by stronger demand for hybrids and petrol-powered cars in Japan and China. This marks a significant recovery from pandemic-induced sales declines in the same month last year. The company also reported better overseas sales of battery electric vehicles, exceeding last year's level. Toyota's global sales are on track for a stronger year.

images.alt_text: Ford is cutting costs in China where its sales have been sliding since 2016.
Toyota is facing pressure from green investors and climate activists who have criticised it for being slower than rivals to embrace all-battery electric vehicles.

site_title: Black-and-white houses: A Singaporean architectural legacy
summary: Singapore's black-and-white houses, built between the 1900s to 1950s, are a unique architectural legacy. These colonial-style houses, characterized by whitewashed walls and black door and window frames, are clustered in prime neighborhoods and can be rented through the Singapore Land Authority (SLA). Rentals vary from S$4,000 to S$25,500 per month, depending on location and size. Pros include unique design, garden space, and large rooms, but cons include short lease periods, high upfront costs, and maintenance responsibilities. An inquiry has been launched into the leases of ministers K Shanmugam and Vivian Balakrishnan, following opposition politician Kenneth Jeyaretnam's questions.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
SLA has earlier said both properties on Ridout Road had been vacant for several years.
In a statement on May 12, SLA gave details of how the properties came to be rented out by Cabinet ministers K. Shanmugam (left) and Vivian Balakrishnan.

site_title: France inaugurates first of four gigafactories
summary: France has inaugurated its first gigafactory, a battery-making plant by Automotive Cells Company (ACC), with a total investment of 2 billion euros. The plant, located in Douvrin, France, will start production of lithium-ion batteries later this year with an initial capacity of 13 gigawatt hours, expected to create up to 2,000 jobs by 2030. This marks a key milestone in Europe's transformation to make its auto industry more resilient, competitive, and sustainable in the electric era, with plans for three more gigafactories in the same region.

images.alt_text: Chinese battery maker SVolt Energy Technology is set to expand its footprint in Europe to as many as five factories, with talks to supply the region’s carmakers well underway.
Tesla, BMW approved for slice of US$3.5b EU battery aid
After wild success at home selling affordable electric cars to the masses, BYD is looking beyond China.
Electric car lithium demand powers mining revival in UK

site_title: Challenges facing  shipping’s ‘green transition’ and the  training of seafarers
summary: The Philippines and Indonesia are working to equip their maritime workers with the skills needed for a low and zero-carbon maritime sector, with a focus on skills development for seafarers. A recent conference in the Philippines explored the challenges and opportunities of shipping's decarbonisation, including a "Maritime Just Transition". The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) and the International Maritime Organization (IMO) supported the event, highlighting the importance of well-qualified and highly skilled seafarers for decarbonisation. The ICS noted that countries with a strong maritime workforce, such as the Philippines, must keep pace with the changing requirements of the industry as it transitions to a low and zero-carbon future.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The "Cap Pembroke"  a VLCC (very large crude carrier), owned by Euronav, the largest NYSE listed independent crude oil tanker company in the world, berthed at the Valero oil terminal at Pembroke in the Port of Milford Haven, the UK's largest energy port, Pembrokeshire, Wales, July 28, 2018. REUTERS/Rebecca Naden/File Photo

site_title: Sweden risks more turbulence on property market woes, watchdog warns
summary: Sweden's financial stability is at risk due to a heavily indebted commercial property sector, according to the country's financial watchdog. Over $40 billion of maturing bond debt must be refinanced within the next five years, sparking concern over the financial viability of many highly leveraged landlords. The watchdog warns that turbulence on financial markets is possible and advises commercial property owners to reduce debt and strengthen their balance sheets to avoid further issues.

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower as investors tread with caution
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% on Tuesday, closing at 3,187.56, as investors remained cautious due to the US debt ceiling matter and its potential impact on the market. Local shares were also influenced by muted institutional inflows and a downward trend in the financial sector. Top gainers included iFast and Nio, while Jardine Cycle and Carriage and Sats were the top decliners.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Share prices of leading Chinese makers of semiconductor equipment have jumped since end-March.
China’s blue-chip CSI300 Index slumped 1.4 per cent at the close, while the Shanghai Composite Index plunged 1.5 per cent.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: An electronic board shows Shanghai and Shenzhen stock indexes, at the Lujiazui financial district in Shanghai, China October 25, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1 per cent lower on Monday, after logging its strongest one-day gain in nearly two months on Friday.

site_title: US GOP primary: Does Tim Scott have a chance?
summary: US Senator Tim Scott, the Senate's lone Black Republican, has announced his candidacy for the 2024 Republican presidential race. Despite low polling numbers, Scott has been able to create buzz among party activists and donors due to his personal and political story embodying the American dream. He credits his mother's hard work and dedication to his rise from poverty to the Senate. Scott's campaign, backed by major donors, aims to unite the divided GOP and appeal to both conservatives and moderates, potentially drawing support from African-American voters and Democrats.

images.alt_text: A sign in support of former US President Donald Trump in front of a home in Wallowa, Oregon, on May 12, 2023.

Former South Carolina governor and former US ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley announces her run for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination at a campaign event in Charleston, South Carolina, Feb 15, 2023.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis remains in a pitched battle with Walt Disney over the company’s criticism of laws prohibiting the teaching of gender identity concepts in public schools.

site_title: Qantas expects international unit to be twice as profitable as tourism rebounds
summary: Qantas forecasts its international division to be twice as profitable in the post-Covid era, driven by a strong recovery in tourism. The airline expects international margins to grow to over 8% in fiscal 2024 and up to 12% with the launch of Project Sunrise in late 2025. The Loyalty division is also projected to reach earnings of A$500-600 million in fiscal 2024, with further growth to A$800-1 billion by fiscal 2030.

images.alt_text: Qantas expects an underlying profit before tax of between A$2.43 billion and A$2.48 billion for fiscal 2023, compared with a A$1.86 billion loss in the previous year.
The reopening of premium lounge at Hong Kong is part of a A$100 million investment by Qantas into its global lounge network.

site_title: WongPartnership in talks with over 40 Credit Suisse AT1 bondholders to launch new suit
summary: LAW firm WongPartnership is in talks with over 40 holders of Credit Suisse Additional Tier-1 (AT1) bonds to represent them in a collective action against the Swiss government. They aim to bring forth an "investor treaty case" arguing that the Swiss government's decision to write off the bonds breached protections under the EFTA-Singapore Free Trade Agreement. The group is seeking third-party financing and hopes to finalize funding in the next few months, potentially avoiding legal fees for investors. This move adds to growing legal actions in Singapore against the Swiss government.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

“The conclusion was very surprising to me, in terms of the way that the bank was resolved through this very unusual sale to UBS, with associated unusual payments to shareholders versus bondholders,” Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters says.
On May 9, Credit Suisse decided against an appeal and withdrew its application for precautionary measures, according to the court.
Bondholders have argued the writedown was an unfair and disproportionate move that put shareholders before bondholders.

site_title: Bank of Japan to patiently keep ultra-easy policy: Governor Ueda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda announced that the central bank will maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy, citing a need to sustainably achieve its 2% inflation target. Ueda expects inflation to slow below 2% by mid-year, rebound thereafter with high uncertainty, and will continue monetary easing until the target is reached. The BOJ will review its forecasts at the July policy meeting, amid speculation that Ueda will phase out predecessor's stimulus to address market distortions.

images.alt_text: Japan’s economy is finally recovering from the scars of the Covid-19 pandemic.
The 10-year Japanese government bond yield has recently hovered around 0.4 per cent after the BOJ took a range of steps to counter market attacks against the cap.

site_title: Bankman-Fried charges should not be tossed, prosecutors say
summary: Prosecutors have urged a Manhattan federal court judge to deny a request by FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried to dismiss 13 counts of fraud, conspiracy, and foreign bribery. Bankman-Fried, 31, has pleaded not guilty to the charges, which allege he stole billions of dollars from customers to plug losses at his hedge fund. Prosecutors described motions to dismiss the charges as "meritless" and said the indictment sufficiently alleges that Bankman-Fried made false and misleading representations to lenders. A hearing on the motion is scheduled for June 15.

images.alt_text: Binance's global business and a US platform are the subject of a web of probes.

Christy Goldsmith Romero, one of five commissioners at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, said cryptocurrency cases account for about 20 per cent of the agency’s portfolio, including recent civil cases against the exchanges Binance and FTX.
Sam Bankman-Fried’s case is part of an escalating crackdown on alleged abuses at digital asset exchanges by US prosecutors and regulators

site_title: Unilever and Nestle to appoint new finance chiefs as industry battles inflation
summary: Nestle and Unilever are appointing new chief financial officers, Anna Manz and Graeme Pitkethly, amid the industry's battle with inflation. Manz will replace Francois-Xavier Roger, while Pitkethly plans to retire by the end of May next year. The changes come as companies face an existential challenge from cost-of-living crisis, forcing shoppers to trade down to unbranded products, threatening market share and profitability. The new CFOs will need to manage costs without excessive advertising or product development.

images.alt_text: Nestle, which makes KitKat chocolate bars, Nescafe coffee and Maggi stock cubes, said sales rose 5.6 per cent to 23.5 billion Swiss francs (S$35.4 billion) in the quarter ended Mar 31.
Nestle said it targeted organic sales growth – which cuts out the impact of currency moves and acquisitions – in a range of 6-8 per cent in 2023.
Nestle to up sustainability spending at Nescafe brand
Unilever's finance chief sees little let-up in inflationary pressures next year
The consumer goods industry has suffered about two years of soaring costs, with everything from sunflower oil and shipping to packaging and grain becoming more expensive.

site_title: MAS to launch consultation on inclusion of coal phase-out criteria in Singapore’s taxonomy
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will launch a consultation on its draft proposals for including specific criteria on the managed phase-out of coal-fired power plants in the Singapore taxonomy. This move aims to provide policy guidance for financial institutions on financing coal phase-out projects. The decision comes after extensive feedback during the third consultation, which ended in March. MAS will review the feedback and may push back the publication of the final taxonomy version to allow market participants to study the additional criteria.

images.alt_text:
ST20230530_202305278429/chmas/Shintaro Tay/Claire Huang/

Ms Gillian Tan, MAS’ Chief Sustainability Officer and Assistant Managing Director (Development & International) at her first interview with the media on Tuesday (May 30, 2023) at the MAS Building.
Janice Lim

site_title: Vietnam’s Mekong Capital plans South-east Asia climate fund as early as 2024
summary: Vietnam-based private equity firm Mekong Capital plans to launch a climate fund worth up to $200 million in 2024, focusing on investments in the regeneration of forests in the Mekong region. The fund will target businesses involved in organic and seaweed farming in Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, and Vietnam. This is the first climate fund to specifically focus on South-east Asia, as investors globally seek investments to combat global warming.

site_title: Swedish GDP stronger than expected in Q1, outlook cloudy
summary: Sweden's economy grew 0.6% in the first quarter, beating expectations, driven by robust exports. The country's GDP expanded 0.8% year-over-year, reversing a decline in the previous quarter. However, the outlook remains uncertain, with consumer sentiment still depressed and housing starts falling. The Riksbank, Sweden's central bank, faces challenges in setting interest rates amid inflationary pressures, with the Swedish crown trading at its weakest levels in over a decade.

images.alt_text: Facing a 20 per cent slump in housing prices, Sweden’s residential market is leading the region’s unfolding real estate crisis.

site_title: BYD outbids Tesla to supply EVs for Indonesian taxi operator
summary: BYD has secured an 80% order for electric vehicles from Indonesia's largest taxi operator, PT Blue Bird, to supply 400 EVs, including the E6 and T3 models. This comes as the company gains ground in the country, with plans to explore investments and potentially build EV plants in the Philippines or Vietnam. Blue Bird is reviewing its Tesla orders due to lower-cost models winning out, and will also buy 50 Hyundai EV units and consider BMW models.

site_title: More US adolescents are getting weight-loss surgery
summary: US adolescents undergoing weight-loss surgery have increased by 20% in 2021, with rates rising among minors between 2019 and 2020, despite adult rates dipping. The American Academy of Pediatrics has called for expanded access to weight-loss surgery and drugs to treat youth obesity, citing rising rates of obesity in adults and children. The practice has attracted controversy, with some questioning whether clinicians are being overly aggressive and whether any ages are too young for medical intervention.

images.alt_text: obesity, fat, nutritionist

site_title: HSBC to rename British arm of Silicon Valley Bank next month: Sky News
summary: HSBC is set to announce that the UK arm of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) will be renamed HSBC Innovation Banking next month, following a private sale facilitated by the British government and the Bank of England in March. This move protects deposits without taxpayer support. SVB's sudden collapse in March roiled global markets and left billions of dollars stranded. The US regulators have appointed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as receiver for SVB, which is undergoing bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: Depository receipts for CP All, Airports of Thailand, PTT E&P debut slightly higher on SGX
summary: Three Thai blue-chip companies - CP All, Airports of Thailand, and PTT Exploration and Production - began trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) as Singapore depository receipts (SDRs) on May 30. CP All opened at S$2.49, 0.8% higher than its SET price, while Airports of Thailand started at S$2.78, 1.5% higher. PTT Exploration and Production opened at S$5.62, 1.1% higher. The SDRs closed at the same price as their SET counterparts, with Airports of Thailand's being 0.4% higher.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Swiss economy starts year with unexpectedly strong growth
summary: Switzerland's economy experienced unexpectedly strong growth in the first quarter of 2023, with a 0.5% increase in gross domestic product. This surpasses economists' median forecast of 0.1% and is attributed to domestic consumption. However, the industry outlook and factory orders indicate a slowdown, with the purchasing managers' index below the growth threshold since January. Interest-rate increases and global tensions pose further risks for growth, and experts predict an expansion of 0.6% in 2023.

site_title: BHP taps Microsoft, AI, to improve recovery at top copper mine
summary: BHP Group has partnered with Microsoft to improve copper recovery at its Escondida mine in Chile using machine learning and artificial intelligence. The goal is to increase metal output from existing mines, as finding and building new mines is costly and difficult. BHP estimates the world needs to double copper production over the next 30 years to support decarbonization technology, such as electric vehicles and renewable energy. The project aims to optimize copper recovery and reduce waste at the mine.

site_title: Bitcoin discount emerges on Binance Australia ahead of payment cutoff
summary: Binance Australia is experiencing a Bitcoin discount of about 20% due to a withdrawal cutoff from a key local currency route. The platform will no longer allow users to withdraw Australian dollars to their bank accounts using the PayID service from May 31. This comes after Binance lost access to Australian dollar deposit services in May and the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission sued the company for allegedly violating derivatives regulations. The discount is attributed to Australian clients selling Bitcoin at a discount to withdraw AUD before the deadline, with prices on other platforms averaging A$42,379.

images.alt_text: Before joining Binance, Richard Teng held other senior positions in the traditional financial sector.
Customers in Australia can still transact using credit or debit cards, Binance said.

site_title: China's Great Wall Motor plans EV battery assembly, research in Thailand
summary: China's Great Wall Motor Co Ltd is investing up to $30 million to set up a battery-pack assembly plant in Thailand, where it plans to produce a compact electric car next year. The company is also considering a research and development centre for battery-powered pickup trucks. Thailand aims to convert 30% of its vehicle production to EVs by 2030, and Great Wall's move is part of the country's efforts to become a regional EV production centre.

images.alt_text: A GWM executive unveils the B07 Fierce Dragon Max from the company’s export-focused Haval brand.
China auto sales head for recovery this year

Great Wall Motor says documents have been submitted on Apr 11 to the ecology and environment ministry, the industry and information ministry and the top market regulator that allege BYD has failed to meet pollutant emissions standards in two hybrids.

site_title: Blackstone-owned Crown Resorts agrees to A$450 million fine in Australia
summary: Crown Resorts, an Australian casino operator owned by Blackstone, has agreed to pay a fine of A$450 million to the federal court for breaking anti-money laundering laws. This fine, subject to court approval, is the third-largest for an Australian company, adding to Crown's total penalties of A$680 million since 2020. The fine comes after allegations of governance problems and investigations into ignoring organized crime and employee safety. The agreement marks a step towards ending Crown's darkest chapter.

site_title: Don’t worship your investment heroes
summary: Investors should not put too much faith in their investment heroes, who are human and prone to mistakes. Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is heavily weighted towards Apple, which accounts for 46% of his portfolio. This highlights the risk of over-exposure to a single company. Individuals should diversify their portfolios to minimize risk, rather than following a single guru's investment strategy.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett, Chairman & CEO, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., speaks at a press conference as part of the company's weekend long shareholder meeting, at a hotel in Omaha, Nebraska, May 5, 2002.

site_title: Condo resale volumes fall 17.9% in April, prices rise 1.2%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's condo resale market saw a 17.9% drop in transactions in April, with 919 units sold, compared to 1,119 in March and a 29.7% decrease from the same period last year. Resale prices rose 1.2% month-on-month, with the highest price of S$18 million for a resale unit at Sculptura Ardmore. The market is expected to remain limited, with owners hesitant to sell due to the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rate hike for foreigners.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
“The rise (in HDB rentals), as opposed to condo rentals, could be reflective of tenants switching to lower rental alternatives in the HDB market,” says 99.co's Luqman Hakim.

site_title: Banks tap Hong Kong’s discount window for most funds since 2021
summary: Banks in Hong Kong borrowed HK$3.77 billion from the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) through its discount window, the largest amount since January 2021, amid a sudden demand for liquidity. The move indicates the city's currency was pushed to 7.85 per greenback, its weakest allowed level. The HKMA's repeated intervention has reduced interbank cash supply, leading to higher borrowing costs. Analysts say the borrowing may not be part of a systematic trend, but rather a response to thin market conditions.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong will roll out a licencing regime for virtual-asset platforms on Jun 1, part of an effort to restore its status as a cutting-edge financial centre.
To draw back talent, Hong Kong has rolled out a special visa programme, which has hooked tens of thousands of applicants.

site_title: Toyota, Daimler in deal to combine Japan truck operations
summary: Toyota and Daimler have agreed to combine their truck operations in Japan under a holding company. The joint venture will be listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and will be equally invested by the two companies. The deal aims to develop hydrogen and other technologies in areas like connectivity and autonomous driving. The companies expect to sign a definitive agreement in 2024 and close the transaction by the end of next year, following a previous emissions scandal at Hino, a Toyota subsidiary, in 2003.

images.alt_text: Toyota in April sold 800,863 vehicles globally, including its luxury Lexus brand, a 4.9 per cent increase compared to the same month last year.

site_title: Budgeting for changes in the property market
summary: The Singapore property market appears resilient despite higher interest rates, wider economic factors, and increased transaction costs. New unit sales showed unexpected strength in January, with developers returning to the market. The government's recent fine-tuning of taxation, including a 1-2% increase in Buyer's Stamp Duty, is expected to affect 15% of residential properties and 60% of non-residential transactions. The government also announced more in CPF housing grants for first-timer families to improve access and affordability.

site_title: Developer sentiment mixed on new residential launch prices: poll
summary: Developer sentiment has softened in the first quarter of 2023, with fewer expecting new launch prices to hold steady and some anticipating a drop. The composite Real Estate Sentiment Index fell to 4.6, below the neutral line of 5.0. Only 29% of developers expect prices to be higher in the next six months, while 65% expect prices to remain the same. Developers are also cautious about new unit launches, with 35% expecting a higher number of units to be launched.

images.alt_text: Staying cool in Singapore has become more expensive amid rising energy costs.
Vivienne Tay

site_title: Singapore private homes the most expensive to own and rent in Asia-Pacific: report
summary: Singapore's private homes are now the most expensive in the Asia-Pacific, with a median price of US$1.2 million, surpassing Hong Kong. Despite this, Singapore's housing is considered the most attainable in the region when including public housing, such as HDB flats. The affordability ratio of private homes stands at 13.7, making them unaffordable, while HDB resale flats remain affordable at 4.7 times the median annual income.

images.alt_text: With high interest rates, developers may benefit from buyers choosing new homes sold off-plan because of the progressive payment scheme.
Rents for the mid and mass market segments may soon plateau and there exists an increasing likelihood that they may soften in H2 2023.
This is the highest proportion of foreign purchases since Q1 2018 when foreign purchases stood at 7.3 per cent.

site_title: Affirming affordability of homes, resilience of Reits
summary: Singapore's housing market remains resilient, with the government affirming its commitment to affordable HDB flats. The median household income can afford 70% of HDB flats launched in 2022, and resale prices rose 10.4% in 2022. Luxury property demand may pick up due to Chinese buyers returning, with high-profile deals possible. Meanwhile, the global housing market faces risks, with shakier markets in the UK and potential 40-50% decline in Singapore properties due to interest rate hikes. Investing in Singapore-listed Reits and business trusts can provide a hedge against inflation.

site_title: Olam Agri faces IPO setback due to delay in obtaining approvals
summary: Olam Agri's initial public offering (IPO) is unlikely to be completed by H1 2023 or before the summer holiday period due to delays in obtaining necessary regulatory approvals. The agribusiness unit aims to list on both the Singapore Exchange and Saudi Exchange, making it the first foreign company not in a Gulf Cooperation Council country to list in Saudi Arabia. Olam Group continues to pursue the IPO, citing growing importance of global agribusiness trends and institutional investors' interest in food security.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Singapore Exchange Centre at 2 Shenton Way, taken on 15 Feb 2019.
Agri-business group Olam proposed a final dividend of 4.5 cents per share, the same as what was declared in the year-ago period.
Olam among first in Singapore market to report detailed natural capital accounts

site_title: The world needs neutrals
summary: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) emphasizes the importance of neutrality in humanitarian aid, particularly in conflict zones. As a neutral body, the ICRC can provide assistance to civilians and prisoners of war without taking sides, allowing it to operate safely and effectively in territories controlled by adversaries. This neutrality enables the ICRC to build trust with parties involved in conflicts, facilitating dialogue and coordination to improve the situation of victims. The ICRC's commitment to neutrality is crucial in preserving humanity and promoting peace, as taking sides can lead to the exclusion of humanitarian aid and exacerbate human suffering.
