site_title: Cathay Pacific nears Boeing 777-8F freighter order: sources
summary: Cathay Pacific is close to ordering around $2 billion worth of Boeing 777-8F freighters as part of its fleet renewal. The airline had compared the 777-8F with Airbus A350 freighter models, ultimately choosing Boeing. Cathay is the world's fifth-largest air freight carrier and is embarking on a partial renewal of its 747 cargo fleet. The airline has no immediate announcement to make, but says it continues to invest in and grow its fleet with new, state-of-the-art aircraft.

images.alt_text: Cathay, whose main shareholder is British conglomerate Swire Pacific with a 45 per cent stake, has been under heavy fire in recent years, from outside the company as well as within.

site_title: Long-dated US Treasury futures rally in wake of debt-ceiling accord
summary: US Treasury futures rallied on Monday ahead of a debt-ceiling bill that may lead to a deluge of short-term Treasury bill issuance, potentially draining liquidity from markets. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates again in June or July, while a month-end rebalancing of the US Treasury bond index may drive demand for long-dated Treasuries. Treasury yields reached their highest levels since early-to-mid-March, with the 10-year rate exceeding 3.85%, as traders anticipate these factors.

images.alt_text: Biden says he doesn’t foresee any sticking points that can derail the agreement.

site_title: Djokovic breezes into French Open second round
summary: Novak Djokovic defeated debutant Aleksandar Kovacevic 6-3 6-2 7-6 (7-1) in the first round of the French Open. Djokovic, seeking a record-breaking 23rd men's Grand Slam singles title, controlled the match before Kovacevic showed signs of inexperience in the tiebreak. Djokovic won with a sizzling service return on his first match point and will face Hungarian Marton Fucsovics in the third round.

site_title: Xi seeks to upgrade China’s education system, boost global sway
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has called for upgrading the country's education system to boost global influence, citing rising youth unemployment. The country needs to establish world-class universities offering scientific courses to meet major strategic needs. Xi also urged attracting more overseas students. The call comes as China faces a 20.4% youth unemployment rate, nearly four times the national level, and a struggling online education industry. Senior officials have pledged to accelerate the modernization of the industrial system to maintain China's global edge.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Graduating students wearing face masks attend a commencement ceremony at Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications in Chongqing, China June 22, 2022. Cnsphoto via REUTERS   ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT./File Photo

site_title: Old Chang Kee’s H2 net profit climbs 52.6% to S$3.5 million on higher sales
summary: Old Chang Kee's net profit for the half year ended Mar 31 rose 52.6% to S$3.5 million, driven by higher sales across retail, non-retail, and catering segments. Revenue increased 18.4% to S$46.1 million, despite a 4.8% rise in selling and distribution expenses. The company's full-year net profit grew 8.4% to S$6.2 million, while revenue rose 15.9% to S$89.8 million. Old Chang Kee plans to continue driving revenue growth, improving gross margins, and rationalizing operations to overcome manpower shortages.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
As at end September, Old Chang Kee operated a total of 80 outlets in Singapore, down from 89 outlets in the previous year.

site_title: Positives for venture debt providers amid macroeconomic uncertainty, SVB collapse
summary: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) has sparked interest in venture debt in South-east Asia, with the ecosystem largely unaffected by the implosion. Venture debt firms have seen a "net positive" from the crisis, with interest in the niche financing market picking up. The market has learned about venture debt's preference for equity funding deals, and providers are focusing on cash-flow positive or longer cash-runway businesses. Despite a slowdown in larger funding deals, seed-stage funding has remained relatively stable, and venture debt firms are seeing a strong pipeline of potential deals.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

The debt funds, with US$250 million for Europe and 20 billion yen for Japan, will be created through Mars Growth Capital, a Singapore-based joint venture between MUFG and Israeli financial tech firm Liquidity Capital, the top Japanese lender said on Monday (May 8).
Chipmaker Arm, owned by SoftBank Group, last month filed confidentially for a US stock market listing, setting the stage for one of the biggest tech IPOs in the US this year.

site_title: F&N may slake investor thirst as mercury soars
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) may experience unexpected growth this year due to the hot weather in Singapore and its neighboring countries. The company, which owns various beverage businesses, has seen its revenue increase despite falling profits in recent years. F&N's Malaysian-listed unit has reported a 9.5% revenue growth, while its Singapore-listed shares have delivered a 25.8% return over the past year. The company's market capitalization is significantly lower than its Malaysian-listed unit, and its shares offer a yield of over 4.5%. F&N's recent investments in new businesses, such as its brewery in Myanmar, may contribute to its growth.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
F&N H1 net profit falls 20% to S$55 million

site_title: Oil ticks up as markets weigh US debt deal, rate hike possibility
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude futures up 12 cents, or 0.2%, to $77.07 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 25 cents, or 0.3%, to $72.92 a barrel. The gains came as markets weighed a tentative US debt ceiling deal and considered the possibility of further Federal Reserve interest rate hikes, which could curb energy demand. Trading was subdued due to UK and US public holidays.

images.alt_text: Oil workers pass a pumping unit, also known as a "nodding donkey" or pumping jack, left, at a drilling site operated by Tatneft OAO near Almetyevsk, Russia, on Friday, July 31, 2015. Eleven months of surviving with oil below $100 have left Russia hardened enough to endure a monthlong drop to $40 a barrel, a survey of economists showed. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Sats H2’s bottom line down 16.7% to S$6 million as higher expenses eat into profits
summary: Sats, an in-flight caterer and ground handler, reported a net profit of S$6 million for the second half of FY2023, down 16.7% year-over-year due to higher expenses. Revenue increased 57.1% to S$953.8 million, but operating expenditure rose 46.7% to S$959.5 million. The company had an operating loss of S$5.7 million, but its share of earnings from associates and joint ventures helped avoid a net loss. A dividend was not proposed, citing operational and working capital requirements.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Ry-Anne Lim
Analyst Jason Sum says that the group's recent share price correction is "overdone" and "overly pessimistic".
Sats' group management board will oversee the company's global business, which is spread over more than 20 countries.
WFS CEO Craig Smyth was also announced to be leaving the company, which Sats said was due to the “new direct reporting lines to Mok”.

site_title: Bank Indonesia targets 30% increase in repo deals this year
summary: Bank Indonesia aims to increase repurchase agreements between commercial banks by 30% this year to 1,026 deals, following 76 banks signing a repo master agreement. This move is aimed at deepening the financial market and helping banks manage short-term liquidity issues in Indonesia, a goal stated by senior deputy governor Destry Damayanti. The increase is intended to reduce volatility in the market during global turmoil.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Central Bank governor Perry Warjiyo says the central bank would continue strengthening measures to support the rupiah currency to mitigate against imported inflation.

site_title: Spain’s government calls snap election after local ballot losses
summary: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez called a snap national election after left-wing parties were routed in regional ballots, losing as many as eight regional governments to the conservative mainstream People's Party. Sanchez cited the defeat as a vote of no confidence in his coalition government and sought to clarify the wishes of Spain's people and the direction of the government. The snap election may limit further losses in support for Sanchez's Socialist Workers' Party and mobilize support for the party by raising the specter of a first far-right government since Francisco Franco's dictatorship.

images.alt_text: The European Commission has urged EU countries to end programmes allowing investors to obtain citizenship, and to tighten checks when issuing residency permits, describing them as a security and money-laundering risk.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Employers in Singapore are offering wage increases to retain staff amid stiff competition and to restore pay cuts during the pandemic. The nominal wage increase reflects efforts to give higher increments to employees to retain them. Real wages, however, have only grown 0.4% in 2022 due to high inflation.

images.alt_text: Chuan Park has been sold for S$890 million to entities related to developers Kingsford Group and MCC Singapore.

site_title: New arbitration brought against SingPost over Famous Holdings share agreement
summary: SingPost has commenced arbitration proceedings against Tan Ho Sung over a share purchase agreement related to Famous Holdings Pte Ltd. The arbitration, started on May 17, seeks declarations on Tan's purported legal and beneficial ownership of unsold shares and fiduciary duties to SingPost. The potential financial impact of the proceedings cannot be quantified at this stage, and SingPost is consulting with its advisors on the dispute. Tan has had previous disputes with SingPost and its units since 2017, with all claims against SPLI and FHPL previously dismissed.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
SingPost's pivot to the Australian logistics market has put pressure on the group’s financial profile, S&P says.

site_title: SIA, Garuda to deepen commercial partnership through proposed JV
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Garuda Indonesia plan to deepen their commercial partnership through a joint venture (JV) covering flight connectivity and new initiatives. The proposed JV, subject to regulatory approvals, will cover routes between Singapore and Denpasar, Jakarta, and Surabaya. The partnership aims to boost flight connectivity, offer joint fare products, and align corporate programs. SIA and Garuda's relationship dates back to 2010, with codesharing agreements in place since then. The joint venture builds on a 2021 memorandum of understanding (MOU) between the airlines.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
SIA, Garuda ink MOU in 'wide-ranging commercial partnership'
SIA notes that its current budget for in-flight meals is about 20 per cent higher than that for FY2019 and 2020, even though it expects that its capacity will be lower than that year.
FILE PHOTO: Singapore Airlines planes sit on the tarmac at Changi Airport in Singapore December 8, 2020.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD
Indonesia is the top source of tourists in April, with Malaysia, India, Australia and China rounding out the top five.
SIA’s board has recommended a final dividend of S$0.28 per share. Including the interim dividend of S$0.10 per share, the total dividend payout for the fiscal year stands at S$0.38 per share.
Garuda plans major restructuring that may halve operating fleet
Garuda Indonesia drops Australia court appeal in price-fixing case, told to pay A$19m fine

site_title: Challenger Technologies requests trading halt
summary: Challenger Technologies, a consumer electronics retailer, has requested an immediate trading halt due to an upcoming announcement. The company reported a 40% decline in net profit for the six months ended December 2022, primarily due to a fair value loss on investment and increased operating expenses. Its shares closed at S$0.55 on Monday, up 0.9%. The halt is pending the release of the announcement, which is expected to provide further details on the company's financial performance.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: President Halimah Yacob not standing for re-election
summary: President Halimah Yacob announced she will not stand for re-election in Singapore's next presidential election, set for mid-September. She thanked Singaporeans for their trust and kindness during her six-year tenure as the country's eighth president, the first woman and second Malay president. Halimah cited her aim to create a more caring society and uphold the presidency's key role in Singapore's democracy. Her decision comes as candidates for the next president remain elusive.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Singapore’s most recent presidential election in 2017 was a walkover for Halimah Yacob as there were no other eligible Malay candidates.
Strict requirements on presidential candidates have greatly reduced the likelihood of a non-establishment candidate surfacing, whether in this or future elections.
The proposed amendments will also allow for polling stations to be set up in adjacent electoral divisions, to make it more convenient for voters who stay near an electoral boundary.

site_title: Japan’s Premier Kishida fires son after scandal tarnishes image
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has fired his son, Shotaro, who worked as his secretary, after a scandal over a party at his official residence in 2022. The decision comes amid criticism of Shotaro's behavior, including photos of him posing in official spaces during the party. The move is seen as an attempt to boost Kishida's approval ratings, which have fallen to 47% following the scandal. Kishida's son will be replaced effective June 1.

site_title: China rejects US claim that ‘de-risking’ is not ‘decoupling’
summary: The US has been trying to convey a "de-risking" approach to its relations with China, rather than a full "decoupling", in an attempt to avoid alienating European allies. However, China has rejected this distinction, with officials and academics stating that "de-risking" is essentially the same as "decoupling". The US aims to limit China's access to cutting-edge chips over national security concerns, but China sees this as a thinly veiled attempt to cut ties. The "de-risking" narrative is seen as a moderate approach to counter Chinese economic risks, but experts warn it may have the opposite effect, increasing dependence on a single location for goods.

images.alt_text: Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao’s trip to the US comes after G7 leaders met in Hiroshima, at which US President Joe Biden and other G7 leaders took aim at China over “economic coercion”

site_title: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai loses bid to terminate national security trial
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai, founder of Apple Daily, had his bid to terminate his national security trial rejected by the High Court. Lai faces charges under the national security law, including collusion with foreign forces, which could lead to life imprisonment if convicted. His lawyer argued for bias in the court's appointment of national security judges, but the court dismissed the challenge, allowing the trial to proceed in September.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People wearing face masks walk on the street during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Hong Kong, China, December 28, 2022. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Philippines’ Ayala eyes investment deals as it recycles capital
summary: Ayala, the Philippines' oldest conglomerate, plans to reinvest its US$1 billion in capital into emerging businesses within a year, benefiting from the country's 6.4% economic growth in Q1 2023. The company aims to recycle its capital, focusing on areas with immediate opportunities, and has already deployed 60% of the funds. Ayala may consider raising funds this year to support future investments, with a focus on health, logistics, and core businesses.

images.alt_text: The Philippines' central bank governor Felipe Medalla sees inflation in May to be “significantly lower” year on year, but the month-on-month figure may be higher.

site_title: Western Australia state leader resigns
summary: Western Australia Premier Mark McGowan resigned on May 29, citing exhaustion after serving since 2017. He will step down from parliament this week. McGowan attributed his decision to the challenges of his role, stating he is "extremely tired" and "exhausted." The resignation comes after McGowan's Labor Party holds a large majority in the state parliament, making his departure a surprise.

site_title: China considers tax breaks for manufacturers as economy cools
summary: China is considering new tax incentives for high-end manufacturers, potentially saving them hundreds of billions of yuan, as the country's economy cools. The move aims to bolster the economy and encourage innovation in technology to counter US competition. China's post-Covid economic rebound is losing momentum, with weakening exports, investment, and a rising youth unemployment rate. The government is under pressure to stimulate the economy, with a relatively modest growth target of 5% this year, and may opt for targeted measures like tax incentives to boost business confidence.

images.alt_text: China’s post-Covid recovery is faltering, recent data has shown, with export growth weakening and industrial deflation worsening in April.

site_title: Finding gems in prime private homes and HDB resale flats
summary: Private home buyers in Singapore are advised to consider prime districts, particularly the Core Central Region (CCR), for attractive value propositions. The price premium for private non-landed homes in CCR has narrowed in recent years. Cushman & Wakefield Singapore notes the value of CCR homes, comprising prime districts 9, 10, 11, Downtown Core, and Sentosa, making them an attractive option for savvy buyers.

images.alt_text: The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter (Feb 28, 2023)
Leslie Yee

site_title: Singapore shares kick off week on dour note; STI down 0.4%
summary: The Singapore stock market ended Monday's trading session 0.4% lower, closing at 3,195.22, due to cautious trading despite a tentative US debt ceiling deal. The benchmark Straits Times Index fell 12.17 points. Market watchers noted that liquidity and financial conditions have tightened, with positive momentum building in US Treasury yields. Top gainers included iFast and Sembcorp Industries, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Jardine Matheson Holdings were among the biggest decliners.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
China’s blue-chip CSI300 Index slumped 1.4 per cent at the close, while the Shanghai Composite Index plunged 1.5 per cent.
Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said on May 3 that no decision on a pause had been made yet, but highlighted the change in rhetoric in the Fed's statement

site_title: Mizuho cuts risk in bond portfolio, awaiting BOJ, Fed shifts
summary: Mizuho Financial Group, Japan's third-largest bank, is adjusting its bond portfolio to prepare for potential central bank actions in the US and Japan. The bank is selling illiquid assets and shortening the average maturity of its holdings, expecting changes in monetary policy within the next 12 months. Co-head Kenya Koshimizu expects the Bank of Japan to change its ultra-easy policy and the Federal Reserve to end aggressive rate hikes, potentially sparking big market moves. The bank aims to be ready for any eventuality, with a focus on extreme uncertainty over inflation and the US economy.

images.alt_text: A man is silhouetted behind the glass entrance of a Mizuho bank in Tokyo July 29, 2011. Mizuho Financial Group posted a 35.6 percent fall in first-quarter net profit on Friday, hurt by the lack of anything comparable to its strong bond trading gains a year earlier, but kept its full-year forecast.  REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao (JAPAN - Tags: EMPLOYMENT BUSINESS)

site_title: Japan puts missile defences on alert as North Korea warns of satellite launch
summary: Japan has placed its ballistic missile defences on alert after North Korea notified it of a planned satellite launch between May 31 and June 11. North Korea claims to have completed its first military spy satellite, with leader Kim Jong Un's approval for the launch. Japan vows to shoot down any projectile that threatens its territory, using its Standard Missile-3 or Patriot Missile PAC-3 systems. The planned launch is the latest in a series of missile tests by North Korea, which would be a serious violation of UN Security Council resolutions.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin says the United States and its allies are fighting an expanding proxy war against Russia after the Kremlin chief sent troops into Ukraine 15 months ago.
South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol (above) held a summit in Seoul with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President Charles Michel.

site_title: A look at past changes to CPF interest rates
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board has announced a 0.01% increase in interest rates for Special and MediSave Accounts, bringing the rate to 4.01% per annum, effective July 1 to September 30. This is the first time interest rates for Special and MediSave Accounts have exceeded 4% since 2008, when the 4% floor interest rate was introduced. Other CPF accounts, including Ordinary Accounts and Retirement Accounts, will remain unchanged at 2.5% and 4% respectively per year.

images.alt_text: Market watchers say the 0.01 percentage point increase in the MediSave Account and Special Account rate is miniscule relative to the rise in inflation and market interest rates.
CPFboard.jpg

The government said it would continue to watch the interest rate environment closely “to ensure that the CPF interest rate pegs remain relevant in the prevailing operating environment”, while taking into consideration the longer term outlook.
Arguably, an increase in CPF contribution is a matter of when, not if.
The increase is due to a rise in the 12-month average yield of 10-year Singapore Government Securities.

site_title: Xiaomi to make wireless audio products in India
summary: Xiaomi's Indian arm will start producing wireless audio products in partnership with Optiemus Electronics in Uttar Pradesh, aiming to increase local component production by 50% by 2025. This move follows Xiaomi's recent loss to Samsung as India's top smartphone company, highlighting the company's push to localize its operations.

site_title: US long-only funds sell US$6 billion in China ADRs this year
summary: US long-only funds have sold over $6 billion in US-listed China stocks this year, driven by China's fading recovery outlook and widening geopolitical tensions. The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index, comprising internet giants like Alibaba Group, lost 5.6% in May, and has lost about half of its gains since October. Investors are diversifying to other options with lower policy risks, such as Japan, and US investors prefer buying "China proxies" rather than directly trading China equities.

images.alt_text: The merger with investment firm Bridgetown Holdings values MoneyHero at about US$200 million including debt. Bridgetown is backed by billionaires Peter Thiel and Richard Li.

site_title: Goodyear's India unit almost doubles Q4 profit to 336 million rupees on easing costs
summary: Goodyear India's standalone profit rose to 336.1 million rupees in the quarter ended March 31, nearly doubling from 173.9 million rupees a year ago, driven by lower raw material costs and growing demand for automobiles. Revenue from operations increased 9.1% to 6.53 billion rupees, while cost of materials consumed fell 5.4%. The company attributed the growth to better demand in the original equipment segment and cost efficiencies.

images.alt_text: The reductions will target salaried employees, representing about 5 per cent of such positions across the company, according to a statement on Friday (Jan 27).

site_title: Philippine inflation may cool below 2% in January, Medalla says
summary: Philippine central bank governor Felipe Medalla predicts inflation may cool below 2% in January, beating the central bank's goal of 2-4%. This could give monetary authorities leeway on monetary policy. Medalla also notes that inflation may be slightly lower than the midpoint of the target in 2024, indicating a potential easing of inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: “There arises an urgent need for a sustainable national investment fund,” Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos says.

site_title: Sustainable bonds in Asia: Look beyond the label
summary: Asia's sustainable bond market has grown rapidly, reaching $3 trillion in 2022, but investors must not assume a bond's "green" label is indicative of its quality. Bottom-up assessment of issuers is crucial, and investors should look beyond labels to understand a company's holistic sustainability strategy and ambition. Engagement with issuers is essential to encourage improvement in ESG standards, and labelled bonds can be a catalyst for this dialogue. Investors should not rely solely on labels, but rather undertake robust due diligence to achieve their desired objective and avoid greenwashing allegations.

images.alt_text: Social bonds are used to finance projects that provide social benefits, such as building affordable housing and expanding access to healthcare and education.

Access to healthcare among citizens of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) member countries is relatively low. Governments in Asean, such as Indonesia, are significantly increasing their spending on healthcare, including national insurance scheme initiatives.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as traders welcome US debt deal
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday as traders welcomed the US debt deal, with Tokyo and Sydney rallying over 1% and Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Singapore also gaining. The deal, which suspends the debt ceiling until January 2025 and imposes spending curbs, has lifted the threat of a debt default and allowed investors to refocus on economic fundamentals. However, some elements of the bill are likely to anger Democrats and Republicans, and economists warn that the global economy could still be affected.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 93 to 29 after 48.8 million securities worth S$55.5 million changed hands.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was up 1.94 per cent, or 599.22 points, at 31,515.53 in early trade, while the broader Topix index added 1.31 per cent, or 28.19 points, to 2,174.03 on Monday morning.
The sinking of the Japanese yen to its lowest in recent weeks as the USD/JPY pair scaled above the 138 level has also lent momentum to the Nikkei rally.

site_title: World’s most valuable chipmaker Nvidia unveils more AI products after US$184 billion rally
summary: Nvidia, the world's most valuable chipmaker, has unveiled a new lineup of artificial intelligence (AI) products and services, further capitalizing on the AI boom. The company's CEO, Jensen Huang, announced a new AI supercomputer platform, DGX GH200, which will help tech companies create successors to ChatGPT. Nvidia is also partnering with WPP to use AI and the metaverse to lower advertising costs. Additionally, the company is releasing a networking offering to turbocharge data center speeds and a service called Nvidia ACE for Games, which uses AI to enliven background characters in video games.

images.alt_text: “Agile companies will take advantage of AI and boost their position. Companies less so will perish,” the Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang says.
Nvidia on Wednesday projected quarterly revenue more than 50 per cent above the average Wall Street estimate.

site_title: GK Goh to delist on Jun 5
summary: Mainboard-listed company GK Goh Holdings will delist on June 5 after a successful privatisation bid by Verveine, a special purpose vehicle owned by GK Goh's founder and chairman. Verveine received 95% of valid acceptances for its S$1.26 per share cash offer, allowing the company's owners to restructure and make strategic long-term decisions without short-term pressure to deliver profits. The delisting follows a month after the privatisation bid was announced in February 2023.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: Japan's Nikkei hits 1990 high on weak yen, US optimism; SoftBank surges
summary: Japan's Nikkei stock index surged to its highest level since 1990, closing at 31,233.54, driven by optimism over a US debt ceiling deal and a weaker yen. SoftBank Group jumped 8% on news of a new chip technology adopted by MediaTek. The broader Topix rose 1.36% as Honda and Subaru rallied. The yen dropped to 141 per dollar, boosting Japanese exporters' overseas revenue.

images.alt_text: The sinking of the Japanese yen to its lowest in recent weeks as the USD/JPY pair scaled above the 138 level has also lent momentum to the Nikkei rally.

site_title: Chinese travel demand may favour aircraft lessors like BOC Aviation, China Aircraft Leasing Group
summary: Aircraft lessors BOC Aviation and China Aircraft Leasing Group are expected to benefit from China's reopening and resilient air travel demand, according to DBS Group Research. Despite recessionary risks and inflation, the report notes that air travel demand has remained strong, with a resurgence in travel in Asia driven by China's reopening. Aircraft supply may be constrained, leading to higher lease rates and values, with DBS projecting a higher portfolio yield from 2024. The research house maintains its "buy" call on both counters.

images.alt_text: Helen Wong, CEO, OCBC
Sri Lanka has battled its worst economic problems since independence in recent years, after protests over soaring inflation, food shortages and lengthy power cuts toppled the government.
Passengers at the Hangzhou East train station in China. Around 270 domestic trips were made during the five-day Labor Day holiday that ran from Apr 29 to May 3 this year.
travel, airport, boarding pass
MAS policy change still not expected as Singapore headline inflation ticks up in April, core remains flat

site_title: Wind industry aims to provide a third of Japan's power by 2050
summary: Japan's wind power body has set a goal to increase installed wind power capacity to 140 GW by 2050, aiming to meet a third of the country's electricity demand and help achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. Currently, Japan has less than 5 GW of installed wind power capacity, with only 0.14 GW of offshore wind power. The Japan Wind Power Association (JWPA) has proposed a more ambitious target than the government's goal of 45 GW of offshore wind power by 2040, and aims to attract foreign investors to build local supply chains.

images.alt_text: With some traders predicting short-term prices could even go negative at times this summer, the picture couldn’t be more different from May last year.
Russian exports to Asia of thermal coal and natural gas, the two fuels most often used for electricity generation, have grown markedly this year.

site_title: Go Air pilots offered extra 100,000 rupees a month to stay
summary: Go Airlines, facing insolvency, plans to raise pilots' salaries by 100,000 rupees (S$1,638) a month for captains and 50,000 rupees for first officers, effective June 1. The airline will also offer a retention allowance to pilots who withdraw their resignations by June 15. Additionally, a "longevity bonus" for long-serving staff will be reintroduced. The move aims to salvage operations after filing for insolvency on May 2, amid a global staff shortage in the aviation industry.

images.alt_text: Go Air  Photographer: T. Narayan/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia’s sovereign wealth fund, ESR, Mitsubishi jointly investing in three Indonesian logistics parks
summary: Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund ESR and Mitsubishi have partnered to invest in three logistics parks in Indonesia, developed and managed by ESR. The assets are located in Cikarang and Karawang, with two expected to complete in May and June 2023. The partnership aims to accelerate ESR's market reach in Indonesia, leveraging INA's customer ecosystem and Mitsubishi's expertise in development and asset management. This joint investment is part of ESR's "accelerating our asset-light strategy" to recycle capital into sustainable growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Sabana Industrial Reit, the only Industrial S-Reit with all of its assets in Singapore, saw FY22 gross revenue rose by 15.9 per cent yoy, while NPI rose 2.6 per cent yoy.
Among Asia Pacific fund managers, ESR came top, propelled by its merger and acquisition growth.

site_title: Uber executive says European taxis joining platform
summary: Uber is seeing an influx of European taxi drivers join its platform, with European taxi drivers' usage of the app doubling to 10% of all rides, according to Uber executive Anabel Diaz. This development comes as business is strong in Europe despite uncertainty over gig economy labor rules. Diaz cited solid business performance in key markets such as Britain, France, and Germany, with innovation and growth in the taxi solution. Despite ongoing conflict, Diaz believes Uber will adapt to changing regulations.

images.alt_text: Uber is teaming up with local fleet operators such as Lithium Urban Technologies, Everest Fleet and Nigeria-based Moove to get EVs on the country’s roads.
As part of the partnership, people will be able to request Waymo’s services through Uber’s apps for ride-hailing and delivery, the companies say.

site_title: Thailand must raise revenue to boost spending, World Bank says
summary: The World Bank recommends Thailand implement progressive tax reforms to boost revenue collection, increasing it by 3.5 percentage points of gross domestic product. This will help meet growing public spending needs, primarily driven by an ageing population, without constraining economic growth and controlling public debt. The reforms aim to achieve a more equitable and resilient economy, improving public spending efficiency and supporting vulnerable populations and climate-related challenges.

images.alt_text: A Tuk-tuk driver waits for customers along the popular Yaowarat street in the Chinatown area of Bangkok on September 5, 2022. (Photo by MANAN VATSYAYANA / AFP)

site_title: Debt-ridden Sri Lanka gets US$350 million loan boost from Asian Development Bank
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has approved a $350 million special policy-based loan to provide budget support to debt-ridden Sri Lanka for economic stabilization. The loan is part of a broader package with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), following Sri Lanka's $2.9 billion bailout in March. The island nation must establish a debt-restructuring framework by September to proceed with the program. ADB President Masatsugu Asakawa expressed concern over Sri Lanka's deep crisis and its impact on vulnerable populations, particularly women.

images.alt_text: Albert Park’s comments come amid growing signs that China’s post-Covid economic recovery is losing steam, intensifying pressure on policymakers to shore up wobbly growth.

site_title: Why UAE oil boss is the right person to preside over the upcoming UN climate summit
summary: US billionaire Michael Bloomberg supports UAE's oil boss, Sultan Al Jaber, as the right person to preside over the upcoming UN climate summit, COP28. A group of US and European officials signed a letter opposing Al Jaber's appointment, citing concerns about the UAE's oil production. However, Bloomberg argues that oil producers, including the US, need to be at the table to address climate change. He notes that Al Jaber is investing heavily in renewable energy and that rejecting him would be counterproductive and short-sighted. Bloomberg's partnership with Al Jaber on clean energy initiatives and his support for the UAE's hosting of COP28 highlight the need for cooperation in addressing climate change.

images.alt_text: Al Jaber, 49, wants “transformational progress.”
Sultan Al Jaber's conflicting interests have raised concerns about the prospects of the COP28 climate summit in November in the United Arab Emirates.

New COP28 president Al Jaber is also chief executive of the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, which pumps nearly all the crude in the UAE. Many concerned with climate policies may find his appointment controversial because of this post he holds.

site_title: SIA Engineering debuts new transformation phase; revenue, flights now at 80% of pre-Covid level
summary: SIA Engineering Company has debuted its new transformation phase, dubbed the "Continuous Improvement Journey (CIJ)", which aims to embed and evolve organizational changes made in its previous phases. The company's revenue and flights handled by its line maintenance unit now stand at about 80% of pre-Covid levels, with weekly passenger traffic at Changi Airport reaching 90% of pre-Covid levels. The CIJ marks an institutional "DNA change" and is expected to prepare the company for a more competitive and difficult environment in the future, with a goal of exceeding pre-Covid levels in one or two years.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
The agreement, commencing on April 1, is for a term of two years, with an option to extend for an additional year.
SIA Engineering posted a 20.4 per cent drop in net profit to S$33.9 million for the six months ended Mar 31, 2023.

site_title: Swedish landlord SBB may seek buyer as debt crisis looms
summary: Swedish real estate group SBB is expanding a strategic review to consider a potential sale of the whole company or business segments due to rising interest rates, inflation, and growing debt. The company's shares rose over 9% after announcing the move. SBB has made several changes to improve liquidity and appease investors, including halting dividend payments and selling its stake in builder JM. Policymakers see this as a risk to financial stability, amid concerns over the impact on the country's real estate companies.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB raises Japan Foods target to S$0.65 as halal segment beats expectations
summary: RHB Research increased its target price for Japan Foods to S$0.65, citing stronger near-term profits and an expansion. The company is expected to report improved net margins and a 7% year-on-year revenue growth in FY2024. RHB maintains a "buy" recommendation, citing the company's robust growth potential, particularly in its halal segment. The stock's current valuation is seen as "compelling" with a dividend yield of 5%.

images.alt_text: Ajisen Ramen is one of the brands under Japan Foods.

site_title: Australian shares post the best day in almost 7 weeks as miners, financials gain
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% to 7,217.4-points, their biggest daily gain since April 11, driven by mining and financial stocks following a deal between US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy to suspend the debt ceiling until 2025. Miners like BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals rose 1.2%, while financials and energy stocks also gained. Analysts expect a relief rally, but warn of potential losses in June due to tax and stock loss selling.

images.alt_text: “With unemployment and retail sales coming in weaker than expected, the chance of another pause is probable,” Josh Gilbert, a market analyst with eToro says.

site_title: Baidu shares jump as Ernie Bot progress rekindles AI bets
summary: Baidu shares rose 6% in Hong Kong after reports that the company will soon launch a large-language model to power its Ernie Bot app. The move is seen as a potential catalyst for the shares, which have been down 25% from a February high due to disappointment over Ernie's pre-recorded demo. The launch could also add to the global AI frenzy following Nvidia's strong revenue forecast, and investors are hopeful that the Chinese internet giant can ride the renewed interest in AI.

images.alt_text: Baidu CEO Robin Li says the company was waiting for government approval before launching its ChatGPT-like Ernie bot.
Baidu’s results suggest China’s largest Internet firms are making some headway in revival efforts after two years of regulatory crackdowns and Covid restrictions.

site_title: Norway’s wealth fund puts Indonesian SOE under observation on risk to prehistoric art
summary: Norway's wealth fund, Norges Bank Investment Management, has placed Indonesian state-controlled cement maker Semen Indonesia under observation for three years due to the risk of damage to prehistoric cave paintings in South Sulawesi. The paintings, believed to be 44,000 years old, are threatened by drilling activities and dust from trucks carrying raw materials. The move follows recommendations from an ethics council and comes after Unesco designated the area a 'global geopark' earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Scientists have recovered the DNA of a woman from the tooth, which was used as a pendant 19,000 to 25,000 years ago.

site_title: Thai economy resilient, on path towards full recovery: finmin
summary: Thailand's economy expanded faster than expected in the first quarter due to a tourism revival, supporting its path towards full recovery. Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith stated that the economy is on a solid recovery path, with revenue collection showing strong signs of recovery and inflation expected to be below 3% this year. The government aims to implement proactive fiscal and monetary policies to sustain the recovery and manage public debt, which rose due to the pandemic response.

images.alt_text: World bank recommends a series of progressive tax reforms that could collectively increase revenues by 3.5 percentage points of gross domestic product for South-east Asia’s second-largest economy.
The Asian currency weakened for its third straight week against the dollar, closing at 34.77 on Friday.
CP All, which operates Thailand's largest convenience store chain through the 7-Eleven brand, is a popular "buy" option according to a Bloomberg poll of analysts.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices edge up 0.54% in April
summary: Hong Kong private home prices rose 0.54% in April, marking the fourth consecutive month of increases, despite being the lowest rise over that period. The slight increase follows a revised 1.6% gain in March, amid macroeconomic uncertainties and rising interest rates. Realtors predict a potential correction in the property market due to conservative buyers, while the city's central bank warns of interest rate risks and further interbank rate increases. Transaction volume is expected to soften to a four-month low in May.

images.alt_text: The city has had a voluntary licencing system for crypto trading platforms since 2019.
FILE PHOTO: People wearing face masks walk on the street during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Hong Kong, China, December 28, 2022. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: ISOTeam awarded S$50.7 million worth of contracts
summary: ISOTeam, a building maintenance company, has secured new contracts worth S$50.7 million, bringing its order book to S$195.1 million. The contracts, valued between June 2023 and March 2026, include public sector projects and repairs for flats in Toa Payoh and other areas. The latest wins are expected to have minimal impact on ISOTeam's earnings, with CEO Anthony Koh attributing the growth to a "steady recovery of the construction industry" and easing labor supply challenges.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
ISOTeam's unit is barred from hiring new foreign workers for three months.

site_title: Wuhan names and shames hundreds of debtors amid financial woes
summary: Wuhan, a city in central China, publicly named 259 debtors with outstanding payments totaling over 300 million yuan, in a rare move to collect debts. The Wuhan municipal government's revenue declined 8.5% in the first quarter, amid a local government debt problem threatening China's economy. Goldman Sachs estimates China's total government debt is around $23 trillion, with many provincial authorities exceeding a debt risk threshold set by Beijing. The move may force some regional governments to scale back spending due to high debt levels.

images.alt_text: China’s post-Covid recovery is faltering, recent data has shown, with export growth weakening and industrial deflation worsening in April.
Passengers at the Hangzhou East train station in China. Around 270 domestic trips were made during the five-day Labor Day holiday that ran from Apr 29 to May 3 this year.

site_title: Trust Bank hits over S$1 billion in deposits; expects to break even by 2025
summary: Trust Bank, a digital bank in Singapore, has reached over S$1 billion in deposits, with 500,000 customers signed up. The bank aims to break even by 2025, driven by customer growth and regular transactions. Over 70% of customers have come through referrals, and customers make 15 credit card transactions per month. Trust plans to expand its offerings, including a newly launched travel insurance product and instant loans, to deepen customer relationships and increase revenue. The bank's CEO, Dwaipayan Sadhu, emphasizes that Trust is targeting average Singaporeans, not high-net-worth individuals, and prioritizes metrics such as transaction frequency over customer spend.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Dwaipayan Sadhu, CEO of Trust
Lim Chung Chun, chairman and chief executive of iFast, says that the company will benefit from offering digital banking and wealth management services to a global market.
Jenn Ong, head of credit products at GXS, said that there are still individuals that are thinly served by banks.
GXS CEO Charles Wong unveiling the digital bank's Flexiloan product, which is its first step to building a profitable bank.

site_title: How the EU can achieve deforestation-free supply chains
summary: The European Union's new law aims to curb deforestation by requiring companies to provide due diligence reports detailing the origin of commodities and products. However, the regulation lacks specificity, allowing companies to identify possible origins instead of actual sources. Transaction-level records are crucial, but smallholder farmers and intermediaries lack digital tools and incentives to achieve this level of traceability. To address this, digital solutions like PemPem, which develops supply-chain management tools for smallholder farmers, can facilitate real-time traceability and generate data-driven insights, ultimately benefiting companies and the environment.

images.alt_text: Indonesia and Malaysia accounts for about 85 per cent of global palm oil exports and the EU is their third-largest market.

A fire rages in the Amazon rainforest, south of Novo Progresso in Para State, Brazil, Aug 16, 2020. Almost half of the companies most reliant on the commodities responsible for deforestation, and the financial firms that back them, have no policy to rein it in, a report on Wednesday said.
The EU agreed to a historic law in December that will stop products causing forest destruction from being sold in European shops and supermarkets.

site_title: New uncompleted private homes may be better buys than resale units amid high interest rates
summary: High interest rates are driving down housing prices globally, but private home prices in Singapore remain resilient. Buying a new home sold off-plan may be a more cost-effective option for buyers due to progressive payment schemes, despite higher prices per square foot compared to resale units. Developers may benefit from this trend, while buyers who borrow to purchase homes face costlier funding due to higher home loan rates. The long-term impact of high interest rates on Singapore's housing market remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

site_title: AI political fakery sparks fears for US 2024 race
summary: Artificial intelligence technology is being exploited to spread misinformation in the 2024 US presidential election, with campaigns using AI-generated images, videos, and audio to sow chaos and fuel hate. Fake images of Donald Trump's arrest and a dystopian video of a dark future under Joe Biden's reelection have gone viral, while AI-generated audio of the two men hurling insults has spread on social media. Experts warn that bad actors will use AI to manipulate media, deny reality, and fuel suspicion, but AI can also be used to engage voters and understand their concerns.

images.alt_text: Ron DeSantis, the leading Republican rival to Donald Trump, will announce his 2024 US presidential bid on May 24, 2023, during a live Twitter event with Elon Musk, a source familiar with his plans told AFP.

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis remains in a pitched battle with Walt Disney over the company’s criticism of laws prohibiting the teaching of gender identity concepts in public schools.

site_title: Frantic push to solve sovereign debt crisis irks Wall Street
summary: US debt-relief activists and politicians are pushing for bills to limit investor recoups when countries restructure debt, amid a record number of government defaults in emerging markets. 11 emerging nations have dollar debt trading at a risk premium of at least 10 percentage points, threatening default. The proposed laws in New York would overhaul the process of restructuring sovereign debt, aiming to help countries move on from default faster and cut down negotiating costs. However, major asset managers on Wall Street warn that the bills would make it harder and costlier for poor countries to access capital markets.

images.alt_text: Many governments are pushing for renewables in an effort to tackle climate change and calling for reduced gas use.

While ill-advised domestic policies sharply reduced Sri Lanka's agricultural production, the government spent down its foreign-exchange reserves and then borrowed at higher interest rates (especially from China) until it could borrow no more.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Citi positive on Sembcorp’s green energy transition, raises target by 37.2% to S$5.98
summary: Citi raised its target price on Sembcorp Industries by 37.2% to S$5.98, citing the company's "solid execution of its green transition strategy" and "inexpensive" price-to-earnings ratio of 10 times. The analyst believes the company's conventional energy segment could benefit from persistently high energy prices, while regional and domestic decarbonisation initiatives could drive long-term growth. This implies a potential upside of 19.1% from Sembcorp's last trading price of S$5.02.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Sembcorp Energy Storage System (ESS) at Banyan on Jurong Island, 2 Feb 2023.

Construction of the centre is expected to commence in the second half of this year, and be fully operational by 2026.
Sembcorp Industries' statement comes in response to a Reuters article about the potential sale of the group's waste and recycling management unit, SembWaste.

site_title: High inflation chips away decade-high salary growth in 2022, with real wages up just 0.4%
summary: Singapore's wage growth in 2022 was the highest in a decade, with nominal wages rising 6.5% and employer Central Provident Fund contributions increasing 6.3%. However, high inflation limited real wage growth to 0.4%, lower than the 1.6% in 2021. The tight labor market, driven by low unemployment and high job vacancy-to-unemployed ratio, contributed to the wage growth. Despite this, companies are expected to take a cautious approach to salary increments in 2023 due to inflation and a tougher economic climate.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore businesses may become increasingly "multi-city" or "multi-region", as they engage more workers abroad.
This will be a “strange year” for attracting, hiring and retaining staff, says a new report on South-east Asian tech talent.

site_title: Arm rolls out new smartphone tech and MediaTek signs up to use
summary: ARM has unveiled new chip technology for mobile devices, including the Immortalis-G720 for video image processing and AI applications, and the Cortex-X4 processor, which offers 15% better performance and 40% less power consumption. MediaTek has announced its intention to use the Cortex-X4 in its next-generation smartphones, marking a shift towards premium market. The Cortex-X4 is an industry first, taped out on TSMC's N3E process, and represents a departure from Arm's traditional business model of providing blueprints to chip makers.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is teaming up with WPP to use AI and the metaverse to lower the cost of producing advertising.
MediaTek launches 5G chip aimed at gaining US market share

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open nearly 2% higher on US debt deal
summary: Tokyo stocks opened nearly 2% higher on Monday, driven by optimism over a US debt deal. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.94%, and the Topix index added 1.31%. The breakthrough in US debt ceiling negotiations averted a potential default, boosting risk sentiment and providing tailwinds for the market. Key shares including SoftBank Group, Sony Group, and Toyota surged, while Fast Retailing jumped 1.72%.

images.alt_text: The sinking of the Japanese yen to its lowest in recent weeks as the USD/JPY pair scaled above the 138 level has also lent momentum to the Nikkei rally.

site_title: Live-action Little Mermaid debut makes box office waves
summary: Disney's live-action remake of "The Little Mermaid" debuted at the top of North American box offices, earning $117.5 million in US and Canadian theaters over the Memorial Day holiday weekend. Internationally, the film grossed $68 million. Despite its success, it doesn't hold the record for the biggest opening weekend for a live-action Disney adaptation.

images.alt_text: The Little Mermaid Source: Walt Disney Co.

Chief financial officer Christine McCarthy said on an earnings call last week that Disney will write off as much as US$1.8 billion of programming in 2023 as it culls the number of films and TV shows on its services.

site_title: OUE C-Reit independent director to remain in role amid unrelated legal dispute, manager says
summary: OUE C-Reit's independent director Tan Huay Lim will remain in his role amid an unrelated legal dispute. The trust's manager, OUE C-Reit, stated that the legal proceedings, filed by Dasin Retail Trust's substantial unitholder Zhang Zhencheng, do not concern the trust's affairs. The board considered the proceedings to be non-criminal and pending, with Tan planning to defend the claim. Tan's track record and experience as a former auditing firm partner were also taken into account.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Substantial unitholder Zhang Zhencheng is suing to remove lead independent director Tan Huay Lim from the manager's board, alleging breaches of fiduciary duties.

site_title: More competition, higher costs, slowing sales could hurt property agents’ earnings
summary: Singapore residential property agents face increasing competition and higher costs, leading to slower sales and lower earnings. The market has slowed down, with sales volumes dipping 22.9% year-on-year in Q1 2023, and agents now take four to six weeks to clinch deals. High hidden costs, such as marketing expenses, also contribute to the decline. The emergence of zero-commission platforms may further erode agents' earnings, but larger agencies argue that they are essential for securing buyers and achieving target sales rates.

images.alt_text: Agents earn a median monthly commission of S$5,000 a month in 2022, based on data from a consultancy.

site_title: Vietnam’s easing inflation gives central bank room for further rate cuts
summary: Vietnam's inflation rate has slowed to 2.43% year-over-year, the lowest level since March 2022, giving the central bank room to lower borrowing costs. The State Bank of Vietnam has cut key policy rates three times this year to support struggling businesses. However, exports continue to contract, falling 5.9% in May, and consumer spending is expected to slow down due to high borrowing costs and rising living expenses. Analysts believe more robust fiscal policies are needed to spur economic growth.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Vietnam will cut the overnight electronic interbank rate to 5.5 per cent from 6 per cent while keeping the discount rate unchanged at 3.5 per cent.

site_title: Special and MediSave Account interest rate to increase in Q3 2023, other CPF accounts unchanged
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board has announced a 0.01% increase in the interest rate for the Special and MediSave Account (SMA) to 4.01% per annum, effective July 1 to September 30. This increase is due to a rise in the 12-month average yield of 10-year Singapore Government Securities. The interest rates for the Ordinary Account and Retirement Account will remain unchanged at 2.5% and 4% per annum, respectively. The Government has maintained a floor interest rate of 4% since 2008.

images.alt_text: This is the first time interest rates for SMA have gone above 4 per cent since 2008.

site_title: Japan startup raises 4 billion yen  to build space robot workforce
summary: A Japanese startup, Gitai, has raised 4 billion yen to develop a robot workforce for space operations, aiming to reduce labor costs and risks in space construction. The company's robots can perform routine tasks such as assembly and inspection, potentially reducing costs by 100 times. Gitai plans to expand in the US, where it will staff up and prepare its robots for space work, with the goal of creating a safe and affordable labor force for lunar and Mars missions.

site_title: Biden, McCarthy signal confidence debt-limit deal will pass Congress
summary: US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy expressed confidence that their debt-ceiling deal will pass Congress, averting a historic US default and setting a course for federal spending until after the 2024 election. Biden called the agreement a bipartisan compromise, saying it prevents the worst possible crisis. No details were provided on the terms of the deal, but both leaders emphasized the importance of passing the agreement to avoid a crisis.

images.alt_text: Unemployment is at its lowest in more than a half-century, at 3.4 per cent, thanks to historically high demand for workers.
Government data on Friday (May 26) are projected to show payrolls in the US increased by less than 200,000 in May.

site_title: UOB, Keppel to provide sustainability and digitalisation solutions for businesses
summary: UOB and Keppel Corporation announced a collaboration to develop and provide sustainability and digitalisation solutions for businesses in South-east Asia. The solutions will focus on energy, built environment, and digital connectivity sectors, aiming to simplify sustainability for businesses. The solutions include energy efficiency and cost savings, smart sustainability solutions, and embedded banking and sustainability reporting solutions. The tie-up will accelerate the adoption of sustainable practices and help businesses contribute to a low-carbon and digital economy.

site_title: Thai blue chips on the SGX: What you need to know
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) will begin trading three Thai blue-chip companies' depository receipts (SDRs) on May 30, allowing investors to trade in the Thai economy through beneficial interest. CP All, the largest convenience store chain operator, is expected to see strong earnings momentum, with analysts recommending a "buy" rating and price targets ranging from 72 baht to 79 baht. Airports of Thailand (AOT) is also expected to perform well, with analysts predicting a record earnings year and a turnaround in the company's operating profit. PTT Exploration and Production (PTTEP) has mixed analyst recommendations, with some expecting a decline in sales volumes and gas prices.

site_title: Deutsche Bank nearly doubles capital allocation in Vietnam to over US$200 million
summary: Deutsche Bank has nearly doubled its capital allocation in Vietnam, increasing it to over US$200 million. The German bank attributed the increase to Vietnam's growth in the past two years, with the country being a key driver for the Asean region. The additional capital will support the bank's growth in Vietnam and enable it to undertake more activities for its clients, following a doubling of revenue for the bank's Asia-Pacific franchise.

site_title: Mbappe named best French player for fourth time in row
summary: Kylian Mbappe was named the best French player for the fourth consecutive time, earning the Ligue 1 player of the season award. The 24-year-old PSG forward scored 28 goals in the league this term, helping the team win a record 11th French title. Mbappe's contract with PSG will run out next year unless he exercises an option to stay until 2025. He is the first four-time winner of the award, surpassing Zlatan Ibrahimovic's three-time wins with PSG.

site_title: China urges Japan to halt export restrictions on chips
summary: China has urged Japan to halt export restrictions on semiconductors, calling them a "wrongdoing" that "seriously violated" international economic and trade rules. Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao made the call during talks with Japanese Trade Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference in Detroit on May 26. Japan has placed restrictions on the export of 23 types of semiconductor manufacturing equipment to China, following a US-led move to limit the sale of chip-making tools to the country.

site_title: Temasek caps exposure to early-stage companies at 6%
summary: Temasek, a Singapore investment firm, has capped its exposure to early-stage companies at 6% of its total portfolio, valued at S$403 billion. This 6% allocation allows for attractive returns and helps the firm stay informed about the latest technologies and innovations. Temasek's early-stage investments have generated returns slightly above the industry average for venture capital funds, with notable successes including Alibaba and Adyen. By investing early, Temasek can build positions in new winners and develop market intelligence, while also introducing disruptive technologies to its existing portfolio companies.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks began the week in positive territory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.7% to 3,229.53. Gainers outnumbered losers 93 to 29, driven by strong performances in the US and European markets. Top gainers included CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, Hiap Tong, and local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC. The market's optimism was fueled by optimism over a potential US debt ceiling deal, which lifted US indices, including the Nasdaq Composite and S&P 500.
