site_title: China’s industrial profits slide as demand weakens
summary: China's industrial profits declined 20.6% in the first four months of 2023, the slowest pace since the same period in 2022, due to weakening demand and deepening factory-gate deflation. Profits for single month of April fell 18.2% from a year earlier, as export growth weakened and foreign purchases of Chinese products slowed. Experts say more policy support and stimulus are needed for a full-year gain in industrial profit, with a potential rebound in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Industrial profits fell 20.6% in the January-April period from the same time frame in 2022. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Passengers at the Hangzhou East train station in China. Around 270 domestic trips were made during the five-day Labor Day holiday that ran from Apr 29 to May 3 this year.
Morgan Stanley is approved to set up a futures company in China, according to CSRC, the country's securities regulator.

site_title: Bitcoin jumps to more than two-week high on relief over US debt ceiling
summary: Bitcoin surged to a two-week high, reaching $28,182, amid relief over a deal to raise the US debt limit. The largest digital token gained 3.2% on Monday, with smaller tokens also posting gains. The debt-ceiling agreement has boosted investor sentiment and risk appetite in global markets, but the agreement still needs to clear Congress to avoid a US default. Despite this, some analysts expect the relief to trigger a rally in Bitcoin prices, with one predicting a "next big leg-up" in the price of Bitcoin.

images.alt_text: Former FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces fraud charges over the collapse of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange, departs from his court hearing at Manhattan federal court in New York City, US, Jan 3, 2023. Temasek wrote down its US$275 million investment in FTX last year after the crypto company’s meltdown
The city has had a voluntary licencing system for crypto trading platforms since 2019.
Singapore plans curbs on retail-investor participation.

site_title: Empowering young artists through theatrical expression
summary: The Rice Company Ltd (TRCL) launched Souljourn 2.0, a fundraising project, in partnership with The Business Times Budding Artist Fund (BT BAF) to empower young artists through theatrical expression. The project has raised S$110,000 so far and aims to share stories of triumph and personal growth, fostering a sense of connection and solidarity. The initiative, led by creative director Vishnucharan Naidu and executive producer Guru Simmar, seeks to unite hearts and souls through the power of art, promoting arts education and opportunities for those with financial limitations.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Stocks to watch: Stamford Land, Dasin Retail Trust, OUE C-Reit, Straco, ISOTeam
summary: Stamford Land's net profit rose to S$184.5 million for its second half-year, significantly higher than the S$15.6 million in the year-ago period. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.005 per share and a special dividend of S$0.01 per share. Meanwhile, a lawsuit was filed against Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager over allegations of "oppressive" conduct.

site_title: Saudi net reserves fall to US$410 billion, lowest since 2010
summary: Saudi Arabia's net foreign assets fell to $555 billion in April, the lowest since 2010, due to a decline in foreign reserves. The kingdom's central bank reported a fifth consecutive month of falling reserves, the longest streak since 2019. Saudi Arabia returned to the debt market by selling $6 billion of Islamic bonds and is forecast to run a budget deficit of 1.1% of GDP this year, contrary to its initial estimate of a surplus. The IMF increased its estimated oil price needed to balance the budget to over $80 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Visitors inside the Skybridge of the Kingdom Tower in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on January 19, 2023. Jeremy Suyker / Bloomberg

site_title: Debt deal adds brake on US economy already at risk of recession
summary: The US economy, already at risk of recession, faces additional headwinds from a new debt deal. The tentative agreement, which includes a cap on government spending, may dampen the growth momentum supported by federal spending in recent quarters. This could increase the chances of a recession, with economists previously estimating a 65% chance in the coming year. The deal avoids a worst-case scenario of a payments default, but its impact on the economy remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong (centre) attended the IPEF ministerial meeting in Detroit on May 26 and May 27, 2023.
As the review gets underway this May, some Biden administration officials argue in favour of lifting some of the tariffs as the Biden administration struggles to contain high inflation.
Government data on Friday (May 26) are projected to show payrolls in the US increased by less than 200,000 in May.

site_title: Traders ready to embrace riskier assets after debt-cap deal
summary: Global markets are poised for a relief rally after the US agreed to a tentative deal to resolve a debt crisis. The deal, which aims to refill the government's coffers, is expected to drain liquidity from the banking system and pressure US banks after months of turmoil. Investors had fled to safety as the debt crisis approached, but the deal is seen as a balanced approach to reducing spending without jeopardizing growth, which could lead to a small positive for US Treasuries. The US dollar is expected to edge lower against most Group of 10 peers.

images.alt_text: stock, business, finance
Biden says he doesn’t foresee any sticking points that can derail the agreement.
Unemployment is at its lowest in more than a half-century, at 3.4 per cent, thanks to historically high demand for workers.

site_title: Golden Energy’s delisting: IFA opinion is faulty
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) is set to hold a shareholder vote on its delisting proposal on June 9. However, the independent financial adviser (IFA) W Capital Markets has deemed the deal "fair and reasonable", despite valuing Gear's stake in Indonesia-listed Gems at below market price. The IFA's valuation range for Gear shares is between S$0.748 and S$0.964, but the exit offer price of S$0.181 per share falls at the top of this range. SGX should ask Gear's IFA to conduct a "reality check" on its opinion, examining if the exit offer is fair and reasonable on a standalone basis.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Excavators at work in Golden Energy and Resources' BIB mine in South Kalimantan.
SGX should devise a strategy to manage companies that attempt to slip away from the public market without properly compensating minority investors
Gear has rationalised its break-up and privatisation with an ESG narrative
Sias' questions about Golden Palm Resources' privatisation offer have triggered queries by SGX.

site_title: Lured by high standards and lower fees, Chinese students flock to Thailand’s international schools
summary: Chinese students are flocking to Thailand's international schools due to the country's high standards and lower tuition fees compared to other popular destinations like Singapore and Hong Kong. Wellington College International School in Bangkok is seeing a growing interest from Chinese students, with industry players citing Thailand's abundance of quality medical facilities and luxury condos as additional attractions. The influx of Chinese students is expected to boost Thailand's economy, particularly in the education sector.

images.alt_text: Thailand has seen foreign investment applications more than double to 155.3 billion baht (S$6.1 billion) in the three months through March from a year ago, led by companies from South Korea, Singapore, and China, according to the nation's Board of Investment.
The Thai economy grew faster than expected in the first quarter, driven by the continued pickup in the travel sector, a key source of jobs that was decimated by the pandemic.
Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat  waves to his supporters during a victory parade in Bangkok on May 15, 2023.

site_title: Gold prices dip on US debt ceiling deal, Fed rate-hike bets
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.3% to $1,941.45 per ounce on Monday, near two-month lows, amid a tentative US debt ceiling deal and rising interest rate expectations. The deal to suspend the US debt ceiling until January 2025, combined with higher interest rate bets, made gold less appealing to investors. The dollar edged up 0.1%, making bullion more expensive for holders of other currencies, while US consumer spending data showed a stronger-than-expected increase in April, boosting the economy's growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Adding pressure on gold, official data showed new US jobless claims rose moderately last week, indicating persistent labour market strength.

site_title: Thai baht under more pressure as political uncertainty persists
summary: The Thai baht weakened for its third straight week against the dollar, closing at 34.77 on Friday, and is expected to reach a new low. Political uncertainty, with hurdles to the Move Forward party coalition, is weighing on the currency, causing foreign funds to sell Thai equities and bonds. The Bank of Thailand's interest rate decision on May 31 is unlikely to halt the decline, with analysts expecting a 25 basis point rate hike. China's economic data and the yuan's performance also pose risks to the baht, which is sensitive to large moves in the yuan.

images.alt_text: CP All, which operates Thailand's largest convenience store chain through the 7-Eleven brand, is a popular "buy" option according to a Bloomberg poll of analysts.
Thai government expects the number of Chinese visitors to meet its target of 5 million this year, with spending of 446 billion baht.

site_title: PM Lee no longer Covid-19 positive, will return to work on Monday
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong tested positive for Covid-19 on May 22 after a string of work trips to South Africa and Kenya. He announced on Facebook that he has since tested negative and will return to work on Monday. This marks the first time he contracted the coronavirus.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said he tested positive for Covid-19 after recent work trips.

site_title: Erdogan seals election victory in Turkey to defy naysayers
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan secured a landslide victory in the presidential election, winning 52.1% of the vote against challenger Kemal Kilicdaroglu. Erdogan's win extends his rule into a third decade, raising concerns about his economic policy and foreign relations, particularly with Western governments. Analysts predict interest rates will rise to combat inflation, and Erdogan may stick to his low-interest rate policy despite criticism. The outcome also means Turkey will likely continue to assert its independence in global affairs, including its stance on Ukraine and its relations with Russia.

images.alt_text: Artificial intelligence has bucked a global decline in venture capital funding for tech startups since OpenAI released its ChatGPT bot last year, leading to a flood of interest in the disruptive technology.
Supporters of Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and AK Party (AKP) wave flags at the AK Party headquarters in Ankara, Turkey, May 14, 2023.

site_title: Why a US debt deal may only provide short-term relief for markets
summary: A tentative US debt ceiling deal reached between President Joe Biden and congressional leader Kevin McCarthy may provide short-term relief for financial markets, but its impact is expected to be fleeting. The deal is likely to be followed by a large issuance of new Treasury bills, which could deplete banks' reserves and accelerate deposit outflows, putting pressure on liquidity and pushing up interest rates. This could exacerbate existing market volatility and make funding more expensive for companies already struggling under high interest rates.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden, right, and US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy have reached a deal to raise the country's debt ceiling, averting a potential default by the world's largest economy.

site_title: Market players demanding changes to sustainability-linked bonds: abrdn
summary: Debt market participants are questioning the structure of sustainability-linked bonds (SLBs), citing concerns over the way performance targets are enforced and proceeds are used. Critics argue that SLBs can reward underperforming borrowers, creating an ethical dilemma for investors. Some SLBs now require issuers to purchase carbon offsets instead of paying higher interest rates, increasing the financing cost for underperforming borrowers. Market players are also examining the size of step-up penalties and the ambition of targets, with some calling for more significant increases in interest rates.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
As we look deeper into the dynamics of Indonesia’s electric two-wheeler market, it’s impossible to overlook the vital role that regulators play in shaping its trajectory.
OCBC is in a good position to capture wealth and trade flows given its strong links between the greater China and Asean regions, said CEO Helen Wong.
While there has been a retreat from ESG funds by public capital, private capital is still going full steam ahead.
While growth and scale still lie abroad for Singapore's e-waste recycling sector, there is guarded optimism that the scene could yet blossom on the back of a greening economy.

site_title: Oil climbs after US leaders strike provisional debt deal
summary: US leaders have reached a tentative debt ceiling deal, potentially averting a default in the world's largest economy and oil consumer. Oil prices rose as a result, with Brent crude futures climbing 39 cents to $77.34 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 45 cents to $73.12 a barrel. The deal, agreed upon by President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, is expected to be supported by both Democratic and Republican parties. This may lead to increased oil prices, which were already on the rise due to global demand and supply concerns.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Climate protesters raise their fist as scuffles between police and protesters broke out with the use of tear gas during a demonstration on the outskirts of the Paris venue for TotalEnergies Annual General Meeting in Paris on May 26, 2023. The French oil and gas giant is gearing up for an electric meeting, targeted by a coalition of associations threatening to block it, but also by some of its shareholders who disagree with its climate policy. (Photo by Geoffroy Van der Hasselt / AFP)
Many governments are pushing for renewables in an effort to tackle climate change and calling for reduced gas use.
Brent crude settled 69 cents, or 0.9 per cent, higher at US$76.95 a barrel on Friday.

site_title:
US dollar set for third week of gains 
as country’s debt talks loom large
summary: The US dollar is expected to gain for a third consecutive week as investors anticipate the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates higher to combat inflation. Last-ditch talks on the US debt ceiling, led by President Biden and Kevin McCarthy, are nearing a deal, but "major issues" remain unresolved. The US dollar index rose 0.038% on Friday, while the euro and sterling also saw gains, as investors await clarity on inflation and interest rates.

site_title: Rolls-Royce may cut thousands of jobs in turnaround plan
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings may cut thousands of jobs as part of its turnaround plan. The company hired consultants to streamline operations, potentially eliminating 10% of around 30,000 non-manufacturing jobs. The headquarters in Derby, with most back-office administration functions, are likely to be hit hardest. Rolls-Royce has not made a decision on the workforce impact, with CEO Tufan Erginbilgic initiating a transformation programme and key management changes. The move comes amid a struggling global aviation industry due to spare parts and skilled labour shortages.

site_title: Boeing works to win another Saudi deal, this time for 737 Max
summary: Boeing is in talks to sell at least 150 of its 737 Max jetliners to Saudi startup Riyadh Air, as part of a potential order of 300-400 single-aisle jets. This deal would follow Boeing's earlier agreement with Saudi Arabian carrier Saudia for 787 Dreamliners. Negotiations are ongoing, with a possible announcement at the Paris Air Show in mid-June, and Airbus may also claim a portion of the order due to limited delivery slots for its A321neo jets.

images.alt_text: The plane maker is keeping its 2023 free cash flow forecast of US$3 billion to US$5 billion, said its chief financial officer Brian West.
FILE PHOTO: Boeing Co's logo is seen above the front doors of its largest jetliner factory in Everett, Washington, U.S. January 13, 2017. REUTERS/Alwyn Scott/File Photo

site_title: Luton complete fairytale rise to Premier League riches
summary: Luton completed a fairytale journey to the Premier League, beating Coventry 6-5 in a penalty shootout after the match ended 1-1 after 120 minutes in the Championship playoff final. The club's promotion is estimated to be worth around £170 million, with funds likely to be used to upgrade their stadium, Kenilworth Road. The team's captain, Tom Lockyer, suffered an early injury, but Luton's players showed poise under pressure to secure their fourth promotion in 10 seasons.

site_title: Fewer full-time platform drivers on Singapore’s roads as employee jobs beckon
summary: Singapore's ride-hailing industry is experiencing a decline in full-time private-hire drivers, with the number of drivers on the road not keeping pace with demand. Major platform companies Gojek and Grab report 30,800 full-time drivers in 2022, down from 34,400 in 2020. The industry is using data analytics to direct riders and drivers to more popular areas and offering referral programs to woo workers. Experts attribute the decline to a tight labor market and the increasing attractiveness of employee jobs, with 12.6% of resident workers moving to full-time jobs in 2022.

images.alt_text: This is part of Singapore’s move to provide platform workers with employee-like protections.

Low-wage platform workers to get 75%

DHL Express Singapore's electric vans

site_title: Nvidia CEO says those without AI expertise will be left behind
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang warns that companies without artificial intelligence (AI) expertise will be left behind, while agile companies will take advantage of the technology to boost their positions. AI will transform the corporate landscape, changing every job, and create new jobs while making others obsolete. Huang urges individuals to familiarize themselves with AI or risk losing out, comparing those who adapt to those who are left behind, saying "Either you are running for food, or you are running from becoming food."

site_title: It’s getting harder to insure your property if you live in California
summary: State Farm, a major US insurer, has stopped accepting new applications for property and casualty coverage in California due to growing "catastrophe exposure" and increased construction costs. The decision affects both business and personal applications, but not auto insurance. California residents face worsening wildfire risks exacerbated by climate change, with 985 wildland fire incident responses and nearly 20,000 other fire responses since 2023. This move puts residents vulnerable to fires in a financial bind, as insurers have increasingly resorted to non-renewals, with 13% of homeowners' policies not renewed in 2021.

images.alt_text: A home for sale near Emerald Bay in Lake Tahoe, California. Photographer: Nina Riggio/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore housing agents reap bumper commissions in 2022 even as sales volume slows
summary: Singaporean real estate agents enjoyed a strong year in 2022, with a median monthly commission of S$5,000 despite slower sales volume. Agents earned higher commissions on luxury sales, with some surpassing past housing market peaks. The transaction value of new sales totaled S$17.6 billion, with agents earning an average commission of S$386.3 million. However, the market is expected to slow further due to government measures to cool prices and moderating demand, posing a challenge for agents' earnings.

images.alt_text: It is now taking a longer time to clinch a deal – from less than a month in 2021 and 2022, to around four to six weeks in the current market, said ERA marketing director Joel Kwok.
Maybe more help can be extended on the homeownership front to local couples who bust the income ceiling to buy BTO flats.
An artist's impression of Klimt Cairnhill, one of eight condominiums observed to have offered discounts in recent months.
Rents for the mid and mass market segments may soon plateau and there exists an increasing likelihood that they may soften in H2 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong treads fine line on regulating retail crypto trade
summary: Hong Kong is introducing new rules to regulate retail crypto trading, allowing investors to buy popular cryptocurrencies at government-licensed exchanges. The move aims to bolster the city's standing as a digital asset hub despite the current "crypto winter" caused by high-profile failures in global markets. The new laws for crypto exchanges began on June 1, and Hong Kong's voluntary licensing system for crypto trading platforms has been in place since 2019. The city's pivot towards the sector began in October, and it is expected to attract more investors despite the current market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Advertisements for crypto exchange show a Bitcoin symbol at Mass Transit Railway (MTR) station, in Hong Kong, China. October 27, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: US review of China tariffs won’t depend on trade ‘breakthrough’: Deputy USTR
summary: The US is reviewing tariffs on Chinese goods without assuming a "breakthrough" in US-China trade relations, according to Deputy US Trade Representative Sarah Bianchi. The review will focus on what's economically sound, consulting with agencies and studying industry comments. Tariffs currently range from 7.5% to 25% on various goods, including vehicles and electronics. The review is expected to conclude by the end of 2023, with some experts speculating that the expiration of tariff exclusions on September 30 could be a decision point.

site_title: Republicans criticise McCarthy, Biden debt ceiling deal
summary: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy's debt ceiling deal with President Biden faces opposition from hardline Republicans, who threaten to block its passage in the House. The deal suspends the federal debt ceiling until January 2025, in exchange for spending cuts and caps on government programs. Moderates from both parties will need to support the bill, as far-left and far-right wings of each party will likely oppose it. A failure to reach a deal by June 5 could trigger a default, causing financial market instability and a recession.

images.alt_text: The deal still faces a difficult path to pass through Congress before the government runs out of money to pay its debts in early June.
US President Joe Biden, right, and US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy have reached a deal to raise the country's debt ceiling, averting a potential default by the world's largest economy.

site_title: Green skills’ training in Singapore burgeons in popularity
summary: In Singapore, the demand for green skills is growing, driven by efforts to transition to sustainable economic models. The need for skills in areas like sustainable investment, carbon management, and green facilities management is increasing, with a 2,300% growth in demand for green facilities management between 2018 and 2021. To meet this demand, numerous training courses and programs are being offered by institutions such as Coursera, Asia Sustainable Finance Initiative, and Enterprise Singapore, with over 250 green-related courses available in transferable skills. However, choosing the right course remains a challenge, with some participants expressing dissatisfaction with the quality and relevance of existing courses.

images.alt_text: The greatest unmet need is in agriculture and forestry at 11 million jobs, says a WEF study, with other key sectors including infrastructure at 480,000 jobs, government at 160,000 and energy at 50,000.
Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience
Women are key economic actors. As business leaders, investors, employees and customers, they play a vital role in shaping the way that markets and societies behave.

site_title: Nikkei 225 rally hits resistance level
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 Stock Average reached levels unseen since 1990, gaining over 6% in May 2023, driven by corporate governance reforms, loose monetary policy, and a strengthening US dollar. Foreign investors bought Japanese equities for the sixth straight week, with exporter and electronics maker shares leading the gains. However, the index faces resistance near 30,700 and may pare gains due to US debt-ceiling negotiations and rising volatility.

site_title: UK government to ask supermarkets to cap prices of basic food items
summary: The UK government is reportedly considering plans to cap prices of basic food items such as bread and milk, following a 19% increase in food prices over the past year. The proposal is similar to a deal in France where major retailers charge the "lowest possible amount." However, the British Retail Consortium has urged the government to simplify rules rather than introduce price controls, which they claim will not make a difference to prices. The government's health minister, Steve Barclay, expressed uncertainty about the plan, and the Prime Minister's Office declined to comment.

images.alt_text: Consumers are doing everything they can to curb the impact of sky-high inflation, shopping at discount grocers and buying supermarkets’ own-brand goods.

site_title: Indonesia seeks US$700 million to install 200 MW of solar power
summary: Indonesian state utility Perusahaan Listrik Negara (PLN) is seeking a $700 million investment to install a 200 MW solar panel, replacing diesel power generators to reduce carbon emissions. The plan is part of its goal to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2060, with a target of installing 4.68 GW of solar panels between 2021 and 2030.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The tanker and dry bulk market saw downward pressure, with capesize rates declining 20% to $13,956. The Panamax market also struggled, with owners resisting tonnage and ballaster tonnage. Ultramax and Supramax markets were poor, with little fresh cargo and tonnage availability growing steadily. MEG LR2's rebounded, with TC20 voyage rates improving to $4,100,000. MR's improved consistently, with USG MR's driven by a surge in enquiry. Handymax and VLCC markets were softer, while LNG rates fluctuated with BLNG1g Aus-Japan finishing at $37,370. LPG rates rose, with TCE earnings improving to $92,653.

images.alt_text: It proved to be another negative week for the Panamaxes with no sign of the recent softening trend abating, with little momentum from week beginning and disrupted somewhat by many holidays towards the latter part of the week.

site_title: Ronaldo ends disappointing debut season in Saudi empty-handed
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo's Saudi Arabian club Al-Nassr failed to win a trophy despite signing him in January for a record-breaking deal. Ronaldo scored 14 goals in 16 league games but Al-Ittihad clinched the league title with one match to spare, ending Ronaldo's hopes of silverware. Ronaldo's departure from Manchester United last year was marred by controversy, and his performance with Al-Nassr was also affected by team dynamics and coaching changes.

site_title: Pound’s rally is at risk given sticky UK inflation, BlueBay says
summary: The British pound's rally is at risk due to sticky UK inflation, according to BlueBay Asset Management. Sterling has been one of the best-performing Group-of-10 currencies this year, recovering from a record low near parity against the US dollar in September. However, the recent hotter-than-expected inflation data has reignited concerns of stagflation, potentially reversing the pound's upward trend and causing yields to return towards levels seen in October.

site_title: World’s richest man throws in towel on Beverly Hills hotel
summary: Bernard Arnault, the world's richest man, will scrap plans to build an ultra-luxury boutique hotel and private members' club in Beverly Hills after voters rejected the project with 50.9% of the vote. The hotel project was expected to generate $800 million in taxes over 30 years, but critics argued it would obstruct views and contribute to traffic congestion. The final results will be certified on June 2, and Arnault has stated that if the project is rejected, he will not bring it back in any form.

site_title: Gas price plunge brings relief to Europe after energy panic
summary: European gas prices have plummeted to their lowest since mid-2021, providing relief to consumers and undermining Russia's ability to squeeze supplies. The slump is attributed to increased LNG imports, reduced energy consumption, and a relatively mild winter. Benchmark Dutch futures have fallen for eight straight weeks, and stockpiles are above average, potentially even filled during the summer. This drop in prices is expected to ease household budgets and inflation, but underlying measures of inflation remain sticky, and the crisis has had a lasting impact on European industries.

images.alt_text: The new price level will be below the UK’s Energy Price Guarantee, a government subsidy that kicks in if rates rise above a certain threshold.

site_title: France in ‘close talks’ over S&P debt rating
summary: France is in "very close talks" with debt rating agency Standard and Poor's after a downgrade from rival Fitch raised concerns over the country's finances. France's debt reached almost 112% of annual output by the end of last year, driven by a response to the coronavirus crisis and support to households and businesses. Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne assured that the government is taking steps to reduce its deficit and bring debt levels down to 108% of GDP in the coming five years.

images.alt_text: “The French ship is resisting in rough weather and is even a little more solid than expected,” Bank of France governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau said.

site_title: Reid Hoffman is on a mission: to show AI can improve humanity
summary: Reid Hoffman, a billionaire entrepreneur, is promoting the benefits of artificial intelligence (AI) to counter growing concerns about its risks. He believes AI can improve humanity and has been actively engaging in thought leadership, speaking to government officials, and publishing a book to nudge the discussion towards a more positive view. Hoffman, who sits on the boards of 11 tech companies, including Microsoft, which has invested heavily in AI, argues that warnings about AI's existential risk overstate its capabilities and that solutions to its problems live in the future, not by enshrining the past.

images.alt_text: Will AI one day produce entirely new goods and services that will outcompete the human desire to please and interact with other people?
OpenAI, backed by US$10 billion from Microsoft, has been leading the call for regulation of AI.
Tools for Humanity co-founder and CEO Alex Blania (left) with OpenAI chief executive officer Sam Altman.

site_title: Modi inaugurates new parliament building as part of New Delhi’s makeover
summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurated India's new parliament building as part of a $2.4 billion project to modernize New Delhi's architecture. The inauguration comes ahead of parliamentary elections, where Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party will emphasize its Hindu nationalist credentials. The event was boycotted by 20 opposition parties, who claimed Modi had violated protocol. The new complex features 1,272 seats and more space for lawmakers, and the old building will be converted into a museum.

images.alt_text: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi carries a sengol as Speaker of the Lok Sabha Om Birla looks on during the inauguration of new Parliament building in New Delhi, India, May 28, 2023. site_title: Thailand says 1 million Chinese tourists visited from January to mid-May
summary: Thailand welcomed 1 million Chinese tourists between January and mid-May, exceeding expectations and reaching the government's target of 5 million this year, with estimated spending of 446 billion baht. This marks a significant increase from the 274,000 Chinese visitors in 2022 and 28% of the total foreign tourist arrivals of 9.47 million. The tourism sector's growth has contributed to Thailand's economy, driven by the border reopening with China.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tourists from mainland China dressed in traditional Thai costumes visit Wat Arun temple ahead of the Chinese Lunar New Year as China reopens the border in Bangkok, Thailand January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust substantial unitholder sues lead independent director, seeks his removal from board
summary: Zhang Zhencheng, a substantial unitholder of Dasin Retail Trust, is suing lead independent director Tan Huay Lim, alleging his conduct is "oppressive" and "in disregard" to Zhang's interests. Zhang seeks Tan's removal from the board, restraint from involvement in refinancing discussions, and termination of FTI Consulting's services. The trustee-manager intends to contest the claim, and Tan also plans to do so. The majority of the board views the dispute as "sub-judice" and under court determination.

Sino-Ocean Capital, an indirect stakeholder in both Dasin Retail Trust and its trustee-manager, is facing a winding-up petition in Hong Kong.

site_title: Trust is important if you want to succeed at work – here’s how to build it
summary: Trust is crucial for success in the workplace, enabling collaboration, reliability, and accountability. Key drivers of trustworthiness include integrity, character, and empathy. Green flags for trust include active listening, willingness to share, respectful communication, and follow-through on commitments. Conversely, common reasons for distrust include unmet expectations, lack of transparency, and weak communication. To build trust, prioritize good communication, be empathetic, and demonstrate consistency and accountability. Rebuilding trust after it's been broken can be more challenging, but by following these principles, individuals and organizations can foster a culture of trust.

images.alt_text: Female TED speakers who used more humour were more popular and perceived as more influential than less funny women and comparably funny men.

People who get stuck in a cycle of self-sabotage possess the promise of a bright future but ultimately hinder their own ability to thrive.

site_title: Here’s why buying a chunk of America can be an inflation hedge
summary: Farmland is emerging as a potential hedge against inflation, with its returns often outperforming gold and other mainstream asset classes. According to Carter Malloy, founder of AcreTrader, farmland tends to be more inflation-linked and has a low correlation to other asset classes, making it an attractive diversifier. Investors can expect a slow and steady compounding of capital, with consistent low-double-digit returns of 11-12% over long periods. The lack of volatility and risk-adjusted returns make farmland an attractive option for those seeking stability and diversification.

The administration of US President Joe Biden is trying to turn the tide toward renewable energy. site_title: Biden says ‘hopeful’ on US debt deal within hours
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed hope for a resolution to the debt ceiling standoff within hours, saying he is "hopeful" of a deal. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that the deadline extension to June 5 does not change the urgency of the situation, which could lead to a default and recession. A deal is reportedly taking shape, with an agreement to extend the government's borrowing authority for two years, but Democrats would need to offer concessions on Republican spending limits.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s announcement allows a little more time for Democratic President Joe Biden and Republican House of Representatives Speaker Kevin McCarthy to reach an accord to raise the federal government’s self-imposed borrowing limit.

US President Joe Biden has previously pulled major legislative rabbits out of the hat in his two years as president – and then too he adopted his largely behind-the-scenes role. So he may yet have the last laugh.
Brent crude settled 69 cents, or 0.9 per cent, higher at US$76.95 a barrel on Friday.

Under the terms of the emerging agreement, defence spending would be permitted to rise 3 per cent next year in line with Biden’s budget request.

site_title: Italy still mulling whether to pull out of China pact: PM Meloni
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has yet to decide whether to pull out of China's Belt and Road programme, a decision that affects multiple interests. Meloni stated that Italy can maintain "good relations" with China without being part of a strategic plan, and the country's government will make a final decision by December 22. Italy is the only G7 country to have joined the programme, which has funded $900 billion in infrastructure projects globally. The decision comes as Europe recalibrates its relationship with China, seeking to reduce dependencies on the authoritarian country.

site_title: Taipei restaurant dishes up giant isopod noodles for adventurous patrons
summary: A Taiwanese ramen restaurant, "The Ramen Boy", has introduced a limited-edition dish featuring a 14-legged giant isopod, which is steamed for 10 minutes and served on top of a bowl of noodles. Over 100 people have joined a waiting list to dine at the restaurant, with some customers praising the unique flavor, likening it to a cross between crab and lobster. However, scholars have expressed concerns over the potential ecological impact and health risks associated with consuming the largely unknown species, which may contain toxins or heavy metals.

site_title: Amazon scientists simulate how warming may impact jungle
summary: Amazon scientists are simulating the impact of global warming on the world's largest rainforest, the Amazon, through the AmazonFACE project. An open-air structure in Brazil will pump CO2 into a ring of 16 metal towers, replicating climate change scenarios. Researchers will analyze processes in leaves, roots, soil, water, and nutrient cycles over a decade. The project aims to understand how the Amazon will behave under rising temperatures and CO2 levels, which may lead to the creation of grassy plains or temporary resistance to changes.

images.alt_text: Many of the firms who quit the insurers alliance remain members of the Net Zero Asset Owner Alliance, including Allianz.
Many governments are pushing for renewables in an effort to tackle climate change and calling for reduced gas use.
At least seven members of the Net-Zero Insurance Alliance (Nzia), which launched in 2021, have now left including five of the eight founding signatories.
G7 leaders at the Itsukushima Shrine during the G7 summit in Hiroshima, Japan, on May 19, 2023.

Installation of solar panels atop a roof in Los Angeles, California. A record of more than US$1.7 trillion will be invested in clean-energy technologies this year, compared about US$1 trillion going into fossil fuel supplies and power production.

site_title: AcroMeta eyes booming co-working lab scene
summary: AcroMeta, a specialist engineering firm, is expanding its coworking laboratory space, the Life Science Incubator (LSI), which has seen around 30 companies rent lab space since its launch in 2021. The facility offers state-of-the-art equipment and provides a 60-80% occupancy rate. AcroMeta aims to grow its coworking lab business in parallel with its engineering operations, with plans to open a second facility by Q1 2024 and explore opportunities in Japan, China, and Australia. The company's revenue from coworking labs is expected to contribute to its growth, alongside its existing engineering projects.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Companies like Moderna are examples of  investments in companies that can build their solutions around long-term trends and enduring behaviours.
Under a cost-sharing agreement, companies share the costs and risks of qualifying R&D activities, while claiming tax deductions on the proportionate amount spent.
Employers that can develop strategies to manage the risks that come along with remote work can harness the shift to its full potential.

site_title: Mapletree S-Reits see strong performance amid active acquisitions
summary: Mapletree S-Reits, including Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT), Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT), and Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT), reported strong full-year results for FY22/23. MPACT saw the strongest growth, with 65.4% increase in gross revenue and 62.6% increase in net property income. Vivocity's tenant sales improved 30.6% yoy, exceeding S$1 billion, setting a new record. MLT's gross revenue and NPI grew 7.7% and 7.2% yoy, respectively, while MIT reported a 12.3% gross revenue growth and 9.7% NPI growth.

images.alt_text: Earlier last week, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit (Clar) announced the proposed acquisition of an integrated high-specification R&D facility and business park property from Seagate Singapore International Headquarters for a purchase consideration of S$218.2 million.

site_title: A once reliable trade is becoming so popular that it may be falling apart
summary: A hedge fund strategy that exploits the index effect, buying stocks entering major indices and selling those exiting them, is losing effectiveness due to its popularity. The strategy, which has been successful for Emmanuel Terraz's Candriam Index Arbitrage fund, has become overused by other investors, including Millennium Management and Man Group. As a result, the fund posted its worst-ever performance in 2022. The strategy's reliance on passive funds' predictable buying and selling patterns is becoming unsustainable, causing it to "fall apart."

site_title: Nearly 3,000 flats in Tengah to be offered at May 30 BTO launch
summary: Nearly 3,000 Build-To-Order flats, including 2,000 units in Parc Meadow @ Tengah and 970 units in Plantation Verge, will be launched for sale in Tengah on May 30, with a waiting time of less than four years. The flats range from two-room flexi to five-room units and will be available with significant market discounts and housing grants. This launch brings the total number of flats released in Tengah since 2018 to over 21,000, covering 70% of the planned 30,000 flats for Singapore's newest town.

site_title: Most Thais concerned about new government formation after election: survey
summary: Most Thais are concerned about the formation of a new government after Thailand's recent election, with 67.8% of voters expressing worry that the Move Forward Party's leader, Pita Limjaroenrat, may not become prime minister. The party needs backing from senators to bypass the 250-member military-appointed Senate. A majority of respondents (58.3%) are not confident that the new government's formation will be smooth, while 32.2% are optimistic that Move Forward can form a new government. The uncertainty has raised concerns about the nation's political stability and potential impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: tiktok Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Asiana stops selling some emergency exit seats after plane door incident
summary: Asiana Airlines has stopped selling emergency exit seats on its A321-200 jets following an incident where a passenger manually opened an aircraft door mid-air. The passenger, Lee, was arrested for allegedly breaking aviation security laws and faces up to 10 years in prison. The airline will no longer offer 31A and 26A seats for sale, even if flights are full, as a safety precaution. The incident occurred on a plane carrying nearly 200 passengers, resulting in hospitalizations but no serious injuries or damage.

images.alt_text: South Korean police arrest a man suspected of opening a door during an Asiana Airlines flight, Daegu, South Korea, May 26, 2023.

site_title: US jobs report is set to provide some solace to the Fed
summary: The US jobs report, set to be released on Friday, is expected to show payrolls increasing by less than 200,000 in May, down from 370,000 over the past year. This moderation in hiring and hourly earnings growth may provide some relief to the Federal Reserve as it aims to control inflation. The data will also shed light on the impact of tighter credit conditions and higher interest rates on the economy. The Fed's policymakers will use this data to inform their decision on whether to raise interest rates again, with a meeting scheduled for June 13-14.

site_title: Canada’s 2022-23 fiscal year budget deficit shrinks to C$41.31 billion
summary: Canada's 2022-23 fiscal year budget deficit decreased to C$41.31 billion, a 57% reduction from the previous year. Revenues rose 8.6% due to economic growth and the waning impact of COVID-19, while programme expenses fell 6.5% due to lower transfers to individuals and businesses. This marks a post-pandemic economic rebound.

site_title: Man who opened Asiana plane door says he wanted out ‘quickly’
summary: A man in his 30s opened an emergency exit door on an Asiana Airlines flight in mid-air, feeling "suffocated" and wanting to exit quickly. The plane, carrying nearly 200 passengers, was approaching the runway at Daegu International Airport in South Korea on a domestic flight. Authorities arrested the suspect, but did not release further details about his identity or motive. The incident occurred about 200 meters above ground, and the plane's safety was not compromised, according to reports.

images.alt_text: epa10654708 The police arrest a man in his 30s at Daegu International Airport, 237 kilometers southeast of Seoul, South Korea, 26 May 2023, as he is suspected of opening a door on an Asiana Airlines plane.  The door suddenly opened in mid-air at 12:45 p.m., just before landing at the airport. The plane carrying 194 passengers landed safely, but some panicked passengers showed symptoms of breathing difficulties and were immediately taken to a hospital. According to an Asiana official, a passenger sitting near the exit said he touched the door lever.  EPA-EFE/YONHAP SOUTH KOREA OUT

site_title: The Reserve Residences sells 520 units, or 71% of project, at average S$2,460 psf
summary: FAR East Organization sold 520 units of The Reserve Residences in Upper Bukit Timah at an average price of S$2,460 psf, representing 71% of the project's total units. The 99-year-leasehold project, developed jointly with Sino Group, saw 635 units released for the launch, with the highest transacted unit selling for S$2,790 psf.

site_title: Gazelle Ventures seeks refund of funds provided to No Signboard Holdings
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a troubled restaurant operator, has received a demand for a refund of funds from investor Gazelle Ventures. The demand comes despite an implementation agreement signed in June setting out terms for a S$5 million investment. The investor is concerned about the risks of leaving funds with No Signboard due to ongoing disputes with a controlling shareholder, Gugong. No Signboard is in discussions with the investor and will provide updates on the request for refund.

Expediting the completion of the proposed investment will allow the company to utilise the full investment amount to settle its liabilities upon completion to meet its working capital requirements for the next 18 months, said the company.

site_title: ISS backs Toyota shareholder proposal on climate disclosure
summary: ISS recommends Toyota shareholders vote in favor of a resolution urging the automaker to improve disclosure of its climate change lobbying activities. The proposal, backed by green investors and climate activists, aims to ensure Toyota provides information about its lobbying efforts, particularly in regions where it operates. Toyota's board has urged shareholders to vote against the proposal, citing the fluidity of such disclosure. The resolution requires a two-thirds majority, but ISS argues that shareholders would benefit from the transparency, while Glass Lewis has not backed the resolution, citing Toyota's responsiveness to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Glass Lewis made the recommendation against Toyota's chairman Akio Toyoda (above) at a time when board independence has been under greater scrutiny from investors.

site_title: Oil prices rise as US closes in on debt deal
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday as US officials appeared close to striking a debt-ceiling deal, with Brent crude settling 69 cents higher at $76.95 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate up 84 cents at $72.67 a barrel. Markets remain cautious due to ongoing debt talks and concerns about a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike, despite possible negotiators reaching a deal on the US government's $31.4 trillion debt ceiling.

images.alt_text: Petronas has cooperated fully with the commission in the investigation involving a project worth RM399 million in the state of Sarawak, the MACC says
Crude has still sunk about 10 per cent this year as the lackluster economic recovery in top importer China and an aggressive monetary tightening campaign by the Federal Reserve pressured prices.

site_title: BA cancels dozens of Heathrow flights before long weekend
summary: British Airways cancelled dozens of flights at Heathrow airport ahead of the long weekend due to a technical issue. The cancellations affected 175 flights over two days, leaving thousands of travelers impacted. The airline attributed the issue to a "knock-on effect" from a technical problem experienced on Thursday. Heathrow airport also warned of potential disruptions due to a security guards strike at Terminal 5 this weekend. The cancellations come as the UK prepares for a public holiday and half-term school holiday.

images.alt_text: “While the vast majority of our flights continue to operate today, we have cancelled some of our short-haul flights from Heathrow due to the knock-on effect of a technical issue that we experienced yesterday,” British Airways says.
Cathay, whose main shareholder is British conglomerate Swire Pacific with a 45 per cent stake, has been under heavy fire in recent years, from outside the company as well as within.

site_title: Twitter cannot hide from EU rules after exit from code, EU’s Breton says
summary: EU industry chief Thierry Breton warned Twitter that it cannot escape EU rules, despite quitting a voluntary code of practice to tackle disinformation. Twitter must still provide regular progress reports on disinformation and advertising revenue, and face fines of up to 6% of its global turnover for violations. The Digital Services Act, set to take effect on August 25, will make these obligations a legal requirement for the platform.

images.alt_text: Neuralink is developing a brain implant it hopes will help paralysed people walk again and cure other neurological ailments.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis remains in a pitched battle with Walt Disney over the company’s criticism of laws prohibiting the teaching of gender identity concepts in public schools.

A judge dismissed a proposed class-action lawsuit against Elon Musk that claimed he cheated Twitter shareholders several times last year in the course of buying the social media company for US$44 billion.
The app, which will be separate from Instagram but will allow people to connect accounts, may debut as soon as June.

site_title: German brewery has high hops for powdered beer
summary: A German brewery has developed a powdered beer made with two ingredients: powder and water. The non-alcoholic version has no bubbles, but the brewer plans to create an alcoholic version and add bubbles in the future. The product targets African and Asian countries due to its ease and cost-effectiveness in transportation. The powdered format reduces the carbon footprint and saves time, but German experts are skeptical about its success, citing concerns about the traditional purity law and the enjoyment of beer in social settings.

images.alt_text: Managing Director of the Neuzelle Kloster Brewery Stefan Fritsche uses a mini hand mixer to mix powdered beer with water at the brewery as he presents his newest product in Neuzelle, eastern Germany on April 20, 2023. With its golden hue, bittersweet notes and frothy head, Stefan Fritsche's latest brew looks and tastes like any other beer. But the revolutionary tipple, developed at Fritsche's brewery in the German town of Neuzelle, was made with just two ingredients: powder and water. "Everyone can have their own home brewery" with his new invention, Fritsche told AFP at the premises near the border with Poland. (Photo by John MACDOUGALL / AFP)

site_title: Initial takeaways from US spending and debt ceiling deal
summary: US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy reached a deal to raise the debt ceiling for two years, averting a potential default by the world's largest economy. The agreement would limit federal spending, protect defense and entitlement programs, and impose new work requirements on some recipients of government aid. Environmental permitting for major energy projects would be streamlined, but tax increases on the wealthy and corporations would not be included. The deal would not be finalized until legislative language is translated and approved by Congress.

site_title: US jury says Google owes Sonos US$32.5 million in smart-speaker patent case
summary: A US jury has ordered Google to pay Sonos $32.5 million in damages for infringing on one of Sonos' smart-speaker patents. The case is part of a larger intellectual property dispute between the two companies, which previously collaborated on devices like Google Home and Chromecast Audio. Sonos initially sought $90 million in damages, but the jury's verdict is a significant victory for the company, which has accused Google of copying its technology.

site_title: China’s holiday spending boom masks patchy recovery
summary: China's holiday spending surge during the Labour Day break masked a patchy economic recovery, with analysts warning of lingering weaknesses in manufacturing and real estate. Despite a 163% increase in domestic trips and a 129% surge in revenue, average per-trip spending was 10% lower than in 2019, driven by low-income tourists and short trips. Industrial production rose 5.6% in April, while fixed-asset investment slowed to 4.7%. The economy's growth is expected to slow, with policymakers unlikely to introduce major stimulus measures, instead focusing on supporting domestic demand and employment.

images.alt_text: US lawmaker warnings about China e-commerce fashion retailers such as Shein could signal upcoming regulatory action.
Automaker BYD showcases its intelligent body control system at its booth at the Shanghai auto show on April 24

site_title: This CEO wants to rent your empty desks: 5 minutes with Larry Gadea
summary: CEO Larry Gadea of San Francisco-based Envoy aims to revolutionize office management by creating a marketplace where companies can rent unused desks and meeting rooms. Using data from 9,000 clients, Gadea has created "heat maps" to identify the most occupied areas in offices, with plans to offer these spaces to companies that need them. The goal is to create a flexible and cost-effective solution, allowing companies to expand and contract to the exact space they need, potentially making traditional real-estate brokerages obsolete.

site_title: Palliative care – meeting the evolving needs of an ageing society
summary: By 2030, one in four Singaporeans will be 65 and above, making palliative care crucial in the ageing society. Integrating palliative care with primary care ensures continuous and coordinated care throughout a patient's condition. The Ministry of Health is scaling up palliative care capability and capacity, while providing better support for caregivers. CEO Bernie Poh of Allium Healthcare emphasizes the importance of palliative care in improving patients' quality of life and supporting families.

images.alt_text: Students from Metta School perform at Singapore Pools' 55th anniversary celebration, held at Gardens by the Bay with more than 350 people in attendance.

site_title: Biden’s low profile in debt crisis – failure or clever strategy?
summary: US President Joe Biden has been criticized for his low profile during the debt crisis, with some Democrats accusing him of failing to take action. However, Biden's strategy is seen by some as a deliberate attempt to let others, particularly Republican Speaker Kevin McCarthy, take the lead. Biden has been focusing on other issues, such as hosting basketball teams at the White House, and has even met with McCarthy in the Oval Office. Polls show voters blaming all sides for the crisis, and Biden's approach may ultimately prove effective, as he has a history of pulling off major legislative victories behind the scenes.

The broad-based S&P 500 rose 1.3 per cent to 4,205.45, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average posted a more modest 1.0 per cent gain to finish the week at 33,093.34.

site_title: IMF slightly lifts US 2023 growth forecast
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has slightly raised its forecast for US economic growth in 2023 to 1.7% from 1.6%, with growth expected to slow to 1.0% in 2024. The IMF also expects a small increase in unemployment to 4.4% by the end of 2024. The organization's managing director, Kristalina Georgieva, warned that the ongoing US borrowing limit stalemate could impact the global financial system, and urged lawmakers to reach a resolution. The IMF now expects inflation to remain above-target into 2025, requiring interest rates to be higher for longer to control inflation.

images.alt_text: Jeremy Hunt, UK chancellor of the exchequer, speaks during a news conference attended by IMF mission chief for the UK S. Ali Abbas, IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva and IMF communications director Julie Kozack, in London, UK, May 23, 2023.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore High Court granted a sale order for Chuan Park, a S$890 million en bloc collective sale, to entities related to developers Kingsford Group and MCC Singapore. The judge concluded that there is no evidence the deal was not arrived at in good faith by the collective sales committee.

site_title: Recent ringgit weakness due to global cues, not local economy: Malaysia central bank
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, attributes the recent weakness of the ringgit to global market developments, citing the US debt ceiling impasse and banking sector stress, rather than local economic factors. The ringgit has lost 4.3% this year, but is expected to improve as global uncertainties subside. The bank maintains its 2023 growth forecast of 4-5%.

site_title: US-led Indo-Pacific talks produce deal on supply chain early warnings
summary: The US-led Indo-Pacific Economic Framework (IPEF) has reached a deal with 14 countries to strengthen supply chain resilience and security. The agreement includes a council to coordinate supply chain activities, a crisis response network for early warnings, and a labour rights advisory board to raise standards. The deal also includes a regional hydrogen initiative to encourage the widespread deployment of low-carbon and renewable hydrogen. The agreement marks the first tangible results of the year-long negotiations and aims to provide countries with an alternative to closer ties with China.

site_title: UOB leads buybacks; PropNex’s Kelvin Fong adds to stake
summary: Institutions invested S$4 million in Singapore stocks from May 19 to 25, with a net inflow, following a previous S$270 million outflow. DBS, UOB, Singapore Airlines, Jardine Matheson Holdings, and ST Engineering led the institutional buying. Meanwhile, PropNex executive director Kelvin Fong increased his stake in the real estate group from 8.75% to 8.85%. The Straits Times Index rose 0.8%, while the Hang Seng Index and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI declined 4.6% and 3.2%, respectively.

images.alt_text: On May 16, Aztech Global executive chairman and CEO Michael Mun Hong Yew acquired 500,000 shares at S$0.70 per share.

site_title: South Africa eyes more corn exports to China after breakthrough
summary: South Africa is seeking to increase corn exports to China after a recent record-breaking export of 108,104 tonnes of yellow feed maize. The country's price edge over major global producers has helped it secure a share of China's huge grain market. With a bumper crop expected this year, South Africa aims to build on its exports and secure a constant relationship with China. The country has also signed a soybean export protocol with China, further expanding its market presence.

images.alt_text: The prospects of a near-term election could have delayed much-needed debate on how to fund PM Kishida's spending wish-list that included childcare – set to cost an extra annual 3 trillion yen.

site_title: Do ESG funds have higher ESG scores?
summary: Investors seeking ESG funds with higher ESG scores may be disappointed, as a study found that ESG indexes typically had only marginally higher ESG scores than their parent market indexes. Researchers manually calculated ESG scores for 20 ESG indexes, including the SPDR S&P 500 ESG ETF, and found that the ESG indexes had an average ESG uplift of 8.3% over the benchmark. However, the range of variation was wide, and some ESG indexes had even lower ESG scores. This suggests that investors may not be getting the higher ESG scores they expect for their higher fees.

images.alt_text: Clients had voiced concerns about “an upward drift in ratings across the fund universe,” which is now being addressed, according to MSCI ESG Research.
While the net flows in ESG funds domiciled in South-East Asia declined, quarterly returns for ESG funds improved with an average return of 4.2 per cent, compared with -6.9 per cent a year ago.

site_title: Apec trade chiefs agree on more inclusive trade, but no joint statement
summary: APEC trade chiefs agreed on promoting inclusive and sustainable trade, but failed to produce a joint statement due to Russia and China's objections to Ukraine-related language. US Trade Representative Katherine Tai issued a chair's statement emphasizing inclusiveness, climate change, and sustainability. The group reaffirmed its commitment to the multilateral trading system and a level playing field. Tai hopes APEC leaders can produce a joint statement at a future summit, highlighting the Biden administration's worker-centered trade policy vision.
