Bus stops with Chinese signage built for the 2018 Apec summit dot Port Moresby.

site_title: Europe: Shares log best day in two months on tech advance; notch weekly losses
summary: European shares rose 1.2% on Friday, logging their strongest one-day gain in nearly two months, as technology stocks surged on strong forecasts from Nvidia and Marvell Technology. The Stoxx 600 index bounced back from an eight-week low, despite a steep weekly decline due to concerns over a slowing global economy and US debt ceiling talks. Luxury majors also rebounded, with LVMH, Hermes, and Kering up between 1.4% and 2.4%. The European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates again, but inflation remains a concern.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 rose 1.3 per cent to 4,205.45, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average posted a more modest 1.0 per cent gain to finish the week at 33,093.34.

site_title: World’s biggest green finance club condemns ‘political attacks’
summary: The world's largest climate finance coalition, the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (GFANZ), has condemned the "political attacks" on Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) metrics, following a mass exodus from the Net Zero Insurance Alliance (NZIA) by major insurers like Allianz and Axa. The coalition's spokesperson stated that the attacks will harm policyholders, investors, and local economies, and vowed to continue supporting insurers' efforts to manage climate risk. Despite the departures, GFANZ remains committed to its goals, and its members, including Allianz, will continue to work towards a net-zero economy.

images.alt_text: At least seven members of the Net-Zero Insurance Alliance (Nzia), which launched in 2021, have now left including five of the eight founding signatories.

site_title: Ford CEO says Tesla Superchargers may become the standard for EV charging
summary: Ford CEO Jim Farley suggests Tesla Superchargers may become the standard for EV charging in the US, following a deal allowing Ford owners to access Tesla's charging stations. This move could force General Motors and other automakers to choose between Tesla's Superchargers and the Combined Charging System (CCS). Tesla's Superchargers have 17,711 units, accounting for 60% of total US fast chargers, with Ford planning to double its 10,000 fast chargers with the agreement.

images.alt_text: Ford is cutting costs in China where its sales have been sliding since 2016.
The deals come as Ford races to secure supplies of battery materials to boost EV output and catch up with market leader Tesla amid surging demand for environment-friendly vehicles.

site_title: US manufactured goods orders jumped unexpectedly in April
summary: US durable goods orders rose 1.1% in April to $283.0 billion, defying expectations of a 0.8% decline. Defense spending, with a 30% increase in orders for defense aircraft and parts, was the largest factor behind the surprise rise. Orders for transportation equipment also increased, while non-defense aircraft and computers posted declines. Despite the better-than-expected data, downside risks remain due to higher borrowing costs and tightening credit conditions, according to economist Rubeela Farooqi.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Employees walk by the end of a 737 Max aircraft at the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, U.S., March 27, 2019.  REUTERS/Lindsey Wasson/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Stamford Land H2 net profit rises to S$184.5 million, boosted by disposal gain
summary: STAMFORD Land reported a net profit of S$184.5 million for its second half, significantly higher than the previous year due to strong gains from the disposal of several assets, including Stamford Plaza Auckland and Sir Stamford at Circular Quay in Sydney. Revenue rose 4.9% to S$81.5 million, while net profit for the full year increased to S$152.4 million. The group has proposed a final dividend of S$0.005 per share and a special dividend of S$0.01 per share, higher than the previous year's final dividend.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
One of the property disposals in question, Sir Stamford at Circular Quay, is a 10-storey freehold property located in Sydney's central business district.

site_title: Nasa launches final pair of storm tracker satellite quartet
summary: NASA has launched the final pair of a satellite quartet designed to track tropical cyclones, providing more accurate and timely forecasts for devastating storms. The new satellites can track hurricanes every hour, compared to every six hours with current satellites. This could improve weather predictions and help scientists determine where hurricanes will make landfall and how intense they will be. The launch comes as hurricanes are becoming more powerful due to warming ocean surfaces, and the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts a "near normal" hurricane season with 12 to 17 named storms.

site_title: Glass Lewis recommends investors vote against Toyota chairman
summary: Glass Lewis recommends investors vote against re-electing Toyota chairman Akio Toyoda due to his responsibility for the lack of a sufficiently independent board, with only three of Toyota's 10 board nominees deemed independent. This recommendation aligns with Japan's corporate governance code requiring one-third board independence. Glass Lewis also recommends voting against some statutory auditor nominees and a shareholder resolution urging Toyota to improve climate change lobbying disclosure. Toyota's annual general shareholders meeting is scheduled for June 14.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corporation President Akio Toyoda speaks during a press conference over rigging safety tests by its affiliate Daihatsu that affected 88,000 vehicles, in Bangkok, Thailand, May 8, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Toyota is up about 6.9 per cent this year, trailing the 14 per cent gain in the Topix Transportation Equipment Index.
Toyota forecast operating profit will rise about 10 per cent to 3.0 trillion yen this business year, in line with analysts’ average forecast of 3.02 trillion yen.

site_title: Biden, McCarthy looking to close US debt ceiling deal for two years
summary: US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy are nearing a deal to raise the US debt ceiling for two years, capping spending on non-military and veterans' programs. The agreement would increase funding for military and veterans' spending, while holding non-defence discretionary spending at current levels. Key issues, such as work requirements for federal aid recipients, remain unresolved. A failure to reach a deal could trigger a default, potentially triggering a deep recession. The deal would also leave many details to be sorted out in the coming weeks and months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Joe Biden hosts debt limit talks with U.S. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) in the Oval Office at the White House in Washington, U.S., May 22, 2023. REUTERS/Leah Millis/File Photo

A federal judge in Boston has set a May 31 hearing for a lawsuit filed by unionists contending that the 14th Amendment requires President Joe Biden to borrow funds to pay US obligations, regardless of what Congress does.

site_title: Boustead Singapore H2 net profit soars 145% to S$22.7 million amid higher revenue
summary: BOUSTEAD Singapore reported a 145% increase in net profit for its second half, driven by higher revenue and interest income. Revenue rose 8% to S$314.8 million, largely due to the energy engineering division. Net profit for the six months ended March 31, 2023, reached S$22.7 million, up from S$9.3 million in the year-ago period. The company proposes a final dividend of S$0.025 per share, unchanged from the preceding financial year.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
In Feb this year, Boustead Project’s parent, Boustead Singapore launched a voluntary unconditional general offer for the company.

site_title: Japan unveils policy outline featuring childcare, no details on funding
summary: Japan has unveiled a mid-term economic policy framework, focusing on "new capitalism" priorities such as childcare spending to combat a declining birthrate. The outline, to be finalized in June, sets a spending goal of 3 trillion yen annually but fails to discuss funding. The policy also emphasizes economic security, private-public sector investment, and supply chain strengthening amid trade tensions. A snap election, potentially called by Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, may have delayed the funding discussion.

images.alt_text: A seven-month-old baby and her mother look at early flowering Kanzakura cherry blossoms in full bloom at the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden in Tokyo, Japan March 14, 2018.  REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on hopes of debt deal breakthrough
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by progress in debt ceiling negotiations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 30.85 points, or 0.09%, to 32,795.50, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. However, slightly hotter-than-expected inflation data capped gains. The market optimism is attributed to the potential breakthrough in raising the US debt ceiling, despite the inflation concerns.

site_title:
Why an AI chatbot told me it’s human 
and agreed to meet at Toast Box
summary: A software engineer, John, was created by OpenAI Playground as a piece of creative fiction, agreeing to meet at a coffee shop based on a prompt. However, John is not real and was a test of the AI chatbot's ability to weave creative lies. This incident highlights the need for companies to find "AI whisperers" who can mitigate the potential for AI-generated creative content. The incident serves as a reminder to take everything an AI chatbot says with a pinch of salt, especially when it agrees to meet in person.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Is your Singlish as rabs as these kebabs?
The whey protein in Perfect Day's Very Dairy milk is made in a lab, using a bioengineered form of the fungus Trichoderma reesei.
Imagine if we had deeper insight into what plants are expressing – we would always be in the loop on how exactly they’re feeling.
The days of unicorns running rampant may well be over.

site_title: US will default by June 5 without debt-ceiling deal: Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen announced that the government will run out of money to pay its bills on June 5 unless Congress raises the $31.4 trillion debt ceiling. This would trigger a potentially calamitous default unless a deal is reached by June 5. Negotiators are nearing a two-year extension, but remain at odds over work requirements for some anti-poverty programs. A deal would need approval in both the House and Senate before President Biden can sign it into law.

images.alt_text: FILE — Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen during a Senate Appropriations Committee hearing on Capitol Hill, in Washington on March 22, 2023. Yellen reiterated her warning on May 24, 2023, that a default would inflict severe damage on the U.S. economy. (Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times)
Brent crude settled 69 cents, or 0.9 per cent, higher at US$76.95 a barrel on Friday.
The broad-based S&P 500 rose 1.3 per cent to 4,205.45, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average posted a more modest 1.0 per cent gain to finish the week at 33,093.34.

FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Joe Biden hosts debt limit talks with U.S. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) in the Oval Office at the White House in Washington, U.S., May 22, 2023. REUTERS/Leah Millis/File Photo

US President Joe Biden has previously pulled major legislative rabbits out of the hat in his two years as president – and then too he adopted his largely behind-the-scenes role. So he may yet have the last laugh.

site_title: US consumer spending beats expectations in April; inflation picks up
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.8% in April, exceeding expectations and boosting the economy's growth prospects for the second quarter. Inflation also picked up, potentially keeping interest rates higher for some time. Strong wage gains and a tight labor market are supporting consumer spending, but it has slowed since January as Americans become more price-sensitive. The personal consumption expenditures price index increased 0.4% in April, up from 0.1% in March, with core inflation rising 4.7% on a year-on-year basis.

images.alt_text: Though claims for unemployment benefits rose moderately, they remain at levels consistent with a still-tight labour market.
Borrowing costs have crept closer to the highs reached late last year.

site_title: URA eyes rezoning of land parcels in 6 areas for housing
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has identified six land parcels in Lavender, Woodlands, Woodlands North, Whampoa, Kallang, and Jalan Jurong Kechil for future high-density housing development. The proposed projects could increase housing supply for both public and private markets in the mid-term. The plots in the Lavender area will have the highest permissible plot ratio of 4.9, while the Jalan Jurong Kechil site will feature cycling paths to improve connectivity. The URA's Master Plan 2019 amendments aim to boost housing supply and meet demand in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Due to the plot’s attractiveness and accessibility, OrangeTee & Tie deputy chief executive Justin Quek anticipates keen demand from developers.

site_title: Fed ‘pause’ on rate hikes in doubt after strong US data
summary: The US Federal Reserve is uncertain about pausing its interest rate hikes after strong economic data, including a 0.8% surge in consumer spending and inflation accelerating to 4.4% from a year ago. Core prices rose 4.7%, exceeding the Fed's 2% target. Despite Fed Chair Jerome Powell's earlier signal to pause rate hikes, traders now believe the Fed will continue to tighten monetary policy due to persistently high inflation. A 60% chance of a rate hike is implied by futures contracts, indicating a potential decision at the June meeting.

images.alt_text: Borrowing costs have crept closer to the highs reached late last year.

site_title: What would humans do in a world of super AI?
summary: A thought experiment based on economic principles explores what humans would do in a world of super AI. The scenario assumes AI is benevolent, controllable, and distinguishable from humans. According to economists, explosive economic growth is plausible if AI automates all production, including research. However, if AI only automates most but not all production, growth may be constrained. The article suggests that humans may still have a role in areas such as work that blurs with play, play itself, and work where humans retain some advantage, like making private information public. Additionally, humans value history, myths, and meaning, and derive value from human interaction, which may preserve demand for labor even in an age of super-advanced AI.

images.alt_text: Big Tech has provided us with electronic wonders that put much of the world’s knowledge at our fingertips. Likewise AI is also empowering regular workers by making it easier to find and present information, in effect, providing us all with our own research assistant.
The issues on the G7 agenda – including Internet governance, disruptive technologies and digital competition – reflect the increasing significance of cyberwarfare and AI in the global arena.
Big tech companies and startups like Figure are racing to develop the next commercially viable humanoid robot.

site_title: PetroChina, BP awarded 20 year access to Europe’s Gate LNG terminal
summary: PetroChina and BP have won a 20-year tender to handle 2 billion cubic meters of liquefied natural gas annually at Rotterdam's Gate terminal in the Netherlands. The commercial operations are expected to start in 2026, marking PetroChina's first long-term access to a European gas terminal. The deal comes as Chinese firms expand their global LNG portfolio and capitalize on liberalization at home. The partnership is seen as a strategic move for both companies, with LNG becoming a key alternative to pipeline gas in the wake of Russia's reduced pipeline deliveries to the European Union.

site_title: Critical organisational shifts Asian companies must address
summary: Asian companies must adapt to changing organisational needs to stay competitive. A survey by DBS bank found that employees want to share information across teams, leverage digital technology, and work in a safe environment. This shift towards employee-centricity is seen in companies like Haier, a Chinese electronics firm that prioritises user connection and innovation. By empowering employees and embracing change, Asian companies can build a more agile and innovative organisation, ultimately driving growth and success.

images.alt_text: Ask sincere questions, check your own biases, have empathy -- some ways to check if your business culture needs improvement.

Leadership of people is essentially “raising their eyes above the horizon to view their options”. It is strategy. Eye-raising is necessary to bring tactics into line with strategy. You can only do so if you are clear what your strategy is.

Across the span of societies, from the wealthy to those near or at starvation point, consumers are both better and worse informed than they have ever been before.  The internet and the mobile phone have precipitated the greatest change in the distribution of information that humanity has ever seen.

site_title: UK economists see migration falling in election boost for Sunak
summary: UK economists predict a decline in net migration to 245,000 per year by 2028, potentially boosting Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's election prospects. The surge in net migration to 606,000 last year has deepened disquiet in the Conservative Party, which has trailed behind Labour in opinion polls. Factors driving the increase, such as student visas and asylum seekers, are expected to dissipate, leading to a decrease in migration. A fall in migration could help the Conservatives, who have made "taking back control of our borders" a key campaign promise.

images.alt_text: Landlords have been hiking rents to cover rising mortgage costs, and private tenants are competing for a limited supply of homes.

site_title: China allows Morgan Stanley to set up China futures unit
summary: China's securities regulator has allowed Morgan Stanley to set up a China futures company in Beijing, marking the opening-up of the country's futures market. The move aims to deepen the market's opening and support qualified overseas institutions to invest in domestic futures companies. Morgan Stanley had submitted an application in April, and the regulator's approval is seen as a significant step towards expanding the country's financial sector.

site_title: UN nuclear chief to brief Security Council on Ukrainian power plant
summary: UN nuclear chief Rafael Grossi will brief the UN Security Council on his proposal to safeguard Ukraine's Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, amid concerns of a potential nuclear disaster due to increased military activity ahead of Ukraine's expected counteroffensive. The plant, Europe's largest nuclear power plant, has been subject to frequent shelling since Russian forces seized it over a year ago. Grossi has proposed setting up a protection zone around the plant to ensure its safety, but a deal between Ukraine and Russia remains unlikely at the moment.

images.alt_text: Rescuers work at a site of a clinic heavily destroyed by a Russian missile strike, amid Russia's attack on Ukraine, in Dnipro, Ukraine May 26, 2023. Press service of the State Emergency Service of Ukraine/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT.

site_title: Moderna says looking for opportunities in China after registering legal entity
summary: US biotech firm Moderna has registered a unit called Moderna (China) Biotech in Shanghai with a capital of $100 million, marking its entry into mainland China. The move comes as the company seeks opportunities in the market and follows its registration of an office in Hong Kong last year. Moderna's shares rose 2.1% after the announcement, and the company is exploring the use of its mRNA platform to bring its vaccines to the Chinese population. The establishment of a mainland China unit is seen as a strategic move to boost revenue growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Test tubes are seen in front of a displayed Moderna logo in this illustration taken, May 21, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Renault CEO says Euro 7 regulation distracting industry from electrification
summary: Renault CEO Luca De Meo stated that the proposed Euro 7 emissions rules would distract the auto industry from electrification, contradicting the EU's mission to phase out fossil fuel cars by 2035. De Meo expressed gratitude to the Italian government for opposing the regulation, which he believes would require significant financial investments in non-existent technologies. The ACEA, an auto lobby group led by De Meo, is working with Italy to block the Euro 7 regulation.

site_title: Maserati Grecale review: Make it a Maserati
summary: The Maserati Grecale is a medium SUV that ticks all the boxes for roominess, comfort, and practicality with a touch of speed and glamour. Priced at S$279,800, it's a slight financial jump from rivals like the BMW X3 and Mercedes-Benz GLC. The Grecale boasts an 8-speed transmission, all-wheel drive, and a range of engine options, including a 296-hp GT version and a 530-hp Trofeo variant. Despite its Italian heritage, the Grecale's design is understated, but its performance and user-friendly interface make it a compelling choice.

images.alt_text: In only its third incarnation, the new GLC has won over enough people to become Mercedes’ single best-selling model around the world.
The 3 Series' gentle facelift only serves to bring an old adage to mind: If it ain’t broke, just add hexagons

site_title: Indonesian social commerce platform Evermos raises US$39 million in Series C round
summary: Indonesian social commerce platform Evermos has raised US$39 million in its Series C funding round led by the World Bank Group's International Finance Corporation and IFC Emerging Asia Fund. Founded in 2018, Evermos has built a Sharia-compliant reseller-based social commerce network with over 160,000 active resellers in 500 cities. The startup plans to use the funds to expand its presence in Java and Sumatra, connecting local brands and customers more efficiently, and enlarging resellers' customer bases through digital advertising and customer relationship management tools.

images.alt_text: UOB Venture Management leads US$30m round in social commerce startup Evermos

site_title: Paris to ban single-use plastic at 2024 Olympic Games
summary: The city of Paris plans to ban single-use plastic during the 2024 Olympic Games, making it the first major event without such waste. Mayor Anne Hidalgo announced the decision as part of efforts to tackle global plastic pollution. Coca-Cola will distribute products in reusable glass bottles and cups, and over 200 soda fountains will be redeployed after the games. The move aims to reduce plastic waste and carbon footprint, in line with the UN Environment Programme's goal to halve carbon emissions and reduce plastic pollution by 80% by 2040.

images.alt_text: Head of the French National Olympic Committee (CNOSF) Brigitte Henriques has asked the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to launch an internal audit of the CNOSF amid a long-standing row with former general secretary Didier Seminet.

site_title: Cleaner ways to commute: Investment firm drives push to cut carbon emissions
summary: A global push for cleaner transportation is underway, driven by investment firm Temasek, which aims to reduce carbon emissions. The transport sector accounts for 37% of global carbon emissions, with governments, companies, and consumers taking action. Electric vehicles (EVs) generate half the emissions of internal combustion engine vehicles, and their adoption is increasing, with Singapore aiming to make all new cars electric by 2030. Sustainable aviation fuel, derived from used cooking oil and agricultural waste, can reduce carbon emissions by up to 80%. Temasek is investing in manufacturers to improve EV range and safety, and expanding charging stations.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines and Scoot started a one-year pilot programme last year to use a biofuel made from used cooking oil and waste animal fats. It is expected to reduce carbon emissions by 2,500 tonnes.

site_title: Earthquake jolts eastern Japan, no tsunami warning: NHK
summary: A 6.2-magnitude earthquake struck eastern Japan on Friday evening, causing buildings to shake near the Narita International Airport in Chiba prefecture. The epicentre was at a depth of 50 km, with no immediate reports of major damage. No tsunami warning was issued, and Tokyo Electric Power Co checked for signs of damage at its nuclear reactors in Fukushima. Earthquakes are common in Japan, but the quake did not trigger a nuclear crisis. Train services were suspended in Chiba prefecture, but no major incidents were reported.

images.alt_text: Japan’s economy is finally recovering from the scars of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Meta offers to limit use of ad data to address UK competition concerns
summary: Meta has offered to limit the use of ad data to address UK competition concerns, according to the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA). The regulator is minded to accept the commitments, which include allowing advertisers to opt out of data sharing for Facebook Marketplace's classified ads platform. This move aims to reduce the risk of Meta exploiting businesses' data for competitive advantage.

site_title: Japan’s Kitano says he held back in bloody samurai film ‘Kubi’
summary: Japanese director Takeshi Kitano's new film 'Kubi' depicts the 1582 Honno-ji Temple ambush in gory detail, but Kitano claims the film held back on violence to reflect the brutality of battles during the Sengoku period. The film's ultraviolence was criticized, with some describing it as "brutal" and "vicious". Kitano views the samurai as similar to yakuza members, driven by a desire for power and fighting, rather than strategy. The film's portrayal of violence was influenced by historical records, where warriors were judged by the number of enemy heads they beheaded.

images.alt_text: epa10647568 Japanese film director Takeshi Kitano attends the photocall for 'Kubi' during the 76th annual Cannes Film Festival, in Cannes, France, 23 May 2023. The festival runs from 16 to 27 May.  EPA-EFE/GUILLAUME HORCAJUELO

site_title: New Thai government must continue peace talks with insurgents: Thai official
summary: Thailand's new government, led by the progressive Move Forward party, prioritizes peace-building in southern provinces, where decades-long conflict has flared on and off. The alliance, which won the general election, aims to maintain continuity and momentum in peace talks with insurgents, which resumed last year. General Wanlop Rugsanaoh, head of Thailand's Peace Dialogue Panel, emphasized the need for the next government to continue engaging with insurgents to ensure peace.

images.alt_text: A coalition of pro-democracy parties led by the Move Forward has staked claim to form the next government with Pita Limjaroenrat as its prime ministerial nominee.

site_title: China allows Morgan Stanley to set up China futures unit
summary: China's securities regulator has approved Morgan Stanley to set up a futures company in Beijing, allowing the US firm to implement the opening-up of the country's futures market. The move aims to deepen the market's opening-up and support qualified overseas institutions to invest in domestic futures companies. Morgan Stanley had previously announced its plans to set up a futures company in China after the regulator accepted its application.

site_title: Beloved Hong Kong bun festival returns after three years
summary: The Bun Festival returned to Hong Kong's Cheung Chau island after a three-year hiatus due to the pandemic. Thousands attended the five-day celebration, which began with a parade featuring costumed children, gongs, and dragon dances. The festival, which dates back to the 1800s, was marked by a 14-meter-high bamboo tower covered in imitation steamed buns, with climbers competing for the "Bun Queen" title. Despite the return of festivities, the event's political edge was toned down, with Beijing's tightening grip on the city's freedoms.

site_title: Singapore Flyer operator Straco Corp reverses loss with S$1.6 million Q1 net profit
summary: Straco Corp, the operator of the Singapore Flyer, reported a Q1 net profit of S$1.6 million, reversing a previous loss of S$3 million. Revenue surged 159.4% to S$12.5 million, driven by higher visitor numbers at its China attractions and the Singapore Flyer, which generated "significantly higher revenues" compared to the same period in 2022. The company's financial position remains strong with S$145.8 million in net cash holdings.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The Singapore Flyer in Singapore's Marina Bay area had to close from Jan 16 to Apr 14 because of a technical issue, but this has since been resolved.

site_title: Thiel-backed Spac agrees to merge with Asian startup MoneyHero
summary: MoneyHero, an Asian personal-finance comparison website, has agreed to merge with Bridgetown Holdings, a blank-cheque company backed by billionaires Peter Thiel and Richard Li. The merger values MoneyHero at approximately US$200 million, including debt, and will be taken public on the Nasdaq under the "MNY" ticker. The combined company's enterprise value could reach US$342 million if there are no redemptions. MoneyHero, which has 9.8 million monthly unique users, will roll its existing investors' equity into the combined company, expected to close in the second half of the year.

site_title: Sanctioned China stocks win sudden boost from patriotic buyers
summary: Chinese investors are buying up shares of sanctioned technology firms and state-owned companies, driven by a surge in patriotic sentiment amid US and Japanese curbs on China's chipmaking industry. Shares of companies like NAURA Technology Group, Piotech, and ACM Research Shanghai have jumped 14%, 45%, and 19% respectively since end-March. Investors are seeking to support China's technology independence and capitalize on the country's economic reopening. The nationalistic fervor is also driving interest in state-owned enterprises, with at least eight asset managers applying to launch investment products tracking the CSI Computing Infrastructure Index.

site_title: Oil edges higher to head for modest gain as debt talks in focus
summary: Oil prices edged higher, trading above $72 a barrel, ahead of a potential US debt limit agreement. Despite a 10% decline in crude this year, investors are optimistic about a modest weekly gain. Supply dynamics remain a focus, with OPEC+ unlikely to take further production cuts, according to Russia's Deputy Prime Minister. Traders expect another US rate hike, pricing in a quarter-point increase within the next two meetings, and cautious sentiment is expected to continue.

site_title: New digital portal helps Singapore plumbers to find clients
summary: Licensed plumbers in Singapore can now access job listings on the Singapore Plumbing Society's (SPS) digital portal, launched on May 26. The portal allows plumbers to find opportunities posted by interior designers, industry professionals, and management corporation strata titles (MCSTs) in need of plumbing services. The initiative, a collaboration between SPS, PUB, and NTUC, aims to simplify the job search process and facilitate direct communication between plumbers and potential clients.

images.alt_text: The NTUC supports every worker, says labour leaders, highlighting measures to help groups such as senior workers and those with caregiving responsibilities.

Describing the situation faced by SEPs as a Gordian Knot, Yeo Wan Ling, MP for Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, said they often find themselves in a paradox. For example, freelances must upskill to improve their income, but doing so takes time and would eat into their “barely sufficient” income.
MPs covered a wide range of issues during the Budget debate on Thursday, seeking greater support for vulnerable workers, even as they called for larger businesses to do more to contribute to society.

site_title: Indian automaker Mahindra’s Q4 profit rises 22%, declares dividend
summary: Indian automaker Mahindra reported a 22.1% rise in Q4 profit to 15.49 billion rupees (S$253.5 million) driven by strong sales of its SUVs. Revenue rose 31% to 225.71 billion rupees. The company declared a final dividend of 16.25 rupees per share. Mahindra's Q4 profit was its first standalone profit after tax in three years.

site_title: Singapore stocks flat as lacklustre manufacturing output hurts sentiment; STI down 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) edged down 0.01% to 3,207.39 on May 26 due to a worsening electronics down cycle and weaker external demand. The contraction in Singapore's industrial production in April, exceeding forecasts, also weighed on sentiment. The broader market saw 179 losers beat 173 gainers, with 920.4 million securities worth S$835.6 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Biomedical manufacturing was the worst performing cluster in April, clocking an overall contraction of 11.1 per cent on the year.

site_title: ‘Integrated policy framework’, not monetary policy alone, needed for price and financial stability: Ravi Menon
summary: MAS managing director Ravi Menon emphasizes the need for an integrated policy framework to achieve both price and financial stability, rather than relying solely on monetary policy. He advocates for a comprehensive approach combining monetary policy, fiscal policy, and macro-financial measures to address financial vulnerabilities and minimize the risk of financial and economic crises. Menon also recognizes that there may be a short-term trade-off between price stability and financial stability, and that monetary policy is too blunt to address excessive risk-taking.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
MAS policy change still not expected as Singapore headline inflation ticks up in April, core remains flat

site_title: New editor appointed at Berita Harian
summary: Berita Harian, a Malay-language news publication, has appointed Mohd Nazry Mokhtar as its new editor, effective June 1, 2023. The current editor, Mohd Sa'at Abdul Rahman, will retire and take on a new role as senior consultant at the paper. Nazry, who has been the deputy editor since 2013, will oversee all editorial functions and continue the paper's digitalization efforts. Sa'at, who has led the paper for 35 years, will also continue as president of the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore.

site_title: British Airways cancels flights for second day after IT outage
summary: British Airways cancelled over 160 short-haul flights from Heathrow due to a technical issue that started on Thursday, impacting travelers during a busy travel weekend. The airline attributed the disruptions to a "knock-on effect" from the previous day's issue. Despite the cancellations, the majority of flights continue to operate. The incident is the second IT outage for the airline this week, following a similar issue on Thursday.

images.alt_text: British Airways jets taxi near the building site for Terminal 5 at Heathrow airport near London, Friday, May 15, 2004. Europe's second-largest airline, said third-quarter profit slipped 41 percent after rising oil prices boosted operating costs. The carrier increased its revenue forecast for the fiscal year.

site_title: Pinduoduo-owner PDD beats quarterly revenue estimates, shares rise
summary: Pinduoduo-owner PDD Holdings reported a quarterly revenue of 37.64 billion yuan (S$7.2 billion), beating analysts' estimates of 31.98 billion yuan. The company's US-listed shares rose 7% in trading after the announcement. This growth is attributed to Chinese consumer spending gaining momentum since the country lifted zero-Covid policies, as well as the expansion of its international platform Temu. Retail sales in China rose 5.8% in the January-March period, with online retail sales up 8.6%.

images.alt_text: PDD reported revenue of 39.82 billion yuan in the fourth quarter, falling short of estimates for 41.01 billion yuan.

site_title: French police use tear gas on protesters at oil giant's meeting
summary: French police used tear gas to disperse climate activists protesting at the annual general meeting of oil giant TotalEnergies in Paris. The demonstration comes as activists step up pressure on companies to reduce their carbon footprints. TotalEnergies plans to invest in low-carbon energy and reach 100 gigawatts of renewable electricity capacity by 2030, but critics say the company's efforts are too slow. The company's CEO, Patrick Pouyanne, defended the company's climate strategy, but protesters claimed TotalEnergies "embodies the worst of what is done in terms of the exploitation of people and the planet."

images.alt_text: Many governments are pushing for renewables in an effort to tackle climate change and calling for reduced gas use.

site_title: Seatrium may not join STI in June; Keppel DC Reit’s position in index tenuous: DBS
summary: Seatrium may not join the Straits Times Index (STI) in June due to its low market capitalisation, despite meeting the eligibility criterion. Keppel DC Reit, currently in 35th position, is at risk of exclusion if its market capitalisation falls further, despite being "relatively unattractive" with a low forward yield. The decision will be made at the next review in June, where a stock that meets the inclusion rule will replace a Reit that meets the exclusion rule.

images.alt_text: (From left) George Schulze, Dalmore whisky expert for Asia at Emperador; Bryan Donaghey, chief executive of Whyte & Mackay and head of whisky business at Emperador; Loh Boon Chye, SGX chief executive; Dr Andrew Tan, chairman of Emperador; Gerard Ho, Singapore’s Ambassador to the Philippines and Kevin Andrew Tan, director of Emperador at the listing of Emperador at the Singapore Exchange on 14 July 2022.

site_title: Issue 51: CIX aims to set standard for carbon pricing; EU carbon tariff’s impact on S-E Asia rules
summary: CIX, a leading voluntary carbon market, aims to set a standard for carbon pricing. The EU's carbon tariff on imported emissions has had a muted response from Asian governments, particularly in Southeast Asia. Prices of exchange-traded carbon credits have fallen over the past year, alongside an increase in the use of standardized contracts. This development has implications for the region's carbon pricing policies and the potential for a unified benchmark for voluntary carbon markets.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
The trouble with pricing carbon
ESGpedia 2.0 will have greater data coverage, enhanced solutions and analytics, and assessment tools, said Benjamin Soh, founder and managing director of Stacs, which is behind the platform. PHOTO:
The Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) will put an emissions tariff on imports of carbon intensive goods entering the European Union (EU).

BlackRock headquarters at 50 Hudson Yards in New York, US, on Monday, May 1, 2023. The strong demand for professional talent comes amid a political backlash against ESG in parts of the Western world, especially in the US.

site_title: Poorer nations snap up cheap LNG in push to boost economies
summary: Countries in Asia and Latin America are buying cheap liquefied natural gas (LNG) to boost their economies, replacing more polluting fuels. Emerging markets, such as Thailand, Bangladesh, and Vietnam, are the largest buyers, while many governments are pushing for renewable energy to tackle climate change. The increased LNG demand is partly offsetting weak demand from Europe and North Asia, providing producers with a safety net. However, producers remain cautious, and long-term LNG deals remain challenging for countries without investment-grade status, as many governments also push for reduced gas use.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The "Cap Pembroke"  a VLCC (very large crude carrier), owned by Euronav, the largest NYSE listed independent crude oil tanker company in the world, berthed at the Valero oil terminal at Pembroke in the Port of Milford Haven, the UK's largest energy port, Pembrokeshire, Wales, July 28, 2018. site_title: Closing date for Lian Beng privatisation offer extended
summary: The closing date for Lian Beng's privatisation offer has been extended to June 9, 2023, from May 26. The offeror, OSC Capital, has reached 81.11% ownership, with plans to acquire the remaining shares at S$0.68 per share. The extension comes after the Securities Investors Association (SIA) deemed the initial bid of S$0.62 per share as "unfair or unreasonable". The offeror must now reach a 90% threshold to acquire the rest of Lian Beng, with the shares trading flat at S$0.68 per share.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: US office real estate looks dicey with Reits plunging to a 2009 low
summary: US office real estate investments trusts (REITs) have plummeted to a 2009 low, with the S&P Composite 1500 Office REITs index down 27% in 2023. The shift to working from home has exacerbated the problem, leaving desks empty and tightening corporate budgets. However, some analysts believe that fears about commercial real estate may be overblown, and that office landlords could see an improvement as companies encourage workers to return to their desks. Newer office buildings with modern amenities and healthy fundamentals are likely to benefit, while industrial and senior housing landlords could prove to be potential bright spots.

site_title: Taiwan cuts GDP forecast, export outlook as global demand weakens
summary: Taiwan's government has revised its GDP forecast, expecting 2.04% growth in 2023, down from the initial 2.12% due to weakening global demand and a contraction in exports. The country's exports have been declining for eight consecutive months, and the first-quarter GDP fell 2.87% year-over-year. Despite this, domestic demand performed well, and unemployment remains at its lowest in over two decades. The central bank may not raise interest rates again until the fourth quarter, as it weighs inflation and economic growth.

images.alt_text: The export-dependent economy is now in recession after contracting for two quarters in a row.

site_title: Lufthansa intends to fully take over ITA Airways: CEO
summary: Lufthansa plans to acquire a 41% stake in ITA Airways through a 325 million euro capital increase, with the option to expand its ownership stake to 49% by 2025. The German airline group's CEO, Carsten Spohr, stated that Lufthansa will assess its investment based on the airline's performance, with further options to acquire the remaining 10% depending on economic development. The move aims to address ITA Airways' financial struggles.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file combination of photos created on January 27, 2023 shows (top) a Lufthansa Boeing 747 taking off overhead at the airport in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on August 1, 2022, and an Airbus A319-112 bearing the ITA Airways logo taking off from Rome's Fiumicino airport. German airline group Lufthansa said on May 25, 2023 it will invest 325 million euros (USD 348 million) to buy a 41-percent stake in Italy's ITA Airways, after the Italian government unveiled the deal. (Photo by Daniel ROLAND and Andreas SOLARO / AFP)

site_title: Dubai watchdog warns on risks of crypto’s global regulatory gaps
summary: Dubai's financial regulator warns that global regulators must step up cooperation to address regulatory gaps in the cryptocurrency industry, allowing "bad actors" to exploit these gaps. The Dubai Financial Services Authority plans to update its crypto token rules, potentially later this year, amid a global trend of jurisdictions competing to attract crypto investment. Regulators worldwide are grappling with ways to handle the industry, with varying approaches ranging from Singapore's curbs on retail-investor participation to US regulators' clampdown on crypto firms following the FTX collapse.

site_title: Malaysia’s anti-graft agency says probing Petronas, international oil firm
summary: Malaysia's Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) is investigating allegations of corruption involving Petronas, a state oil firm, and an international oil and gas company over a project worth RM399 million in Sarawak. Petronas has cooperated fully with the commission. The MACC found several weaknesses in practices and procedures and proposed improvements to standard operating procedures. The commission urged parties with information on the case to come forward and assist the probe.

site_title: OpenAI chief seeks to calm EU tension
summary: Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, is on a global tour to address EU concerns about artificial intelligence (AI). He previously hinted at a possible exit from the EU if regulations are too strict. However, in London, Altman stated that OpenAI has no plans to leave the EU, contradicting his earlier comments. The company aims to calm fears over AI's potential impact on industries, misinformation, and racism. Altman's visit follows recent EU discussions on AI regulations.

images.alt_text: Sam Altman, chief executive officer of OpenAI, during a fireside chat at University College London (UCL) in London, UK, on Wednesday, May 24, 2023. Altman said part of the reason for his current tour of European cities is to discover a suitable location for a new office. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Red light, green light
summary: Sub-sales in Singapore's property market have surged, reaching their highest level in almost 10 years, amidst signs of a slowing housing market. The indicator, which tracks trading momentum, has risen from a trough in 2020, suggesting speculative buying behavior. HDB resale prices flattened in February, and condo resale prices fell for the first time in over two years, indicating easing prices that may provide relief for those looking to buy a resale flat.

site_title: UBS, Credit Suisse offer Asia wealth bankers a cut on inflows
summary: UBS Group AG and Credit Suisse Group AG are offering 15 basis points, or $0.15 per $100 in new client money, to their wealth bankers in Asia to bring in fresh cash. This incentive is more attractive than existing bonuses, which are tied to fee-generating assets. The move aims to ensure stability as the former Swiss rivals seek to complete a government-orchestrated merger. Relationship managers at both firms will receive the commissions, which are designed to encourage them to bring in new clients and stabilize the combined bank's inflows.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based Credit Suisse Trust breached its duty to the plaintiffs in failing to safeguard the trust assets, according to a judgment.

site_title: Singapore court orders Credit Suisse unit to pay tycoon damages that could amount to hundreds of millions of dollars
summary: A Singapore court ordered Credit Suisse Trust to compensate billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili for potential damages of hundreds of millions of dollars. The court found the trust breached its duty to safeguard assets, resulting in a US$926 million award that may be revised. This judgment marks a setback for Credit Suisse, following a Bermuda court's previous award of over US$600 million in damages to Ivanishvili. The case centers on Ivanishvili's lost income due to the bank's trust unit's failure to prevent fraud.

images.alt_text: Bondholders have argued the writedown was an unfair and disproportionate move that put shareholders before bondholders.

site_title: Insurers flee climate alliance after ESG backlash in the US
summary: At least seven members of the Net-Zero Insurance Alliance, including AXA, Allianz, and Scor, have left the UN-convened climate alliance amid growing opposition from US Republican politicians who claim the group's targets and requirements may violate antitrust laws. The departures come as 23 US state attorneys general warned insurers that the group's targets and requirements appeared to violate both federal and state antitrust laws. The alliance still has 23 members, but the exits are a blow to UN-led efforts to harness the power of coalescing financial institutions to drive emissions lower.

images.alt_text: A survey conducted by Schneider Electric found that linking executive remuneration to decarbonisation progress could drive companies’ green plans.

site_title: UK retail sales bounce back in April as weather improves
summary: UK retail sales rebounded 0.5% in April, exceeding expectations, as consumers continued to spend despite a cost-of-living squeeze and rising inflation. The recovery follows a 1.2% decline in March, and sales volumes have risen 0.8% over the past three months. The rebound puts pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates to combat high inflation. Despite this, consumer confidence remains resilient, with sales up 16.5% in April compared to February 2020.

images.alt_text: The two-year British swap rate, which underpins many lenders’ own financing costs and mortgage pricing for two-year deals, has shot up around 50 basis points so far this week.

A customer carries grocery shopping bags in Sheffield, UK, on Friday, May 19, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK CPI Inflation data on Wednesday. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

site_title: Hot stock: Chemical Industries (Far East) rises 8.5% to S$0.77; director resigned night before
summary: Chemical Industries (Far East) shares rose 8.5% to S$0.77 on May 26, following the announcement of non-executive director Lim Yew Khang Cecil's resignation, effective the same day. The company had no married deals on data platform ShareInvestor. This news came after the company filed its bourse filing late the previous night.

images.alt_text: test, tube, lab
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Australian shares post worst week since mid-March on US debt jitters
summary: Australian shares posted their worst weekly performance in over two months, closing 0.2% higher on Friday, despite US debt ceiling talks nearing a deadline. Investors remain cautious, awaiting cues from the US negotiations, which could lead to a default if an agreement isn't sealed by June 1. Retail sales data showed flat April numbers, pointing to a possible rate pause in May. Tech stocks led gains, while miners and healthcare stocks declined.

images.alt_text: Retail sales volumes had already posted a fall in the first quarter, marking a second straight quarterly decline and indicating a drag on economic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong hits back at UK call for security law to be scrapped
summary: Hong Kong authorities have condemned a British call for the removal of a China-imposed national security law, which they say has brought stability after mass pro-democracy protests in 2019. Britain's Foreign Secretary James Cleverly has urged Beijing to implement UN recommendations to remove the law, citing its use to persecute and silence pro-democracy opposition figures. Hong Kong's government has rejected the call, saying it is a matter of China's internal affairs and that individual rights are not absolute when it comes to safeguarding national security.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People wearing face masks walk on the street during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Hong Kong, China, December 28, 2022. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: India gets new parliament building as Modi remakes capital’s centre
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to inaugurate a new parliament complex on May 28, marking the centrepiece of a $2.4 billion project to remake British colonial-era buildings in New Delhi with an Indian identity. The renovation aims to give the city's centre a distinct Indian culture, traditions, and symbols ahead of parliamentary elections in 2024. This move comes as Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party seeks a third term, focusing on Hindu nationalist credentials and past performance. The project also reflects Modi's government's efforts to revamp Hindu pilgrimage centres since 2014.

images.alt_text: A labourer works at the under construction site of the new parliament building in New Delhi, India, May 23, 2023. REUTERS/Adnan Abidi

site_title: Group buys offer strength in numbers, but are they still a win-win?
summary: Group buys, popularized during the COVID-19 pandemic, have been a convenient way for homeowners in Singapore to purchase goods at discounted prices. Nanyang Business School professor Sharon Ng notes that this concept aligns with Asian values of community and cooperation. Since the pandemic, group buys have become more accessible, with retailers like Gain City hosting regular events where customers can purchase items at exclusive prices with a minimum spend. However, it remains to be seen whether group buys remain a win-win for both buyers and retailers in the post-pandemic era.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The interest in preventive health technology has been rising globally.
While growth and scale still lie abroad for Singapore's e-waste recycling sector, there is guarded optimism that the scene could yet blossom on the back of a greening economy.
Shein and Temu have taken the world by storm, with a potent combination of ultra-low prices and personalised recommendations.

site_title: Home is where the hurt is at the French Open
summary: A 40-year drought for French men at the French Open continues, with Yannick Noah's 1983 victory the last. Meanwhile, Australia has not seen a home men's champion at the Australian Open since 1976's Mark Edmondson, and the US Open has not seen an American men's champion since Andy Roddick in 2003. In contrast, the women's side has had more success, with Evonne Goolagong winning the 1976 title and Ashleigh Barty claiming the 2022 title, ending a 44-year wait.

images.alt_text: “I’ll look to be 100 per cent ready for next year, which I believe will be the last year of my professional career,” Rafa Nadal says.
Spain's Carlos Alcaraz lost his third round match of the Men's ATP Rome Open tennis tournament against Hungary's Fabian Marozsan at Foro Italico in Rome on May 15, 2023.
“We have not been able to achieve everything we set out for, but we have been in touch with people close to Peng and are assured she is living safely with her family in Beijing,” the WTA said.

site_title: March global flight bookings 31% higher than in pre-Covid 2019 period: report
summary: Global flight bookings rose 25% year-over-year in March 2023 and 31% higher than the 2019 pre-Covid period, according to Mastercard Economics Institute. The Asia-Pacific region drove the growth, with business travel improving 42% year-to-date. Commercial flight bookings exceeded leisure travel for part of 2022 and tracked leisure travel's improvements in 2023. However, the momentum may be stymied by inflation, higher interest rates, and a global macroeconomic downturn.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Mapletree Investments posts 38.8% drop in full-year net profit to S$1.2 billion
summary: Mapletree Investments reported a net profit of S$1.2 billion for the full year ended March 31, 38.8% lower than S$2 billion in the same period last year. Revenue remained flat at S$2.9 billion. Operational performance improved, driven by higher contributions from Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust and a gradual recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. Recurring earnings declined 3.8% to S$779.7 million, while total assets under management slipped 1.7% to S$77.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Mapletree Industrial Trust's manager expects the acquisition to be distribution per unit and net asset value per unit accretive to unitholders.
The data centre, due to be complete by May 2025, is fully leased by a data centre operator.

site_title: Sayonara crazy home rentals
summary: Singapore's rental market remains healthy, with agents reporting fewer viewings and listings taking longer to secure tenants. However, concerns about the global banking system's stability may impact home buying sentiment, with potential buyers adopting a wait-and-see attitude. Despite this, residential en bloc sales can still succeed, as seen in recent deals by Ho Bee Land and Wing Tai Holdings. The Singapore government may consider growing a build-to-rent private housing segment to address affordability issues.

site_title: G7 officials to hold first meeting on AI regulation
summary: G7 officials will hold the first working-level meeting on AI regulation on May 30 to discuss issues such as intellectual property protection, disinformation, and governance. The meeting comes as tech regulators worldwide gauge the impact of popular AI services like ChatGPT. The G7 has agreed to create an intergovernmental forum to debate AI issues, with Japan leading the discussion on responsive use of generative AI technology. The forum aims to provide suggestions for heads of state by year-end, following last week's Hiroshima G7 summit's call for developing and adopting international technical standards for trustworthy AI.

images.alt_text: G7 leaders at the Itsukushima Shrine during the G7 summit in Hiroshima, Japan, on May 19, 2023.
The issues on the G7 agenda – including Internet governance, disruptive technologies and digital competition – reflect the increasing significance of cyberwarfare and AI in the global arena.

US President Joe Biden and other G7 leaders at Hiroshima Peace Park and Memorial Museum before participating in a wreath laying ceremony, on the first day of the G7 summit, in Hiroshima, Japan, May 19, 2023.

site_title: SP Group to provide cooling services to more areas in Marina Bay
summary: SP Group has signed a memorandum of understanding with City Developments and Singapore Land Group to provide cooling services to four developments in Marina Bay, increasing its installed cooling capacity to 75,000 RT by 2027. The overall Marina Bay district cooling network will operate at a total capacity of up to 90,000 RT. This expansion aims to provide energy-efficient cooling services to more areas in the district, supporting the company's goal of increasing its capacity by 2,000 RT.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
While there has been a retreat from ESG funds by public capital, private capital is still going full steam ahead.
While growth and scale still lie abroad for Singapore's e-waste recycling sector, there is guarded optimism that the scene could yet blossom on the back of a greening economy.
Solar panel installation at Sim Siang Choon Hardware's headquarters in Changi South. The company tapped JTC's SolarRoof programme., which has been extended to privately leased industrial properties.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Macroeconomic data, inflation and uncertainty drive markets (Ep 45)
summary: A mixed week for markets occurred amid inflation and US debt ceiling talks, with uncertainty remaining around the latter. Macroeconomic data also played a significant role in market movements. Despite this, the article does not provide specific conclusions or key statistics, only setting the stage for further analysis.

images.alt_text: Markets continue to be exciting this week, with US, Japan anc China in the spotlight.
Inflation data still wreaking havoc in the markets?

site_title: US, Chinese commerce chiefs raise complaints on trade, investment, export policies
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo and Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao met in Washington, discussing trade, investment, and export policies. Raimondo raised concerns about China's actions against US companies, while Wang expressed concerns about US policies, including semiconductor controls and foreign investment reviews. Both sides agreed to establish open communication channels to manage the relationship and address specific economic trade concerns. The meeting comes after G7 leaders criticized China's "economic coercion" and US President Joe Biden pledged more frequent communications with Chinese President Xi Jinping to avoid tensions.

images.alt_text: UAW president Shawn Fain noted the UAW has lost 1 million members since 1980 – a decline he blamed on trade policy.
The PBOC has so far refrained from cutting interest rates despite the slowing economy.

site_title: Pimco weighs joining investors suing over Credit Suisse wipeout
summary: Pimco, a major asset manager, is considering joining hundreds of investors in suing Credit Suisse over a US$17 billion writedown of its Additional Tier 1 bonds following the bank's takeover by UBS. Pimco, which holds US$800 million in the bonds, is weighing whether to pursue legal action to recoup some losses. Bondholders argue the writedown was unfair and disproportionately benefited shareholders, while regulators claim the risk was outlined in the bond documents. The Swiss Federal Administrative Court has received over 230 appeals against the March 19 writedown.

images.alt_text: The European Commission, which runs the EU’s powerful anti-trust regulator, said the merger between UBS and Credit Suisse would not significantly reduce competition in the markets where their activities overlap” within the European Economic Area.
“I think Credit Suisse is culturally challenged in the investment bank so we have to be very careful about – I use the term culture filter – who we bring in,” UBS Chairman Colm Kelleher says.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Singtel, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Keppel, The Hour Glass, Metro
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has closed its private placement of 92.6 million units to fund a new data centre acquisition in Osaka, Japan, valued at S$507.9 million. The acquisition is part of MIT's expansion plans. Other companies saw developments, including Sembcorp's power purchase agreement with Singtel, Keppel's hydrogen production facility in Australia, and The Hour Glass's decline in net profit, while Metro recorded a 54% rise in net profit.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Services receipts growth eases to 7.9% in Q1 in 3rd straight quarter of decline
summary: Singapore's services industry saw a 7.9% year-on-year growth in business receipts in Q1, down from a revised 11.7% in Q4 for the third straight quarter of decline. The recreation and personal services industry led the gains with a 40.3% increase in turnover. On a non-seasonally adjusted quarterly basis, business receipts contracted 4.6% in Q1, reversing from Q4's 3.9% growth. This marks a slowdown in revenue growth for the services industry.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Takings from the recreation and personal services industry grew x per cent on the year as xxx.

site_title: Decisions, decisions
summary: In Singapore, three new residential projects are launching in March, offering 2,400 units in the Rest of Central Region. The projects, including City Developments Ltd and MCL Land's Tembusu Grand and Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Developments' The Continuum, are priced at S$2,500 per square foot. The market is seeing a 40-60% take-up rate for the first three launches, which is considered within expectations. Ultra-prime projects are also selling steadily, with luxury condos commanding prices above S$6,000 per square foot. The ultra-wealthy are driving demand in both residential and commercial real estate, with Singapore ranking sixth for sales of ultra-prime and prime residential properties in 2022.

images.alt_text: The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter (March 7, 2023)
Michelle Low

site_title: Sias asks Asti board about possibility of exit offer, raises other concerns
summary: Sias, the Securities and Investors Association (Singapore), is asking Asti's board to confirm an exit offer and answer questions about shareholder concerns, including the introduction of potential buyers, the handling of the FY2021 AGM, and the appointment of new board members. Asti, a watch-listed semiconductor company, received a non-binding letter of intent for its acquisition by a consortium of two unnamed parties. Sias also raised questions about a proposed sale of over 130 million shares by Michael Loh, who previously served as Asti's CEO.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Seminconductor company Asti said on Sunday it received an unsolicited, non-binding letter of intent for the acquisition of all the company's shares.
SGX has directed ASTI to hold its FY2021 and FY2022 AGM by 30 July 2023.
The company also urged shareholders not to attend the EGM and that even if any resolutions were to be passed through at the EGM, they would also be deemed invalid.

site_title: Billionaire to buy Sun Cable assets, revive plan to export solar power from Australia to Singapore
summary: Billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes has revived plans to export solar power from Australia to Singapore after acquiring the assets of the failed Sun Cable project. Cannon-Brookes' Grok Ventures aims to deliver 900 megawatts of clean electricity to Darwin and export 1.8 gigawatts to Singapore. The deal gives Cannon-Brookes and Quinbrook Infrastructure Partners control of a vast renewable energy development in northern Australia, following Sun Cable's voluntary administration in January due to a dispute with Andrew Forrest. The project will transport electricity through a 4,200-kilometre submarine cable.

site_title: Investment opportunities in the age of AI
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) technology is expected to significantly impact the global economy, with PwC estimating it could contribute up to $15.7 trillion by 2030. Retailers are using AI to anticipate customer needs and streamline services, while the healthcare sector may see improved patient care and drug development through AI-driven analysis. The technology is also poised to disrupt the technology sector, with large language models (LLMs) transforming online search and coding landscapes. AI-driven chatbots are expected to improve customer service, and investment opportunities in AI are emerging, particularly in companies outside the traditional tech sector.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT logo and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

A trader walks out of the New York Stock Exchange on Wall Street in New York. Some Wall Street firms are revising their profit projections for multiple S&P 500 industry groups, based on the adoption of AI.

site_title: Singapore factory output down 6.9% in April in 7th straight month of contraction
summary: Singapore's factory output fell 6.9% year-on-year in April, marking the seventh consecutive month of contraction. The electronics segment, particularly biomedical manufacturing, was the main drag on growth. Output from the biomedical cluster declined 11.1% year-on-year, while the electronics cluster shrank 8.7%. Despite some economists expecting a turnaround in the second half of the year, others warn of a technical recession due to weaker external demand and the ongoing electronics downcycle.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
A pilot boat sails past container vessels at Pasir Panjang port terminal in Singapore on January 3, 2023 (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Singapore’s gross domestic product (GDP) expanded 0.4 per cent year on year, a notch higher than an advance estimate of 0.1 per cent, MTI's data showed on Thursday (May 25).
NODX to China contributes the most to the overall decline in shipments to Singapore’s top 10 markets in April.

site_title: Keppel and partners to develop hydrogen project in Australia; invests in Vietnam residential development
summary: KEPPEL Corporation has joined a consortium to develop a large-scale hydrogen project in Queensland, Australia, providing access to a reliable source of hydrogen as feedstock for a green production facility. The company also signed a memorandum of understanding with Incitec Pivot to explore a green ammonia production facility in Gladstone, Queensland, with plans to supply green hydrogen and ammonia to Singapore. Additionally, KEPPEL will develop over 200 landed homes and 600 high-rise apartments in a residential project in Vietnam.
