site_title: Hot stock: Hiap Tong rises 7% to S$0.138, up 72.5% in May
summary: Hiap Tong, a crane rental service provider, saw its share price rise 7% to S$0.138 on May 26, up 72.5% since May 2. The company attributed its higher net profits to new construction projects and the full resumption of business operations after the pandemic. Hiap Tong expects to record "significantly higher" net profit after tax for FY2023 compared to FY2022.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Daniel Bian, a Chinese potential property buyer from Shanghai, visits a luxury condominium in Bangkok, Thailand, April 20, 2023.
In Feb this year, Boustead Project’s parent, Boustead Singapore launched a voluntary unconditional general offer for the company.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise on US debt ceiling optimism
summary: US debt ceiling optimism lifted Asian markets on Friday, with Tokyo leading the gains. Despite President Biden's pledge to avoid default and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy's determination to reach a deal by June 1, traders remain nervous due to a looming deadline. Fitch's "rating watch negative" warning and lingering rancour on Capitol Hill have raised concerns about a potential downgrade. Despite this, the broad consensus is for the borrowing limit to be raised, with markets mostly rising in Asia.

site_title: Singapore High Court grants sale order to Chuan Park’s S$890 million en bloc deal
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted a sale order for Chuan Park's S$890 million en bloc deal, approving the collective sale of the 444-home condominium to entities related to developers Kingsford Group and MCC Singapore. The court found no evidence that the deal was not arrived at in good faith by the collective sales committee and rejected claims that the sale price was a "deep discount" due to undisclosed development baseline information. The sale price was based on a valuation report of 78,152.76 square meters and a plot ratio of 2.1, and the minority owners have until June 23, 2023, to file an appeal.

images.alt_text: Dissenting owners filed their objections to the STB, alleging that Chuan Park’s CSC and marketing agent ERA Realty failed to disclose material facts relating to a higher development baseline for the condominium - which translates into a “deep discount” for the buyers - among other issues.
位于罗弄泉的春景花园（Chuan Park）私人公寓外观。Chuan Park, a 446-unit condominium near Lorong Chuan MRT station.

site_title: China easing bets climb to highest this year as growth sputters
summary: China's interest rate swaps have fallen to 2.06% this week, marking the highest level this year, as traders bet on monetary easing amid slowing economic growth. The nation's benchmark 10-year bond yield has also dropped to a six-month low of 2.70%. Despite the PBOC's reluctance to cut interest rates, data shows the economy is sputtering, with industrial production, retail sales, and fixed investment missing forecasts. Analysts predict further policy support may be needed to protect growth, but caution is advised due to the potential impact on the weakening yuan.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: China Eastern set to operate C919’s first commercial flight on Sunday
summary: China Eastern Airlines will launch the world's first commercial flight of the C919, a domestically manufactured narrow-body jet, on Sunday, May 28. The flight will depart from Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport to Beijing Capital Airport. The airline's contract for five C919s was signed in March 2021, and the aircraft has undergone 100 hours of empty aircraft verification test flights. The 164-seat C919 features a two-class cabin layout and relies on Western components for engines and avionics. This marks a milestone in China's hopes to break the Airbus-Boeing duopoly in the airline manufacturing industry.

images.alt_text: Comac delivered the first C919 to China Eastern in December, and the maiden commercial flight is expected to take place in spring this year.

site_title: China reopening drives demand for industrial land in Thailand
summary: Thailand has seen a significant increase in foreign investment applications, more than doubling to 155.3 billion baht (S$6.1 billion) in the three months through March, led by companies from South Korea, Singapore, and China. The demand for industrial land is expected to surge, with WHA, Thailand's largest industrial estate developer, predicting a "very good" year with sales of 1,200-1,300 rais (208 hectares) of land in the first half. The majority of Chinese demand is coming from companies setting up units to manufacture electric vehicles, auto parts, and electronics.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust’s private placement closes at S$2.212 apiece
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust's private placement closed at S$2.212 apiece, exceeding the estimated price range of S$2.16 to S$2.212. The placement was 4.5 times covered by strong participation from new and existing investors. The issuance of 92,593,000 new units is expected to begin trading on June 6, with the trust's manager expecting the acquisition to be distribution and net asset value per unit accretive to unitholders.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
MIT's data centres in North America alone make up just over half – or 50.3 per cent – of the Reit’s entire portfolio.
Of the 32 S-Reits that provided gross revenue figures in the latest reporting period, 23 reported an improvement while nine saw their topline decline.
Sabana Industrial Reit, the only Industrial S-Reit with all of its assets in Singapore, saw FY22 gross revenue rose by 15.9 per cent yoy, while NPI rose 2.6 per cent yoy.

An artist’s impression of Mapletree Industrial Trust’s proposed high-tech industrial precinct at Kallang Way. To-date, about 39 per cent of the redevelopment at 161, 163 and 165 Kallang Way’s net lettable area have been committed.

site_title: Gap posts surprise profit, shares jump 16% after hours
summary: Gap reported a surprise profit in the first quarter, with shares jumping 16% in extended trading. The apparel retailer cited restructuring efforts and easing supply chain costs as key factors. The company's quarterly merchandise margin increased 610 basis points due to lower air freight expenses and improved promotional activity. This marks a relief for US companies from years of supply-chain snags and sky-high costs. Gap's earnings beat expectations, providing a positive sign for the retail industry.

images.alt_text: Gap has yet to hire a new CEO since Sonia Syngal was ousted last July.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.1% to 3,210.81 points, following strong overnight gains on Wall Street. The top traded stocks were Seatrium and Singtel, with Singtel rising 0.4%. Meanwhile, US indices closed higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.9% and 1.7%, respectively, driven by Nvidia's record quarterly revenue forecast.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Industrial Trust's private placement of about 92.6 million units will be used to fund a new data centre acquisition in Osaka, Japan.

site_title: Ford CEO says China main EV rival, not GM, Toyota
summary: Ford CEO Jim Farley stated that Chinese electric vehicle makers are the main rivals to Ford, surpassing General Motors and Toyota, due to their scale and cost advantages. Chinese automakers have dominated EV production and possess the world's best battery technology. To compete, Ford needs to either adopt distinctive branding or reduce costs, but Farley questioned how to beat Chinese rivals on cost with their significantly larger scale.

images.alt_text: Lynk’s expansion plans are the latest example of Geely seeking to grow its foothold in Europe as the appeal of Chinese cars, particularly electric vehicles, increases.
The deals come as Ford races to secure supplies of battery materials to boost EV output and catch up with market leader Tesla amid surging demand for environment-friendly vehicles.

site_title: Australia retail sales flat in April as consumers cut back on food, dining out
summary: Australia's retail sales were flat in April, with volumes unchanged from March and a 0.1% decline in food sales. Consumers cut back on discretionary spending due to high living costs and rising interest rates. Despite a 4.2% year-over-year increase in total sales, the slowdown in consumer spending suggests the Reserve Bank of Australia's 375 basis-point rate hikes are having the desired effect of cooling demand. This data supports the case for a pause in rate hikes next month, with economists citing upside risks to the inflation outlook.

images.alt_text: David Jacobs, head of domestic markets at the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), says around A$20 billion of purchased bonds have matured and the pace would pick up to A$35-45 billion per year.

site_title: Emerging US debt deal would raise limit, cap spending for two years
summary: US negotiators close in on a deal to raise the debt limit and cap federal spending for two years, averting a potential default. The agreement would allow defence spending to rise 3% next year in line with Biden's budget request. While details are tentative, the sides have narrowed differences in talks. A final accord is still pending, but the emerging agreement brings relief to the US as time runs out to avoid a catastrophic default.

images.alt_text: A federal judge in Boston has set a May 31 hearing for a lawsuit filed by unionists contending that the 14th Amendment requires President Joe Biden to borrow funds to pay US obligations, regardless of what Congress does.

White-knuckled analysts in Singapore are monitoring developments closely, with some noting that the continued uncertainty could ironically strengthen the US dollar and weaken the Singdollar in the near term. PHOTO: Pixabay

The US Treasury Department in Washington, DC, on May 8, 2023. - US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned on May 7, 2023, that unless Congress acts soon to raise the nation's debt ceiling, "financial and economic chaos would ensue." US President Joe Biden will meet with the top Republicans and Democrats from Congress to breach the impasse. (Photo by Mandel NGAN / AFP)

site_title: Why investors are rediscovering Japan
summary: Global investors are rediscovering Japan's under-allocated stocks, which have been quietly transforming into one of the most attractive markets globally. Top-down regulatory overhauls are boosting capital efficiency, and Japanese companies have returned more capital to shareholders than ever, with record share buybacks and high dividend payments. Warren Buffett's $10 billion investment in Japanese stocks is a testament to the country's improving earnings yields and capital returns. Japan's steady and stable growth, driven by business reform and cost-cutting, has outgrown the developed world, with expanding margins and a relatively strong currency contributing to its relative outperformance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian holding her mobile phone walks past electronic boards showing the Japan's Nikkei average (top L) and the Japanese yen's exchange rate against the euro (top R) outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, February 9, 2016.  REUTERS/Yuya Shino/File Photo

A Tokyo Stock Exchange analysis shows that about half of the 1,800 companies on the exchange’s prime section were trading below their book value in January, meaning that the market is under-pricing the shares.
Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc

site_title: Louis Vuitton braves rain on its Italian island paradise
summary: Louis Vuitton's Cruise 2024 collection was presented on the Italian island of Isola Bella, despite heavy rain. The show, led by artistic director Nicolas Ghesquiere, took place in the Palazzo Borromeo, with celebrity guests such as Catherine Deneuve, Cate Blanchett, and Emma Stone attending. The collection featured eclectic, futuristic designs with a focus on texture and movement. The event marked the first-ever fashion show on Isola Bella, a former fishing village transformed into a luxury paradise.

images.alt_text: Ling Fu decided to start her own luxury handbag label when she got frustrated with the buying process of coveted handbags.
Abara's first boutique opened in Ngee Ann City shopping mall last week.

site_title: Mortgage rates in the US rise to highest level since mid-march
summary: US mortgage rates rose to 6.57% for a 30-year, fixed loan, the highest level since mid-March, according to Freddie Mac. This increase follows a jump in government bond yields amid federal debt-limit negotiations. Borrowing costs are creeping closer to last year's highs, adding to affordability issues for homebuyers. Federal Reserve policymakers are considering pausing interest-rate hikes in June but are not ready to end their campaign against inflation. This may lead to further fluctuations in mortgage rates in the coming weeks.

site_title: At Apec trade meeting, union leaders call for new ‘balance’ with China
summary: US trade policy with China and other nations must achieve a more balanced relationship between worker needs and corporate profits, said UAW president Shawn Fain at the Apec trade meeting. The US has lost 1 million union members since 1980, a decline Fain attributes to trade policy. Fain emphasized that the US is not against trade, but rather against one-sided agreements that favor corporations over workers. The UAW and US Trade Representative Katherine Tai called for a more equitable balance in trade negotiations.

images.alt_text: A jumbo screen showing the latest economy and stock exchange updates in Shanghai. Among equities, the worst performers this year are stocks tied to consumer spending, reflecting concerns over the fragility of the consumption-led recovery.

site_title: Allianz, AXA and SCOR quit UN climate alliance as insurers hold talks
summary: Three major insurers, Allianz, AXA, and SCOR, have quit the Net-Zero Insurance Alliance (NZIA) amid growing US opposition, citing concerns over antitrust laws. The move follows the exits of Swiss Re, Munich Re, Zurich Insurance, and Hannover Re, with at least five founding members now departed. Insurers are facing pressure to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, with the US state attorneys general warning NZIA members about potential antitrust law violations. The NZIA's future is uncertain, with Lloyd's chief executive John Neal advising the alliance to make membership rules less prescriptive.

site_title: Chipmaker Marvell Technology expects AI revenue to double this year
summary: Marvell Technology forecasts its artificial intelligence (AI) revenue to double this year, driven by the growing demand for AI technology and the success of open-source AI chatbot ChatGPT. The company expects its second-quarter revenue to reach US$1.33 billion, surpassing analyst estimates. Marvell's AI revenue is expected to continue growing rapidly, with CEO Matt Murphy stating that it will double again next year. This follows a similar forecast by Nvidia, and shares of Marvell rose 17.2% in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Outside of the United States Headquarters of Marvell Technology Group Ltd., Santa Clara, California, U.S., on Tuesday, February 8, 2011. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: ‘Food from air’ makes global debut in Singapore
summary: Finnish startup Solar Foods has introduced "Solein," a food ingredient produced from air, water, electricity, and microbes, making its global debut in Singapore. The powder, 65-70% protein, can be used to make various food products, including bread and pasta. The technology, similar to brewing beer, is gaining attention due to its potential to produce edible calories without farmland. Solar Foods plans to expand its commercial-scale plant, but approval in the EU is expected in 2025.

images.alt_text: Technology like these food dispensers are what eFishery offers to fish and shrimp farmers in Indonesia.

site_title: Viasat wins unconditional EU antitrust approval to acquire Inmarsat
summary: US company Viasat has won unconditional European Union antitrust approval to acquire British satellite rival Inmarsat for $7.3 billion. The merger, valued at $7.3 billion, does not raise competition concerns and is expected to close by the end of May. Viasat owns four geostationary Earth orbit satellites, while Inmarsat has 15. The deal has already received approval from the UK and US Federal Communications Commission.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Viasat offices are shown at the company's headquarters in Carlsbad, California, U.S. March 9, 2022. Picture taken March 9, 2022. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Gold faces third weekly drop on dollar strength, US debt deal hopes
summary: Gold prices fell near a two-month low on Friday, marking its third consecutive weekly decline, as the dollar strengthened due to US debt deal negotiations. Spot gold was flat at $1,939.18 per ounce, and US gold futures were down 0.2% at $1,939.60. The dollar's rise and benchmark Treasury yields near highs seen in March made gold less attractive for overseas buyers, while a deal to cut spending and raise the US debt ceiling is expected to bolster the dollar.

images.alt_text: The hallmark details on a one kilogram gold bar are seen at London bullion dealers Gold Investments Ltd. in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Thursday, April 4, 2013. Gold traders are split on whether bullion will plunge into its first bear market since 2008 as economies improve or rally as central banks buy more debt. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Russia moves ahead with deployment of tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus
summary: Russia has begun deploying tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus, according to President Alexander Lukashenko, who said the move had started with an order signed by Vladimir Putin. The deployment plan was announced by Putin in March, and the US State Department has denounced the move as "irresponsible behavior." The US has warned that use of nuclear weapons in the conflict would be met with "severe consequences," but has no intention of altering its strategic nuclear posture. Russia has more nuclear weapons than any other country, and the deployment is seen as a significant escalation in the conflict.

images.alt_text: “Today, relations between Russia and China are at an unprecedented high level,” Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin tells Chinese Premier Li Qiang in their meeting.

site_title: JPMorgan notifies some First Republic employees of job losses: source
summary: JPMorgan Chase has notified nearly 1,000 First Republic Bank employees of job losses as the company integrates the failed lender it bought in early May. The bank has offered employment to about 85% of First Republic's 7,000 employees for transitional or full-time roles, with temporary positions lasting 3 months to a year. JPMorgan claims to have been transparent with employees and kept its promise to update them on their employment status within 30 days.

images.alt_text:
First Republic Bank's incentive system helped drive up compensation for employees to an average of US$310,000 apiece last year, according to regulatory filings. 
The amount actually paid to individuals varied widely, depending on their roles, performance and the size of their client portfolios.
Scientists estimate that the world may need to remove billions of tons of CO2 from the atmosphere annually by mid-century to limit global warming.

site_title: Hyundai Motor Group, LG Energy to build US$4.3 billion EV battery plant in US
summary: Hyundai Motor Group and LG Energy Solution have announced a joint venture to build a US$4.3 billion electric vehicle (EV) battery plant in the US. The plant, located in Georgia, will start construction in 2023 and begin production by 2025, with an annual capacity of 30 gigawatt-hours to support 300,000 EVs. The move is in response to new US sourcing requirements for EV battery components, which will allow Hyundai and Kia vehicles to qualify for up to US$7,500 in tax credits under the Inflation Reduction Act.

site_title: Elon Musk’s Neuralink gets US FDA approval for study of brain implants in humans
summary: Elon Musk's Neuralink has received US FDA approval to launch its first-in-human clinical study for a brain implant aiming to treat paralysis and other neurological conditions. The approval comes after the company delayed its application for seven years, with the FDA rejecting it in March 2022. Neuralink's brain implant is designed to help paralysed individuals walk again and potentially cure other ailments. The company has been developing the implant since 2016, with Musk predicting human trials would start soon. The study's success could lead to a significant breakthrough in treating neurological disorders.

images.alt_text: The investigation has come at a time of growing employee dissent about Neuralink’s animal testing, including complaints that pressure from CEO Musk to accelerate development has resulted in botched experiments.

site_title: TikTok testing AI chatbot called Tako, research firm says
summary: TikTok is testing an AI chatbot called "Tako" that assists users in discovering short videos and encourages them to watch more content. Unlike ChatGPT, Tako is designed as a navigation assistant, providing users with relevant videos in response to their questions. The chatbot is currently being tested with select users in the Philippines and is available on some versions of the TikTok app on Apple devices. TikTok has set a disclaimer that responses from Tako may be inaccurate and warned users not to share private information with it.

images.alt_text: TikTok is currently facing federal- and state-level legislation that aims to ban or limit the app’s use in America on national security grounds.
FILE PHOTO: TikTok logo is displayed on the smartphone while standing on the U.S. flag in this illustration picture taken, November 8, 2019. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
TikTok called on the federal court to declare the Montana ban on its app unconstitutional and block the state from ever putting it into effect.

site_title: US pending home sales stall on lack of available properties
summary: US pending home sales stagnated in April, holding at 78.9, as high mortgage rates and limited inventory continued to curb buyer demand. Existing-home sales eased to a three-month low, while new-home purchases rose to the highest level since March 2022. The National Association of Realtors' chief economist, Lawrence Yun, attributed the slowdown to affordability challenges and a need for increased housing inventory to boost sales.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increases 12 basis points to 6.69 per cent, according to Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data.

site_title: Inflation in Japan’s capital slows slightly in May, but remains elevated
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation in Tokyo rose 3.2% in May, slowing from the previous month but remaining above the Bank of Japan's 2% target. This may lead to speculation of a gradual withdrawal of ultra-loose monetary policy later this year. The economy is recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic, but risks of a global slowdown and rising food prices persist. New Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda has stated that inflation must sustainably hit the 2% target and accompanied by solid wage growth before considering policy changes.

images.alt_text: The 10-year Japanese government bond yield has recently hovered around 0.4 per cent after the BOJ took a range of steps to counter market attacks against the cap.

Wednesday’s monthly poll, which tracks the Bank of Japan’s closely watched tankan quarterly survey, found that manufacturers’ mood is expected to rise further over the coming three months, while the service-sector morale slid only slightly.

site_title: Singapore Manufacturing Federation appoints CEO and CSO
summary: The Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) has appointed Dennis Mark as its new CEO, effective June 15, replacing Lawrence Pek. Mark, with over 20 years of experience in the manufacturing sector, will oversee the federation's operations. Additionally, Clement Teo was appointed as the first Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO) and Assistant Chief Executive, effective June 5, bringing expertise in sustainability to the organization, according to SMF President Lennon Tan, who stated that the new appointments will bring new ideas and focus to the federation's members.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Oil settles lower as Russia downplays additional Opec+ cuts
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday after Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak downplayed the prospect of additional Opec+ production cuts. Brent crude futures settled down 2.7% to $76.25 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude settled down 3.4% to $71.83 a barrel. The uncertainty surrounding Opec+ policy, following conflicting messages from top producers, led to the price drop.

images.alt_text: The US Memorial Day holiday on May 29 marks the beginning of the peak summer travel season and higher fuel demand.

site_title: OpenAI offers US$100,000 grants for ideas on AI governance
summary: OpenAI, backed by Microsoft's $10 billion, is offering $100,000 grants to researchers and experts to develop frameworks for governing AI software, addressing bias and other concerns. The grants aim to determine how AI should be governed to benefit all of humanity. The startup, which recently threatened to pull out of the European Union over proposed AI regulations, believes the results of the funding could shape its own views on AI governance. OpenAI's CEO, Sam Altman, has been a leading voice in calling for AI regulation, citing concerns over AI's potential to spread misinformation and factual inaccuracies.

images.alt_text: The updates to Bing are part of Microsoft’s effort to capture more of the estimated US$286 billion market for search advertising globally.
OpenAI plans to offer its app in more countries in the coming weeks and expects to roll out the Android version soon.

Sam Altman, who will testify for the first time since OpenAI’s ChatGPT exploded in popularity, plans to tell Congress that AI companies should be subjected to a “combination of licensing or registration requirements” for the release of advanced models.

site_title: US first quarter growth slightly higher than previously forecast
summary: The US economy experienced a slight increase in growth in the first quarter, with GDP rising to 1.3% compared to the previously forecasted 1.2%. This growth is attributed to an upward revision in private inventory investment. Despite this, the Federal Reserve predicts a mild recession towards the end of the year due to the impact of multiple interest-rate hikes to tackle inflation.

images.alt_text: Though claims for unemployment benefits rose moderately, they remain at levels consistent with a still-tight labour market.
US businesses have increased headcount, with companies reporting that vacancies were being more easily filled.
The US dollar index, which tracks the US currency against six major peers, rises to as much as 103.77, up 0.25 per cent on the day, its highest since Mar 20.

site_title: Metro Holdings’ H2 earnings up 54% to S$8.3 million
summary: Metro Holdings posted a 54% increase in second-half earnings to S$8.3 million, driven by a 10.5% growth in retail takings and a 12.8% increase in rental income. The company's full-year earnings rose 6.1% to S$25.2 million, with revenue up 16.7% to S$117.2 million. However, finance costs increased 68.8% to S$15.8 million due to higher borrowings and interest rates. The company recommended a final dividend of S$0.02 per share and special dividend of S$0.0025 per share, totaling S$0.0225.

images.alt_text: Metro’s retail division saw a 33.9 per cent year-on-year jump in revenue due to the lower base last year, when department stores had shorter operating hours as Singapore went through a “heightened alert” owing an increase in Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Boustead Projects H2 net profit nearly doubles to S$10.7 million
summary: Boustead Projects' net profit nearly doubled to S$10.7 million in the six months ended March 31, 2023, driven by a 97% increase in net profit and a 4% rise in revenue. The company's gross profit rose to S$14.8 million, and the board proposed a final ordinary dividend of S$0.007 per share and a special dividend of S$0.007 per share. The improved Covid-19 situation and construction activities being restored to pre-pandemic levels contributed to the growth.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

SGX Regco told Boustead Projects that it must restore its free float after its shares are suspended at the close of the takeover offer. Otherwise, Boustead Projects would be directed to delist and provide an exit offer which is deemed fair and reasonable.

site_title: How CBDCs can democratise banking and improve financial health
summary: Central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) have the potential to democratize banking and improve financial health by providing access to formal financial services for underbanked populations. Implementing CBDCs as a form of payment for public wages and salaries can encourage early adoption, as those receiving the digital currency are more likely to continue using it for payments. This can lead to improved financial health through increased savings, debt management, and access to financial services. Several countries, including the Bahamas, Ukraine, and China, have already begun testing CBDCs for such purposes.

images.alt_text: It seems that people actually like holding euro banknotes, despite the fact that, for many retail purposes, they are being replaced by more convenient digital means. This preference has implications for the digital euro.

The development of various digital currencies over the past few years implies a need for digital representations of money, and it is the job of the central banks to meet this need, said Agustin Carstens, general manager of BIS.
The promise and peril of central bank digital currencies

site_title: Volkswagen Group Singapore becomes agent for Cupra and Seat brands, prepares for EV shift
summary: Volkswagen Group Singapore (VW Singapore) will take over as the official agent for Cupra and Seat brands in June, marking a shift towards electric vehicles. VW Singapore will assume distributorship and dealership for Cupra and aftersales and service support for Seat, replacing agent Vertex Euro Motors. Cupra's fully electric hatchback, the Cupra Born, may launch in Singapore in 2024. Vertex will cease retail sales and aftersales support for Cupra in June and continue as a service partner for Seat until the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: US: Wall Street ends higher as Nvidia sparks rush for AI stocks
summary: US stocks ended higher on Thursday, driven by Nvidia's record-breaking forecast and surge in AI-related stocks. Nvidia's stock soared 24% as it ramped up supply for its AI chips, with investors exchanging almost $60 billion worth of shares. Other AI players like Microsoft and Alphabet rose, while Intel dropped 5.5% due to lagging in the AI race. The S&P 500 climbed 0.88% to 4,151.28 points, with the Nasdaq surging 1.71% to 12,698.09 points. Market uncertainty remains due to ongoing debt ceiling talks and economic growth slowdown.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.8 per cent to 32,799.92.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise moderately; first-quarter GDP growth revised up
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose moderately, increasing 4,000 to 229,000 for the week ended May 20, with prior week's data revised sharply lower. Despite this, claims remain consistent with a tight labour market. The low claims align with recent data on retail sales and factory production, suggesting the economy regained speed in the second quarter. The labour market has been resilient despite 500 basis points of interest rate increases, with 1.6 job openings for every unemployed person in March.

images.alt_text: A 'Now Hiring' sign outside a Starbucks Coffee location in Seymour, Indiana, U.S., on Monday, Dec. 6, 2021. U.S. job openings jumped in October to the second-highest on record, underscoring the ongoing challenge for employers to find qualified workers for an unprecedented number of vacancies. Photographer: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office forecast on Friday that the country could default on its debts by June 15 if lawmakers fail to agree on a deal with Biden to raise current limits on government spending.

A British Union flag on top of the Bank of England in the City of London, UK, on Monday, May 15, 2023. The upcoming batch of jobs data, due on Tuesday, May 16, is likely to show price pressures in the economy remain way too high for the Bank of England to tolerate. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Chip giant Nvidia nears trillion-dollar status on AI bet
summary: Nvidia projected quarterly revenue more than 50% above average Wall Street estimates, resulting in a 24% surge in stock value and a market capitalization increase of about $184 billion to nearly $939 billion. The chip designer's dominance in the AI market has sparked a rally in the sector, with analysts raising their price targets and predicting a potential trillion-dollar valuation. Analysts believe AI will drive growth, comparing Nvidia's potential to the impact of the internet.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of NVIDIA as seen at its corporate headquarters in Santa Clara, California, in May of 2022. Courtesy NVIDIA/Handout via REUTERS

site_title: Alibaba says to hire this year, refuting layoff rumours
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has announced plans to hire 15,000 people this year, refuting rumors that the company planned to cut 20% of its workers. The move includes hiring over 3,000 newly-graduated students. The company stated that talent movement is a normal process for all enterprises, including itself. However, its cloud unit has started a round of downsizing that will impact 7% of staff as it streamlines its business in preparation for an IPO.

site_title: US FDA approves Pfizer’s Covid antiviral pill
summary: The US FDA has granted full approval to Pfizer's oral antiviral Covid-19 treatment, Paxlovid, for adults at high risk of progression to severe disease. This approval allows Pfizer to sell Paxlovid at commercial rates on the private market in the US. The treatment, consisting of two oral drugs ritonavir and nirmatrelvir, was initially authorized in late 2021 for emergency use. The FDA's approval demonstrates the treatment's safety and effectiveness, providing doctors with more flexibility in prescribing it to high-risk patients.

site_title: US debt crisis: Biden vows ‘no default’
summary: US President Joe Biden has declared that the US will avoid a disastrous credit default, despite lawmakers' failure to raise the nation's borrowing limit. A federal judge has set a May 31 hearing for a lawsuit filed by unionists arguing that the 14th Amendment requires Biden to borrow funds to pay US obligations. The government estimates it could run out of money to service its debts by June 1, which could lead to a recession. Negotiations between Biden and Republican Speaker Kevin McCarthy have been "productive," but disagreements over spending cuts remain.

images.alt_text: White-knuckled analysts in Singapore are monitoring developments closely, with some noting that the continued uncertainty could ironically strengthen the US dollar and weaken the Singdollar in the near term. PHOTO: Pixabay
US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy has insisted that any deal must not raise taxes and must cut discretionary spending, not hold it steady as Biden has proposed.

site_title: Ralph Lauren results top estimates as shoppers snap up Polos, pricey sweaters
summary: Ralph Lauren reported a surprise rise in fourth-quarter revenue, beating profit estimates as its new seasonal collections resonated with affluent shoppers. The company's shares rose nearly 8% after posting a 30% jump in sales in China, where luxury spending has rebounded sharply. Despite overall US luxury spending taking a hit, Ralph Lauren's focus on outdoor wear and women's clothing collections drew more shoppers. The company's efforts appear to be paying off, with revenue exceeding expectations.

images.alt_text: Armani Group’s operating profit rises 30 per cent in 2022, to 202.5 million euros.

The increase of sales with Chinese shoppers, in mainland China and as they resume travelling, is “more than enough to compensate the temporary softness in the US,” says  Chanel’s CEO Philippe Blondiaux.

site_title: US hospital operator Cedars-Sinai launches Singapore venture unit
summary: Cedars-Sinai Medical Centre has launched a new Singapore-based venture unit, Coronet Ventures, to invest in early-stage healthcare and biomedical science startups. The unit plans to make equity investments in 12-15 Singapore startups over the next five years, with initial funding of up to $50 million. Coronet will focus on startups with "first-in-class and best-in-class" solutions, and has partnered with Enterprise Singapore's Seeds Capital to co-invest in startups. This marks the first time CSIP has set up an investment entity outside the US, with the goal of nurturing more disruptive healthtech startups in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The interest in preventive health technology has been rising globally.
Dr. Tan Min-Han, founder and chief executive officer, Lucence, sees the approval of Medicare as a door opener for other insurance providers in the US.

site_title: EU clears UBS takeover of Credit Suisse
summary: The European Commission has approved the takeover by UBS of Credit Suisse, ruling that the merger does not significantly reduce competition in the European Economic Area. The deal, worth 3 billion Swiss francs, was brokered after fears of contagion from the collapse of US regional banks. The commission found that the merger would not harm competition in the markets where the banks' activities overlap, allowing the takeover to proceed.

images.alt_text: “I think Credit Suisse is culturally challenged in the investment bank so we have to be very careful about – I use the term culture filter – who we bring in,” UBS Chairman Colm Kelleher says.
The order affects the top three levels of Credit Suisse management and follows the multi-billion franc state rescue of Switzerland’s second-biggest bank.

“The conclusion was very surprising to me, in terms of the way that the bank was resolved through this very unusual sale to UBS, with associated unusual payments to shareholders versus bondholders,” Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters says.
The Swiss government has also agreed to absorb up to 9 billion francs in potential losses incurred by UBS as a result of the takeover.

site_title: Vietnam’s VinBrain gives healthcare sector a leg-up with AI-infused solutions
summary: Vietnam-based healthcare startup VinBrain has developed AI-infused solutions to aid in faster and more accurate diagnoses of patients. The startup's flagship product, DrAid, uses AI analysis of chest X-rays to detect abnormalities in patients' hearts, lungs, and bones. By incorporating health data from millions of Vietnamese people, VinBrain aims to improve diagnostic accuracy and reduce health inequalities. The company's approach addresses the "data poverty" issue in AI tool development, where disparities in data sets can lead to biases and widen health disparities.

images.alt_text: 4k wallpaper, 4k wallpaper 1920x1080, background image

site_title: Chanel flags weaker US sales, sees pickup in China
summary: Chanel's US sales have slowed to a single-digit growth rate over the past six months, a decline from double-digit growth in 2022. The luxury brand attributes this to the post-pandemic spending splurge in the US tapersing off. However, sales in mainland China and among Chinese shoppers have picked up, compensating for the US softness. Chanel plans to accelerate hiring and invest in the US market, despite concerns about the US luxury market, where younger consumers are holding off on purchases due to economic uncertainty.

site_title: Soaring UK borrowing costs force lenders to hike mortgage rates
summary: UK lenders, including Nationwide, have raised mortgage rates in response to soaring market interest rates following strong inflation data. The two-year British swap rate has increased around 50 basis points, prompting lenders to hike rates on selected fixed and tracker mortgage products by up to 0.45 percentage points. This move is reminiscent of a temporary shutdown of the mortgage market in late 2022, triggered by investor reaction to a former UK prime minister's economic agenda. The increase in mortgage rates is expected to affect homebuyers and the broader housing market.

images.alt_text: Terraced residential housing in Sheffield, UK, on Friday, May 19, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK CPI Inflation data on Wednesday. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

site_title: How earphones freed the individual
summary: The invention of portable private sound, particularly earphones, has been a liberating force in modern society, allowing individuals to control their aural environment and mood. First introduced in 1979 with the Sony Walkman, this technology has enabled urbanites to live in a sensory bubble, shielding themselves from unwanted noise and distractions. While the impact of earphones has been widespread, their use remains uneven, with many still exposed to ambient noise. The author argues that mobile audio has been a more significant factor in improving urban living than other technological advancements, and that it has enabled the creation of "privatised pleasure palaces" where individuals can find solace in their own soundscapes.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) A picture taken on February 8, 2019 in Paris shows a smartphone and its earphones as an audio podcast is being played. As people brace for the disruptive impact of artificial intelligence on jobs and everyday living, those in the world of audio books say their field is already being transformed.
AI has the ability to create human-sounding recordings -- at assembly-line speed -- while bypassing at least part of the services of the human professionals who for years have made a living with their voices. (Photo by Thomas SAMSON / AFP)
The TPS-L2 was the first ever Sony Walkman to hit the streets in 1979.

site_title: Euro lower as Germany enters recession, US dollar scales 2-month peak
summary: The euro fell against the US dollar as Germany's economy contracted in the first quarter, entering a recession, and as worries mounted about a US default. The US dollar hit a two-month peak, benefiting from safe-haven demand. Fitch put the US' "AAA" debt ratings on negative watch, citing concerns over the debt ceiling. The US dollar index rose 0.3% to its highest since March 17, while the euro slipped 0.2% to a two-month low at US$1.0715.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product (GDP) falls by 0.3 per cent in the first quarter of the year when adjusted for price and calendar effects.

site_title: First Republic’s US$35 million banker out-earned JPMorgan’s Dimon before bust
summary: First Republic Bank's US$35 million banker out-earned JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon before the bank's collapse. The bank's incentive system paid employees an average of US$310,000 apiece last year, with some individuals earning over US$10 million annually. A banker's compensation exceeded US$35 million, surpassing Dimon's award. The bank's failure left the FDIC facing a multibillion-dollar hit, with regulators investigating potential insider trading. First Republic's failure was attributed to its high-risk jumbo mortgages and the collapse of its balance sheet.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co agreed to acquire First Republic from the FDIC which seized the bank after a tumultuous period in which its stock had cratered and depositors had pulled almost half their money.
FILE PHOTO: A First Republic Bank branch is pictured in Midtown Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo
First Republic has been struggling to find a rescuer for weeks, and any steps to raise capital or sell holdings quickly could be painful for current shareholders.

site_title: Boeing says top end of 2023 cash flow goal 'a bit pressured'
summary: Boeing's CFO stated the top end of its 2023 free cash flow forecast is under pressure due to supply-chain issues in its defense business. Despite this, the company maintains its forecast of $3 billion to $5 billion. Boeing has also restarted deliveries of reworked 737 jets after halting production due to manufacturing issues with supplier Spirit AeroSystems Holdings Inc. The company's shares rose 1% following the announcement.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as macro gloom weighs; luxury stocks rebound
summary: European stocks slipped 0.3% on Thursday, shedding 2.7% in three consecutive days, due to concerns over the US debt ceiling standoff and a global economic slowdown. Luxury stocks rebounded, stabilizing after a selloff, while energy stocks declined on a slide in crude oil prices. Technology stocks, however, rose, driven by European chipmakers, including Nvidia's forecast of a 50% above-estimate revenue boost. Germany's DAX slipped 0.3% after data showed the country's economy contracted in the first quarter, signaling a recession.

images.alt_text: The Europe-wide Stoxx 600 index slid 1.8 per cent, its worst one-day showing since mid-March, with all regional markets in the red.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 0.4% year on year in Q1, down from 2.1% in the previous quarter. The Ministry of Trade and Industry downgraded its 2023 export forecasts due to weak external demand and lower oil prices. Some economists predict a technical recession this year, despite the MTI's baseline scenario. The Singapore T-bill cut-off yield rose to 3.85% in the latest auction.

site_title: Local high-end handbag brand aiming for the stars
summary: Local luxury handbag brand Abara has opened its first boutique in Ngee Ann City shopping mall. Founder Yuki Yang, a Hunan native, started her career reselling luxury handbags in Shanghai before launching her own brand in 2021. Abara offers ready-made leather goods made with Italian calfskin and bespoke crocodile skin bags made in Singapore. The brand aims to put Singapore on the global fashion map, with plans to expand to South-east Asia and China. Yang's success is seen as a smart decision, given her humble beginnings and experience in the luxury handbag industry.

images.alt_text: Customers look at bags displayed at ZZER, a second-hand luxury goods platform in Shanghai, China, Sept 9, 2022.

site_title: German economy enters recession as inflation hurts consumers
summary: Germany's economy entered recession in early 2023, with GDP falling 0.3% in the first quarter, according to a second estimate from the statistics office. This follows a decline of 0.5% in the fourth quarter of 2022. Household consumption and government spending decreased significantly, while investment in machinery and equipment increased. The economy is expected to grow modestly in the second quarter, but analysts warn of weak economic activity due to factors such as high inflation, energy prices, and a slowdown in the US economy.

images.alt_text: “We want to present plans for the budget soon,” German Finance Minister Christian Lindner says.

It is the latest in a series of gloomy economic data out of Germany in recent weeks, denting hopes of a quick rebound after gross domestic product shrank by 0.5 per cent in the final quarter of 2022 on the back of high energy prices.

site_title: Aston Martin unveils new DB12 coupe amid Formula 1 successes
summary: Aston Martin has unveiled the new DB12 coupe, succeeding the DB11, with a V8 engine and starting at $245,000. The car boasts 671-bhp, a redesigned front end, and a hand-built engine. It features an all-new suspension system, an eight-speed automatic transmission, and five drive modes. The DB12 is wider and more powerful than its predecessor, with top speed at 325 km/h and a zero-to-100 kmh sprint of 3.5 seconds. The new car is a critical addition to Aston Martin's portfolio, aiming to boost sales after recent struggles.

images.alt_text: As part of a £234 million transaction, Geely will acquire a 17 per cent stake in Aston Martin.
Aston Martin launches 'swan song' V12 Vantage before going electric
Aston Martin posts lower 2021 loss on surging sales
Aston Martin F1 team signs long-term deal with Saudi’s Aramco

site_title: 3D printer maker Stratasys to merge with Desktop Metal in deal valued at US$1.8 billion
summary: Stratasys, a 3D printer maker, is merging with Desktop Metal in an all-stock deal valued at US$1.8 billion. The combined entity aims to diversify its customer base by offering designing, prototyping, and tooling services to mass production. Stratasys shareholders will own about 59% of the combined company, with Desktop Metal's CEO Ric Fulop saying the deal will complement their portfolio of production metal 3D printing solutions. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter of this year and generate US$1.1 billion in revenue by 2025.

site_title: UK energy bills to drop as easing gas costs finally register
summary: UK energy bills are set to drop 17% below the current government subsidy level, resulting in a £430 average reduction per household starting from July. This follows a decline in natural gas prices, which have fallen 65% this year. The new price cap, set by regulator Ofgem, will be below the Energy Price Guarantee, which kicks in if rates rise above a certain threshold. The drop is seen as a positive milestone in the government's efforts to halve inflation, but concerns remain about the impact on low-income and vulnerable households.

site_title: Sembcorp unit signs 10-year power purchase agreement with Singtel worth around S$180 million annually
summary: Sembcorp Industries' subsidiary Sembcorp Power signed a 10-year power purchase agreement with Singtel, valued at around S$180 million annually. The agreement will commence on October 1, subject to shareholder approval at Singtel's upcoming annual general meeting. This contract is expected to be accretive to Sembcorp's earnings for its 2023 financial year.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Food review: Tinto brings casual Spanish fare and garden flair to Dempsey in Daniel and Tamara Chavez’s new venture
summary: Tinto, a new Spanish eatery in Dempsey, Singapore, has transformed a pastel building into a vibrant Mediterranean playground. Owners Daniel and Tamara Chavez have perfected their formula from their previous success at Canchita, a Peruvian eatery. The menu features a compact selection of tapas, paella, and fideua, with bold flavors that sometimes overstep boundaries. Standout dishes include succulent prawns in chilli garlic oil, a refreshing crab salad, and saffron-infused Bomba rice. While the cooking can be inconsistent, the effort is genuine, and the ingredients are good quality. The restaurant's focus on ambience makes it a crowd-pleaser, with a beautiful conservatory surrounded by lush greenery.

site_title: Richard Branson’s space-tourism dreams face crucial test flight
summary: Virgin Galactic, a space-tourism startup founded by Richard Branson, is set to conduct a crucial test flight on Thursday, sending a six-person crew to the edge of space and back. The Unity 25 mission, led by two experienced test pilots, aims to assess the company's readiness for commercial service, which was initially expected to start in June 2023. A successful launch could alleviate concerns about financial viability, while a failure would raise doubts about the company's future. This test flight comes after a high-profile crash in 2014 and a recent bankruptcy filing by Virgin Orbit Holdings Inc.

images.alt_text: Virgin Galactic’s May flight would mark the first powered trip of the company’s VSS Unity spaceplane since July 2021.

Workers prepare the SpaceX Starship as the sun sets behind them ahead of the launch from the SpaceX Starbase in Boca Chica, Texas on April 18, 2023. - SpaceX has rescheduled for April 20, 2023, the first test flight of Starship, the most powerful rocket ever built, designed to send astronauts to the Moon, Mars and beyond, after a technical glitch forced a halt to the countdown. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)
Branson's Virgin Orbit reaches space for first time
Amazon's Bezos, latest tycoon to pursue his 'passion'
Virgin Galactic unveils newest spacecraft

site_title: Air-taxi makers urge investors to stay on board ahead of commercial lift-off
summary: Air-taxi firms like Volocopter and Lilium are facing challenges in securing investment ahead of commercial launch. The companies are navigating a risk-averse investment environment in Europe, combined with decreased tech stock valuations and economic pressures. Despite this, CEOs from the industry are urging investors not to lose faith, citing the potential for urban air mobility and the growing interest from cities worldwide. Volocopter plans to introduce its VoloCity air taxi in mega cities by 2024, with certification from regulators a key hurdle to overcome.

images.alt_text: The VoloCity, a two-seater multi-rotor aircraft, at the opening ceremony of the Volocopter-ITE Urban Air Mobility (UAM) Showcase at ITE College Central, 12 Jul 2022.
Volocopter raises 200m euros for air taxi certification push
Flying-taxi SPAC accused of stealing aircraft technology
Air taxi maker Archer seeks US$1b in damages from Boeing-backed rival
US flying taxi startup steps up legal pressure on rival over trade secrets

site_title: Apollo swells ranks in UK and Europe as private credit booms
summary: Apollo Global Management plans to increase its headcount in the UK and Europe, stepping in to provide more credit to back buyout deals amid tightening lending by Wall Street banks. The firm has doubled its staff in London over the past few years and expects this trend to continue. Apollo sees private credit as a "legitimate" tool for getting deals done, with lenders now earning interest rates north of 10%. The firm remains committed to the UK and western European markets, employing around 400 people across Europe.

site_title: Armani sales up 18% in Q1 as Asia rebounds, US faces slowdown
summary: Armani Group reported a 18% sales increase in the first quarter, driven by a rebound in Asia and modest growth in the US. The privately-owned luxury group's 2022 full-year revenues rose 16.5% to 2.35 billion euros, boosted by sales in Europe and the US. Operating profit increased 30% in 2022 to 202.5 million euros. The group expects a slowdown in the US in the coming months, which will be offset by a positive trend in Asia.

site_title: (Amended) UOB’s head of FX leaves to join Maybank
summary: UOB's head of foreign exchange, Yousoof Mohamed, is leaving the bank after just over one-and-a-half years to join Maybank, where he will lead a new team. Mohamed spent 27 years at ANZ before joining UOB, and two other UOB traders, Harry Lo and Lim Siow Wei, are also departing for Maybank. The trio's departure comes amid a period of change for UOB, with no further comment available from the bank.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
With the latest drop, the ringgit’s value has decreased by 4.15 per cent against the Singapore dollar since the start of the year.
DBS, OCBC and UOB branches in Singapore.

site_title: Malaysia signs US$2.3 billion in defence deals at biennial fair
summary: Malaysia's defense ministry signed agreements worth RM10.1 billion (S$2.95 billion) at the Langkawi Maritime and Aerospace exhibition, including the purchase of 18 FA-50 light attack aircraft from Korea Aerospace Industries for about US$920 million. Additionally, four units of Sikorsky's Black Hawk helicopters will be leased from Aerotree Defence and Services. The deals are part of Malaysia's efforts to modernize its defense capabilities.

site_title: Chanel’s 9,700-euro handbags may become even pricier in September
summary: Chanel's handbag prices, including the signature "flap" bags, may increase again in September, according to the company's chief financial officer. A classic medium-sized flap bag currently costs 9,700 euros in France, a 1,900-euro increase from 18 months ago. This would be the second price hike this year, following an 8% increase in March. The price review is typically conducted twice a year, in March and September.

images.alt_text: Chanel 2.55 Handbag in Aged Calfskin & Gold-Tone Metal Burgundy.

site_title: Goldman says big tech aversion capping gains for US mutual funds
summary: US mutual funds are underperforming broader indexes due to their reluctance to invest in big tech stocks, which have driven the market's rally this year. The average fund is 15 percentage points underweight Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon.com, Nvidia, Tesla, and Meta Platforms, according to Goldman Sachs. This underweight position has resulted in funds beating their benchmarks just a third of the time, compared to the long-term average of 38%. The recovery in US equities is led by tech giants, with the Nasdaq 100 Index up 24% and its best start to a year since 1998.

site_title: The 2022 Bordeaux wine vintage is brilliant – and a big surprise
summary: The 2022 Bordeaux wine vintage has exceeded expectations, with top winemakers praising its quality despite a challenging growing season. The extreme weather conditions, including April frosts, June rainstorms, record-breaking heat waves, severe drought, and hail, were expected to produce unbalanced wines. However, the resulting wines have been described as "amazing, unique," and "brilliant." This is attributed to the winemakers' adaptations, such as planting cover crops to train roots deep to obtain water, which has led to a remarkable outcome. The vintage is considered a surprise success.

images.alt_text: “Our brand awareness in China has gone up in the last two years on Penfolds,”  Australia’s Treasury Wine Estate chief executive Tim Ford says.

site_title: Thai Election Commission confirms opposition win in May 14 vote
summary: Thailand's pro-democracy parties won a majority of seats in the May 14 general election, with the Move Forward Party securing 151 seats. The coalition, led by Pita Limjaroenrat, claims the right to form the next government. However, Pita is short of the required 376 lawmakers to become prime minister. The Election Commission has until July 13 to certify the official results, paving the way for the first meeting of the House of Representatives and the selection of a new prime minister.

images.alt_text: The eight parties in Pita Limjaroenrat's (centre left) coalition have adopted a unified stance on issues including charter amendments and reinstating cannabis in the list of narcotics.

site_title: Swedish housing starts slump 55% in latest sign of crisis
summary: Sweden's residential property market experienced a 55% slump in housing starts in the first quarter, with 7,437 new dwelling starts compared to 16,675 in the same period of 2022. The sector is facing its worst crisis since the 1990s, with housing construction expected to more than halve in two years, according to the Swedish Construction Federation. The European Commission predicts Sweden will suffer the biggest economic contraction in the EU this year due to higher interest rates and a declining housing market.

site_title: Ringgit hits fresh low of RM3.42 against Singdollar on US debt ceiling jitters, weaker China economy
summary: The Malaysian ringgit hit a fresh low of RM3.42 against the Singapore dollar on May 25 amid concerns over the US debt ceiling impasse and China's weaker economy. The currency has declined nearly 4% year-to-date, with economists expecting a continued downtrend due to risk aversion and negative market sentiment. The US dollar's gain is attributed to expectations of another interest rate hike, while China's economic outlook is seen as a major factor in the ringgit's weakness, with exports to China declining nearly 20% year on year.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara Malaysia Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said: "The economy is no longer in crisis and in fact, continues to gain strenth."

site_title: Sifa 2023: Mixed bag of hits and misses
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (Sifa) 2023 kicked off with a mixed bag of hits and misses. Notable performances included "£¥€$ (Lies)" by Ontroerend Goed, a satirical theatrical game that explores the global economy, and "Abyss" by 99 Art Company, a contemporary dance piece that delves into Korea's deep-seated melancholy. Other works, such as "Materia" by Andrea Salustri and "Angel Island" by Huang Ruo and Brian Gothong Tan, were also praised for their unique concepts and artistic merits. However, some pieces, like "Realm Of Silk" by Sougwen Chung, were criticized for being underdeveloped. The festival runs until June 4.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Jane Lee's continues her exploration into the nature of painting with several stunning works. at SAM.
PheNoumenon choreographed by Kuik Swee Boon is the main highlight of the upcoming cont.act Contemporary Dance Festival.

site_title: The Hour Glass H2 net profit falls 5% on higher costs and expenses
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 5% decline in net profit for its second half of 2023, despite a 9% revenue rise to S$1.1 billion for the full year. Higher costs and expenses, including increased advertising and promotion activities, contributed to the decline in net profit. The company also wrote off goodwill from its acquisition of a New Zealand business unit. A final dividend of S$0.06 per share was recommended, unchanged from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Entrance of Malmaison by The Hour Glass, located at Knightsbridge, Orchard Road.
The company noted that the higher operating expenses were due to increased staff costs, rental expenses and advertising and promotion activities.

site_title: New banding system for developers, builders and private residential projects
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has introduced a new banding system, Conquas, to assess the quality of private residential projects in Singapore. The system categorizes developers, builders, and projects into Bands 1 to 6 based on the incidence of major defects. Bands 1 and 2 recognize good-performing firms with consistently delivered projects with no or very low incidences of major defects. Currently, 20 developers and 15 builders are in Band 1, and homebuyers can check project details and quality on the BCA's Quality Housing Portal.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
More project details, simpler payment schedule for homebuyers among URA's proposed changes

site_title: F&B group behind 1-Altitude to open 7 lifestyle concepts in Melaka skyscraper
summary: Singapore's 1-Group, the operator of the popular 1-Altitude rooftop dining and nightlife destination, is launching seven lifestyle and hospitality concepts in Melaka's tallest building, Hatten City. The total investment is expected to be over RM10 million (S$2.9 million), with the group occupying the penthouse space and various rooftop levels from the 44th floor upwards. The concepts, which will open in stages from July to December 2023, include a speakeasy bar, Italian fine-dining restaurant, Japanese-Peruvian fusion restaurant, and a rooftop bar and clubs, among others.

images.alt_text: Recipe for F&B growth in 2022

site_title: 🧳 Is unlimited leave truly without limits?
summary: Gen Zs are questioning the concept of unlimited leave, citing uncertainty and lack of clarity on its true nature. They express concerns that it may not be as flexible as claimed, sparking debate about its effectiveness. The article series explores Gen Z's job market struggles, including their desire to redefine management roles, necessary skills for employment, and the challenges of the job hunt. The series highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of Gen Z's workforce aspirations and the limitations of corporate jargon.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: Temasek-backed eFishery raises US$108 million Series D round, becomes unicorn
summary: eFishery, a Temasek-backed startup, has raised US$108 million in its Series D funding round, becoming a unicorn with a valuation of US$1.3 billion. The lead investor is 42X fund, with SoftBank and Northstar also participating. The startup provides technology, feed, financing, and market access to Indonesian fish and shrimp farmers, disbursing over 70 billion rupiah (S$6.3 million) to over 6,000 farmers since 2021. This funding round more than triples the company's pre-funding valuation of US$407 million.

images.alt_text: A fish pond equipped with eFishery dispensers in Subang Regency in West Java, Indonesia, on Sunday, June 26, 2022. The fish-feeding firm eFishery provides farmers with a dispenser that scatters pellets based on data from thousands of users. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
Benjamin Cher

site_title: Some economists brace for technical recession this year even as MTI says it is not expecting one
summary: Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) expanded 0.4% year-on-year in Q1, marginally better than expected, but still lower than the previous quarter's 2.1% growth. Despite this, some economists, including Maybank and UOB, warn of a technical recession due to a weak manufacturing sector and dire export outlook. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) does not expect a technical recession this year but notes downside risks and expects a "fairly flattish" growth in the first half, with a gradual pick-up in the second half.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore GDP grew 0.4% in Q1; full-year growth expected at mid-point of 0.5 to 2.5% range
A pilot boat sails past container vessels at Pasir Panjang port terminal in Singapore on January 3, 2023 (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Indonesia central bank keeps benchmark interest rate unchanged, as expected
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.75% for a fourth consecutive meeting, as expected. The move aims to support the rupiah currency and mitigate imported inflation. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that core inflation is within the target range and headline inflation is expected to return to target in the third quarter. Economists predict the bank may consider easing monetary policy to support growth amid slowing exports.

images.alt_text: Exports of copper, iron ore, lead, zinc and anode mud from copper concentrates will be allowed until smelters, many of which were delayed by the pandemic, are ready to handle the materials, says Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Arifin Tasrif.
All 31 economists in the May 15-22 Reuters poll expected no change to the 5.75 per cent seven-day reverse repurchase rate at its May 25 meeting, where it has stood since January.

site_title: Singapore stocks decline amid mixed regional showing; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,207.72 on Thursday, as regional markets showed a mixed performance. The decline was attributed to China's weak economic data and the People's Bank of China's inaction on monetary policies. Local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC rose, while DFI Retail Group fell 3%. The mixed regional market was driven by Japan's Nikkei 225 up 0.4%, South Korea's Kospi down 0.5%, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index declining 1.9%.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Centre at 2 Shenton Way, taken on 15 Feb 2019.
Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Startup Zuzu Hospitality bags US$9 million in Series B funding
summary: Zuzu Hospitality, a Singapore-based hotel tech services provider, has secured US$9 million in Series B funding led by SoftBank Ventures Asia. The funding will be used to double the company's hotel partner count and make strategic investments in artificial intelligence tools to improve pricing and guest management. Founder Vikram Malhi stated that the funding will enable the company to innovate its offerings further and accelerate its growth trajectory. The company aims to reach 5,000 partners by the end of 2024.

site_title: Australia's biggest wine-maker warns of demand hit from inflation
summary: Australia's largest winemaker, Treasury Wine Estates, has warned of a demand hit from inflation, with shares falling 7.8% due to challenging market conditions and a weaker performance of its commercial wine. The company is re-calibrating its business strategy, moving away from low-margin "commercial" wine towards higher-end products, and is undertaking a review of its domestic supply chain. Treasury Wine estimates a 2-3% drop in fiscal 2023 net sales revenue, citing a decline in entry-level premium wine sales in the US.

images.alt_text: avfeature11 - Penfolds II launch in Bordeaux

site_title: OK Lim relied on hard copy printouts from staff as he did not use a computer: witness
summary: Singapore's former oil tycoon Lim Oon Kuin, 81, is on trial for 130 forgery and cheating charges. A long-time employee of Hin Leong Trading, Katherine Ong, testified that Lim relied on hard copy printouts from staff, not computers, to make operational decisions. Ong described the accounts department's cash flow process, which involved updating an Excel spreadsheet and instructing banks on loan payments. Lim's son and daughter, Lim Chee Meng and Lim Huey Ching, were also signatories for bank documents. The trial, which began on April 11, will continue until July 20.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
How it all went south for Hin Leong
