site_title: Abu Dhabi makes its Falcon 40B AI model open source
summary: Abu Dhabi's Advanced Technology Research Council (ATRC) has made the Falcon 40B AI model open source for research and commercial use. Developed by the Technology Innovation Institute, Falcon 40B is a foundational large language model with 40 billion parameters and trained on one trillion tokens. The model will be backed by ATRC's commercial investment arm, VentureOne, to support viable ideas generated from its use. This move aims to promote innovation and collaboration in the field of artificial intelligence.

site_title: European Film Festival serves up a buffet for the filmgoer’s soul
summary: The European Film Festival is underway, featuring a diverse selection of films from across the European Union. Must-see picks include "The Quiet Girl" (Ireland), a poignant portrayal of childhood and grief, and "Hope" (Norway), a deeply moving exploration of terminal brain cancer. Other highlights include "Precious Ivie" (Germany), a humorous and earnest family drama, "Confine" (Italy), a documentary about civilian women fighting for peace, and "Champions" (Spain), a feel-good comedy-drama about a pro basketball coach. The festival runs until May 31.

images.alt_text: Return to Seoul follows Freddie (Park Ji-Min), a Korean-born French adoptee who returns to her homeland in search of her biological parents.

site_title: Woh Hup unit buys freehold Kew Lodge at Kheam Hock Road for S$66.8 million
summary: Woh Hup subsidiary Aurum Land has acquired a freehold landed site at Kheam Hock Road, Kew Lodge, for S$66.8 million, a 5% premium over the guide price of S$63.8 million. The 34,433 sq ft site will be redeveloped into 8-10 luxury homes. The land price is approximately S$1,940 per square foot. The sale is awaiting Strata Titles Board approval and owners may receive at least S$5.3 million for their units, depending on size. This acquisition broadens Aurum Land's scope into the landed property sector.

images.alt_text: Located in District 7, Golden Mile Tower was completed in 1974

site_title: China warnings flash across global markets as growth disappoints
summary: China's muted economic rebound and reluctance to deploy large-scale stimulus are affecting global markets, with commodity prices and equity markets weakening. The country's gross domestic product growth this year is expected to be around 5%, contrary to earlier expectations of a large overshoot. Consumer services are driving the recovery, while industrial activity lags behind, raising concerns about the fragility of the consumption-led recovery. This is leading to a correction in investor expectations for the world's second-largest economy.

images.alt_text: The central bank has held its policy rates steady since August 2022.
Nationwide lottery sales jumped 62 per cent on the year to 50.3 billion yuan, for the highest April figure in a decade.

Some analysts say local government financing vehicles have become the “black holes” of the country’s financial system, with surging debtloads exceeding US$9 trillion and weak revenues beginning to alarm investors.

site_title: The G7 must accept that it cannot run the world
summary: The G7's economic dominance is fading, with the US and Western countries' share of global output expected to decline from 44% to 30% between 2000 and 2023, while China's share is rising from 7% to 19%. The G7's comprehensive communique at the Hiroshima summit suggests a desire for cooperation, but its focus on a wide range of issues, including climate change and human rights, may be unrealistic. The G7 cannot "run the world," and a more realistic approach is needed, including greater representation for emerging economies like China and India, and a reevaluation of global economic governance.

images.alt_text: In his speech at the Nikkei forum in Tokyo, DPM Wong HAS reiterated that Asean will continue to grow its links with both the US and China.

“This is all about de-risking - not de-coupling,” Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak says. “With the G7, we are taking steps to prevent China from using economic coercion to interfere in the sovereign affairs of others.”

US President Joe Biden and other G7 leaders at Hiroshima Peace Park and Memorial Museum before participating in a wreath laying ceremony, on the first day of the G7 summit, in Hiroshima, Japan, May 19, 2023.
Senior EU and US officials want to use the May 30-31 Trade and Technology Council meeting to strengthen their cooperation in addressing the assertive rise of China.

site_title: Heatwave spells trouble for ringgit bonds as food prices to soar
summary: Malaysia's heatwave is expected to drive up inflation, threatening the nation's ringgit bonds. Benchmark yields may face further upward pressure, prompting Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) to tighten policy again. The central bank has delivered five rate hikes in the past year, and economists expect another hike if inflation risks persist. Despite this, some analysts believe the gains in Malaysian bonds may have run their course, with yields potentially dropping to 3.50% by year-end.

images.alt_text: Indonesia and Malaysia accounts for about 85 per cent of global palm oil exports and the EU is their third-largest market.
With the latest drop, the ringgit’s value has decreased by 4.15 per cent against the Singapore dollar since the start of the year.
Bank Negara Malaysia Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said: "The economy is no longer in crisis and in fact, continues to gain strenth."

site_title: De-risking, taken too far, will lead to fragmented and decoupled world economy: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warns that de-risking from China, aimed at reducing dependencies, could lead to a fragmented and decoupled global economy. In a speech at the Nikkei forum, Wong notes that geopolitical lines are being drawn, and global foreign direct investment flows are becoming more concentrated among countries aligned with the US and China. He cautions that a fragmented economy will lead to less trade, investments, and ideas, potentially harming Asia's growth and development. Wong emphasizes the need for open economic cooperation and the restoration of the World Trade Organization's effectiveness to prevent a system where "might is right and the law of the jungle prevails".

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) said he was happy to see Chinese Premier Li Qiang again, "in a different capacity".

site_title: Head of French Olympic Committee steps down: statement
summary: Brigitte Henriques, the president of the French Olympic Committee (CNOSF), has stepped down from her position a year before the Paris 2024 Summer Games. Henriques had requested an internal audit of the CNOSF amid a long-standing dispute with former general secretary Didier Seminet, whom she accused of "psychological violence." The IOC has been notified of her request. Henriques' resignation comes after she returned to her position last December following a two-month leave. Seminet has denied the allegations and filed a defamation suit against Henriques.

site_title: Crypto lender Celsius picks Fahrenheit’s bid for bankruptcy exit
summary: Celsius, a bankrupt crypto lender, has chosen Fahrenheit's bid to manage a new entity, Celsius Network (NewCo), owned by creditors. Fahrenheit will provide capital, a management team, and technology. NewCo will be overseen by a new board, majority-appointed by creditors. Celsius initially planned to accept NovaWulf's bid but took more time to develop additional bids. A backup bid was secured with the Blockchain Recovery Investment Consortium. Celsius filed for Chapter 11 protection in July 2022, following the rapid growth of the crypto industry during the pandemic.

site_title: URA releases state land sites for sale in Woodlands, Toa Payoh, Punggol
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) released two residential sites and a commercial site for sale in Singapore. The residential sites, located in Woodlands and Toa Payoh, have a combined yield of 1,125 units and will be sold under the first half 2023 Government Land Sales (GLS) programme. The commercial site in Punggol Walk has a 30-year lease and is expected to attract interest due to the lack of office space in the area. Developers anticipate keen demand for the sites, with prices ranging from S$950 to S$1,050 per square foot per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: The site at Lentor Central is launched under the confirmed list while Lentor Gardens site was launched under the reserve list for H1 GLS 2023.
The Tampines Avenue 11 and Plantation Close land parcels can potentially yield about 1,685 residential units, said the Housing & Development Board (HDB) in a press statement.
In all, the seven new sites in both the confirmed and reserved lists can generate 2,075 private homes.

site_title: BYD and Great Wall Motor locked in rare war of words over emissions
summary: Great Wall Motor has accused BYD of failing to meet China's pollutant emissions standards for its two top-selling hybrid models. The accusation was made in a report filed with the ecology and environment ministry, industry and information ministry, and top market regulator on April 11. BYD responded that its products comply with China's standards, sparking a rare public dispute between the two companies.

images.alt_text: EV car Good Cat by Ora, a brand by Great Wall Motors, is displayed at the Bangkok International Motor show in Bangkok, Thailand, March 22, 2022. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

site_title: Fitch puts US credit rating on negative watch as debt ceiling deadline looms
summary: Fitch Ratings has placed the US credit rating on a negative watch due to the looming debt ceiling deadline, citing the high risk of a downgrade if lawmakers fail to raise the debt ceiling or suspend it before the X-date. The agency expects a deal to be reached but warns that the risks have risen that the government could miss payments on its obligations. A downgrade could affect the pricing of trillions of dollars of Treasury debt securities, and Fitch's prediction is that the US government will spend more than it earns, creating a deficit of 6.5% in 2023 and 6.9% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Money market mutual funds have enjoyed US$614.8 billion in net inflows so far this year.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.8 per cent to 32,799.92.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds fire again on rates, trims growth forecast
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) held interest rates steady for a third meeting, keeping the policy rate at 3.5%, as expected. The decision follows a one-and-a-half-year-long tightening cycle, with inflation and economic growth easing. The BOK cut its economic growth forecast to 1.4% from 1.6% and kept its inflation projection unchanged at 3.5%. The decision matches predictions from 40 economists surveyed by Reuters, who forecast a rate cut in the final quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea (BOK) complex in Seoul. Photographer: Woohae Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust buys Osaka data centre for 52 billion yen, to raise S$200 million via new units
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has acquired a 45,280 sq ft Osaka data centre in Japan for 52 billion yen (S$507.9 million), with a weighted average lease to expiry of about 20 years. The trust plans to raise S$200 million via issuing new units at an issue price of between S$2.16 and S$2.212 per unit. The acquisition is expected to be distribution per unit and net asset value per unit accretive to unitholders. The trust aims to finance the transaction through a combination of debt and equity, with the new units expected to be issued on June 6.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) and sponsor Frasers Property Limited (FPL) jointly acquired a 50 per cent stake in suburban mall Nex for S$652.5 million.
MIT's data centres in North America alone make up just over half – or 50.3 per cent – of the Reit’s entire portfolio.

site_title: Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling to step down from operating roles by year-end
summary: Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling will step down from her operating roles and directorship by year-end, ending the dual stewardship of the company's co-founders. Tan, who has led technology development, will remain as an adviser. The move comes as Grab seeks to win back investors, having only recently turned a profit. Tan's departure follows an internal memo from CEO Anthony Tan, who praised the company's leadership bench.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on March 18, 2022 shows ride-hailing and food delivery company Grab's co-founder and chief operating officer Tan Hooi Ling speaking during an interview in Singapore. - As co-founder of the multi-billion company, Tan Hooi Ling is already smashing stereotypes in tech -- but she's also blazing a trail for the next generation of female entrepreneurs in the industry. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP) / TO GO WITH Singapore-Grab-transport-women, INTERVIEW by Martin Abbugao
Sharanya Pillai
Claudia Chong

site_title: Australian tech tycoon nears rescue of US$20 billion solar project to send power to Singapore
summary: Australian tech tycoon Mike Cannon-Brookes' consortium, including Quinbrook Infrastructure Partners, is in final talks to acquire the collapsed US$20 billion solar megaproject Sun Cable. Grok Ventures, Cannon-Brookes' family office, is nearing a deal with FTI Consulting, the administrators for Sun Cable, after competing with Squadron Energy. Deliberations are ongoing, with no certainty of a deal. The consortium aims to send power from Australia to Singapore via a high-voltage direct current undersea cable, following a similar model used in European countries.

images.alt_text: Singapore welcomes Sun Cable to resume discussions when it is ready to do so, said Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong.

Sun Cable designed its key project, Australia-Asia PowerLink, to send power from a 20 gigawatt (GW) solar farm in northern Australia across what would be the world’s longest undersea cable, to Singapore.
While it would be a sweet victory for climate goals to see this radical project take fruition, Sun Cable’s fate has been eclipsed by shareholder spat

site_title: Nondisruptive creation: An alternative to innovation and growth?
summary: Business leaders have long viewed "disruption" as a synonym for innovation, but researchers W Chan Kim and Renee Mauborgne argue that there's an alternative: "nondisruptive creation." This approach involves creating brand-new markets outside existing industry boundaries, achieving growth without displacing jobs or industries. Examples of nondisruptive creation include Cirque du Soleil's creation of a new market space in circus and theatre, and Pfizer's development of Viagra, which solved a prevalent problem without displacing the existing industry. The authors argue that this approach can lead to positive-sum growth, where both business and society thrive together.

images.alt_text: Creative destruction? Once upon a time, venture capitalists refused to fund anybody who didnt promise to break things.

site_title: Chinese hackers spying on US critical infrastructure, Western intelligence says
summary: US and Western intelligence agencies have confirmed that a state-sponsored Chinese hacking group, dubbed 'Volt Typhoon', has been spying on critical US infrastructure organizations, including telecommunications and transportation hubs. The hacking group, active since 2021, has targeted industries such as manufacturing, utility, and government, and could potentially target US military networks and critical infrastructure if China invades Taiwan. The US National Security Agency is working with partners to identify breaches and has urged companies to take action to prevent malicious activity.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping has made science and technology pillars of his long-term vision for China’s national wellbeing.
US lawmaker warnings about China e-commerce fashion retailers such as Shein could signal upcoming regulatory action.

site_title: Singapore T-bill’s cut-off yield at 3.85% in latest auction
summary: Singapore's six-month Treasury bill (T-bill) closed with a cut-off yield of 3.85% per annum, seven basis points higher than the previous auction. The higher yield is attributed to market expectations of a potential US Federal Reserve rate hike in the third quarter. The auction received 2% competitive applications and was 2.3 times subscribed, with a median yield of 3.6% and average yield of 3.15%. The higher yield may impact demand for future T-bill auctions, prompting market speculation about potential changes in Singapore's investment options under the Central Provident Fund.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Demand for the latest six-month T-bill and Singapore Savings Bond fell, according to data released on Wednesday.
For the 6-month T-bills’ yield to break past its glorious 4.4 per cent record, a sharp spike in inflation will be needed to drive interest rates higher.
Savvy investors have been applying to invest their CPF savings – particularly OA funds with lower yields – with many opting for Singapore Treasury bills.
OCBC and UOB’s Central Provident Fund Investment Account customers using their ordinary account savings will be able to buy T-bills online.

site_title: RBI may need to buy 1.5 trillion rupees of bonds to add cash: ICICI
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) may need to buy up to 1.5 trillion rupees of government bonds to replenish banking liquidity, which is expected to tighten later in the year. The central bank has already injected 468 billion rupees into the banking system via a repo auction on May 19. Higher spending amid state elections and a busy credit season in October may lead to money leaving the system, causing liquidity to tighten. The RBI's move aims to maintain banking liquidity at current levels, with estimates suggesting it will add about one trillion rupees of liquidity.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) seal is pictured on a gate outside the RBI headquarters in Mumbai, India, February 2, 2016. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo
“The governor also emphasised the need for banks to ensure continued financial and operational resilience,” according to a statement from the RBI.

site_title: London leads record increase in rental costs across UK
summary: London experienced a record 5% increase in rental costs in April, the steepest annual rate since 2012, as landlords hike rents to cover rising mortgage costs. The trend is a growing concern for the UK government amid a cost-of-living crisis. Private tenants are competing for a limited supply of homes, with the average UK house price increasing by 4.1% in the year to March. The shortage is attributed to an exodus of smaller landlords, with new legislation aimed at making it harder to evict tenants.

images.alt_text: A view of residential properties with the skyline of London's financial district seen behind, seen from Alexandra Palace in London on January 15, 2023. (Photo by Justin TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: Swatch dares Malaysia to confiscate rainbows after Pride watches raid
summary: Malaysia's home affairs ministry confiscated over 100 Swatch watches from its Pride Collection, sparking a furious response from the watchmaker. The watches, featuring rainbow wristbands, were deemed "harmful" by the authorities, fueling concerns about the country's commitment to LGBTQ rights. The move has raised doubts about the government's commitment to minority rights, amid resurgent support for conservative parties. The raids have been criticized as a "political game" by the government, with rights groups urging the government to promote acceptance and understanding rather than repression and discrimination.

images.alt_text: In a summons notice against one Swatch outlet, the law enforcement unit of Malaysia’s home affairs ministry said “22 Swatch watches with LGBT elements” have been confiscated.

site_title: Sri Lanka could wrap up debt restructure talks by September, president says
summary: Sri Lanka's president, Ranil Wickremesinghe, expects the country to conclude its debt restructuring talks by September or November, marking a significant progress in negotiations. The talks aim to restructure Sri Lanka's $7.1 billion debt, with $2.9 billion secured from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in March. The IMF has called for timely restructuring pacts with creditors, and the country's macroeconomic situation is improving, according to the global lender.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka is banking on information technology, solar and wind, bunkering and mineral processing to attract investments.
Sri Lanka has battled its worst economic problems since independence in recent years, after protests over soaring inflation, food shortages and lengthy power cuts toppled the government.

site_title: Solar power investment set to surpass oil production spending this year
summary: A record $1.7 trillion will be invested in clean-energy technologies this year, surpassing $1 trillion in fossil fuel supplies and power production. The International Energy Agency (IEA) notes that clean-energy spending is growing 24% this year, outpacing 15% growth in fossil fuel investments. While progress is being made, the report warns that investment levels will need to double by 2030 to meet global warming goals. Fossil fuel investment, particularly in coal, is expected to reach a record high this year, but will need to decline sharply to align with a net-zero emissions scenario by mid-century.

images.alt_text: Wind turbines, at the RWE offshore windpark Kaskasi, north of Helgoland, Germany, March 23, 2023.
China is adding intermittent wind and solar generation at a much more rapid pace than energy storage.
China already has the world’s largest fleet of renewable generation and plans to boost that with about 455 gigawatts of wind and solar in mainly desert areas.

To complete its transition to carbon neutrality with total phase-out of coal by 2050, the government estimates it needs a whopping US$658 billion, of which one-fifth would have to be disbursed this decade.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip at Thursday’s open after GDP data; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at Thursday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 11.07 points to 3,203.14. The decline came after the Ministry of Trade and Industry estimated the full-year GDP growth to be around the mid-point of its forecast range of 0.5 to 2.5%. The US stock market also declined, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.8% and the S&P 500 down 0.7%. The decline in Singapore and US markets was attributed to concerns over the US debt ceiling negotiations.

images.alt_text: Singtel's total dividend for the full year is S$0.149 per share.

site_title: Honestbee ex-staff, trade creditors won’t get any of the S$320 million owed
summary: Honestbee, a failed grocery delivery startup, has no money left to pay former staff, vendors, and other creditors who are owed S$319.9 million. Its sole secured creditor, Formation Group, recovered about S$700,000 from the startup's assets, far short of its US$4 million worth of debentures. The liquidator, BDO, is set to apply to the High Court to discharge itself and dissolve the company, marking the end of the road for honestbee, which was placed under liquidation in July 2020 after failing restructuring attempts.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Joel Sng left his CEO position at honestbee in 2019.
Mirae Asset Daewoo awarded US$5.1m claim against ex-honestbee CEO Joel Sng

site_title: BOJ may abandon bond yield cap this year: government panellist
summary: The Bank of Japan may abandon its 0.5% bond yield cap this year if global risks subside, according to economist Toshihiro Nagahama. The cap has drawn criticism for distorting market pricing, and the BOJ must ensure steady wage and consumption growth before raising interest rates. Nagahama suggests the central bank will wait until concerns over global banking sector woes and the US debt ceiling standoff ease before considering a move. If markets remain calm, the BOJ may tweak yield curve control, potentially removing the cap as early as this year.

images.alt_text: Wednesday’s monthly poll, which tracks the Bank of Japan’s closely watched tankan quarterly survey, found that manufacturers’ mood is expected to rise further over the coming three months, while the service-sector morale slid only slightly.
Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda participates in a news conference at the Fairmont Washington D.C. Georgetown hotel in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: Bank of America to ask about 40 bankers in Asia to find jobs in other units
summary: Bank of America plans to redeploy 40 bankers in Asia to other divisions to address the decline in dealmaking in China and the country's economic slowdown. The majority of affected employees are in junior positions, primarily based in Hong Kong. This move aims to avoid headcount reduction and instead offer a temporary solution. The redeployment is part of the bank's efforts to manage the industry-wide decline in dealmaking and focus on growing its business in the middle-market sector.

images.alt_text: “Clients recognise the fact that there are only a few institutions like ours that can make the investments to remain committed over the long term, and at a larger scale,” says BofA's Bernard Mensah.

site_title: ‘Extensive to moderate’ redesign needed for 2 in 5 roles in food services: Jobs Transformation Map
summary: Singapore's food services sector is undergoing a transformation, with 12 out of 30 identified job roles expected to require "extensive to moderate" redesign over the next three years. The Jobs Transformation Map, launched by Enterprise Singapore and EY, identifies trends such as shifting consumer preferences, increased technology adoption, and greater competition for workers. New job roles emerging include a sustainability specialist, while existing roles can be reconfigured to include new skill sets, such as a food and beverage operations associate. The map recommends redesigning operations around future opportunities and challenges, and optimising processes using technology and data analytics.

images.alt_text: The refreshed ITM for the food services industry looks to shift the focus towards catalysing innovation to create new revenue streams and encourage food companies to capture new growth opportunities.
Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling and Senior Minister of State for Communications and Information Tan Kiat How with service robots installed by local cafe chain Heavenly Wang.

Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Trade and Industry, viewing automated pau encrusting at Sin Mui Heng Food Industries. The dim sum manufacturer is set to automate 80 per cent of its processes by 2023.

site_title: China RRR cut gives bigger growth boost than rate move
summary: China's central bank may provide a bigger boost to economic growth by cutting the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) rather than interest rates, according to a Bloomberg Economics report. A 25 basis point reduction in the RRR could add 500 billion yuan to banks' liquidity, boosting growth by 0.3 percentage point, compared to a 0.1 percentage point increase from a 10 basis point cut in the policy rate. The report suggests that monetary easing could help boost confidence and signal growth as the focus, amid China's softening recovery.

images.alt_text: For Xi Jinping’s Communist Party, the secretive industry represents something far more ominous: a threat to national security that must be reined in.
Helen Wong, CEO, OCBC
Some analysts now expect the PBOC could lower the amount of cash banks must set aside as its next policy move.

site_title: Asia: Most markets down as US debt impasse sparks Fitch ratings warning
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday as the US debt impasse sparked a Fitch ratings warning, with most markets down by over 1%. The US debt limit standoff has raised concerns about a potential default, which could have devastating economic consequences. Despite Fitch's "rating watch negative" notice, the agency still expects a resolution before June 1. Markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Manila, and Jakarta fell, while Tokyo and Taipei edged up. Analysts warn that investors are growing increasingly agitated and risk-averse, with a possible downgrade of the US credit rating on the horizon.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Tokyo gave up more than one per cent, while there was also hefty selling in Shanghai, Seoul, Sydney, Taipei, Singapore, Manila, Wellington and Jakarta on Wednesday.

site_title: Ron DeSantis jumps into White House race but Twitter launch marred by glitches
summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis announced his candidacy for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, launching his campaign on Twitter with a video featuring Elon Musk. However, the event was marred by technical glitches, drawing attention to the governor's executive competence. DeSantis, 44, faces a tough challenge from former President Donald Trump, who has a 2-to-1 lead in polls and has had a head start in organizing his campaign. DeSantis will focus on defeating Democratic President Joe Biden, citing his record as governor and his ability to lead the country.

images.alt_text: Ron DeSantis, the leading Republican rival to Donald Trump, will announce his 2024 US presidential bid on May 24, 2023, during a live Twitter event with Elon Musk, a source familiar with his plans told AFP.
Unfiltered by his aides, Trump damaged himself in the CNN town hall on May 10 for purposes of a general election campaign.

site_title: Indonesian, Malaysian palm oil producers set for talks with EU  about deforestation law
summary: Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's largest palm oil producers, will send top officials to the European Union to discuss concerns over a new deforestation law that could impact small farming businesses. The law, approved by the European Parliament, bans imports of commodities unless companies provide "verifiable" information on deforestation. Both countries have accused the EU of discriminatory policies targeting palm oil and have expressed concerns about the law's potential impact on smallholders. The visit aims to discuss ways to minimize negative effects on smallholders and the global supply chain.

images.alt_text: BMI Research, a unit of Fitch Solutions, noted that CPO prices have averaged RM3,872 per tonne this year as at May 19, nearly 20 per cent lower than they were at end-2022.
The expansion will be done in phases based on the readiness of biodiesel blending facilities across Malaysia, Commodities Minister Fadillah Yusof says.

site_title: Gold steady after release of Fed minutes, debt talks in focus
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,957.69 per ounce after the US Federal Reserve released minutes from its last meeting, signaling a possible pause in rate hikes in June. The minutes also indicated that further rate increases may not be necessary, with Fed officials stating the need had become less certain. Meanwhile, debt ceiling negotiations kept investors cautious, with US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen maintaining a June deadline for a potential default. The dollar index held firm, making gold less attractive for overseas buyers.

images.alt_text: The dollar index held firm, keeping a lid a gold prices.

site_title: Default on US debt risks ‘permanently’ denting nation’s credit rating
summary: The US government's debt ceiling standoff risks permanently denting its credit rating if a default occurs, according to three major ratings companies. Fitch has placed the US rating on watch for a downgrade, and Moody's has warned that a default would lower its rating, potentially dropping the US from the top tier of highly rated debt issuers. A brief default could alter the perception of debt-ceiling brinkmanship, leading to a permanent downgrade, with S&P having previously lowered its rating in 2011. The US benefits from its central role in the global economy, but doubts about its creditworthiness could spook foreign investors.

images.alt_text: The US Treasury Department in Washington, DC, on May 8, 2023. - US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned on May 7, 2023, that unless Congress acts soon to raise the nation's debt ceiling, "financial and economic chaos would ensue." US President Joe Biden will meet with the top Republicans and Democrats from Congress to breach the impasse. (Photo by Mandel NGAN / AFP)
A stronger dollar makes bullion less attractive for overseas buyers.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.8 per cent to 32,799.92.

site_title: AI frenzy helps Asia tech exporters’ shares beat US growth woes
summary: Interest in artificial intelligence has driven a surge in shares of Asia's technology hardware exporters, outperforming US growth. The Goldman Sachs basket of Asian exporters has risen 11% this year, compared to 3.1% in the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index and 7.2% in the S&P 500. The electronics cycle is seen as having bottomed out, with global semiconductor sales rising for the first time in ten months. Investors are optimistic about the sector's fundamentals, despite geopolitical risks, and expect further gains for Asian exporters, which trail the US rally.

images.alt_text: A man is reflected in an electronic stock board showing stock information at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, July 14, 2009. China's benchmark stock index, the Shanghai Stock Exchange Composite Index, rose 0.52 percent at 9:35 a.m. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg News

site_title: The US-Asean corridor: Opportunities aplenty as the bloc moves ahead
summary: US foreign direct investment (FDI) in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has accelerated, surpassing investments in China, Japan, South Korea, and India combined in the first half of 2022. Asean's economy is projected to reach $5.2 trillion by 2027, driven by a young, educated, and growing population. US firms see significant opportunities in various sectors, including technology, pharmaceuticals, and sustainability. However, navigating Asean's complex laws and regulations, as well as ensuring political stability and governance, is crucial for success. A reliable partner, such as Standard Chartered, with a presence in every Asean nation, can provide valuable expertise and support for US firms looking to tap into the region's growth potential.

images.alt_text: Steven Cranwell
Freddy Ong , head, Client Coverage, Singapore, Corporate, Commercial & Institutional Banking, Standard Chartered.

site_title: Yoma Strategic H2 loss widens to US$32.7 million on higher finance costs
summary: Yoma Strategic's net loss widened to US$32.7 million in the second half-year ended March 31, 2023, from US$14.8 million the previous year, primarily due to higher finance costs. Revenue rose 126.1% to US$82.7 million, driven by record home sales and the completion of the Wave Money acquisition. The company remains cautiously optimistic about its business prospects, focusing on improving profitability and cash flow.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Yoma in February 2022 announced a change of its financial year end from Sep 30 to Mar 31. Its financial reporting period for FY2022 will therefore span 18 months from Oct 1, 2021, to Mar 31, 2023.
Both IFC and ABD, lenders to Meehyahta, have agreed to grant the latter a standstill period until Jun 15, 2025.

site_title: Xi remade China’s tech industry in his own image with crackdown
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has reshaped China's tech industry in his own image through policy, capital, and decree, prioritizing research and development of homegrown alternatives to foreign semiconductors. The tech sector has seen significant growth, with hardware companies accumulating over $100 billion in cash reserves, while Internet companies like Alibaba and Tencent have also grown rapidly. However, regulatory risks have eased, and the sector's future is uncertain due to intensifying competition and US efforts to restrict Chinese access to technology. Xi's focus on national strategic needs and scientific research may mark the frontlines of China's tech war with the US.

images.alt_text: For Xi Jinping’s Communist Party, the secretive industry represents something far more ominous: a threat to national security that must be reined in.
The 'Jing-Jin-Ji' region’s development will focus on sectors such as integrated circuits, network security and power equipment and biopharmaceutical industry.

site_title: Nvidia shares surge 21% as sales forecast jumps and AI booms
summary: Nvidia's shares surged 21% to a record-high $370 after the company forecast second-quarter revenue exceeding Wall Street estimates, driven by a booming artificial intelligence (AI) market. The AI boom has helped Nvidia become the fifth-most valuable US company by market value, with the company boosting supply to meet surging demand for its AI chips. Nvidia's data centre chip sales beat analyst estimates, with net income rising to $2.04 billion.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is the world’s top maker of graphics processing units (GPUs), which are in high demand because they can be used to speed up artificial intelligence work.
Nvidia’s two biggest markets during the pandemic were China and Taiwan, which between them accounted for more than half of the company’s revenue in fiscal 2022.

site_title: Singtel H2 net profit up 6.1% to S$1.1 billion, proposes final dividend of S$0.053
summary: Singtel reported a 6.1% increase in H2 2023 net profit to S$1.1 billion, driven by growth in its mobile segment, price uplifts, and rising 5G adoption. The telco's operating revenue fell 4.2% to S$7.4 billion. The company proposes a final dividend of S$0.053. This result translates to an earnings per share (EPS) of S$0.0639 for H2.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Derryn Wong
Singtel said it expects to benefit from the recovery in international travel as borders continue to reopen.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit’s recent buy highlights risk of buying properties with short lease
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit successfully completed a private placement, raising S$500 million to partially fund the purchase of The Shugart. The issue price of S$2.727 per unit offered a 3% discount to the previous day's volume-weighted average price. This move is seen as a positive step for the trust, strengthening its balance sheet. The development comes amid rising interest rates making it more challenging for Reits to raise equity.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Clar's manager says the private placement draws "strong demand from new and existing institutional, accredited and other investors".

site_title: SIA reintroduces appetisers to economy class meals; lists tender for hot towel
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will reintroduce appetisers to economy class meals starting June 1, 2023, for medium, long-haul, and ultra-long-haul flights. Meals on short-haul flights will include a bread roll and butter, along with a main course and dessert. Despite a 20% increase in in-flight meal budget compared to FY2019 and 2020, SIA expects lower capacity.

images.alt_text:
[SIA has made airline food palatable with
recipes from a panel of eight renowned chefs
from around the world. ]

site_title: Vietnam EV maker recalls some US SUVs due to software error
summary: Vietnam-based electric vehicle maker VinFast is recalling some US SUVs due to a software error causing malfunctioning head unit displays to go blank. The recall affects an unspecified number of vehicles, with an over-the-air software update set to be released on May 25. The move comes after the company's VF 8 City Edition received negative reviews, with some citing the vehicles' readiness for the US market. VinFast plans to build a factory in North Carolina and deliver vehicles to Europe this summer.

images.alt_text: Interior of a VinFast’s VF8 electric vehicle. Photographer: Linh Pham/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s Netflix revives Hong Kong listing plan after curbing losses
summary: China's streaming giant, iQiyi, is reviving its plan to list in Hong Kong, seeking new investors to finance original programming and AI-driven content. The company, which has lost nearly $5 billion since 2018, is projected to report its first annual profit in six years in 2023. CEO Gong Yu credits cost discipline and selective content for turning around the company's financials. iQiyi aims to deliver double-digit growth this year and is working on technical details for a Hong Kong share float, despite facing challenges in convincing investors due to its 70% decline in value since its 2018 IPO.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cainiao's logo, Alibaba's logistics unit, is seen at the warehouse in Wuxi, Jiangsu province, China October 26, 2020. Picture taken October 26, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
iQIYI, China’s answer to Netflix, has recorded quarterly profits only a couple of times and is expected to report its first annual profit this fiscal year since going public.

site_title: Singapore downgrades 2023 export forecasts on weaker-than-expected Q1 showing
summary: Singapore has downgraded its 2023 export forecasts due to weaker-than-expected Q1 showing, citing weak external demand and lower oil prices. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) are now expected to contract by 8-10% and total merchandise trade by -8% to -6%. Private-sector economists are mixed on the outlook, with some expecting a tentative recovery in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: A pilot boat sails past container vessels at Pasir Panjang port terminal in Singapore on January 3, 2023 (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Tessa Oh

site_title: Tina Turner: The raw power of rock ‘n’ roll
summary: Tina Turner, a rock 'n' roll legend, passed away at 83 in Switzerland. She overcame abuse during her marriage to Ike Turner and emerged as a star on her own, inspiring many with her resilience and determination. Turner's music and life epitomized heart, energy, and the power to thrive in the music industry for five decades. Tributes poured in from artists like Magic Johnson, Janet Jackson, and Beyoncé, praising her as a trailblazer and a true entertainer.

images.alt_text: Tina Turner sells music rights to BMG
Tina Turner meets 'new generation' with moving new documentary

site_title: Republicans, White House see progress in US debt ceiling talks
summary: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and President Joe Biden held productive talks on raising the US debt ceiling, with progress reported. McCarthy stated that negotiations have improved, and an agreement is expected, despite unresolved issues. The talks aim to avoid a catastrophic default without raising taxes and instead focus on cutting discretionary spending. The meeting marked a positive step in the negotiations, with both sides expressing optimism about reaching a deal.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden, left, confers with House Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) during a St. Patrick's Day luncheon at the Capitol in Washington on March 17, 2023. The US Treasury is running out of cash, leaving little time to resolve a debt ceiling standoff that could result in default.

The US Treasury Department in Washington, DC, on May 8, 2023. - US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned on May 7, 2023, that unless Congress acts soon to raise the nation's debt ceiling, "financial and economic chaos would ensue." US President Joe Biden will meet with the top Republicans and Democrats from Congress to breach the impasse. (Photo by Mandel NGAN / AFP)

site_title: Sri Lanka expects FDI to jump to US$1.3 billion with India taking lead
summary: Sri Lanka expects foreign direct investment (FDI) to rise by 20% to $1.3 billion this year, with India likely to lead, despite the country's economic crisis. The country raised FDI by 38% last year to $1.08 billion, with proposals worth $600 million received in the first quarter. Sri Lanka is targeting investments in information technology, solar and wind, bunkering, and mineral processing to attract investors, including India's Adani group and Japan's MCS Group.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka has battled its worst economic problems since independence in recent years, after protests over soaring inflation, food shortages and lengthy power cuts toppled the government.

site_title: PropertyBT: Foreigners’ love for Singapore property (Ep 19)
summary: Foreigners are increasingly attracted to Singapore's housing market, driven by its safety and strong currency, despite high transaction costs and low yields. Senior correspondent Leslie Yee and Alan Cheong, executive director of Savills Singapore, discuss the impact of higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty and foreign interest in non-residential properties. They also explore the perception of locations and the potential for more restrictions on foreign property ownership. The podcast highlights the ongoing appeal of Singapore properties despite uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Mature or non-mature estate for BTOs?
Maybe more help can be extended on the homeownership front to local couples who bust the income ceiling to buy BTO flats.
Robust demand and a strong currency can draw foreigners to Singapore property despite high taxes and low yields.

The rarity of shophouses make it a valuable tool in wealth preservation, especially for high-net-worth individuals and family offices, said Richard Tan, PropNex senior associate group district director.

site_title: Talent crunch creates drag on Malaysia’s goal of becoming global medtech hub
summary: Malaysia's medtech industry faces a significant challenge due to a severe talent shortage, hindering its progress in moving up the value chain. The country aims to become a global offshore manufacturing hub for medical devices, but industry players say a lack of skilled professionals in automation and high-tech companies is a major obstacle. To address this, the government is exploring ways to upskill the existing workforce and attract more foreign talent, including creating special packages for highly skilled workers and their families.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Tan Ru-Ding, managing director of FlexMech, said the precision enginering sector has made significant strides in work conditions and offers lucrative career prospects now.

site_title: Oil prices gain 2% on falling US stockpiles, Saudi warning
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on May 24, driven by a 12.5 million-barrel drawdown in US crude inventories and a warning from Saudi Arabia's energy minister that Opec+ may consider further production cuts. Brent crude futures rose to $78.36 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $74.34 a barrel. The US Memorial Day holiday marks the start of peak summer travel season and higher fuel demand. Analysts attribute the price increase to tightening supply and demand, despite concerns about the debt ceiling and interest rates.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose 85 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$76.84 a barrel on Tuesday

site_title: Singapore GDP grew 0.4% in Q1; full-year growth expected at mid-point of 0.5 to 2.5% range
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 0.4% in Q1, slightly higher than the 0.1% growth in advance estimates. The country's external demand outlook for the rest of the year is expected to weaken, with full-year growth likely to fall within the 0.5-2.5% range. Despite this, the government is not expecting a technical recession this year, with growth expected to pick up gradually in the second half of the year. Key sectors such as manufacturing and wholesale trade are expected to contract, while sectors like construction, tourism, and aviation are expected to remain resilient.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
A pilot boat sails past container vessels at Pasir Panjang port terminal in Singapore on January 3, 2023 (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

Singapore’s economy has grown 0.1 per cent year on year in Q1, advance estimates from the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) on Friday (Apr 14) show, slower than the 2.1 per cent expansion recorded in the fourth quarter of last year.

site_title: EU, Google to develop voluntary AI pact ahead of new rules
summary: The European Union and Google are developing a voluntary artificial intelligence (AI) pact ahead of new EU rules. EU industry chief Thierry Breton met with Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai to agree on the pact, aiming to establish minimum AI standards before legislation takes effect. Breton also urged EU countries and lawmakers to finalize the commission's proposed AI rules by the end of the year. This cooperation aims to establish a unified approach to AI regulation before the EU's rules come into force.

site_title: Montenegro court scraps bail for crypto entrepreneur Do Kwon
summary: A Montenegrin higher court has scrapped the bail of 800,000 euros for Do Kwon, a South Korean cryptocurrency entrepreneur charged with a multibillion-dollar fraud in the US, and his ally Han Chang-joon, pending a trial. The pair, who were detained in March, had attempted to board a flight to Dubai. A higher court agreed with the prosecution that the bail could not be taken as a guarantee and that the defendants' promise to stay in Montenegro would not be sufficient. The defendants remain in pre-trial detention.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Do Kwon, the cryptocurrency entrepreneur, who created the failed Terra (UST) stablecoin, is taken to court in handcuffs, to face charges of forging official documents, in Podgorica, Montenegro, March 24, 2023. REUTERS/Stevo Vasiljevic MONTENEGRO OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN MONTENEGRO/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks fall again as key debt deadline looms
summary: US stocks fell 0.8% on Wednesday as a critical debt ceiling deadline looms, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping to 32,799.92. President Biden offered to freeze government spending, and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned the US could run out of money to pay existing obligations as early as June 1. Despite this, some individual companies saw gains, including Citigroup, Palo Alto Networks, and retailers Abercrombie & Fitch and Kohl's.

site_title: Fast-fashion giant Shein plans Mexico factory: sources
summary: Shein, a fast-fashion giant, plans to build a factory in Mexico as part of its push to localise production. The factory, expected to produce Shein items, aims to shorten shipping times and cut distribution costs for Latin American customers. This move follows its announcement to build a manufacturing network in Brazil. Shein's recent capital raise of $2 billion will fund the expansion, despite a valuation cut to $66 billion. The company's localisation strategy aims to expand product variety and support local economies, with plans to launch a similar marketplace in the US.

site_title: Higher EP salaries for renewals mean employers may have to give big raises – or lose workers
summary: Singapore's Employment Pass (EP) qualifying salaries will increase with age, starting at S$5,000 for those aged 23-29, S$6,000 for 30-39, S$7,500 for 40-49, S$9,500 for 50-59, and S$11,500 for 60 and above. The changes aim to provide a level playing field, preventing locals from being exposed to lower-paid foreigners. However, some companies worry about retaining skilled workers, with some converting EP holders to S Passes or considering outsourcing non-critical functions to countries like Malaysia and the Philippines.

images.alt_text: Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Mar 02, 2023. Elysia Tan
Renald Yeo

site_title: Two hundred days of Rishi Sunak
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has managed to last 200 days in office, surpassing his predecessor Liz Truss's 49-day tenure. However, his party's divisions over Brexit and economic issues, such as inflation, pose significant challenges. The Conservative party's internal conflicts, including a recent put-down of a Brexit supporter, indicate a deep malaise. Sunak's attempts to address these issues, including a promise to reduce inflation, are being met with skepticism, and some critics accuse him of abandoning his anti-EU stance.

images.alt_text: While Sunak has said that he wants to get immigration down “over time”, his focus has been on reducing the number of people arriving on Britain’s shores in small boats.
The results suggest Sunak still has a long way to go to turn his party’s fortunes around after a chaotic 2022 that saw the Tories oust two prime ministers – Boris Johnson and Liz Truss.
British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is the richest ever occupant of 10 Downing Street, and his fortune has opened him up to regular attacks from opposition politicians.

site_title: Candidates for Singapore’s next president remain elusive
summary: Singapore's next presidential election, due by mid-September, has yet to see new candidates emerge. Strict requirements introduced in 2017 have reduced the likelihood of a non-establishment candidate, with the current president, Halimah Yacob, potentially facing a contest. The requirements, which include public sector and private sector service, have led to a potential pool of only around 50 and 1,200 companies, respectively. The strict rules may result in uncontested elections, deepening the perception of the president as a figurehead and undermining the elected presidency's check on the government.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s most recent presidential election in 2017 was a walkover for Halimah Yacob as there were no other eligible Malay candidates.
The proposed amendments will also allow for polling stations to be set up in adjacent electoral divisions, to make it more convenient for voters who stay near an electoral boundary.

site_title: BlackRock prevails over shareholder activists at annual meeting
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, prevailed over shareholder activists at its annual meeting, with each director nominee receiving "well over a majority" of votes. The company's CEO, Larry Fink, received 92% support for his pay, while climate resolutions received less than 10% support, and a resolution targeting diversity policies won less than 1%. BlackRock's stance on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) policies was seen as a middle ground, with Fink stating the company's role is to work with clients, not to engineer decarbonization.

images.alt_text: BlackRock headquarters at 50 Hudson Yards in New York, US, on Monday, May 1, 2023. BlackRock Inc.'s assets swelled to $9.09 trillion in the first quarter as depositors sought cover following the collapse of several US banks by pouring money into the firms cash-management funds. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Golden Mile Tower’s bid at S$600 million collective sale closes with no bids
summary: The collective sale of Golden Mile Tower in District 7, Singapore, closed on May 8 with no bids at S$600 million, the reserve price. Despite this, private treaty negotiations are underway with "several" interested parties. The 99-year leasehold commercial development is valued at S$598 million, with owners expecting to receive between S$370,000 and S$14.7 million for retail units and S$540,000 to S$12.4 million for office units if the reserve price is matched.

images.alt_text: Golden Mile Tower, a 99-year leasehold commercial development at 6001 Beach Road.
Jessie Lim

site_title: Charging ahead: Indonesia’s EV revolution and the road to success
summary: Indonesia is poised to become a significant player in the global electric vehicle (EV) market, driven by its growing middle class, urbanization, and abundant natural resources, particularly nickel for EV battery production. The government has set a target to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 31.9% by 2030, with policies and initiatives designed to foster the growth of the EV market. The country aims to allocate 7 trillion rupiah (S$633.2 million) in state funds to subsidize electric motorcycle sales, with incentives such as tax breaks, subsidies, and financial assistance for buyers.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor’s IONIQ 5, a model eligible for the tax cut, sees sales jump three-fold to more than 600 units in April.
Nickel smelting in South Sulawesi province. Indonesia produced one million metric tonnes of nickel in 2021 and earned US$21 billion in revenue from those exports.
An excavator loads raw nickel ore into a dump truck at a nickel mining site of Vale in Sorowako, South Sulawesi province, Indonesia, March 29, 2023.
There were nearly 32,000 electric motorcycles on Indonesia’s roads as of October last year and the government hopes that adding another 1 million by 2024 will help reduce fossil fuel consumption.
Oyika offers single-use, weekly and monthly packages for electric motorbike riders to swap their motorbike batteries at a “swap station”.

site_title: Boeing to embed experienced pilots with new airline customers
summary: Boeing is deploying experienced pilots to airlines that are training employees to fly Boeing aircraft, as part of efforts to reduce aviation safety risks. The company has 125 "flight operations representatives" working with over 60 airlines, mostly former retired airline pilots with 13,000+ flight hours. Boeing hopes to recruit more, but faces challenges in retaining a workforce. The move comes after two 737 MAX crashes in 2018 and 2019, and is part of Boeing's wider safety initiative.

images.alt_text: Boeing announced plans in February to double its SAF purchases in 2023, buying 5.6 million gallons of fuel from Neste.

site_title: What’s next for AI after the G7 summit?
summary: G7 leaders have called for the development of standards to keep artificial intelligence (AI) trustworthy, recognizing the increasing significance of cyberwarfare and AI in the global arena. The summit addressed issues such as responsible AI, global AI governance, and digital competition, acknowledging AI's potential impact on various sectors and the need for balanced governance and education to reap its benefits while managing its risks. The declaration emphasizes the importance of global cooperation and inclusive solutions to address the complexities of AI, as its effects will not be limited by geographical boundaries.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden and other G7 leaders at Hiroshima Peace Park and Memorial Museum before participating in a wreath laying ceremony, on the first day of the G7 summit, in Hiroshima, Japan, May 19, 2023.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Yoma Strategic, Meta Health
summary: Singtel reported a 6.1% increase in net profit to S$1.1 billion for the second half ended March, with a proposed total dividend of S$0.149 per share. Yoma Strategic's net loss widened to US$32.7 million for the six months ended March, driven by net fair value losses and impairment losses. Meta Health commenced legal proceedings against its former chief medical officer and may impact its financial performance. Mapletree Industrial Trust requested a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: A world of debt
summary: A global debt crisis is unfolding, with 41 heavily indebted countries facing financial difficulties. However, the situation varies between two groups: those that borrowed more to finance pandemic-related expenditures and those with high and rising debts due to ill-advised domestic policies. The IMF works with governments to formulate policies to restore growth and creditworthiness, but debt reduction and restructuring are often hindered by private lenders, particularly China, which has been reluctant to restructure debts. To address this issue, officials from creditor countries' governments will meet to agree on debt-restructuring terms, which may include a reduction in debt value or a rescheduling of principal repayments.

images.alt_text: Market scene in Colombo, March 20, 2023. Cash-strapped Sri Lanka was seeking a 10-year moratorium on its foreign debt.
Kantamanto market in Accra, Ghana, Nov 30, 2022. Ghana recently became only the fourth country to apply for support under the G20's Common Framework facility.

site_title: Bank of England’s Bailey sweats over risk of ‘sticky’ summer for inflation
summary: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey expressed concern over the risk of "sticky and stubborn" inflation over the summer, citing the recent fall in food prices and core inflation. The consumer price index rose 8.7% in April, higher than expected, and food prices are up 19% over the past year. Bailey emphasized the need to focus on food prices and core inflation, which gathered steam, and warned that inflation could fall slowly from now on. The BOE is likely to raise interest rates further to tame inflation, with economists predicting a 5.25% interest rate by September.

images.alt_text: A customer carries grocery shopping bags in Sheffield, UK, on Friday, May 19, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK CPI Inflation data on Wednesday. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

site_title: Santander targets dozens more Credit Suisse hires in M&A push
summary: Banco Santander is in talks to hire dozens more Credit Suisse dealmakers, including senior bankers and junior bankers under them, as part of its push to expand its talent base, particularly in the US. The move comes as Credit Suisse faces uncertainty over its pending sale to UBS Group. Santander has offered generous compensation packages and is targeting 20% annual growth in its US corporate and investment bank. The recruitment effort is being led by José Linares and Darren Jones, with some Credit Suisse bankers concerned about potential job losses or being passed over for promotions.

images.alt_text: “I think Credit Suisse is culturally challenged in the investment bank so we have to be very careful about – I use the term culture filter – who we bring in,” UBS Chairman Colm Kelleher says.
The order affects the top three levels of Credit Suisse management and follows the multi-billion franc state rescue of Switzerland’s second-biggest bank.

site_title: Citi’s US$7 billion Banamex sale scuttled after Amlo intervenes
summary: Citigroup's planned $7 billion sale of its Mexican retail unit, Banamex, has been scrapped after Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador (Amlo) intervened, seizing a section of Grupo Mexico's railroad tracks and introducing bills that would extend the state's reach into aviation and mining. This move spooked potential buyer Grupo Mexico, led by billionaire Carlos Larrea, into seeking assurances that the banking industry wouldn't be next. With no deal possible, Citigroup has decided to proceed with an initial public offering (IPO) for the business, which will allow the bank to resume share buybacks and simplify its operations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past a Citibanamex bank branch in Mexico City, Mexico January 30, 2023. REUTERS/Henry Romero/File Photo

site_title: UK set to win battle to host Tata electric car battery plant: BBC
summary: The UK is set to win the bid to host a multibillion-pound electric car battery plant from Tata Motors, according to a BBC report. The decision is seen as a major boost to the British car industry, following warnings from major automakers about the risks of post-Brexit trade rules. The plant's location in the UK would also help the country catch up with global battery production, addressing concerns about tariffs on British cars under the upcoming trade rules. Tata Motors' boss is expected to finalize the deal in London next week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tata Motors' electric sport-utility vehicle (SUV) Nexon EV is displayed during its launch in Mumbai, India, January 28, 2020. REUTERS/Hemanshi Kamani/File Photo

site_title: Activist investor Cevian ends Aviva campaign after selling stake
summary: Activist investor Cevian Capital has sold its entire stake in British insurer Aviva, ending its campaign to drive up investor payouts. Cevian praised Aviva CEO Amanda Blanc and her management team for improving the company's fortunes, despite mixed quarterly trading figures. Aviva has paid out over £5 billion to investors since 2021. The firm deemed Aviva well-positioned for continued success, but its shares fell 5% on the day.

images.alt_text: Aviva said it had paid more than £5 billion to investors since 2021, including a final dividend of 20.7 pence per share for 2022.

site_title: India's Adani Group weighs US$3 billion investment in Vietnam
summary: India's Adani Group is considering a $3 billion investment in Vietnam, initially in Lien Chieu Port in Danang. Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh welcomed the investment, stating that the country is willing to create favorable conditions for Indian companies to invest and do business. The meeting between Chinh and Adani CEO Karan Adani took place in Hanoi, marking the start of negotiations for the potential investment.

site_title: Amazon to expand in UK with WeWork space for 1,000 staff
summary: Amazon has agreed to take 70,000 square feet of space at Moore Place in the City of London from WeWork, accommodating approximately 1,000 staff. The deal includes an option to expand into more space. The agreement comes after Amazon had been weighing expansion of its London office footprint before the 2020 coronavirus pandemic. Details of the deal remain private, with WeWork declining to comment and Amazon not immediately responding to a request for comment.

site_title: EU sets out plans to cut the price of financial products
summary: The European Union has set out plans to reduce the cost of financial products for retail investors, aiming to encourage investment and deepen its capital market. The retail investment package includes a ban on banks and insurers paying commissions to brokers who provide no advice to customers. Currently, retail investors pay 40% more in fees than institutional investors, with only 17% of EU household assets invested in stocks and bonds, compared to the US. The EU aims to make its capital market more efficient and attractive to investors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, June 5, 2020.  REUTERS/Yves Herman//File Photo

site_title: Mortgages in the UK look set to get a lot more expensive
summary: The UK's mortgage market is expected to become more expensive due to high inflation, which may lead to a peak interest rate of 5.5%. This could further increase mortgage rates and make it harder for potential homebuyers to afford properties. The Bank of England's data shows net mortgage lending fell to virtually zero in March, and over a million homeowners will face refinancing this year with potentially higher payments. Economist Niraj Shah predicts house prices will drop by 10% from last year's peak.

site_title: Why Singapore depository receipts are quite different from Clob
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is launching Singapore depository receipts (SDRs) for three Thai companies: Airports of Thailand, CP All, and PTT Exploration & Production. This marks a significant move to broaden the scope of investments available in the Singapore market to include overseas-listed companies. Unlike the failed Clob International market, which was not recognized by Malaysian authorities, the SDRs are backed by the Securities and Exchange Commission of Thailand and are expected to be a successful initiative, offering a new opportunity for Singapore investors to gain exposure to the Thai market.

自撮马股持有人排队接受效益资本的分批转移自撮马股献议。[Clob
investors queuing at DBS securities.]

site_title: Fewer SMEs ran environmental and social programmes in 2022: survey
summary: Singapore SMEs saw a decline in environmental and social initiatives, with 52% conducting at least one initiative in 2022, down 7% from 2021. Cost was the top barrier, cited by 32% of respondents. Other challenges included a lack of staff skills and time constraints. The survey also found that 51% of SMEs experienced workplace incidents in 2022, highlighting the need for improved workplace safety and health measures. The results suggest that SMEs are prioritizing short-term impacts over long-term climate change risks.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Most SMEs are preparing for a rise in expenditure in the next 12 months, the survey by QBE Insurance found.

site_title: Meta Health starts legal proceedings against ex-chief medical officer of subsidiary
summary: Meta Health, a healthcare technology company, has commenced legal proceedings against Vasanthan Metupalle, the former chief medical officer of its subsidiary 5Digital, over alleged irregularities in sale transactions of another subsidiary, Gainhealth. Other parties involved include a former director and entities not part of the company. The lawsuit aims to recover losses and wrongful payments. The outcome may impact Meta Health's financial performance for the 2023 financial year.
