site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as debt ceiling impasse keeps investors on edge
summary: US stock markets opened lower on May 24, 2023, due to a deadlock in talks between the White House and Republican representatives over raising the debt ceiling. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 33.75 points, or 0.10%, to 33,021.76, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The impasse has kept investors on edge, contributing to a lower opening on Wall Street.

site_title: Airbnb preps for ‘anti-party’ summer, wants neighbours to snitch
summary: Airbnb is implementing an "anti-party" system for Memorial Day and Fourth of July weekends to ease strained relationships between hosts and guests. The system uses guest reviews and booking patterns to identify high-risk reservations and blocks them. Neighbors are encouraged to report parties to Airbnb's support line. This measure follows a pilot last year and a global party ban introduced in 2020, requiring guests to make an "anti-party attestation" upon booking. The goal is to reduce unauthorized parties and improve host relations.

site_title: German Cabinet approves legal framework for hydrogen core network
summary: The German Cabinet has approved a draft law to create a hydrogen core network, aiming to expand reliance on hydrogen as a future energy source to make the economy more green and reduce reliance on Russian gas imports. The network is scheduled to go into operation by 2032 and will be integrated into the existing gas distribution network. The plan also includes a comprehensive hydrogen network development plan, which will be ready by the end of the year. Germany aims to become climate-neutral by 2045.

site_title: No date in sight for end of Germany’s budget dispute
summary: Germany's budget dispute between coalition partners remains unresolved, with Finance Minister Christian Lindner failing to commit to a timetable for resolving the issue. Lindner only sketched out a rough plan in a 90-minute committee session, casting uncertainty over spending plans. The budget needs to address massive pandemic spending and energy costs, with a gap of around 20 billion euros expected for 2024. A budget agreement is now expected before the parliamentary summer break, with a first proposal ready by mid-July and a detailed draft by mid-August.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Christian Lindner attends the weekly cabinet meeting at the Chancellery in Berlin, Germany May 24, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse

site_title: Unlocking Japan’s baby boom savings
summary: Japan, the world's largest creditor country, has a vast wealth of $3.2 trillion in household financial assets, accumulated over 30 years, but much of it is not being effectively deployed. The country's demographic shift, with 50% of its wealth held by those aged 70 or older, presents a unique opportunity for policymakers to channel this wealth into investments for the future. To achieve this, Japan needs to reform its inheritance tax system and create a new philosophy of self-directed wealth investment, rather than simply paying down government debt.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc

FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian holding her mobile phone walks past electronic boards showing the Japan's Nikkei average (top L) and the Japanese yen's exchange rate against the euro (top R) outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, February 9, 2016.  REUTERS/Yuya Shino/File Photo
How Japan can escape financial socialism

site_title: Chinese snap up lottery tickets amid economic gloom
summary: China's nationwide lottery sales surged 62% in April, reaching a decade-high of 50.3 billion yuan, amid economic uncertainty following the pandemic. Young people, particularly those facing job insecurity, are driving the trend. Economists attribute the increase to people seeking a quick win to alleviate financial worries. This is the highest April figure in a decade, with overall first-four-month sales up 49.3% to 175.2 billion yuan.

images.alt_text: Traders said the yuan was also pressured by strong demand for dollars, but they had not spotted any moves by state banks to slow the pace of the currency’s declines.
Beyond this year, economists expect growth in China to slow to 5 per cent or lower.

site_title: Ringgit slumps to record low of 3.41 against the Singdollar
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has hit a record low of 3.41 against the Singapore dollar, a 4.15% drop from the start of the year. Experts attribute the decline to weakening commodity prices, US dollar strength, and China's economic slowdown, which poses risks to Malaysia's trade exposure. The drop is expected to benefit Malaysians working in Singapore but could exacerbate the brain drain issue. A new low of RM3.45 against the Singdollar is predicted within a month if these trends continue.

site_title: US mortgage rates rise to highest since March, slowing demand
summary: US mortgage rates surged to a two-month high of 6.69% after rising 12 basis points, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This increase slowed home purchase and refinance activity, with the index of applications for home purchases falling 4.3% and refinancing applications declining 5.4%. The high borrowing costs have discouraged homeowners from selling, pushing buyers to new construction. The decline in mortgage applications contributes to a challenging housing market.

site_title: Cayman Islands regulator explores legal options after SVB deposit seizure: WSJ
summary: The Cayman Islands Monetary Authority (Cima) is exploring legal options after the US Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC) seized deposits held at Silicon Valley Bank's branch in the territory. Cima has retained lawyers and is seeking ways to help affected depositors, according to a government official. The seizure follows California regulators shuttering SVB in March and First Citizens BancShares purchasing the bank with a $20 billion loss from a government-run insurance fund. Cima did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.

site_title: Higher interest rates boost hedge fund stock borrowing to record high: Goldman
summary: Hedge funds have reached record-high stock borrowing, driven by cheaper borrowing costs due to rising interest rates. This makes it more profitable for speculators to bet on stock price movements. Despite this, hedge funds remain uncertain about market direction, held back by macroeconomic uncertainty. Short exposures have reached a record high, catching up with bullish positions, as hedge funds benefit from higher interest payments on collateral. The uncertainty surrounding a global recession continues to influence hedge fund decisions.

images.alt_text: The trading positions of non-commercial players such as hedge funds are near the most bearish levels since at least 2011 across a combination of all major oil contracts.

site_title: Singapore Pools gives back to celebrate its 55th anniversary
summary: Singapore Pools celebrated its 55th anniversary by launching a year-long fundraising effort, "Community with a Heart," targeting S$1.5 million. The organization will set aside 15,000 square feet of retail space for social service agencies to use rent-free, with the support of the Tote Board and other beneficiaries. Members of the public can pledge support for four causes through a mobile app, and the event featured performances by students from Metta School and other beneficiaries, including Sky Shen from ART:DIS.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

Julian Chia, Men’s Champion & Hole-in-one winner, says: “I’m always happy to be able to support an important cause such as this, and to be able to play a round of golf with good friends, on a day with great weather is an added bonus.”

site_title: Facebook owner Meta starts final round of layoffs
summary: Meta Platforms has begun the final round of layoffs, cutting approximately 10,000 roles, as part of a plan announced in March. The cuts, which started on May 24, primarily affect non-engineering roles, reinforcing the company's focus on coding. The move comes after Meta reduced its workforce by over 11,000 employees in the fall, bringing the headcount down to levels seen in mid-2021. The company aims to restructure business teams and achieve a more optimal ratio of engineers to other roles, following a period of waning revenue growth and high inflation.

images.alt_text: The European Commission had sought the information related to its investigation into Facebook’s data and online marketplace, prompting the company to compare the competition enforcer to a fishing super-trawler hoovering up data.
Britain’s competition regulator last year orders Meta to sell Giphy over fears that it could deny or limit competitors such as Snapchat and Twitter access to the target’s content.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on January 12, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows a tablet displaying the logo of the company Meta. Facebook owner Meta has been fined a record 1.2 billion euros ($1.3 billion) for transferring EU user data to the United States in breach of a previous court ruling, Ireland's regulator announced May 23, 2023. The Irish Data Protection Commission, which acts on behalf of the European Union, said the European Data Protection Board had ordered it to collect "an administrative fine in the amount of 1.2 billion euros". Meta said it would appeal the decision. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)

site_title: Xiaomi Q1 revenue falls 18.9% as global smartphone demand stalls
summary: Xiaomi reported a 18.9% drop in Q1 revenue to 59.5 billion yuan, falling short of analyst estimates. The decline was attributed to weak global smartphone demand, with sales in China and India also experiencing declines. Despite a 13.1% increase in net income, the company is diversifying into the automotive sector, planning to start mass production of its first car in 2024. Xiaomi is cutting prices to stimulate demand in key markets.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi is among the major China tech players scheduled to announce results. A return to growth would mark a revival for the tech stocks, which have been heavily discounted in the past two years, says Bloomberg Intelligence analyst Marvin Chen.

site_title: Philippines’ Marcos seeks immediate approval of wealth fund bill
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. is pushing for the immediate approval of a bill creating a sovereign wealth fund, known as the Maharlika Investment Fund. The fund aims to shield the country from slowing economic growth and rising borrowing costs by tapping and securitizing dividends from state-owned companies. Marcos stated that the fund will serve as a new growth catalyst for infrastructure projects, stimulating economic activity and development. The bill was approved by the House of Representatives in December and now needs Senate approval before it can be signed into law.

site_title: AI startup Figure raises US$70 million to build humanoid robots
summary: Figure, an AI startup, has raised US$70 million to develop its first autonomous humanoid robot. The funding, led by Parkway Venture Capital, will accelerate the robot's development and manufacturing, expected to launch in the next few months. Figure aims to create general-purpose humanoid robots that can handle various tasks, with the goal of enabling them to learn and interact with their environment. The company's valuation is estimated to be over US$400 million, with founder Brett Adcock investing US$20 million personally. This investment joins a growing trend of startups and big tech companies racing to develop commercially viable humanoid robots.

site_title: The face of Sweden’s property bust fights for US$13 billion empire
summary: Ilija Batljan, a Yugoslav refugee turned Swedish property tycoon, is struggling to stabilize his $13 billion empire, Samhallsbyggnadsbolaget i Norden (SBB), amid a 20% slump in Swedish housing prices. The company faces a $8 billion debt pile and has been downgraded to junk status. Batljan must raise capital, divest properties, or sell a stake in the company to avoid restructuring pressure. The crisis is part of Europe's unfolding real estate crisis, with Sweden's residential market leading the way.

images.alt_text: Detached houses in the Slottsberget district of Gothenburg, Sweden, on Tuesday, Dec. 6, 2022. Home prices in Sweden, one of the countries hardest hit by the global housing slump, have dropped by nearly 15%, suggesting that estimates by most forecasters -- including the Riksbank and state-owned mortgage lender SBAB -- may be too conservative. Photographer: Nora Lorek/Bloomberg

site_title: Government to spend S$3.3 billion on infocomms technology in 2023
summary: The Government of Singapore plans to spend S$3.3 billion on infocomms technology in 2023, down from S$3.8 billion in 2021 and 2022. About S$400 million will be spent on personal computers and printers, and S$600 million on subscription-based software for customer relationship management and case management. The majority of the spending will go towards application development, with an estimated S$1.49 billion allocated for co-developed projects with private companies.

site_title: UBS to have ‘incredibly high bar’ on Credit Suisse staff it takes on: chairman
summary: UBS Chairman Colm Kelleher stated that the bank will have an "incredibly high bar" for investment banking staff it takes on from Credit Suisse following their merger. Kelleher expressed concerns over the "cultural contamination" of UBS due to Credit Suisse's investment bank, which he deemed "out of control" and absorbed huge amounts of capital into suboptimal products. UBS plans to downsize the investment bank operations and will integrate Credit Suisse's other businesses, including its universal bank and asset management business, more easily.

images.alt_text: The order affects the top three levels of Credit Suisse management and follows the multi-billion franc state rescue of Switzerland’s second-biggest bank.
On May 9, Credit Suisse decided against an appeal and withdrew its application for precautionary measures, according to the court.

“The conclusion was very surprising to me, in terms of the way that the bank was resolved through this very unusual sale to UBS, with associated unusual payments to shareholders versus bondholders,” Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters says.

site_title: Top Global puts ground floor of 15 Scotts Road up for sale at S$38.8 million
summary: The ground floor of 15 Scotts Road, a nine-storey commercial building in District 9, Singapore, is up for sale at S$38.8 million. The two adjacent strata retail units, totaling 6,437 sq ft, have an indicative price of S$6,000 per square foot. This sale comes as strata subdivision of commercial developments in Orchard Road is being restricted, making it a rare opportunity to own a piece of prime investment asset.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
The EOI exercise for the strata office floor on 15 Scotts Rd will close on Oct 6 at 3pm.

site_title: How to pick the best hotel loyalty programme for you
summary: To choose the best hotel loyalty program, consider your travel style and needs. For families, Hilton Honors stands out with Embassy Suites and Homewood Suites offering suites with kitchenettes and pools. For global travelers, Marriott Bonvoy offers a vast network of over 8,500 hotels worldwide. Frequent flyers can link their airline loyalty program with Marriott or Hyatt, earning points and reciprocal status. Those who like to plan ahead prefer World of Hyatt's award chart, which provides a benchmark for points savings. Luxury travelers can opt for Ritz-Carlton, while those seeking home rentals can use Homes & Villas by Marriott Bonvoy.

images.alt_text: Hotel Des Horlogers' avant-garde architecture is inspired by the Vallée de Joux’s topography, with zigzagging slabs that gradually leads down towards the meadows behind the hotel.
Although US$500 to US$1,000 per night for a room might sound high, that range eliminates the fanciest hotels in most major markets, including New York City.

site_title: German business morale worsens in May
summary: German business morale worsened in May, with the Ifo institute's monthly confidence barometer dropping to 91.7 points from 93.4 points in April. This marks the first decline after six consecutive increases, adding to fears of a recession. Analysts had expected a reading of 93 points. The survey also showed managers were more pessimistic about their current business situation and future growth prospects, particularly in manufacturing and trade.

images.alt_text: The outlook for the coming twelve months remains gloomy, according to a DIHK survey of 21,000 German companies.

site_title: Asia-focused HSBC puts 12 countries on exit watchlist
summary: HSBC is reviewing possible exits from 12 countries to focus on Asian expansion, with Chinese shareholder Ping An pushing for prioritization of the lender's profitable Asian business. The review follows pressure from investors, including Ping An, to streamline the bank's global operations. HSBC has already sold or streamlined businesses in France, Greece, Russia, and Canada, and is focusing on increasing revenue growth through fee-based products and services, particularly in China and Hong Kong. The bank's CFO, Georges Elhedery, said the goal is to deliver for the business and customers, while also managing challenges such as asset sales and interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank and Citi have admitted to involvement in anti-competitive activity, while HSBC, Morgan Stanley and RBC have not admitted any wrongdoing.
Kai Zhang will be responsible for expanding the bank’s WPB business in South Asia.
HSBC, which counts Hong Kong as its biggest market, has been diversifying its presence in other markets in the region, amid rising geopolitical tension.

site_title: Russia, China seal economic pacts despite Western disapproval
summary: Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin signed economic agreements with Chinese Premier Li Qiang, describing bilateral ties as "at an unprecedented high level" despite Western disapproval. The agreements include increased investment cooperation, agricultural product exports, and sports cooperation. Russia is seeking support from China due to Western sanctions, with energy shipments projected to rise 40% this year. China's policy towards Ukraine is characterized as "declaring neutrality, supporting Putin, and paying no price," with Beijing rejecting Western attempts to link its partnership with Moscow to Ukraine.

site_title: US dollar gains on flight to safety; pound, Swedish krona, kiwi struggle
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-month high against a basket of peers, reaching 103.77, as investors sought safe-havens amid uncertain US debt ceiling negotiations. The pound, Swedish krona, and New Zealand's dollar struggled, with the pound hitting a one-month low against the US dollar. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand raised interest rates to 5.5%, but unexpectedly signaled the end of its tightening cycle. Global share markets fell due to the uncertainty, with the euro and yen steady against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A picture illustration shows U.S. 100 dollar bank notes taken in Tokyo August 2, 2011. REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao/File Photo

site_title: China solar panel maker Jinko to sell unit for 4.3 billion yuan
summary: China's Jinko Solar to sell unit Xinjiang Jinko Solar to government-linked fund and private investor for 4.3 billion yuan, aiming to lower operational costs and increase production efficiency. The sale is pending an antitrust review by China's State Administration for Market Regulation. Xinjiang Jinko Solar reported an unaudited net profit of 139.9 million yuan in the first quarter, with net assets of 1.1 billion yuan as of March. The deal is expected to optimize Jinko's facility mix and improve overall efficiency.

site_title: South Korea's Naver says website access disrupted in China
summary: Naver, South Korea's largest web portal and search engine, reported disruptions to its website access in China, leaving the cause unclear. The company suspects either a technical glitch or action by Chinese authorities. Naver is unsure whether the disruptions were caused by a glitch or were the result of action by authorities in China.

images.alt_text: Poshmark is the largest fashion consumer-to-consumer platform in North America, with 80 million registered users led by Millenial and Gen Z active users.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: BMI Research reported that CPO prices averaged RM3,872 per tonne this year, nearly 20% lower than at end-2022. Regional palm oil players saw lower revenue and earnings due to the decline in CPO prices, with market watchers warning of continued troubles in the second half of the year. Meanwhile, Singapore's SMEs are outsourcing backend roles to cut costs and address labor shortages, with five digital banks set to launch in Malaysia in the coming months. The Straits Times Index fell 0.1% amid fears of further rate hikes.

site_title: India’s aviation regulator to audit Go First for service restart: internal memo
summary: India's aviation regulator, the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA), will conduct an audit of Go First to ensure the airline's preparedness to restart operations following a service restart. The audit will focus on the airline's monsoon operations and other areas. Go First's CEO, Kaushik Khona, has assured employees that their April salaries will be credited before resuming operations. The audit is expected to be completed in the coming days, with operations commencing after the regulator's approval.

images.alt_text: The low-cost carrier, recently rebranded as Go First, was plunged into financial crisis this year, sparked by what it called “faulty” Pratt & Whitney engines that grounded about half its 54 Airbus A320neos.

site_title: China's Kunming denies debt repayment difficulties as concerns grow
summary: China's Kunming city has denied rumors that its local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) are having difficulty repaying debts, amid concerns about municipal debt risks. LGFVs, which fund infrastructure projects, have surged debtloads exceeding $9 trillion, sparking worries about contagion and potential defaults. Analysts say Kunming's weakening property market and lack of core industries contribute to the concerns, with Goldman Sachs estimating that local governments' scheduled bond repayments could reach a new high in 2023.

images.alt_text: The total debt of China’s LGFVs has swelled to a record 66 trillion yuan, equivalent to half of the country’s economy.

site_title: Indonesia to allow exports of five raw minerals despite June ban
summary: Indonesia has announced it will allow exports of copper, iron ore, lead, zinc, and anode mud from copper concentrates until smelters are ready to handle the materials. The export ban, initially set for June, will be delayed to accommodate smelter development, which was hindered by the pandemic. Companies will be required to pay export duties and must have their smelters at 50% completion as of January to continue exporting. Bauxite shipments will be stopped in June due to limited smelter capacity.

images.alt_text: Freeport is building a US$3 billion copper smelter in East Java to process 1.7 million tonnes of copper concentrate.

site_title: PwC referred to Australian police over tax document leak scandal
summary: The Australian government has referred a tax document leak scandal involving PwC Australia to police, alleging the firm shared confidential information about new anti-tax avoidance measures with corporate customers to win business. PwC Australia's CEO stepped down, and the firm has apologized and committed to learning from the mistake. The Australian Treasury claims "a wide range of individuals" at the firm had access to the confidential information. The matter has been referred to the Australian Federal Police for a potential criminal investigation.

site_title: UK house prices up 4.1% yoy in March
summary: UK house prices rose 4.1% in the 12 months to March, according to the Office for National Statistics. London saw the slowest annual growth, with prices increasing 1.5%. This marks a slowdown from February's revised 5.8% rise. The data contrasts with recent reports from mortgage lenders Halifax and Nationwide, which also showed a slowing housing market.

site_title: ByteDance co-founder sets up new venture firm in Hong Kong
summary: ByteDance co-founder Zhang Yiming has set up a new venture firm, Cool River Venture HK, in Hong Kong, listing himself as its sole director. The move comes after he quit his leadership roles at ByteDance in 2021. Zhang, who holds a $42.3 billion fortune, is creating a new venture in Hong Kong as the city seeks to attract rich people after years of isolation. The government plans tax cuts and measures to attract 200 family offices by the end of 2025. This is part of Zhang's post-ByteDance chapter, following his "common prosperity" drive to reduce inequality in China.

images.alt_text: Zhang Yiming’s estimated net worth has fallen to $42.3 billion after a US testimony detailed a smaller ByteDance ownership stake than previously known.

site_title: EU court rejects Meta challenge against antitrust requests for information
summary: The European Union's General Court rejected Meta Platforms' challenge against antitrust regulators, allowing the European Commission to receive information related to its investigation into Facebook's data and online marketplace. Meta had compared the Commission to a "fishing super-trawler hoovering up data," but the court found the request was reasonable and did not go beyond what was necessary. The General Court's decision upholds the European Commission's investigation into Facebook's practices.

site_title: Japan’s Uniqlo to exit Russia, paving way for sale of business: newspaper
summary: Uniqlo, a Japanese clothing brand, will exit Russia after suspending operations in March 2022 due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The company, Fast Retailing, has decided to completely leave Russia but has not submitted a sale application yet. Deputy Trade Minister Viktor Yevtukhov stated that Fast Retailing can offer potential buyers its business model, including lease agreements and equipment. The company will continue to monitor the situation and make decisions accordingly.

site_title: Panasonic says Japan carmakers showing interest in its batteries
summary: Panasonic Holdings, a key supplier of batteries to Tesla, is experiencing increased interest from Japanese carmakers in its cylindrical batteries as the company plans to quadruple annual production capacity. CEO Yuki Kusumi stated that carmakers will have to decide what to do with their factories as they transition to electric vehicles. Panasonic aims to boost production to 200 gigawatt hours by March 2031 and has broken ground on a $4 billion battery factory in Kansas, with plans to ramp up output to meet growing demand.

images.alt_text: Panasonic predicts net profit will grow 32 per cent from a year earlier to a record 350 billion yen.

site_title: Uber to add 25,000 EVs in India in green push
summary: Uber plans to launch 25,000 electric vehicles in India, partnering with local fleet operators to expand its presence. The move aims to support India's clean-energy push and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal of making the nation net-zero by 2070. However, the lack of charging stations in India may hinder the adoption of EVs, making them more expensive than internal combustion engine vehicles. Uber plans to launch EV Uber Green in Mumbai, Bengaluru, and Delhi in June, and has partnered with startup Zypp Electric to supply 10,000 electric scooters by 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Uber electric taxis are seen outside a charging station in Mumbai, India, February 21, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares fall amid fears of further rate hikes; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,214.21 on Wednesday, amid fears of further rate hikes. The US Purchasing Managers Index figures unexpectedly rose to 54.5, indicating growth in the private sector. Market analysts attribute the decline to hawkish remarks from Fed officials and the lack of progress in US debt talks, which led to further de-risking on Wall Street. The STI was affected by losses from major banks OCBC, UOB, and DBS, with CapitaLand Investment being the largest gainer.

images.alt_text: SGX: Asia’s international, multi-asset exchange
Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Turkish AI-backed startup worth almost US$2 billion in funding
summary: A Turkish AI-backed marketing platform, Insider, has raised $105 million in a funding round, valuing the company at nearly $2 billion. The company, founded in 2012, received financing from Qatar Investment Authority and Esas Private Equity. Despite a global decline in venture capital funding for tech startups, Insider's valuation has increased due to its growing numbers, with CEO Hande Cilingir stating that "good companies with good metrics are still fundable." The company plans to use the funds for expansion and considers an initial public offering in 2025 or 2026.

images.alt_text: Generative AI models have become well known for making mistakes, or “hallucinations”, spewing up misinformation with uncanny certainty.

site_title: Wanda to mull sale of 20 malls in wealthy parts of China: sources
summary: Dalian Wanda Group is considering the sale of up to 20 shopping malls in wealthy areas of China, including Jiangsu, Zhejiang, and Shanghai, to address a potential liquidity crunch. The company has reached out to investors about divesting the malls, with a valuation of 700 million yuan to 800 million yuan per mall. The sale plan comes as Wanda faces a cash squeeze if it fails to list its mall operator unit in Hong Kong by the end of this year, with a potential repurchase of 30 billion yuan of equity.

images.alt_text: Wanda Commercial is the property services arm of Dalian Wanda Group (DWG), China’s largest commercial property developer.
FILE PHOTO: A sign of Dalian Wanda Group in China glows during an event in Beijing, China, March 21, 2016. REUTERS/Damir Sagolj/File Photo

site_title: UK inflation falls by less than expected, core inflation jumps
summary: The UK's consumer price index (CPI) rose 8.7% in April, the joint highest rate among Group of Seven advanced economies, leaving inflation expectations unchanged for a potential Bank of England interest rate hike. Core inflation, excluding energy and food prices, reached a 31-year high, further fueling bets on further interest rate hikes. Despite the drop in food price inflation, Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt warned that food prices remain too high, and the BOE is expected to raise interest rates in June.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt has defended borrowing billions of pounds to protect families and businesses against the impacts of the pandemic and Putin’s energy crisis.

site_title: More SMEs outsource back-end roles amid rising business costs, labour shortages
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are increasingly outsourcing back-end business functions to cut costs and tackle labour shortages. The trend, accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, has seen SMEs save up to 50% on overhead and labour costs by contracting third-party providers. Service providers have reported a surge in demand, with some expecting to double their client base. While data security concerns remain, SMEs can tap into expertise they would otherwise lack, and outsourcing allows them to focus on growing their businesses.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

smemci - At the Enterprise 50 Awards 2021, MCI Outsourcing was a first-time winner, while MCI Career Services won for a second time. From left: Ryan Ng, chief executive officer of MCI Career Services and MCI Outsourcing; Ong Boon Huat, chairman of MCI Investment Holding; Jo Ong, regional director of MCI Investment Holding; and Eunice Tan, business development manager of MCI Career Services.

copyright/source: MCI
The telegraph and telephone in the 19th century, and later, containerised shipping and better infotech, allowed multinational companies to subcontract ever more tasks to ever more places.

site_title: Aviva firmly against forcing pension funds to back UK start-ups: CEO
summary: Aviva CEO Amanda Blanc opposes a UK proposal to force pension funds to back more British start-ups, citing concerns over creating a complex and bureaucratic fund. The proposal, part of a £50 billion 'Future Growth Fund', aims to keep London competitive with rival finance hubs. Blanc believes pension fund trustees should make their own decisions, rather than being mandated to invest. The British government is expected to lay out plans to boost pension investment in the coming months, with the opposition Labour party prepared to compel pension funds to invest in the fund.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A pedestrians walks past the Aviva logo outside the company head office in the city of London, Britain March 7, 2019. REUTERS/Simon Dawson/File Photo

site_title: Australia’s central bank expects smooth unwinding of balance sheet
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia expects the unwinding of its balance sheet to run smoothly, with around A$20 billion of purchased bonds maturing and the pace increasing to A$35-45 billion per year. Head of domestic markets David Jacobs stated the process will be managed to minimize challenges, with private sector absorption of issuance potentially placing modest pressure on yields.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pedestrians walk past the Reserve Bank of Australia building in central Sydney, Australia, February 10, 2017. REUTERS/Steven Saphore//File Photo

site_title: EU’s imported-carbon tariff may trigger reviews of S-E Asia policies: Sustainable Fitch
summary: The European Union's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), set to launch in October 2023, may prompt a re-evaluation of carbon policies in South-east Asia. The mechanism imposes an emissions tariff on imported carbon-intensive goods, affecting suppliers of cement, iron, steel, aluminium, fertilizers, electricity, and hydrogen. This could lead to higher costs for major suppliers and potentially prompt a review of existing carbon policies in the region, according to a report by Sustainable Fitch.

images.alt_text: The Dalat Photovoltaic Base in Ordos city, China, April 2023.

The Asian Development Bank will “almost definitely” upgrade its 2023 growth forecast for developing Asia when it releases its outlook report in April, “if nothing crazy happens” between now and then, the lender's chief economist Albert Park said.

site_title: South Korea to impose 1% countercyclical capital buffer requirement on banks
summary: South Korea's Financial Services Commission plans to introduce a 1% countercyclical capital buffer requirement for banks and their holding companies starting May 2024. The measure aims to improve banks' ability to absorb losses amid higher external and internal macroeconomic uncertainties and financial risks. The regulator stated that all South Korean banks already hold sufficient capital and can raise additional funds, increasing the credibility of their soundness.

site_title: No way to police all cryptocurrency fraud, CFTC commissioner says
summary: US CFTC Commissioner Christy Goldsmith Romero stated that it's impossible to police all cryptocurrency fraud due to the vast amount, accounting for about 20% of the agency's portfolio. The CFTC is working on several big cases, including civil cases against Binance and FTX, with Romero pushing back on the idea of a "turf war" between the CFTC and SEC over regulating crypto. She emphasized that crypto companies should not view the CFTC as a more lenient regulator.

images.alt_text: The 18 measures planned apply long-established safeguards from mainstream markets to eliminate conflicts of interest between the different parts of a crypto transaction.
Hong Kong will roll out a licencing regime for virtual-asset platforms on Jun 1, part of an effort to restore its status as a cutting-edge financial centre.
After much-touted claims of possibly remaking the entire financial system, crypto has gone through a spectacular decline.
Sam Bankman-Fried’s case is part of an escalating crackdown on alleged abuses at digital asset exchanges by US prosecutors and regulators
Global authorities are increasingly anxious of the lack of oversight of the sector, whose most popular units are bitcoin and ether.
Regulating crypto has become more urgent for regulators after the collapse of crypto exchange FTX.
Canada has tightened regulations for crypto asset trading platforms in recent months, with the introduction of a pre-registration process.

site_title: Asean palm oil listcos battle revenue, profit dips on sliding CPO prices
summary: Palm oil producers in the Asean region saw a decline in revenue and net profit in the first quarter of 2023 due to weakening crude palm oil (CPO) prices. CPO prices averaged RM3,872 per tonne, nearly 20% lower than at end-2022. Companies such as Bumitama Agri, First Resources, and Pure Palm Oil reported lower revenue and net profit due to lower selling prices and higher production costs. Despite this, integrated players like Wilmar International reported a higher volume of sales in their sugar and edible oil segments. Analysts predict further price declines in the immediate term and a softening of palm oil prices between 2025 and 2027.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Sime Darby is seen at its headquarters in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia February 7, 2018. REUTERS/Lai Seng Sin/File Photo
The expansion will be done in phases based on the readiness of biodiesel blending facilities across Malaysia, Commodities Minister Fadillah Yusof says.
Golden Agri says its first-quarter performance “demonstrated the company’s resilience” amid lower crude palm oil prices, coming on the back of a record year in 2022.
It adds that overall sales volumes were also impacted by a net inventory build-up of 19,000 tonnes and lower production volumes.
Bumitama's fall in net profit comes amid lower average selling prices and higher fertiliser prices.
First Resources reported a 73.8 per cent fall in net profit to US$19.3 million for the first quarter ended Mar 31, 2023.
Penang shrouded in haze in April. The island had to grapple with pollution and extreme hot weather during the  monsoon season.

site_title: China says Nato's plan for Japan office not welcomed in Asia-Pacific
summary: China's foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning stated that the Asia-Pacific region does not welcome NATO's plan to open a liaison office in Japan, citing concerns over group confrontation and military security. Mao also advised Japan to be "extra cautious" on military security due to its history of aggression. Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida acknowledged the plan but stated the country has no plans to join NATO.

site_title: HSBC, Citi, Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley and RBC traders may have broken competition law, watchdog finds
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has found that five major global banks - HSBC, Citi, Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley, and RBC - may have broken UK competition law by sharing sensitive information on government bond trading activities through one-to-one online chats between 2009 and 2013. The watchdog alleges that the banks exchanged information on pricing and trading strategies, potentially denying taxpayers and pension savers the benefits of full competition. The CMA will consider further representations from the banks before reaching a final decision.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of HSBC is seen on its headquarters at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Japan's Rakuten set to raise 294.2 billion yen through share issue
summary: Rakuten Group, a Japanese e-commerce and fintech conglomerate, plans to raise up to 294.2 billion yen (S$2.9 billion) through a new share issue. The company will issue 407,045,400 new shares at 566 yen per share, with a green shoe option of up to 61,056,700 shares. This move aims to offset financial losses from its mobile business, which has struggled to gain market share. The shares will be offered starting May 31.

site_title: US money market fund assets hit record highs despite debt-ceiling fears
summary: US money market fund assets have reached a record high of $5.8 trillion, with $614.8 billion in net inflows so far this year. Despite concerns over the debt ceiling, investors are seeking higher yields, with money market funds offering up to 5% returns. This contrasts with the 2011 debt-ceiling standoff, when outflows occurred. Money market funds are considered safe havens, but officials warn they may be vulnerable to rapid redemptions in times of stress, a concern after previous crises.

images.alt_text: New home sales have increased 4.1 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 683,000 units last month, the highest reading since March 2022.
US businesses have increased headcount, with companies reporting that vacancies were being more easily filled.

site_title: Taiwan central bank to weigh inflation, GDP in next rate move
summary: Taiwan's central bank will consider both inflation and economic growth when deciding on its next interest rate decision in June, amid a recession-hit economy. The export-dependent economy has contracted for two quarters, and Governor Yang Chin-long predicts it won't rebound until the fourth quarter. Despite inflation concerns, Taiwan has managed to control inflation "quite well" compared to other countries. The bank will take cues from the US Federal Reserve, with Yang noting low expectations for a US rate hike in June.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's central bank, in a unanimous decision, raised the benchmark discount rate by 12.5 basis points (bps) to 1.875 per cent.

site_title: Xi upends the secretive world of US$10,000-an-hour China experts
summary: China is cracking down on the secretive "expert networks" industry, which has been a key tool for foreign investors to access on-the-ground intelligence about the Chinese economy. The crackdown, targeting companies like Capvision, has reignited concerns that Xi Jinping's push for foreign investment will be hindered by a tightening grip on information. The move may lead to a decrease in foreign direct investment, with China's stock and bond markets experiencing steady outflows. The government's focus on national security is seen as a threat to its economic growth and its ability to lure foreign capital.

images.alt_text: The 'Jing-Jin-Ji' region’s development will focus on sectors such as integrated circuits, network security and power equipment and biopharmaceutical industry.
China is adding intermittent wind and solar generation at a much more rapid pace than energy storage.
Hegang, a city with nearly a million people near the Russian border, had debt of more than double its fiscal income when it hit the headlines almost 18 months ago.

site_title: UK’s Great Portland forecasts 3%-6% rental growth in prime office spaces
summary: UK property firm Great Portland Estates forecasts 3%-6% rental growth in prime office spaces this fiscal year, despite a near 7% fall in property valuation due to rising interest rates and macro-economic worries. The company cited a recovery in London's office sector, with centrally-located offices returning to normal levels of occupation. However, the overall portfolio valuation fell 6.6% year-on-year to £2.4 billion, with office and retail segments declining 7.3% and 4.5%, respectively.

site_title: Sime Darby Plantation warns of challenging 2023 as Q1 profit plummets
summary: Sime Darby Plantation Berhad reported a 90% year-on-year decline in Q1 profit to RM69 million due to falling palm prices and higher costs. Revenue shrank 7% to RM4.07 billion. The company cited lower production of palm fruit bunches and higher finance costs due to increased benchmark interest rates. Prices are expected to hover around current levels, with macroeconomic and geopolitical challenges posing further challenges to prices. The company aims to rehabilitate its upstream operations and reduce dependency on manual labor.

images.alt_text: Sime Darby Plantation said the decision indicated CBP’s recognition of the firm’s efforts “in the last two years to review, revise and... upgrade its protocols for recruiting, managing and working with its workers”.

site_title: Billionaire Infosys founder to double private firm’s investments
summary: Billionaire Narayana Murthy's private firm, Catamaran Ventures, plans to double its $1 billion investments to $2 billion in the next five years, focusing on emerging manufacturing hub in India. The firm will explore strategic partnerships in deep tech, precision engineering, and manufacturing, and renewables. It aims to raise its assets under management and add four specialists to its team of investment professionals. The move is part of a shift from its prior focus on services, with the goal of supporting India's growth trajectory through innovation and scale.

images.alt_text: Infosys’ consolidated net profit rose 7.77 per cent to 61.28 billion rupees (S$991.6 million) in the three months ended Mar 31, while revenue rose 16 per cent to 374.41 billion rupees.

site_title: India plans sweeping overhaul of digital law as market swells
summary: India plans to publish a first draft of a new digital law in June, aiming to create an environment where Big Tech can operate while being more accountable to the government and protecting users. The existing 20-year-old law is deemed insufficient to achieve India's digital economy target of $1 trillion. The proposed law will cover a range of topics, including proposals for Big Tech to operate in a more accountable manner.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman uses a smartphone on a beach in Mumbai, India, January 4, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: PropertyGuru cuts Q1 losses to S$10.2 million
summary: PropertyGuru, a New York Stock Exchange-listed company, reported net losses of S$10.2 million in its first quarter, a significant drop from S$120.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 15.6% year-over-year to S$32.6 million, driven mainly by its marketplaces, which generated S$31.2 million in revenue. The company's fintech and data services business also saw a 40.1% increase in revenue to S$1.4 million. Despite the losses, PropertyGuru reaffirmed its forecast for FY2023 revenue between S$160 million and S$170 million, citing a long-term growth trajectory despite short-term challenges.

images.alt_text: PropertyGuru is still bulllish on the Singapore property market, seeing price stability even transaction volumes wane.

site_title: India central bank chief says inflation has moderated, but no room for complacency
summary: India's annual retail inflation eased to 4.7% in April from 5.66% in the previous month, according to data. Reserve Bank of India Governor Shaktikanta Das stated that inflation has moderated but there's no room for complacency due to potential weather-related uncertainties and geopolitical risks. Das also mentioned that India's GDP growth could be above 7% for 2022-2023, with the RBI targeting inflation at 4% and aiming to maintain financial stability.

images.alt_text: “The governor also emphasised the need for banks to ensure continued financial and operational resilience,” according to a statement from the RBI.

site_title: Collaborating on R&D might be worth the risks of competition
summary: Singapore SMEs may benefit from collaborating on research and development (R&D) activities under a cost-sharing agreement (CSA) tax treatment, which allows companies to share costs and risks while claiming tax deductions on the proportionate amount spent. This can help overcome the barriers to investing in R&D, such as high costs and risks. The Enterprise Innovation Scheme (EIS) provides a greater incentive to conduct R&D, offering up to 400% tax deductions on qualifying expenditure. By pooling resources and sharing expertise, SMEs can reduce costs, increase job security for skilled workers, and mitigate the fear of competition.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area, 2 March 2023.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: South Africa presses for recognition of its high-end olive oil
summary: South Africa is gaining recognition for its high-quality olive oil, with many farms producing artisanal and extra virgin oils. The country's Mediterranean climate and rolling vineyards have led to the growth of the olive oil industry, with some farms producing up to 1,800 tonnes annually. The industry has seen an increase in demand from the local market, driven by the quest for healthier diets. With global olive oil prices rising due to climate disasters, South Africa may start to position itself for the export market, offering a new opportunity for the country to compete with traditional producers.

images.alt_text: A worker picks Frantoio olives using a rake to pull the fruit off the trees where it is collected on nets at Tokara Wine and Olive Estate near Stellenbosch on May 18, 2023. South Africa is famous for its wines and not necessarily for olive oil where Spain, Italy, France or Greece are kings, but South African producers are sliding to the top. (Photo by RODGER BOSCH / AFP)

Christophe Dehosse, Chef Patron of the Vine Bistro at Glenelly Wine and Olive Estate, prepares Bouillabaisse, starting with frying fish and a prawn in olive oil from the estate in Stellenbosch on May 18, 2023. South Africa is famous for its wines and not necessarily for olive oil where Spain, Italy, France or Greece are kings, but South African producers are sliding to the top. (Photo by RODGER BOSCH / AFP)

site_title: South Korea asks US to review China rule for chip subsidies
summary: South Korea has asked the US to review its criteria for new semiconductor subsidies, concerned over the impact of rules limiting chip investment in countries like China. The US Commerce Department proposed rules to prevent China from tapping funds under the Chips Act, but South Korea believes the "guardrail provisions" impose an unreasonable burden on companies investing in the US. The country is seeking to raise the limit from 5% to 10% for existing facilities. This comes as South Korean chipmakers Samsung and SK Hynix have invested billions in chip factories in China, with Samsung's Texas plant potentially costing over $25 billion.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s debt markets stabilised after authorities pledged billions of dollars in support.
Senior EU and US officials want to use the May 30-31 Trade and Technology Council meeting to strengthen their cooperation in addressing the assertive rise of China.
South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol (above) held a summit in Seoul with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President Charles Michel.

site_title: South Korea tackles property risk with loan conversions for brokerages
summary: South Korea's financial regulator has taken steps to address property risk by encouraging brokerages to convert short-term risky property debt into longer-term loans. The move aims to counter the risks in the real estate market and prevent a repeat of last year's turmoil. The regulator has pledged billions of dollars in support and lowered risk weights on capital ratios to encourage the conversion. This comes as the country's debt markets stabilized after a global policy tightening and a missed debt payment by a property developer last September.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol (above) held a summit in Seoul with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President Charles Michel.

site_title: Republican DeSantis to launch White House bid in event with Musk
summary: US Republican Governor Ron DeSantis is set to announce his 2024 presidential bid in a live Twitter event with billionaire Elon Musk on May 24, 2023. DeSantis aims to leverage Musk's star power to outshine frontrunner Donald Trump, who has a significant polling lead. Despite declining ratings and concerns about his readiness, DeSantis has a large cash advantage and strong turnout at recent campaign events. Musk will host the event, which will be unscripted, and DeSantis will also launch a campaign video and hold a retreat for donors.

images.alt_text: A sign in support of former US President Donald Trump in front of a home in Wallowa, Oregon, on May 12, 2023.
Unfiltered by his aides, Trump damaged himself in the CNN town hall on May 10 for purposes of a general election campaign.

In America, money makes the campaigns go around, and a candidate can even be measured by his or her ability to attract political donations – the theory being that if enough influential people are willing to donate, that person is a winner.
President Joe Biden meets with House Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) to continue negotiations over increasing the debt limit, at the White House in Washington, May 22, 2023.

site_title: CICC cuts pay 40% as China crackdown roils broker bonus season
summary: China International Capital Corporation (CICC) is cutting bonuses by over 40% due to a 30% profit drop in 2022, amid China's "common prosperity" campaign to curb pay for the elite. The move follows delays in announcing payouts, with rivals Haitong Securities and Citic Securities also lagging. The cuts are part of a broader regulatory crackdown and come as top bankers in Asia face similar reductions, averaging a 40-50% drop in total compensation.

images.alt_text: For Xi Jinping’s Communist Party, the secretive industry represents something far more ominous: a threat to national security that must be reined in.

site_title: China’s Lenovo revenue falls for third consecutive quarter as PC demand slumps
summary: Lenovo Group reported a 24% fall in revenue for the January-March quarter, marking the third consecutive decline, as global PC shipments declined 29% to 56.9 million units. The company's fourth-quarter revenue was $12.63 billion, down from $16.73 billion a year earlier. This decline is attributed to the post-pandemic slump in PC demand, which began after the Covid-19 outbreak gave electronics sales a boost. Non-PC businesses, such as smartphones and IT services, grew 7% and now account for 40% of total revenue.

images.alt_text: A man walks past the Samsung logo displayed on a glass door at the company's Seocho building in Seoul on April 7, 2023. - Samsung Electronics said on April 7 it expected first-quarter operating profits to plunge over 95 percent on-year to a 14-year low, as memory chip sales were hammered by a global downturn. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: Inflation crashes the party as ECB marks 25 years
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) marks its 25th anniversary amidst soaring inflation in the eurozone, which reached record highs over the past 12 months. Despite this, ECB President Christine Lagarde has expressed optimism, citing the bank's achievements in delivering price stability and European sovereignty. The eurozone's GDP per capita has more than doubled since the single currency was introduced in 1998, and unemployment has fallen to record lows. However, critics argue that the ECB was too slow to raise interest rates, leading to a prolonged campaign of monetary tightening to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: XpertHR said the median basic pay settlement in the three months to the end of April remained at 6 per cent, two percentage points higher than the same time period a year ago.

Jeremy Hunt, UK chancellor of the exchequer, speaks during a news conference attended by IMF mission chief for the UK S. Ali Abbas, IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva and IMF communications director Julie Kozack, in London, UK, May 23, 2023.
Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt has defended borrowing billions of pounds to protect families and businesses against the impacts of the pandemic and Putin’s energy crisis.
Consumers are doing everything they can to curb the impact of sky-high inflation, shopping at discount grocers and buying supermarkets’ own-brand goods.
Largely healed supply chains and lower energy prices has led to input costs for factories falling at the fastest pace in over seven years.

site_title: New Zealand dollar slides, yields retreat after RBNZ signals hikes are over
summary: The New Zealand dollar fell 1% to a three-week low of US$0.6180 after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) signaled that interest rate hikes are over, raising the possibility of rate cuts from the third quarter of next year. The RBNZ raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 5.5%, but sees rates peaking at the current level before cuts commence. This led to a decline in benchmark two-year interest rate swaps and a 0.9% gain for the Australian dollar against the New Zealand dollar.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the greenback against a basket of major peers, has risen 0.3 per cent to 103.53, not far from a roughly two-month high of 103.63 hit last week.
The RBNZ says the New Zealand housing market is close to reaching a sustainable level.

site_title: Virgin Orbit auctions US$36 million in remaining assets as company folds
summary: Virgin Orbit, a satellite launch firm founded by Richard Branson, has auctioned off its remaining assets for $36.4 million, leading to its closure. The company, which laid off 85% of its 750 employees in March, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April. Assets sold include its Long Beach, California headquarters to Rocket Lab USA for $16 million, and its aircraft assets to Stratolaunch for $17 million. Most remaining employees will be laid off within the next week.

images.alt_text: Oita prefecture had estimated the spaceport, similar to Virgin Orbit’s Cornwall, England facility, would produce economic benefits worth about 10.2 billion yen (S$101 million) in the region over the five years from the initial launch.
The Virgin Orbit building is seen after the company paused operations last week, in Long Beach, California, U.S., March 22, 2023.   REUTERS/Mike Blake

site_title: Alibaba unit ordered to pay NetEase US$7.2 million over game copyright violation
summary: A Chinese court ordered Ejoy, an Alibaba subsidiary, to pay NetEase $7.2 million in compensation for copyright infringement in the mobile game Three Kingdoms Tactics, which infringed on Shuai Tu Zhi Bin's copyrights. Ejoy was ordered to delete 79 infringing items and will appeal the decision. If upheld, the fine would be one of the largest issued by a Chinese court involving video games.

site_title: Manulife US Reit to sell Phipps Tower; exclusivity period for Mirae lapses
summary: Manulife US Reit has entered into a letter of intent to sell Phipps Tower in Atlanta, Georgia, to The Manufacturers Life Insurance Company, with a proposed sale by June 30, 2023. The Reit's manager aims to enhance unitholder value by redeploying proceeds into debt repayment or capital expenditure. The exclusivity period with Mirae Asset Global Investments has lapsed, allowing the Reit to consider other proposals. The sale comes as part of the Reit's ongoing strategic review, which includes exploring fundraising options and asset dispositions to reduce gearing.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Tanasbourne is a 132,851 square foot office campus comprising three flex-office buildings. It was constructed between 1986 and 1995, and was refurbished in 2015, 2017 and 2020.
Manulife US Reit's properties could continue to be marked down with rising interest rates, slowing US economic growth and a continuation of hybrid work arrangements

This comes after the reit said it would be exploring options to enhance shareholder value through the formation of a new strategic working group comprising the senior members of the manager and the board of the manager.
MAS should set out its expectations of troubled Reits' managers and sponsor groups

site_title: Hong Kong tackles a talent crunch for the ‘hardest position to fill’ in crypto
summary: Hong Kong is struggling to find qualified "responsible officers" (ROs) for cryptocurrency companies, a crucial position under the city's new regulatory regime. The shortage, described as the "hardest position to fill," could delay the launch of new crypto exchanges and hinder Hong Kong's efforts to become a major crypto hub. The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) has proposed a provision allowing a single individual to act as RO, and has received interest from several crypto companies, including Huobi Global and OKX.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong will roll out a licencing regime for virtual-asset platforms on Jun 1, part of an effort to restore its status as a cutting-edge financial centre.
Hong Kong starts a new licensing regime for virtual-asset service providers on Jun 1; it plans to let retail investors trade major tokens, such as Bitcoin and Ether.

site_title: Indonesian credit builder SkorLife bags US$4 million seed round
summary: Indonesian fintech company SkorLife has secured a US$4 million seed round led by Hummingbird Ventures, with QED Investors and returning investors AC Ventures and Saison Capital also participating. SkorLife's mobile app allows users to check their credit scores, detect identity theft, and receive credit improvement tips. The startup plans to use the funds for product development, marketing, and hiring. SkorLife aims to bring financial fairness and freedom to the Indonesian market, paving the way for a more inclusive and prosperous future for all Indonesians.

images.alt_text: Visa and Mastercard credit cards are displayed for a photograph in Tiskilwa, Illinois, U.S., on Tuesday, Sept. 18, 2018. Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. agreed to pay as much as $6.2 billion to end a long-running price-fixing case brought by merchants over card fees, the largest-ever class action settlement of an antitrust case. Photographer: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg

site_title: Honda to power Aston Martin’s F1 title ambitions from 2026
summary: Honda will return to Formula One as a full engine manufacturer for Aston Martin in 2026, powering the team's title ambitions. The partnership marks Honda's return to F1 after withdrawing in 2021, with the goal of achieving carbon neutrality. The new regulations and sustainable fuel use align with Honda's carbon neutrality goals, and the team aims to apply the technologies gained from F1 to their future electric vehicles. This move will enable Aston Martin to compete independently, having previously relied on Mercedes engines.

images.alt_text: The FIA said “security measures and the protocols which were expected to be in place for the event were not enforced, resulting in an unsafe environment for the spectators, drivers and race officials”.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Manulife US Reit, Japan Foods
summary: Manulife US Reit's manager plans to divest Phipps Tower in Atlanta as part of a strategic review. The company also considers proposals from other prospective partners for the potential sale. Meanwhile, Japan Foods posted a 63.3% drop in net profit for its second half, but saw a 27.7% increase in full-year net profit. Mercurius Capital Investment has requested a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink as US debt talks stall
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Wednesday as US debt ceiling talks stalled, with Hong Kong and Tokyo losing over 1% and Shanghai, Seoul, and Singapore experiencing hefty selling. Investors are concerned about the possibility of a painful default, with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warning that an agreement must be reached by June 1 to avoid default. The US economy is bracing for a potential crisis, with economists warning that a default could spark global market turmoil.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past an electric monitor displaying Nikkei share average and the Japanese yen exchange rate against the U.S. dollar outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan May 2, 2023.  REUTERS/Issei Kato//File Photo
SGX: Asia’s international, multi-asset exchange
Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta all rose on Tuesday, though there were small losses in Shanghai and Wellington.

site_title: Oil rises as US petrol supplies tighten, Saudi says: ‘watch out’
summary: Oil prices rose 1.1% on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures settling at $76.84 a barrel, amid forecasts for a tighter petrol market and warnings from Saudi Arabia's energy minister to speculators. US petrol inventories are expected to decline for the third straight week, and production cuts by Opec+ members take effect this month. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies may consider further output cuts at a meeting on June 4, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: More than 100 activists interrupt the opening remarks from chief executive Wael Sawan, according to Fossil Free London, while others attempt to occupy the stage.
Russia does appear to be exporting less crude via pipelines.
Brent futures for July delivery rose 41 cents, or 0.5 per cent, to settle at US$75.99 a barrel.

site_title: Gold holds steady on caution over US debt talks
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,975.99 per ounce on May 24, amid a lack of progress in US debt talks and investors assessing potential further rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The dollar index held firm, limiting gold price gains. US gold futures edged 0.1% higher to $1,977.10.

images.alt_text: While gold is considered a hedge against economic uncertainties, rising rates hurt demand for the zero-yielding asset.

site_title: Credit Suisse withdraws appeal over AT1 writedown, court says
summary: Credit Suisse has withdrawn its appeal over the writedown of AT1 bonds by Switzerland's banking regulator, according to a Swiss court. The writedown, which reduced the value of the bonds to zero, was part of an emergency rescue and takeover by UBS Group. Credit Suisse had argued that the writedown should not apply to contingent capital awards made to bankers, but the court ruled in favor of the regulator. The decision was made without explanation and no precautionary measures were sought.

site_title: UK pay awards hold at 6% in three months to April: XpertHR
summary: UK pay awards remain at 6% in the three months to April, matching record increases seen in the previous quarters. This is two percentage points higher than the same period last year. Despite inflation expectations easing to 8.2% in April, the Bank of England is concerned about the impact of growing pay deals on taming inflation. The International Monetary Fund forecasts Britain's economy will grow 0.4% in 2023, citing unsustainable wage rises as a threat to the economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Jeremy Hunt, UK chancellor of the exchequer, speaks during a news conference attended by IMF mission chief for the UK S. Ali Abbas, IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva and IMF communications director Julie Kozack, in London, UK, May 23, 2023.
Foreign direct investment into China has slowed substantially since the country abandoned its strict Covid-19 curbs late last year.
Markets are still leaning towards the BOE’s key lending rate hitting 5 per cent by September, up from 4.5 per cent currently.
Britain is a net food importer, meaning it’s extra vulnerable to tight supply.

site_title: Chinese fast-fashion platforms could be next US target
summary: US lawmakers warn of potential regulatory action against Chinese fast-fashion platforms, including Shein and Temu, amid concerns over data security and trade practices. China remains the US' largest apparel supplier, accounting for 21.7% of its clothing imports by value in 2022. The US-China tensions may impact the expansion of these e-commerce companies in North America, potentially leading to increased scrutiny and potential regulatory hurdles.

images.alt_text: Shein and Temu have taken the world by storm, with a potent combination of ultra-low prices and personalised recommendations.
Miniso currently has more than 70 outlets in America, with plans for total store count to grow to more than 100 by the end of this year.
Temu topped US app download rankings in early April, a spot it held since January.

site_title: EU and US discuss aligning investment controls with eye on China
summary: The European Union and the US are discussing aligning their investment controls to address national security risks posed by countries like China. The two partners aim to strengthen cooperation on sensitive technologies, including artificial intelligence and semiconductors, during a May 30-31 Trade and Technology Council meeting in Sweden. They plan to target non-market policies and practices in fields like legacy chips and explore cooperative measures to address distortionary effects. The EU and US have begun mapping out the network of third-country enterprises benefiting from government-owned or government-controlled investment funds.

images.alt_text: The 'Jing-Jin-Ji' region’s development will focus on sectors such as integrated circuits, network security and power equipment and biopharmaceutical industry.
Singapore’s shipments to China of integrated circuit chips has increased 3.5 per cent last month compared to March.

site_title: China’s yuan weakens to near 6-month low, gives up YTD gains against basket
summary: China's yuan weakened to a near six-month low against the dollar, losing all its year-to-date gains, amid tensions in Sino-US relations. The yuan fell to 7.0560 per dollar, 0.33% weaker than the previous fix, and the trade-weighted CFETS yuan basket index dropped to 98.51, its lowest since December 2022. Strong demand for dollars and a widening trade dispute between China and the US contributed to the decline, with state-run media saying the yuan's volatility is unlikely to increase due to stable economic fundamentals.

site_title: ‘Last Of Us’ drama success drives Sony gaming sales
summary: Sony's gaming sales are expected to catch up and exceed PlayStation 4 sales during the current financial year, driven by the success of hit drama "The Last Of Us" from HBO. The show's boost in game sales demonstrates Sony's efforts to repurpose popular franchises. Additionally, the company's PC business is expected to reach $450 million in revenue this year, a significant increase from $80 million two years ago. Sony is also investing in live-service games and cloud technology, with plans to accelerate its initiatives in the coming months.

images.alt_text: A year earlier, Sony articulated a strategy for carving out a bigger share of mobile and PC gaming with the help of live services.
The announcement comes just three years after Sony took full control of the business in a US$3.7 billion transaction.

site_title: Japan manufacturers’ mood turns positive as economy recovers
summary: Japan's manufacturers show a positive mood for the first time this year, with a sentiment index of +6, up from April, according to a Reuters Tankan poll. The service sector also sees a slight increase in morale, hitting a five-month high. The readings suggest the economy is recovering after a Covid-led recession, fueling speculation about the Bank of Japan normalizing its easing policy sooner. However, the central bank's governor has stated that inflation must remain at a sustainable rate of 2% before policy changes can occur.

images.alt_text: Chipmaker Arm, owned by SoftBank Group, last month filed confidentially for a US stock market listing, setting the stage for one of the biggest tech IPOs in the US this year.

Nominal wages in Japan rose 1.9 per cent in the last fiscal year ended in March, the fastest increase in 31 years, but inflation at 3.8 per cent outpaced those pay gains, resulting in real wages falling 1.8 per cent  in fiscal 2022.

site_title: Locally listed landlords face tough calls as Singapore office property market reprices
summary: Singapore's office property market is experiencing a repricing phase, with several big-ticket office buildings on the market. MPACT is eyeing S$880 million for its Mapletree Anson office tower, while Qatar Investment Authority's Asia Square Tower 1 is expected to fetch nearly S$2 billion. Keppel Corporation is also selling a 50% stake in its Keppel South Central project for an estimated S$1 billion. The lacklustre demand for office buildings is attributed to institutional investors' cautiousness due to high borrowing costs and interest rates exceeding office property yields.

The rarity of shophouses make it a valuable tool in wealth preservation, especially for high-net-worth individuals and family offices, said Richard Tan, PropNex senior associate group district director.
