Assuming the Thye Hua Kwan entities receive regulatory nods to purchase levels 10 and 14 at Solitaire on Cecil, eight of the freehold project's 15 office floors would be sold.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping 0.2% to 3,210.85. Losers outnumbered gainers 64 to 62, with 78.4 million securities changing hands. Seatrium, a marine engineering group, was the most actively traded counter, losing 0.8% to S$0.128. The market trend follows global market fluctuations, with no specific reason cited for the decline.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
The Reit's manager intends to divest Phipps Tower in Atlanta, Georgia, as part of the Reit’s ongoing stategic review

site_title: Toyota climbs most in 16 months, recovering from surprise drop
summary: Toyota's stock jumped 5.5% in early Tokyo trading, erasing a 4.8% drop from the previous day, after a sudden sale of 14.5 million shares temporarily erased $11 billion from its market value. The stock is up 6.9% this year, trailing the 14% gain in the Topix Transportation Equipment Index. Analysts attribute the sudden drop to a "wide range of reasons," possibly including a "fat finger" trading error or a need to raise funds. The company's earnings earlier this month were unsurprising, with shares remaining little changed since then.

site_title: US: Stocks drop on worries about debt ceiling talks
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday due to worries over uncertain debt ceiling talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.1% and 1.3%, respectively. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that an agreement must be reached by June 1. Analysts expressed nervousness about the debt situation, with some attributing the decline to the realization that time is running out for a deal. Individual companies like Apple and Lowe's reported mixed results amidst the market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has fallen 95.98 points, or 0.29 per cent, at the open to 33,190.60.

site_title: US top health official sounds alarm on child social media use
summary: US Surgeon General Vivek Murthy warned of the potential harm of social media to children's mental health and well-being, citing a nearly universal use of social media among US adolescents (95% reporting use, 1/3 saying they use "almost constantly"). Social media can expose children to extreme content, online bullying, and perpetuate body dissatisfaction, eating disorders, and depression. Murthy called on policymakers to strengthen safety standards and tech companies to assess the impact of their products on children.

images.alt_text: TikTok is currently facing federal- and state-level legislation that aims to ban or limit the app’s use in America on national security grounds.
TikTok called on the federal court to declare the Montana ban on its app unconstitutional and block the state from ever putting it into effect.

Montana is the first US state to ban TikTok, with the law set to take effect next year as debate escalates over the impact and security of the popular video app that is owned by Chinese company ByteDance.

site_title: KKR expects big private credit deals to keep coming forward
summary: KKR expects a surge in private credit deals, with $5-6 billion-sized packages expected to emerge, driven by market disruption and opportunities for private lenders. The firm's head of US debt capital markets, Cade Thompson, cited the example of a $6 billion debt package for Finastra Group Holdings, the largest private credit deal ever. Thompson notes that while macroeconomic uncertainty hinders broader M&A activity, it creates opportunities for firms like KKR to provide debt financing and capitalize on the private credit market.

images.alt_text: SembWaste is one of three public waste collectors appointed by Singapore’s National Environment Agency to provide waste and recyclable collection services to residential, schools and trade premises in the city-state, according to its website.
KKR reported US$719.3 million in distributable earnings, or 81 cents a share, during the quarter ended Mar 31, according to a Monday (May 8) statement.

site_title: Early-stage investor Antler still bullish on South-east Asia despite funding challenges
summary: Antler, a Singapore-based early-stage venture capital firm, remains bullish on South-east Asia despite global funding challenges. The firm's annual report shows that over 9,000 founders in the region applied to its founder program last year, with portfolio companies raising $718 million globally. Antler's co-founder Jussi Salovaara notes that investors now prioritize companies with a clear path to profitability and solid unit economics, rather than just growth. The firm plans to invest $100 million in new startups in South-east Asia over the next few years, with a focus on Indonesia.

site_title: JPMorgan pledges US$200 million to suck carbon from the sky
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has pledged US$200 million to pull carbon from the air through partnerships with startups Climeworks and Charm Industrial. The bank will purchase US$20 million in removal services from Climeworks and commit to 800,000 tons of carbon removal services. The move aims to scale up Climeworks' services and support the development of scalable solutions for net-zero emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: Vapour pours from a steel mill chimney in the industrial town of Port Kembla, about 80 km (50 miles) south of Sydney July 7, 2011. REUTERS/Tim Wimborne

site_title: UK police looking at fresh ‘Partygate’ claims against Johnson
summary: UK police are assessing new information related to alleged Covid lockdown breaches in Downing Street between June 2020 and May 2021, potentially involving Boris Johnson's family and friends. The Metropolitan Police and Thames Valley Police received material from the Cabinet Office, which supports prime ministers, and are investigating potential breaches. Johnson, the former UK prime minister, was ousted last summer following accusations of lockdown breaches and other scandals, with fines issued to his aides and a parliamentary committee investigating whether he lied to MPs about "Partygate".

images.alt_text: While Sunak has said that he wants to get immigration down “over time”, his focus has been on reducing the number of people arriving on Britain’s shores in small boats.
BBC chairman Richard Sharp said he had agreed to a request to stay on until the end of June to give the government time to find his successor.
In a letter to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, Raab said the inquiry had set a dangerous precedent, but that he would remain supportive of the government.

Former British Prime Minister Boris Johnson making his opening statement as he attends a Parliamentary Privileges Committee hearing, in central London on March 22, 2023. He said he was not warned the events broke the rules and has accused the committee of bias.

FILE PHOTO: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson delivers a speech during an engagement to mark the completion of the Elizabeth Line at Paddington Station in London, Britain, May 17, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Goldman backs Japan’s biggest taxi app at 135 billion yen valuation
summary: Goldman Sachs has invested 10 billion yen in Go, Japan's leading taxi-hailing provider, valuing it at 135 billion yen. The investment will fund aggressive acquisitions and an initial public offering (IPO) in the near future. Go, which launched its app in 2020, has become the most-used platform in Japan, outpacing Uber and Didi Global. The company plans to use the raised cash on new business initiatives, including a car-management system to promote electric vehicles and expand into related industries such as logistics.

images.alt_text: “Goldman Sachs cutting Adani group stakes from ESG funds and Adani Group companies now seeking to raise capital are two entirely separate events,” a spokesperson for Adani says.
Abu Dhabi has been attracting some big names in recent months.

site_title: IMF forecasts UK economic growth in major U-turn
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its forecast for the UK economy, predicting a 0.4% growth in 2023, up from its previous forecast of a 0.3% contraction just a month ago. The change was attributed to weaker energy prices, easing concerns over Brexit, and improved financial stability. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva defended the U-turn, praising the UK government's efforts to restore stability and tame inflation. The IMF also warned that the global economy remains highly uncertain, with US politicians still needing to address the nation's debt ceiling.

images.alt_text: Boris Johnson was ousted as prime minister last summer following a revolt within his ruling party after being dogged for months by the accusations of lockdown breaches and other scandals.
The interior ministry says the new measures will help cut migration “substantially” and stop people from using student visas as a backdoor route to find work in Britain.
Foreign direct investment into China has slowed substantially since the country abandoned its strict Covid-19 curbs late last year.
Markets are still leaning towards the BOE’s key lending rate hitting 5 per cent by September, up from 4.5 per cent currently.

site_title: MAS responds to queries over Angolan money launderer’s account in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has emphasized the importance of strict anti-money laundering controls in the financial industry, following the recent failed bid by an Angolan tycoon, Carlos Manuel De Sao Vicente, to release S$2.6 million from his frozen Bank of Singapore account. MAS requires financial institutions to file Suspicious Transaction Reports with the police and extend a copy to the regulator if they suspect a transaction could be linked to a crime. The bank, Bank of Singapore, has robust anti-money laundering controls in place, including ongoing monitoring and stepping up surveillance for higher risk situations.

images.alt_text: ST20221201_202287636190/pixmas/Jason Quah Generic photos at Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) taken on Dec 1, 2022. // to go with financial stories such as inflation, strengthening of Sing dollar, rise in interest rates

site_title: Credit Suisse managers’ 2022 bonuses cancelled or cut by Swiss government
summary: Credit Suisse senior managers will have their 2022 bonus payments either cancelled or reduced, following an order by the Swiss Finance Ministry. The move affects the top three levels of management and comes after a multi-billion franc state rescue of the bank. The decision is a response to public backlash against excessive bonus payouts, which were criticized as being out of touch with the bank's financial struggles. The state rescue provided roughly 260 billion Swiss francs of funding and guarantees.

images.alt_text: On May 9, Credit Suisse decided against an appeal and withdrew its application for precautionary measures, according to the court.

“The conclusion was very surprising to me, in terms of the way that the bank was resolved through this very unusual sale to UBS, with associated unusual payments to shareholders versus bondholders,” Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters says.
The claims against Finma relate to 2,500 individual parties.

site_title: Credit Suisse sale to UBS was ‘surprising’, Standard Chartered CEO says
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters described the sale of Credit Suisse to UBS as "surprising" due to the unusual terms, prioritizing shareholders over bondholders. The rescue deal, facilitated by Swiss authorities, involves UBS buying Credit Suisse for 3 billion Swiss francs and assuming up to 5 billion francs in losses. The deal rendered about $18 billion in debt worthless, leading to litigation from bondholders. Winters also emphasized that a transformation of banks is still needed despite the end of the banking crisis.

images.alt_text: The claims against Finma relate to 2,500 individual parties.
Law firms Quinn Emanuel and Pallas have received multiple requests from senior managers at Credit Suisse to take legal action on their behalf.
The example of Credit Suisse also shows that having liquidity facilities in place that are communicated to investors “reduces risks of contagion and supports resolution strategies,” said Laviola.

site_title: Japan’s Nikkei seen sliding to 30,000 by year-end: poll
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 share average is expected to drop 4% from its 33-year highs, reaching the 30,000 level by year-end and trading around the same level in mid-2024, according to analysts polled by Reuters. Forecasts range from 26,000 to 35,000, with a narrow consensus on a range-bound trading period. The outlook for the Nikkei is influenced by the Tokyo Stock Exchange's push for stronger corporate governance and the Bank of Japan's ultra-easy monetary policy, with some analysts citing China's sputtering post-lockdown recovery as a key risk.

images.alt_text: Wednesday’s monthly poll, which tracks the Bank of Japan’s closely watched tankan quarterly survey, found that manufacturers’ mood is expected to rise further over the coming three months, while the service-sector morale slid only slightly.
Beyond this year, economists expect growth in China to slow to 5 per cent or lower.
S&P has lowered SoftBank’s rating to “BB” from “BB+”, citing its exposure to unlisted companies that are susceptible to changes in the external environment.
The lender is planning a yen-denominated two-part AT1 note, with pricing expected as early as July.

site_title: World’s richest man loses US$11 billion after LVMH stock rout
summary: Bernard Arnault, the world's richest person, had $11.2 billion wiped from his fortune in one day due to a decline in LVMH shares amid concerns over a softening US economy's impact on luxury goods demand. Despite the selloff, Arnault still has a net worth of $191.6 billion, and the gap between his fortune and Elon Musk's has narrowed to $11.4 billion. Analysts attribute the decline to a "relatively more subdued" US performance and expect investors to become more selective with European luxury stocks.

images.alt_text: Mytheresa set up its first Asian office in Shanghai last summer to provide on-the-ground personal shopping services since top local clients couldn’t visit overseas luxury hubs given the Chinese pandemic curbs.
Tiffany has been working over the past two years to nail down top locations in the country, with three or four new spaces lined up, including in the Sanlitun fashionable shopping area in Beijing.

site_title: Driver crashes near White House, arrested for trying to kill Biden
summary: A 19-year-old man, Sai Varshith Kandula, crashed a U-Haul truck containing a Nazi flag near the White House, driving deliberately into security barriers at Lafayette Park. The driver was arrested and charged with attempting to kill or harm President Joe Biden, as well as other federal crimes. No one was injured in the incident, and President Biden was briefed on the situation. The motive behind the attack is still unclear.

images.alt_text: A Nazi flag and other objects recovered from a rented box truck are pictured on the ground as the U.S. Secret Service and other law enforcement agencies investigate the truck that crashed into security barriers at Lafayette Park across from the White House in Washington, U.S. May 23, 2023.   REUTERS/Nathan Howard     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: Uber to offer autonomous rides through Alphabet’s Waymo
summary: Uber and Alphabet's Waymo are partnering to offer autonomous rides in parts of Arizona, starting later this year. Passengers and deliveries will be transported in self-driving cars equipped with Waymo technology within a 180-square-mile area. The service will be limited to a set number of vehicles. Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi stated that fully autonomous driving is becoming part of everyday life, and the companies are excited to bring Waymo's technology to the Uber platform.

site_title: The circular economy of tyres
summary: The tyre industry is exploring sustainable sources of raw materials and production methods, aiming to reduce waste and emissions. Retreading, a process of replacing the tread on worn tyres, is considered a more sustainable alternative, with companies like Bandag reporting significant oil and tyre waste savings. The use of retreading and recycling efforts can reduce resource usage by nearly 70% and CO2 emissions by 65%. The industry is also investing in technology, such as smart tyre monitoring, to optimize tyre performance and extend their lifespan, ultimately reducing the environmental impact of the tyre life cycle.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of waste glass for ESG, sustainability and climate resilience  stories for Budget 2023
Reduce, repair, recycle as EU plans 'circular' rules for everyday items

site_title: BandLab raises US$25 million in extended Series B round
summary: BandLab, a Singapore-based social music creation platform, has raised an additional US$25 million in Series B1 funding, bringing its post-money valuation to US$425 million. The new funding round was led by Cercano Management and Prosus Ventures, with super pro-rata participation. The company plans to use the funds to expand its team, double down on marketing efforts, and support services such as its music education platform BandLab for Education. This brings BandLab's total Series B funding to US$90 million.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit by slide in luxury majors, Julius Baer weighs
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.6% lower on Tuesday, its steepest one-day percentage fall in three weeks, due to losses in luxury majors and a weak update from Swiss wealth manager Julius Baer. The Stoxx Europe Luxury 10 index plummeted 4.3%, its largest daily drop since mid-December. The decline was also attributed to economic data and the US debt ceiling deadlock.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.7 per cent lower at 33,055.51 on Tuesday.

site_title: Sony prepares ‘aggressive’ cloud gaming push in coming months
summary: Sony is preparing an "aggressive" push into cloud gaming in the coming months, with the goal of expanding its reach beyond consoles. The company is building on its acquisition of Bungie last year, which will help it offer more live services on PlayStation consoles and beyond. Sony Interactive Entertainment president Jim Ryan stated that cloud computing will be fundamental to tapping into mobile gaming trends, and the company has "some fairly interesting and quite aggressive plans" to accelerate its initiatives in cloud gaming.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on October 31, 2022 shows a woman walking past the Sony logo outside the company's headquarters in Tokyo. - The Japanese entertainment and electronics conglomerate will release second quarter earnings later in the day on November 1. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia’s digital banks a disruptor but will also bring collaboration opportunities
summary: Malaysia is set to have five digital banks operational in the coming months, but they are unlikely to replace traditional lenders. Industry observers believe these newcomers will serve different market segments, creating opportunities for collaboration between traditional and digital banks. Experts predict that the banking sector will become more digitalized, with digital banks playing a facilitator or connector role in orchestrating collaborations. Traditional banks will likely acquire digital banks to stay competitive, and the lines between digital and conventional banks will eventually blur.

images.alt_text: Many businesses in Malaysia are struggling to balance their accounts, after several new measures were implemented in 2022, such as an adjustment of the minimum wage and an increase in electricity prices.
Bank Negara Malaysia Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said: "The economy is no longer in crisis and in fact, continues to gain strenth."
GXS CEO Charles Wong unveiling the digital bank's Flexiloan product, which is its first step to building a profitable bank.

site_title: Nearshoring in automotive logistics
summary: South-east Asia is emerging as a viable nearshoring option for vehicle manufacturers to strengthen supply chain resilience. Companies like Mitsubishi Motors are already utilizing local expertise in design, engineering, and manufacturing in countries such as Japan. The Covid-19 pandemic highlighted the vulnerability of global supply chains, and nearshoring aims to mitigate these risks by moving production closer to customers. By leveraging local talent and reducing reliance on international suppliers, nearshoring can improve supply chain efficiency and reduce costs. This strategy is gaining traction in the automotive industry.

images.alt_text: Toymaker Mattel expands Mexican plant in 'nearshoring' push
Global supply chains are falling out of fashion

site_title: White House rules out constitutional solution to debt crisis
summary: The White House has ruled out invoking the 14th Amendment to the US constitution to prevent a debt default, stating that it "is not going to fix the current problem we have right now." White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre made the statement in response to speculation about using the amendment to ignore the debt limit. The move suggests that the administration is exploring other solutions to the debt impasse, but has not yet identified a viable alternative.

site_title: Japan Foods H2 profit falls 63% to S$1.8 million on higher costs
summary: Japan Foods Holding reported a 63.3% drop in net profit to S$1.8 million for its second half, despite a 21.4% increase in revenue to S$40.6 million. Higher costs, mainly due to manpower expenses and depreciation of assets, contributed to the decline. Despite this, the company attributed its improved performance to the "strong momentum" of its Halal segment and new brand additions. A final dividend of one Singapore cent per share was proposed, down from 1.35 cents last year.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
MOM’s investigation uncovered erroneous Central Provident Fund contributions, which inflated the foreign employee entitlement for the subsidiary, Japan Foods Enterprises.

site_title: Climate protesters disrupt Shell shareholder meet
summary: Environmental protesters disrupted Shell's shareholder meeting in London, with over 100 activists interrupting CEO Wael Sawan's opening remarks and others attempting to occupy the stage. Pressure groups, including Greenpeace and Fossil Free London, protested Shell's pledge to tackle carbon emissions, citing concerns over the company's "greenwashing" and profiteering. The protesters also blocked speeches from Shell chairman Andrew Mackenzie and other board members, with chants of "Shut down Shell" and "Go to hell Shell."

site_title: China plans for ‘Jing-Jin-Ji’ world-class industrial cluster
summary: China plans to develop the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region, known as Jing-Jin-Ji, into a world-class industrial cluster focusing on sectors such as integrated circuits, network security, and biopharmaceuticals. The region's development aims to promote coordinated industrial development, reduce income gaps, and curb pollution. The plan also includes industries in new energy vehicles, intelligent connected vehicles, biomedicine, and research on artificial intelligence and aerospace technology. This move aims to confirm China's global competitiveness and technological breakthroughs in the face of growing tensions with the US.

images.alt_text: Beyond this year, economists expect growth in China to slow to 5 per cent or lower.

site_title: US dollar strengthens broadly on Fed rate expectations
summary: The US dollar index has risen 0.3% to 103.53, nearing a two-month high, due to expectations that the Federal Reserve will maintain higher interest rates for longer. Federal Reserve officials, including Minneapolis Fed president Neel Kashkari and St Louis Fed president James Bullard, hinted that rates may need to reach 6% to control inflation. The dollar's strength also comes amid ongoing debt ceiling negotiations, keeping investors on edge.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ Dollar bills are printed at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing facility in Fort Worth, Texas on Dec. 8, 2022. The $24 trillion U.S. Treasury market is the largest debt market in the world. (Adam Perez/The New York Times)

site_title: Vietnam central bank to cut policy rates from Thursday
summary: The State Bank of Vietnam announced rate cuts, reducing the overnight electronic interbank rate to 5.5% from 6% and keeping the discount rate at 3.5%. This is the central bank's third rate cut since mid-March to support economic growth amid weak demand in key markets. The move aims to lower lending rates, supporting the economy and accelerating growth, particularly in the real estate sector.

images.alt_text: “The State Bank of Vietnam will continue to closely monitor the economic situation, and will cut its policy rates in case of favourable conditions,” governor Nguyen Thi Hong says.

site_title: Apple inks multi-billion-dollar deal with Broadcom for US-made chips
summary: Apple has signed a multi-billion-dollar deal with chipmaker Broadcom to produce 5G radio frequency components in the US. The deal will utilize film bulk acoustic resonator (FBAR) chips, which aid in mobile data networks for Apple devices. Broadcom's US facilities, including Fort Collins, Colorado, will be involved in the production. This move aligns with Apple's goal of increasing US manufacturing and supporting over 1,100 jobs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A women uses an iPhone mobile device as she passes a lighted Apple logo at the Apple store at Grand Central Terminal in New York City, U.S., April 14, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: Netflix expands password sharing crackdown around the world
summary: Netflix has expanded its crackdown on password sharing to over 100 countries, including the US, with emails alerting users that their accounts cannot be shared for free outside of their households. The company aims to make money as it faces market saturation, with efforts including limits on password borrowing and a new ad-supported option. As of March, 232.5 million households subscribed to Netflix, with an estimated 100 million households sharing passwords. Users can add a member outside their homes for an additional fee, and transfer a person's profile to keep viewing history and recommendations.

images.alt_text: Netflix launchs a significant increase in Japanese content in 2021, including anime, live action and animated feature films.
Netflix launched a US$7-per-month ad-supported tier in November in 12 markets.

site_title: How to beat the heat sustainably? Investment firm joins forces with innovative partners to pave the way
summary: Investment firm Temasek joins forces with innovative partners to develop sustainable energy solutions to mitigate the effects of climate change. The firm aims to achieve its net-zero carbon ambition through three pathways: investing in climate-aligned opportunities, enabling carbon-negative solutions, and encouraging decarbonization in businesses. A district cooling network, which reduces energy consumption by 17% annually, is being explored in Tampines Central, Singapore. The initiative will power 1,665 three-room HDB flats and reduce carbon emissions by 0.5°C by 2100, equivalent to a 6cm rise in sea levels.

site_title: Why the West has high hopes for India
summary: The Western world has high hopes for India, with the country poised to become the world's most populous nation by 2023. This demographic milestone coincides with India's growing economic potential, making it a key counterweight to Beijing. Western powers, including the US, UK, and EU, are seeking bilateral free trade deals and believe India's longer-term economic future is bright. However, India's success will depend on overcoming infrastructure, governance, and social spending challenges, and Prime Minister Modi must "walk the walk" to deliver on these critical agendas.

images.alt_text: Over the period to 2040, India will likely add 270 million people to its urban population.
Crowding at a raillway station in Mumbai. India has become the world's most populous nation, overtaking China.
Commuters outside a railway station in Mumbai, India; April 2023.

site_title: Hotpot chain Little Sheep ends franchise agreement with No Signboard
summary: Little Sheep Hong Kong Holdings has terminated its franchise agreement with No Signboard Holdings due to the seafood restaurant operator's failure to launch the required number of new restaurants under the 10-year agreement. No Signboard cited the failure as the reason for the termination, while also owing Little Sheep an outstanding payment of US$61,695.85. The company's shares have been suspended from trading since January 2022.

images.alt_text: No Signboard outlet at Esplanade.
Tessa Oh

site_title: US new home sales soar to 13-month high in April
summary: US new home sales reached a 13-month high in April, increasing 4.1% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 683,000 units, the highest reading since March 2022. This surge is attributed to a persistent shortage of previously owned houses on the market. Economists had forecast a decline, but sales rebounded 11.8% on a year-on-year basis. The median new house price in April was $420,800, an 8.2% drop from a year ago, and it would take 7.6 months to clear the supply of houses on the market.

images.alt_text: FOLSOM, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 22: A sign is posted in front of an available home at a KB Home housing development on March 22, 2023 in Folsom, California. Homebuilder KB Home will report first quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Global dividends hit first quarter record US$326.7 billion
summary: Global companies paid a record US$326.7 billion in dividends to shareholders in the first quarter of 2023, a 12% increase from the same period last year. Automakers Ford and Volkswagen accounted for nearly a third of all special dividends, with Volkswagen using proceeds from a Porsche stock listing to pay out US$6.3 billion. Globally, 95% of companies increased or held steady dividends, and forecasted to pay out US$1.6 trillion in 2023. This growth is seen as a positive sign despite a challenging economic environment in 2022.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Ford logo is pictured at the Ford Motor Co plant in Genk,Belgium December 17, 2014. REUTERS/Francois Lenoir/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia seizes Swatch watches over ‘LGBT elements’
summary: Malaysian authorities seized 164 rainbow-colored Swatch watches from 11 shopping malls worth $14,000, citing the Printing Presses and Publications Act of 1984. The watches, from Swatch's Pride Collection, were deemed to have "LGBT elements" despite CEO Nick Hayek's statement that they conveyed a message of peace and love. The seizure is part of a larger crackdown on content deemed to offend or undermine racial relations, with the law being criticized as draconian.

images.alt_text: Budget Omega watch lures mobs of shoppers, buoys Swatch stock

site_title: Citizens Bank to pay US$9 million penalty over credit card practices: US regulator
summary: Citizens Bank, a US regional bank, agreed to pay a US$9 million civil penalty to resolve charges of mismanaging credit card disputes and fraud claims. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) accused the bank of violating the federal Truth in Lending Act by making customers "jump through unnecessary hoops" to resolve billing errors and unauthorized card use. The bank will improve its credit card practices, including providing refunds on valid claims and not requiring customers to sign fraud affidavits. The settlement resolves a CFPB lawsuit filed in 2020 and requires federal judge approval.

site_title: Vietnam’s No Va Land in talks with Credit Suisse, others to restructure debt: source
summary: Vietnam's No Va Land Investment Group, the country's fifth-largest developer, is in talks with Credit Suisse and other foreign creditors to restructure part of its $1 billion foreign debt. The real estate sector has been hit hard due to government crackdowns on corruption and stricter rules on corporate bonds. No Va Land has missed payments on three domestic bonds and faces further repayment obligations worth $806 million on 30 bond tranches. The company is seeking to negotiate deals with foreign creditors to reduce repayment pressure and has already reached agreements with some creditors.

images.alt_text: No Va Land, which was founded in 2007 and is active mostly in residential property and luxury resorts.

site_title: Alphabet-backed AI startup Anthropic raises US$450 million as funding freeze thaws
summary: Anthropic, an AI startup backed by Alphabet, raised $450 million in funding, bringing its valuation to $4 billion. The latest round was led by Spark Capital and included participation from Google and other investors. Anthropic's AI systems are deemed safe as they would not provide instructions on building weapons or using biased language. This funding comes as the private funding market begins to show signs of recovery, with optimism about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike cycle boosting venture capitalist sentiment.

site_title: JTC extends solar deployment programme to privately-leased industrial buildings
summary: JTC has extended its SolarRoof programme to privately leased industrial properties, aiming to increase Singapore's solar capacity from 225.4 MWp to 900 MWp by 2030. The programme, which offers discounted rates for power generated from solar panels, has already seen almost 400 companies install solar panels on their roofs. The extension aims to make solar adoption easy and accessible, with the potential to generate 1,250 MWp and contribute 60% to Singapore's total solar deployment target.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

This will bring Jurong Island’s total solar energy capacity to 103.2 megawatt peak (MWp), an eightfold increase from the current 12.3 MWp generated from Jurong Island companies’ rooftop installations.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as debt ceiling talks remain deadlocked
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, May 23, as debt ceiling talks remained deadlocked. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 95.98 points, or 0.29%, to 33,190.60, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The uncertainty over the US debt limit has raised concerns of an unprecedented government default, sparking market volatility.

site_title: SoftBank pushes back after S&P cuts rating deeper into junk
summary: SoftBank's credit rating has been lowered to "BB" from "BB+" by S&P, citing exposure to unlisted companies susceptible to external environment changes. The downgrade led SoftBank to push back, stating it will "play defence" with prudent financial management. The company has sold assets, including its Alibaba stake, to stabilize its balance sheet amid portfolio value decline. SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son has urged S&P to consider an upgrade once chip designer Arm's proposed IPO is completed.

images.alt_text: Chipmaker Arm, owned by SoftBank Group, last month filed confidentially for a US stock market listing, setting the stage for one of the biggest tech IPOs in the US this year.

site_title: Better analysis of corporate sustainability data now available to banks with upgraded platform
summary: Singapore-based ESG registry Stacs has launched ESGpedia 2.0, an upgraded platform providing banks and corporates with better access to and analysis of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) data from businesses worldwide. The platform now covers over 5 million sustainability disclosure data points, with more than 180,000 companies' sustainability data, and includes enhanced solutions and assessment tools. Additionally, a digitalized and simplified self-assessment tool will be launched for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to help them kick-start their sustainability journey.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Dr Darian McBain, chief sustainability officer of MAS, was the guest of honour at the Project Greenprint industry showcase event, where ESGpedia was launched.

Having access to STACS’ ESGpedia portfolio monitoring tool would allow the investment manager to see greater asset level details, such as the green certifications of the buildings financed by green bonds, thus supporting its due diligence and monitoring of investee companies, says Eric Nietsch, Manulife’s head of sustainable investing.
New platforms to tackle ESG data gaps in Singapore

site_title: Demerit system for manufacturing, stricter criteria for public tenders among workplace safety changes
summary: Singapore is introducing new workplace safety measures to improve safety and health in the manufacturing sector. The country's workplace safety demerit point system will be extended to manufacturing, with stricter safety requirements added to government tenders. The new measures, announced as part of the National WSH Campaign 2023, aim to strengthen workplace safety ownership and build a strong safety culture. The measures include improved safety training for workers, enhanced surveillance systems, and stricter penalties for companies with WSH lapses.

images.alt_text: A lorry crane is found toppled on its left side at an ExxonMobil project site.
The maximum fines for breaches of WSH Act Subsidiary Legislation will be increased to S$50,000 from S$20,000.
New workplace safety and health (WSH) measures are being considered; This includes increased maximum fines and mandatory training for those found to have serious WSH lapses

site_title: Microsoft beefs up ChatGPT and Bing in wide-ranging AI product launch
summary: Microsoft has launched a wide-ranging AI product update, including enhanced ChatGPT, Bing search engine, and cloud services. Live search results from Bing will now be available to ChatGPT users, and the company is expanding plug-ins for Bing, allowing businesses to transact with consumers more easily. The updates aim to narrow the gap with Alphabet Inc's Google in the estimated US$286 billion search advertising market. Microsoft also announced an AI assistant, Copilot, available as a preview for Windows users, and plans to let companies configure their own AI copilots more broadly.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Microsoft logo is seen a day after Microsoft Corp's $26.2 billion purchase of LinkedIn Corp, in Los Angeles, California, U.S. June 14, 2016. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: An MIT verdict on artificial intelligence
summary: MIT economists Daron Acemoglu and Simon Johnson warn that the regulation of artificial intelligence (AI) is crucial to maximize its benefits and minimize its risks. Their book, "Power and Progress: Our Thousand-Year Struggle Over Technology and Prosperity," suggests that AI has the potential to improve most aspects of life but also poses a threat to human extinction. The authors argue that AI has been hijacked by self-seeking elites, leading to a surveillance capitalism system that exploits workers and manipulates people's emotions. To mitigate this, they propose policies such as providing government subsidies for socially beneficial technologies, breaking up big-tech companies, and imposing a digital advertising tax.

images.alt_text: There's been a carefully constructed narrative around technology, one of techno-optimism : invent as much as you can, and good things – higher wages, better health, and more opportunity – will follow. Not so.
Rise of the robots speeds up in pandemic with US labour shortage

site_title: World Bank seeks grants, new capital to fight global crises
summary: The World Bank is seeking billions of dollars in grants and new capital to combat global crises, including climate change, as its crisis facility for the world's poorest countries faces depletion. Managing Director of Operations Anna Bjerde hopes to secure funding by the end of the year, citing the need for resource transfers from developed countries to lower-income ones. The World Bank plans to increase lending and explore new financing tools, including sub-national lending, to tackle pressing global issues.

images.alt_text: Greater persistence in inflation and accompanying unsustainable increases in wages were the biggest threat to Britain’s economic outlook, the IMF says.

We expect that an endowment approach will stand investors to good stead in the years ahead in a climate marked by higher interest rates and more volatile inflation than before, says Hugues Rialan, Asia chief investment officer and head of discretionary portfolio management at Pictet Wealth Management.

site_title: Britain to limit migration by family of overseas students
summary: The UK interior ministry plans to limit migration by family members of overseas students, starting from January. The measures aim to reduce net migration substantially and prevent students from using student visas as a backdoor route to find work in Britain. Postgraduate students except those on research programmes will no longer be allowed to bring partners and children to the country. The move is part of the government's efforts to reduce high levels of legal migration and protect public services, with numbers of student dependents having jumped eightfold since 2019.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt has defended borrowing billions of pounds to protect families and businesses against the impacts of the pandemic and Putin’s energy crisis.
Greater persistence in inflation and accompanying unsustainable increases in wages were the biggest threat to Britain’s economic outlook, the IMF says.
Consumers are doing everything they can to curb the impact of sky-high inflation, shopping at discount grocers and buying supermarkets’ own-brand goods.

site_title: From mangoes to luxury watches, Indians look to offload 2,000-rupee notes
summary: In India, the 2,000-rupee note, set to be withdrawn from circulation by the end of September, has been causing a surge in purchases of daily essentials and premium goods. People are using the note to avoid hassle of exchanging or depositing at banks, which is expected to be less disruptive than a 2016 demonetization move. Indian shops are seeing an increase in sales, with some sellers receiving up to 8-10 notes per day, while others are hesitant to accept the notes due to potential tax scrutiny.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A cashier displays 2000 Indian rupee banknotes inside a bank in Jammu, November 15, 2016. REUTERS/Mukesh Gupta/File Photo

site_title: China stocks post biggest fall in a month as recovery falters
summary: China's blue-chip CSI300 Index fell 1.4% and the Shanghai Composite Index plummeted 1.5% on Tuesday, marking the largest daily percentage drop in a month. Investors are worried about the country's slowing economic recovery, weakening yuan, and geopolitical risks. Foreign investors sold nearly 8 billion yuan of Chinese stocks, while the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong fell 1.3%. Experts say market pricing is difficult to justify unless the recovery completely collapses, but policymakers still have room to maneuver, making pessimism overdone.

site_title: Warner Bros Discovery relaunches HBO Max streamer as ‘Max’ in bid for broader audience
summary: Warner Bros Discovery is relaunching HBO Max as "Max" with a broader audience in mind, combining HBO's high-end scripted programming with Discovery's food, home, and lifestyle content. The revamped service aims to retain viewers who typically cancel after watching a favorite show, a strategy that proved successful for Discovery+. The new "Max" will feature a mix of critically acclaimed dramas and reality fare, including a forthcoming "Harry Potter" series and "Game of Thrones" prequel. The service will have three tiers, including an ad-supported version for $10/month and an ad-free version for $16/month.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose in April, reaching 7.1%, despite core inflation remaining flat. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) reported mixed inflation across categories. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% on Tuesday. The MAS policy change on interest rates is still not expected, and Singapore investors will soon be able to buy exposure to three Thai listed companies through newly launched Singapore depository receipts. S&P downgraded SingPost's credit rating to 'BBB' due to weakness in its post and parcel segment.

site_title: High inflation swells UK budget deficit in April
summary: The UK government borrowed £25.56 billion in April, exceeding expectations, due to high inflation pushing interest bills to a new record. The borrowing is part of efforts to protect families and businesses from the pandemic and energy crisis. Despite tax cuts, debt remains high, with borrowing levels not seen since World War II. The government aims to reduce debt, but economists doubt this will happen in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, speaks during the Bank of England's financial stability report news conference, at the Bank of England, London August 4, 2022. Yui Mok/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Halcyon Agri Q1 earnings fall 93.4% to US$1 million on high raw material prices
summary: Halcyon Agri's Q1 earnings plummet 93.4% to US$1 million due to high raw material prices, despite a 2% increase in sales volumes to 309,737 tonnes. Revenue fell 20.3% to US$492.2 million, and gross profit dropped 35.1% to US$30.5 million. The company cited margin compression as the main factor, with a low rubber-tapping season also affecting earnings. CEO Li Xuetao remains cautiously optimistic about the group's long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
China Hainan Rubber launched the offer for Halcyon Agri at S$0.413 per share in February this year.

Sinochem International (Overseas) – which still holds a direct interest in around 29.2 per cent of Halcyon Agri’s shares following the closing of the November acqusition – has provided an irrevocable undertaking that it will reject the offer.
Ex-Halcyon Agri co-founder named CEO of fund manager set up by former StanChart Singapore chief
Halcyon Agri bags three-year syndicated loan facility of up to US$300m
Halcyon Agri swings to profit in H1 amid higher rubber prices

site_title: Last Qing emperor Puyi’s Patek Philippe watch sells for US$5.1 million
summary: A Patek Philippe Ref 96 Quantieme Lune timepiece once owned by Aisin-Gioro Puyi, the last emperor of China's Qing Dynasty, sold for HK$40 million (US$5.1 million) at a live auction in Hong Kong on May 23, 2023. The watch, completed in 1937, was given to Puyi's interpreter Georgy Permyakov during Puyi's imprisonment in the Soviet Union. The auction, attended by mainland and local Hong Kong collectors, lasted about seven minutes.

images.alt_text: The Patek Reference 96 Quantieme Lune. Only eight versions were made, and a mere three had this dial configuration.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise amid improving sentiment; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,218.08 on May 23, driven by improving investor sentiment globally. The market has recovered since mid-March, with declining volatility and a preference for liquid, large, and profitable companies. DBS was the top gainer, while UOB and OCBC also saw gains, while DFI Retail Group and Singapore Airlines were the biggest losers.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
MAS policy change still not expected as Singapore headline inflation ticks up in April, core remains flat

site_title: Credit Suisse AT1 bonds – Swiss court receives 230 claims against Swiss regulator
summary: A Swiss court has received 230 claims against the country's financial regulator Finma over the government-orchestrated rescue of Credit Suisse in March, which wiped out the value of AT1 bonds. The claims are from 2,500 individual parties, with a law firm representing the bondholders seeking redress for expropriated assets. Finma has defended its decision, saying it was legally watertight, while the government has also defended the decision. The bondholders will receive nothing, while shareholders will receive $3.23 billion under the takeover deal.

images.alt_text: Law firms Quinn Emanuel and Pallas have received multiple requests from senior managers at Credit Suisse to take legal action on their behalf.

site_title: Meta sells Giphy to Shutterstock to comply with UK regulator order
summary: Meta Platforms has sold Giphy to Shutterstock for $53 million in cash, complying with a UK regulator's order to divest the animated-images platform due to concerns it could limit competitors' access to its content. Meta had acquired Giphy for $400 million in 2020, and its sale follows a successful campaign by Britain's Competition and Markets Authority, which forced the US tech giant to sell the company. The deal marks the end of a dispute over competition concerns, with Shutterstock set to acquire the platform.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on January 12, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows a tablet displaying the logo of the company Meta. Facebook owner Meta has been fined a record 1.2 billion euros ($1.3 billion) for transferring EU user data to the United States in breach of a previous court ruling, Ireland's regulator announced May 23, 2023. The Irish Data Protection Commission, which acts on behalf of the European Union, said the European Data Protection Board had ordered it to collect "an administrative fine in the amount of 1.2 billion euros". Meta said it would appeal the decision. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)

site_title: S&P downgrades SingPost’s credit rating to ‘BBB’ on weakening prospects
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded SingPost's credit rating to 'BBB' from 'BBB+' due to weakening prospects in the post and parcel segment, which may be more prolonged than anticipated. The downgrade comes amid SingPost's pivot to the Australian logistics market, which has put pressure on the group's financial profile. Debt remains elevated, and the company may need to invest further, increasing its leverage profile. However, the logistics segment is expected to remain profitable with further growth potential.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The board recommends a final dividend of S$0.40 per share, subject to approval from shareholders at its next annual general meeting.
SingPost Centre’s overall occupancy stands at 98.7 per cent as at end-2022.
Vincent Yik, Group CFO, Singapore Post
The board has declared an interim dividend of S$0.0018 per share for the half-year, which will be paid to shareholders on Nov 30.
Singpost’s subsidiary QSI was also granted two put options by Cainiao to dispose of its equity interest in 4PX.
Upon completion of the transaction, SingPost’s total stake in FMH will increase from 51 per cent currently, to 88 per cent.

site_title: Political instability ‘puts decarbonisation of shipping at risk’
summary: A new report from the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) warns that political instability and financial instability pose significant risks to the decarbonization of shipping. The ICS Maritime Barometer Report 2022-2023 found that maritime leaders are concerned about the need for clear direction from governments to accelerate the green energy transition. The report highlights the importance of regulatory clarity in the shipping industry, particularly in the area of decarbonization, and cautions that delays in government decision-making could have far-reaching consequences for the industry.

images.alt_text: By the end of the Singapore Maritime Week 2023, top international industry leaders should have come away with a clear idea of Asian shipowners’ views.

site_title: Malaysia, UAE to start talks on bilateral trade deal
summary: Malaysia and the UAE agreed to negotiate a Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA), covering trade in goods and services, investments, and economic cooperation. The UAE is Malaysia's 17th trade partner globally and second in the Middle East, accounting for 32% of Malaysia's trade with Arab countries. The agreement follows strong growth in bilateral trade and investment, with Malaysian investments in the UAE at US$150 million and UAE investments in Malaysia at US$220 million.

site_title: Messi, Ronaldo lead Saudi Arabia’s multi-billion-dollar makeover
summary: Saudi Arabia is investing heavily in sports and entertainment to boost its tourism industry, with a reported $400 million annual offer to Lionel Messi, following Cristiano Ronaldo's $200 million-a-year contract with Al-Nassr FC. The kingdom aims to attract 100 million visitors by 2030, with projects like the luxury travel destination Al-Ula, which has drawn high-end hotels and pop stars like Alicia Keys. Critics say the efforts are aimed at improving the kingdom's international image, but human rights campaigners argue that the spending deflects attention from domestic issues, including poor free speech and human rights records.

images.alt_text: Paris Saint-Germain's Argentine forward Lionel Messi reacts during the French L1 football match between AJ Auxerre and Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) at Stade de l'Abbe-Deschamps in Auxerre, central France, on May 21, 2023. (Photo by JULIEN DE ROSA / AFP)

site_title: Geely premium automaker Lynk looks to further European growth
summary: Lynk, a premium automaker jointly owned by Geely and Volvo, plans to expand in Europe, including Britain, by opening its first showroom in France by early 2024. The company, which offers monthly car subscriptions, aims to launch a fully-electric model, the 02, by the end of 2024 and enter other European markets, including Norway, Austria, and Switzerland. Lynk's CEO, Alain Visser, said the company has "ambition" to branch out into the US market and may need to manufacture cars in Europe due to rising tensions between China and the US.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Lynk & Co 08 EM-P is displayed at the Auto Shanghai show, in Shanghai, China April 18, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Cathay Pacific apologises after passenger alleges discrimination
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has apologized after a passenger accused its flight attendants of discriminating against non-English speakers on a flight from Chengdu to Hong Kong. The airline has suspended the flight attendants involved and launched an internal investigation into "inappropriate words and deeds" that allegedly violated its rules and professional ethics. The incident has caused "widespread concern" among passengers, prompting Cathay to sincerely apologize and assure that any misconduct will be dealt with seriously.

site_title: “We need to talk about the rent.”
summary: Singapore's 42% surge in residential rents over the last three years is driving expatriates and employers to reevaluate their living arrangements, with some comparing rents to those in Hong Kong. Similar market dynamics are seen in Dubai, where 90% of residents are foreign and rentals are being driven up by a surge of crypto enthusiasts, bankers, and wealthy individuals. The rising costs may lead businesses to reconsider relocating to Singapore, posing a challenge to the city-state's attractiveness as a financial hub.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low
The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter.
The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter
The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter (April 11, 2023)
The Business Times' Property Newsletter (May 23, 2023)
The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter (April 18, 2023)
BT's Property Insights newsletter.
BT's Property Insights newsletter.

site_title: Review to be carried out on Ridout Road properties; Shanmugam and Vivian requested it: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that a review will be carried out on properties rented to Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam and Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan on Ridout Road, following concerns about the ministers' involvement. The review, led by Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean, aims to ensure the government maintains integrity and address allegations of wrongdoing. The review's findings will be made public before the parliamentary sitting in July, and the ministers have requested an independent review.

images.alt_text: In a statement on May 12, SLA gave details of how the properties came to be rented out by Cabinet ministers K. Shanmugam (left) and Vivian Balakrishnan.

site_title: China faces decades-long growth ‘plateau’, says EU Chamber head
summary: China is facing a decades-long economic growth "plateau," with growth expected to slow to 5% or lower in the next two decades, according to the EU Chamber of Commerce in China. The country's growth outlook is expected to return to pre-pandemic rates of 6% this year, but will settle at 2-3% in the long term. Outgoing EU Chamber head Joerg Wuttke warns that China needs to tackle deep-rooted problems and implement painful reforms, including overhauling the education system, to improve its growth prospects and avoid a Japan-like scenario.

images.alt_text: Mytheresa set up its first Asian office in Shanghai last summer to provide on-the-ground personal shopping services since top local clients couldn’t visit overseas luxury hubs given the Chinese pandemic curbs.

site_title: A healthy investment: Why putting your money in this sector pays off
summary: The healthcare sector is poised to outperform the broader market due to its defensive characteristics and growth potential. Despite macroeconomic challenges, the sector's resilience in delivering innovation to patients and addressing unmet medical needs drives growth. The pharmaceuticals segment is particularly resilient, while segments like healthcare technology and biotechnology offer growth opportunities. With the global population aging and middle-class growth in emerging markets, the healthcare sector is well-positioned for long-term growth. Investing in the healthcare sector, such as through exchange-traded funds like the iShares Global Healthcare fund, may provide potential for outperformance against the broader market.

images.alt_text: thermometer, medications, tablets

site_title: At Antwerp Art Weekend, collectors buy with their gut
summary: During Antwerp Art Weekend, collectors in Antwerp, Belgium, focused on buying art with their intuition rather than relying on expert advice. The event, which featured 30 commercial galleries, saw a commercial success with at least 25 artworks selling for prices ranging from €3,000 to €13,000. Young Belgian artists, such as Inès van den Kieboom and Ben Sledsens, were popular, with their works selling to international collectors. The event aimed to promote Belgium's thriving contemporary art scene, which has been boosted by the city's reputation for having a high number of collectors per capita.

images.alt_text: Visitors view “Scan Time (Nature),” a 2023 painting by Antonia Rodrian, on display at Newchild Gallery during Antwerp Art Weekend in Antwerp, Belgium, May 19, 2023. The Belgian city doesn’t have a huge dealer base, nor is it home to as many artists as other major centers — but it has a tradition of art buying that goes back to Rubens and Breughel. (Jussi Puikkonen/The New York Times)

site_title: What should we do in a falling market?
summary: A global economic crunch is looming, with inflation remaining high despite interest-rate hikes. Warren Buffett warned of potential lower earnings for his conglomerate's businesses this year. As a result, stock markets may remain in the doldrums, leaving investors with three options: holding out for a recovery, selling investments, or buying more shares. Each option has its merits, but patience and a focus on fundamental analysis are key to making informed decisions.

images.alt_text: The wall of worry describes a period of improving stock market performance when logic would suggest it should not be happening. Only when the wall of worry has been conquered will the bull market end.

site_title: IMF says UK no longer heading for a recession in 2023
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast, saying the UK's economy is no longer expected to enter a recession in 2023. The country's gross domestic product is now projected to grow by 0.4% this year, up from a previous forecast of a 0.3% contraction. The improved outlook is attributed to factors such as resilient demand, faster-than-expected pay growth, lower energy costs, and improved business confidence. The IMF warns, however, that the economic outlook remains subdued.

images.alt_text: Consumers are doing everything they can to curb the impact of sky-high inflation, shopping at discount grocers and buying supermarkets’ own-brand goods.

site_title: Volvo Group in deal to buy half of new Swedish wind farm’s power
summary: Volvo Group has signed a 10-year deal to buy half of the power produced by Sweden's new 140 MW wind farm, Bruzaholm, starting in 2025. The agreement marks the company's commitment to low-carbon investments and renewable energy. Volvo CEO Martin Lundstedt stated that the deal demonstrates the company's priority on climate action. This move aligns with Volvo Trucks' plan to source 50% of its truck sales to be electric by 2030.

site_title: US business activity rises to 13-month high in May: S&P Global survey
summary: US businesses reported a 13-month high in May, with the S&P Global flash US Composite PMI Output Index reaching 54.5, indicating strong growth in the services sector. This follows a final reading of 53.4 in April and is the fourth straight month above 50, suggesting private sector growth. Labour market resilience also improved, with job growth accelerating and the unemployment rate at a 53-year low of 3.4%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A hiring sign is seen in a cafe in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., August 5, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: US Treasuries one-month yields jump to fresh record high
summary: US one-month Treasury bill yields jumped to a fresh record high of 5.865% after hitting 5.888% in London trade on May 23, amid concerns over the US debt ceiling. The US Treasury Department warned that the government could be unable to pay all debts by June 1. The yields' increase comes as US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy failed to reach an agreement on raising the debt ceiling. The situation remains tense with less than two weeks before the June 1 deadline.

site_title: Prepayment model can deliver knockout punch to gyms in long term: industry observers
summary: Singapore's gyms and fitness studios are facing financial struggles, with many closing abruptly due to unpaid prepaid memberships. The prepayment model can lead to short-term cash flow and long-term viability issues, said industry observers. High rents and saturated markets also contribute to the demise of businesses like UFC Gym and Haus Athletics. To avoid financial difficulties, operators should ringfence advance payments, set aside funds in separate accounts, and offer flexible packages with shorter validity periods. Customers with prepaid memberships may have limited recourse, with some liable to pay remaining instalments to the card issuer.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Haus Athletics first announced the closure of its OUE outlet on Apr 19, followed by the closure of its Cross Street Exchange outlet on Apr 24.
Several users who bought packages ranging from about $200 to $600 from Kyklos Studio are unable to gain refunds.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts cut Frencken targets after Q1 results miss, expect 2024 recovery
summary: Analysts from DBS Group Research, UOB Kay Hian, CGS-CIMB, and Maybank have lowered their target prices for Frencken Group after the semiconductor player's Q1 2023 results missed expectations. Frencken reported a 59.5% drop in net profit to S$5.2 million and a 13% year-on-year decline in revenue. Despite maintaining "hold" or "buy" calls, the analysts reduced their target prices, with DBS cutting its target price by 28.4% to S$0.78, implying a potential downside of 6% from the stock's last trading price.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Working from home and realising what matters
summary: The US economy has made a remarkable recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, with employment, labor force participation, and GDP returning to pre-pandemic levels. A key factor in this recovery is the shift to remote work, which has resulted in a significant reduction in commuting time, estimated to be around 100 hours per year per worker. While the benefits of reduced commuting are substantial, it's unclear how to quantify them, but they could be equivalent to a gain in national income of at least one percentage point. The shift to remote work is permanent, with many winners, including highly educated workers, but also some losers, such as commercial real estate and tax bases of cities.

images.alt_text: Arvind Krishna in an interview in New York on May 1.
Singapore office rents may dip by 5% this year as WFH continues: Knight Frank

FILE PHOTO: Jamie Dimon, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of JPMorgan Chase & Co., gestures as he speaks during an interview with Reuters in Miami, Florida, U.S., February 8, 2023. REUTERS/Marco Bello/File Photo
The move will add to an office glut in San Francisco, which has been battered by remote work and a downturn in the tech industry that fuels the local economy.

site_title: Book review: The Little Book of Picking Top Stocks
summary: CFA Singapore Insights presents a book review of "The Little Book of Picking Top Stocks" by Martin Fridson. The book offers a systematic approach to identifying top-performing stocks by analyzing fundamental and industry-specific stories, free cash flow, and qualitative characteristics such as outside pressure for change and competitive dominance. Fridson's method is evidence-based and simple, using metrics like the Fridson-Lee statistic to identify top stocks. The book also covers non-S&P 500 stocks that delivered exceptional performance, including Nio and GameStop. It encourages analysts and investors to go for No 1 systematically, without relying solely on Wall Street research.

images.alt_text: A book for all investors

site_title: Eurozone business growth solid in May but shows signs of easing
summary: Eurozone business growth remained resilient in May, but slowed slightly as the services industry lost some momentum and the manufacturing sector deepened its downturn. The Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 53.3, below a Reuters poll estimate of 53.5. Input costs for factories declined at the fastest pace in over seven years, allowing factories to cut prices for the first time since September 2020. However, prices charged by services firms rose faster, and the European Central Bank is expected to add another 25 basis points to the deposit rate next month.

images.alt_text: S&P Global’s flash composite purchasing managers’ index has climbed to 52.3 in February, from 50.3 in January.

site_title: Food inflation shows little sign of respite for UK shoppers
summary: UK grocery price inflation edged lower to 17.2% in the four weeks to May 14, down from 17.3% the prior month, but still the third-fastest rate since 2008. Consumers are continuing to shop at discount grocers and buy own-brand goods to curb the impact of high inflation. The rate drop is considered marginal, with prices still being "incredibly high," according to Kantar's head of retail and consumer insight. This could add £833 to the average family's grocery shopping.

images.alt_text: The average price of homes coming to the market jumped by 1.8 per cent, or £6,647 (S$11,280) from April, above the average rise for May of 1.0 per cent, Rightmove said on Monday.

site_title: China buying of chipmaking gear from Singapore hits 8-month high
summary: Singapore has seen a 3.5% increase in semiconductor shipments to China in April, with the country importing $407 million worth of chipmaking machinery, the highest amount since August. This rise is attributed to US-China tensions, which has led to diminishing semiconductor exports to China from other Asian suppliers. Singapore aims to capitalize on the trend, seeking to win investments in semiconductor assembly and design. The country offers more tax incentives and subsidies, attracting companies like Applied Materials and STMicroelectronics.

site_title: Pita sets aside lese majeste law in bid to become Thai PM
summary: Thailand's pro-democracy parties, led by Pita Limjaroenrat, have formed a coalition government after winning the election, but have omitted an amendment to a law forbidding royal insults. The eight-party coalition has adopted a unified stance on issues including charter amendments and reinstating cannabis, but has not included a pledge to revise the lese majeste law, which critics say undermines the monarchy. Pita remains optimistic about his chances of becoming prime minister, but investors remain uncertain due to the ongoing political crisis, which may lead to a delay in government formation until late July or early August.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate, Pita Limjaroenrat, celebrate the party's election results in Bangkok, Thailand, May 15, 2023. REUTERS/Jorge Silva

site_title: Julius Baer posts weaker than expected asset gain on Swiss crisis
summary: Julius Baer Group reported a 1% gain in assets under management for the first four months of the year, with net new money of 3.5 billion Swiss francs, despite analysts' expectations. The bank's assets under management reached 429 billion francs, partly offset by a negative currency impact. Julius Baer shares fell 8% after the announcement. The bank attributed the results to a challenging backdrop for wealth managers, citing uncertainties in the banking sector.

images.alt_text: A businessman passes the headquarters of Julius Baer Group Ltd. in Zurich, Switzerland, on Monday, Aug. 20, 2012. At least five Swiss banks supplied e-mails and telephone records containing as many as 10,000 names to the U.S. Justice Department, according to estimates by Douglas Hornung, a Geneva-based lawyer representing 40 current and former employees of HSBC Holdings Plc's Swiss unit, Credit Suisse Group AG and Julius Baer Group Ltd. Photographer: Gianluca Colla/Bloomberg

site_title: Billionaire’s South African lender weighs Vietnam expansion
summary: Tyme Group, a South African digital lender majority owned by billionaire Patrice Motsepe, is considering entering Vietnam as early as next year. The country is seen as a "perfect fit" for the business due to its chronic underserving of small businesses. Vietnam's young and fast-growing economy, with a US$366 billion GDP, is also attractive. This expansion follows the company's successful entry into the Philippines last year. Tyme Group's CEO, Coen Jonker, believes the market's potential for growth makes it an ideal destination for the company's expansion.

images.alt_text: Patrice Motsepe, founder and chairman of African Rainbow Minerals Ltd., smiles on stage during the Milken Institute Global Conference in Beverly Hills, California, U.S., on Wednesday, May 2, 2018. The conference brings together leaders in business, government, technology, philanthropy, academia, and the media to discuss actionable and collaborative solutions to some of the most important questions of our time. Photographer: Dania Maxwell/Bloomberg

site_title: On trigger-shy developers and tax probes
summary: Singapore's private home prices continued to rise in the first quarter, but developers are cautious about buying housing sites due to concerns over demand and prices. Only one bid was submitted for a 99-year leasehold private housing site at Lentor Gardens, with GuocoLand emerging as a potential "King of Lentor." Rising interest rates and slowing economic growth affect home sales in other markets, and a large supply of sites in the Lentor Hills estate may be contributing to the lack of interest. Despite this, the housing market remains resilient, with a 62.5% increase in million-dollar HDB flat transactions in March.
