site_title: Nepali climber reclaims Everest record with 28th summit
summary: Kami Rita Sherpa, a 53-year-old Nepali guide known as the "Everest Man," has reached the top of Mount Everest for a record 28th time. This achievement comes just a day after his competitor, Pasang Dawa Sherpa, tied his previous record with 27 summits. Kami Rita, who first climbed Everest in 1994, has climbed the mountain almost every year since then, leading the first rope-fixing team on several occasions. The record-breaking climb has captivated the mountaineering community, with over 500 climbers having already summited Everest this season, including 10 who have lost their lives.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 2, 2021, Nepal's mountaineer Kami Rita Sherpa poses for a picture during an interview with AFP at the Everest base camp in the Mount Everest region of Solukhumbu district. Kami Rita Sherpa reached the top of Mount Everest for the 27th time on May 17, reclaiming the record for the most summits of the world's highest mountain. (Photo by Prakash MATHEMA / AFP)

site_title: Mizuho becomes third Japan bank to sell AT1s after crisis
summary: Mizuho Financial Group, Japan's third major bank, plans to sell a yen-denominated two-part Additional Tier 1 (AT1) note with pricing expected in July. This follows Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, which also recently sold AT1 bonds. The move indicates a resilient local credit market and improved investor mood, with AT1 bonds rebounding in recent weeks. The proceeds will be used for working capital, and demand for higher-yielding notes is rising in Japan due to low interest rate expectations.

images.alt_text: Mizuho joins its Japanese rivals to expand investment banking tie ups in the US – though goes a step further in making an acquisition.

site_title: Michelle Yeoh introduces mythological heroes in TV show ‘American Born Chinese’
summary: Michelle Yeoh introduces the TV show "American Born Chinese," a show based on Chinese myths, which premieres on Disney+. The show, an action-comedy-drama, features cast members from the Oscar-winning film "Everything "Everywhere All at Once," including Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan. Yeoh plays Guanyin, the Goddess of Mercy, in the show, aiming to introduce Chinese myths to American audiences. The series is based on the 2006 graphic novel by Gene Luen Yang and will be available on Disney+ starting May 24.

images.alt_text: Michelle Yeo, 60 years old, won my first Oscar.

Best Actress Michelle Yeoh reacts after having her Oscar engraved at the Governors Ball following the Oscars show at the 95th Academy Awards in Hollywood, Los Angeles, California, U.S., March 12, 2023. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni

site_title: Crypto-asset service providers should place client assets in trust or segregate them: Iosco
summary: International regulators are recommending that crypto-asset service providers place client assets in a trust or segregate them from company assets to address conflicts of interest and protect client funds. The International Organization of Securities Commissions (Iosco) has outlined 18 policy recommendations to regulate the crypto industry, including measures to prevent market manipulation and insider trading. The recommendations aim to ensure investor protection and market integrity in cross-border crypto markets, with a deadline for feedback set for July 31.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Hong Kong will roll out a licencing regime for virtual-asset platforms on Jun 1, part of an effort to restore its status as a cutting-edge financial centre.
The exchange is embroiled separately in an ongoing bankruptcy spat over failed crypto lender Genesis Global Capital, to which Gemini is a major creditor

site_title: Japan stocks drop as chip news spur profit-taking after rally
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 stock index dropped 0.9% on May 23, reversing an earlier 0.6% gain, after news about restrictions on chip-technology exports triggered profit-taking. The 14-day relative strength index hit 84, the highest since November 2017, and exceeding levels seen as overbought by traders. The Topix gauge fell as electronics shares were the biggest drag, with the Nikkei 225 Stock Average snapping an eight-day rally. The move was attributed to profit-taking selling, as investors unwound supply and demand following the announcement of stricter export controls.

site_title: Judge throws out shareholder lawsuit against Elon Musk over Twitter buyout
summary: A US District Judge Charles Breyer dismissed a class-action lawsuit against Elon Musk, claiming he cheated Twitter shareholders during the $44 billion buyout. The judge ruled that plaintiff William Heresniak lacked standing to sue as he didn't show harm from Musk's disclosure of a 9.2% Twitter stake or the delayed closing. The judge also found no proof of Musk's involvement in favoring his friends, Jack Dorsey and Egon Durban, on Twitter's board, which breached their fiduciary duties.

images.alt_text: Twitter on Thursday accused Microsoft of breaking the social network’s rules for developers who access the platform’s data.
FILE Ñ Linda Yaccarino in New York on May 11, 2017. Yaccarino is is set to become the new chief executive of Twitter. (Tawni Bannister/The New York Times)
In a sign of tough times even for Tesla, the market leader in electric cars, Elon Musk said the company would try to advertise its vehicles, something it has not done before.
Elon Musk plans to turn Twitter into an “everything app”, with a variety of features to entice new users including financial services.

site_title: MAS policy change still not expected as Singapore headline inflation ticks up in April, core remains flat
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rebounded to 5.7% year-over-year (yoy) in April, exceeding economists' forecasts, while core inflation remained unchanged at 5%. The upside surprise is not enough to prompt the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to change its monetary policy settings in October. Private transport and accommodation inflation are expected to moderate over the year, driven by increased COE quotas and housing supply. Economists predict that inflation pressures will remain sticky, with potential risks from agricultural prices and a potential recession.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
If you want to beat inflation in the long term, besides having physical real estate, you should be investing into equities, says Christopher Tan of Providend.
By expenditure division, food inflation marks the largest jump, up 7.7 per cent on the year in March, Singstat data shows.

site_title: The next decade – a changed landscape for strategic asset allocations
summary: The next decade will be marked by a changed landscape for strategic asset allocations, driven by rising interest rates, strategic rivalry, and scarcity. Higher interest rates and volatile inflation will impact growth and inflation expectations, with global GDP growth projected at 3.1% and inflation at 2.1%. A 60:40 portfolio split between stocks and bonds is expected to remain viable, despite increased inflation. Corporate margins will come under pressure, with US equities expected to deliver an annual total return of 6.2% and European equities 7.3%. Alternative assets, particularly private equity, are expected to produce strong returns.

images.alt_text: Hugues Rialan
Expected returns of assets are higher across the board., and equities are expected to outperform bonds.

site_title: Tesla offers China-made electric vehicles for sale in Canada
summary: Tesla is listing China-made Model 3 and Model Y electric vehicles for sale in Canada, marking the company's first shipments to North America from its Shanghai factory. The vehicles qualify for federal incentives of C$5,000, which do not link to the plant location. This move may help Tesla keep vehicles made in California and Texas for sale in the US, as US subsidies are location-dependent. The export to Canada is seen as a strategic move to expand Tesla's global presence.

images.alt_text: Tesla has described a goal of selling 20 million electric vehicles a year in 2030, a level that would require massive new investment in assembly plants and battery production.

site_title: Majority of British firms cautious on new investments in China: survey
summary: A majority of British firms are taking a cautious approach to new investments in China, with pessimism hitting record levels, according to the British Chamber of Commerce in China. The top challenges include strained geopolitical relationships, a slowing global economy, and shifting investor perceptions. Despite willingness to invest, uncertainty and uncertainty around China's business environment are causing concern. The survey results indicate a wait-and-see approach, as British companies weigh the risks and opportunities in China.

images.alt_text: Helen Wong, CEO, OCBC

site_title: Finding luxury bargains; helping young couples
summary: Singapore's luxury condominium market is experiencing a buying opportunity, with top-selling projects in the Core Central Region seeing price drops in April. Developers are offering discounts to lure buyers, particularly those with unsold stock nearing Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) deadlines. Foreign buyers are also being deterred by the 60% ABSD hike. Meanwhile, consultancy Knight Frank predicts a 18% growth in ultra-wealthy residents in Singapore by 2027. The article also highlights the need for support for young local couples, who are struggling to meet the income ceiling for subsidized HDB flats.

site_title: Gemini issued warning in Philippines over crypto derivatives exchange
summary: Gemini Trust, a New York-based crypto trading platform, has been warned by the Philippines' Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for operating a derivatives exchange without authorization in the country. The SEC advises investors to halt all current investments with Gemini and not invest further, citing a lack of necessary registration. The platform, known as Gemini Foundation, offers perpetual futures contracts in Bitcoin and Ether, considered securities under local law. The penalties for non-compliance include up to 21 years in jail or a fine of 5 million Filipino pesos.

images.alt_text: Genesis lawyer Sean O’Neal said on Friday (Apr 28) that the crypto lender has agreed to a 30-day mediation period including its committee of unsecured creditors, which has opposed the proposed restructuring deal.

site_title: McCarthy says Biden debt talks ‘productive’, but no deal
summary: US Speaker of the House Kevin McCarthy said his meeting with President Joe Biden on raising the debt limit was "productive" but no deal was reached. The meeting came after Biden returned from a trip to Asia to hammer out a deal ahead of the US Treasury's June 1 cut off date for Congress to authorize more borrowing. McCarthy expressed that the discussion was productive in areas where they have differences of opinion, but no agreement was reached.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden meets with House Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) to continue negotiations over increasing the debt limit, at the White House in Washington, May 22, 2023.
The US dollar index, which measures the greenback against six other major currencies, is flat at 103.04.

Speaking at a press conference before leaving to return to Washington from the G7 summit in Hiroshima, Joe Biden said Republicans’ latest demands for spending cuts as a condition for raising the US government borrowing authority were “frankly unacceptable.”

site_title: MAS issues prohibition order to former AIG and Liberty insurance agent for corruption
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a prohibition order to James Yeo Siew Liang, a former insurance agent, for eight years due to corruption convictions. Yeo bribed an Indonesian embassy official to accredit insurance companies to sell performance bonds to foreign workers, amounting to S$92,574. He was previously convicted of 18 counts of corruption in 2021 and sentenced to 15 months' imprisonment and a fine. The MAS prohibits Yeo from carrying on business and participating in the management of insurance intermediaries.

images.alt_text: MAS issues 10-year prohibition order to former DBS wealth manager for fraud

site_title: How a billion-dollar Hong Kong luxury tower highlights developer distress
summary: A luxury Hong Kong tower, The Corniche, has sold only three units out of 295 as of May 22, despite a record price paid for the land. The project was expected to generate HK$30 billion in sales but now bears little resemblance to its intended French Riviera design, mirroring the financial struggles of its developers, Logan Group and KWG Group Holdings, who face at least US$10 billion in offshore debt. The Corniche is a stark reminder of the developers' rapid fall from grace.

images.alt_text: In Hong Kong, most variable rate home loans have a cap based on the prime lending rate. Major lenders have raised that rate by about 75 basis points since last year.
New Zealand’s housing market posted the biggest slump, with luxury home prices in Wellington, Auckland and Christchurch falling by double digits.

site_title: Bankers see Asia-Middle East dual listings as a budding trend
summary: Dual listings between Asia and the Middle East are expected to become a trend as investment flows between the two regions rise. Olam Group, a Singapore-based commodity trader, plans to list its agribusiness unit in both Singapore and Saudi Arabia, marking the first such deal. Saudi Arabia's stock exchange has been actively seeking international ties, signing pacts with Hong Kong and Singapore bourses to cooperate in areas like cross listings. This could pave the way for other firms to follow, capitalizing on the significant export market between the two regions and gaining exposure to the high-growth Middle East economies.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Centre at 2 Shenton Way, taken on 15 Feb 2019.

site_title: Bank Indonesia to stand pat on rates this year, cut in early 2024: poll
summary: Bank Indonesia is expected to keep its key interest rate at 5.75% for the rest of 2023, according to a Reuters poll of 31 economists. The rate has been steady since January due to eased inflation, which fell to 4.33% in April, and a strong Indonesian rupiah that has kept imported inflation low. Only a small minority of economists forecast a rate cut this year, with some predicting a 50-100 basis point cut in 2024.

images.alt_text: BI’s move and bets the global rate hike cycle is also ending have seen foreign investors plough US$4.1 billion into Indonesian debt this year, the second biggest inflow in Asia.
An initial investment plan detailing how Indonesia will green its power supply and cut greenhouse emissions is due mid-August.

site_title: Hong Kong lets retail investors trade crypto in new rules that contrast with clampdowns in Asia
summary: Hong Kong has introduced new rules allowing retail investors to trade cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin and Ether, under a licensing regime starting June 1. The framework aims to safeguard investors while attracting crypto firms and restoring the city's status as a cutting-edge financial centre. Licensed platforms must adhere to robust investor protection measures, including knowledge tests, risk profiling, and token due diligence. This move contrasts with clampdowns in Asia, with jurisdictions like Singapore planning curbs on retail investor participation and South Korea considering standalone crypto legislation.

images.alt_text: The exchange is embroiled separately in an ongoing bankruptcy spat over failed crypto lender Genesis Global Capital, to which Gemini is a major creditor
The NFT and meme-token craze spurred record transactions and an ensuing fee windfall for miners, who run the computers underpinning Bitcoin.

site_title: HSBC appoints new head of wealth and personal banking for South Asia
summary: HSBC has appointed Kai Zhang as the new head of wealth and personal banking for the South Asia region, effective June 26. Zhang, based in Singapore, joins from Manulife-Sinochem Life Insurance Company and previously held leadership roles at Citigroup and McKinsey. Her appointment is tied to the bank's strong momentum in South Asia expansion, according to HSBC.

site_title: Europe: Stocks muted as US debt ceiling concerns linger
summary: European stocks were largely unchanged on Monday as investors awaited the outcome of US debt ceiling talks and assessed monetary policy outlooks. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index touched a one-year high on Friday but remained flat. Germany's DAX dropped 0.3% after hitting an all-time high, while French ECB policymaker Francois Villeroy de Galhau noted interest rate hikes may peak by summer's end. Meanwhile, European chip stocks rose, and Greek government bond prices outperformed peers following a national election that may lead to continued economic growth policies.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent lower at 33,286.58 on Monday.

site_title: Million-dollar ‘unlivable shack’ in Sydney shows split with New Zealand home market
summary: Australia's housing market continues to diverge from New Zealand's, with prices rising for a second straight month in April, while New Zealand's began falling in 2022. The Reserve Bank of Australia's dovish stance contrasts with the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's hawkish approach, leading to the price disparity. Despite New Zealand's housing market being less affordable, the drop in prices has helped first-time buyers, with a record 25% market share in the past two quarters. Australia's market, however, remains challenging for first-time buyers, with 90% unable to purchase a property.

images.alt_text: The new laws will impact consumer credit firms from Zip to Afterpay, which compete with banks to provide interest-free credit that is typically repaid in instalments.

The RBNZ has warned that a boost in government spending could add to red-hot inflation, which it has aggressively tried to temper by increasing the official cash rate by 500 basis points since October 2021.

site_title: SGX to launch depository receipts for Airports of Thailand, CP All, PTT E&P
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch depository receipts (SDRs) for three Thai companies: Airports of Thailand, CP All, and PTT Exploration & Production (PTT E&P). The move aims to provide Singapore investors with direct exposure to the companies. The three stocks are constituents of the benchmark SET50 Index, with Airports of Thailand carrying a 8% weightage and CP All and PTT E&P each carrying a 5% weightage. The launch follows a Thailand-Singapore DR Linkage, allowing for more investment opportunities between the two markets.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The Singapore Exchange (SGX) signs a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Shanghai Stock Exchange for the future cross-listing of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) on both bourses.

site_title: Gold prices steady as US debt ceiling impasse drags on
summary: US gold prices remained steady at US$1,971.09 per ounce on Tuesday, as investors focused on the ongoing debt ceiling talks between President Joe Biden and congressional Republicans. The talks, which have been ongoing for days, have yet to produce a deal, with just 10 days left before a potential default that could impact the US economy. Despite rising interest rates, which typically boost demand for gold, investors are instead pricing in a 74.3% chance of the Federal Reserve keeping interest rates unchanged next month.

images.alt_text: Gold tends to lose appeal in a high-rate environment.
Non-interest-bearing bullion tends to become less attractive in a high-interest-rate environment.

site_title: Britain’s inflation rate may fall at sharpest pace in 30 years
summary: Britain's inflation rate is expected to fall to 8.2% in April, the sharpest decline in over 30 years, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. This could lead to a pause in interest rate hikes by the Bank of England, with some predicting the key lending rate could hit 5% by September. However, some analysts warn that if inflation slows more than expected, investors may rush to buy UK bonds, causing gilt yields to fall. The BOE's next decision on June 22 will depend on the April data.

images.alt_text: The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) said its measure of new buyer enquiries fell to a net balance of -37 in last month from -30 in March, the lowest since January.
The outlook of British firms’ optimism about the wider economy improved by five points to 28 per cent.

site_title: TikTok will ‘soon’ grant Oracle full access to code, algorithm
summary: TikTok will grant Oracle full access to its source code, algorithm, and content-moderation material as part of its Project Texas initiative, aimed at alleviating national security concerns. Oracle will monitor data entry and exit points, and the arrangement is part of efforts to address criticism from policymakers regarding TikTok's Chinese ownership. The move is part of a larger plan to cordon off US users' data and allow partners to review security risks. This comes amid federal- and state-level legislation aiming to ban or limit the app's use in America.

images.alt_text: TikTok called on the federal court to declare the Montana ban on its app unconstitutional and block the state from ever putting it into effect.

Montana is the first US state to ban TikTok, with the law set to take effect next year as debate escalates over the impact and security of the popular video app that is owned by Chinese company ByteDance.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise after ‘productive’ Biden-McCarthy debt talks
summary: US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy held productive talks on the debt ceiling, boosting market optimism that the country will avoid a calamitous default. Asian markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney, rose on Tuesday, while Shanghai and Wellington saw small losses. The talks come with just weeks to go before the US runs out of cash, but months of negotiations have failed to lift the borrowing limit from $31.8 trillion. The positive development has lifted equities, supporting the view that the US will avert a calamitous default.

images.alt_text: People walk past a screen displaying the Hang Seng Index at Central district, in Hong Kong, China March 17, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: China’s big-spending, picky youth are global luxury’s lifeline
summary: China's youth, born since 1990, are driving the global luxury market with their big spending and high expectations for personalized experiences. As the country's top clients, they account for about a fifth of the US$325.4 billion global luxury market and spend 30% more per week than the rest of the world. By 2025, China is expected to surpass the US and Europe as the world's top buyer, with Gen Z's spending projected to rise fourfold from 2019 to 16 trillion yuan by 2035. Luxury brands are expanding their domestic footprint to cater to these young shoppers.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Sept. 13, 2022. Australia's central bank will dial back the pace of policy tightening to quarter percentage-point moves from next month as it tries to navigate a path to cooling inflation while maintaining economic growth. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg
The predicted influx of Chinese investment into Japan also comes as rich individuals increasingly explore the country as a place to invest or even live.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.3% to 3,200.79, after US equities ended mixed. Talks on lifting the debt ceiling continued, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.4%. Gainers outnumbered losers 70 to 56, with Thai Beverage gaining 0.9% and DBS largely unchanged. The European Stoxx 600 also ended flat, amid evaluations of monetary policy outlook in Europe and the US.

images.alt_text: The group warns that the fresh round of property cooling measures is likely to lead to a slowdown in sales transactions.

site_title: The future of energy transition and climate finance
summary: A panel discussion at the Insead Alumni Forum Europe explored the future of energy transition and climate finance. Despite a retreat from ESG funds by public capital, private capital is still investing in climate-related technology, with experts estimating $4 trillion annually needed to meet the 1.5°C warming goal. Companies must adopt a holistic approach to reduce emissions, involving the entire organization, rather than just hiring sustainability officers. "Brown" companies, such as oil and gas players, can also play a crucial role in creating solutions, and governments must provide capital to these industries.

images.alt_text: While much focus has been placed on reducing carbon emissions, other serious environmental problems such as deforestation, water shortages and soil erosion should not be overlooked.
Each plant has to be screened for its suitability based on affordability, energy security, and the “people dimension”, said ADB's Ramesh Subramaniam.

When it comes to achieving sustainability goals, business leaders (and not investment professionals) must take charge, with ESG considerations integrated as part of the business decision-making process.

site_title: Bank of Korea to hold rates until end of September, cut in Q4: poll
summary: The Bank of Korea (BoK) is expected to hold interest rates steady until the end of September, according to a Reuters poll of 40 economists. The BoK's base rate remains at 3.50%, the highest since late 2008, to assess the impact of previous hikes on inflation and economic growth. Economists predict the economy will grow below potential this year, with some forecasting a rate cut by the end of 2023, but none expect further hikes. The decision will be made on May 25.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol (above) held a summit in Seoul with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President Charles Michel.
The Overseas Market Workshop included a visit to Web portal Naver on May 16.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Bukit Sembawang
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates, a property development and investment group, posted a 26.2% drop in net profit to S$21.8 million for its second half-year ended March 31, 2023. The group also warned that the fresh round of property cooling measures by the Singapore government will likely lead to a slowdown in sales transactions. As a result, its shares closed 0.5% down at S$4.10 on May 23.

site_title: Japan fiscal 2022 real wages fall most in 8 years as inflation bites
summary: Japan's real wages fell 1.8% in fiscal 2022, the largest decline in eight years, as inflation (3.8%) outpaced nominal wage gains (1.9%). This marks the biggest yearly decline since 2014. To boost consumers' purchasing power, wages must rise even more to outpace inflation. Major firms have agreed to raise wages by nearly 4% this year, the fastest gain in three decades, to secure skilled workers in a labour-crunch economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of HSBC is seen on its headquarters at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
“I’m not considering imposing new tax burdens, including sales tax hikes, to secure sources of funding childcare support,” Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida says.

Compared with a year earlier, core orders, a highly volatile data series regarded as a leading indicator of capital spending in the coming six to nine months, fell 3.5 per cent in March, versus a forecast of 1.4 per cent rise, the Cabinet Office data found.

site_title: On weekends, these bank staff teach young kids how to manage their money
summary: Bank staff in Singapore volunteer to teach young children about money management, starting from as young as six years old. They use simple rules, such as spending 60% of income, saving 30%, and donating 10%, to help kids develop good financial habits. Nine-year-old Nur Fatrisha Diana Alias, a Marsiling Primary School pupil, is already setting aside half of her $4 daily allowance, demonstrating the effectiveness of these methods in shaping young minds about money management.

site_title: Qantas eyes record annual profit on strong travel demand, raises share buyback
summary: Qantas expects an underlying profit before tax of A$2.4 billion to A$2.5 billion for fiscal 2023, a record high compared to a A$1.9 billion loss in the previous year. Strong travel demand and lower fuel prices are expected to drive the profit. The airline has also raised its share buyback by up to A$100 million. Qantas expects domestic capacity to reach above pre-Covid levels by the end of the second half and international capacity to grow to over 80% of pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: The reopening of premium lounge at Hong Kong is part of a A$100 million investment by Qantas into its global lounge network.
Vanessa Hudson, who has been in Qantas’ executive ranks for more than 28 years, will become chief executive and managing director when Alan Joyce retires in November.
SAF is a biofuel used to power aircraft that has similar properties to conventional jet fuel without the need to develop new planes or engines.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Kashkari cautions against all-clear on banking woes
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari cautioned against declaring the banking sector's stresses are over, citing his experience in the 2008 financial crisis. Despite the Fed's efforts to stabilize the banking system, Kashkari believes it's too soon to declare all-clear, as history shows more trouble can't be ruled out. The Fed has extended over $300 billion in loans to banks, and while lending has backed off, Kashkari notes that the central bank is still prepared to take action if needed.

images.alt_text: Two weeks after First Citizens acquired SVB on Mar 27, HSBC poached 42 bankers on Easter Sunday and brazenly took and misused SVB’s confidential.

Gregory Becker, the former chief executive of Silicon Valley Bank, testifies before a Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee hearing to examine the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank on Capitol Hill in Washington, May 16, 2023.
The remarks follow comments from Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, who said she expects US regulators to be open to such deals as firms consolidate.
Annual inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index peaks at 9.1 per cent last summer, the highest since the early 1980s, and remains elevated now at 4.9 per cent.

Economists now believe the US central bank, which is debating whether it needs to raise rates again, will lower its targeted policy rate in the first quarter of next year, according to the survey released by the National Association for Business Economics.

site_title: What happens if the US fails to raise its debt ceiling?
summary: US President Joe Biden and Republicans in Congress are negotiating to avoid a US debt default, which could occur as early as June 1, if the debt ceiling is not raised. Biden wants a "clean" increase to the debt ceiling, while Republicans are seeking a commitment from Democrats to reduce future spending in exchange for their support. The talks aim to prevent "catastrophic" consequences of a default, which could severely impact the US economy. A deal must be reached before the deadline is reached, with the outcome uncertain.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.4 per cent lower at 33,286.58 on Monday.
Analysts believe that a default on US debt would be unprecendented and unpredictable.
The US dollar index, which measures the greenback against six other major currencies, is flat at 103.04.

FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says: “There’s always uncertainty about tax receipts and spending, and so it’s hard to be absolutely certain about this, but my assessment is that the odds of reaching Jun 15 while being able to pay all of our bills is quite low.”

site_title: Oil rises 1% as supplies shrink, demand seen higher
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Monday, driven by a decline in global supplies and forecasts of higher demand in the second half of the year. Brent futures for July delivery increased 41 cents to $75.99 a barrel. The rise was tempered by a stronger US dollar and uncertainty over US debt ceiling talks.

images.alt_text: Oil workers pass a pumping unit, also known as a "nodding donkey" or pumping jack, left, at a drilling site operated by Tatneft OAO near Almetyevsk, Russia, on Friday, July 31, 2015. Eleven months of surviving with oil below $100 have left Russia hardened enough to endure a monthlong drop to $40 a barrel, a survey of economists showed. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

Brent crude futures climbed 14 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to US$75.72 a barrel by 0018 GMT while US West Texas Intermediate crude for July delivery, the more actively traded contract, was at US$71.84 a barrel, up 15 cents, or 0.2 per cent.

site_title: Russia uses less crude at home but high exports cast doubt on cuts
summary: Russia's refineries processed less crude in May due to seasonal maintenance, but the 100,000-barrel daily reduction was insufficient to confirm production cuts. Despite claims of achieving 500,000-barrel daily cuts, Russia's oil exports have surged, contradicting the pledge. The International Energy Agency estimates Russia has made less than half of the pledged cuts, casting doubt on the country's production reduction efforts.

images.alt_text: Russian exports to Asia of thermal coal and natural gas, the two fuels most often used for electricity generation, have grown markedly this year.

site_title: Private banking transformation starts with its underlying philosophy: UOB’s Chew Mun Yew
summary: UOB's Managing Director and Head of Private Wealth, Chew Mun Yew, emphasizes the importance of assembling a strong team and galvanizing members to achieve "management alpha" in delivering better-than-normal results. Chew, who has an unconventional background in teaching philosophy and banking regulation, believes that experience and mistakes hone one's instinct and that some challenges cannot be thought out of. He notes that Asia is on the cusp of a large transfer of wealth, requiring private bankers to move beyond investment-focused services and consider the broader needs of high-net-worth clients.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

UOB’s newly-acquired Citi consumer portfolio will likely double contributions from the bank’s unsecured lending business by the end of 2023, said Jacquelyn Tan, UOB head of group personal financial services.
All three banks’ chief executives said they will remain prudent ahead of rising credit quality risks.
UOB attributed the strong Q1 performance to growth across its wholesale, global markets and retail businesses.
DBS, OCBC and UOB branches in Singapore.

site_title: Blackstone in talks with lenders on maturing Chicago office loan
summary: Blackstone is in talks with lenders on a $310 million mortgage for its Chicago office tower, 350 North Orleans. The property, which Blackstone effectively wrote down to zero last year, is experiencing challenges due to falling occupancy and rising borrowing costs. KBRA has downgraded ratings on the loan, citing weaker performance. The tower, built in the 1970s, has undergone renovations, including one in 2018, and is located in the River North submarket. The loan is set to mature in July.

images.alt_text: Blackstone is attempting to unlock an estimated US$50 trillion cash pile held by Europe’s affluent, a huge potential source of fees and growth for the private lending industry.
The disclosure sheds light on how much competition exists for assets of collapsed banks.

site_title: China’s solar boom is already accelerating past last year’s record surge
summary: China's solar sector is accelerating past last year's record surge, with the country installing almost three times the volume of solar capacity between January and April 2023 compared to the same period in 2022. The nation aims to add 154 gigawatts of solar capacity this year, surpassing the US total. Falling costs and rising electricity consumption are driving demand for clean power, with China set to reach net zero by 2060. The world is on track to have 5,300 gigawatts of solar capacity by 2030, meeting global net zero targets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker inspects solar panels at a solar farm in Dunhuang, 950km (590 miles) northwest of Lanzhou, Gansu Province September 16, 2013. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo/File Photo##########impact28##########
China already has the world’s largest fleet of renewable generation and plans to boost that with about 455 gigawatts of wind and solar in mainly desert areas.

site_title: ECB not done raising rates, should keep them high, de Cos says
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Governing Council member Pablo Hernandez de Cos stated that borrowing costs should remain high for a prolonged period to control inflation. The ECB has slowed rate hikes to 25 basis points, with markets predicting two more steps of that size in June and July. De Cos believes interest rates will need to remain in restrictive territory for a long time to reach the ECB's 2% inflation target, indicating a growing consensus that high borrowing costs are necessary to bring inflation under control.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
ECB president Christine Lagarde says: “We are not done yet, we are not pausing based on the information I have today,” she said, adding that the “inflation outlook is too high and for too long”.

Pedestrians pass a Commerzbank AG bank branch in Hamburg, Germany, on Monday, May 6, 2019. The city has more than its fair share of millionaires and, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, at least five of the 30 richest Germans live in Hamburg. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: JPMorgan’s Dimon says has same intensity for job, confident in management
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon stated that his tenure plans remain unchanged, despite not providing specifics. He expressed confidence in the bank's management and emphasized that his intensity for the job remains the same as when he was younger. Dimon also mentioned he plans to remain in his role for another 3.5 years, but acknowledged that he cannot do it forever. He cited his love for his country, company, and family as reasons he cannot change.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan, the biggest US bank, raises its guidance for net interest income this year to US$84 billion.

site_title: TikTok sues to stop ban in US state of Montana
summary: TikTok has filed a federal court lawsuit to block a Montana ban on its app, claiming it violates the constitutionally protected right to free speech. The ban, set to take effect in 2024, was signed into law by Governor Greg Gianforte, citing national security concerns over the app's ownership by Chinese firm ByteDance. TikTok argues that the state is overstepping its authority and violating free speech rights, and seeks to have the ban declared unconstitutional and blocked.

images.alt_text: Montana is the first US state to ban TikTok, with the law set to take effect next year as debate escalates over the impact and security of the popular video app that is owned by Chinese company ByteDance.
tiktok Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
TikTok's new programme will help students gain a deeper understanding in coding languages, tech architecture, server management, quality assurance and site reliability.

site_title: AIG to offload reinsurance business for US$3 billion to free up capital
summary: American International Group (AIG) will sell its reinsurance business to RenaissanceRe Holdings for $3 billion, freeing up $400 million in capital. The deal includes AIG's Validus Re unit, AlphaCat, and Talbot Treaty reinsurance business, and will be completed through a cash and share payment. The transaction simplifies AIG's business model, reducing volatility in its portfolio, while generating significant cash liquidity and capital efficiencies. RenaissanceRe expects AIG to make substantial investments in its Capital Partners business.

site_title: Singapore, Kazakhstan sign four agreements, including one to boost economic cooperation
summary: Singapore and Kazakhstan signed four agreements, including one to boost economic cooperation, on May 22, 2023. The services and investment agreement allows Singapore companies to access Kazakhstan's services sectors and protects investors' interests. The agreements also include a memorandum of understanding to train officials from Central Asian countries and a cooperation agreement with the Astana International Financial Centre. Singapore President Halimah Yacob witnessed the signing and welcomed the plans for direct flights to Singapore, expected to facilitate more business and tourist traffic. The agreements aim to generate opportunities in various sectors and strengthen economic ties between the two countries.

images.alt_text: “We will jointly foster a new paradigm of deeply complementary and high-level win-win cooperation.” Chinese President Xi Jinping says.

site_title: Planning to relocate to Johor from Singapore? There’re challenges
summary: Singapore residents are increasingly considering relocating to Johor, Malaysia due to the city-state's high cost of living. However, Johor faces public service challenges, including long commutes and limited domestic help. While property transactions in Johor have reached a record high, it's driven mainly by Malaysians seeking to trim overheads, rather than expats. A light-rail system connecting Johor Bahru with Singapore is set to begin in a few years, which may impact the area's appeal. Experts say Johor can't replicate Singapore's success, and the dynamic is complex, with both countries relying on each other for economic and social benefits.

images.alt_text: Johor Bahru (JB) Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Zoom raises annual sales forecast in sign pandemic-era customers here to stay
summary: Zoom Video Communications raised its annual sales forecast to $4.47-$4.49 billion and adjusted profit to $4.25-$4.31 per share, exceeding earlier expectations. The company's focus on large corporate customers, acquired during the pandemic, is now crucial to its growth. Despite this, Zoom did not add as many large corporate customers as anticipated. The positive forecast signals the company's efforts to continue growing in a post-pandemic world.

images.alt_text: The executive had taken a high-profile role at Zoom during his short tenure, appearing on earnings calls and overseeing the company’s sales operation.

site_title: We still have time to make choices about AI
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is rapidly advancing, with predictions of 83 million job losses over the next five years and 300 million jobs potentially replaced by technology. As AI becomes more prevalent, policymakers must enact regulations to guide its development towards the common good, ensuring it is used ethically and respects data privacy. The development of AI should focus on creating "marginal productivity" gains, allowing workers to expand their services and elevate their contributions, potentially leading to higher wages. It is a choice that will determine whether AI is celebrated or feared, and its impact on humanity's future.

images.alt_text: A trader walks out of the New York Stock Exchange on Wall Street in New York. Some Wall Street firms are revising their profit projections for multiple S&P 500 industry groups, based on the adoption of AI.

site_title: S-Reit investors wary of falling NAVs as interest rates weigh on sentiment
summary: S-Reit investors are concerned about declining net asset values (NAVs) due to weakening portfolio valuations and increasing debt ratios. 14 out of 27 Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) reported double-digit percentage year-on-year declines in NAV. Analysts attribute the decline to the current macro environment, including high interest rates and limited commercial property transactions. Experts advise investors to focus on credit metrics, distribution per unit, and hedging policy rather than NAV figures, and some S-Reits have started to show signs of recovery.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Mapletree Logistics Trust was one of the S-Reits that performed better year-on-year, but declined compared to the preceding period.
Uncommon Wilmington in the US is in the portfolio of CapitaLand Ascott Trust which saw strong performance in its Q1 2023 gross profit.
Sabana Industrial Reit's manager lost the general mandate to issue new units at its AGM on Apr 25.

site_title: Credit Suisse shows failed lenders would need central bank money
summary: Credit Suisse's failure highlights the need for European top lenders to receive liquidity assistance from central banks in the event of a crisis, exceeding the bloc's bank failure fund and a planned facility. The Single Resolution Board stated that the needs of a global systemically important bank would outstrip the Single Resolution Fund's capacity, emphasizing the need for involvement from the Eurosystem. The Swiss National Bank provided 200 billion Swiss francs in liquidity lines to stabilize the bank.

images.alt_text: Law firms Quinn Emanuel and Pallas have received multiple requests from senior managers at Credit Suisse to take legal action on their behalf.

site_title: Clearer guidelines needed to help investors requisition EGMs
summary: Dissident shareholders in Singapore-listed companies are requisitioning extraordinary general meetings (EGMs) to propose resolutions to remove existing directors, often leading to acrimonious boardroom battles. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has called for a more structured approach, and the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) has shown willingness to enforce requirements. A clearer framework or guidelines could minimize disputes and ensure fair meetings, benefiting both issuers and minority shareholders.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
business, conference room, boardroom

While the requisition of a general meeting may be unwelcomed, boards should consider the merits of the proposals from the perspective of the issuer and its shareholders as a whole, said Tan Boon Gin, CEO of SGX RegCo.
Minority shareholders of watch-listed USP Group are looking to take the company out of the watchlist by gaining control of its board and injecting it with new projects.
The company also urged shareholders not to attend the EGM and that even if any resolutions were to be passed through at the EGM, they would also be deemed invalid.

site_title: France unveils new, more ambitious emissions-cutting plan
summary: France has unveiled a new plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2030, targeting a reduction of 25% more than its 1990 levels. The plan includes measures to speed up the transition to electric cars and switch freight from road to rivers. France aims to align its ambitions with the European Union's 2030 target, but critics warn that the plan may be too ambitious and costly, echoing concerns from a 2018 increase in fuel taxes that sparked major protests. The plan will focus on companies, households, and local administrations, with around half of efforts going to companies and a quarter to households.

site_title: Greening the ferrous industry
summary: The global ferrous industry is shifting towards sustainability, driven by growing concerns over climate targets and the need for lower-carbon production techniques. The industry is exploring the use of renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, and biomass in steelmaking, while also adopting alternative raw materials and recycling steel infinitely. By optimizing supply chains and reducing waste, the industry can reduce its carbon footprint while delivering economic benefits. The Singapore International Ferrous Week is a key event for the industry, bringing together stakeholders to discuss challenges and opportunities in the transition to a greener ferrous industry.

images.alt_text: Some mills in top steel producer China now hurting from lacklustre steel demand and a slump in prices “have started to actively limit production”, Sinosteel Futures analysts said in a note.
“Hopes that China’s reopening and the building season from April to June would boost steel consumption have faded,” analysts at National Australia Bank say.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat amid debt limit talks; Micron slides
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday amid uncertainty over the debt ceiling talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.05% to 33,408.54, while the S&P 500 opened 0.03% lower at 4,190.78. Shares of Micron dropped following China's ban on its memory chips. Markets await updates on the debt ceiling negotiations, which may impact investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 16, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Inflation has eroded US households’ financial security, Fed survey shows
summary: The US Federal Reserve's survey of household economics and decisionmaking found that inflation has eroded US households' financial security, with 73% saying they were doing "at least okay financially" in 2022, down 5 percentage points from the previous year. The share of those worse off increased to 35%, with many households reducing savings, feeling less secure about retirement, and delaying purchases. The survey also showed a souring mood about the national economy, with only 18% rating it as "good" or "excellent."

images.alt_text: Economists now believe the US central bank, which is debating whether it needs to raise rates again, will lower its targeted policy rate in the first quarter of next year, according to the survey released by the National Association for Business Economics.

site_title: BT Podcast: Opportunities abound in small cap
summary: Alfie Yeo, head of small-mid cap research at RHB Singapore, discusses opportunities in small-cap stock investing, highlighting that these stocks can deliver higher returns when markets are rising. He notes that 2022's small-cap market and current trends in small-cap stocks are worth considering. In 2023, Alfie identifies opportunities to note, but also cautions investors to consider risks such as inflation and recessionary fears. The discussion is part of the BT Podcast series, sponsored by RHB Singapore.

images.alt_text: Vijay Natarajan, real estate and REITs analyst at RHB Singapore

site_title: US: Dow falls, Nasdaq rises as debt ceiling talks loom
summary: US stocks ended the session mixed ahead of White House negotiations to avert a US debt default. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4% to 33,286.58, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.5% to 12,720.78. Market experts warn that a default could lead to a plunge into bear market territory. Meanwhile, Chevron fell 1.8% after announcing a $6.3 billion acquisition, while regional banks rose, with Comerica up 3.5% and Western Alliance Bancorporation up 10.3%.

images.alt_text:
Bloomberg's Best Photos 2012: The World at Work. Bloomberg photographers have documented a breathtakingly diverse world of work in 2012. From the frantic trading floor at the London Metals Exchange to precarious descents into Indian mines; from trudging across the frozen Yamal Peninsula to Gazprom's Bovanenkovo gas field and traveling through the night on West Virginian coal barges to mucking in with the animals at Lehmann Brothers Farms in Illinois, they haven't hesitated to get their hands, cameras and boots dirty, see their work here in The World at Work.
