U.S. stock futures retreated, indicating the Dow Jones Industrial Average will drop for a sixth straight day, as Greece's political impasse intensified concern about a worsening of the European sovereign-debt crisis. Photographer: Scott Eells/Bloomberg

site_title: Ford signs battery material supply deals to charge up EV output
summary: Ford Motor has signed deals for the supply of lithium products, including lithium hydroxide, to boost electric vehicle (EV) production to 2 million units by 2026. The deals aim to catch up with market leader Tesla amid surging demand for environment-friendly vehicles. Ford's shares edged up 1% before the announcement. The move is part of the automaker's efforts to secure battery materials and ramp up EV production.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Ford logo is pictured at the 2019 Frankfurt Motor Show (IAA) in Frankfurt, Germany September 10, 2019. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Number of ultra-rich in Singapore expected to reach 5,300 in 2027: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's ultra-wealthy population is expected to reach 5,300 by 2027, a 17.7% growth from 4,498 in 2022, according to Knight Frank's Wealth Report. The number of ultra-high-net-worth individuals in Singapore increased 6.9% in 2022, while the global number declined 3.8% due to weak equities and bond markets. Globally, Singapore ranks eighth for the fastest-growing UHNWI population, with the UAE leading with an 18.1% growth rate. The global UHNWI population is projected to grow 28.5% to 744,000 over the next five years.

images.alt_text: People walking outside Esplanade with Singapore Flag flying and skyline of the Central Business District, 26 December 2022.
Tessa Oh

site_title: JPMorgan boosts net interest outlook on First Republic deal
summary: JPMorgan Chase raised its net interest income guidance for the year to $84 billion, up from a previous forecast of $81 billion. The boost is attributed to its purchase of First Republic Bank, which will benefit from rising interest rates. However, several uncertainties remain, including the Federal Reserve's plans and consumer reactions to higher borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: A man exits the JPMorgan Chase & Co. headquarters building in New York, U.S. in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 8, 2011. LivingSocial, the second-largest daily-coupon site, is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase & Co. as one of the banks to manage its initial public offering, a person with knowledge of the talks said. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: PacWest to sell US$2.6 billion of real estate loans at discount
summary: PacWest Bancorp, a US regional lender, is selling a $2.6 billion portfolio of real estate construction loans to Kennedy-Wilson Holdings at a discounted price of $2.4 billion. The buyer will also assume future funding obligations of $2.7 billion. Additionally, PacWest will sell six more loans to Kennedy-Wilson for $363 million if it receives certain approvals. The move aims to bolster PacWest's finances amid turmoil.

site_title: Fosun to sell shares in diamond-grading firms for US$455 million
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun International has agreed to sell its indirect subsidiary's stake in International Gemological Institute's (IGI) business in three regions for $455 million. The sale, part of a larger asset sale, is part of Fosun's efforts to address financial challenges, including a 95% plunge in profit. The deal, combined with other sales, totals $4.8 billion since last May. Fosun was working with Deutsche Bank on the potential divestment, and the sale is expected to be "payable in cash" to the sellers.

site_title: US dollar steady as debt ceiling talks to resume
summary: The US dollar remained steady on Monday, with the US dollar index flat at 103.04, as debt ceiling negotiations between the US President and House Speaker resumed. The greenback was little changed against other major currencies, despite a six-day winning streak on Friday. Analysts attribute optimism over the debt limit and the Federal Reserve's cautious approach to policy moves as factors supporting the US dollar. Markets are now awaiting a meeting between the President and Speaker to discuss the debt ceiling.

site_title: EU targets fast fashion in push for durable goods
summary: The European Union has approved plans to crack down on fast fashion with a ban on destroying unsold clothes and a push for more durable goods. The rules, which will be implemented after negotiations with the European Parliament, include requirements for products to be more durable, reliable, reusable, upgradable, reparable, recyclable, and easier to maintain. The EU aims to reduce the environmental impact of unsold goods, particularly in the fashion industry, which has the fourth-highest environmental impact across the bloc. The ban will exempt medium-sized and small companies for a four-year period.

site_title: Tech advances don’t necessarily create shared prosperity
summary: Economist Simon Johnson argues that technology advances don't necessarily create shared prosperity, contradicting the "techno-optimism" narrative. Johnson suggests that stablecoins, AI, and social media pose significant risks to financial stability and inequality. To mitigate these risks, he advocates for countervailing power, such as stronger regulations and taxes on corporate profits. Johnson proposes redirecting AI development towards complementing human capabilities, rather than pure automation, and implementing a tax on digital advertising to re-empower users of social networks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: Mizuho to buy investment bank Greenhill in US$550 million deal
summary: Mizuho Financial Group has agreed to buy investment bank Greenhill in an all-cash transaction valued at US$550 million, including debt. The deal gives Mizuho another 370 employees and allows Greenhill to continue operating in 15 locations worldwide. Mizuho plans to complete the transaction by the end of the year, with Greenhill's leaders, including CEO Scott Bok, retaining their roles. The acquisition complements Mizuho's investment banking teams and marks the firm's expansion into US investment banking, joining its Japanese rivals in making a move.

site_title: First Citizens sues HSBC for stealing SVB staff, secrets
summary: First Citizens Bank & Trust has sued HSBC Holdings, alleging the bank poached 42 SVB employees and misused confidential information, part of a scheme dubbed "Project Colony." The lawsuit claims HSBC's David Sabow, a former SVB executive, helped identify key SVB leaders to hire. First Citizens acquired SVB in March, and the alleged poaching occurred on Easter Sunday, two weeks later.

images.alt_text: A First Citizens Bank branch in Alpharetta, Georgia. Photographer: Elijah Nouvelage/Bloomberg

site_title: The artificial intelligence stock-market rush
summary: Artificial intelligence is driving a stock market surge, with investors flocking to companies that mention the technology in their SEC filings. The "magic words" AI has become, with many predicting a machine-led revolution and significant job displacement. However, regulators are already sounding the alarm, warning of the need for AI regulation. Despite this, many experts believe AI will have a profound impact on industries such as law, accountancy, and surgery, and could boost corporate profits by nearly 400 basis points over a decade. The AI bull market has created a "baby bubble," with some warning of a period of restraint on investment as the regulatory landscape emerges.

images.alt_text: Singapore targets to be a leader in developing and deploying AI solutions in key sectors from health care to finance and education by 2030.
Nvidia is the world’s top maker of graphics processing units (GPUs), which are in high demand because they can be used to speed up artificial intelligence work.
Generative AI models have become well known for making mistakes, or “hallucinations”, spewing up misinformation with uncanny certainty.

site_title: Taiwan excluded from WHO annual assembly following Chinese opposition
summary: Taiwan failed in its bid to attend the World Health Organization's annual assembly in Geneva, with the decision made despite growing support for its participation. China and Pakistan urged members to reject Taiwan's inclusion, citing Beijing's claim of sovereignty over the island. Eswatini and the Marshall Islands were the only countries to speak in favor of Taiwan's participation. The decision marks a setback for Taiwan, which has sought greater international recognition as a separate country.

images.alt_text: Some analysts now expect the PBOC could lower the amount of cash banks must set aside as its next policy move.

site_title: MAS, CSRC to explore ETF links for SGX and Shanghai Stock Exchange
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to explore exchange-traded fund (ETF) product links on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Shanghai Stock Exchange. The move aims to deepen cross-border cooperation between the two markets, following a similar link established between SGX and the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2022. The ETF product link is expected to promote connectivity products and meet growing demand for cross-border opportunities between China and Singapore.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Singapore, China ink 14 pacts to step up cooperation, including an ETF product link

site_title: As costs rise, Apac firms turn to Vietnam, Philippines for talent: report
summary: Companies in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in Vietnam and the Philippines, are turning to skilled yet affordable talent in developing countries due to challenging economic conditions and rising costs. Foreign investors are pouring into Vietnam, granting licenses for 750 new foreign-invested projects valued at over US$4.1 billion in the first four months of this year. Meanwhile, job openings from domestic companies in Vietnam and the Philippines have decreased by 51%, with Vietnam experiencing significant layoffs in the real estate and manufacturing sectors.

images.alt_text: Strings of closed down stores and spaces offered for rent along the Nguyen Hue walking street located in Central District 1, the most vibrant commercial area of Vietnam’s Ho Chi Minh City

site_title: Taiwan April export orders miss forecast, outlook cautious
summary: Taiwan's export orders fell 18.1% in April to $42.49 billion, missing forecasts and marking the eighth straight month of contraction. The decline was driven by soft demand for technology products and slowing global growth. The Ministry of Economic Affairs warned that persistently high inflation and rising interest rates could continue to impede economic growth momentum, with orders expected to contract in the first half and until the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: For the January-March period, annual GDP shrank by 3.02 per cent from a year earlier, following a contraction of 0.41 per cent in the previous quarter, preliminary data from the statistics agency showed on Friday (Apr 28).

site_title: Japan won’t raise taxes to fund childcare plan, PM Kishida says
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has stated that he will not raise taxes to fund a proposed childcare package aimed at reversing Japan's declining birthrate. The package, set to be implemented over three years, is estimated to cost around 8 trillion yen ($77.8 billion). Kishida has pledged to double childcare spending, aiming to make it easier for both parents to work and share household chores more fairly. The government will unveil draft guidelines for the measures at a panel meeting, but has yet to specify how the package will be funded.

images.alt_text: Japan is among the world’s fastest ageing societies, with the annual number of newborns falling below 800,000 for the first time, having previously peaked at 2.09 million in 1973 during the second baby boom.

site_title: ‘Deepfake’ scam in China fans worries over AI-driven fraud
summary: A "deepfake" scam in northern China used AI-powered face-swapping technology to convince a man to transfer 4.3 million yuan ($823,002) to a supposed friend. The scammer impersonated a friend during a video call, receiving the money under false pretenses. The victim only realized he was duped when the friend expressed ignorance of the situation. Authorities have recovered most of the stolen funds and are working to trace the rest. The case has sparked concerns over the potential of AI-driven fraud to aid financial crimes, leading to increased scrutiny of "deepfake" technology and apps in China.

images.alt_text: Generative AI models have become well known for making mistakes, or “hallucinations”, spewing up misinformation with uncanny certainty.

site_title: Malaysian tycoon weighs selling a stake in RM12 billion port business: sources
summary: Malaysian tycoon Syed Mokhtar Al-Bukhary's conglomerate MMC may sell a stake of up to 30% in MMC Ports, valued at over RM12 billion, to a financial investor or company. This deal could be a precursor to a potential listing of MMC Ports on the Malaysian stock exchange in a few years. Several financial investors have approached MMC about their interest in the ports business, indicating a potential sale. The move is seen as a strategic move by MMC to bring in external capital and support the company's growth.

site_title: DPM Wong receives highest honour at NTUC May Day Awards 2023
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong received the Medal of Honour at NTUC's May Day Awards 2023 for his longstanding support of workers and unions. Wong supported NTUC and unions' efforts, making key decisions to protect workers and their livelihoods. He also introduced initiatives such as the Jobs-Skills Integrator and Progressive Wage Credit schemes to improve training and job-matching for low-income workers. The award was seen as a recognition of the importance of the tripartite partnership between the government, unions, and employers in taking the country forward.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: India central bank pushes for stronger governance at banks
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has urged government-owned banks to strengthen their boards and increase risk management focus. RBI governor Shaktikanta Das emphasized the need for banks to identify risks early and ensure financial and operational resilience during a meeting with senior management. This push aims to improve governance and mitigate potential risks, ultimately benefiting the country's banking sector.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Indonesia tops the list of tourist sources in April, followed by Malaysia, India, Australia, and China. Singapore's international visitor arrivals exceeded one million for the second consecutive month in April. Analysts expect US debt talks to impact currency markets, with a "no deal" potentially strengthening the US dollar and weakening the Singapore dollar. Companies in the Asia-Pacific region are turning to Vietnam and the Philippines for affordable talent amid economic challenges. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and China Securities Regulatory Commission are exploring ETF links between the Singapore and Shanghai stock exchanges.

site_title: Prospects for profitability
summary: Singapore's housing developers are holding back from replenishing their land banks amid uncertain market conditions, with only one bid received in the latest government land sale tender. Despite this, developers like GuocoLand, which has secured three state land sites in Lentor Hills, are gaining an advantage due to their first-mover advantage. Resale transactions show that residential properties remain profitable, with only 5% of deals resulting in losses, but profitability may decline in the near future due to flattening prices and increasing mortgage financing costs.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low
The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter
The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter.
BT's Property Insights newsletter.
BT's Property Insights newsletter.

site_title: London developers kick off record green office refurbishments
summary: London developers have started work on a record 37 office refurbishments in the six months through March, spanning 3.2 million square feet, as demand for green premises exceeds supply. This surge in refurbishments is driven by large corporations seeking to meet environmental targets and lure staff back, while also reducing embodied carbon from building projects. The trend is encouraged by phasing in rules dictating minimum efficiency standards for office buildings, and a "race to avoid obsolescence" among developers.

images.alt_text: The UK housing market is facing disruption as a double whammy of high interest rates and a cost-of-living crisis threatens to weigh on property prices.

site_title: Christie’s hires former Sotheby’s Asia CEO as region’s chairman
summary: Christie's appoints Kevin Ching as Asia chairman, replacing Sotheby's Asia CEO. Ching, who led Sotheby's Asia for 15 years, aims to develop business and increase global buying in Asia. Christie's is "cautiously optimistic" about the China market, which saw a 14% decline in art sales last year, but is expecting a recovery. The firm's Hong Kong operation recorded $835 million in sales last year, with 40% of new buyers being millennials. Christie's is set to move to a new space in 2024, amid competition from rival Sotheby's and Phillips.

site_title: HSBC upgrades 2023 outlook for Asia ex-Japan’s economic growth; expects sustainable finance issuances to trail 2022
summary: HSBC has upgraded its economic outlook for Asia ex-Japan to 5.1% growth in 2023, driven largely by China's forecast of 6.3% growth. Despite weakness in global trade, domestic demand in Asia has helped prop up growth. However, HSBC expects sustainable finance issuances in the region to decline this year compared to 2022, due to anti-ESG sentiments, tighter regulations, and market volatility. Despite this, the bank aims to double its sustainable financing volumes from South-east Asia over the next three years.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
FILE PHOTO: A logo of HSBC is seen on its headquarters at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
The US dollar index firms 0.3 per cent to 103.17, its highest level since Mar 27.
Albert Park’s comments come amid growing signs that China’s post-Covid economic recovery is losing steam, intensifying pressure on policymakers to shore up wobbly growth.
While Chinese stock markets have bounced off their October lows after the reopening, the optimism has been deflated by an uneven economic recovery.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang H2 profit down 26.2% to S$21.8 million
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a 26.2% drop in net profit to S$21.8 million for its second half ended Mar 31, 2023, due to lower profits recognized on development projects. Revenue fell 14.5% to S$76.5 million, and gross profit tumbled 53.7% to S$13.9 million. The group warned of a slowdown in sales transactions due to the recent property cooling measures and economic uncertainty. It will focus on selling its remaining projects, including The Atelier and Liv@MB, and prepare for a new development at Bukit Timah Link.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Bukit Sembawang’s specialisation in developing landed properties and luxury condominiums may also make it worthy of investor attention amid the current property boom.
Some 24 units of Pollen Collection have been released for sale so far, with four units sold, said developer Bukit Sembawang Estates.
An artist's impression of Klimt Cairnhill, one of eight condominiums observed to have offered discounts in recent months.

site_title: Thai coalition signs pact in move to hasten government formation
summary: Thailand's pro-democracy parties signed a pact to form the country's next government, a step seen as crucial for Move Forward leader Pita Limjaroenrat to become prime minister. The coalition of eight parties agreed on a unified agenda that includes pushing for charter amendments, reinstating cannabis, and making military enlistment mandatory. However, the amendment of the lese majeste law, which punishes royal insults, was not specifically mentioned in the agreement. The signing comes as Pita's coalition falls short of the 376 votes needed to become prime minister without Senate support.

images.alt_text: tiktok Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
The Thai economy grew faster than expected in the first quarter, driven by the continued pickup in the travel sector, a key source of jobs that was decimated by the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals climb, continue to surpass one million in April
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals reached 1.13 million in April, exceeding one million for the second consecutive month and the second time since the pandemic began in 2020. This marks a new post-pandemic record, although it remains below the 1.7 million visitors recorded in January 2020. Indonesia was the top source of tourists, followed by Malaysia, India, Australia, and China.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The Jobs Transformation Map identifies how job roles and skills in the hotel industry will be affected by technology, as well as global and local trends, over the next three years.
Singapore's tourism arrivals rose to 1,021,036 in March, up from the 957,839 visitors recorded in the previous month.

site_title: South Korea, EU agree to boost security ties amid Ukraine, North Korea tension
summary: South Korea and the European Union agreed to launch a strategic dialogue to develop a security partnership amid tensions over Russia's invasion of Ukraine and North Korea's nuclear threats. The agreement was reached during a summit in Seoul, where South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol and European leaders vowed to deepen relations and cooperate on issues such as climate change, health, and supply chains. The partnership aims to strengthen ties between the two regions, sharing universal values of freedom, human rights, and rule of law.

site_title: Regional markets rise on hopes of US debt ceiling breakthrough; STI up 0.3%
summary: Regional markets rose on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.3% or 8.5 points to 3,211.09 points, driven by hopes of a US debt ceiling breakthrough. Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi also rose, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index gained 1.2%. In Singapore, losers narrowly beat gainers 278 to 277, with Sats and Singapore Airlines being the top gainers. The market remains cautious due to ongoing US debt ceiling negotiations.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

Speaking at a press conference before leaving to return to Washington from the G7 summit in Hiroshima, Joe Biden said Republicans’ latest demands for spending cuts as a condition for raising the US government borrowing authority were “frankly unacceptable.”

FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says: “There’s always uncertainty about tax receipts and spending, and so it’s hard to be absolutely certain about this, but my assessment is that the odds of reaching Jun 15 while being able to pay all of our bills is quite low.”

site_title: Meta fined record 1.2 billion euros in EU over US data transfers
summary: Meta Platforms has been fined a record 1.2 billion euros (US$1.3 billion) by the European Union for failing to protect personal data from US security services. The fine, announced by Ireland's regulator, requires Meta to stop transferring personal data to the US and to suspend future transfers within five months. The decision follows a long-running saga over transatlantic data flows, which led to the EU's top court annulling a previous pact regulating data transfers in 2020. Meta has vowed to appeal the decision.

images.alt_text: AI’s rapid rise in recent months has raised alarm bells about the technology’s risks, including how it could upend the job market if it is not properly deployed.
The rise of artificial intelligence has also renewed fears about people’s jobs being replaced.
Meta introduced the “AI Sandbox” for advertisers to test early versions of features that use artificial intelligence technology.

site_title: Vietnam property developer No Va Land delays bond payments
summary: Vietnam property developer No Va Land has delayed payments on a $57.2 million bond due to a credit crunch amid difficult market conditions. The company, founded in 2007, is among the hardest-hit by turmoil in Vietnam's real estate sector, which has been caused by high debt and tightened credit rules. No Va Land is in talks with bondholders to extend the bond's maturity and needs to pay back the principal and interest. The company's shares have plummeted 83% since last year, and it has struggled to make repayments, selling assets to stay afloat.

site_title: Pay for privilege
summary: Singapore's private residential property market has been hit by further cooling measures, with higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for foreigners and local investors. The measures, which take effect on April 27, aim to curb renewed interest in property investment. Foreigners and local investors will pay 60% and 30% ABSD respectively, up from 30% and 17% previously. The measures may slow down private home prices, which have already faced headwinds from higher interest rates and economic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
BT's Property Insights newsletter.
BT's Property Insights newsletter.

site_title: ERP rates at 7 locations to be reduced by S$1 for June school holidays
summary: ELECTRONIC Road Pricing (ERP) rates at seven locations in Singapore will be reduced by S$1 for the June school holidays, starting May 29. The adjustments will revert to pre-school holiday charges on June 26. The affected locations include the Ayer Rajah Expressway, Central Expressway, and Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway, among others. Motorists will face reduced charges during specific time periods, with some gantries charging S$1 and others S$4, depending on the location and time of day.

images.alt_text: Based on LTA's monitoring of traffic conditions in February, traffic has built up at several stretches of expressways.

site_title: Gold struggles for direction with US debt talks in standstill
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$1,978.32 per ounce on Monday as traders awaited clarity on US debt ceiling negotiations and the Federal Reserve's interest rate path. The next catalyst for gold could be a dovish Fed guidance, with investors also watching for clues on future US central bank interest rate strategy. US President Joe Biden and House Republican Speaker Kevin McCarthy are set to meet to discuss the debt ceiling, which could impact gold prices if a resolution is not reached.

images.alt_text: Non-interest-bearing bullion tends to become less attractive in a high-interest-rate environment.

site_title: New rules to dampen Chinese interest to list in Europe, say bankers
summary: China has introduced new rules for companies planning to list in Europe via Global Depository Receipts (GDRs), requiring them to disclose state secrets, ensure "rational" fundraising, and undergo national security reviews. The new rules, published by the China Securities Regulatory Commission, could significantly increase underwriters' costs and make the listing process longer. This may slow Chinese companies' plans to issue GDRs on the SIX Swiss Exchange and the London Stock Exchange Group, which relies on Refinitiv for financial news and information.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka has battled its worst economic problems since independence in recent years, after protests over soaring inflation, food shortages and lengthy power cuts toppled the government.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts see NetLink as a defensive play amid volatility, raise target prices
summary: Analysts from UOBKH, CGS-CIMB, Maybank Securities, and Lim & Tan Securities have raised their target prices on NetLink NBN Trust, citing the fibre network infrastructure provider as a defensive play amid market volatility. NetLink reported strong earnings of S$54.7 million for the second half of its fiscal year, up 6.9% from the previous year. The research teams continue to like NetLink for its strong earnings visibility, stability, and high yields, making it a defensive investment option.

images.alt_text: Revenue for H2 rose 7.5 per cent to S$203.9 million from S$189.7 million. This was due chiefly to higher revenue from ancillary projects, non-building address points (NBAP) and segment connections, residential connections, and colocation orders.

site_title: DBS expects medium-term earnings to reach S$10 billion, ROE up to 17%
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, forecasts medium-term earnings of over S$10 billion and a return on equity (ROE) of 15-17%. The bank's targets are driven by a strong balance sheet and tech capabilities. Despite this, DBS shares have fallen 8.8% year-to-date due to a high interest rate environment and bank collapse anxiety. The bank's investor day presentation aims to reassure investors and provide a roadmap for growth.

images.alt_text: Generics of DBS building
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Analysts split on US debt talks’ impact on US dollar; ‘no deal’ could have unprecedented effects
summary: US debt ceiling talks are nearing the "X-date" of June 1, with analysts split on the impact on the US dollar. A "no deal" could lead to a strengthening US dollar and weakening of the Singapore dollar, while a deal may result in some US dollar weakness. Analysts expect heightened volatility and potential safe-haven demand for the US dollar and gold, but a crisis could speed up a resolution. A default on US debt would be unprecedented and unpredictable, with the US dollar likely to fall and US bond yields rising.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The debt-ceiling debate has become an unwelcome sideshow for investors already dealing with the uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve’s next policy decision in June.

Alessio de Longis, a New-York based fund manager at Invesco, sees the euro strengthening to US$1.20-1.30 on a multi-year period, but does not expect a material impact on short-term corporate earnings.
ECB president Christine Lagarde says: “We are not done yet, we are not pausing based on the information I have today,” she said, adding that the “inflation outlook is too high and for too long”.

site_title: Nvidia chips away at Intel, AMD turf in supercomputers
summary: Nvidia has collaborated with the University of Bristol and Hewlett Packard Enterprise to build a new supercomputer, Isambard 3, using Nvidia's Grace CPU chips, marking a significant shift in the company's approach to supercomputing. This system outperforms the university's previous system, Isambard 2, with six times more performance and energy efficiency. The new system will be used for climate science and drug discovery research. This move positions Nvidia as a competitor in the supercomputing market, traditionally dominated by Intel and AMD.

site_title: Godard’s afterlife begins at Cannes
summary: Jean-Luc Godard's posthumous short film "Phony Wars" was presented alongside a new documentary about the Swiss director at the Cannes film festival. Godard, who died last year aged 91, was one of the most influential filmmakers of the 20th century. The screening was attended by US director Jim Jarmusch, actor Salma Hayek, and Chinese filmmaker Wang Bing, among others. The event marked the beginning of Godard's afterlife at Cannes, a fitting tribute to his legacy.

site_title: Singapore seeks to groom AI talent for banks amid shortage
summary: Singapore aims to develop and deploy AI solutions in key sectors by 2030, with a focus on responsible AI in the finance sector. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will work with banks and schools to create training programs incorporating the latest AI developments and trends. Due to a global shortage of AI resources, Singapore will prioritize key areas such as experimentation and financing commercially scalable ideas. This move is part of the city-state's goal to become a leader in AI development and deployment across various sectors, including healthcare, finance, and education.

site_title: Cool tribal tattoo. Is it from the 1990s?
summary: Tribal tattoos, once considered uncool and associated with the 1990s, have seen a resurgence in popularity. Tattoo artist Leo Zulueta, 71, is credited with pioneering the style in the US. However, some argue that the trend has been co-opted by "meatheads and cultural appropriators," who adopt the designs without understanding or respecting their Indigenous origins. As a result, some people still view tribal tattoos as a relic of the past, while others appreciate their unique aesthetic.

images.alt_text: Leo Zulueta, who is generally credited with pioneering and popularizing tribal style tattoos in the U.S., at Spiral Tattoo in Ann Arbor, Mich., May 16, 2023. Tribal style tattoos, once dismissed for being culturally appropriative, are back in vogue. (Nic Antaya/The New York Times)

site_title: Do not use money meant to fight inflation in the long term to mitigate inflation now
summary: Christopher Tan, CEO of Providend Ltd, advises against using money meant to fight inflation in the long term to mitigate inflation now. Instead, he recommends investing in equities, alongside physical real estate, to beat inflation in the long term. Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (Tips) may be used tactically to mitigate inflation, but investors should include them before an expected rise in inflation rate to maximize returns. Tips can provide a guaranteed return adjusted for inflation, but may result in lower returns if inflation is lower than expected.

images.alt_text: coins, calculator, budget
Positive returns do not necessarily mean you have accumulated enough for retirement.

site_title: EU’s next food fight – regulating gene-edited crops
summary: The European Union is set to propose new rules for genetically modified (GM) crops, aiming to increase food production and resilience to climate change. The proposed law would loosen regulations on plants produced by new genomic techniques (NGTs), which are seen as less vulnerable to drought and disease. However, some EU lawmakers oppose the move, citing concerns over environmental and health risks. The debate is likely to focus on safeguards, with the Greens pushing for a full risk assessment and labelling requirements.

images.alt_text: Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister James Marape (fourth from right), India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi (fourth from left) and leaders posing for a group photo during the Forum for India-Pacific Islands Cooperation in Port Moresby. Papua New Guinea, May 22, 2023.

site_title: Australia to regulate buy now, pay later sector with credit laws
summary: Australia has introduced new laws to regulate the buy now, pay later (BNPL) sector under credit laws, impacting firms like Zip and Afterpay. The regulations will require companies to adhere to "responsible lending" obligations, hold Australian credit licenses, and meet minimum standards on conduct and products. The move aims to address concerns about the industry's impact on consumers, who often take on debt they can't afford. The new laws will also bring the industry into line with other regulated credit providers, simplifying the regulatory system and addressing competitive neutrality concerns.

images.alt_text: buy now, pay later bnpl afterpay Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Tokyo stocks close up, Nikkei hits fresh 33-year high
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 reaching a fresh 33-year high of 31,086.82, driven by active buying by foreign investors. The benchmark index added 0.90% to 278.47 points, while the Topix index rose 0.66%. Polls showing a modest rise in support for Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's government also contributed to the boost. Key shares, including Advantest and Tokio Marine Holdings, rallied, while others like SoftBank Group and Nippon Steel advanced.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian holding her mobile phone walks past electronic boards showing the Japan's Nikkei average (top L) and the Japanese yen's exchange rate against the euro (top R) outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, February 9, 2016.  REUTERS/Yuya Shino/File Photo

site_title: Private markets in 2023 – new ideas for a new regime
summary: Investors in private markets are adapting to a new era of challenges and opportunities in 2023. Higher interest rates and a shrinking Federal Reserve balance sheet are lowering liquidity, creating financial headwinds across asset classes. Private equity and venture capital markets are experiencing a reset, with PE exit activity dropping sharply and venture capital in a period of deep revaluation. However, private credit is gaining traction, with distressed debt opportunities on the rise. Emerging trends such as energy transition, food innovation, and decentralization are expected to propel private investments for the next decade.

images.alt_text: Rajeev Mittal, Fidelity International MD, at the official opening of the China fund management company. Fidlity raised RMB1 1 billion in its first China equity fund launch earlier this year.

site_title: Volvo wins record order for electric trucks from Holcim
summary: Volvo Trucks has signed a record order for 1,000 electric trucks with Swiss building solutions provider Holcim, set to be delivered over the next seven years. The deal, valued by Volvo, is the largest commercial order to date for the company's electric trucks. The replacement of 1,000 diesel trucks with electric versions could save up to 50,000 tons of carbon dioxide emissions annually. The first 130 trucks will be delivered in the fourth quarter of 2023 and 2024 to various European markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Volvo logo is seen in truck for sale in Linden, New Jersey, U.S., May 23, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: German economy shows resilience but lacks momentum: DIHK survey
summary: The DIHK survey of 21,000 German companies found that the economy is showing resilience in a challenging environment, but growth will remain muted this year, with GDP forecast to stagnate in 2023. Despite high energy prices, rising interest rates, and the war in Ukraine, companies are showing remarkable resilience. The outlook for the coming year remains gloomy, with "signs of a broad-based upswing continuing to be missing," according to a DIHK board member.

site_title: Consider waiving Buyer’s Stamp Duty for some young Singaporean couples buying their first home
summary: Singapore is considering waiving Buyer's Stamp Duty (BSD) for young local couples buying their first homes, with a monthly household income of S$14,000 or less. Currently, couples above this income threshold face restrictions on buying BTO flats and receiving CPF Housing Grants. The BSD waiver would apply to homes below S$3 million and could help high-earning young couples buy private homes, potentially boosting the government's goal of encouraging homeownership among locals. The move aims to support marriage and parenthood, while also nudging high-earning locals to get married and anchor themselves in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
The number of households and grant amount given out have increased each year since, in line with more flats being sold.
SRX

site_title: Former investor darling GLP is now sliding into distress in Asia
summary: GLP, a major Asian logistics operator, is experiencing distress in Asia after years of being a sought-after investor. Its investment-grade dollar bonds have been the worst performers in Asia this year, putting the firm at risk of being downgraded to junk territory. Four out of six GLP entities' notes issued are indicated to trade between 31 and 60 US cents, according to Bloomberg data. This decline in sentiment has raised concerns about GLP's financial stability.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Government of Singapore Investment Corp. (GIC) is displayed during GIC's 30th anniversary conference, in Singapore, on Monday, May 9, 2011. Singapore's economic prospects over the next decade will be "bright" and the country will need to ensure it has sufficient reserves as global uncertainties will be the "new norm," Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said. Photographer: Munshi Ahmed/Bloomberg

site_title: Regulators dust off rule books to tackle generative AI like ChatGPT
summary: Regulators are revisiting old laws to address concerns about generative AI models like ChatGPT, which have made mistakes or "hallucinations" spewing up misinformation. The European Union is drafting new AI rules, including proposals that would force companies to disclose copyrighted material used to train models, and US regulators are examining AI tools for discriminatory practices. It will take several years for these regulations to be enforced, and industry insiders are calling for greater engagement between regulators and companies to find a balance between consumer protection and business growth.

images.alt_text: OpenAI plans to offer its app in more countries in the coming weeks and expects to roll out the Android version soon.
ChatGPT logo and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Credit Suisse staff prepare to sue Swiss regulator over lost AT1 bonuses: FT
summary: Credit Suisse staff plan to sue the Swiss regulator Finma over $400 million of cancelled bonuses following the troubled lender's rescue by UBS Group. Senior managers have requested law firms Quinn Emanuel and Pallas to take legal action on their behalf. The Swiss regulator ordered the cancellation of bonus payments for top management as part of the takeover, citing Swiss banking law that allows for such measures if a bank received state aid. The lawsuit is part of ongoing disputes over Additional Tier-1 (AT1) bonds issued by Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: In reaching its faster-than-expected decision, the Credit Derivatives Determinations Committee took the view that the AT1 securities were in fact junior to the subordinated bonds underlying the swaps.

site_title: OpenAI brings ChatGPT app to your smartphone
summary: OpenAI has released its ChatGPT app on iOS devices, allowing users to type or speak questions and receive written responses from the chatbot. The app, available for free, syncs text-based conversations across devices and includes voice recognition. A premium version, ChatGPT Plus, offers faster response times and previews of new features. OpenAI plans to roll out the app to Android devices soon and expand its availability to more countries. The move comes as chatbots, including ChatGPT, face scrutiny over biases and fabrications, with Apple restricting internal use of the tools.

images.alt_text: openai ChatGPT Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: The Greek economy is roaring back, but voters are counting the cost
summary: Greece is experiencing a significant economic recovery, with its GDP expected to reach 223 billion euros this year, roughly the same level as in 2010. Unemployment has more than halved from its peak of 28%, and controls to stop the exodus of euros were lifted over three years ago. However, the recovery has left many Greeks struggling, with the legacy of the coronavirus pandemic and cost-of-living crisis affecting households already squeezed by years of austerity. Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis and former premier Alexis Tsipras are the main contenders in a tight election this weekend, with the winner expected to decide Greece's trajectory and whether it can avoid another period of political drama.

images.alt_text: Greece has been fighting to repatriate looted artefacts from museums and private collections around the world.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of US debt talks
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday ahead of US debt talks between President Joe Biden and congressional leaders. Despite expectations of a deal to avert a catastrophic default, markets fluctuated as investors awaited solid signs of a compromise. Hong Kong and Shanghai markets edged up, while Tokyo, Seoul, and Singapore also rose. Sydney, Taipei, Manila, Jakarta, and Wellington slid, with investors focusing on the Federal Reserve's potential pause in interest rate hikes after a year of tightening.

images.alt_text: in Asia, Tokyo raced higher again, building on a recent surge in the Nikkei, while Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila, Wellington and Jakarta were also up on Thursday.

site_title: India’s plan to remove rupee notes from circulation boosts bonds
summary: India's plan to remove 2,000 rupee notes from circulation is expected to add up to 1 trillion rupees (S$16.2 billion) to the financial system, boosting bonds and easing money market rates. The move is expected to increase liquidity in the banking system, causing a rally in shorter-maturity bonds and easing rates on commercial paper and treasury bills. The yield on 5-year bonds dropped 10 basis points to 6.86%, while the 10-year yield decreased 3 basis points to 6.98%. The move may revive a rally in rupee government bonds, which lost momentum last week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man holds 2000 Indian rupee notes as he leaves a bank in Mumbai, India, November 24, 2016. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: China holds lending rates steady; cautious on weak yuan, capital outflow risk
summary: China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) kept its benchmark lending rates unchanged for the ninth month in May, matching market expectations, due to a weakening yuan and widening yield differentials with the US. The decision aims to limit capital outflow risks and stabilize the yuan. Analysts now expect the PBOC to lower the amount of cash banks must set aside as its next policy move, rather than cutting interest rates. The decision follows data showing an economy losing momentum after the initial post-Covid bounce.

images.alt_text: Hegang, a city with nearly a million people near the Russian border, had debt of more than double its fiscal income when it hit the headlines almost 18 months ago.
Helen Wong, CEO, OCBC

Chinese 100 yuan banknotes are seen in a counting machine while a clerk counts them at a branch of a commercial bank in Beijing, China, in this March 30, 2016 file picture. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/Files

site_title: Biden to meet with McCarthy, says Republican demands unacceptable
summary: US President Joe Biden will meet with Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy on Monday to discuss raising the US debt ceiling, with a June 1 deadline looming. Biden has rejected Republicans' demands for spending cuts, calling them "frankly unacceptable," while McCarthy remains committed to his stance. The Treasury Department warns of a potential default on US debt if Congress doesn't authorize more borrowing, with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen describing June 1 as a "hard deadline." The negotiations come as the US faces a recession risk and the 2024 election campaign heats up.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says: “There’s always uncertainty about tax receipts and spending, and so it’s hard to be absolutely certain about this, but my assessment is that the odds of reaching Jun 15 while being able to pay all of our bills is quite low.”

US President Joe Biden, who is travelling in Japan for the Group of Seven summit, has sought the call after his negotiating team briefed him on the status of talks that broke up on Friday with no signs of progress.
G7 host Japan will likely discuss with President Joe Biden whether he might look to reopen US participation in the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership.
Members of the group are looking to “de-risk, not decouple” from China.

site_title: Economists push back expected Fed rate cut to 2024, Nabe poll shows
summary: Economists now expect the US Federal Reserve to lower its targeted policy rate in the first quarter of 2024, according to a survey by the National Association for Business Economics. They have also raised forecasts for inflation and the job market, with an expected 3.3% rise in consumer prices and an average of 142,000 jobs gained per month. The median view sees modest growth through 2024, with a projected jobless rate of 3.7% this year, down from 3.9% in the February survey. The Fed's benchmark interest rate remains at 5-5.25%.

images.alt_text: The debt-ceiling debate has become an unwelcome sideshow for investors already dealing with the uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve’s next policy decision in June.
For the week, the Dow gains 0.38 per cent, the S&P 500 climbs 1.65 per cent and the Nasdaq advances 3.04 per cent.

“While the financial stability tools helped to calm conditions in the banking sector, developments there on the other hand are contributing to tighter credit conditions and are likely to weigh on economic growth, hiring and inflation,” Fed chair Jerome  Powell says.

site_title: Why G7 summit may prove critics wrong
summary: The G7 summit in Japan has taken key decisions on various global issues, including Ukraine, China, supply chains, and AI. The group reversed its opposition to providing F-16 fighters to Ukraine, doubling down on its support for Kyiv, and announced a $375 million US military aid package. The G7 also focused on broadening its appeal to the Global South, with 16 nations attending the summit. The group emphasized economic coercion as a threat to its positions and committed to a toolkit to counter China's influence. Additionally, the G7 agreed on measures to diversify energy supplies, decarbonize transportation, and promote AI governance.

images.alt_text: G7 host Japan will likely discuss with President Joe Biden whether he might look to reopen US participation in the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership.

“This is all about de-risking - not de-coupling,” Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak says. “With the G7, we are taking steps to prevent China from using economic coercion to interfere in the sovereign affairs of others.”

site_title: The trouble with pricing carbon
summary: Singapore's carbon credit market is plagued by inconsistent pricing, with no common benchmark established. The Climate Impact X has introduced a solution, but the market remains volatile. The National Environment Agency (NEA) is expanding its whitelist of carbon credits through new Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs). The NEA sets criteria for good carbon credits, while Climate Impact X defends voluntary carbon credits from intact forests. The company will launch a spot exchange with curated nature-based projects and publish carbon credit prices. The move aims to increase transparency and standardization in the market.

site_title: Syngenta’s IPO seen as key to lure foreigners to China’s market
summary: Syngenta, a Switzerland-based seed giant, is set to list on the Shanghai Stock Exchange's main board with a 65 billion yuan (S$12.44 billion) IPO, potentially the world's biggest this year. The move is seen as a key to lure foreigners to China's onshore equities market, following regulatory improvements and investment vehicles. The listing is expected to boost liquidity and attract global investors, further legitimizing China as a viable money center, according to experts. The IPO is the latest success story for China's onshore listings, which have raised more proceeds than any other country last year.

site_title: Gold inches higher on US debt ceiling talks, banking sector uncertainty
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,979.79 per ounce on Monday, driven by less-hawkish comments from US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and uncertainty surrounding the US debt ceiling and banking sector stability. The dollar index eased, making gold more affordable for overseas buyers. Markets now price in a 90.8% chance of the Fed holding interest rates steady in June, reducing the need for higher rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Liquid gold is poured to form gold dore bars at Newmont Mining's Carlin gold mine operation near Elko, Nevada May 21, 2014. REUTERS/Rick Wilking/File Photo

site_title: WealthBT: Opportunities in private debt - Are returns still attractive? (Ep 26)
summary: Private debt has emerged as an attractive asset class, delivering attractive returns with little correlation to stocks and bonds since the 2008 financial crisis. However, the current macro environment poses challenges. According to Goh Hui Yang, Pictet's head of alternative investments in Asia, careful credit selection can still yield equity-like returns. The podcast highlights the importance of understanding the risks and challenges associated with private debt investments.

site_title: PM Lee Hsien Loong Covid-19 positive for the first time, says he is ‘generally feeling OK’
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has tested positive for Covid-19 for the first time, after recent work trips to South Africa and Kenya. He is "generally feeling OK" and has been advised to self-isolate until asymptomatic.

images.alt_text: PM Lee Hsien Loong urges Singapore businesses to look further afield while strengthening their existing ventures
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and President William Ruto deliver remarks at the Joint Press Conference at State House in Nairobi, Kenya on Thursday, 18 May.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at a welcome ceremony at Tuynhuys, South Africa’s presidential office, with South African President Cyril Ramaphosa on May 16.

site_title: Papua New Guinea, US to sign security pact with eye on China
summary: Papua New Guinea will sign a defense pact with the US, amid concerns over China's growing influence in the region. The agreement follows talks between US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi with Pacific leaders in Port Moresby. The move aims to counterbalance China's diplomatic and financial efforts in the region. The pact is seen as a strategic response to China's growing presence, with the Pacific island nation strategically located near trade routes to Australia and Japan.

images.alt_text: Bus stops with Chinese signage built for the 2018 Apec summit dot Port Moresby.

site_title: Confidence returning to UK housing market as asking prices jump: Rightmove
summary: UK housing market confidence is returning as asking prices for homes jumped 1.8% in May, the highest monthly rise this year. The average price of homes coming to market rose £6,647 (S$11,280) from April. This increase is attributed to a better economic outlook and steady mortgage rates, offsetting the impact of the Bank of England's interest rate hikes. Buyer demand is also higher, 3% above the same month in 2019.

images.alt_text: Britain is a net food importer, meaning it’s extra vulnerable to tight supply.
Business leaders argue that firms need workers as they struggle to fill jobs after the pandemic drove many people out of the labour force.
British households have been grappling with high inflation which was running at 10.1 per cent in March with the cost of food and drinks surging by the most since 1977.

site_title: China reopening likely to mitigate tightening NIM: OCBC chief Helen Wong
summary: OCBC's CEO, Helen Wong, expects China's reopening to boost the bank's wealth and trade segments, mitigating tightening net interest margins. The bank's operations across Greater China and Asean regions are expected to capture fund flows in areas including wealth, investment, and trade. With interest rates likely to peak, OCBC's volume of clients and assets will help mitigate any drop in net interest margin. Wong also expects investment and trade flows to improve as China posts a 5% GDP growth for 2023, with the services sector and domestic consumption leading the recovery.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
OCBC is in a good position to capture wealth and trade flows given its strong links between the greater China and Asean regions, said CEO Helen Wong.

OCBC's chief executive officer Helen Wong (middle), head of global whole banking Tan Teck Long (left) and head of global wholesale banking sustainability office Mike Ng (right) announcing the bank's decarbonisation targets on May 16, 2023.
NODX to China contributes the most to the overall decline in shipments to Singapore’s top 10 markets in April.
The lender was the last among its local peers to report its quarterly results this season.

site_title: Japan’s March core machinery orders fall 3.9% month/month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 3.9% in March from the previous month, worse than the 0.7% gain forecast by economists. This decline, compared to a 3.5% drop from a year earlier, is attributed to the highly volatile core orders data series, which is seen as a leading indicator of capital spending for the next six to nine months.

site_title: Crippling heat deepens Asia’s reliance on Russian energy
summary: Crippling heat in Asia has led to a surge in Russian energy imports, as countries struggle to secure sufficient fuel supplies. Shipments of liquefied natural gas have grown, driven by declining prices that made the fuel unaffordable for poorer nations. This trend is a result of Russia's push to fund its Ukraine invasion, now seen as a pull by Asian economies. The extreme heat, potentially the hottest year on record, has heightened energy demands, making Russian energy an attractive option.

images.alt_text: OCBC is in a good position to capture wealth and trade flows given its strong links between the greater China and Asean regions, said CEO Helen Wong.
Organisations in the Asia-Pacific region showed the least improvement in reducing their greenhouse gas emissions and natural-resource consumption, says Sustainable Fitch.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Frencken, Hiap Tong
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) reported a slowdown in sales for the first quarter, with total sales value falling to S$213.2 million. Frencken Group's net profit decreased 59.5% to S$5.2 million, while Hiap Tong expects "significantly higher" net profit for FY2023 due to new projects and business operations resuming in Singapore and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Malaysia to meet Coldplay concert organiser over ticket scalpers
summary: Malaysian authorities will meet Coldplay concert organiser over ticket scalpers. Tickets sold out within hours after sales began on May 17, with fans taking to social media to vent frustration over bulk purchases by resellers. The meeting aims to prevent similar issues in the future, with the Communications Minister examining legal provisions if needed.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks began the week lower, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.3% to 3,193.55 points, following a decline in US equities due to paused debt ceiling negotiations. Marco Polo Marine was the top traded counter, gaining 2% on its shares. A total of 38.8 million securities worth S$48.9 million changed hands, with 69 losers outnumbering 46 gainers.

images.alt_text: City Developments Limited (CDL) reported a slowdown in its sales for the first quarter of 2023.

site_title: Instagram back up after global outage affecting thousands of users
summary: Instagram, a service from Meta Platform Inc, experienced a global outage affecting thousands of users. The outage, which began on Sunday, disrupted services for some users, with over 180,000 reporting issues. The issue was resolved as quickly as possible, with Downdetector tracking over 100,000 incidents in the US, 24,000 in Canada, and 56,000 in Britain. Instagram returned to normal for most users, with the company attributing the outage to a technical issue.

site_title: Manulife US Reit recapitalisation: Placement of new units to Mirae should be priced at NAV
summary: Manulife US Reit is considering a recapitalization deal with Mirae Asset Global Investments, which could involve Mirae acquiring the manager and taking up a placement of new units in the Reit. The deal aims to limit dilution for existing unitholders and demonstrate Mirae's credibility as a sponsor. Manulife US Reit's office properties have declined in value, and its gearing is approaching the statutory ceiling of 50%. A successful deal could trigger a rebound in the Reit's market price, but the extent of the recovery depends on how much dilution the deal inflicts on unitholders.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Tanasbourne is a 132,851 square foot office campus comprising three flex-office buildings. It was constructed between 1986 and 1995, and was refurbished in 2015, 2017 and 2020.
Manulife US Reit's properties could continue to be marked down with rising interest rates, slowing US economic growth and a continuation of hybrid work arrangements
MAS should set out its expectations of troubled Reits' managers and sponsor groups
With the Reit’s portfolio having a weighted average lease expiry (WALE) of five years, its manager expects positive rental reversion for 2023.
Manulife US Reit's aggregate leverage stands at 49.5%, its Q1 2023 operational updates indicates.

site_title: Thai jobless rate lowest in 3 years in Q1 as tourism rebounds
summary: The unemployment rate in Thailand reached a three-year low of 1.05% in the first quarter, driven by a strong recovery in the tourism industry. The economy grew faster than expected, with employment increasing 2.4% from a year earlier. The tourism sector, a key source of jobs, rebounded after being decimated by the pandemic. This growth is a positive sign for Thailand's economy, which is Southeast Asia's second-largest.

site_title: SpaceX launches crew of private astronauts to space station
summary: SpaceX successfully launched a crew of four private astronauts, including the first woman from Saudi Arabia, to the International Space Station (ISS). The crew, led by Peggy Whitson, lifted off atop a Falcon 9 rocket from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on May 21. The mission, operated by Axiom Space, aims to prepare for sending people to Axiom's own private space station. The crew will spend eight days on the ISS conducting over 20 experiments before returning to Earth.

images.alt_text: Companies are in a race to tap the market for satellite-enabled calls offering connections in remote areas beyond the reach of cell towers.

site_title: Oil edges up on supply worries, G7 pledge to enforce Russian price caps
summary: Oil prices rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by supply cuts from Canada and OPEC+ producers, and a softer dollar. Brent crude futures climbed to $75.72 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $71.84 a barrel. The Group of Seven nations pledged to strictly enforce price caps on Russian energy exports, but its impact on exports is yet to be seen.

images.alt_text: An oil pumping jack, also known as a 'nodding donkey,' stands in an oilfield operated by Bashneft PAO in the village of Otrada, 150kms from Ufa, Russia, on Saturday, March 5, 2016. Bashneft is an upstream and down stream oil & gas provider which explores, produces and refines its own oil and gas which it extracts from brownfield reserves in the Russian Federation. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Google offers 15,000 scholarships to 300 local SMEs for training in digitalisation
summary: Google Singapore is offering 15,000 scholarships to 300 local small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) for digitalisation-related courses. The scholarships, offered in partnership with Enterprise Singapore and SGTech, cover courses such as digital marketing, e-commerce, and data analytics. Minister of State Alvin Tan noted that companies whose employees have gone through the programme have seen encouraging results, including improved revenue. The initiative aims to help SMEs improve efficiency and productivity through digitalisation.

images.alt_text:
ncgoogle24 -  Alvin Tan, Minister of State for Ministry of Trade and Industry and Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, encouraged SMEs to upskill themselves with digitalisation.  


Credits - GOOGLE SINGAPORE

site_title: Biden says US-China relations set to improve ‘very shortly’
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that US-China relations are set to improve "very shortly" following a recent spat over an alleged spy balloon. This comes after the US shot down the balloon, which was carrying spying equipment, changing the dynamic after a meeting between Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping last year. Biden expressed optimism about a long-anticipated phone conversation with Xi, and his administration is considering lifting sanctions on Chinese Defense Minister Li Shangfu. Despite tensions, the US and China are engaging in multiple diplomatic efforts, including meetings between officials.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden speaks during a news conference following the G-7 leaders summit in Hiroshima, Japan, on May 21. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS upgrades Sats to ‘buy’, lowers TP
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Sats to "buy" from "hold" with a target price of S$3.40, citing a change in valuation method and a "highly complementary" acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services. Analyst Jason Sum views the recent share price correction as "overdone" and sees an opportunity for buying, despite concerns about the acquisition's timing and valuation. He expects growth opportunities in the air cargo market and predicts Sats' ground handling and in-flight catering businesses will benefit from a recovery in global air passenger traffic.

images.alt_text: Since mid-March, Sats shares have been rebounding. It closed Monday (Apr 3) at $2.78, representing a 16.8 per cent gain from its Mar 14 close.

site_title: Investors in Asia’s worst-performing market on edge after poll
summary: Thailand's pro-democracy parties won a historic win in national elections, but investors remain uncertain about the formation of a new government. The benchmark SET Index tumbled 3% after a historic weekly slide, and outflows of funds worsened the country's poor-performing stock market. A planned coalition may not have enough votes to form a government, and investors are waiting for clarity before making investment decisions. A quick formation of a government is crucial to easing investor worries and removing electoral concerns.

images.alt_text: “We have a lot of momentum, my coalition is taking shape,” the Harvard-educated, 42-year-old Pita told reporters in Bangkok on Thursday.
A bedrock of Thailand’s economy before the pandemic, tourism is reclaiming its key role as investors are waiting and watching days after a national vote on Sunday.

site_title: London home presales slump as slowing price growth deters buyers
summary: London's off-plan home presales have declined, with the proportion of new homes sold in advance dropping to 44% last year, down from a peak of 71% in 2016. Investors are shifting to higher-yielding regions outside London, such as the northwest of England, as interest rates and a cost-of-living crisis threaten to weigh on property prices. The UK housing market faces disruption, with builders relying on alternative sales methods, such as bulk sales to build-to-rent operators, to de-risk developments.

images.alt_text: A row of residential properties stand in front of the City of London financial district in London, U.K., on Monday, April 3, 2017. U.K. house prices fell for the first time in almost two years in March, according to the latest report from Nationwide Building Society. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: ECB has more ground to cover to tame inflation: Lagarde
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde stated that the fight to tame inflation is not over, requiring more action. She said the "inflation outlook is too high and for too long" and that the ECB is not done yet, despite covering a significant portion of the journey to achieve its target. Lagarde expressed concerns about forward guidance due to various uncertainties, and did not have a predetermined number in mind for future interest rate adjustments.

site_title: More than S$520,000 raised for Breast Cancer Foundation
summary: Over S$520,000 was raised at the Breast Cancer Foundation's (BCF) Tee for Pink Charity Golf event, held on May 18 at Tanah Merah Country Club. The event, supported by a Tote Board matching grant, brought together about 100 golfers to raise funds and awareness for BCF. The raised amount will be used to set up two Breast Cancer Support Centres in hospitals and fund programmes and services at the centres.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Man City beat Chelsea to celebrate Premier League title triumph
summary: Manchester City secured their third consecutive Premier League title with a 1-0 win over Chelsea at the Etihad Stadium. The victory, coupled with Arsenal's loss to Nottingham Forest, sealed City's fifth title in six seasons under Pep Guardiola. The team will now focus on winning the FA Cup and Champions League, with Guardiola acknowledging that winning in Europe is crucial to being considered one of the greatest teams in English football history.

images.alt_text: Each group winner secures a place at the first finals featuring 48 teams, which will be hosted by the US, Canada and Mexico.
A fight breaks out on the sidelines of the men's football final match between Thailand and Indonesia during the 32nd SEA Games in Phnom Penh, May 16, 2023.
Manchester United fans display banners in protest of the Glazer family’s ownership of the club.
Liverpool (in red) defeated Leicester 3-0 in the English Premier League on May 16. The two teams will play each other again in Singapore on Jul 30 at the National Stadium.

site_title: China bars purchases of Micron chips in escalation of US clash
summary: China has banned the purchase of Micron Technology chips due to "relatively serious" cybersecurity risks found in the products sold in the country. The decision comes amid an escalating semiconductor war between the US and China. Beijing's move is seen as retaliation for the US's export controls on semiconductors, with Chinese officials claiming it's a necessary measure to safeguard national security. Micron is evaluating the conclusion of the review and assessing its next steps.

images.alt_text: Helen Wong, CEO, OCBC

site_title: China’s US$23 trillion local debt mess is about to get worse
summary: China's local debt of approximately $23 trillion is at risk of worsening, with heavily indebted municipalities likely to follow Hegang's financial restructuring. The city, near the Russian border, had debt exceeding double its fiscal income and implemented emergency measures in 2021. Residents are feeling the effects, with complaints of inadequate public services, reduced benefits, and delayed salaries. Experts warn that local governments may have to make painful spending cuts or divert funds away from growth-boosting projects to repay debt. The situation threatens China's economic growth and social stability, with President Xi Jinping's ambition of doubling income levels by 2035 at risk.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden has previously voiced optimism about holding a long-anticipated phone conversation with Xi, though he didn’t give any indication on how soon that might take place.
Helen Wong, CEO, OCBC

site_title: How to be an effective workplace whistleblower
summary: A young woman, Anita, reported her team leader's sexual harassment to the company's HR department, but was subsequently terminated as part of an internal restructuring. She believes her complaint led to her job loss, but cannot prove it. To be an effective whistleblower, it's essential to approach the situation as an opportunity for management to address the issue, rather than pitting oneself against the company. This can help prevent further harm and create a safer work environment.

images.alt_text: Stefanie Yuen Thio
ByteDance responded to the scraping allegations, saying it acquired data in line with industry practice and its global policy.
The reward of a better-quality workplace environment, culture and relationships will make the effort of complaining, or establishing a positive feedback culture, worthwhile.

site_title: Traders brace for volatility with US debt deal still elusive
summary: US lawmakers are still struggling to reach a debt-limit deal, leading to market uncertainty and volatility. The dollar is trading in tight ranges, and investors are bracing for potential spikes in currency volatility and losses in equities. A meeting between House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and President Joe Biden is set for Monday, but a resolution is unlikely before mid-June. Strategists warn that an impasse could threaten the outlook for equity markets, while traders are hedging their portfolios with swaps and options.

images.alt_text: Speaking at a press conference before leaving to return to Washington from the G7 summit in Hiroshima, Joe Biden said Republicans’ latest demands for spending cuts as a condition for raising the US government borrowing authority were “frankly unacceptable.”

site_title: How women leaders benefit from using humour
summary: Research suggests that women leaders benefit more from using humor in public speaking, gaining influence and being perceived as more influential. A study analyzing 2,407 TED talks found that female speakers who used humor were more popular and influential than those who didn't, and comparably to male speakers. Humor helped female speakers make a stronger connection with their audience, leading to higher ratings and view counts. The study's findings support the idea that humor is a valuable tool for women leaders, particularly in male-dominated fields.

Setting an expectation that it’s OK (or even necessary) to work beyond your contracted hours disadvantages those that need more flexibility, such as carers, who are typically women.

site_title: Carbon credits: knowing how to pick the right investments
summary: Carbon credits are poised to take a major leap forward in scale and sophistication, according to industry leaders. The application of the Core Carbon Principles will effectively differentiate high-quality from low-grade credits, providing assurance for investors. Successful projects depend on close collaboration with stakeholders, particularly local communities. Investors must understand the importance of project managers working with these communities to ensure effective carbon asset management. This shift aims to address concerns around poorly-run projects and mitigate harm to communities.

ICVCM states that forestry projects under Redd+ – a UN framework created to guide activities in the forest sector that reduces emissions from deforestation and forest degradation – must also conform to the Cancun safeguards.

site_title: Business leaders to discuss navigating to net zero in a fast-changing world
summary: Business leaders from Singapore's banking, tourism, and energy sectors will discuss navigating to net zero at a panel discussion on May 23. The event, organized by The Business Times and presented by Schneider Electric, features OCBC Bank's CEO Helen Wong, Sentosa Development Corporation's CEO Thien Kwee Eng, and Schneider Electric's Yoon Young Kim. A survey by Schneider Electric found that linking executive remuneration to decarbonization progress could drive companies' green plans, highlighting the need for businesses to adapt to a low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Organisations in the Asia-Pacific region showed the least improvement in reducing their greenhouse gas emissions and natural-resource consumption, says Sustainable Fitch.
