site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts lower ComfortDelGro’s target price on Q1 earnings miss
summary: Analysts at RHB and DBS Group Research lowered their target price for ComfortDelGro (CDG) after the transport operator reported lower-than-expected earnings for Q1 2023. RHB cut its target price to S$1.25, while DBS trimmed its target price to S$1.62. Despite revenue growth, analysts attributed the underperformance to weaker margins in the public transport business and lower earnings from the taxi business. However, they expect earnings to gradually improve in the second half of 2023.

images.alt_text: Geographically, ComfortDelGro said Singapore is showing “signs of slowing economic growth”. Over in Australia, there are driver shortages but also new terms from successful re-tenders, the company said.

site_title: ECB needs to keep interest rates ‘sustainably high’ to combat inflation: Lagarde
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde says interest rates need to remain high to combat inflation, indicating the cycle is not over. The ECB slowed rate hikes this month with a 25-basis-point rise, but Lagarde signals more monetary tightening. The bank aims to curb inflation, which slowed to 7.3% in April, and will pursue its 2% inflation target despite challenges in the eurozone. Markets expect further rate hikes, with potential cuts starting early next year. Lagarde vows the ECB will take necessary decisions to bring inflation back to target, despite a "critical" economic moment.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde delivers a speech, at a ceremony where former German Chancellor Angela Merkel receives North Rhine-Westphalia's 'State Prize', in Cologne, Germany, May 16, 2023. REUTERS/Thilo Schmuelgen

site_title: Jun Yamamura to become CEO of Daiwa House Logistics Trust’s manager from Jun 1
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust announced that Takeshi Fujita, 59, will step down as CEO of the trust's manager on May 31, succeeded by Jun Yamamura on June 1. The change is part of succession planning, with Fujita returning to Japan to assume another appointment in Daiwa House Industry Co, the trust's sponsor. Yamamura, currently head of planning, will oversee business strategies.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

The manager expects to increase its supply of properties in Japan in 2023, mostly in Greater Tokyo. Demand for its properties are also expected to be buoyed by third party logisitics companies as well as those in e-commerce.

site_title: European banks’ rates bonanza is peaking as savers shift money
summary: European banks' net interest income peaked in the first quarter, with several leaders attributing the drop to increasing competition and customers shifting to higher-yielding term deposits. The trend is expected to continue as interest rates approach their peak and savers opt for better returns. This marks a reversal of the industry's windfall from the European Central Bank's rate hikes, which boosted profitability last year. Net interest income is likely to continue above pre-rate hike levels, but at a lower rate, as banks pass on more of the interest earned to clients.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass a Commerzbank AG bank branch in Hamburg, Germany, on Monday, May 6, 2019. The city has more than its fair share of millionaires and, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, at least five of the 30 richest Germans live in Hamburg. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore e-waste recyclers all charged up to sate appetite abroad
summary: Singapore's e-waste recycling sector is largely dependent on importing feedstock from abroad due to the country's small population and low e-waste volume. Despite having a capacity to process 14 tonnes of lithium-ion batteries per day, only 30% of batteries from communications devices and 20% of electric vehicle batteries come from Singapore sources. Local companies like TES and Se-cure Waste Management are importing spent batteries from markets such as China, Thailand, and Indonesia to meet their operational needs. However, there is guarded optimism that the sector could expand as Singapore aims to electrify its fleet and increase e-waste recycling rates.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Palmer (left) and Bryan Oh of NEU Battery Materials with the battery-grade lithium hydroxide from recycling batteries.
An excavator loads raw nickel ore into a dump truck at a nickel mining site of Vale in Sorowako, South Sulawesi province, Indonesia, March 29, 2023.
Apple is pushing to become carbon neutral through its entire supply chain and the life cycle of every product by 2030.

site_title: Biden admin supports Mountain Valley Pipeline for second time in week
summary: The Biden administration has supported the Mountain Valley natural gas pipeline for the second time in a week, despite opposition from environmental activists. The US$6.6 billion project, which would unlock gas supplies from Appalachia, has won backing from Secretary of Energy Jennifer Granholm, who emphasized the need for energy security. The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) has issued a Record of Decision, moving forward with the project's next step, pending remaining federal and state permits. The pipeline's approval is seen as a key step in Senator Joe Manchin's bill to speed fossil fuel and transmission line projects.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Lengths of pipe wait to be laid in the ground along the under-construction Mountain Valley Pipeline near Elliston, Virginia, U.S. September 29, 2019. Picture taken September 29, 2019. REUTERS/Charles Mostoller/File Photo

site_title: China appoints Li Yunze as director of new financial regulatory body
summary: China has appointed Li Yunze as the director of its National Financial Regulatory Administration (NFRA), a new government body tasked with overseeing the multi-trillion dollar financial industry. Li, a former deputy governor of Sichuan province, aims to eliminate regulatory gaps. Deputy directors Cao Yu, Zhou Liang, Xiao Yuanqi, and Cong Lin were also named, with the four previously serving as vice chairmen of the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission. The NFRA replaces the CBIRC and absorbs supervisory functions from the central bank and securities regulator.

site_title: India regulator 'draws a blank' in foreign links probe into Adani, shares rise
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has failed to find evidence of wrongdoing by Adani Group, despite a multi-agency investigation into foreign links and suspected securities law breaches. The group's shares rose 1.2-7% after a court-appointed panel found that SEBI's suspicion of "opaque" structures and unclear ownership chains was unfounded. The panel noted that tracing the ultimate beneficial owner of foreign investments could be a "journey without a destination" due to the complexity of the issue.

images.alt_text: Adani's shares climbed 5.1 per cent after the earnings were announced which showed gross debt paring to 383.2 billion rupees from 410 billion rupees last year.

site_title: Fujitsu General’s US$1.1 billion stake sale said to stall
summary: Fujitsu General's US$1.1 billion stake sale has stalled due to disagreements between bidders and the Japanese firm. The sale of 42% stake in its air-conditioner manufacturing unit has been unable to agree on a price. A recent rise in Fujitsu General's shares has weighed on negotiations, causing the stock to slump 10.3% in Tokyo. The stake's value is now around US$1.1 billion, valuing the company at approximately S$3.46 billion. The stalled sale has raised concerns about the company's future plans.

images.alt_text: Fujitsu’s business now increasingly caters to a growing number of Japanese companies embracing more digital workflows to keep pace with technological shifts.

site_title: Netflix, Amazon addiction turns into ‘digital deficit’ for Japan and hassle for the yen
summary: Japan's "digital deficit" has increased to 4.8 trillion yen (S$48.7 billion) in 2022, largely due to payments to overseas technology companies like Netflix and Amazon. This deficit, which accounts for almost 90% of Japan's services account deficit, is expected to pressure the local currency. The growing demand for home entertainment during the pandemic has driven this trend, with these companies expected to see their outgoings climb even if their market share remains unchanged.

images.alt_text: The rise in April, the start of Japan’s new business year when many firms tend to modify retail prices, suggests heightening price pressures may keep inflation above the Bank of Japan’s 2 per cent target longer than expected, analysts say.
Netflix launched a US$7-per-month ad-supported tier in November in 12 markets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Shares in Unusual have risen 10% in May, driven by the success of Jacky Cheung's concerts. Concerts in Singapore have seen a resurgence, with demand surpassing pre-pandemic levels. Thermo Fisher Scientific launched a new sterile drug facility in Singapore, completing the country's end-to-end vaccine manufacturing chain. A US-Singapore digital payment trial showed potential with distributed ledger technology, and Singapore e-waste recyclers are meeting high demand abroad. GIC partnered with Brookfield to acquire Indian commercial assets worth $1.4 billion, while Singapore shares rose 0.63% on upbeat US macro data and easing debt concerns.

site_title: Issue 50: Banks walk different paths to net-zero oil; coal programme under fire
summary: Singapore's three banks - OCBC, DBS, and UOB - have taken different approaches to decarbonizing their financed emissions in the oil and gas sector, reflecting the complexity of addressing climate change. OCBC has set comprehensive and ambitious targets, including Scope 3 emissions, while DBS has focused on a "just transition" and UOB has committed to stopping new upstream project financing. The banks' policies differ on whether to focus upstream or downstream, with DBS including downstream companies in its targets and UOB excluding them. The lack of consensus highlights the need for better data and system-wide shifts to effectively decarbonize the oil and gas sector.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim

OCBC's chief executive officer Helen Wong (middle), head of global whole banking Tan Teck Long (left) and head of global wholesale banking sustainability office Mike Ng (right) announcing the bank's decarbonisation targets on May 16, 2023.
Dr Amy Khor, Senior Minister of State of the Ministry of Sustainability and the Environment & Ministry of Transport, speaks about energy efficiency.
An initial investment plan detailing how Indonesia will green its power supply and cut greenhouse emissions is due mid-August.
Pulp producer Asia Symbol will benefit from lower interest rates if it meets specific key performance indicators in the next three years.
“Goldman Sachs cutting Adani group stakes from ESG funds and Adani Group companies now seeking to raise capital are two entirely separate events,” a spokesperson for Adani says.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange to roll out new dual counter model in June
summary: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) plans to launch a new dual counter trading model on June 19, allowing investors to trade securities in both Hong Kong dollar and renminbi (RMB) counters. The model aims to increase liquidity and reduce price differences between the two currencies. The move is expected to support the internationalisation of the RMB and provide more choices for issuers and investors. Several major companies, including Ping An Insurance Group and Tencent, have already submitted applications for dual currency counters.

images.alt_text: Signage for Hong Kong Stock Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx) during the listing ceremony of ZJLD Group Inc. at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, April 27, 2023. Shares of Chinese liquor company ZJLD tumbled on their debut in Hong Kong on Thursday following what was the Asian financial hub’s biggest initial public offering this year. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
IPO applicants will also have to disclose material ESG information in their prospectuses.

site_title: Tycoons’ bids value “Google of Russia” at US$7 billion
summary: Yandex, Russia's dominant search engine, has received bids from billionaires Vladimir Potanin and Vagit Alekperov to buy a controlling stake in its Russian business valued at around $7 billion. The bids seek at least a 51% stake in Yandex's Russian assets, which include a popular ride-hailing app and ecommerce platform. The company's board is set to discuss the bids next week, with no final decision expected. Yandex's Dutch domicile has attracted a Kremlin-mandated 50% discount for foreign companies exiting Russia.

site_title: Singapore firms should be aware of opportunities in Africa, ‘break new ground’: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urges businesses to explore opportunities in Africa, citing the continent's vibrancy and desire for relationships with Singapore. Despite risks, he notes that ventures can succeed with a focus on stable societies and political systems. He encourages companies to "break new ground" and points to South Africa and Kenya as examples of opportunities, citing existing Singaporean firms that have grown and prospered in these countries. The government plans to continue nudging relations with African countries to ease conditions for local businesses.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at a welcome ceremony at Tuynhuys, South Africa’s presidential office, with South African President Cyril Ramaphosa on May 16.

site_title: BT Market Focus: US, Japan and China take spotlight along with local earnings (Ep 44)
summary: US, Japan, and China markets took center stage this week, alongside local earnings in Singapore. The episode, part of the 'BT Market Focus' podcast, analyzed market drivers and movements. SGX's wrap for the week was discussed, along with insights from The Business Times' newsdesk and a breakdown of macroeconomic news. Earnings highlights were also covered, featuring analysis from SGX Securities and the newsdesk.

images.alt_text: Inflation data still wreaking havoc in the markets?
Find out what data domintaed markets this week.

site_title: Boom time for organisers as concerts roar back to life
summary: Concerts in Singapore have experienced a booming revival since Covid-19 restrictions were lifted, with demand surging past pre-pandemic levels. Ticket sales for concerts organized by Unusual have more than doubled, with some events selling out instantly. The surge in demand is attributed to pent-up desire for live shows and the unique experience they offer. Despite rising ticket prices, concert organizers are expected to enjoy huge growth and pricing power, with some predicting a huge recovery in revenue. Companies like Unusual and GHY Culture and Media are benefiting from the resumption of concerts, with increased revenue and profitability anticipated.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Cinemas here are tapping growing demand for premium experiences: screening formats such as Imax and 3D, as well as luxurious viewing environments.
Melvin Ang, mm2 Asia executive chairman, noted that demand for live events in Asia has grown "significantly" in recent years.
Singapore Repertory Theatre's open-air production of A Midsummer Night’s Dream reimagines Shakespeare’s enchanted forest as “an inverted industrial-chic set with lots of water”.

site_title: Managing aspirations and expectations
summary: Singapore's property market continues to show resilience despite higher additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rates. Two new launches, Blossoms by the Park and The Continuum, sold 202 and 216 units respectively at launch, with average prices of S$2,423 and S$2,732 per square foot. Baseline demand remains strong, driven by local buyers' aspirations to own private property. The government's "Singaporeans first" policy aims to refocus the market on domestic demand, potentially deterring foreign buyers.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low
BT's Property Insights newsletter.

site_title: Vietnam starts planned blackouts as heat stretches grid
summary: Vietnam is experiencing power shortages in some areas through May 25 due to a severe heat wave and drought, which reduced water levels in hydropower reservoirs. The country has begun planned nationwide blackouts, with outages lasting up to 7 hours in some areas. The disruptions are expected to affect most of the country, including the capital Hanoi, as the nation struggles to meet surging power demand.

images.alt_text: Vietnam aims to become a developed and high-income nation by 2050 with economic growth based on science, technology, innovation and digital transformation.
“The State Bank of Vietnam will continue to closely monitor the economic situation, and will cut its policy rates in case of favourable conditions,” governor Nguyen Thi Hong says.

site_title: Alibaba breakup begins with spinoff of US$12 billion cloud arm
summary: Alibaba Group Holding is breaking up, starting with the spinoff of its $12 billion cloud arm, Cainiao, and the listing of its grocery arm, Freshippo, within six months. The move aims to simplify the structure and respond to market needs, as the company faces anemic revenue growth and a slowdown in China's consumer spending. The breakup is part of a larger restructuring plan, which includes the dispatch of half of Alibaba's investment team to the six different business units. The cloud spinoff is intended to attract external financing and potentially surpass Alibaba in size, but analysts question its viability given Beijing's emphasis on government-controlled data storage and internet services.

images.alt_text: Alibaba's revenue for the full year climbs 2 per cent to 868.69 billion yuan, marking its slowest rate of growth since the company went public in 2014.
Ant is waiting for a financial holding company licence, more than two years after authorities torpedoed its planned initial public offering.
Meituan has been hiring aggressively in preparation for its debut in Hong Kong for months.
Cloud services only represent “a mid single digit percentage” of Tencent’s total revenue, chief strategy officer James Mitchell says.
Platforms like Amazon, Alibaba or Zalando would have to ensure goods sold online comply with all customs obligations.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts positive on Grab after losses shrink in Q1
summary: Analysts remain positive on Grab's prospects for achieving profitability in the near term, citing an easing competitive landscape. Despite a Q1 loss of $250 million, Grab's financial results beat expectations, with analysts raising their target prices to $3.07 and $4.50. However, Grab's valuation is seen as difficult to sustain due to its high revenue multiples. Analysts project a 15% compound annual growth rate in gross merchandise value and 13% normalized Ebitda margins for Grab's on-demand business.

images.alt_text: Grab logo.

site_title: The dangers of pandemic amnesia
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared an end to the Covid-19 emergency, but case numbers have resurged in parts of Asia. Experts warn of "pandemic amnesia" as people become less vigilant about safety measures, with over 35% of Singaporeans showing no intention of taking additional vaccinations. The economic cost of the pandemic is estimated to be between 0.6-1.6% of annual GDP, with indirect costs accounting for 96% of the total costs. Governments must balance their books by increasing revenues and making significant fiscal adjustments to address long-term challenges and prevent over-reaction to future outbreaks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A medical worker administers a dose of the "Cominarty" Pfizer-Bivalent coronavirus disease (COVID-19) vaccine to a patient at a vaccination center in Nice as a new surge in the COVID-19 outbreak starts in France, December 7, 2022. REUTERS/Eric Gaillard/File Photo
South Korea on Thursday lowered its crisis level for Covid-19 and will from June no longer require infected people to quarantine for seven days.

site_title: Tokyo stocks extend rally as Nikkei 225 reaches 1990 high
summary: Tokyo stocks surged, with the Nikkei 225 reaching its highest level in nearly 33 years at 30,808.35. The blue-chip gauge advanced 0.8% on optimism the US will avoid default, fueling a bullish sentiment. The Topix also reached a 33-year high, gaining 0.2%, driven by electronics makers and service-sector firms. Strategists attribute the rally to corporate governance reforms and loose monetary policy, with Morgan Stanley forecasting a potential 9% increase in the Topix.

images.alt_text: epa10253755 A stock market indicator board displays the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average figures in Tokyo, Japan, 20 October 2022. Tokyo stocks lost more than 300 points in the morning trading session following overnight fall at Wall Street.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

site_title: South Korean nurses strike after president vetoes Bill on pay, working conditions
summary: Thousands of South Korean nurses went on strike after President Yoon Suk Yeol vetoed a law to improve their pay and working conditions. The Korean Nurses Association denounced Yoon, claiming he abandoned his promise as a presidential candidate to improve nurses' conditions. The strike was largely limited, with most protesters using holiday time or shortened business hours. The government urged medical facilities to monitor the situation to prevent the strike from affecting patients.

images.alt_text: South Korea on Thursday lowered its crisis level for Covid-19 and will from June no longer require infected people to quarantine for seven days.

site_title: A continued focus on fixed income versus equities
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised the federal funds rate 25 basis points to a target range of 5.00-5.25% in May, indicating the end of the tightening cycle for some time. The Fed has moved into restrictive territory to achieve its 2% inflation target, but economic slack is building, and lending conditions are tightening. Fixed income markets offer good opportunities for diversification, particularly in investment-grade corporate credit and US Treasuries, as equities are expected to be flat or slightly negative due to slower economic growth and higher costs.

images.alt_text: SGX Group CEO Loh Boon Chye believes the overall business will be much stronger when markets turn more conducive.
FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., November 11, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
Stubbornly high inflation and aggressive central bank action could lead to stagflation and erode the safety offered by long-term sovereign bonds.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.2% to 3,190.28. Gainers outnumbered losers 60 to 47, with top-traded counters including Genting Singapore and Marco Polo Marine. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also opened in positive territory. The global markets were boosted by better-than-expected results from Walmart and optimism over artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: DFI retail, which reported a "significantly improved" performance for Q1 2023, is a subsidiary of Jardine Matheson Holdings, which also announced a “strong overall performance” in the first quarter of the year ended March.

site_title: Chinese buyers return to resurgent Australian property market
summary: Chinese buyers are returning to the Australian property market, driven by rising rents, limited supply, and population growth. Buyer inquiries from China increased 127% in the first quarter of 2023 compared to the previous year, with forecasts predicting a 30% increase in Chinese investment this year. This surge is expected to add pressure on prices, particularly in luxury housing, with luxury apartments selling for over A$100 million. Australia's improved relations with China and its appeal as a safe and environmentally clean destination are contributing to the return of big-spending foreign buyers.

images.alt_text: The budget’s build-to-rent proposals apply to projects of 50 or more apartments or dwellings made available for rent to the general public.

site_title: Nike removes Ja Morant signature shoe from site, app
summary: Nike has removed Ja Morant's signature shoe, the Ja 1, from its website and app following the Memphis Grizzlies' suspension of the 23-year-old player due to a video showing him holding a gun. This is Morant's second suspension for the same reason in two months. The move also appears to impact his endorsement relationship with Powerade, which has stopped running any Ja-related content. The shoes were still available at Dick's Sporting Goods and secondary reseller StockX, but their availability has now been removed from Finish Line stores and apps.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Nike swoosh logo is seen outside the store on 5th Ave in New York, New York, U.S., March 19, 2019.   REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: Gold’s shine is a mirage
summary: Gold's recent price surge is misleading, as its long-term returns are lower than those of stocks and bonds. Individual investors may benefit from gold's volatility, but timing is crucial, as gains can be sporadic with long stagnations and declines in between. Historically, gold's returns are positive in only about half of rolling 12-month periods, while US stocks have risen 81% in the same periods. The article argues that gold is not a reliable hedge against inflation or bear markets, and its fluctuations are largely driven by sentiment swings rather than fundamental value.

images.alt_text: While gold is considered a hedge against inflation, rising interest rates dull non-yielding bullion’s appeal.

site_title: Singapore-US digital cross-border payment trial shows potential, but scaling up needed
summary: A digital payment experiment between Singapore and the US, led by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has shown that distributed ledger technology can improve the efficiency of cross-border payments. The trial, which used simulated wholesale CBDCs, completed payments in under 30 seconds, compared to the two-day period it usually takes for illiquid currencies. While the results show potential, scaling up the technology to handle large volumes of transactions is needed, and further exploration is required to determine its viability.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The central banks of 5 South-east Asia countries, including Bank Negara Malaysia will be running tests of Nexus cross-border transactions on a larger scale.
China has been a leader among countries that are developing the CBDC – digital tokens issued by central banks, although adoption is still in the early stages.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine Matheson, Hongkong Land, DFI Retail, NetLink, Sembcorp
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a "strong overall performance" in Q1, but warned of challenges from the global economic environment. Hongkong Land's underlying profit fell due to reduced sales from its development properties business. DFI Retail Group showed significantly improved year-on-year performance, while NetLink NBN Trust reported a 6.9% increase in earnings. Sembcorp Industries announced plans to develop a new multi-utilities centre, estimated to cost S$900 million.

site_title: Oil prices settle down 1%; strong US data boosts dollar
summary: Oil prices fell about 1% on Thursday due to strong US economic data and a rising dollar, which can reduce oil demand. The US dollar reached a two-month high, with Brent futures falling $1.10 to $75.86 a barrel and WTI crude falling 97 cents to $71.86 a barrel. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates again in June, and a stronger dollar can weigh on oil demand.

The crude inventory build added to concerns about US growth after data showed retail sales rose 0.4 per cent in April, short of estimates for an increase of 0.8 per cent.

site_title: Frencken Q1 earnings down 59.5% to S$5.2 million amid ‘steep’ industry downturn
summary: Frencken Group reported a 59.5% decline in net profit to S$5.2 million in Q1 FY2023, due to a "steep cyclical downturn" in the semiconductor industry and global economic uncertainties. Revenue fell 13% year-over-year to S$172.5 million, with a decline in the mechatronics division. The company attributed the decline to lower sales in Asia operations offset by stronger sales in Europe. The semiconductor industry's downturn is expected to continue, posing a challenge to technology sector businesses.

Frencken is guiding for lower revenue in its semiconductor, medical, and industrial automation segments.

site_title: Apple, Samsung looking to expand in India, says minister
summary: Apple and Samsung are expanding their presence in India, driven by the country's financial incentives for smartphone manufacturing. The government's $2 billion plan aims to boost local output of laptops, servers, and other electronics. India's success in the smartphone segment has attracted interest from companies like Apple and Samsung, which export billions of dollars of handsets from the country. The government also plans to attract chip fabrication and packaging plants to India, with billionaire Anil Agarwal's $19 billion plan underway. This expansion is part of India's push to challenge China as a manufacturing hub.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS nearly halves Manulife US Reit’s target to US$0.24, maintains ‘buy’
summary: DBS Group Research lowered its target price for Manulife US Reit to US$0.24, a 46.7% decrease from US$0.45, while maintaining a "buy" rating. The analysts cited the Reit's high leverage of 49.5% as a concern, but suggested a capital injection could ease gearing woes. The new target represents a 70.2% upside from the current trading price.

images.alt_text: With the Reit’s portfolio having a weighted average lease expiry (WALE) of five years, its manager expects positive rental reversion for 2023.

site_title: Japan’s consumer inflation stays above central bank target as price hikes broaden
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 3.4% in April, exceeding the Bank of Japan's 2% target, as price hikes broadened. The increase accelerated from a 3.1% rise in March, casting doubt on the central bank's view that inflation will slow later this year. Analysts suggest that heightening price pressures may keep inflation above the target longer than expected, potentially prolonging the inflationary period.

images.alt_text: Genesia Ventures Team

Japan is among the world’s fastest ageing societies, with the annual number of newborns falling below 800,000 for the first time, having previously peaked at 2.09 million in 1973 during the second baby boom.

epa10253755 A stock market indicator board displays the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average figures in Tokyo, Japan, 20 October 2022. Tokyo stocks lost more than 300 points in the morning trading session following overnight fall at Wall Street.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON
Japan is bolstering advanced chipmaking at home for cutting-edge chips amid growing US-China tensions and as concern grows about over-reliance on Taiwan.
Exports slumped 4.2 per cent in January-March, the first decline in six quarters.

site_title: US: Stocks finish higher on Walmart earnings, AI optimism
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the S&P 500 gaining 0.9% to 4,198.05 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing up 0.3% to 33,535.91. Walmart's better-than-expected earnings and optimism over artificial intelligence (AI) drove the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index up 1.5%. Optimism also surrounds talks to lift US borrowing limits, with Republican House speaker Kevin McCarthy suggesting a vote could be possible as early as next week. However, investors remain cautious due to concerns over debt ceiling talks and interest-rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 10, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: GIC to jointly acquire commercial assets in India at enterprise value of US$1.4 billion
summary: GIC, in partnership with Brookfield India Real Estate Trust, will acquire two commercial assets in India valued at US$1.4 billion. The assets, totaling 6.5 million square feet, are located in Mumbai and Gurugram. This is the first joint venture of its kind involving a listed REIT and a global institutional investor. GIC expects growth in India's office sector, driven by the country's IT industry and digital adoption. The acquisition adds to GIC's global office portfolio diversification.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Messer, which is based on the outskirts of Frankfurt, has been under family control for 125 years.

The Ho Chi Minh City-headquartered company, whose businesses include online games, payment, cloud services and the country’s most popular messaging app Zalo, is working with Maybank on the fundraising.

site_title: If your city is sinking, why not make it float?
summary: Floating cities may be a viable solution for sinking megacities, with over 40.5 million people already displaced due to the climate crisis. Engineering solutions like pontoon structures and semi-submersible structures can support floating cities, but they must be designed with sustainability and minimal ecological impact in mind. The Oceanix Busan prototype, set to begin construction in 2023, aims to create a zero-waste, closed-loop system with clean energy and habitat regeneration. However, concerns remain about shading, light pollution, and potential impacts on marine life, requiring further research and careful planning.

images.alt_text: Artist’s impression of climate-resilient nearshore urban developments or “floating cities”, which Keppel Land is exploring in collaboration with other Keppel business units.
Keppel working on project to explore floating city in Singapore

The new Presidential Palace under construction in Nusantara. Located in eastern Borneo – the world's third-largest island – Nusantara is set to replace sinking and polluted Jakarta as Indonesia's political centre by late 2024.
99 of 100 cities most at risk environmentally in Asia

site_title: UK unveils £1 billion semiconductor strategy
summary: The UK has unveiled a £1 billion semiconductor strategy to invest in infrastructure, research, and security, aiming to diversify its chip supply chain. The 20-year plan includes £200 million in investments between now and 2025, focusing on design, R&D, and compound semiconductors. The strategy aims to safeguard supply chains from disruption and protect tech against national security risks. The move comes as European carmakers, including Stellantis, have expressed concerns about Brexit trade rules affecting battery supply for electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: British households have been grappling with high inflation which was running at 10.1 per cent in March with the cost of food and drinks surging by the most since 1977.

Customers use the automated teller machines (ATMs) at a bank branch of Lloyds Banking Group Plc in London, U.K., on Monday, Feb. 18, 2019. Lloyds, along with Barclays Plc and HSBC Holdings Plc, will report earnings this week. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
TThe group’s total number of workers would reduce from 130,000 to between 75,000 and 90,000 by its 2030 financial year at the latest.

site_title: US existing home sales post second straight monthly decline
summary: US existing home sales declined for a second consecutive month in April, falling 3.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.28 million units. Home resale plummeted 23.2% year-over-year, while median existing house prices dropped 1.7% to $388,800. Tightening credit conditions and shortages of building materials are hindering new home construction, contributing to the housing market's struggles.

images.alt_text: After dropping to a low of more than 40 per cent last year, the recent rally in homebuilders represents a massive rebound from last June’s slump.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rally on US debt deal hope
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday as traders became increasingly hopeful that US lawmakers will reach a deal to lift the debt ceiling, averting a potential default. Tokyo surged, building on recent gains in the Nikkei, while Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, and other markets also rose. Congressional leaders are reportedly close to a proposal, with Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy expressing optimism about a potential agreement. The positive sentiment was fueled by the prospect of avoiding a calamitous default, which could have significant economic implications.

images.alt_text: epa10253755 A stock market indicator board displays the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average figures in Tokyo, Japan, 20 October 2022. Tokyo stocks lost more than 300 points in the morning trading session following overnight fall at Wall Street.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON
Tokyo and Hong Kong each piled on more than one per cent, while there were also healthy gains in Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila, Taipei and Wellington.

site_title: The shape of things to come
summary: New home sales in April saw a 80% increase from March, with 887 units sold, the highest in seven months. Pricing at the top of the market is softening, and take-up at new launches is now price-sensitive. Foreign buying of private homes reached a five-year high in Q1, but is expected to slow down due to the higher additional buyer's stamp duty for foreigners. Developers may face pressure to lower prices to close the gap in sales.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low

In the UK, more than a third of fixed-rate mortgages on rental properties – known as buy-to-let – are due to end in the next two years, leaving landlords vulnerable to the highest interest rates since 2008.
The highest number of super-prime deals took place in the borough of Kensington, with 26 properties sold.
The Property Insights newsletter will be produced by deputy news editor Michelle Low and senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

site_title: Australian dollar testing lows, kiwi gains as rate hike looms
summary: The Australian dollar reached a three-week low at US$0.6605, and the kiwi gained 0.7% on the week as investors reduced expectations for Australian interest rate hikes. The Aussie's decline is attributed to unexpectedly falling employment data in April, which may signal a cooling labor market. In contrast, New Zealand's interest rate hike next week is expected to boost the kiwi. Analysts predict a 25 basis point hike in New Zealand, while the Aussie is expected to end the quarter at US$0.64.

images.alt_text: Albert Park’s comments come amid growing signs that China’s post-Covid economic recovery is losing steam, intensifying pressure on policymakers to shore up wobbly growth.
Customers in Australia can still transact using credit or debit cards, Binance said.
The US dollar index firms 0.3 per cent to 103.17, its highest level since Mar 27.

site_title: Disney to yank shows from streaming service in savings push
summary: Disney plans to remove up to 90 unrenewed programs from its Disney+ streaming service, citing a need to reduce losses and make the service profitable. The move is part of a broader effort to cut spending, with CEO Bob Iger aiming to reduce costs by up to $3 billion. The company will write off up to $1.8 billion in programming costs in 2023. Notable shows set to be removed include "Big Shot" and "The Mysterious Benedict Society." Disney aims to reach profitability for Disney+ by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: Peltz-owned Trian Fund Management has purchased roughly 500,000 more Walt Disney shares since the end of March, giving it a total of 6.4 million.
The total subscribers to Disney+ dropped by 4 million to 157.8 million.
That path to success is hard to find in today’s Hollywood, the writers say.

site_title: US and Taiwan conclude trade negotiations
summary: The US and Taiwan have concluded trade negotiations under the US-Taiwan Initiative on 21st-Century Trade, aiming to deepen economic ties and boost trade. The agreement aims to streamline customs checks, improve regulatory procedures, and establish anticorruption measures. US Trade Representative Katherine Tai described the agreement as a "step forward" in strengthening the US-Taiwan economic relationship. The deal is seen as a rare bipartisan agreement, despite growing tensions between the US and China, which claims Taiwan as its territory. The agreement still needs to be signed by both sides.

images.alt_text: UBS Taiwan’s wealth management business is hoping to achieve double-digit revenue growth this year, in line with business expectations.
Polls commissioned by the KMT, as well as surveys conducted by other organisations, show Hou Yu-ih had a better shot at winning than Foxconn founder Terry Gou, who was also in the fray.

The choice of Hou Yu-ih over Foxconn Technology Group founder Terry Gou (above), is due to his strength in opinion polls and broader support among lawmakers and local government leaders, the source says.

site_title: China’s Xi unveils grand development plan for Central Asia
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping unveiled a grand development plan for Central Asia, aiming to foster a new paradigm of win-win cooperation with Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. The plan includes building infrastructure and boosting trade, with the goal of modernizing all six countries. This marks a new leadership role for China in the region, traditionally influenced by Russia. Xi emphasized the importance of regional peace and stability, stating that the summit has added new impetus to the region's development and revitalization.

images.alt_text: Alibaba shares closed 5.4 per cent lower at US$85.77 in New York.
Albert Park’s comments come amid growing signs that China’s post-Covid economic recovery is losing steam, intensifying pressure on policymakers to shore up wobbly growth.

site_title: In Twitter case, US Supreme Court protects companies from terrorism lawsuits
summary: The US Supreme Court has ruled 9-0 in favor of Twitter, protecting the social media company from terrorism lawsuits. The justices reversed a lower court's ruling that revived a lawsuit by the American relatives of a Jordanian man killed in an ISIS attack during a 2017 New Year's celebration in Istanbul. The court's decision sidesteps a bid to weaken legal protections for internet firms, allowing Twitter to continue its stance that allowing lawsuits would threaten its liability for providing services to billions of users.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ Linda Yaccarino in New York on May 11, 2017. Yaccarino is is set to become the new chief executive of Twitter. (Tawni Bannister/The New York Times)

site_title: UK consumers turn more confident despite inflation pain: GfK
summary: British consumer confidence has risen for the fourth consecutive month, reaching its highest in 15 months, despite high inflation at 10.1% in March. The GfK headline confidence index rose to -27 in May, surpassing forecasts. Households are taking a more positive view of the economy, with measures of consumer sentiment edging up. However, experts caution that the economic outlook remains uncertain, and households should remain cautious.

images.alt_text: Customers use the automated teller machines (ATMs) at a bank branch of Lloyds Banking Group Plc in London, U.K., on Monday, Feb. 18, 2019. Lloyds, along with Barclays Plc and HSBC Holdings Plc, will report earnings this week. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

In the UK, more than a third of fixed-rate mortgages on rental properties – known as buy-to-let – are due to end in the next two years, leaving landlords vulnerable to the highest interest rates since 2008.

site_title: Twitter says Microsoft broke its rules for developers
summary: Twitter accused Microsoft of breaking its rules for developers who access Twitter data, citing potential "abusive usage" and violating the "reasonable request volume." Microsoft stopped accessing Twitter data in April after refusing to pay fees for APIs. Twitter demands Microsoft identify all controlled content from the past two years and provide details on storage and usage. This comes as Elon Musk seeks to generate revenue by charging developers for Twitter access, and as Microsoft invests in AI technology rivaling Twitter's own efforts.

site_title: New Indiana Jones director gives ‘best version’ of Spielberg
summary: New Indiana Jones director James Mangold says he aimed to deliver the "best version" of Steven Spielberg's iconic films, with the fifth installment, "Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny," premiering at the Cannes Film Festival. Mangold, who has directed films like "Girl, Interrupted" and "Logan," said he emulated his mentor while still bringing his own style to the story. The film features Harrison Ford, 80, in a role that explores themes of aging, regret, and choice, and has received praise from Spielberg, who called it a "really, really good" film.

images.alt_text: Around a thousand police and security guards are in place for the festival, which has been held under a heightened security alert ever since a wave of terror attacks in France in the 2010s.
Guardians had unseated Universal’s The Super Mario Bros Movie from the top spot the week before.
Return to Seoul follows Freddie (Park Ji-Min), a Korean-born French adoptee who returns to her homeland in search of her biological parents.

site_title: Nadal to miss French Open, says 2024 likely to be last year of his career
summary: Rafael Nadal will miss the French Open due to a hip injury, which he suffered at the Australian Open in January. He believes 2024 may be his final year of professional tennis career. Nadal, a 14-time Roland Garros winner, aims to regain full fitness by next year but won't set a specific return date, instead opting to monitor his body's response. He hopes to return until the end of the year for the Davis Cup, but it's unclear if he'll be able to play the tournaments he wants to end his career with.

site_title: How smart cars are upending China’s auto supply chain
summary: China's auto industry supply chain is undergoing a significant overhaul as the country's electric vehicle (EV) penetration rate continues to rise. The industry is shifting towards a smart car era, where automakers need to jointly develop systems with chip and software suppliers. This has led to the emergence of new-energy vehicle manufacturers and the rise of domestic semiconductors. Foreign suppliers, such as Bosch and ZF, are also investing in China to capture the smart-car market. The cost of smart driving solutions is decreasing, with prices falling by up to 60% in the past year. As competition intensifies, cost control will be a key factor in the industry's survival.

images.alt_text: To draw back talent, Hong Kong has rolled out a special visa programme, which has hooked tens of thousands of applicants.

A clerk from ICBC bank counts Chinese banknotes in Beijing. China's six biggest state lenders saw growth in net profits slump to 6.7 per cent on average last year, about half the pace of 12.7 per cent in 2021.
China's artficial intelligence industry is dealing with a shortage of both talent and chips as companies seek to meet growing demand.

Startups don’t need to build models and should instead focus on developing applications, where “brand new entrepreneurial opportunities that are 10 times greater than WeChat and Douyin will emerge,” says Baidu CEO Robin Li.

site_title: Montana TikTok ban unrealistic and misguided: experts
summary: Montana has become the first US state to ban TikTok, set to take effect in 2024, amid concerns over the app's security and potential ties to the Chinese government. However, experts argue that the ban is unrealistic and technically impossible, as users can easily access the app through virtual private networks (VPNs). The law faces a likely court challenge, with advocates arguing that it violates fundamental free speech laws and is motivated by a lack of understanding of TikTok's culture.

images.alt_text: tiktok Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
TikTok's new programme will help students gain a deeper understanding in coding languages, tech architecture, server management, quality assurance and site reliability.
ByteDance responded to the scraping allegations, saying it acquired data in line with industry practice and its global policy.
The European Union on April 25, 2023 designated 19 online platforms, including Instagram, TikTok and Twitter, as having user numbers so big they will come under stricter regulatory rules for content.

site_title: New York’s record-breaking rents squeeze tenants across boroughs
summary: New York City's median rent has reached a record high of $4,241 in Manhattan, an 8.1% increase from last year and $66 more than the previous record in March. The surge is attributed to landlords cutting incentives and pushing up prices, affecting tenants across boroughs. The data shows a significant squeeze on tenants, with no bargains available, as landlords take advantage of the strong market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb on US debt ceiling optimism
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by optimism over a potential US debt ceiling deal, with Germany's DAX index hitting its highest level in over a year. Automobiles and technology stocks led the gains, while France's CAC 40 and Italy's FTSE MIB also rose. A media report suggested House Speaker Kevin McCarthy may reach a deal to raise or suspend the debt ceiling by next week, alleviating concerns about a potential financial shock.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 gained 0.9 per cent to 4,198.05, while The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.3 per cent to 33,535.91 on Thursday.

site_title: Amid funding winter, Japan’s Genesia Ventures bucks the trend
summary: Japan's Genesia Ventures has bucked the trend of a funding winter, closing its third fund at 15 billion yen (S$146.4 million) exceeding its target of 12 billion yen. The venture capital firm, which has invested in over 140 startups across Japan and South-east Asia, attributes its consistent investment pace to "disciplined investors with a defined set of investment principles." Despite a global funding squeeze, Genesia Ventures remains committed to its mission of "building a platform that creates sustainable industries in Asia."

images.alt_text: Since fundraising from established foreign funds faced rocky path amid global economic distress, local venture capital firms took the lead to provide growth capital for Vietnamese early-stage startup

site_title: Singapore’s world-class gastro cred imperiled by staffing woes
summary: Singapore's reputation as a gastronomic hub is threatened due to staffing woes, exacerbated by rising rents, ingredient costs, and tightened labor laws. The government's policies, including hiring quotas and minimum salary increases, have worsened the labor shortage. Restaurants are forced to cut corners or close, with some owners considering reducing staff, sourcing cheaper ingredients, and increasing prices, which may alienate long-term customers. The industry's future is uncertain, and the government is urged to reconsider its policies to support the sector.

images.alt_text: Merry-makers and live music fans came out in full force at Clarke Quay on Saturday, 2 April 2022, with many excited to welcome the end of a two-year ban on live music at food and beverage (F&B) outlets due to Covid-19.The relaxed measures — which allowed live performances to resume, and alcohol to be served past 10:30pm — were relaxed on March 29.
Chaleur's calm, bright, neutral toned interiors.

NODX to China contributes the most to the overall decline in shipments to Singapore’s top 10 markets in April.

site_title: Blackstone’s new credit fund struggles to lure Europe’s rich
summary: Blackstone's new European credit fund, ECRED, has struggled to attract investors, raising only €240 million (S$348.7 million) six months after its launch, compared to $12 billion for its US equivalent, BCRED. The firm's efforts to tap into Europe's estimated $50 trillion wealth pool have been hindered by risk-averse investors preferring conservative investments like insurance products and real estate. ECRED's limited liquidity and high-risk nature have also raised concerns among investors, with some questioning the suitability of the fund for non-professional investors.

images.alt_text: The disclosure sheds light on how much competition exists for assets of collapsed banks.

In an undated image provided by The Related Companies, a rendering of the proposed stadium development at Willets Point. site_title: Making the transition to governance for good
summary: Boards and organizations must reframe their roles to prioritize long-term value beyond financial returns. Stakeholder capitalism emphasizes customer value, people value, and societal value, requiring a strong focus on ethical, responsible, and sustainable decision-making. To achieve this, boards should define and embed their organization's purpose, integrate ESG considerations into their agenda, and ensure sufficient time for sustainability matters. Additionally, boards must be diverse, authentic in their disclosures, and hold management accountable for creating long-term value. This approach not only benefits the planet and society but also makes good business sense, as companies that prioritize sustainability are more likely to report higher-than-expected financial value.

images.alt_text: As the apex body, the board sets the tone for corporate morality by encouraging and reinforcing moral reasoning and behaviour. PHOTO:
Stakeholder capitalism places attention on all private actors in society.

site_title: Singapore and Kenya sign three new deals on sustainability, skills development, digital economy
summary: Singapore and Kenya signed three agreements on sustainability, skills development, and the digital economy, marking a significant boost to bilateral relations between the two countries. The agreements include a bilateral investment treaty and an avoidance of double taxation agreement, as well as memoranda of understanding (MOUs) on climate change, cybersecurity, and skills development. The partnerships aim to promote trade, investment, and cooperation in areas such as technology, education, and environmental sustainability. Both leaders expressed their commitment to strengthening ties and exploring opportunities for growth, despite geographical distance and global challenges.

images.alt_text: CMG20230518-OA-HoKJ01 Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and President William Ruto deliver remarks at the Joint Press Conference at State House in Nairobi, Kenya on Thursday, 18 May.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at a welcome ceremony at Tuynhuys, South Africa’s presidential office, with South African President Cyril Ramaphosa on May 16.

site_title: Hong Kong’s CK Group never withdraws from any markets: chairman
summary: CK Hutchison, the ports-to-telecoms arm of billionaire Li Ka-shing, has never withdrawn from any markets, its chairman Victor Li said at an annual general meeting. Despite recent asset sales in Europe, the group considers quality projects regardless of location. Li stated that "every market is a local market" and that the group has invested in Hong Kong, Mainland China, the UK, Europe, Australia, and Canada. The company is also progressing with a £15 billion merger plan with Vodafone's UK telecoms business.

images.alt_text: CK Hutchison, the ports-to-telecoms conglomerate owned by billionaire Li Ka-shing is considering issuing 5- and 10-year bonds, the term sheet shows.

site_title: DFI Retail reports ‘significant improvement’ in Q1 performance, but pre-Covid profitability still a way off
summary: DFI Retail Group reported a "significant improvement" in Q1 performance, driven by the reopening of the Hong Kong border and the recovery in South-east Asia. However, profitability remains below 2019 levels, with the grocery retail division experiencing lower results due to cautious customer shopping behavior and rising cost-of-living pressures. The company's health and beauty division saw substantial sales and profit growth, while the convenience division reported strong like-for-like sales growth across all markets. DFI remains optimistic on the outlook for the rest of the year, despite global headwinds and uncertain consumer confidence.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Cycle & Carriage authorised service centre at Ubi
Leadership changes at Mandarin Oriental, DFI Retail
The fall in sales in the grocery retail segment was primarily driven by the easing of movement restrictions in South-east Asia, said DFI Retail Group.

site_title: Sam Zell, billionaire real estate investor, dies at 81
summary: Billionaire real estate investor Sam Zell, known for his high-risk investment strategies, has died at 81. With a net worth of $5.9 billion, Zell built a fortune in real estate, radio stations, and other investments through his Chicago-based Equity Group Investments. He was known for his rebellious persona and made headlines with his leveraged buyouts, including the sale of Tribune Co. to Blackstone in 2007, which ultimately led to his company's bankruptcy in 2008. Zell's legacy as a shrewd businessman and entrepreneur will be remembered.

site_title: McCarthy predicts US debt-limit deal on House floor next week
summary: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy predicts a deal on the federal debt limit will be considered on the House floor next week, offering his most positive take yet on negotiations. Negotiators are in a "much better place" and discussions are happening two to three times a day, with a "structure" to the talks. The size of spending cuts and debt-ceiling increase or suspension remain key issues, but McCarthy expressed confidence in two of President Joe Biden's chief negotiators. The news led to gains in stocks and the dollar against currencies.

site_title: Apple slashes sales estimates of its headset
summary: Apple has lowered its sales estimates for its mixed-reality headset by about two-thirds, from 3 million units to 900,000 units per year, according to Bloomberg News. The iPhone-maker initially hoped to sell the headset for around $3,000, similar to Meta Platform's Quest Pro virtual and mixed reality headset. Apple's reduced sales estimate suggests the product may not be as commercially viable as expected, and the company's developers conference on June 5 is expected to provide further insight into the product's prospects.

site_title: US exchanges to bust erroneous CDW Corp trades after shares briefly dive 96%
summary: US stock exchanges will cancel erroneous trades in CDW Corp shares that briefly plummeted 96% to $7 in premarket trading due to a mistaken ticker. The trades occurred between 04:00 am ET and 04:22 am ET at or below $162.85. The NYSE and Nasdaq will bust all affected trades, allowing shares to recover and close at $173.50, up 0.2%. The mistake was attributed to investors confusing CDW Corp's ticker with that of newly listed asset manager CaliberCos.

site_title: China to take more measures to expand domestic demand, stabilise external demand
summary: China plans to expand domestic demand and stabilize external demand to promote a sustained economic rebound. Premier Li Qiang said the country will develop new business models for foreign trade and stabilize international market share. To boost domestic demand, China will create more consumption hot spots and promote urban and rural infrastructure construction. Li also warned of efforts to prevent and resolve risks and create a favorable environment for economic development.

site_title: Pakistan crippled economy fuels Khan's protests
summary: Imran Khan's supporters in Pakistan have rallied against the current government amid an economic crisis that has left people struggling to feed their families. The crisis, which includes a risk of default and spiraling inflation, has fueled Khan's bid to reclaim power. Violent clashes broke out last week, with at least nine people killed, as protesters protested against Khan's arrest on corruption charges. The unsteady coalition that replaced Khan struggles to address the crisis, galvanizing support for the former prime minister.

images.alt_text: Khan was presented before the top court that’s heard an appeal against his arrest, which has fuelled countrywide protests.

site_title: Philippine central bank plans tighter grip on money supply
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), the Philippine central bank, plans to tighten its grip on the money supply by expanding auctions of its securities and discontinuing the practice of rationing offers. The central bank aims to manage inflation by adjusting interest rates and the supply of money. Governor Felipe Medalla stated that the BSP will no longer ration the reverse repo, its primary monetary instrument to absorb excess liquidity. This move is part of the central bank's long-term plan to manage the economy.

site_title: Rival claims over Prince Harry, Meghan New York 'car chase'
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle claimed to have endured a "relentless" 2-hour car chase with paparazzi in New York, but New York police, the city's mayor, and a taxi driver have downplayed the incident. A photographer involved alleged the couple's driver was to blame for the tension, while Prince Harry's security team described the pursuit as "chaotic" and "dangerous." The couple has long had a difficult relationship with the media, citing press intrusion as a reason for their decision to step back from royal duties in 2020.

site_title: Design inspiration: This terrace house in Upper East Coast brings light in and keeps heat out
summary: A Singaporean couple transformed their 30-year-old inter-terrace house into a modern and energy-efficient home. With blistering heat, the house initially received direct sunlight, but the couple's designer, Kelvin Bing, implemented a steel roof with skylights, concrete slab, and sun-shading screens to filter out heat and let in light. The result is a well-lit and well-ventilated home, suitable for aging in place. The renovation has also freed up the backyard for greenery and created an elderly-friendly home, allowing the couple to enjoy their property for years to come.

images.alt_text: In three years, SG Interiors KJ has grown into a team of 34 interior designers,.
Hermès emphasised its use of organic materials at Milan Design Week 2023.
Nissi Gicalde transformed a rundown property into a desirable home.

site_title: US: Dow opens lower as losses in Cisco cloud upbeat Walmart forecast
summary: The US stock market opened lower on May 18, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 46.21 points, or 0.14%, to 33,374.56. This came after Cisco's cloud division showed slower demand, affecting Walmart's strong annual forecast and optimism over a potential debt default deal. The S&P 500 opened 1.09 points lower, or 0.03%, at 4,157.68, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 13.30 points, or 0.11%, to 12,513.87.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 10, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Apac investors eyeing active funds exposed to beneficiaries of decarbonisation: BlackRock
summary: Asia-Pacific investors are increasingly seeking active funds with high exposure to companies and sectors benefiting from the energy transition and other sustainability-related factors, according to BlackRock. Institutional investors focus on decarbonizing core portfolios, while wealth investors prefer thematic strategies. Key areas of interest include the future of transport, sustainable energy, and agriculture. BlackRock expects innovation in alternative investments to facilitate decarbonization, with opportunities in private equity and private credits, and expects companies to access their entire capital stack.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Doubts around the ability of indexes to address serious environmental and social issues coincide with a growing sense of urgency to come up with genuine ESG investing solutions.
BlackRock's chief executive officer Larry Fink has been outspoken about investing with ESG goals, making it a focal point in his annual letters to the industry.

site_title: Indian carrier IndiGo stays profitable on demand, forex boost
summary: India's IndiGo, the country's top airline, reported its second consecutive quarterly profit, driven by strong demand for air travel and foreign exchange gains. The carrier's revenue grew 76.5% in the quarter, outpacing fuel costs, and its yield and load factor improved. IndiGo flew 23.4 million passengers, a 60.5% increase from the previous year, and expects capacity to rise 5-7% sequentially in the current quarter. The airline's shares closed down 1.6% after hitting a one-and-a-half year high.

images.alt_text: India wants to have more than 90 carbon-neutral airports by 2024, a difficult challenge considering only two such airports exist now, in New Delhi and the southern port city of Kochi.

site_title: Middle East sports retailer launches first Asia store in Singapore
summary: Middle East sports retailer Sun & Sand Sports (SSS) has opened its first Singapore store, spanning 11,000 square feet, at Raffles City, marking its entry into Asia. The store will be followed by two more locations at Bugis+ and Westgate this year, with plans for a total of 11 stores across Southeast Asia over the next three years. The store features digital technology and experiential zones, carrying products from over 21 sports brands.

images.alt_text: At 5,000km, Charge+'s electric vehicle charging highway is set to be South-east Asia's longest.

FILE PHOTO: People pass a JD Sports store in London, Britain April 11, 2017.  Shares in Britain's JD Sports Fashion Plc climbed to a record high after strong demand for leisure clothing helped to drive a 55 percent rise in headline annual pretax profit, its biggest increase in eight years REUTERS/Neil Hall/File Photo
A bedrock of Thailand’s economy before the pandemic, tourism is reclaiming its key role as investors are waiting and watching days after a national vote on Sunday.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall more than expected
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell 22,000 to 242,000 in the week ending May 13, exceeding economists' forecast of 254,000. Despite a decrease, the labor market remains tight, with 1.6 job openings for every unemployed person in March. The number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid fell 8,000 to 1.799 million, indicating hiring activity. The tight labor market is being closely watched for signs of stress from the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to tame inflation.

site_title: Grab cuts Q1 loss to US$250 million, bumps up adjusted Ebitda guidance
summary: Grab reported a Q1 2023 loss of US$250 million, narrowing from US$435 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 130% to US$525 million, driven by growth across all business segments. Adjusted Ebitda improved 77% to a loss of US$66 million, and the company revised its adjusted Ebitda guidance range upwards to US$195-235 million for the full year 2023, with a potential breakeven point in the fourth quarter.

GXS CEO Charles Wong unveiling the digital bank's Flexiloan product, which is its first step to building a profitable bank.

site_title: Developers dangle discounts to move sales of upmarket condos
summary: At least eight new condominium projects in Singapore's prime Core Central Region (CCR) have offered discounts in April and May to draw buyers. Discounts range from 2.5% to 10% off median prices, with some units selling at prices 6% lower than their original prices. Developers are believed to be offering discounts ahead of the Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty (ABSD) deadline later this year or to push sales for cash flow. Despite this, market watchers expect prices to increase slightly in the months ahead due to high interest rates and construction costs.
