site_title: Ex-Reve chef Kawano Masahiko brings Michelin-starred flair to Japanese-French outpost Chaleur
summary: Former Reve chef Kawano Masahiko brings his Michelin-starred flair to his new Japanese-French concept Chaleur, located on Neil Road in Singapore. The restaurant boasts a bright and cozy interior, with a focus on technique and complexity in its cuisine. The menu features dishes such as crisp-skinned amadei with Japanese crown daisy sauce and a signature pigeon, as well as a heartwarming duck broth with chewy noodles. Prices are slightly higher than at Reve, but the attention to detail and skillful preparation make it a worthwhile experience. Chaleur is still finding its footing, but it shows promise as a new venture for Kawano.

images.alt_text: Peony Jade is decked out in fire engine red curtains and rosewood chairs.

site_title: STI ends 0.3% higher, as fears over US debt ceiling crisis ease
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% to 3,182.55 on May 18, 2023, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street as fears over the US debt ceiling crisis eased with talks progressing. The Straits Times Index (STI) followed gains in US stocks, with key gauges across the region rising. The move was seen as a positive sign for the market, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
The improved sentiment about the debt ceiling talks also boosted the dollar and contributed to gains in oil prices.
Tokyo and Hong Kong each piled on more than one per cent, while there were also healthy gains in Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila, Taipei and Wellington.

site_title: Debt ceiling hopes lift US dollar to seven-week peak
summary: The US dollar index reached a seven-week peak at 103.17, driven by optimism over the US debt ceiling negotiations between President Joe Biden and Kevin McCarthy. Investors scaled back expectations for Federal Reserve easing, with traders pricing in a 20% chance of a rate hike at the June meeting. The euro fell to a six-week low, while sterling was near a three-week low, and the Chinese yuan hit its lowest level against the US dollar since December.

site_title: UK's Lloyds faces resistance over 'attack' on flexible working
summary: Lloyds, the UK's largest domestic bank, is facing resistance from staff over a pilot scheme to assess flexible working arrangements. Thousands of employees have signed a collective grievance opposing the scheme, which could make it harder for staff with caring responsibilities to work flexibly. The pilot, which could lead to changes to compressed hours arrangements, was described as a "direct attack on working parents and carers" by union representatives. The bank's chairman stated that no decisions have been taken, but unions claim the initiative could result in significant financial costs for affected staff.

images.alt_text: Customers use the automated teller machines (ATMs) at a bank branch of Lloyds Banking Group Plc in London, U.K., on Monday, Feb. 18, 2019. Lloyds, along with Barclays Plc and HSBC Holdings Plc, will report earnings this week. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Jardine Matheson books ‘strong performance’ in Q1 but warns of macro challenges
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a "strong overall performance" in Q1, with most business units delivering increases in underlying net profit. Jardine Cycle & Carriage saw strong growth, mainly due to Astra's 25% increase in underlying earnings, while Hongkong Land's profit was lower due to reduced sales from its development properties business. The company remains confident in its markets' economic resilience and its ability to benefit from their recovery.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Contributions from the investment properties segment was “marginally” higher year on year with a stronger showing from the retail segment.
Leadership changes at Mandarin Oriental, DFI Retail

site_title: Fed poised for big upgrade to outlook despite swirling risks
summary: Federal Reserve officials are poised to deliver their largest upward revision to the US economic outlook since 2021, citing robust job growth, high auto sales, and stabilizing manufacturing despite looming banking sector stress and a potential debt default. The upgrade is likely to reinforce the plan to keep interest rates at peak levels through the end of 2024, defying expectations of a recession.

images.alt_text: New York Federal Reserve President John Williams also said he does not see “any reason to cut interest rates this year” in his baseline forecast, citing a need to lower stubborn inflation.

site_title: TikTok advantage behind Move Forward Party’s big win in Thailand election
summary: The Move Forward Party in Thailand's election won 151 seats in the lower house, exceeding pre-balloting polls, thanks in part to its effective use of social media platforms, particularly TikTok. The party's official TikTok account gained 2.8 million followers, and its leader's Twitter account reached 1 million, helping it capture younger voters. The party's creative and organic content strategy, including user-generated content and viral campaign videos, contributed to its success, outperforming traditional campaigning and rival parties.

images.alt_text: “We have a lot of momentum, my coalition is taking shape,” the Harvard-educated, 42-year-old Pita told reporters in Bangkok on Thursday.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Ant profit falls 56% amid overhaul
summary: Ant Group's quarterly profit fell 56% to 3.18 billion yuan (S$609 million) due to a shift in focus from expansion to regulatory compliance. The company's valuation has been trimmed to US$63.8 billion, down from a peak of US$235 billion. Billionaire Jack Ma, who has largely stepped back from public sight, plans to cede control of the company amid regulatory changes. Ant's consumer lending affiliate has recently been allowed to increase capital, marking a softening stance from the government towards the firm.

images.alt_text: Alibaba's revenue for the full year climbs 2 per cent to 868.69 billion yuan, marking its slowest rate of growth since the company went public in 2014.

site_title: Credit default swaps panel says Credit Suisse AT1 wipe-out won’t prompt payout
summary: A Credit Derivatives Determinations Committee (CDDC) panel ruled that Credit Suisse Group AG's Additional Tier-1 (AT1) notes are junior to subordinated bonds underlying credit default swaps (CDS), making a payout unlikely. The ruling, issued on May 17, determined that AT1 securities are "excluded obligations" in regard to the swaps, and the holders of these bonds are "priority creditors" versus AT1 holders. The decision, made by the 11-member panel, came after a faster-than-expected decision, and the price of default swaps tied to Credit Suisse's junior debt rose before paring some gains.

images.alt_text: The Swiss government has also agreed to absorb up to 9 billion francs in potential losses incurred by UBS as a result of the takeover.

The logo of a Credit Suisse Group AG bank branch beyond a UBS Group AG office building walkway in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 25, 2023. UBS attracted $28 billion from wealthy clients in the months running up to its takeover of Credit Suisse Group AG, in an early indication of how many assets the combined firms will be able to retain. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg
Credit Suisse cannot undertake any capital expenditure of more than 10 million francs or enter into certain contracts worth more than 3 million francs per year.

site_title: India’s top lender SBI posts record Q4 profit
summary: India's State Bank of India (SBI) reported a record fourth-quarter profit of 166.95 billion rupees, a 83% jump from the previous year, driven by a sharp drop in provisions on bad loans and healthy credit growth. The bank's gross non-performing assets (NPA) ratio fell to 2.78% and net NPA ratio improved to 0.67%. SBI's net interest income jumped 29.5% and net interest margin rose to 3.84%. The bank's chairman expressed hope for 12-14% credit growth this fiscal year.

images.alt_text: SBI surged 70 per cent last year as analysts turned bullish, though concerns about bank exposure to the embattled Adani Group have slammed the sub-index in the past two weeks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: High temperatures in Singapore from May 7 to 13 drove up energy demand and wholesale electricity prices. The mercury levels soared, leading to a peak in power demand. The exact reasons for the surge are not specified, but high temperatures are often a contributing factor to increased energy consumption. The article does not provide further details on the consequences of the price hike or any long-term effects.

site_title: Singapore drone startup Performance Rotors acquired by Xtend
summary: Singapore drone startup Performance Rotors has been acquired by Israeli drone software company Xtend, with financial terms undisclosed. Performance Rotors develops drones for data collection in confined spaces, serving the maritime, oil and gas, and infrastructure sectors. Xtend's semi-autonomous operating system offers an alternative to traditional drone controllers, allowing operators to perform accurate maneuvers with minimal training. The acquisition marks a strategic expansion for Xtend, following funding from Royal Vopak and EDB New Ventures in 2020 and 2021, respectively.

images.alt_text: Performance Rotors drone in action

site_title: Japan eyes annual US$22 billion for childcare to tackle birth rate decline
summary: Japan's government is considering a $22.2 billion annual funding package for childcare to address the country's declining birth rate, which has fallen below 800,000 for the first time. The plan, proposed by Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, aims to boost child care over the next three years. The government plans to identify the necessary funds by June, potentially through a combination of tax hikes, debt issues, or issuing extra bonds. The move aims to reverse the trend, which has been blamed for labor shortages and reduced economic growth potential.

images.alt_text: “The declining birthrate problem is a fight against time,” Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said.

site_title: PrimeMovers Equity, Lingotto acquire majority stake in Malaysia’s EngTek for S$150 million
summary: Singapore-based private equity firm PrimeMovers Equity and London-based investment management company Lingotto Investment Management are acquiring a majority stake in Malaysia's precision manufacturing company EngTek Group for S$150 million. The deal values EngTek at S$150 million and will be completed in the second quarter this year, subject to approvals and closing conditions. EngTek, established in 1974, currently has 1,400 employees and runs four factories in Malaysia and the Philippines.

images.alt_text: Headquartered in Penang, EngTek has three manufacturing plants in Malaysia and one in the Philippines.
Australian media had reported that the group may seek at least A$800 million (S$713.89 million) for the sale of Tutt Bryant Group (TBG), based on valuations in recent transactions
Li argues that Sea has a unique opportunity to bring e-commerce to emerging markets, the kinds of places where Amazon may be at a disadvantage.
HMI Group and MHC will join forces to deliver seamless patient journeys and better health outcomes through technology.

site_title: NetLink pays out record full-year distribution as H2 earnings rise 6.9% to S$54.7 million
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported record-high earnings of S$54.7 million for the second half of its fiscal year, up 6.9% from the same period last year, and a full-year earnings increase of 19.7% to S$109.3 million. The trust also paid out a record-high total full-year distribution of S$0.0524 per unit. Revenue rose 7.5% to S$203.9 million, driven by higher revenue from ancillary projects, non-building address points, and residential connections.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
UOB Kay Hian sees NetLink NBN Trust as a good shelter amid market volatility despite its recent share price weakness.
NetLink NBN Trust will explore opportunities in overseas telecoms infrastructure businesses.

site_title: Fund managers parked more money in real estate in 2022: survey
summary: Global fund managers invested more in real estate in 2022, with average assets under management (AUM) rising 8% to $35.1 billion. The top four managers accounted for nearly 28% of total real estate capital, with Blackstone leading with over $500 billion in AUM. ESR vaulted into the global top 10 list, ranking sixth, and Asia-Pacific fund managers dominated single-sector industrial and logistics investment managers. Non-listed real estate funds made up 60% of global non-listed real estate AUM, with the industry showing signs of consolidation.

images.alt_text: ESR Fujiidera Distribution Centre has powered self-generated solar energy to tenants since August 2021.
The move expands the Singapore state investor’s exposure to logistics assets.

site_title: Meituan planning Hong Kong debut as soon as monday, sources say
summary: Meituan, China's largest food delivery service, plans to launch its "KeeTa" meal delivery service in Hong Kong as early as Monday, May 22, marking its first expansion beyond mainland China. The service will initially serve the Mong Kok neighborhood and may expand to other areas if operations are successful. Meituan aims to compete against local businesses like Deliveroo and Foodpanda, and the company has been hiring aggressively in preparation for its debut. The launch is part of Meituan's strategy to move beyond its home market and expand internationally.

images.alt_text: Meituan was hit hard by Covid-19 curbs last year but it swung to a profit in the third quarter as it cut back investment on new initiatives.

site_title: Alibaba misses revenue estimates, approves cloud unit spinoff
summary: Alibaba reported a 2% increase in full-year revenue to 868.69 billion yuan, missing expectations. The company's cloud unit will be spun off via a stock dividend distribution within the next 12 months. Alibaba's quarterly revenue fell 4.9% to US$86.20, with its cloud division seeing a 2% year-on-year decline. The company is restructuring into six units, with the exception of its e-commerce division, and expects some units to seek outside funding and go public. Alibaba's chairman, Daniel Zhang, expressed optimism for the future, citing the potential for smaller units to grow into larger ones.

images.alt_text: Ant is waiting for a financial holding company licence, more than two years after authorities torpedoed its planned initial public offering.
Alibaba has made AI development a priority as a flurry of investments and talent have entered the burgeoning sector following the launch of OpenAI’s ChatGPT.

site_title: Tesla held talks with India on auto incentives, battery making: source
summary: Tesla has held talks with Indian officials on auto incentives and battery production, with a focus on setting up a factory to build electric vehicles and manufacturing local batteries. The discussions come as the company seeks to expand its presence in the Indian market, where it aims to sell 20 million electric vehicles by 2030. This marks a shift in Tesla's stance, following previous talks that became deadlocked over import taxes and export plans. India has set aside $6 billion under two programs to boost EV sales and manufacturing, offering cashback incentives for local production.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s Shanghai plant, its largest worldwide, produced about 726,000 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles in 2022, more than half of the automaker’s global sales.
The billionaire is expected to address Tesla shareholders on Tuesday at the automaker’s annual meeting at its headquarters in Austin, Texas.
Elon Musk bought Twitter for US$44 billion in October and runs rocket and spacecraft manufacturer SpaceX.

site_title: 🕑 Picking when to start investing
summary: Investors often struggle with timing the market, with a 2017 study finding that fund managers' attempts to boost returns by timing the market do not help and may even hurt returns. A simpler strategy, dollar-cost averaging, involves investing a fixed amount of money at regular intervals, regardless of market fluctuations. This approach limits losses and reduces the impact of emotions on investment decisions. While it may not yield the highest returns, dollar-cost averaging can be a viable strategy for those who want to minimize risk and avoid the pitfalls of market timing.

images.alt_text: Daryl Choo

site_title: China recovery looms large at Sohn 2023 hedge fund conference
summary: Asian-focused hedge funds are becoming increasingly bullish on China, with seven out of 15 funds pitching investment ideas at the Sohn Hong Kong Investment Leaders Conference. Despite an uneven economic recovery, investors are targeting sectors like education, hydropower, and electric cars, citing opportunities in areas such as vocational education and state-owned enterprise China Yangtze Power. Optimism has been tempered by foreign investors trimming exposure due to economic and geopolitical risks.

images.alt_text: Investors pour money into private tutoring leaders, including New Oriental and TAL Education, that have come through a near two-year crackdown in China on after-school education.

site_title: A hat trick for Singapore Art Museum
summary: The Singapore Art Museum has opened three exhibitions simultaneously, featuring local artists and emerging creatives. Abstract painter Jane Lee debuts her solo exhibition, exploring the nature of painting through scale, space, and optical illusion. The exhibition "Residues And Remixes" showcases six Singaporean artists examining historical narratives and their influence on the present. Lastly, German artist Hito Steyerl's video work "Factory Of The Sun" is on display, exploring the blurring of truth and fiction in a world of misinformation. The exhibitions run until September at Tanjong Pagar Distripark.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Ghafir Akbar (left) and Julie Wee as the king and queen of fairies Oberon and Titania respectively.
Chng Nai Wee's multi-channel video work Sin Of Apathy invites audiences to question their apathy and indifference towards global crises.

site_title:
Hongkong Land posts lower Q1 underlying profit 
on weaker development properties contribution
summary: Hongkong Land reported a lower underlying profit for the first fiscal quarter due to reduced contributions from its development properties business. However, the investment properties segment showed a "marginally" higher year-over-year contribution, driven by stronger performances from the retail segment. Rental reversions in its office portfolio were positive, but expected to moderate as global uncertainties rise. Physical vacancy fell to 4.6% in Q1, and the company expects planned sales completions for 2023 to be higher than in the prior year.

images.alt_text: This aerial photo shows a view of residential and commercial tower blocks on the eastern side of Hong Kong island on April 3, 2022. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)
Uma Devi

site_title: Top Abu Dhabi wealth fund taps Manulife exec for US real estate
summary: Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, has appointed Pritesh Patel, former chief investment officer at Manulife's Americas Real Estate division, to lead its US real estate unit. Patel will join the $1 trillion fund this summer, replacing Gerald Fang. The fund has been expanding its US real estate portfolio, raising its target allocation range for North America to 45-60%. ADIA has participated in several high-profile real estate investments, including the take-private of logistics Reit Indus and US student housing ventures, amid a shift in investment strategies following the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Founded in October 2015, ADGM said it has 5,500 business licences operating within it.

site_title: ADB warns China it risks wasting money on state-led growth
summary: The Asian Development Bank's chief economist, Albert Park, warned China that its state-led growth model risks "wasting a tonne of money" and urged policymakers to level the playing field between private and state-owned firms. China's post-Covid economic recovery is losing steam, and policymakers must shore up wobbly growth. Park noted that a one-percentage-point increase in China's growth can increase growth in developing Asia by 0.3%. He emphasized the importance of improving the business environment and sustainability in China's development.

images.alt_text: Reduced fossil fuel use and increased demand for land during climate change mitigation adversely affect agricultural production and pushes up food prices.

site_title: Inside the quest for totally transparent cocktail ice
summary: Camper English, a writer and cocktail enthusiast, has published "The Ice Book" to help home bartenders master clear ice. English's research, which began with attempts to create clear ice using various methods, led to a breakthrough in directional freezing, a process that mimics how lakes freeze. This process, achieved by freezing water in a hard-sided, insulated cooler, results in clear ice. English's book, out May 23, includes ice-centric cocktail recipes and has gained attention from social media influencers, who have credited him with advancing the clear-ice movement.

images.alt_text: Various boxed wines in New York, May 2, 2023. Thoughtful winemakers, motivated by environmental concerns, are turning to boxes. (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

site_title: Agarwal’s Vedanta seeks cash as US$500 million bond maturity looms
summary: Agarwal's Vedanta Resources is seeking to raise funds to repay a US$500 million junk-rated bond maturing at the end of the month. The company is considering a loan to free up cash and reduce its debt load, which has been strained by weaker metals prices and high costs. Vedanta's board will meet on May 22 to discuss paying out a first dividend for the current business year. The company is in talks with banks to raise at least US$500 million, potentially increasing the loan size to US$900 million.

images.alt_text: The Indian government has threatened to stop Anil Agarwal’s Vedanta Group from selling a zinc manufacturing unit to its subsidiary Hindustan Zinc.

site_title: Australia April employment unexpectedly falls, jobless rate ticks up
summary: Australia's jobless rate ticked up to 3.7% in April, exceeding expectations, while employment fell by 4,300. Hours worked increased by 2.6%, but job ads fell for the third straight month. The data suggests the labour market may be cooling, potentially weakening the case for another interest rate hike by the Reserve Bank of Australia. Analysts expect a gradual softening in labour market conditions over 2023.

images.alt_text: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he hoped the Quad summit could go ahead as planned on May 24 with the United States sending a “senior representative” to attend.
Higher living costs meant consumers were holding off on buying a major household item, with the index dipping 0.4 per cent.

site_title: Sembcorp to develop multi-utilities centre on Jurong Island for S$900 million
summary: Sembcorp Industries plans to develop a multi-utilities centre on Jurong Island, costing S$900 million, with construction expected to start in the second half of 2023 and be operational by 2026. The facility will supply power, steam, firewater, and demineralised water, featuring a 600-megawatt hydrogen-ready power plant. The project will be financed through internal cash resources and external bank borrowings, with no expected impact on Sembcorp's earnings per share and net tangible assets.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

SembWaste is one of three public waste collectors appointed by Singapore’s National Environment Agency to provide waste and recyclable collection services to residential, schools and trade premises in the city-state, according to its website.
Sembcorp Industries' statement comes in response to a Reuters article about the potential sale of the group's waste and recycling management unit, SembWaste.

site_title: Micron to invest 500 billion yen in Japan for new Dram chips
summary: Micron Technology plans to invest up to 500 billion yen (S$4.88 billion) in Japan to produce extreme ultraviolet (EUV) technology for 1-gamma chips, a type of memory chip used in complex applications. This will be the first time EUV technology is brought to Japan for production. The investment is part of Micron's efforts to ramp up EUV production in Taiwan and Japan, starting from 2025. This move aims to support Japan's reinvigorated chip sector, which has seen its global market share decline to around 10% from 50% in the late 1980s.

site_title: New Jobs Transformation Map for hotel sector focuses on sustainability, technology
summary: Singapore's hotel industry has committed to transforming 135 jobs across 18,000 local workers over the next three years, following a government roadmap. The Jobs Transformation Map identifies four major trends: changing guest expectations, sustainability, a competitive landscape, and changing workforce aspirations. 87 current job roles will be redesigned, with 40 likely to be completely overhauled and 33 requiring moderate redesign. The map also recommends upskilling and new job roles in the "hotel of tomorrow", focusing on sustainability, technology, and placemaking.

images.alt_text: The luxury, upscale, mid-tier and economy segments all record lower average room rates in March.

site_title: BMW 318i review: Still a sturdy 3?
summary: BMW's 3 Series, now known as the 318i, has received a mid-life facelift, but it appears to be more of a cosmetic update than a significant overhaul. The car retains its spacious rear seating, serenity on the move, and fluid handling, with a well-mannered 2.0-litre turbo engine and fuel-efficient performance. The revamped interior features a wide freestanding touchscreen and a new OS8 operating system, but some may find the interface confusing. The 318i M Sport trim offers a sporty package, but the firm suspension may be uncomfortable for some drivers. Overall, the 318i approaches perfection, satisfying most needs with a blend of performance and practicality.

images.alt_text: In only its third incarnation, the new GLC has won over enough people to become Mercedes’ single best-selling model around the world.
