site_title: Philippine central bank holds rates as inflation eases
summary: The Philippine central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), maintained its benchmark interest rate at 6.25% for the third consecutive month, pausing its 10-month tightening cycle. This decision comes after inflation eased in April for the third straight month, with the BSP now forecasting inflation to return to its 2-4% target range by the fourth quarter of the year. The decision was seen as a surprise, with only six out of 22 economists predicting a 25 basis point rate hike. The BSP stands ready to respond to emerging price threats.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea pushed back against rate cut expectations at its Apr 11 policy decision citing its goal to combat inflation.

site_title: cont.act Dance festival returns as a fully live event
summary: The cont.act Contemporary Dance Festival, a live event after three years of digital showcases, will take place from June 9 to 27. The 13th edition will feature four live platforms, including the highly anticipated centerpiece "PheNoumenon" by choreographer Kuik Swee Boon. The festival will also include the "Open Stage" platform, showcasing short pieces by talented dancers from around the world, and the returning "Dance At Dusk" platform with free outdoor performances. Due to financial challenges, the festival will have fewer offerings than its 2019 edition, but aims to promote contemporary dance despite the economic downturn.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Jane Lee's continues her exploration into the nature of painting with several stunning works. at SAM.
Cathy-Di Zhang (left) and Austin Haynes play lovers in the opera The Butterfly Lovers by Wild Rice and Melbourne-based Victorian Opera.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.4% or 11.44 points to 3,185.28. The top-traded counters were Marco Polo Marine, Seatrium, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, with gains ranging from 0.8% to 2.1%. The gains were driven by overnight positive sentiments on Wall Street, where US indices rose due to speculation of a possible agreement to avoid a debt default.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines announces bonuses of up to eight months for eligible staff.

site_title: BT to cut up to 55,000 jobs by 2030 after fibre build ends
summary: BT, Britain's largest broadband and mobile provider, plans to cut up to 55,000 jobs by 2030 as part of its transformation plan to build a national fibre network. The company's workforce is expected to reduce from 130,000 to between 75,000 and 90,000 by the end of the decade. Following the completion of the fibre roll-out, BT aims to become a leaner business with a significantly reduced cost base.

images.alt_text: Virgin and O2 clinch UK approval for US$44.4b deal

site_title: Tat Hong eyes A$800 million sale of Australian unit in review of strategic options
summary: Tat Hong, a Singapore-based crane supplier, is reviewing the sale of its Australian unit, Tutt Bryant Group (TBG), due to strategic options. The company may seek at least A$800 million (S$713.89 million) for the sale, according to reports. Tat Hong's group CEO, Roland Ng, stated that the process is a review of strategic options for shareholders, potentially using proceeds to re-enter the Australian market through partnerships. The decision comes after the company went private in 2018 and identified growth areas in Australia, but requires "financial muscle" to compete with larger players.

images.alt_text: Crane and heavy equipment supplier Tat Hong was established in Singapore in the 1970s and has operations throughout the region.

site_title: Binance Australia says banking disrupted after payment provider cuts off service
summary: Binance Australia's payment provider, Cuscal, cut off its service, disrupting deposits and withdrawals. Customers can still use credit or debit cards for transactions. Binance is working to find an alternative provider. This is the second blow to Binance's Australian operation in months, following a financial services licence relinquishment amid a regulatory investigation.

images.alt_text: Canada has tightened regulations for crypto asset trading platforms in recent months, with the introduction of a pre-registration process.
In March, the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission sued Binance and its CEO Changpeng Zhao for operating what the regulator alleged was an “illegal” exchange and a “sham” compliance programme.

site_title: 2023 Mercedes-Benz GLC review: Long-range game changer
summary: The 2023 Mercedes-Benz GLC 300 e is a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) that has won over enough people to become Mercedes' single best-selling model worldwide. The GLC 300 e boasts a 31.2-kilowatt hour battery pack, allowing for a useful electric range of 138 km. In real-world testing, the car achieved 110 km on battery power, making it a champion of the PHEV world. The GLC 300 e offers silky and responsive acceleration, smooth and quiet electric propulsion, and a zero-layer design interface. However, it has a tendency to rock and feel firmly sprung over uneven tarmac, and the hybrid hardware imposes on the cargo area.

images.alt_text: If you happen to be in the market for a fairly large, fairly plush sport utility vehicle, you have a reason to look at Jeep and its latest model for Singapore, the Grand Cherokee Limited.
The McLaren Artura is a contemporary take on the supercar breed.

site_title: Business recovery to drive CapitaLand Ascott Reit’s leverage further down: Fitch Ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings upgraded CapitaLand Ascott Reit's long-term issuer default rating to BBB with a stable outlook, citing the business recovery in the Asia-Pacific region, which will boost revenue and deleverage the Reit. The Reit focuses on the hospitality sector, with key markets in Australia, Japan, and Singapore. Its rating is two notches below peer CDL Hospitality Trusts due to the latter's weaker business profile, but is a notch higher than Mapletree Logistics Trust due to better cash-flow visibility.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Citadines City Centre Frankfurt, one of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s (Clas) properties. As at Mar 31, 2023, the stapled group’s net asset value per stapled security stands at S$1.13.

site_title: Qiming closes China’s largest venture capital renminbi fund for 2023 at 6.5 billion yuan
summary: Qiming Venture Partners closed its largest renminbi fund for 2023 at 6.5 billion yuan (S$1.2 billion), marking the largest renminbi fundraising in China's venture capital market this year. The fund, which drew strong participation from existing investors, brings Qiming's total capital raised to US$9.5 billion across 18 funds, focusing on technology, consumer, and healthcare sectors. Qiming, an early backer of tech giants like Meituan and Xiaomi, made 90 investments last year, including OriCell Therapeutics and ArkBio, and has over 530 portfolio companies.

site_title: The era of huge UK house price rises is ending, economist says
summary: A senior economist at the Office for Budget Responsibility, David Miles, says the era of huge UK house price increases may be ending due to slowing population growth, changing working habits, and a flattening interest rate environment. This trend is expected to continue for the next 40 years, making explosive house price growth less likely. The UK's housing shortage, a major issue, is also expected to ease as the population grows more slowly.

images.alt_text: UK unitied kingdom house housing rent Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg
With inflation still at the highest level in decades, the FCA has issued several reminders to banks about treating customers fairly, particularly if they run into difficulties.

site_title: The promise of crypto has not lived up to initial excitement
summary: Cryptocurrencies have failed to live up to their initial promise of revolutionizing the financial system, with market value declining from $3 trillion to $1.3 trillion since 2021. Despite efforts to create regulatory clarity, public trust remains low due to high-profile swindles and crashes. However, some countries with weak economies, such as Argentina and Nigeria, have seen increased adoption of cryptocurrencies. Regulators are now acting, with some countries imposing bans, and advocates argue that regulation could help the industry. While cryptocurrencies may still have uses, such as cross-border payments and hedging against inflation, their potential to remake the global financial system remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Souvenir tokens representing cryptocurrency Bitcoin plunge into water in this illustration taken May 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic//File Photo

site_title: Royal Mail plunges to £1 billion loss after fight with union
summary: Royal Mail, the UK postal service owned by International Distributions Services, reported a £1 billion operating loss due to industrial action, a weak online retail market, and severance costs from redundancies. The company reached an agreement with the Communication Workers Union, which will be voted on by staff, offering grounds for optimism. Revenue fell 5.3% to £12 billion, and shares dropped over 5% in early trading. CEO Simon Thompson is set to leave at the end of October, and the company won't recommend a final dividend due to performance issues.

images.alt_text: Simon Thompson draws heavy criticism from the CWU and its postal workers over his handling of the pay dispute, which is causing financial distress and major disruptions to mail deliveries.

site_title: Nissan launches its most expensive SUV here yet
summary: Nissan has launched its most expensive SUV yet, the X-Trail, priced at S$249,800 in Singapore. The new model features a series hybrid electric system, known as e-Power, which combines a petrol engine with two electric motors, delivering instant response and smooth acceleration. The X-Trail can stretch up to 820 km on a full tank of petrol, with a fuel consumption of 6.7 litres per 100 kilometres. This marks the X-Trail's entry into the S$250,000 pricing territory, previously dominated by luxury SUVs.

images.alt_text: In only its third incarnation, the new GLC has won over enough people to become Mercedes’ single best-selling model around the world.
If you happen to be in the market for a fairly large, fairly plush sport utility vehicle, you have a reason to look at Jeep and its latest model for Singapore, the Grand Cherokee Limited.
The McLaren Artura is a contemporary take on the supercar breed.

site_title: US banks rethink social media as a threat, not a marketing tool
summary: US banks are reevaluating their social media presence as a potential risk factor, rather than a marketing tool, following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) due to internet-fueled rumors and deposit outflows. Executives are developing risk management programs, monitoring social media, and preparing emergency procedures to counter online threats. This shift comes as smaller lenders focus on addressing misinformation and engaging with influential community members to maintain depositor confidence. Regulators and major lenders are also taking note, with some ordering social media monitoring tools and human resources dedicated to social media monitoring.

images.alt_text: Gregory Becker, the former chief executive of Silicon Valley Bank, testifies before a Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee hearing to examine the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank on Capitol Hill in Washington, May 16, 2023.
The remarks follow comments from Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, who said she expects US regulators to be open to such deals as firms consolidate.

site_title: RGE’s Asia Symbol obtains 1 billion yuan sustainability-linked loan
summary: Asia Symbol, a pulp producer and member of Royal Golden Eagle (RGE), has secured a 1 billion yuan (S$190 million) sustainability-linked loan from a consortium of Chinese banks. The loan is contingent on meeting specific key performance indicators (KPIs) in the next three years, which would result in lower interest rates. A third-party environmental certification agency will verify the annual assessment results, ensuring Asia Symbol meets the sustainability standards.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Japan’s export growth hits two-year low on weak China demand
summary: Japan's export growth hit a two-year low in April, with exports rising 2.6% from the previous year, slower than expected. This decline is attributed to weak demand from China, Japan's largest trading partner, with exports to China dropping 2.9% year-on-year. The trade balance also showed a deficit of 432.4 billion yen, marking the first decline in six quarters. The weak exports weigh on factory activity and hinder a broader recovery, despite the country's economy emerging from recession in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: The number of foreign visitors for business and leisure has climbed to 1.95 million last month from 1.82 million in March, according to the Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO).

A Samsung flag flutters outside the company's Seocho building in Seoul on April 27, 2023. - Samsung Electronics on April 27, reported its worst quarterly profits in 14 years, blaming slowing consumer spending on electronics and a global microchip glut that hit its core memory business. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: Vienna becomes epicentre of Europe’s housing woes
summary: Vienna's housing market has become the weakest among major European capitals, posting a 12.2% decline from peak levels a year ago, according to the Bloomberg City Tracker. Stricter mortgage rules and rising interest rates are exacerbating the slump, dragging down offer prices to an average of €7,084 (S$10,306) per square meter. In contrast, Madrid, Milan, and Zurich showed gains, while Stockholm's decline was 6.4%. The European housing market is experiencing divergent trajectories due to varying factors, including higher interest rates and supply shortages.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank researchers say the "negative effects of the increase in monetary policy interest rates in the euro area are likely to intensify over time".

site_title: Homebuilder stocks soar to new highs on insatiable demand for US housing
summary: Homebuilder stocks surged to new highs due to insatiable demand for US housing, with the S&P Composite 1500 Homebuilding sector reaching a 52-week high. Despite mortgage rates above 7%, orders for new construction rose 18% ahead of estimates, and builders are offering incentives to help buyers afford homes. Industry giant DR Horton reported better-than-expected earnings, signaling a positive start to the spring selling season. Analysts predict accelerating positive order growth for builders through 2023 and into 2024.

images.alt_text: Single-family housing starts, which accounted for the bulk of homebuilding, have risen 1.6 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 846,000 units last month.

site_title: Whampoa Group to set up digital bank in Bahrain
summary: Whampoa Group, a Singapore-based investment group, plans to establish a digital bank in Bahrain by the end of 2023. The bank will offer digital banking services and the trading, custody, and asset management of digital assets. Bahrain, which issued crypto-asset licenses in the Middle East, aims to solidify its position as a leading hub for crypto services and fintech innovations. The establishment of the digital bank aligns with the kingdom's economic recovery plan, prioritizing digitization across the financial services sector, and is expected to contribute to the country's growing digital-assets industry.

images.alt_text: Institutions are seriously looking into crypto assets, says Aureole Foong, Whampoa senior partner

site_title: China’s Geely to double Aston Martin stake in £234 million deal
summary: China's Geely Automobile Holdings has agreed to a £234 million deal, doubling its stake in Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings to 17%, becoming the company's third-largest shareholder. The deal, which includes purchasing 42 million existing shares and 28 million new shares, will unlock £95 million for Aston Martin. Geely will also have the right to appoint one director on the company's board, following the acquisition of shares from chairman Lawrence Stroll's Yew Tree consortium.

images.alt_text: A view shows the logo of Chinese automobile manufacturer Geely at a dealership in Moscow, Russia, March 23, 2023. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov

site_title: NYC’s record-breaking rents squeeze tenants across boroughs
summary: New York City's record-breaking rents have squeezed tenants across Manhattan, Brooklyn, and northwest Queens, with median rents increasing 8.1% in Manhattan, 15% in Brooklyn, and 13% in Queens. The median luxury rent in Manhattan rose 13% to $11,310, while the median rent for studios in Brooklyn increased 8.5%. Many renters are staying put rather than looking for a new spot, with 3,869 Manhattan leases signed in April reflecting a 20% drop from March, as landlords continue to push up prices and cut incentives.

images.alt_text: Single-family housing starts, which accounted for the bulk of homebuilding, have risen 1.6 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 846,000 units last month.
UK unitied kingdom house housing rent Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Gold prices flat as traders seek direction from US debt talks
summary: Gold prices remained flat in early Asian trade on May 18 as traders awaited direction from US debt talks. The dollar index held firm, making gold less attractive for overseas investors, while US Treasury yields rose amid cautious optimism around lawmakers' talks to raise the US debt ceiling. Markets now price in a 71.6% chance of the Federal Reserve holding interest rates at the current level in June, dulling gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation.

images.alt_text: A stronger dollar weighs on overseas demand for greenback-priced gold, while higher rates blunt non-yielding bullion’s appeal.

site_title: Central Asia leaders converge in China as Xi touts ‘enduring’ friendship
summary: Central Asian leaders gathered in China's Xian city for one-on-one talks with President Xi Jinping, marking the start of a regional pact with Beijing. The summit, coinciding with a Group of Seven meeting in Japan, aims to deepen economic and security ties. Key agreements include a "weal and woe" deal with Kazakhstan, cooperation in oil and uranium, and measures to secure the China-Central Asia natural gas pipeline. The talks set the stage for a regional pact, with Xi touting "enduring friendship" between China and Central Asia.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping will host the leaders of the five countries in the western city of Xi’an this week for a summit Beijing has described as of “milestone significance”.

site_title: Amazon’s cloud unit to invest 1.06 trillion rupees in India by 2030
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) plans to invest 1.06 trillion rupees (S$17.3 billion) in India by 2030, doubling its previous investments to cater to growing demand. The investment will support over 100,000 full-time jobs annually and build cloud infrastructure. This move comes as India steps up efforts to attract big-ticket investments and the government drafts a cloud and data centre policy to oversee the sector. Other global companies, including Microsoft and Alphabet's Google, are also ramping up cloud investments in India, driven by the country's rising digital consumption.

site_title: Power demand zaps new peak amid soaring mercury levels
summary: Singapore's energy demand surged to a record high of 6,597 megawatts in the week of May 7-13, driven by soaring mercury levels and increased usage of air-conditioners. Wholesale electricity prices more than doubled to S$774.52 per megawatt hour, with supply increasing only 0.1 per cent. Experts attribute the high prices to tight supply and increased demand, while noting that the electricity market is functioning as expected. The increase in prices is expected to be temporary, with electricity tariffs reflecting long-run fair costs of production.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
EMA noted that global energy prices have been “less volatile” in recent months, and that more longer-term retail contracts are now also available to large consumers.
The proposed enhancements will address certain gaps highlighted by recent upheavals in the retail electricity market, EMA said.

site_title: New Zealand sees bigger deficit as economy sputters, spending boost to fan inflation
summary: New Zealand's economy is showing signs of slowing, leading to a worse-than-forecast budget deficit. The country's inflation remains high, and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) has warned that increased government spending could exacerbate this issue. To combat inflation, the RBNZ has raised interest rates by 500 basis points since October 2021. The government has announced billions in infrastructure spending and measures to help those struggling with living costs, which has put pressure on its finances. The budget deficit is expected to fan inflationary pressures ahead of the country's election in October.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Grant Robertson will deliver his annual budget on Thursday in Wellington with little room for sweeteners ahead of a general election in October.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei closes at 20-month-high, spurred by chipmakers' investment plans
summary: Japan's Nikkei stock index surged 1.6% to a 20-month high of 30,573.93, driven by chipmakers' investment plans and reasonable April trade data. This marks the index's biggest daily gain since March 22 and its sixth consecutive winning session. The Nikkei has risen nearly 17% this year, outperforming the global market's 8% gain. The recent gains are fueled by buybacks and enthusiasm about governance reform.

images.alt_text:
A man looks at an electric quotation board flashing the Nikkei key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 12, 2017.
Tokyo stocks fell April 12 morning as the yen shot to five-month highs against the dollar over fears about growing tensions on the Korean peninsula and in the Middle East. / AFP PHOTO / Kazuhiro NOGI

site_title: Asia: Markets rally with Wall Street on US debt optimism
summary: Asian markets rallied with Wall Street on Thursday, driven by optimism over US debt talks. Tokyo and Hong Kong gained over 1%, while Shanghai, Sydney, and Seoul also saw healthy gains. The news comes after talks between President Joe Biden, House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, and congressional leaders appeared to be more fruitful, with a potential deal on the budget and debt ceiling. Despite Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's warning of a potential US default, economists and investors remain optimistic, with JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon stating the US will not default.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore and Wellington fell on Wednesday..

site_title: Bankman-Fried faces long odds of tossing charges despite Supreme Court decision
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX, faces slim odds of having his charges dismissed despite a recent Supreme Court decision limiting the scope of fraud prosecutions. The court's decision invalidated the "right to control" theory, which was used to prosecute a Buffalo construction executive accused of bid-rigging. Bankman-Fried's lawyers argue that the decision applies to his case, but prosecutors can point to tangible property losses suffered by victims. Bankman-Fried still faces 12 other counts at his upcoming trial, with experts predicting he will have a difficult time escaping liability.

images.alt_text: FTX filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States on Nov 11 in the biggest crypto firm failure.

site_title: Kishida meets Intel, TSMC, Micron execs as Japan joins chip race
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida met with top executives from Intel, TSMC, Micron, Samsung, and IBM to bolster domestic chipmaking capacity amid US-China tensions and concerns about over-reliance on Taiwan. The government is providing financial incentives for Micron's Hiroshima plant and supporting a new chip venture, Rapidus, backed by Toyota and Sony. TSMC is also building a plant in Kumamoto prefecture with Sony, with plans for a second plant. Japan aims to increase its advanced chipmaking capabilities to reduce dependence on Taiwan.

site_title: Jailed Angola tycoon fails in bid to have money released from US$558 million Bank of Singapore account
summary: Angolan tycoon Carlos Manuel De Sao Vicente, sentenced to nine years' jail for embezzlement, money laundering, and tax fraud, failed in his bid to release S$2.6 million from his Singapore Bank of Singapore account. The account, containing over US$558 million, was seized by the Commercial Affairs Department in 2021. De Sao Vicente had applied to the Singapore High Court for the release of the funds, but his request was denied.

images.alt_text: Scam victims in Singapore lost a total of $660.7 million in 2022.
Johnny G Plate is the fifth minister in President Joko Widodo’s administrations to be charged with corruption.
Alejandro Burzaco admits to paying bribes and kickbacks to officials at Fifa and regional affiliates for marketing rights to tournaments including the World Cup and Copa America.

site_title: Tourism to limit Thai economic pain as new government awaited
summary: Thailand's tourism industry is expected to shield the country's economy from political uncertainty, with 6.5 million visitors in the first quarter of 2023, a significant increase from last year. Tourism is seen as a key growth driver, with the government aiming for three times more foreign guests this year. Despite potential delays in government formation and its impact on the budget, economists believe tourism will remain unaffected, supporting the country's 3.6% GDP growth forecast for the year.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate, Pita Limjaroenrat, celebrate the party's election results in Bangkok, Thailand, May 15, 2023. REUTERS/Jorge Silva
Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat  waves to his supporters during a victory parade in Bangkok on May 15, 2023.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as Biden, McCarthy offer reassurances on talks
summary: US stocks rallied on Wednesday, May 17, as President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy offered reassurances on debt ceiling talks, boosting the dollar and oil prices. Despite no compromise, Biden expressed confidence in avoiding a default, while McCarthy remained optimistic about working together. Markets continue to watch the talks, with analysts citing caution until a deal is reached.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.0 per cent to 33,012.14.

site_title: Thai opposition leader confident of forming government
summary: Thai opposition leader Pita Limjaroenrat, head of the Move Forward Party, expressed confidence in forming a government despite junta-appointed senators blocking his appointment. The MFP emerged as the largest party in Sunday's election, securing 313 out of 500 seats in the lower house after two small parties joined their coalition. Pita attributed the party's success to its momentum and the shape of its coalition, with a record turnout delivering a defeat for army-linked parties that had ruled the kingdom for nearly a decade.

images.alt_text: Hurdles have emerged in Pita’s path to power after some of the 250 unelected members of the Senate express their opposition to his bid for the top job.

site_title: Nvidia chip king’s fortune doubles this year to US$27.3 billion on AI boom
summary: Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang's fortune has doubled to US$27.3 billion this year due to the surge in artificial intelligence (AI) investments. The company's AI-related chips have seen a significant increase in demand, making Nvidia the best-performing stock on the S&P 500. Huang's wealth has grown 98% this year, surpassing that of Mark Zuckerberg. However, Nvidia faces challenges in China, where sales tumbled 20% due to US restrictions on high-tech exports. The company plans to shift research and development and supply operations out of China to mitigate the impact.

images.alt_text: A chip industry source in China told Reuters the Nvidia H800 mainly reduced the chip-to-chip data transfer rate to about half the rate of the flagship H100.

site_title: Cisco’s orders hit by sluggish demand, shares fall
summary: Cisco Systems reported a 23% decline in product orders in the third quarter, despite a quarterly profit that beat estimates. The company cited a large backlog of products due to supply chain constraints and "macroeconomic conditions" as contributing factors. This led to a 4% drop in shares in extended trading. Cisco's aggressive efforts to resolve supply chain bottlenecks helped drive the profit beat, but the company's revenue outlook remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Cisco logo is displayed, during the GSMA's 2023 Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona, Spain March 1, 2023. REUTERS/Nacho Doce/File Photo
Cisco says it will support the growing demand from customers in India and expand supply chain capabilities.

site_title: Sony eyes listing for heavyweight finance unit
summary: Sony is considering a partial spin-off of its financial business, Sony Financial Group, which includes life insurance and banking, within the next 2-3 years. The conglomerate aims to drive synergies between its entertainment and image sensor businesses. The financial unit reported a 5% decline in revenue to 1.45 trillion yen (S$14.15 billion) in the year ended March, despite a 49% operating profit rise. A partial spin-off would allow the newly listed business to retain the Sony branding, and shares rose 6% in Tokyo morning trade following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Tokyo-based Sony joins a long list of Japanese firms executing buybacks in recent weeks.
Sony sold 19.1 million units of the PlayStation 5 videogame machine in the past business year, up from 11.5 million a year earlier.

site_title: Netflix ad tier now has nearly 5 million monthly active users
summary: Netflix's ad-supported tier, launched in November, now has nearly 5 million global monthly active users. The median age of these viewers is 34, according to Netflix's president of worldwide advertising, Jeremi Gorman. The tier, priced at $7 per month, offers lower subscription fees but includes commercials on programming, competing with traditional TV networks. This marks a significant milestone for the company's foray into advertising, following the launch of a similar tier in 12 markets.

site_title: Tech manufacturing counters take a beating in Q1 on weak end-consumer demand
summary: Semiconductor manufacturing counters took a hit in Q1 due to weak end-consumer demand, leading to a cyclical downturn. Companies such as UMS Holdings, Micro-Mechanics, and Nanofilm Technologies International reported declines in revenue and margins. However, some analysts remain bullish about the longer-term fundamentals of the industry, citing expected inventory corrections and advancements in technology nodes. They also point to onshoring and near-shoring efforts, as well as potential benefits from diversifying manufacturing away from China.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
TSMC expects its business to hit a bottom in the second quarter and pick up after that.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Foxconn is seen outside the company's building in Taipei, Taiwan, Nov. 10, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

site_title: Biden ‘confident’ on reaching debt deal as he heads to Japan
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed confidence in reaching a debt deal to avoid a default, despite obstacles remaining with Republicans seeking spending cuts and easing permits for energy projects. Biden said he would be in close contact with negotiators, including House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, and would return to Washington by the beginning of next week for continued negotiations. The Treasury Department warns of a potential breach of the debt ceiling as early as June 1, which could spike borrowing costs and prompt job losses.

images.alt_text: G7 host Japan will likely discuss with President Joe Biden whether he might look to reopen US participation in the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership.
Financial firms' message to the Biden administration and Congress on the debt ceiling: Get it done – now.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Ever Glory, Oiltek, ST Engineering
summary: Singapore Airlines has announced bonuses of up to eight months for eligible staff. The airline reported record earnings and expects robust demand for the near-term and peak travel season. Shares of SIA rose 1.5% to close at S$6.01. Ever Glory United, a mechanical and electrical engineering service provider, will begin trading on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange on a "ready" basis.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay US$75 million to settle lawsuit by Epstein accusers
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay $75 million to settle a lawsuit by women who claim they were abused by financier Jeffrey Epstein, who was a client of the bank from 2013 to 2018. The settlement resolves claims of facilitating Epstein's sex trafficking and was confirmed by his accusers' lawyers. The bank did not admit wrongdoing, citing people familiar with the matter. The agreement comes as Deutsche Bank has invested over $4 billion to bolster its controls and hire more people to fight financial crime.

images.alt_text: The Deutsche Bank headquarters in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg
Jeffrey Epstein bought the 29-hectares island of Little St James, which had a main house and additional structures, in 1998 for US$7.95 million.

site_title: SIA to pay bonus of about 8 months to rank-and-file staff following record profit
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) will award eligible employees with a 6.65-month profit-sharing bonus following the group's record earnings. The bonus is based on a long-standing formula agreed with staff unions and includes an additional 0.5-month ex-gratia bonus for each of the last three financial years, up to a maximum of 1.5 months. This recognition is for the employees' hard work and sacrifices during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
FILE PHOTO: Singapore Airlines planes sit on the tarmac at Changi Airport in Singapore December 8, 2020.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: Ever Glory ends Catalist trading debut at S$0.36, 63.6% above IPO price
summary: Ever Glory United Holdings, a Singaporean company, successfully completed its initial public offering (IPO) and ended its first day of trading on the Catalist board at S$0.36, 63.6% above its IPO price of S$0.22 per share. The company plans to use the raised S$3.1 million to scale its existing business and venture into property development and property investment, including the provision of maintenance services.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The company’s shares will begin trading on a “ready” basis on the Catalist board at market open on May 18.

Ever Glory United Holdings has projects in both the public and private sectors, including the development and redevelopment of public housing residential flats under the Housing and Development Board.

site_title: Boeing launches data tool to chart path to net-zero emissions target
summary: Boeing has launched a data tool called Cascade to help airlines and policymakers determine the most efficient path to reducing aviation emissions to zero by 2050. The tool allows users to adjust various factors, such as sustainable fuels and electric propulsion, to project decreases in carbon emissions over time. Boeing believes sustainable aviation fuel provides the most immediate pathway to reducing emissions, but acknowledges it will take a "collection" of technology or process changes to achieve net-zero emissions. The tool's public launch comes amid efforts to scale up sustainable aviation fuel production.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Boeing Co's logo is seen above the front doors of its largest jetliner factory in Everett, Washington, U.S. January 13, 2017. REUTERS/Alwyn Scott/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia bond bulls bet on rate cuts as hike-cycle end signalled
summary: Indonesia's benchmark bond yields reached their lowest in over a year as inflation slowed more than expected, signaling the end of the global rate hike cycle. Foreign investors have poured US$4.1 billion into Indonesian debt this year, betting on rate cuts. Bank Indonesia (BI) is set to meet next week, with traders anticipating a dovish stance that could add to the rally. Analysts predict the central bank may cut interest rates later this year, possibly by 75 basis points, and that BI will be among the first in emerging Asia to do so.

images.alt_text: An initial investment plan detailing how Indonesia will green its power supply and cut greenhouse emissions is due mid-August.
Bank Indonesia headquarters in Jakarta.Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Commercial real estate prices in the US fall for first time since 2011
summary: US commercial real estate prices fell for the first time in over a decade in the first quarter, driven by drops in multi-family residences and office buildings. The decline, led by Moody's Analytics, heightens the risk of financial stress in the banking industry, particularly for smaller lenders with significant exposure to the sector. Experts warn of a potential "doom loop" where reduced lending leads to steeper price drops, and credit losses at banks.

images.alt_text: A "Commercial Real Estate" sign in the Financial District of San Francisco, California.Photographer: Jason Henry/Bloomberg
Single-family housing starts, which accounted for the bulk of homebuilding, have risen 1.6 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 846,000 units last month.

site_title: Oil settles up US$2 on optimism about US debt ceiling, demand
summary: Oil prices rose by about US$2 on Wednesday, driven by optimism over US debt ceiling negotiations and demand, outweighing concerns about abundant supply. Brent crude futures settled at US$76.96 a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate US crude settled at US$72.83 a barrel. A crude inventory increase of 5 million barrels was offset by a drop in petrol stocks, which rose to their highest level since December 2021. The International Energy Agency predicts demand will outpace supply by 2 million barrels per day in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 32 US cents lower to US$74.91 a barrel. US West Texas Intermediate crude edged down 25 US cents to US$70.86.

site_title: Nomura cuts 2025 profit target as banking turmoil dents expansion hopes
summary: Nomura Holdings has cut its 2025 profit target by a quarter due to the global banking crisis affecting its investment banking advisory business and offshore expansion plans. The company now aims for an annual pre-tax income of 288 billion yen, down from a previous range of 350-390 billion yen. To reduce costs, Nomura plans to cut administrative and systems operations by 50 billion yen by March 2025.

images.alt_text: A sign is lit up outside a Nomura Securities Co. branch in the Shinjuku district of Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, April 23, 2009.  Nomura Holdings Inc., Japan's largest brokerage, is expected to announce earnings today. Photographer: Kimimasa Mayama/Bloomberg News

site_title: Applications open for Emerging Enterprise Awards 2023; Asian entries welcome
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Awards 2023 is now open for applications, expanding to include entries from companies in Hong Kong, Indonesia, and Malaysia for the first time. The awards, now in its 16th year, aim to recognize business innovation, resilience, and excellence in small and medium-sized enterprises. A new category, Emerging Enterprise Sustainability Award, will be introduced, recognizing businesses capitalizing on growth opportunities in the green economy. Applications close on June 30, with prizes including a two-year interest-free loan and a consulting package.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
A new Emerging Enterprise (EE) Sustainability Award will be launched, in an extension of the existing category within the EE Awards, said OCBC head of global commercial banking Linus Goh.
From left: Speedoc's Shravan Verma, Lumos Labs' Eu-wen Ding, and AP Technologies' Charles Tang, at the Emerging Enterprise Awards on Tuesday (Nov 22).

site_title: Tencent cuts cloud service prices up to 40% to fend off rivals
summary: Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings is cutting prices for cloud services by up to 40% starting June, amid a price war with rivals such as Alibaba Group and China Mobile. The price cuts are triggered by soft corporate demand and high sales targets despite slowing growth in the market. Despite this, Tencent's cloud services only represent a mid single digit percentage of its total revenue, and the company's chief strategy officer believes the impact on Tencent as a whole is not notable.

images.alt_text: Globally, Tencent’s appetite for content isn’t waning even at a time it’s divesting assets and spending more judiciously at home.

Tencent Music has been ramping up its original content slate to attract more users and stave off competition from the likes of NetEase-owned Cloud Music and Bytedance’s short-video sharing platform Douyin.

site_title: Swiss parliament to investigate Credit Suisse collapse
summary: The Swiss government has agreed to investigate the collapse of Credit Suisse and its takeover by UBS, with a parliamentary commission to be formed to examine the events leading up to the emergency rescue. The commission will consider the use of emergency laws to facilitate the takeover and the financial impact on UBS. The government has also agreed to absorb up to 9 billion francs in potential losses incurred by UBS as a result of the takeover, which was backed by 200 billion francs in government support.

images.alt_text: The logo of a Credit Suisse Group AG bank branch beyond a UBS Group AG office building walkway in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 25, 2023. UBS attracted $28 billion from wealthy clients in the months running up to its takeover of Credit Suisse Group AG, in an early indication of how many assets the combined firms will be able to retain. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg
Credit Suisse cannot undertake any capital expenditure of more than 10 million francs or enter into certain contracts worth more than 3 million francs per year.

(FILES) The sign and logo of Credit Suisse bank is seen at their headquarters in Zurich on March 20, 2023. - More than $68 billion had been withdrawn from Credit Suisse in the first three months of 2023, the bank said on April 24, 2023 in what are likely its final quarterly results before it is swallowed by rival UBS. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)

site_title: Shell reports ‘operational upset’ at unit in Singapore complex
summary: A unit at Shell's Pulau Bukom refinery and petrochemical complex in Singapore experienced an "operational upset" on Tuesday, resulting in flaring. The incident occurred at about 10.15 pm local time and affected a cracker, with the unit now operating at a reduced rate. Shell declined to name the unit or the impact on production for commercial reasons. The company's statement noted that the issue led to flaring, but no further details were provided.

site_title: Hong Kong targets young talent, tech sector in post-Covid push
summary: Hong Kong is targeting young, tech-savvy talent with a special visa program, which has attracted tens of thousands of applicants. The city is positioning itself as a hub for innovation, particularly in the metaverse and Web3, with a relatively light regulatory approach. Key events include the Web3 Festival, which drew over 10,000 attendees, and the establishment of the Institute of Web 3.0 Hong Kong. Despite concerns about the Chinese mainland's stance on cryptocurrency, Hong Kong's proximity to Asia's Web3 talent pool is seen as an advantage.

images.alt_text: Tech recruiters, one of the biggest roles impacted by tech layoffs,  have found mixed results in the job market.

Banks can borrow against the HK$1.2 trillion (S$205.6 billion) they hold of exchange fund bills, which are debt securities issued by the HKMA, to get quick cash from the monetary authority’s discount window.

site_title: Biden’s Asia Pacific booster plan thwarted
summary: US President Joe Biden's Asia-Pacific trip, scheduled to include a G7 summit in Japan and the Quad meeting in Australia, has been cut short due to domestic US political brinkmanship over the debt ceiling. The trip, intended to intensify US attention on the region and balance China's rise, has been thwarted. The cancellation of the Quad meeting will disappoint regional allies, particularly India, which may be re-elected for a third term this year. The G7 summit in Japan will still focus on China, with plans to issue a statement on economic security and a commitment to deter economic coercion.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden announces that he will be cutting his upcoming trip to Asia short and will return to Washington earlier than planned, to continue US debt ceiling negotiations, Washington, May 16, 2023.
Financial firms' message to the Biden administration and Congress on the debt ceiling: Get it done – now.
A “G7 Hiroshima” flower installation near the Peace Memorial Museum, ahead of the G7 summit, in Hiroshima, Japan, May 17, 2023.

site_title: Global debt on the rise, hitting almost US$305 trillion, says Institute of International Finance
summary: Global debt has reached nearly $305 trillion, a $45 trillion increase from pre-pandemic levels, according to the Institute of International Finance's quarterly Global Debt Monitor. This represents a $8.3 trillion increase in the first quarter of 2023, with the debt-to-output ratio stabilizing at 335% above pre-pandemic levels. Rising healthcare costs, ageing populations, and geopolitical tensions are expected to drive further increases in national defence spending. The report also notes concerns over tighter lending practices and the growth of shadow banking, which could lead to a sharp contraction in lending to some segments.

images.alt_text: Financial firms' message to the Biden administration and Congress on the debt ceiling: Get it done – now.

site_title: Elon Musk’s embrace of advertising at Tesla grabs marketers’ attention
summary: Elon Musk has announced Tesla's plans to use traditional advertising for the first time, reversing the company's years-long avoidance of ads. Musk revealed the plans during Tesla's annual meeting, stating that the company will try out a little advertising to see how it goes. Ad agency executives expect a unique and irreverent take that highlights Tesla's technology and personality. Musk envisioned ads emphasizing the features, safety, and affordability of Tesla vehicles, and did not have a fully formed strategy yet. The move is seen as a positive by some, including a Tesla shareholder, who expects the company to differentiate its products from competitors.

images.alt_text: In a sign of tough times even for Tesla, the market leader in electric cars, Elon Musk said the company would try to advertise its vehicles, something it has not done before.
Tesla’s Shanghai plant, its largest worldwide, produced about 726,000 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles in 2022, more than half of the automaker’s global sales.
The billionaire is expected to address Tesla shareholders on Tuesday at the automaker’s annual meeting at its headquarters in Austin, Texas.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on US debt ceiling concerns
summary: European shares slipped 0.2% on Wednesday, May 17, amid concerns over a potential US debt default and downbeat corporate updates. The Stoxx 600 index traded in a tight range this month as investors assess European and US interest rates. German lender Commerzbank fell 3.8%, while Euronext dropped 3.0%. However, UBS Group rose 1.1% after estimating a one-off gain from the takeover of Credit Suisse. The US debt ceiling talks are ongoing, with a deadline looming, and a cautious mood prevails in global markets.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.4 per cent lower, with the retail sector taking the biggest hit.

site_title: Next five years set to be hottest period ever: UN
summary: The UN's World Meteorological Organization (WMO) warns that the next five years (2023-2027) will be the hottest period ever recorded, with a 98% likelihood of at least one year exceeding the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C target. Global temperatures have been rising steadily since 2015, with a 66% chance of annual surface temperatures exceeding 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels during 2023-2027. The WMO attributes this to the combination of greenhouse gases and El Niño, a warming weather phenomenon that will push global temperatures into uncharted territory.

images.alt_text: With scientists warning that 2023 will likely be another year marked by dangerously high temperatures, signs of strain are emerging across Asia as the heat wave that started in April continues to blast through the region.

site_title: Sony plans US$1.5 billion buyback after warning of weak demand
summary: Sony plans a $1.5 billion share buyback, citing weak global consumer spending. The Tokyo-based electronics firm will spend up to 200 billion yen (S$2 billion) to buy up to 25 million shares, marking its latest move in a string of buybacks. The company warned of a slump in the global mobile market and fewer PlayStation Studios games this fiscal year, contributing to the decision. This move follows other Japanese firms executing buybacks, with investors expecting more to follow as the country's stock exchange pushes companies to lift market values.

site_title: Apac entities’ climate disclosures on par with North America, but lag Europe
summary: Organisations in the Asia-Pacific region have "average" environmental disclosure ratings, comparable to those in North America, but lag behind Europe, Middle East, and Africa. Energy companies generally performed well, with oil and gas companies among the top sectors in terms of emissions disclosure. However, entities in the Asia-Pacific showed the least improvement in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and natural-resource consumption, and lag their counterparts in Latin America.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Generic photo of greenery in city state Singapore. For stories regarding ESG, sustainability, sustainability investing, and business environmental governance
Developing Asia – which relies on steady and cheap access to power, currently coal generated for the most part, for economic growth – cannot simply replace coal with renewable energy.

site_title: Prince Harry, wife Meghan in 'near catastrophic car chase' with paparazzi
summary: Prince Harry and his wife Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, were involved in a near catastrophic car chase with paparazzi photographers in New York after attending an awards ceremony. The pursuit lasted over two hours, resulting in multiple near collisions and endangering pedestrians and NYPD officers. The incident is a reminder of the intense media harassment the couple has spoken out against, with Harry blaming it for his mother Princess Diana's death. The couple stepped down from royal roles in 2020 to escape the harassment.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 5, 2022 Britain's Meghan, Duchess of Sussex and Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, react as they attend the annual One Young World Summit at Bridgewater Hall in Manchester, northwest England. - Prince Harry and his wife Meghan are being evicted from their home on the British royal family's Windsor estate, leaving them without a UK base, reports said on March 1, 2023. Frogmore Cottage, which they refurbished at a reported cost of £2.4 million ($2.9 million), had been a wedding present from the late Queen Elizabeth II in 2018. It has now been offered to Prince Andrew, King Charles III's disgraced brother, reports in The Sun and Daily Telegraph said. (Photo by Oli SCARFF / AFP)

site_title: ST Engineering sets up joint venture with Chinese cargo carrier SF Airlines
summary: ST Engineering has established a joint venture with Chinese cargo airline SF Airlines, holding a 60% stake in the company. The joint venture, operating a greenfield airframe facility in China's Hubei province, will provide airframe maintenance, repair, and overhaul services to cargo and passenger airlines in Asia. The first hangar facility is set to be ready in 2025, with ST Engineering's president stating that China will be a "strong growth driver" for the commercial aerospace sector over the next decade.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The notes will be issued under the S$5 billion global medium term note programme, which is unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by ST Engineering.
ST Engineering Q1 revenue up 13% to S$2.3 billion on growth in most segments

site_title: Deutsche Bank seeks 40% cut to Frankfurt offices on remote work
summary: Deutsche Bank is seeking to cut its Frankfurt office space by 40% due to the shift to remote work, following a growing trend among companies. The German lender expects to achieve this reduction by the end of 2024, with almost two-thirds of its employees working from home at least three days a week. This move is part of the company's efforts to adapt to the post-pandemic work landscape.

images.alt_text: The Deutsche Bank headquarters in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Black Sea grain deal extended for two months
summary: The Ukraine Black Sea grain deal has been extended for two months, just one day before Russia was set to quit the pact. The deal, brokered by the UN and Turkey, aims to help tackle a global food crisis by allowing Ukraine to export grain and fertilizers. The extension comes after Moscow initially appeared unwilling to extend the pact unless its own agricultural exports were met with certain demands. The deal has helped export 30.3 million tonnes of grain and foodstuffs, including aid shipments to several countries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Vessels are seen as they wait for inspection under United Nation's Black Sea Grain Initiative in the southern anchorage of the Bosphorus in Istanbul, Turkey December 11, 2022. REUTERS/Yoruk Isik//File Photo
Brokered by the United Nations (UN) and Turkey, the deal was signed in Istanbul last July, allowing Ukraine to export more than 27 million tonnes of grain from several of its Black Sea ports.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as regional banks bounce, debt talks grind on
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by a regional bank bounce amid cautious optimism over a potential debt limit breakthrough in Washington. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 80.34 points, or 0.24%, to 33,092.48. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 12.95 points and 45.53 points, respectively.

site_title: India launches US$2 billion incentive package to boost IT hardware production
summary: India has launched a US$2 billion incentive package to boost IT hardware production, doubling the original plan. The scheme, covering laptops, servers, and personal computers, aims to attract global and Indian companies like Dell, Wistron, and Foxconn. The goal is to create nearly US$41 billion of IT products and 75,000 jobs by 2026, with the country targeting a US$300 billion annual output by 2026. The six-year program offers cash-backs for manufacturers on locally made goods exceeding an annual target.

site_title: An 1,100-year-old Hebrew Bible sells for US$38.1 million
summary: A 1,100-year-old Hebrew Bible, known as the Codex Sassoon, has sold for US$38.1 million at Sotheby's in New York. The nearly complete codex, which contains all 24 books of the Hebrew Bible except for some pages from Genesis, was purchased by the American Friends of the ANU – Museum of the Jewish People in Tel Aviv as a permanent gift. The buyer, Alfred Moses, donated funds for the acquisition, and the sale price was set at US$32.5 million, with Moses agreeing to receive a prearranged cut of the total if the price exceeded that amount.

images.alt_text: The Codex Sassoon is more than 1,000 years old and is one of only two codices containing all 24 books of the Hebrew Bible to have survived into the modern era.

site_title: Challenging backdrop for alternative assets warrants caution
summary: Higher interest rates and lower growth have strained alternative assets such as private equity, with some segments showing significant headwinds. Despite diversification benefits, lower correlations with traditional stocks and bonds, and higher returns, investors should demand a higher risk premium for illiquid alternatives. Private equity, which flourished in 2021, saw a significant slowdown in 2022, with fewer exits and lower valuations. Private credit funds, a more attractive alternative, are expected to deliver average annual returns of 8.4% between 2021 and 2027, down from a historical return of 9.4%. Prudence dictates modest allocations to alternatives, recalibrating return expectations.

site_title: EU customs reform to target online sellers like Amazon, Alibaba
summary: The European Union proposed a customs reform to target online sellers like Amazon, Alibaba, and Zalando, aiming to streamline reporting requirements and ensure compliance with customs obligations. The reform includes introducing data-driven systems, a single EU interface, and artificial intelligence to predict problems before goods are shipped to the EU. Platforms will have to charge customs duties and VAT at the time of purchase, eliminating hidden charges. The proposal aims to simplify the customs system for e-commerce parcels, generating an additional 1 billion euros in customs revenue per year.

site_title: BOE’s Bailey warns of inflation persistence in UK
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey warned of persistent inflation in the UK, citing high food prices despite expectations of moderation. Food producers expect costs to decrease, but uncertainty remains on when this will impact consumer prices. Bailey reaffirmed his commitment to the UK's 2% inflation target, noting that the current economic conditions are the "biggest test" yet of the inflation-targeting regime. He expects inflation to fall sharply in the coming months due to lower energy costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Commuters walk across the London Bridge during the morning rush hour, amid an outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), in London, Britain September 17, 2020. REUTERS/Hannah McKay

site_title: Icing on cake for Keppel’s many reboots in recent years
summary: Keppel Corp has announced its latest "grow fast, grow big" move under CEO Loh Chin Hua, aiming to transition from a conglomerate to a "differentiated global alternative real asset manager and operator". This shift involves integrating its diverse businesses in real estate, data centers, infrastructure, and connectivity, effectively escaping the "conglomerate discount" that affects such stocks. The move is seen as a significant change effort in a rapidly changing landscape, aiming to position Keppel as a leading player in the real asset management sector.

images.alt_text: 0503 Darwis 吉宝企业提供照片 Suggested caption: Mr Loh Chin Hua, CEO of Keppel Corporation briefing media and analysts on Keppel’s major reorganisation to fast-track its transformation into a global alternative real asset manager and operator
Anita Gabriel

site_title: IMF's Gopinath sees 'sizeable' upside inflation risks, says markets too optimistic
summary: IMF's Gita Gopinath warns of "sizeable" upside inflation risks in emerging markets, urging central banks to keep monetary policies tight. Despite encouraging signs, Gopinath believes price pressures are entrenched and inflation may accelerate. Markets are too optimistic about bringing down inflation, and insufficient monetary tightening may necessitate more painful actions. She advises fiscal restraint and judicious use of financial tools to support the fight against inflation. Gopinath also notes that emerging market economies face considerable downside risks from monetary policy tightening in advanced economies.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo is displayed outside its headquarters in Washington, DC, on October 8, 2022. The International Monetary Fund warned May 11, 2023 of severe consequences if the US defaults on its debt, ahead of a rapidly-approaching deadline for the country to raise or suspend its debt ceiling. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: Nintendo sells 10 million copies of Zelda in three days
summary: Nintendo sold over 10 million copies of its latest Zelda game, Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom, within three days of its release, making it the fastest-selling game in the series' history. This achievement surpasses other blockbuster releases, including Hogwarts Legacy, and is expected to boost Nintendo's profits and prolong the life of its Switch console, which is nearing the end of its lifespan. The game has received widespread critical acclaim, with a 96 out of 100 Metacritic score.

images.alt_text: The game featuring the exploits of Princess Zelda and the elf-like warrior Link has sold 125 million copies worldwide since its first edition in 1986.
“We try to not only put one system in every home, but several in every home, or even one for every person,” Nintendo said in a statement accompanying its earnings report on Tuesday (May 9). T

site_title: Insurtech startup Bolttech raises US$196 million in Series B round
summary: Singapore-headquartered insurtech startup Bolttech has raised US$196 million in its Series B funding round, increasing its valuation to US$1.6 billion. Insurance group Tokio Marine led the round, joined by MetLife and Malaysia's Khazanah Nasional. The funds will be used to enhance technology and talent, as well as fuel international expansion through potential acquisitions.

site_title: Yuan slides past seven per dollar in new warning sign for China’s economy
summary: The Chinese yuan slid past 7 per dollar for the first time this year, signaling a slowdown in the country's economic recovery. The currency fell over 4% from its January high due to lackluster economic data, including slower-than-expected factory output, retail sales, and fixed-asset investment in April. This weakening of the yuan is a warning sign for China's economy, which is struggling to regain momentum after its Covid restrictions were lifted.

site_title: Singapore has to be consistent, credible and principled in navigating China-US rivalry: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of Singapore being consistent, credible, and principled in navigating the China-US rivalry. The country aims to maintain good relations with both powers, but cannot prescribe policy. Wong believes open communication is key to preventing misunderstandings and managing differences. He expressed optimism about recent high-level talks between China and the US, and hopes Singapore can facilitate better mutual understanding. Wong's visit to China aimed to build rapport with Beijing and explore opportunities for cooperation, including restoring flights and reinstating a visa-free policy.

site_title: S$1.56 billion in Enhanced CPF Housing Grants given out to nearly 50,000 households since 2019: HDB
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has given out S$1.56 billion in Enhanced CPF Housing Grants (EHG) to nearly 50,000 households since its introduction in 2019. The number of households and grant amounts have increased each year, in line with more flats being sold. The EHG provides up to S$80,000 to lower- and middle-income families buying their first new or resale flat, and has helped households service their HDB loans using their monthly CPF contributions.

images.alt_text: The new HDB Flat Eligibility letter would give buyers a clearer picture of their purchase costs and financing options.
The project will offer a total of 984 units across five residential blocks ranging from 22 to 28 storeys.
SRX

site_title: Safe-haven US dollar climbs to 6-week high, US debt risks in focus
summary: The US dollar rose to a 6-week high against a basket of peers, driven by its safe-haven status amid concerns of a US debt default. The dollar index rose 0.25% to 102.86, with gains against the yen and sterling. Solid US consumer spending data and comments from Fed officials dampened expectations of near-term interest rate cuts, while a deal to raise the US debt ceiling is still uncertain. The euro fell to a 6-week low, and other currencies, such as the Turkish lira and Thai baht, also declined.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are displayed in this illustration taken, February 14, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Twitter’s new CEO will find myriad challenges awaiting at shrunken company
summary: Twitter's new CEO, Linda Yaccarino, will oversee business operations, while Elon Musk retains control of product design and technology. Yaccarino, a 60-year-old former NBCUniversal executive, is seen as a known quantity in the advertising business, which is crucial for boosting Twitter's flagging revenues. Musk's role in the company's direction remains unclear, leaving the future of Twitter's leadership uncertain. Yaccarino's appointment aims to stabilize the company, but her ability to implement changes will depend on Musk's level of involvement and support.

images.alt_text: In a sign of tough times even for Tesla, the market leader in electric cars, Elon Musk said the company would try to advertise its vehicles, something it has not done before.
Without naming Linda Yaccarino, Elon Musk says in a tweet on Thursday that he had chosen a new CEO who would begin in six weeks.

site_title: Broadcom offered remedies to address EU antitrust concerns over VMware deal: sources
summary: Broadcom has submitted remedies to address European Union antitrust concerns over its $61 billion bid for VMware, following a meeting with EU regulators. The proposal includes interoperability measures, aiming to alleviate concerns that the deal could stifle competition in the cloud computing market. The European Commission has extended its deadline for a decision to July 17, as Broadcom reiterates its aim to close the transaction in the 2023 fiscal year. The company maintains that the deal does not present competition issues and is confident that regulators will see the benefits of the combination.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Broadcom Limited company logo is shown outside one of their office complexes in Irvine, California, U.S., March 4, 2021.  REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
Broadcom announced a new chip, Jericho3-AI, which can connect up to 32,000 GPU chips together.

site_title: No Singapore Airlines group A320neos with Pratt engines grounded: Scoot CEO
summary: Singapore Airlines group A320neos with Pratt engines are not currently grounded, contrary to Go Airlines (India) claims of "faulty" engines. Scoot CEO Leslie Thng stated that the engines have spare parts available, unlike Go Airlines which had 12% of its A320neos inactive due to engine issues. Pratt & Whitney denies the engine's reliability issues, attributing the grounding to the airline's financial woes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Singapore Airlines planes sit on the tarmac at Changi Airport in Singapore December 8, 2020.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD
SIA’s board has recommended a final dividend of S$0.28 per share. Including the interim dividend of S$0.10 per share, the total dividend payout for the fiscal year stands at S$0.38 per share.

The low-cost carrier, recently rebranded as Go First, was plunged into financial crisis this year, sparked by what it called “faulty” Pratt & Whitney engines that grounded about half its 54 Airbus A320neos.
The airline, widely known as Go First, filed for bankruptcy protection last week, blaming “faulty” Pratt & Whitney engines for the grounding of about half its 54 Airbus A320neo.

site_title: Malaysia says committed to raising palm oil biodiesel mandate
summary: Malaysia commits to progressively raising its biodiesel mandate from 20% to a higher percentage, with expansion done in phases based on biodiesel blending facility readiness. This move follows Indonesia's 35% palm oil mix mandate and aims to improve environmental practices while maintaining sustainability. Malaysia and Indonesia will discuss the impact of the European Union's new deforestation law on their palm oil sectors with EU envoys at the end of May. The Council of Palm Oil Producing Countries (CPOPC) also welcomes Honduras as its third full member.

site_title: Should the ECB proceed with a digital euro?
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is considering launching a digital euro, but experts argue it's unlikely to be successful due to market saturation and the need for significant innovation to compete with existing digital payment systems. Despite growing deposits at the ECB, the popularity of cash remains steady, with many retail transactions being replaced by digital means. A digital euro would require significant investment and infrastructure, and its introduction could lead to a move away from bank deposits, potentially causing financial instability.

images.alt_text: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), during a news conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, July 21, 2022. The ECB raised its key interest rate by 50 basis points, the first increase in 11 years and the biggest since 2000 as it confronts surging inflation even as recession risks mount. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg
Britain is due to launch a public consultation in the coming weeks on what should be the legal attributes of a digital pound which backers say would mean faster transactions.
Central banks edging toward money's next frontier in digital world

The US should scale up efforts to ensure that the future of money, payments, philanthropy, and commerce remains anchored in dollars, including creating a legal and regulatory framework for the digital-asset industry, starting with legislation on stablecoins.

site_title: Charge+ to launch South-east Asia’s longest EV charging highway
summary: Charge+, a green mobility unit of Sunseap Group, is set to launch South-east Asia's longest electric vehicle (EV) charging highway spanning 5,000 km across five countries. The 45 direct current (DC) fast-charging stations will be located 120 km apart on average, with 18 stations operational by end-2024 and the rest by end-2025. The project aims to revolutionize societal perception of EVs and provide cross-border convenience, boosting confidence in the transition to EVs as the primary mode of land transport in the region.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined in April due to broad-based weakness, with NODX to China contributing the most to the decline. Economists expect the slump to persist as external demand conditions remain lacklustre. Despite this, Singapore Airlines sees robust demand for near-term and peak travel periods. Companies are encouraged to adopt intellectual property strategies for growth. Real estate investment trust CapitaLand Ascendas Reit raised S$500 million through a private placement, while Charge+ plans to develop South-east Asia's longest EV charging highway. The STI tumbled 1.3% due to weak export data.

site_title: STI tumbles 1.3% on weak export data, Wall Street’s overnight losses
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% to 3,173.84 on Wednesday, May 17, 2023, due to weak export data and overnight losses on Wall Street. The data raised concerns of a technical recession in the second quarter of 2023, with exports to China, a key trading partner, contracting sharply. Analysts warn that this could exert downward pressure on the STI in the second half of the year, with the index underperforming the rest of the world.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.4 per cent lower, with the retail sector taking the biggest hit.
Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.3%
In early Asian trade, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore and Wellington fell on Wednesday..

site_title: India's GlaxoSmithKline Pharma's pre-tax profit falls on government pricing caps
summary: GlaxoSmithKline Pharmaceuticals India reported an 8.6% drop in pre-tax profit for the fourth quarter, falling to 1.90 billion rupees (S$30.9 million), due to government pricing caps on essential medicines. Revenue from operations decreased 2.7% to 7.87 billion rupees. The decline is attributed to the government's curbs on pricing, which negatively impacted the company's profit.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: GSK (GlaxoSmithKline) logo is seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: India's top court gives market watchdog three more months to finish Adani probe
summary: India's Supreme Court granted the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) three more months to complete its investigation into Adani Group's possible securities law violations and regulatory disclosures. The probe, initially due by May 2, will now be completed by August 14. SEBI sought additional time to unravel complex transactions involving Adani's listed, unlisted, and offshore entities, following criticism from US-based short-seller Hindenburg Research in January. The regulator has formed a preliminary view on the allegations, but its findings have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: Adani's shares climbed 5.1 per cent after the earnings were announced which showed gross debt paring to 383.2 billion rupees from 410 billion rupees last year.

site_title: JD Sports' profit to top £1 billion this year
summary: JD Sports expects profit to exceed £1 billion for the first time this year, driven by its differentiated proposition attracting young shoppers. The company reported a record profit before tax and exceptional items of £991.4 million for the year to January 28, beating guidance and surpassing £947.2 million in 2021-22. For 2023-24, JD Sports forecasts £1.03 billion in profit, in line with current average consensus expectations.

site_title: Singapore businesses encouraged to adopt intellectual property strategies
summary: Singapore businesses are encouraged to adopt intellectual property strategies, with two recent studies showing a positive link between IP and business performance. The IP Office of Singapore released findings that companies with strong brands and patent portfolios had twice the revenue, net profit, and market capitalization of those without. The government aims to bring more small and medium-sized enterprises into the IP ecosystem, with a focus on innovation and branding.

images.alt_text: One way for SMEs to cope with rising costs is to innovate by tapping existing government grants to adopt the digitalisation and subsequent automation of certain back-end functions.
In recent years, homegrown brands such as Razer and Irvins have optimised their intangible assets to protect their brands and products to expand successfully overseas.

site_title: Singapore GDP growth moderating but has ‘ample fiscal space’ against downside risks: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that Singapore's economy is moderating amid a global economic slowdown, but the city-state has "ample fiscal space" to address potential downside risks. The IMF projects a 1% GDP growth for 2023, lower than its previous 1.5% forecast, driven by weak trade-oriented sectors and external headwinds. Downside risks are mostly external, including an abrupt global slowdown and premature monetary policy loosening. The IMF welcomes Singapore's tight monetary policy stance and its plans to accelerate digital adoption and innovation.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

The UN  forecasts are less than the IMF, which said earlier this year that global growth would fall to 2.9 per cent in 2023 from 3.4 per cent in 2022 and for 2024 would pick up slightly to 3.1 per cent.
The reopening of China’s economy will be pivotal for the region with the spillover to Asia seen focused on consumption and service-sector demand rather than investment, the IMF said.
IMF's chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas said Singapore’s economy will grow by 1.5 per cent this year, slower than the 3.7 per cent growth achieved in 2022.

site_title: Goldman Sachs slashes Adani Group stakes from its ESG funds
summary: Goldman Sachs reduced its stake in Adani Group companies from ESG funds to approximately 400,000 shares in Ambuja Cements following allegations of fraud by Hindenburg Research. Other asset managers, including Northern Trust and Storebrand, also cut their holdings in Adani Group companies. Despite this, Adani companies are attempting to raise up to $2.6 billion in capital, with the companies seeking shareholder approval. Adani has denied the allegations of fraud and claims the stake reduction has no impact on its fund-raising plans.

images.alt_text: Adani Transmission and Adani Total Gas will drop out of the India index effective at the close of trading on May 31, according to a statement issued by MSCI on Thursday.
Adani Enterprises, Adani Green Energy and Adani Transmission may raise between US$3 billion and US$5 billion, according to Bloomberg News.
Adani's shares climbed 5.1 per cent after the earnings were announced which showed gross debt paring to 383.2 billion rupees from 410 billion rupees last year.

site_title: France's Sarkozy loses corruption appeal, must wear electronic tag
summary: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy lost his appeal against a 2021 conviction for corruption and influence peddling at the Paris Court of Appeals. The court upheld a three-year prison sentence, with two years suspended, and Sarkozy will wear an electronic bracelet instead of serving the remaining year in jail. Sarkozy's lawyer claims he is innocent and plans to challenge the verdict at France's highest court.

images.alt_text: Ex-French president Sarkozy found guilty of corruption

site_title: SIA expects robust demand for near-term, peak periods this year
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported record earnings for FY2023, with net earnings of S$2.2 billion, surpassing previous losses. The airline expects robust demand for near-term and peak periods, driven by the recovery in air travel in East Asia. SIA is raising group capacity to 90% by March 2024, but has not resumed capacity to 100% for the Chinese market yet. Despite increased competition, passenger yields are still 20% higher than pre-pandemic levels. The airline's shares jumped 3% to S$6.10, driven by a strong dividend payout ratio of 52%.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
SIA’s board has recommended a final dividend of S$0.28 per share. Including the interim dividend of S$0.10 per share, the total dividend payout for the fiscal year stands at S$0.38 per share.
