SIA has had a 205 per cent jump in passenger numbers to 2.7 million in March; and for February, the surge was 338 per cent to 2.4 million.
SIA Engineeing Company chief executive Ng Chin Hwee warned that macroeconomic factors could weigh on the company's growth.

site_title: Oiltek bags Indonesia contracts worth RM62.1 million
summary: Oiltek International announced that its subsidiary, Oiltek Sdn Bhd, secured new contracts in Indonesia worth approximately RM62.1 million. This brings the group's current order book to a record RM393.4 million, expected to be fulfilled over the next 18 to 24 months. The new contracts are expected to positively contribute to Oiltek's financial performance in FY2023 ending December.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Following the RM101 million worth of new contracts secured in the first quarter of this year, the cumulative value of new contracts that Oiltek has won in the current year to date amounts to approximately RM157.8 million.
Oiltek, however, said it is unable to provide a definitive assessment on the financial impact of carrying out the rectification works on the group.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts positive on Cromwell E-Reit on attractive distribution yield, stable operating metrics
summary: Analysts from DBS Group Research, RHB, and UBS maintain a "buy" rating on Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) due to its stable operating performance and attractive distribution yield. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rate and positive rent reversion are key indicators of its current health. The analysts' target prices range from 2.10 euros to 2.17 euros, implying a potential upside of 38.2% to 42.8% from its last trading price.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
The Reit also reports gains in both gross revenue and net property income thanks to higher portfolio occupancy.

site_title: Eurozone housing investment weakened by higher rates, ECB says
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) warns that housing investment in the euro area will decline further due to tighter monetary policy and stagnating real disposable income. Despite initial resilience, the negative effects of higher interest rates are expected to intensify over time. The mortgage markets in the euro area are less deep than those in the US, making it less affected by recent central-bank tightening. The ECB projects a substantial decline in housing investment in the short term and a weak outlook for the projection horizon.

site_title: Hong Kong banks hike deposit rates as cash conditions tighten
summary: Hong Kong banks have raised deposit rates to attract retail money amid tightening cash conditions. Nearly a dozen banks have increased rates over the past two weeks, with some offering 3.9-4% per year on three-month deposits. The move follows a sharp fall in banking system liquidity, with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's aggregate balance at its lowest since 2008. Analysts attribute the rise in interbank rates to growing loan demand and international appetite for Chinese assets cooling.

images.alt_text: In Hong Kong, most variable rate home loans have a cap based on the prime lending rate. Major lenders have raised that rate by about 75 basis points since last year.
The HKMA has been draining liquidity from the banking system to boost the local dollar, and reduce a gauge of interbank liquidity to its lowest since 2008.

site_title: Wall Street bosses warn US debt talks are already doing damage
summary: Wall Street executives are urging the Biden administration and Congress to raise the US debt ceiling, warning that failure to do so could lead to catastrophic consequences for businesses, investors, and the economy. The industry is preparing for the worst-case scenario, with banks assigning workers and executives to study the effects of a default. Executives from major banks, including JPMorgan and Citigroup, are calling for swift action to avoid a prolonged standoff, which could hurt confidence in US creditworthiness and raise costs for taxpayers.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden announces that he will be cutting his upcoming trip to Asia short and will return to Washington earlier than planned, to continue US debt ceiling negotiations, Washington, May 16, 2023.

site_title: Indonesia communications minister arrested for graft
summary: Indonesian Communications Minister Johnny G Plate was arrested on corruption charges, marking the fifth minister in President Joko Widodo's administration to be charged with graft. The arrest was made in a case that allegedly caused over $500 million in state losses due to the procurement of equipment for building thousands of communications towers. Plate's ministry had claimed the project would bring internet access to thousands of villages. The Attorney General's Office made the arrest on May 17, 2023.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as sluggish debt talks worry investors H
summary: Asia's markets fell on Wednesday as US debt talks continued to stall, despite a boost from Japan's forecast-beating economic growth data. Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other Asian markets declined, while Seoul, Taipei, and Jakarta edged up. The US debt ceiling standoff has raised concerns about a potential market-rattling default, which could have global economic implications. Japanese stocks, however, rose after the country's economy grew more than expected in the first quarter, driven by a surge in tourism.

images.alt_text: In early trade, Asian markets struggled to extend on Monday’s strong performance.

site_title: Credit Suisse faces restrictions on business till deal closure
summary: Credit Suisse faces restrictions on business until its acquisition by UBS Group is completed. The bank cannot undertake capital expenditure exceeding 10 million francs or enter contracts worth more than 3 million francs per year. It also cannot grant credit facilities exceeding 100 million francs to investment-grade borrowers or 50 million francs to non-investment grade borrowers. UBS has set aside US$4 billion for potential litigation and regulatory issues. The acquisition is expected to result in a "negative goodwill" of US$34.8 billion for UBS.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The sign and logo of Credit Suisse bank is seen at their headquarters in Zurich on March 20, 2023. - More than $68 billion had been withdrawn from Credit Suisse in the first three months of 2023, the bank said on April 24, 2023 in what are likely its final quarterly results before it is swallowed by rival UBS. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)

site_title: Japan visitors rise to nearly 2 million in April after China eases travel curbs
summary: Japan welcomed nearly 2 million foreign visitors in April, a post-pandemic high, driven by China's easing of travel restrictions. The number of visitors rose to 1.95 million, up 7.7% from March, with 108,300 Chinese arrivals, a 43% increase from March. Despite a 33% decline from pre-pandemic levels, the weak yen has made trips to Japan the cheapest they have been in years, with tourism expected to continue to rise as international flights from China increase.

site_title: Taiwan’s Kuomintang picks New Taipei City mayor as presidential candidate
summary: Taiwan's Kuomintang (KMT) party has selected New Taipei City mayor Hou Yu-ih as its presidential candidate for the 2024 election, with polls showing he has a better shot at winning than Foxconn founder Terry Gou. The decision was made based on polling data and senior party opinions, with Hou trailing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) William Lai by about 5-10 percentage points. The election is set to take place at a time of increased tensions between Taipei and Beijing, with the KMT favouring close ties with China.

site_title: Shell to use new AI technology in deep sea oil exploration
summary: Shell is using artificial intelligence technology from SparkCognition to improve operational efficiency and speed in its deep sea oil exploration and production. The AI algorithms will analyze large amounts of seismic data to find new oil reservoirs in the US Gulf of Mexico. According to Shell's vice-president, the company is committed to finding innovative ways to boost offshore oil output. The partnership aims to increase production and success in exploration, with the goal of improving operational efficiency and speed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The Shell logo is seen at a Shell petrol station in London, Britain, January 31, 2008. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo/File Photo
A view shows a logo of Shell petrol station in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James

site_title: Commerzbank profits soar on higher interest rates
summary: Commerzbank, Germany's second-largest lender, reported a significant increase in net profit to 580 million euros (S$844.9 million) in the first quarter, nearly doubling its profit from the same period last year. The bank attributes the surge to higher interest rates, which have benefited its fee business. Quarterly revenues fell slightly to 2.7 billion euros, mainly due to charges related to legal costs. Commerzbank aims for a full-year net profit "well above" 2022 levels, following a successful turnaround strategy that has included job cuts and digitalization efforts.

images.alt_text: epa10493444 Banners of German Commerzbank AG hang at the building of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, 27 February 2023. Commerzbank AG will return into the group of 40 businesses listed in German Stock Market Index DAX with opening of stock trading on 27 February morning. The bank lost its rank in the DAX in autumn 2018 due to severe loss in their stocks value. The bank, that was one of the founding businesses of the DAX, can now return due to the withdrawal of the Linde company from trading at the Franfurt Stock exchange, the 'Deutsche Boerse Group' said on their website.  EPA-EFE/RONALD WITTEK

A sign for Deutsche Bank AG at a bank branch in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. Deutsche Bank vowed to increase profit and revenue further this year, after snapping a long streak of market share gains in trading in the final quarter of Chief Executive Officer Christian Sewing's turnaround plan. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Disruption will always be capitalism’s secret sauce
summary: The term "disruption" in the business world has become oversold, leading to its decline in usage. Ten years ago, startups and venture capitalists sought to "disrupt" every industry, but many industries remained resilient, and some that adopted disruption came to regret it. According to Harvard Business School professor Clayton Christensen, only 9% of his 77 cases of disruptive innovation ultimately succeeded. As a result, companies have shifted to using terms like "transformation" and "advanced" to describe innovation, highlighting the need for a more nuanced approach to disruption.

images.alt_text: Rampant public-service strikes in Britain, Germany and France, which has also suffered eruptions of street chaos, may point to the most concerted fightback yet seen after decades when employees suffered declining proceeds from countries’ national incomes.
Corporate activism: Barbarians at the gate no more

site_title: Tencent’s revenue grows most in over a year after China reopens
summary: Tencent Holdings reported its fastest revenue growth in over a year, with 11% growth to 150 billion yuan (S$28.8 billion) in the three months ended March. The company's net income rose to 25.8 billion yuan, beating projections. The growth suggests the return to robust growth for mainstay internet businesses in China, despite regulatory challenges and the post-pandemic reopening. This positive trend may indicate a recovery for the global tech industry.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on July 10, 2022 shows a man walking past the Tencent headquarters in Shenzhen, in China's southern Guangdong province. - Chinese tech giant Tencent suffered a 16 percent decline in annual net profit year on year in 2022, according to an earnings report released on March 22, 2023. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP)

site_title: Car COE premiums fall in first tender after quota increase; open category hits record S$125,000
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for cars fell in the first tender since a quota increase, with the Open category hitting a record high of S$125,000. Motorcycle COE premiums rebounded to S$10,602, more than twice the price set two weeks ago. COE premiums for smaller cars and electric vehicles dropped, while commercial vehicle COE premiums rose slightly. The price fluctuations are attributed to ongoing market adjustments and efforts to curb speculation.

images.alt_text: The COE as a one-size-fits-all traffic management tool is too blunt, given the technology we have today.
COE prices will continue to rise as incomes grow and supply remains limited, says Iswaran.
Government studying COE market, ready to refine it if needed: Iswaran

The COE premium for smaller cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp, as well as for electric vehicles (EVs) with up to 110 kilowatts of power, finished at S$101,001, down 2.6 per cent from the previous high of S$103,721 at the April 19 tender.

site_title: Vietnam EV maker Vinfast expects to break even by end-2024
summary: Vietnam's electric vehicle maker VinFast expects to break even by the end of 2024, according to its founder Pham Nhat Vuong. The company plans to launch an electric vehicle pickup truck and a city car as future models. VinFast's special purpose acquisition company (Spac) deal is expected to close in the second half of 2023, paving the way for the company's entry into the US and European markets. The company received US$2.5 billion in funding pledges from Vietnam's largest conglomerate and its founder.

site_title: Restructurings spreading across Indonesia’s construction sector
summary: Indonesia's construction sector is facing concerns about a ballooning debt burden as PT Wijaya Karya, the nation's largest listed construction company, seeks restructuring. The company has asked banks to delay payments on its liabilities as it reorganizes debt and strengthens its capital. This move follows a record first-quarter loss reported by the firm and is part of a larger issue affecting Indonesia's construction push, which has seen the country's four biggest construction firms see their debt load swell to roughly 130 trillion rupiah.

images.alt_text: Indonesia announced in 2019 a plan to move its capital city from Jakarta to a forested area in Indonesian Borneo, a project estimated to cost US$32 billion.

site_title: Smaller consultancies eye opportunities as China crackdown hits sector leader
summary: China's crackdown on firms supplying sensitive information to foreigners has created an opportunity for smaller consultancy and due-diligence firms. With market leader Capvision facing repercussions, these firms see a chance to fill the gap and provide expert knowledge to foreign companies seeking to navigate China's regulatory landscape. The market for expert insights is estimated to nearly double to $1.9 billion by 2025, driven by foreign companies' growing demand for compliance and due diligence.

images.alt_text: A man walks past screens showing stock information at a brokerage house in Jiujiang, Jiangxi province, China October 8, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer

Futu Holdings and Up Fintech Holding, also known as Tiger Brokers, said on Tuesday that the move was to comply with the Chinese securities regulator’s requirements on cross-border brokerage businesses.

site_title: Bringing automation to clinics
summary: Singaporean software vendor Plato Medical is automating front-desk processes in clinics using its clinic management system, allowing doctors to run without receptionists. The system, Plato, enables automated appointment scheduling, patient registration, and billing, as well as digital medical records and task management. The company's growth has been driven by the Healthier SG initiative, which requires clinics to integrate with the National Electronic Health Records system. Plato has 2,100 doctors subscribed to its service, with annual revenue of S$4.7 million, and expects to maintain a 25% year-on-year growth rate.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The interest in preventive health technology has been rising globally.

site_title: Thailand’s opposition parties meet for coalition talks
summary: Thailand's opposition parties met for coalition talks on May 17, 2023, following the liberal Move Forward Party's victory in the recent election. The party, led by Pita Limjaroenrat, looks to form a government, but Senate opposition and intense political jockeying may delay the process. Analysts warn that this could lead to a delayed new budget bill for 2023-24, potentially extending the delay into next year. The talks come after the military-allied parties were defeated by Move Forward, a major blow to Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's establishment.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat  waves to his supporters during a victory parade in Bangkok on May 15, 2023.

site_title: Siemens raises full year outlook after Q2 sales beats forecasts
summary: Siemens has raised its full-year sales and profit guidance after beating sales forecasts in its second quarter. The company expects 9-11% comparable revenue growth and a 9.60-9.90 euros increase in underlying basic earnings per share. Siemens' second-quarter revenue jumped 14% to 19.42 billion euros, exceeding forecasts, and its industrial profit rose 47% to 2.61 billion euros. The company's order backlog increased to 105 billion euros, with its CEO citing "outstanding performance" and "impressive margin increases."

images.alt_text: “We take this seriously and we are looking into this. We cannot reveal any information about the identity of the person due to data protection laws,” Siemens said on Friday (Mar 31).
The results of Siemens, whose sensors, components and software are used in factories, transport systems and buildings are seen as indicators for the health of the broader industrial economy.

site_title: SBF leads innovation workshop in South Korea for Singapore companies
summary: A delegation of 20 senior business representatives from 16 Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) is visiting South Korea as part of the Overseas Market Workshop, organized by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and supported by Enterprise Singapore. The trip includes visits to major South Korean companies, such as Naver and SK Telecom, and networking sessions with member companies from Daedeok Innopolis Venture Association. The workshop aims to help Singapore companies learn from South Korean innovation and establish partnerships to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Hainan Jones has had to adapt and improvise, to get the taste of its chicken rice in New York as close as possible to the original from Singapore.
One advantage of Indonesia is the market of about 280 million people, but SBF's country head for Indonesia Hisyaamuddin Abu Bakar noted that the Indonesia market is a “marathon game” for companies.

The KSDPA’s “expeditious” entry into force is reflective of Singapore and South Korea’s commitment towards integrating both countries’ digital ecosystems to unlock new growth opportunities for businesses, says the authorities.

site_title: Nikkei closes above 30,000, first in 20 months
summary: Japan's Nikkei index closed above 30,000 for the first time in 20 months, ending the day up 0.84% at 30,093.59, driven by a weaker yen and strong domestic earnings season. The broader Topix index rose 0.3%, also reaching a 33-year peak. Analysts note that the gains may be short-lived, with some predicting a potential adjustment to around 28,700.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei share average rose 0.8 per cent to 29,626.34, its highest close November 2021.

site_title: China’s Baidu confident its AI chatbot won’t make mistakes on ‘sensitive topics’
summary: Baidu CEO Robin Li expressed confidence that its AI chatbot, Ernie, won't make mistakes on sensitive topics due to its experience in tailoring its search engine to Chinese regulatory requirements. The company is waiting for government approval before launching Ernie, which has been found to refuse answering questions on politics, particularly those related to Chinese government leaders. Li emphasized the need to prevent "hallucination" in AI models, where they generate outputs different from expectations, for important and sensitive topics.

images.alt_text: Baidu’s results suggest China’s largest Internet firms are making some headway in revival efforts after two years of regulatory crackdowns and Covid restrictions.
China's artficial intelligence industry is dealing with a shortage of both talent and chips as companies seek to meet growing demand.

site_title: Singapore key exports to extend slump on broad-based weakness, slow China reopening: economists
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 9.8% in April, the seventh consecutive month of decline, as external demand conditions remained weak. NODX to China, the largest market, fell 20.9% year-on-year, deepening from March's 14.1% decline. Economists expect the weakness to persist, with some predicting a recession in Singapore, citing weak expectations for the eurozone and Germany. The global electronics industry demand turnaround may be pushed out to end-2023 or early 2024, according to some forecasts.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Both electronics (-22.3 per cent) and non-electronics (-4.7 per cent) record year-on-year export declines in March.
xxx

site_title: UBS flags US$17 billion hit from Credit Suisse takeover
summary: UBS estimates a negative financial impact of approximately US$17 billion from its takeover of Credit Suisse Group, including US$13 billion from fair value adjustments and US$4 billion in potential litigation and regulatory costs. However, the deal is expected to result in a one-off gain of US$34.8 billion from "negative goodwill." The financial cushion may help absorb potential losses and boost UBS's second-quarter profit if the transaction closes next month as planned.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The sign and logo of Credit Suisse bank is seen at their headquarters in Zurich on March 20, 2023. - More than $68 billion had been withdrawn from Credit Suisse in the first three months of 2023, the bank said on April 24, 2023 in what are likely its final quarterly results before it is swallowed by rival UBS. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)

site_title: UK to crack down on landlords in private rental sector shake-up
summary: The UK government plans to introduce the Renters' Reform Bill, which will abolish "section 21" evictions, give renters more power to challenge poor standards, and provide extra protections for millions of people in England. The bill will also allow renters to request pets in their homes and introduce a new ombudsman to settle disputes with landlords. However, landlords have expressed concerns about the impact on the rental market, citing higher mortgage costs and stricter regulation. The bill aims to improve the lives of 11 million people renting from private landlords and address the UK's housing woes.

images.alt_text: In the UK, more than a third of fixed-rate mortgages on rental properties – known as buy-to-let – are due to end in the next two years, leaving landlords vulnerable to the highest interest rates since 2008.

site_title: Telehealth startup ORA bags US$10 million in Series A round led by TNB Aura, Antler
summary: ORA, a Singapore-based vertically integrated telehealth platform, has secured US$10 million in Series A funding led by TNB Aura and Antler. The funding brings ORA's total investment to over US$17 million. The startup plans to use the funds to expand into new regions and develop new products, with its brands expected to be available in 1,300 retail stores later this year.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit’s private placement closes at S$2.727 apiece; upsizes placement to raise S$500 million
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's private placement has closed at S$2.727 per unit, with 183.3 million new units issued and gross proceeds of S$500 million. The issue price represents a 5.1% discount to the volume-weighted average price (VWAP) of S$2.8727 per unit. The private placement, which was 3.1 times subscribed, drew strong demand from new and existing institutional, accredited, and other investors.

images.alt_text: The acquisition of The Shugart from Seagate Singapore is expected to be distribution per unit (DPU) accretive to unitholders, said CapitaLand Ascendas Reit manager.

site_title: Jokowi rallies Global South to follow commodities refining path
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is rallying developing countries to follow his country's path in deriving wealth from natural resources by refining and processing raw materials, rather than just exporting them. Since Indonesia forced companies to refine nickel onshore, the metal's exports value has surged tenfold in five years. The country is now planning to process other commodities like copper and fish, and urging other nations, such as the Philippines and Democratic Republic of Congo, to follow suit.

images.alt_text: awtanker4 - An oil tanker is docked near fuel tanks at Tanjung Priok Port in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Tuesday, July 13, 2021. Indonesia will release trade figures on July 15. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
The global nickel market is facing a massive oversupply this year due to surging Indonesian output.

site_title: Japan ramps up G7 security after PM attacks
summary: Japan is ramping up security for the upcoming G7 summit in Hiroshima, with 24,000 security personnel deployed to the city and surrounding areas. The measures come after a series of high-profile attacks on Japanese officials, including the 2022 assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Security checks are being conducted at major train stations, and public areas such as Peace Park and the Atomic Bomb Dome are being sealed off. The measures aim to provide a "peace of mind" for summit guests, with leaders from G7 members and invitees including Brazilian and Indian presidents set to attend the May 19-21 talks.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden announces that he will be cutting his upcoming trip to Asia short and will return to Washington earlier than planned, to continue US debt ceiling negotiations, Washington, May 16, 2023.

Okonomiyaki is a pancake-shaped mix of noodles, cabbage, egg, meat and seafood, topped with a distinctive sweet and sour sauce and fried on a hot metal plate. It is a local speciality in Hiroshima, western Japan.
The G7 finance leaders are expected to set a year-end deadline for launching a new scheme to diversify global supply chains.

site_title: Elon Musk warns of tough economy, says Tesla not immune
summary: Elon Musk warned of a difficult global economy for the next 12 months, impacting even Tesla, the market leader in electric cars. Musk stated that the company would attempt to advertise its vehicles, a first for Tesla. Additionally, he announced a third-party audit of cobalt mines supplying Tesla with key battery ingredients. Musk emphasized Tesla's resilience in a slow economy, where the company is still making more money than competitors.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s Shanghai plant, its largest worldwide, produced about 726,000 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles in 2022, more than half of the automaker’s global sales.
Elon Musk plans to turn Twitter into an “everything app”, with a variety of features to entice new users including financial services.
The billionaire is expected to address Tesla shareholders on Tuesday at the automaker’s annual meeting at its headquarters in Austin, Texas.

site_title: Singapore home to world’s largest production facility for jet fuel made from waste materials
summary: Singapore is now home to the world's largest production facility for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), made from waste materials like used cooking oil and animal fats, after Finnish energy giant Neste expanded its Tuas South refinery. The facility can produce up to 1 million tonnes of SAF annually, a 10-fold increase, and is expected to ramp up production throughout 2023. This expansion is part of Neste's 1.6 billion euros project, which aims to reduce carbon emissions in the aviation sector, with SAF expected to contribute 65% of the reduction needed by 2050.

images.alt_text: OCBC's chief executive officer Helen Wong (middle), head of global whole banking Tan Teck Long (left) and head of global wholesale banking sustainability office Mike Ng (right) announcing the bank's decarbonisation targets on May 16, 2023.
The sustainable aviation fuel targets are the EU’s attempt to cut flight emissions pending breakthrough technologies such as zero-emission aircraft, which are not expected for at least a decade.

site_title: In pursuing peace, Japan’s leader must also prepare for war
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is hosting the G7 summit in Hiroshima, a city devastated by an atomic bombing, amidst a backdrop of increasing tensions over nuclear disarmament and military expansion. Kishida has a lifelong commitment to denuclearization but is overseeing the greatest expansion of Japanese military power since World War II. The summit will focus on Ukraine and China's increasing assertiveness, with little hope for concrete steps on denuclearization. US support for Japan's military expansion has helped Kishida lift a decades-old cap on defense spending, but progress on denuclearization seems distant.

images.alt_text: A woman walks past a “G7 Hiroshima” flower installation near the Peace Memorial Museum, ahead of the G7 summit, in Hiroshima, Japan, May 17, 2023. REUTERS/Androniki Christodoulou

site_title: Japan arranging subsidies for Samsung chip facility: source
summary: Japan is arranging subsidies worth 15 billion yen (S$147 million) for Samsung Electronics to construct a chip facility in Japan, including its first chip packaging test line. The facility, estimated to cost 40 billion yen, would be subsidized by the Japanese government, with about a third of the cost covered. The move comes as Japan and South Korea ease tensions and the US urges allies to counter China's rising influence in chips and other technologies. Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida plans to meet with Samsung executives to strengthen multilateral cooperation.

images.alt_text: A Samsung flag flutters outside the company's Seocho building in Seoul on April 27, 2023. - Samsung Electronics on April 27, reported its worst quarterly profits in 14 years, blaming slowing consumer spending on electronics and a global microchip glut that hit its core memory business. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: Crypto should be regulated like gambling: UK lawmakers
summary: UK lawmakers recommend regulating cryptocurrencies like the gambling industry due to their lack of oversight, price volatility, and potential for substantial gains or losses. The global cryptocurrency market has fallen from a peak of $3.0 trillion to $1.1 trillion since 2021, with the industry being rocked by scandals. Britain's Conservative government seeks to establish a regulatory framework for crypto, while the EU has approved world's first comprehensive crypto rules to protect investors.

images.alt_text: Dogecoin and shiba inu, the eighth and 15th largest cryptocurrencies respectively, often experience wild price swings.
Regulating crypto has become more urgent for regulators after the collapse of crypto exchange FTX.

Memecoin booms typically start during frothy periods; once the frenzy fades – as it inevitably does – most traders lose their funds, and have less to invest back in Bitcoin and Ether, says Arca's Kyle Doane.

site_title: China’s home-price growth slows as housing rebound fizzles
summary: China's home-price growth slowed in April, with new-home prices rising 0.32% and secondary market prices increasing 0.01%. This marks a reversal from a brief recovery, underscoring the challenges facing the property market. The slowdown is a concern for the country's economic growth outlook, as the property sector accounts for about 20% of GDP. The results suggest the housing market rebound fizzled, leaving investors and policymakers to monitor the situation closely.

images.alt_text: Industrial output grew 5.6 per cent in April from a year earlier.
The jobless rate for 16 to 24-year-olds hit 20.4 per cent last month, nearly four times the national rate, data from the National Bureau of Statistics showed.

site_title: Aon launches new climate innovation hub in Singapore
summary: Aon launches a new climate innovation hub in Singapore to provide clients with better analytical capabilities and solutions on environmental risk and opportunities. The hub, housed under Aon's Centre for Innovation and Analytics, aims to grow to over 350 people in the next 10 years. The partnership with the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) will help identify local talent, pursue innovation, and develop new solutions to tackle climate and sustainability challenges. The hub complements Singapore's growing ecosystem of sustainability solutions providers and supports businesses meeting their climate commitments.

site_title: New Zealand budget to show rising debt, wider deficits as economy slows
summary: New Zealand's Finance Minister Grant Robertson is set to deliver a "no frills" budget on Thursday, May 18, with little room for significant spending or tax relief ahead of a general election in October. The budget is expected to show rising debt and wider deficits due to a slowing economy, with economists predicting a recession in 2023. The government's forecasted budget deficit will likely be NZ$3 billion in 2024, and a sixth straight deficit in 2025 before a return to surplus in 2026.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand’s quarterly survey of expectations showed business managers forecast annual inflation to average 4.28 per cent over the coming year, easing from 5.11 per cent in the previous survey in the first quarter.

site_title: Pfizer sells US$31 billion of bonds in fourth-largest deal ever
summary: Pfizer sold $31 billion in bonds, the fourth-largest US bond sale ever, to finance its $43 billion acquisition of Seagen. The deal, which surpassed AT&T and AbbVie's previous offerings, was oversubscribed with $85 billion in orders. Pfizer modified the deal's terms after the US sued to block Amgen's $27.8 billion deal to buy Horizon Therapeutics, citing concerns over competition. The deal's terms imply swift debt repayment, with the company's balance sheet capable of absorbing the acquisition without significant damage.

images.alt_text: Pfizer said it expects significantly lower sales contributions from Covid products in the second quarter from the first quarter.
FILE PHOTO: Pfizer logo is seen in this illustration taken, May 1, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Stubborn cash squeeze risks derailing India’s economic recovery
summary: A cash squeeze in India is posing risks to the country's economic recovery, with short-term borrowing costs above the Reserve Bank of India's policy rate of 6.75%. The weighted average call rate has surged, and yields on one-year treasury bills exceed those on 10-year government debt, indicating a malfunctioning bond market. Economists expect the central bank to offer short-term liquidity relief but are cautious about the situation, which may linger due to the RBI's determination to fight inflation. The funding squeeze is further raising financing costs just as the economy needs cheaper funding to sustain its recovery.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea pushed back against rate cut expectations at its Apr 11 policy decision citing its goal to combat inflation.
Data released on Friday showed retail inflation slowed to 4.70 per cent – the weakest in 18 months.

site_title: Japan’s economy expands more than expected on post-Covid spending
summary: Japan's economy expanded 1.6% in the January-March period, marking the first increase in three quarters, driven by a post-Covid rebound in consumption. Private consumption grew 0.6% and capital expenditure rose 0.9%, exceeding forecasts. However, external demand was a concern, shaving off 0.3 percentage points from GDP. The growth was attributed to a delayed recovery in spending from the removal of Covid-related curbs, but sluggish global demand and rising living costs cloud the outlook for a sustained recovery.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past a sign board of Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, part of Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group Inc (SMFG) outside its branch in Tokyo, Japan, January 27, 2017.    REUTERS/Toru Hanai/File Photo
Japanese investors have historically begun each financial year as net sellers, says Prashant Newnaha, a senior Asia-Pacific rates strategist at TD Securities.
Profit is expected to rise to 841.6 billion yen at number two lender Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, which will also be an all-time high.
The data may diminish market expectations that broadening inflationary pressure will prod the BOJ to seek an early exit from ultra-low interest rates.

site_title: Indonesia’s population to fall behind Nigeria’s by 2045
summary: Indonesia's population is expected to decline by 2045, falling behind Nigeria's and Pakistan's in the world's population ranking. The country's population growth is projected to slow to 0.4% in 2045, from 1.17% last year, with the population estimated to reach 324 million. This decline is attributed to slowing birth rates, with the average annual growth rate at 0.67% in the 2020-2050 period.

images.alt_text: An initial investment plan detailing how Indonesia will green its power supply and cut greenhouse emissions is due mid-August.

awtanker4 - An oil tanker is docked near fuel tanks at Tanjung Priok Port in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Tuesday, July 13, 2021. Indonesia will release trade figures on July 15. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: If we want affordable COEs, islandwide road pricing is the way to go
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices have surged 109% in the last two years, sparking concerns about affordability. To address this, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) has introduced a one-time redistribution of 6,000 COEs, increasing the quota supply by 24% and 15% in Cat A and Cat B, respectively. However, experts argue that a more effective solution is to implement a usage-based road pricing system, where drivers pay more for driving, but are taxed less upfront when purchasing a car, to encourage a "car-lite" society and reduce congestion.

images.alt_text: Dennis Chan
BT's COE tracker
COE prices will continue to rise as incomes grow and supply remains limited, says Iswaran.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.3% to 3,205.35. The broader market saw losers outnumber gainers 67 to 53, with 69 million securities worth S$80.8 million changing hands. Notable movers included Seatrium, which rose 0.8%, and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, whose counter decreased 3.8%. US and European stocks also fell, with the Dow Jones down 1% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 index down 0.4%.

images.alt_text: ST20230303_202311925234 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.
Singapore Airlines posted its highest full-year net profit in its 76-year history, S$2.2 billion for FY2022/23.

site_title: Indonesia warns US$20 billion climate deal looks too expensive
summary: Indonesia is warning that a US$20 billion international effort to transition its power supply and cut greenhouse emissions may not materialize due to concerns over funding costs. The country's Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs & Investment, Luhut Panjaitan, says that the deal hinges on low-cost funding and that if the terms are not favorable, Indonesia will proceed with its own plans. The country's debt burden is already at 43% of its GDP, and officials are concerned that the green push could add to the debt burden if funding is not offered at low enough rates.

images.alt_text: The South-east Asian country is marketing a Samurai deal which includes several blue bond tranches.

awtanker4 - An oil tanker is docked near fuel tanks at Tanjung Priok Port in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Tuesday, July 13, 2021. Indonesia will release trade figures on July 15. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Theranos founder Holmes loses bid to stay out of prison, hit with huge restitution bill
summary: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes has been ordered to pay $452 million in restitution to victims of the blood-testing startup's fraud. Holmes, convicted of misrepresenting the company's technology and finances, was also denied a request to remain out of prison while challenging her conviction. She was previously sentenced to 11 years and three months in prison. Both Holmes and former CEO Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani are equally responsible for the restitution amount, which was determined by Judge Edward Davila.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes arrives at the federal courthouse accompanied by her partner Billy Evans, to ask a U.S. judge at a hearing to pause her prison sentence of more than 11 years while she urges an appeals court to review her conviction on charges of defrauding investors in the blood testing startup at the federal courthouse in San Jose, California, U.S., March 17, 2023. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo
The key to reputation management is to be sufficiently proactive without becoming obsessively self-centred in how you present yourself and your organisation to others.

Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes leaving a federal courthouse accompanied by her partner Billy Evans, after asking a US judge at a hearing to pause her prison sentence of more than 11 years while she urges an appeals court to review her conviction on charges of defrauding investors in her blood-testing startup.

site_title: Singapore key exports contract 9.8% in April in seventh straight month of decline
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) contracted 9.8% in April for the seventh consecutive month, according to Enterprise Singapore. The decline was wider than forecast, with electronics and non-electronics continuing to fall. Shipments to key markets such as China, Malaysia, and Taiwan declined, except for those to South Korea, the EU, and the US. The decline in NODX was attributed to weak global electronics demand and a subdued manufacturing sector. Total trade also fell 18.8% year-on-year, with exports and imports contracting by 18.1% and 19.5% respectively.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Singapore's glum manufacturing sentiment is in sync with other regional economies, which also saw manufacturing activity soften in April.
Overall, firms have become more pessimistic about business prospects for the next six months, showed the latest quarterly BT-SUSS Business Climate Survey.

site_title: Lawrence Wong meets Chinese Premier, takes over as leader overseeing cooperation with China
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong met Chinese Premier Li Qiang, marking the first meeting between the two men since their promotions in 2022. The meeting laid the ground for a refreshed relationship between Singapore's fourth-generation leadership and China's new leaders, following an official upgrade in April to an "all-round, high-quality, future-oriented partnership". Wong takes over as co-chair of the Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation (JCBC), overseeing cooperation with China, and is responsible for delivering on a new relationship characterized by high-quality and forward-looking collaboration.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at a welcome ceremony at Tuynhuys, South Africa’s presidential office, with South African President Cyril Ramaphosa on May 16.

site_title: Google to delete inactive accounts starting December
summary: Google will delete inactive accounts that haven't been used or signed into for at least two years starting December. This move aims to prevent security threats, including hacks. The policy change applies only to personal Google Accounts and not to those for organizations. Google will send multiple notifications before deletion, and the action will also affect content across Google Workspace, including Gmail, Drive, and YouTube.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Google LLC is seen at the Google Store Chelsea in New York City, U.S., January 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Luxury London home sellers offer discounts galore as deals slump
summary: Britain's luxury housing market is experiencing a slowdown due to higher borrowing costs and possible house price drops. Over half of prime London homes were sold at a discount in April, with average price reductions rising to 9.1% for the first time in over three years. Despite this, sales dropped by over a third from last year. The market is being driven by sellers referencing past prices and buyers expecting future price falls, causing a stall in sales activity.

images.alt_text: A British Union flag on top of the Bank of England in the City of London, UK, on Monday, May 15, 2023. The upcoming batch of jobs data, due on Tuesday, May 16, is likely to show price pressures in the economy remain way too high for the Bank of England to tolerate. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: UBS maintains investment flows in Taiwan as tensions mount
summary: UBS maintains investment flows in Taiwan despite rising tensions with China, with its wealth management business expecting double-digit revenue growth this year. Clients are reconfiguring portfolios and bringing funds back to Taiwan due to geopolitical concerns, intergenerational wealth transfers, and supply-chain issues. UBS plans to offer alternative investments and focus on onshore banking for the Taiwanese economy, with a goal of increasing staff to over 500 in the next five years. Taiwanese firms have reduced investments in China, and the country's listed companies repatriated a record NT$114 billion of investment income from China last year.

images.alt_text: UBS hires a trio of Barclays bankers in April as it pushes to expand in US investment banking, including Marco Valla, who will become co-head of global banking.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Singtel, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, ST Engineering, Delfi
summary: Singapore Airlines posted its highest full-year net profit in its 76-year history, reaching S$2.2 billion for FY2022/23. The airline's net profit increased by 32.7% in the second half of the year, driven by a turnaround from a net loss in the previous year. Meanwhile, Singtel's quarterly earnings missed analyst expectations, and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit closed its private placement at S$2.727 per share. ST Engineering issued US$500 million in three-year notes, while Delfi posted a 24.5% increase in its first-quarter earnings.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Malaysia eager to reel in Asia’s wealthy with tweaks to visa scheme
summary: Malaysia is reviewing its MM2H (Malaysia My Second Home) visa scheme, which has seen a 90% drop in applications since 2021. The program, which allows wealthy foreigners to live in the country for 10 years, was made more stringent in 2021, including requiring a minimum deposit of RM1.5 million and a minimum monthly salary of RM40,000. The government hopes to make the program more attractive by offering flexible options, which could lead to an influx of new applicants and boost the economy. Experts say the current requirements have deterred many interested applicants, and a review of the criteria is a step in the right direction.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Malaysia's Home Affairs Ministry is looking at attracting at least 1,000 participants in the first year after the Premium Visa Programme kickstart on Oct 1, 2022.

site_title: UN forecasts world economic growth of 2.3% in 2023, 2.5% in 2024
summary: The UN forecasts global economic growth of 2.3% in 2023 and 2.5% in 2024, lower than the IMF's earlier projection of 2.9% in 2023 and 3.1% in 2024. Despite this, some countries' growth prospects have improved, including the US, EU, and China. However, developing countries face deteriorating growth prospects due to tightening credit conditions and rising costs of external financing. The least developed countries are forecast to grow at 4.1% in 2023 and 5.2% in 2024, below their 7% target.

site_title: Australia says Quad meeting could still proceed without Biden
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said a Quad summit on May 24 could proceed without US President Joe Biden, who canceled his trip due to debt ceiling negotiations. A senior US representative is expected to attend. The leaders had agreed to reschedule Biden's visit to Australia at the earliest opportunity. Meanwhile, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is still set to travel to Australia next week for a bilateral meeting and an event with the Indian diaspora. Discussions with Japan are ongoing to determine how to proceed.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden announces that he will be cutting his upcoming trip to Asia short and will return to Washington earlier than planned, to continue US debt ceiling negotiations, Washington, May 16, 2023.
US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo says that a green steel arrangement will be a “game changer” for the industry’s efforts to deal with Chinese excess steel manufacturing capacity.
“This is an exciting and an historic day and continues an ongoing effort to ensure that rural America is a full participant in the clean energy economy,” Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack says.

site_title: Gold prices steady with focus on US debt-ceiling talks
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,992.19 per ounce, as investors awaited the outcome of US debt-limit negotiations, which may impact the market. The US dollar index held firm, weighing on overseas demand for gold, while higher interest rates are expected to blunt the appeal of non-yielding bullion. Meanwhile, US retail sales rose less than expected, but consumer spending is expected to remain strong.

site_title: Elvis Presley’s widow settles over late daughter’s will
summary: Priscilla Presley, Elvis Presley's widow, has settled a dispute over her late daughter Lisa Marie Presley's will. Lisa Marie initially named Priscilla as a co-trustee, but an amendment in 2016 made Riley Keough the beneficiary instead. Priscilla filed a petition arguing the amendment was invalid due to lack of notarization and being presented after Lisa Marie's death. The settlement resolves the dispute, with terms not disclosed.

images.alt_text: Lisa Marie Presley, 54, suffered cardiac arrest in her home in the Los Angeles suburb of Calabasas.

site_title: Slower growth and fewer perks – the new buzzwords for tech unicorns
summary: South-east Asia's tech unicorns, such as GoTo, are shifting their focus from hyper growth to long-term profitability, embracing concepts like slower growth and reduced perks. Investors, sensing this change, are supporting these companies, with GoTo's share price increasing over 11% since its earnings release. This shift is aimed at convincing investors that these startups can balance growth with financial sustainability, marking a significant departure from the previous "move fast, break things" approach.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The on-demand services segment, which includes Gojek’s ride-hailing and food delivery services, saw a slowdown in Q1 with GTV dipping 5 per cent.
Li argues that Sea has a unique opportunity to bring e-commerce to emerging markets, the kinds of places where Amazon may be at a disadvantage.

site_title: UK watchdog warns millions more Britons in financial trouble due to inflation
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has warned that 10.9 million Britons, roughly half of the population, are struggling to meet bills and credit repayments due to inflation. This represents a 40% increase in the past year, with 28.4 million people feeling anxious about the rising cost of living. The FCA has issued reminders to banks to treat customers fairly, particularly those facing financial difficulties.

site_title: Inflation in Canada quickens to 4.4% with housing costs rising
summary: Canada's inflation rate accelerated to 4.4% in April, the first increase in headline inflation since June 2022, surpassing economists' expectations of 4.1%. Housing costs, particularly rent and mortgage interest, drove the increase. Core measures, however, eased, giving the Bank of Canada room to keep interest rates on pause. Policymakers may need to reconsider their stance on further rate hikes, as inflation expectations remain elevated and service prices continue to rise.

site_title: Four red cards and two brawls as Indonesia clinch SEA Games gold
summary: Indonesia clinched gold in the men's football match at the 32nd SEA Games, defeating Thailand 5-2 in extra time. The match was marred by controversy, including four red cards, two mass brawls, and a heated sideline fight. The victory marks Indonesia's first gold in the competition since it became an under-23 event, and comes after a tumultuous period for the national team following a stadium disaster and loss of hosting rights.

images.alt_text: Liverpool (in red) defeated Leicester 3-0 in the English Premier League on May 16. The two teams will play each other again in Singapore on Jul 30 at the National Stadium.

site_title: China online brokers pull apps as trades come under scrutiny
summary: China's leading cross-border online brokerages, Futu Holdings and Up Fintech Holding (Tiger Brokers), are removing their trading platforms from app stores in mainland China due to stricter regulations on capital flows. The move is to comply with the Chinese securities regulator's requirements. As a result, shares of Futu fell 16% and Up Fintech dropped 12% in pre-market trading.

images.alt_text: A man walks past screens showing stock information at a brokerage house in Jiujiang, Jiangxi province, China October 8, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer

site_title: Biden administration announces US$11 billion for rural clean energy projects
summary: The Biden administration has announced $11 billion in funding for rural clean energy projects, primarily through the Inflation Reduction Act. Rural electric cooperatives, utilities, and energy providers can apply for grants and loans starting July 31 and June 30, respectively. The funds aim to bring good-paying jobs to rural communities and help them reach parity with private utility companies investing in clean energy. The goal is to support the administration's goal of net-zero emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: Stronger consumer spending early in the first quarter  contributes to the inventory rundown.
Motor vehicle production surges 9.3 per cent last month after declining 1.9 per cent in March.
The rise in retail sales adds to strong job growth in April, suggesting that the economy is experiencing a spring revival after activity slowed in February and March.

site_title: Meta touts metaverse’s potential for job training and education
summary: Meta is promoting the metaverse as a tool for job training and education, despite concerns about AI replacing jobs. President Nick Clegg said AR and VR technology can dramatically improve re-skilling in skilled trades and schools, with potential to create a "boot camp style" training in just 5-6 weeks. Clegg also believes that AI and the metaverse are not mutually exclusive, with the technology complementing each other. A bipartisan bill has been introduced in the US House of Representatives to support the use of VR in classrooms, and Meta has welcomed guardrails on regulating the metaverse.

images.alt_text: Meta introduced the “AI Sandbox” for advertisers to test early versions of features that use artificial intelligence technology.
Social media giant Meta has forecast the tech would eventually replace mobile as the main computing platform.

site_title: US manufacturing production surges in April on motor vehicles
summary: US manufacturing production surged 1.0% in April, driven by a 9.3% increase in motor vehicle production. Despite this, manufacturing remains constrained by higher interest rates and a shift in spending from goods to services. The Institute for Supply Management's measure of national manufacturing activity has contracted for six straight months, and businesses are holding excess inventory, reducing demand for goods. Overall industrial production rose 0.5% in April, with capacity utilization for the manufacturing sector at 78.3%.

images.alt_text: The rise in retail sales adds to strong job growth in April, suggesting that the economy is experiencing a spring revival after activity slowed in February and March.

site_title: Singapore and South Africa sign two agreements, deepen ties
summary: Singapore and South Africa have signed two agreements to deepen their ties, focusing on information and communications technology (ICT) and human capital development. The memorandums of understanding aim to broaden cooperation into new areas, including digitalisation, water management, and skills development. The agreements follow a visit by Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to South Africa, where he witnessed a 19-gun salute and met with President Cyril Ramaphosa. Trade between the two countries has grown by over 60% since 2018, with a value of over S$2.7 billion in 2022.

site_title: SAP says it’s still open to acquisitions after Qualtrics sale
summary: SAP, Europe's largest software company, is open to making acquisitions if they are a "strategic fit" after its recent sale of Qualtrics International for $12.5 billion. CFO Dominik Asam stated that the company's share buyback won't limit its ability to pursue deals if they make sense. SAP also plans to discontinue providing long-term guidance after 2025 due to the "ambiguity and risks" associated with setting future targets.

images.alt_text: An automobile passes a SAP SE logo at the software company's headquarter campus building in Walldorf, Germany, on Tuesday, Jan.  29, 2019. SAP, Europe’s biggest software company that spent more than $10 billion on acquisitions last year, is starting a restructuring program in the face of intense competition from Salesforce.com Inc. and Oracle Corp. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil dips as weaker China, US economic data offset IEA demand forecast
summary: Oil prices dropped 32 US cents to $74.91 a barrel and 25 US cents to $70.86 a barrel, as weaker-than-expected Chinese and US economic data offset higher global demand forecasts from the International Energy Agency. China's industrial output and retail sales growth underwhelmed, but oil refinery throughput rose to a record high. The IEA forecasted a record 102 million barrels of global oil demand this year, while US interest rates may be raised further to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Global crude supplies could also tighten in the second half as Opec+  plan additional output cuts.

site_title: Australian luxury wine to China will take years to rebuild: winemaker
summary: Australian luxury wine maker Treasury Wine Estate's profits from China are unlikely to return to pre-2020 levels, even if tariffs are dropped, according to CEO Tim Ford. Despite investing in marketing and maintaining staff relationships, the company made no profit from China due to tariffs of up to 212%. Ford predicts it will take 2-4 years to rebuild Australian wine sales in China, which were once a third of the company's profits. The company will instead focus on other markets to replace lost Chinese sales.

site_title: Former SVB head draws outrage at hearing on US bank failures
summary: Former Silicon Valley Bank CEO Gregory Becker testified before a Senate committee, blaming the bank's failure on factors beyond his control, including a "social media fueled" bank run and the Federal Reserve's shift in monetary policy. However, senators criticized Becker and Signature Bank's former executives for poor risk management and excessive executive pay, with some calling for legislation to claw back pay from bankers. The hearing highlighted concerns over the failures of the two banks, which were blamed on poor management and reckless decision-making.

images.alt_text: Gregory Becker, the former chief executive of Silicon Valley Bank, testifies before a Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee hearing to examine the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank on Capitol Hill in Washington, May 16, 2023. (Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times)

site_title: Qatar’s Sheikh Jassim makes improved bid for Manchester United: source
summary: Qatari banker Sheikh Jassim bin Hamad Al Thani has made an improved bid to buy Manchester United from the Glazer family, a source close to the bid told AFP. Sheikh Jassim's bid is for 100% control of the club, promising to wipe the club's £970 million debt. This bid comes after British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe appeared to be the front runner in a bidding war. The Glazer family is reportedly holding out for a world record £6 billion fee before agreeing to sell, with Manchester United Supporters' Trust calling for a swift conclusion to the process.

images.alt_text: Liverpool (in red) defeated Leicester 3-0 in the English Premier League on May 16. The two teams will play each other again in Singapore on Jul 30 at the National Stadium.
