site_title: Trump will be the next US president, unless...
summary: Former US President Donald Trump maintains a lead in the Republican primary race for president despite personal and political scandals, with many Republican voters wanting him to run again. Trump's recent CNN town hall appearance was met with a standing ovation, with some audience members applauding his mocking of a rape accuser and others laughing at his comments about former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Despite concerns about Trump's candidacy, opinion polls show him ahead of other prospective candidates, and many Democrats believe he would lose again in the general election. A recent Washington Post-ABC News poll found President Biden losing head-to-head races against Trump, with the former president winning among young voters.

images.alt_text: Unfiltered by his aides, Trump damaged himself in the CNN town hall on May 10 for purposes of a general election campaign.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall with Embracer leading losses
summary: Europe's stocks declined 0.4% on Tuesday, with the retail sector leading losses. Swedish gaming firm Embracer fell 15.9% after warning on full-year earnings. Weak US retail sales data and Home Depot's lower forecast also contributed to the decline. Investors remain cautious due to the US debt ceiling standoff and hawkish ECB rhetoric, with interest rates expected to rise further.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed the day 0.4 per cent higher.

site_title: US charges Apple ex-employee for trying to steal technology, fleeing to China
summary: The US Justice Department has charged a former Apple engineer, Weibao Wang, with attempting to steal the company's technology related to autonomous systems and fleeing to China. Wang accepted a US-based job with a Chinese company in 2017 to develop self-driving cars before resigning from Apple. The case is part of a "strike force" formed to counter efforts to illicitly acquire American technology by nations including Russia and China. Four arrests were made in connection with the cases, which include export violations, smuggling, and trade secrets.

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment rises to 10-month high in May
summary: US homebuilder sentiment reached a 10-month high in May, rising to a reading of 50 on the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB)/Wells Fargo housing market index. This marks the fifth straight monthly increase, with builders citing tight housing supply and low existing home inventory as drivers of demand. However, builders continue to face challenges, including shortages of building materials and tightening credit conditions, despite rising optimism. The share of builders reducing home prices dropped to 27%, and 54% offered incentives to bolster sales.

images.alt_text: US buyers have begun flocking to builders’ sales offices, where offers of discounts and rate buy-downs are so generous that it’s often cheaper to buy new than pre-owned.

site_title: International expansion: Why branding and intellectual property matter more than ever
summary: Singaporean businesses are expanding overseas, with over 60% of small and medium-size enterprises prioritizing international expansion. However, without a strong intellectual property (IP) strategy, they risk counterfeiting and trademark infringements. A recent survey found that businesses with IP outperformed their peers, with trademark owners delivering a 10% increase in profits and those with both trademarks and patents delivering two times more profits. To succeed abroad, businesses should ensure IP management is part of their expansion plans, work with IP lawyers, and take advantage of international agreements and domestic IP schemes.

images.alt_text: RazerStore有专门区域展示各种电子竞技设备。（品牌提供）

Expediting the completion of the proposed investment will allow the company to utilise the full investment amount to settle its liabilities upon completion to meet its working capital requirements for the next 18 months, said the company.
Musician Ed Sheeran smiles while standing with his legal team after winning his copyright infringement case in New York, May 4, 2023.

site_title: US Commerce chief says green steel pact would disadvantage China
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo stated that a "green steel" arrangement with the European Union and other partners would disadvantage China's carbon-intensive steel manufacturing capacity, a move seen as a "game changer" for the industry. The Biden administration aims to erect trade barriers to steel produced with higher carbon emissions, prioritizing higher quality, green steel and aluminium. US steelmakers, which are among the world's lowest carbon emitters, will benefit from the deal. The negotiations are ongoing, with a potential October deadline, and Raimondo emphasized the need for strong trade enforcement.

site_title: Gucci courts South Korea’s wealthy with fashion show in Seoul palace
summary: Gucci hosted its first fashion show in Seoul in eight years, showcasing its designs in the courtyard of the Gyeongbokgung Palace. The event featured traditional Korean elements and music from the Oscar-winning movie Parasite. The show is part of Gucci's efforts to tap into South Korea's luxury market, where it generated 9% of its retail sales in 2022. The event comes as Gucci's parent company, Kering, struggles to regain momentum after Gucci's former creative director Alessandro Michele left in November. Gucci's new creative director, Sabato de Sarno, will unveil his debut collection in September.

images.alt_text: Gucci is weathering a transition after naming Sabato De Sarno as its new creative director in January.

site_title: Biden cancels post-G7 Asia tour due to debt crisis
summary: US President Joe Biden is cutting short his upcoming trip to Asia due to the ongoing US debt ceiling negotiations. He will return to Washington earlier than planned to continue talks with Congressional leaders to avert a potentially catastrophic debt default. Biden will attend the G7 summit in Japan on Wednesday but will not visit subsequent stops in Papua New Guinea and Australia. The White House statement said President Biden will return to the US on Sunday to ensure Congress takes action by the deadline to avoid default.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Joe Biden announces that he will be cutting his upcoming trip to Asia short and will return to Washington earlier than planned, to continue U.S. debt ceiling negotiations, during his remarks at a Jewish American Heritage Month celebration at the White House in Washington, U.S., May 16, 2023. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein

site_title: ST Engineering unit to issue US$500m of 4.125% fixed rate notes due 2026
summary: ST Engineering's wholly-owned subsidiary STE TransCore priced US$500 million in three-year notes with a 4.125% fixed-rate coupon. The notes will mature on May 23, 2026, and will be issued in denominations of US$200,000 and integral multiples of US$1,000. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing outstanding short-term US commercial papers. The notes are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on May 24, under the S$5 billion global medium term note programme unconditionally guaranteed by ST Engineering.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
ST Engineering Q1 revenue up 13% to S$2.3 billion on growth in most segments

site_title: Cryptoverse: Every frog has its day as pepe pops 7,000%
summary: Pepe, a cryptocurrency inspired by an internet meme of a frog, has surged nearly 7,000% in 17 days after its launch, reaching a market value of $1.8 billion. This has sparked renewed interest in "memecoins," a class of highly speculative and volatile cryptocurrencies. Pepe's rise comes as Bitcoin's 2023 rally stalls, with overall trading volumes jumping to $2.6 billion in the first week of May. Despite its popularity, Pepe's creators remain unknown, and its utility is described as "completely useless" on its website.

images.alt_text: The power-hungry companies that pump new bitcoin into circulation have been thrown a lifeline by the cryptocurrency’s rally to above US$30,000 this year.
Bitcoin’s market depth indicates the asset is at its lowest level of liquidity in 10 months, even lower than in the aftermath of the FTX collapse in November, according to data provider Kaiko.
The infamously volatile cryptocurrency seems positively hale and hearty, just as a banking meltdown drives markets into the arms of a recession.

site_title: India's markets regulator to widen definition of qualified buyers for bonds
summary: India's markets regulator, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi), proposed widening the definition of "qualified institutional buyer" to include more entities, such as cooperatives, housing finance companies, and universities, to invest in debt securities. This move aims to increase fund supply, aid price discovery, and reduce fundraising costs. The regulator has invited comments from stakeholders until May 29, as the current definition relies on equity investment guidelines.

site_title: US retail sales increase moderately; core sales strong
summary: US retail sales rose 0.4% in April, exceeding expectations, as consumer spending rebounded despite higher borrowing costs and prices. The underlying trend, known as core sales, also showed a 0.7% increase, driven by a surge in online retail sales and a moderate rise in auto dealership receipts. This suggests the economy may be experiencing a spring revival, with strong job growth and wage gains underpinning spending. However, economists caution that a recession is still possible due to delayed effects of the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and tightening lending standards.

images.alt_text: The average age of battery electric vehicles (BEV) in the US actually fell to 3.6 years, down slightly from 3.7 years in 2022. That figure has hovered between 3 and 4 years since 2017, the group said.

site_title: India's Bharti Airtel misses Q4 revenue estimates on soft 4G user growth
summary: India's Bharti Airtel reported Q4 revenue of 360.1 billion rupees, missing analyst estimates of 365.52 billion rupees. The company's 4G user growth and per-user revenue stagnated, and its average revenue per user (ARPU) remained flat from the previous quarter. Airtel's net profit rose 50% to 30.06 billion rupees, despite a rise in costs. The company added 7.4 million 4G data customers, with total 4G subscribers at 224.12 million.

images.alt_text: Airtel said revenue from its India mobile services, which has about 332.24 million subscribers as of the December quarter, rose 20.8 per cent to 193.53 billion rupees.

site_title: Global central banks use record amount of yuan from PBOC swaps
summary: Global central banks utilized a record 109 billion yuan from the People's Bank of China's foreign-exchange swap lines at the end of March, indicating the yuan's growing international status. This represents a 20 billion yuan increase from the previous year's level, with countries like Argentina and Brazil also using the facility to settle trade with China. The surge in yuan usage may be driven by efforts to reduce reliance on the US dollar and promote the currency for international transactions, despite China's strict capital controls.

site_title: US business inventories fall in March
summary: US business inventories unexpectedly fell 0.1% in March, with a 6.5% year-over-year increase. The decline was driven by a reduction in stock at manufacturers and private inventory investment, which restricted GDP growth to a 1.1% annualized pace in the first quarter. Stronger consumer spending early in the quarter contributed to the inventory rundown, but some economists believe the inventory liquidation may be over, potentially affecting GDP growth in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Motor vehicle production surges 9.3 per cent last month after declining 1.9 per cent in March.
The rise in retail sales adds to strong job growth in April, suggesting that the economy is experiencing a spring revival after activity slowed in February and March.
The housing market has been the biggest casualty of the Fed’s fastest monetary policy tightening campaign since the 1980s, aimed at taming inflation.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Home Depot, retail sales data weigh
summary: US stocks opened lower on May 16, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 73.23 points, or 0.22%, to 33,275.37. The decline was attributed to a dour forecast from Home Depot and April retail sales data, which indicated consumers are feeling the pinch from rising prices and interest rates. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 opening 8.33 points, or 0.20%, lower, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 38.16 points, or 0.31%.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 10, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: J&T Express unit acquires Shenzhen Fengwang  subsidiary for 1.183b yuan
summary: J&T Express, a unit of Indonesian logistics player J&T Express, has acquired Shenzhen Fengwang Information Technology (Fengwang Information) for 1.183 billion yuan (S$226.9 million). The acquisition marks J&T Express's entry into the e-commerce express delivery sector in the Chinese market. Fengwang Information is a subsidiary of SF, China's largest integrated logistics service provider. This move expands J&T Express's presence in the Chinese market, further solidifying its position as a major logistics player in the region.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
J&T Express expands fleet network with its first dedicated all-cargo aircraft in Indonesia.

site_title: US dollar hovers shy of 5-week high; pound swings after jobs data
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.14% to 102.29, hovering just below its five-week high, while the pound dropped 0.5% against the US dollar before recovering. The decline was attributed to a rise in Britain's jobless numbers, suggesting fewer Bank of England rate increases may be needed to combat inflation. Analysts point to slowing US and eurozone growth, weak Chinese economic data, and debt-ceiling worries as factors contributing to the US dollar's recent strength.

site_title: Citigroup appoints head of international personal bank in Singapore
summary: Citigroup has appointed Sharad Mohan as head of international personal bank in Singapore, responsible for Citi's offshore wealth management business serving affluent individuals in the region. The appointment comes as Singapore benefits from strong inflows of wealthy individuals amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Alphabet adds US$115 billion in value after defying AI doubters
summary: Alphabet's stock surged 9% after unveiling a more conversational search engine and expanding its AI-powered chatbot, adding $115 billion in market value. The company's AI tools provided a timely boost, erasing its underperformance against peers like Apple and Microsoft. Analysts believe Alphabet is solidly in the "winner camp" as AI continues to build excitement, with some predicting further upside. Despite lingering concerns about AI risks, Alphabet's cheaper market valuation multiple remains attractive compared to peers like Microsoft and Apple.

images.alt_text: Google will start experimenting with a more conversational search engine and has made its AI-powered chatbot available more broadly.

site_title: EU countries set to finalise first green aviation fuel goals
summary: The European Union is set to finalize targets for airlines to increase their use of sustainable aviation fuel, aiming to cut CO2 emissions from aviation. The targets include 2% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by 2025, rising to 70% by 2050, with synthetic fuels also being introduced. The plan has been met with mixed reactions from airlines, with some expressing concerns about competition and costs. The European Parliament and EU countries are expected to endorse the final version of the law, which is seen as a step towards reducing flight emissions pending breakthrough technologies like zero-emission aircraft.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A decal stating "This Aircraft Flies On Renewable Fuel" is seen on a business jet in Las Vegas, Nevada, U.S. October 21, 2019.  REUTERS/David Becker//File Photo

site_title:
Sea posts another profitable quarter, but
weighed down by gaming woes
summary: Sea Ltd posted its second profitable quarter, with a net profit of US$87.3 million, despite gaming division Garena's weaker showing. Revenue grew 4.9% to US$3 billion, driven by e-commerce arm Shopee's 50.7% surge. However, Sea's digital entertainment segment saw a 52.5% decline in revenue. The company continues to focus on growth in Brazil and improving logistics capabilities, with a goal to make Free Fire a long-term franchise. Sea's digital bank, MariBank, is still at an early stage.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Sea Limited founder Mr Forrest Li, who is taking over Singapore Premier League club Home United and privatising it to become Lion City Sailors.
Sea executed a “decisive pivot to focus on efficiency and profitability”, said CEO Forrest Li in a press statement.
Li argues that Sea has a unique opportunity to bring e-commerce to emerging markets, the kinds of places where Amazon may be at a disadvantage.

site_title: WHO warns against bias, misinformation in using AI in healthcare
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned against bias and misinformation in using artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare, citing the potential for biased data and disinformation generated by large language model tools like ChatGPT. The WHO urges caution in using AI as a decision-support tool and diagnostic care, highlighting the need to assess the risks and protect public health. The organization's cautionary note comes as AI applications rapidly gain popularity and could upend the way businesses and society operate.

site_title: We do not want a hostile environment for tech, UK’s competition boss says
summary: UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) chief executive Sarah Cardell defended the decision to block Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, saying it was not seeking to create a "hostile environment" for tech companies. Despite EU approval, Microsoft plans to appeal the ruling, and the US Federal Trade Commission has also filed a complaint. Cardell stated the CMA engaged with companies across the sector to ensure competition conditions, and the regulator's goal is to support UK startups and competitors.

images.alt_text: Activision Blizzard headquarters in Santa Monica, California, US, on Monday, May 15, 2023. Microsoft Corp.'s $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard Inc. won European Union approval, putting the bloc at odds with its UK and US counterparts. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg
The agreement  with Nware marks the latest effort by Microsoft to ease fears its purchase of Activision would hinder competition in cloud gaming
“The CMA’s decision rejects a pragmatic path to address competition concerns and discourages technology innovation and investment in the UK.” Brad Smith, vice-chair and president of Microsoft, said.

site_title: Russia approves sale of Volkswagen assets for about US$140 million
summary: Russia has approved a deal for Volkswagen to sell its Russian assets to autodealer group Avilon for up to 125 million euros (approximately US$181.9 million). The sale includes the Kaluga plant with over 4,000 employees. The deal, which was agreed on April 17, requires approval from a Russian government commission that monitors foreign investment. Volkswagen's exit from Russia marks a departure from other major automakers, which have sold their assets for a nominal fee with buyback clauses.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: New cars are seen parked at the plant of Volkswagen Group Rus in Kaluga, Russia March 30, 2022. Picture taken March 30, 2022. REUTERS/Evgenia Novozhenina/File Photo

site_title: EU states approve world's first comprehensive crypto rules
summary: European Union states have approved the world's first comprehensive crypto rules, requiring firms to obtain a licence to issue, trade, and safeguard cryptoassets. The rules aim to protect Europeans from the misuse of crypto for money laundering and financing of terrorism. The move follows the collapse of FTX and puts pressure on countries like Britain and the US to regulate the industry. The EU's approach contrasts with the US, which has focused on existing securities rules, and highlights the need for global norms in the crypto sector.

images.alt_text: The European Union has finalised the world’s first comprehensive rules for cryptoasset markets, known as MiCA, but others like Britain and the US are further behind.

site_title: Pressure mounts on Thai senators to support Pita’s premier bid
summary: Thailand's Move Forward leader Pita Limjaroenrat faces opposition from some senators in his bid for premier, despite his party's win in the election. The 250-member Senate, stacked with pro-military allies, expressed opposition to Pita's bid, citing concerns over his party's pledges to amend the lese majeste law and rewrite the junta-era constitution. Pita's proposed coalition of six parties is short of the 376 votes needed for a prime minister, and supporters are putting pressure on the Senate to back the popular mandate.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat  waves to his supporters during a victory parade in Bangkok on May 15, 2023.
Move Forward has promised to raise the daily minimum wage to 450 baht (S$17.7), with annual revisions, from an average 337 baht.

epa08810633 Muslim Thai royalists wearing yellow hold a large portrait of Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkunattend during a pro-monarchy rally at Chalerm Phrakiat National Administration Center for Islamic Affairs in Bangkok, Thailand, 10 November 2020. Muslim royalists gathered in support for the Thai King after the pro-democracy protesters held street protests calling for monarchy reform.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: OpenAI’s CEO casts global gaze in urging AI regulation in US
summary: Sam Altman, OpenAI CEO, plans to testify to Congress that AI companies should be subject to "a combination of licensing or registration requirements" for releasing advanced models, citing the need for regulation due to AI's increasing power. Altman will testify for the first time since ChatGPT's popularity, stating that AI companies should adhere to "an appropriate set of safety requirements."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of OpenAI is displayed near a response by its AI chatbot ChatGPT on its website, in this illustration picture taken February 9, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: EU joint gas purchases demand more than matched by supply offers
summary: The European Union's joint gas buying scheme has seen suppliers offer over 13.4 billion cubic meters of gas, exceeding the 11.6 billion cubic meters requested by EU companies. This response has largely met expectations, but European Commission Vice-President Maros Sefcovic warns that the bloc must do more to reinforce its energy security, particularly as it phases out Russian fuels amidst ongoing war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: For this first tender, which covers deliveries expected between June 2023 and May 2024, 77 European companies have clubbed together with applications for a total volume of around 11.6 billion cubic metres of gas.

site_title: China's Tencent Music revenue beats estimates on jump in paying users
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group topped quarterly revenue estimates with a 5.4% increase to 7 billion yuan, driven by a 30.4% year-over-year surge in music subscription revenues. Paying users rose to 94.4 million, up from 88.5 million in the prior quarter. The company's monthly average revenue per user (ARPU) grew 10.8%, while net profit attributable to equity holders reached 1.15 billion yuan. This marks the first quarter of revenue growth for the company in five consecutive quarters.

images.alt_text: Tencent Music, China’s answer to Spotify, has seen torrid paid user growth as it invested heavily into music licensing deals and offering live shows and concerts on the platform.

site_title: Ever Glory raises S$3.1 million from fully subscribed IPO
summary: Ever Glory United Holdings, a mechanical and electrical engineering service provider, successfully raised S$3.1 million from the full subscription of 14 million placement shares through its Catalist listing. The company's shares will begin trading on May 18. The offer was oversubscribed, with 215 placees participating, and about half of them received shares ranging from 1,000 to 9,000. The remaining three placees received at least a million shares each.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A global wealth management group, AlTi Tiedemann Global, has acquired AL Wealth Partners, a Singapore-based multifamily office, to enhance advisory services for wealthy families. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank aims to reduce its oil and gas sector emissions by 95% by 2050 and will stop financing projects approved after 2021. Vietnam companies have adopted digitalisation strategies at a higher rate than the global average, according to a DBS study. Singapore shares closed slightly lower due to weak China data, while SIA posted record full-year earnings.

site_title: SIA posts record full-year earnings as demand recovery pushes H2 profit to S$1.2b
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has posted a record full-year net profit of S$2.2 billion for FY2022/23, driven by strong demand and a recovery in the global aviation industry. The airline's second-half net profit soared to S$1.2 billion, reversing a loss of S$125.2 million in the same period last year. SIA's board has recommended a final dividend of S$0.28 per share, totaling S$0.38 per share for the fiscal year. The airline attributes the improved figures to better operating performance and a net interest income in the second half.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
SIA has had a 205 per cent jump in passenger numbers to 2.7 million in March; and for February, the surge was 338 per cent to 2.4 million.
The 2020 and 2021 MCBs were part of the S$15 billion rights issue approved by SIA shareholders in April 2020 to tide the airline group through the pandemic, which decimated travel for two years.

site_title: Delfi Q1 Ebitda up 24.5% to US$25.5m on higher revenue
summary: Delfi Ltd reported a 24.5% increase in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) for its first fiscal quarter to US$25.5 million, driven by higher revenue and profitability. Revenue grew 20.8% to US$160.8 million, with contributions from the SilverQueen and Delfi Premium products in Indonesia. The company expects a positive momentum in Q1 to carry on for most of the year, but faces uncertainty from global economic factors.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Although Delfi expects to have higher working capital requirements to support future business growth, it said it will remain vigilant and tightly manage appropriate levels of receivables, inventories, and payables.

Given Delfi’s premiumisation strategy that focuses on product differentiation and increasingly places emphasis on the modern trade sector, UOBKH believes the stock is “well-positioned” to capitalise on premiumisation trends.

site_title: Indian commercial real estate lull to last at least two more years, says Anarock chairman
summary: Indian commercial real estate is expected to remain in a lull for at least two more years, according to Anarock chairman Anuj Puri. Despite residential sales hitting an all-time high in the first quarter of 2023, commercial real estate continues to struggle to match pre-pandemic levels. Factors contributing to the decline include the hybrid working model and excess supply, with approximately 0.3 million new homes expected to be completed in metropolitan cities this year. Interest rates are not expected to pressure demand, but may cause short-term deferment if rates breach 10%.

images.alt_text: This is part of New Delhi’s strategy to combat the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism designed to push local industries to invest in new technologies to bring down carbon emissions, while also raising the issue in bilateral talks.

site_title: Morgan Stanley becomes latest substantial shareholder at Vertex Tech
summary: Morgan Stanley has acquired 1.2 million shares of Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation (VTAC) on May 12, increasing its stake to 7.9% with a total of 3.3 million shares. This is a significant development, making Morgan Stanley a substantial shareholder of Singapore's first special purpose acquisition company (Spac).

images.alt_text: ST20230303_202311925234 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.
Uma Devi

site_title: A look at the Fed’s likely next No 2
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Philip Jefferson was nominated by President Biden on May 12, 2023, to be the Fed's next vice-chair. Jefferson, a centrist economist, has a reputation for being an inquisitive listener and has given several speeches on topics such as inflation and technology's impact on the post-pandemic economy. His nomination is part of a broader reshuffle of the Fed board of governors, which also includes the nomination of Adriana Kugler, a Colombian American economist.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Governor Philip Jefferson speaks at a monetary policy conference at the Hoover Institution, in Palo Alto, California, U.S. May 12, 2023. Earlier in the day he was nominated by U.S. President Joe Biden to be the Fed's next vice chair. REUTERS/Ann Saphir

site_title: Volkswagen’s Skoda Auto sees easing chip crunch spur output recovery
summary: Skoda Auto, a Czech Republic-based manufacturing company, is expecting a recovery in output due to easing chip supply difficulties. CEO Klaus Zellmer aims to boost annual deliveries to 1 million cars within the next two to three years. The company's optimism is driven by booming sales in Europe and Asia, as well as a mild recession in the Czech economy. Skoda plans to invest 5.6 billion euros in electric vehicles and has proposed a new battery plant in the Czech Republic to reduce dependence on Asian imports.

images.alt_text: The software would enable so-called “Level 4” autonomous driving and was due to be implemented across the fleet from 2026, but its development has suffered delays.

site_title: Adnoc unit’s US$607 million Abu Dhabi IPO sells out in minutes
summary: Adnoc's US$607 million maritime logistics unit IPO sold out in minutes, with strong demand exceeding deal size. The IPO priced shares between 1.99 dirhams and 2.01 dirhams, valuing the company at up to US$4.05 billion. Cornerstone investors, including Abu Dhabi wealth fund ADQ and Abu Dhabi Pension Fund, committed to US$180 million. This is Adnoc's second unit listing this year, following its US$2.5 billion gas business IPO in March.

site_title: GIC-backed Vietnamese Internet company VNG seeks US$100 million in funding round: sources
summary: Vietnamese internet company VNG Corp, backed by Singapore's GIC, is seeking US$100 million in funding from Maybank, with plans to use the funds for further expansions. VNG, which owns the popular messaging app Zalo, is working with Maybank to raise the capital, and its market value is estimated at S$1.6 billion. The company aims to go public on the Singapore stock exchange next year, following a fundraising round that comes amid global fundraising challenges.

images.alt_text: A Vietnamese national flag outside a store in the old town of Hoi An, Qung Nam Province, Vietnam, on Thursday, May 4, 2023. Vietnam’s retail sales grew 11.5% in April, according to figures released by the General Statistics Office of Vietnam. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Asian hedge funds piled to China education, US AI shares in Q1
summary: Asian hedge funds poured money into Chinese education companies, including New Oriental and TAL Education, in the first quarter of 2023, despite a near two-year crackdown in China on after-school education. They also bought stocks in US tech giants expected to benefit from AI systems, such as Nvidia, Meta Platforms, and Microsoft. Investors are betting on the future investment themes of US AI areas, driven by technology advantage and applications. The 13F filings show that these companies are among the top holdings of several hedge funds, including Greenwoods Asset Management and Tairen Capital.

images.alt_text: TSMC expects sales of US$15.2 billion to US$16 billion this quarter, a shade below the US$16.1 billion analysts projected on average.
The swaps this week had their biggest increase since UBS Group agreed to buy Credit Suisse in an emergency weekend deal in March.

site_title: Tesla applies to expand Shanghai plant, add pouch battery cell output
summary: Tesla has applied for regulatory clearance to expand its Shanghai plant, increasing its annual powertrain unit production to 1.75 million, up from 1.25 million. The expansion also aims to produce pouch-type battery cells, initially with a capacity of 20,000 ampere-hours, for use in electric vehicles. The move is part of Tesla's efforts to increase production and cut costs, with the company also looking to establish facilities for recycling chemicals and producing commercial energy storage units in the plant.

images.alt_text: The billionaire is expected to address Tesla shareholders on Tuesday at the automaker’s annual meeting at its headquarters in Austin, Texas.

site_title: STI closes 0.02% lower as traders digest weak China data
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.02% lower on May 16, as traders digested weak China data, despite overnight gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index fell 0.68 points to 3,214.04. Key gauges in Asia were mixed, with gains in Japan, Hong Kong, and other countries, while China and Australia finished lower. The market's performance was largely driven by concerns over China's economic reopening, which appears to be losing momentum.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.3 per cent higher, after hitting a two-week high during the session.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.1 per cent at 33,348.60.
Singapore stocks rise on Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.2%

site_title: Bayern Munich, Liverpool among five teams to grace Festival of Football in Singapore in July
summary: Liverpool and Leicester will play each other again in Singapore on July 30 at the National Stadium as part of the inaugural Festival of Football, a week-long event featuring five European clubs. The teams previously met in the English Premier League on May 16, with Liverpool winning 3-0. Bayern Munich, Tottenham, and Roma will also participate in the festival, with Bayern facing Liverpool on August 2. The festival will take place from July 26 to August 2.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

Soccer Football - Premier League - Arsenal v Brighton & Hove Albion - Emirates Stadium, London, Britain - May 14, 2023

By owning multiple clubs in different regions, the likes of Sheikh Mansour’s CFG aim to cut costs on scouting and player development and also build global fanbases for their top teams, boosting revenue from merchandise and TV rights.
Messi’s move to Saudi Arabia is a “done deal”, a source says.

site_title: Thai elections: Voting done, now more politics
summary: Thailand's general elections have concluded with the pro-democracy parties Move Forward and Pheu Thai emerging as the clear winners, but a coalition of the two parties falls short of the required majority of 376 seats in the House of Representatives. The Bhumjaithai Party, a key kingmaker, may demand significant portfolios and authority, potentially complicating the formation of a government. The establishment, including the military-backed government, has options to enforce laws and regulations to disqualify individuals or dissolve parties if the coalition falters. The country's economic recovery remains uncertain, and investors should be cautious of ongoing politicking and potential conflict.

images.alt_text: Thai opposition leader Pita Limjaroenrat said he was ready to be prime minister after a stunning election result that left his upstart progressive party as the biggest in parliament.

Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat leaves the party’s headquarters as votes continue to be counted, during Thailand's general election in Bangkok on May 14, 2023.

site_title: Credit Suisse deal set to face historic Swiss parliamentary probe
summary: Switzerland's parliament is launching a historic parliamentary probe into the Credit Suisse takeover deal, despite it not preventing the sale from going forward. The inquiry, led by a parliamentary commission with judicial powers, aims to uncover who pulled the strings in confidential meetings leading up to the takeover. This is the first time a PUK has been called since 1995 amid a scandal over state pension funds. The probe will likely yield information on the deal's confidential meetings and the government's use of emergency law to facilitate the takeover.

site_title: Ex-Audi boss Stadler pleads guilty in German 'dieselgate' trial
summary: Ex-Audi CEO Rupert Stadler pleaded guilty to "dieselgate" fraud charges in a Munich trial, becoming the highest-ranking former executive to confess in the emissions cheating scandal. Stadler, who learned of the scam in 2015, neglected to inform business partners about vehicles equipped with illegal software, allowing them to go on sale. As part of a plea deal, Stadler will avoid jail time. This guilty plea marks a significant development in the ongoing investigation into Volkswagen's role in the scandal.

site_title: Games in Washington, anxiety on Wall Street
summary: US President Joe Biden and Republican lawmakers remain locked in a standoff over raising the US debt ceiling, with the Biden administration demanding unconditional increases and Republican leaders insisting on major spending cuts. The negotiations have taken place against a backdrop of growing anxiety in the financial markets over the possibility of a US default, which could have dire consequences for the US and world economy. A deal must be reached before the expected "x-date" in June or August, with both sides having vested interests in ending the crisis to avoid economic recession and defeat in the 2024 elections.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden is due to leave Wednesday for a foreign trip that includes the Group of Seven and Quad summits.

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office forecast on Friday that the country could default on its debts by June 15 if lawmakers fail to agree on a deal with Biden to raise current limits on government spending.

site_title: Malaysia eyes late surge in tourist arrivals to meet 2023 target
summary: Malaysia is targeting 16.1 million foreign tourists in 2023, a 60% increase from last year. Authorities are banking on a late surge in tourist arrivals to meet the target, driven by improved visa approvals and flight connectivity. The government is speeding up approval for chartered flights and increasing flights to China, a key market, to boost arrivals. Despite a slow start, the government expects a surge in demand for the fourth quarter and is targeting at least 5 million Chinese arrivals this year. This is part of the government's broader goal to reach 23.5 million total arrivals by 2025.

images.alt_text: Asia is in the midst of a blistering heatwave, in line with predictions from climate scientists that 2023 could be the world’s hottest year.
Bank Negara Malaysia Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said: "The economy is no longer in crisis and in fact, continues to gain strenth."

site_title: Microsoft-Activision gets sliver of hope as EU defies UK
summary: The European Union (EU) has approved Microsoft's $69 billion takeover bid for Activision Blizzard, citing that the deal will boost competition and improve the cloud gaming market. The decision contrasts with UK and US antitrust authorities, who previously blocked the deal. Microsoft and Activision still face a challenge in convincing UK and US judges to side with them in legal challenges, particularly in Britain, where a specialized court has a history of siding with EU decisions. The EU's backing may provide greater ballast for Microsoft's appeal of the UK decision, but the outcome remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Microsoft logo is seen on a smartphone placed on displayed Activision Blizzard logo in this illustration taken January 18, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
“The CMA’s decision rejects a pragmatic path to address competition concerns and discourages technology innovation and investment in the UK.” Brad Smith, vice-chair and president of Microsoft, said.

site_title: EU agency revises down first-quarter growth figure
summary: The European Union's statistics agency, Eurostat, revised its first-quarter growth figure for the 27-member EU, reporting a 0.2% expansion instead of the previously estimated 0.3%. This represents a decrease from the initial projection. The single currency eurozone area saw no change in economic growth, recording 0.1%.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.3 per cent higher, after hitting a two-week high during the session.

site_title: Polestar: ‘We would like to team up’
summary: Polestar, an electric vehicle maker, is open to partnerships to tackle industry challenges, according to its chief operating officer Dennis Nobelius. The company, which is produced by Volvo, has lowered its 2023 production guidance and cut headcount by 10% due to industry difficulties. Nobelius emphasized the need for collaboration to decarbonize the supply chain, create cross-industry standards, and quickly adapt to new technologies. Polestar aims to make an impact by partnering with others to upscale the EV market.

site_title: Baidu’s revenue beats after China recovery fuels advertising
summary: Baidu's revenue surpassed expectations, rising 10% to 31.1 billion yuan (S$6 billion) in the first quarter, driven by strong demand for advertising and cloud services. The Chinese internet search leader's results indicate a revival for China's largest internet firms after two years of regulatory crackdowns and COVID restrictions. Baidu's AI efforts, including its ChatGPT-style service Ernie Bot, are gaining traction, but the company still relies on advertising sales to generate cash and fund riskier projects.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Men interact with a Baidu AI robot near the company logo at its headquarters in Beijing, China April 23, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: German finance ministry challenges EU bank rescue proposals
summary: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner criticized EU proposals on bank rescues, calling them "questionable" from an ethical, economic, and regulatory standpoint. He emphasized the importance of shareholder and national involvement in bank crisis management. EU finance ministers are meeting in Brussels to discuss the proposals, which include reforms to the bank crisis management and deposit insurance framework, as well as regulation on markets in cryptoassets. The proposals aim to strengthen the EU's banking system, but Lindner's comments suggest opposition to the measures.

images.alt_text: UBS will pay 3 billion Swiss francs (S$4.33 billion) for 167-year-old Credit  Suisse and assume up to US$5.4 billion in losses in a deal backed by a massive Swiss guarantee and expected to close by the end of 2023.

site_title: EU must build cutting-edge computer chips: industry chief
summary: EU industry chief Thierry Breton says Europe must manufacture its own cutting-edge computer chips, setting a goal to double its share in chip manufacturing to 20% of the global total. The EU's Chips Act aims to support chip manufacturing across the entire supply chain, not just research. Breton rejected the idea of focusing solely on older chip production, instead seeking to produce advanced nodes alongside Asia and the US. The plan has led to new projects and potential investments, with TSMC considering an investment in Germany.

images.alt_text: Josep Borrell stressed the aim was not to “de-couple” the European and Chinese economies but to rebalance the relationship.

site_title: East Ventures raises US$250 million for new Growth Plus fund
summary: East Ventures, an Indonesia-focused venture capital firm, has raised US$250 million for its Growth Plus fund, doubling down on growth portfolio companies within its ecosystem. The fund will invest in 5-10 companies from its existing Growth fund, following the close of US$585 million for its Seed and Growth funds. This comes amid a global venture slowdown and a record 48.8% decline in aggregate capital raised in Asia-Pacific in 2022.

site_title: China’s record-high youth jobless rate is set to get even worse
summary: China's youth jobless rate reached a record high of 20.4% in May, nearly four times the national rate. The rate is expected to worsen further with an estimated 11.58 million graduates entering the market this summer. This surge in joblessness highlights the economy's struggle to absorb new workers, despite growth rebounding from its pandemic slump and a declining labour force. Policymakers are under pressure to take action to address the issue.

images.alt_text: People attend a job fair in China's southwestern city of Chongqing on April 11, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: IEA says oil price downturn ignores looming supply crunch
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has raised its forecast for global oil demand by 200,000 barrels per day to 102 million bpd, citing China's strong recovery after lifting Covid-19 curbs. Despite weeks of declining oil prices due to recession concerns, the IEA expects a supply crunch in the second half of the year, with demand surpassing supply by almost 2 million bpd. The US and Brazil are expected to lead modest growth in oil supply, while China will account for nearly 60% of global demand growth in 2023.

site_title: Taiwan’s opposition to pick Hou for president over Foxconn’s Gou
summary: Taiwan's main opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), is set to nominate New Taipei City Mayor Hou Yu-ih as its candidate for next year's presidential election, bypassing Foxconn Technology Group founder Terry Gou. Hou's selection is due to his strength in opinion polls and broader support among lawmakers and local government leaders. He will face off against Vice President Lai Ching-te of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). A KMT nomination could make the 2024 presidential election a more competitive three-way race, with significant implications for US-China relations.

site_title: China chip firm seeking to rival ASML weighs IPO filing, sources say
summary: China's semiconductor software firm, Dongfang Jingyuan Electron, is reportedly preparing for an initial public offering (IPO) in China as early as next year. The company, valued at about 8 billion yuan, is considering listing on Shanghai's STAR board. This move comes as China spars with developed democracies over access to chipmaking technology. Dongfang attracted global attention in 2022 after semiconductor equipment giant ASML warned of potential intellectual property infringement. The company has denied any wrongdoing and claims its operations comply with relevant laws and regulations.

site_title: Macquarie raises hurdles to CDP joining KKR bid for Telecom Italia grid
summary: Australian fund Macquarie is raising legal issues about a possible alliance between CDP and KKR to buy Telecom Italia's landline grid, potentially hindering CDP's plan to join forces with KKR. CDP and Macquarie are co-investors in Open Fiber, a rival to TIM, and some clauses in the Open Fiber shareholder pact may complicate CDP's decision. The sale of TIM's grid is key for the phone group to cut its debt pile, with KKR's approach seen as the stronger alternative by TIM CEO Pietro Labriola and some government officials.

images.alt_text: SembWaste is one of three public waste collectors appointed by Singapore’s National Environment Agency to provide waste and recyclable collection services to residential, schools and trade premises in the city-state, according to its website.

site_title: India plans to challenge EU carbon tax at WTO: sources
summary: India plans to file a complaint to the World Trade Organization (WTO) against the European Union's proposed 20-35% carbon tax on high-carbon imports, targeting Indian steel, iron ore, and cement exports. The EU aims to become a net-zero emitter by 2050, ahead of India's 2070 target. India sees the levy as discriminatory and a trade barrier, and will seek relief for exporters, particularly small companies. The move is part of New Delhi's strategy to combat the EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism and protect its industries.

images.alt_text: Developing Asia – which relies on steady and cheap access to power, currently coal generated for the most part, for economic growth – cannot simply replace coal with renewable energy.

site_title: OCBC to stop backing upstream oil and gas projects approved after 2021
summary: OCBC Bank, Southeast Asia's second-largest lender, has announced it will reduce absolute emissions from its oil and gas sector by 95% by 2050 and stop financing upstream oil and gas projects approved after 2021. The bank also set decarbonisation targets for five other sectors, including power, real estate, steel, aviation, and shipping, aiming to reduce emissions per unit of output or activity. OCBC aims to reach net zero by 2040 for the power sector, which is expected to have a significant impact on revenue and client relationships.

images.alt_text: OCBC's chief executive officer Helen Wong (middle), head of global whole banking Tan Teck Long (left) and head of global wholesale banking sustainability office Mike Ng (right) announcing the bank's decarbonisation targets on May 16, 2023.
Janice Lim

site_title: UK’s Landsec swings to annual loss as property valuation drops
summary: UK's Landsec reports annual loss as rising interest rates and economic worries dampen commercial property sector's recovery from pandemic lows. The company expects low- to mid-single digit rental value growth in London and major retail destinations this fiscal year. This follows a tentative recovery in the highly leveraged British commercial property sector. Landsec is likely to sell more assets than purchase due to surging interest rates and economic woes. The office space portfolio, in particular, has struggled with evolving work habits.

images.alt_text: Britain’s housing market is facing disruption in the wake of higher borrowing costs and the threat of a house price plunge.

site_title: China’s property investment, sales drop sharply in April on subdued demand
summary: China's property investment and sales declined sharply in April, with property investment falling 16.2% year-over-year and property sales by floor area slumping 11.8% on-year. This marks the fastest decline since November 2022, and follows a 7.2% decline in March. The decline suggests weak sustainability of the market rebound and highlights the need for more policies to boost the market. Moody's recently changed its outlook on China's property sector to stable from negative, predicting uneven recovery and improved funding conditions with policy support.

images.alt_text: In Hong Kong, most variable rate home loans have a cap based on the prime lending rate. Major lenders have raised that rate by about 75 basis points since last year.

epa10476862 A general view shows real estate buildings in Beijing, China, 19 February 2023. New home prices in China rose for the first time in a year in January 2023, according to official data released by the National Bureau of Statistics.  EPA-EFE/WU HAO

site_title: Morgan Stanley weighs cutting 7% of Asia investment bank jobs
summary: Morgan Stanley is considering a 7% cut in its Asia-Pacific investment banking workforce, with over 40 jobs at risk, mainly in China due to deteriorating US-China relations and weaker economic growth. This is part of the bank's plan to reduce 3,000 global jobs by the end of the quarter. The cuts come as dealmaking activity slows, with Morgan Stanley already having axed 50 investment-banking jobs in Asia last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., November 11, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
Morgan Stanley in December cut roughly 1,600 jobs.

site_title: Activist investor Peltz adds to Disney stake following share sale
summary: Activist investor Nelson Peltz has added to his stake in Walt Disney Co, purchasing roughly 500,000 more shares to bring his total to 6.4 million. Peltz-owned Trian Fund Management initially had 9.4 million shares but cut its stake by 34% by March-end. Peltz had ended his quest for a board seat after Disney's CEO, Bob Iger, announced plans to cut 7,000 jobs to save $5.5 billion. Peltz stated that he believes Disney's initiatives can create value and is monitoring management's execution closely.

images.alt_text: Nelson Peltz, who says Disney’s problems are primarily self-inflicted, has not given a detailed plan for achieving his goals.

site_title: Banks call for scrapping UK share tax to boost London
summary: UK banks have called for the scrapping of UK share tax to boost London's attractiveness as a global financial centre. The 0.5% stamp duty on share purchases is seen as a major deterrent to investors. UK Finance, the banking body, has made recommendations to reduce costs and increase accessibility, including removing the tax and fast-tracking the issuance of digitized UK government bonds. The aim is to make London's markets more attractive and dependable, in response to global competition post-Brexit.

images.alt_text: A British Union flag on top of the Bank of England in the City of London, UK, on Monday, May 15, 2023. The upcoming batch of jobs data, due on Tuesday, May 16, is likely to show price pressures in the economy remain way too high for the Bank of England to tolerate. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
Britain’s housing market is facing disruption in the wake of higher borrowing costs and the threat of a house price plunge.

site_title: China stocks fall after April activity data misses forecasts; HK flat
summary: China's blue-chip CSI300 Index and Shanghai Composite Index declined 0.5% and 0.6% respectively on May 16, after April activity data missed forecasts, indicating a slow economic recovery trend. Industrial output and retail sales growth undershot expectations, with Goldman Sachs analysts describing the data as "broadly and significantly" missed. The data added to recent data highlighting a wobbly post-Covid recovery, leading to a risk-off tone in Chinese assets with bonds rallying.

images.alt_text: While there have been recent signs of stabilisation in China's property sector, there is uncertainty over the strength of the momentum.
Industrial output grew 5.6 per cent in April from a year earlier.

site_title: European investors keen to buy more social bonds: survey
summary: European investors are keen to invest more in social bonds, with nearly half of surveyed investment professionals planning to increase their allocations to the asset class in the next 12 months. The market for social bonds has grown to 464 billion euros, with 29% of investors already investing and 36% interested in allocating capital. However, respondents cited a shortage of investment products and concerns over market diversification as top impediments. The market is expected to continue growing, with GSAM's global head of green, social and impact bonds stating that social bonds should be included in a well-diversified portfolio.

images.alt_text: The energy crisis has raised the prospect of more long term sustainable debt issuance to finance Europe's energy transition.

site_title: Making Asian shipowners’ voices heard
summary: Asian shipowners gathered at the Singapore Maritime Week 2023 to discuss the challenges and opportunities facing the global shipping industry. The International Shipping Forum (ISF) of the Asian Shipowners' Association (ASA) emphasized the importance of achieving common prosperity, mutual trust, and cooperation in shipping. Key industry leaders, including the International Maritime Organization's secretary-general Kitack Lim and the International Chamber of Shipping's secretary-general Guy Platten, highlighted the urgency for decarbonization and the need for a credible plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The forum also explored topics such as "blue and safe shipping," safety at sea, and the role of human resources in the industry.

images.alt_text: port, ships, cranes

site_title: Fidelity eyes expansion of private-asset capability in Asia
summary: Fidelity International, led by Asia-Pacific managing director Rajeev Mittal, plans to expand its private-asset capability in the region, starting with distribution and potentially asset management. The company has been building its private-asset business over the past three to four years and aims to bring its global capabilities to Asia. Fidelity has already raised one billion yuan in its first China equity fund launch earlier this year. The move is driven by growing demand for private-market investments in Asia, particularly in the institutional and wealth segments.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
BlackRock still hasn’t issued any products under the new programme even though its wealth management joint venture was allowed to join given its experience with a previous trial.
Vanguard, with US$7.1 trillion in assets under management globally, owns a 49 per cent stake in the Ant-controlled JV.

site_title: Don’t learn the wrong lessons from market crashes
summary: During the 2022 market crash, investors often learned the wrong lessons, including avoiding all stocks due to high interest rates, timing entry based on the Fed's next move, selling before bad news hits, falling for the stock price narrative, and waiting for lower volatility. Experts warn against making blanket conclusions and emotional decisions, instead emphasizing the importance of a long-term view, staying invested, and avoiding timing the market. Historically, missing the best days in the stock market is worse than missing the worst days, and investors should focus on maintaining a steady investment strategy, as suggested by Peter Lynch.

site_title: Vodafone to cut 11,000 jobs, forecasts flat earnings
summary: Vodafone's new boss, Margherita Della Valle, plans to cut 11,000 jobs over three years to simplify the telecoms group, aiming to regain competitiveness. The company forecasts flat earnings for the new financial year, with a 1.3% decline in group core earnings due to underperforming Germany and higher energy costs. However, growth in Africa and higher handset sales resulted in a 0.3% rise in revenue to 45.7 billion euros. Della Valle prioritizes customers, simplicity, and growth, seeking to cut complexity and regain competitiveness.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A branded sign is displayed on a Vodafone store in London, Britain,  May 16, 2017. REUTERS/Neil Hall/File Photo

site_title: Winners and risks for investors from changing the meritocratic system
summary: Singapore's meritocratic system, which emphasizes equal opportunities and merit-based promotions, is set for significant changes. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong aims to narrow the wage gap across professions and provide fairer starting conditions. Investors can benefit from consumer-related plays, such as food and beverage groups and suburban mall landlords, as the middle-income group grows in disposable income. However, there are risks, including higher costs and inflation, and potential negative impacts on businesses and consumers. The changes may also affect the country's competitive edge and global GDP.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Singapore will continue to sustain real income growth for the middle, which is why economic growth is “non-negotiable” for the city-state, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

The government will invest in Singaporeans “throughout life”, said Education Minister Chan Chun Sing, ith plans to make training more accessible for working adults with competing commitments and support more targeted for mid-career workers, including SkillsFuture Credit top-ups.
If meritocracy necessarily results in unequal outcomes, the question is: Can we rely on such a system to deliver good outcomes for everyone?

site_title: Thai industry group warns of impact of big wage increases
summary: A Thai industry group, the Federation of Thai Industries (FTI), warns that big wage increases promised by the new ruling coalition will hurt businesses, jobs, and competitiveness. The group, which has proposed a daily minimum wage of 450 baht (S$17.7), suggests that wages should be set based on skills and productivity. The FTI's sentiment index dropped to 95.0 in April, citing weak global demand, higher production costs, and currency volatility. The group urges a new government to address economic challenges quickly, amid concerns that high wages will lead to job losses.

images.alt_text: epa08810633 Muslim Thai royalists wearing yellow hold a large portrait of Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkunattend during a pro-monarchy rally at Chalerm Phrakiat National Administration Center for Islamic Affairs in Bangkok, Thailand, 10 November 2020. Muslim royalists gathered in support for the Thai King after the pro-democracy protesters held street protests calling for monarchy reform.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Embattled Rakuten announces 332 billion yen share issue to bolster finances
summary: Rakuten, a Japanese e-commerce and fintech firm, announced a 332 billion yen share issue to bolster its finances. The funds will be used for debt repayment and building base stations. The company aims to raise 290 billion yen through a public offering and 41.8 billion yen for its founder and CEO, Hiroshi Mikitani. Shares in Rakuten lost 5.1% ahead of the announcement, following a previous day's sharp decline.

images.alt_text: Rakuten’s market capitalisation has fallen about US$1.66 billion.

site_title: Philips says tests on 95% of recalled devices show limited risks
summary: Philips, a Dutch medical devices maker, announced that 95% of its respiratory devices involved in a major global recall have shown limited health risks, according to independent tests. The recall was initiated in June 2021 due to concerns over toxic foam used in the machines. Philips expects to have test results for the remaining machines later in the year.

site_title: A long way to go for India’s demographic dividend
summary: India's demographic dividend, touted as a means to boost its economy, is being overhyped due to regional disparities. While the southern peninsula, with higher literacy rates and more industrialized states, is driving growth, the northern regions lag behind, hindered by the caste system and limited access to education. India's GDP has declined to 17% of China's, and overcoming these obstacles will take time, making the country's economic growth a long slog ahead.

images.alt_text: Over the period to 2040, India will likely add 270 million people to its urban population.
Children playing in the village square after school in Xiasha village in Shenzhen, China, Nov 16, 2022. Deaths outnumbered births last year in China for the first time in six decades.
The population declines seen today in some countries have come about largely as a happy story of greater longevity and freedom.
Crowding at a raillway station in Mumbai. India has become the world's most populous nation, overtaking China.
Vietnam will soon become the 16th country in the world with more than 100 million people.

site_title: Musk buys job tool Laskie in first acquisition for Twitter
summary: Elon Musk's X has acquired tech talent recruiting service Laskie in its first major acquisition, marking one of Musk's first major initiatives since buying Twitter for $44 billion in October. Laskie matches tech talent with potential employers and will be integrated into Musk's holding company, although its current website displays a message indicating it is no longer available. Musk plans to turn Twitter into an "everything app" with various features, including financial services, as part of his efforts to revamp the platform.

site_title: Climate risks push Indonesia to explore blue bond market
summary: Indonesia is marketing a Samurai deal of blue bonds in the yen market to raise funds for ocean-related projects. This would be the first yen-denominated blue bond issuance from a foreign borrower, marking a rare sale. Proceeds will fund ocean conservation and climate change mitigation programs, following the pioneering efforts of Seychelles in 2018. The move aims to tap yield-hungry Japanese investors, with the Bank of Japan's ultra-dovish policy keeping rates anchored close to zero.

site_title: UAE invites Syria's Assad to COP28 climate summit
summary: The UAE has invited Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to the COP28 climate summit in December, a move that has sparked controversy given the country's human rights record and Assad's involvement in a brutal civil war. Fellow Arab states have warmed to Syria again after isolating Assad for over a decade, following a devastating earthquake in February. The invitation aims to promote inclusivity at the summit, with thousands of world leaders expected to attend. The move has been met with skepticism from the US, which does not see merit in Assad's readmission to the Arab League.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Syrian President Bashar al-Assad addresses new members of parliament in Damascus, Syria, in this handout released by SANA on August 12, 2020. SANA/Handout via REUTERS/File Photo

The Arab League decision to disregard US reservations reflects America’s waning influence in the oil-exporting region and a growing willingness among allies to forge their own political path and build stronger strategic ties with US rivals.

site_title: South-east Asia seeks global recognition for ‘special’ kebaya craft
summary: Southeast Asian countries Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, Brunei, and Thailand have jointly nominated the kebaya, a traditional blouse worn by women across the region, for the UN's intangible cultural heritage list, with a decision expected in 2024. The kebaya, which originated in the Middle East and was once worn by both men and women, has evolved into a symbol of cultural heritage and identity, with over a dozen styles developed across Southeast Asia. The blouse is suited to hot tropical weather and can range from simple machine-made designs to intricate handmade pieces, often worn to formal events and daily life.

images.alt_text: Love, Kebaya exhibition at the National Museum of Singapore features different varieties of the kebaya.

site_title: PBOC vows ‘appropriate’ monetary policy, sees inflation rising
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has pledged to keep monetary policy "appropriate" while interest rates remain reasonable, amid concerns over the sustainability of China's economic recovery. Inflation is expected to rise, but the central bank stressed that China is not in "deflation." The PBOC has maintained a cautious approach to rate decisions, citing uncertainty in the global economy, and vowed to make its support for the economy more sustainable.

images.alt_text: The PPBOC offered 125 billion yuan of the medium-term lending facility (MLF), 25 billion yuan more than the amount maturing in May.

site_title: UK jobless rate rises as people return to labour market
summary: The UK's unemployment rate unexpectedly rose to 3.9% in the three months to March as more people sought to rejoin the labor market. This rise was attributed to men, with employment and unemployment both increasing. The Office for National Statistics (ONS) reported a first fall in payrolled employees in over two years in April. The data may ease concerns at the Bank of England about inflation pressures, contradicting economists' expectations of a steady 3.8% rate.

images.alt_text: Soaring inflation has delivered a squeeze on household spending power that may tighten in the next few months.

site_title: Gold dips as markets assess rate-hike remarks, debt-ceiling debate
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.3% to $2,014.62 per ounce as traders assessed US central bank officials' comments on maintaining high interest rates, which dulls the appeal of non-yielding bullion. US interest rates are seen staying high, with markets pricing in a 75.3% chance of holding rates steady in June. The US Treasury Department warned of a possible government shutdown if a debt ceiling deal isn't reached, with President Joe Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy set to meet for talks.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.4 per cent at US$22,018.76 per ounce by 0727 GMT, after falling for three sessions. US gold futures rose 0.2 per cent to US$2,023.60.

site_title: Asia: Markets wobble as US struggles to reach debt deal
summary: Asian markets struggled to extend gains on Tuesday as the US debt deal remained uncertain, with Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy warning that staff-level meetings were unproductive and that a deal was "nowhere near" being reached. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the government would likely run out of cash on June 1, sparking concerns of a potentially devastating default. Meanwhile, Federal Reserve officials suggested pausing interest rate hikes next month, citing the ongoing impact of previous increases on inflation.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Wellington were all down, though Tokyo and Jakarta edged up on Monday.

site_title: A bird in hand is worth less than two in the bush
summary: Investors are advised to consider the trade-off between income generation and capital growth when creating their investment portfolios. A "bird in the hand" approach, focusing on income generation through bonds, may underperform a "birds in the bush" strategy, prioritizing capital growth through equities. According to a recent CIO Office analysis, expected returns on bonds have risen to 4% and on global equities to 7%, suggesting equities are expected to outperform bonds over the long run. Investors with a long-term horizon (over 10 years) are recommended to allocate a significant portion of their portfolio to a growth-oriented strategy.

images.alt_text: Acknowledging that there are several potential outcomes in markets benefits investors. It prevents you from investing on the expectation of just one oucome, and helps to prepare you for market fluctuations.

site_title: Musk tells Tesla staff he must approve all hiring: report
summary: Elon Musk has reportedly instructed Tesla staff to submit all hiring requests for approval, including contractors, to him personally. He has also asked executives to send him a list of hiring requests on a weekly basis. This move is expected to allow Musk to focus more time on running Tesla, following his recent appointment of Linda Yaccarino as Twitter's new CEO.

site_title: Rakuten shares slump 6% on expected 300 billion yen new share issuance
summary: Rakuten shares plummet 6% after the company announced plans to issue 300 billion yen in new shares to shore up its finances, following a quarterly loss. The move is expected to dilute existing shareholders, prompting concerns about share price stability. Rakuten's market capitalization has fallen approximately $1.66 billion since the news broke, marking the company's largest one-day drop in three years.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on November 9, 2022 shows people walking past a mobile shop of Japanese e-commerce firm Rakuten in Tokyo. - Rakuten are expected to announce their second quarter results on November 11. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

This picture taken on November 9, 2022 shows people walking past a mobile shop of Japanese e-commerce firm Rakuten in Tokyo. - Rakuten are expected to announce their second quarter results on November 11. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)
The investor questions, not previously reported, highlight how concerns about the e-commerce giant’s losses and mounting debt cast a shadow on Japan’s biggest IPO in more than four years.

site_title: China’s factory output, consumption highlight frail post-Covid economic recovery
summary: China's industrial output and retail sales growth in April fell short of expectations, indicating the economy's fragile post-Covid recovery. Industrial output grew 5.6% year-over-year, while retail sales jumped 18.4%, both below forecasts. The data signals weak domestic demand and pressure on policymakers to shore up the economy, which is facing challenges from global growth falters, Western bank failures, and the Ukraine war. China's central bank kept interest rates unchanged, but markets expect further monetary easing.

images.alt_text: Many Chinese women are reluctant to have more than one or even any children due to the high costs of child-rearing and as the lack of childcare.
While there have been recent signs of stabilisation in China's property sector, there is uncertainty over the strength of the momentum.

site_title: Hot stock: OUE Healthcare up 19.2% on heavy trading after hospital commissioning
summary: OUE Healthcare shares surged 19.2% on heavy trading after the company launched its new hospital in Changshu, China, in a 50:50 joint venture with China Merchant Group. The hospital, which spans 23,000 square meters, offers obstetrics, gynaecology, and other medical services. The stock hit an 11-month high, with 34.6 million shares changing hands during the midday trading break. The hospital's commissioning was officially marked by Singapore's Senior Minister Koh Poh Koon and Suzhou mayor Wu Qingwen.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

Mount Elizabeth Hospital, which is under PLife Reit. In addition to the ongoing recycling of its nursing homes properties in Japan and the acquisition pipeline from its sponsor, the manager of PLife Reit is looking to build a “third pillar” for the next phase of growth.
OUE Lippo Healthcare was notably in a negative working capital position as at end-December last year, with net current liabilities amounting to S$21.5 million.

site_title: Alibaba vows ‘historic’ investment in Taobao and content
summary: Alibaba's e-commerce division, Taobao, plans to make significant investments in AI-powered tools and content creation to boost user engagement and compete with social media platforms. The move aims to improve the user experience, offering merchants free smart operation tools and adjusting platform fees to benefit them. Following the launch of OpenAI's ChatGPT, Alibaba prioritizes AI development, attracting investments and talent to the sector.

images.alt_text: Shein and Temu have taken the world by storm, with a potent combination of ultra-low prices and personalised recommendations.
Cainiao, which has started work on the IPO, is looking to raise between US$1 billion and US$2 billion in Hong Kong, according to three sources.

site_title: China courts Central Asia as Russia’s influence wanes
summary: China is strengthening its ties with Central Asian countries, seeking to fill the economic vacuum left by Russia's influence waning due to Western sanctions. President Xi Jinping will host leaders of the five countries in Xi'an for a "milestone significance" summit, aiming to push ahead with massive infrastructure projects. Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative has already received $150 billion in funding for roads, ports, and railways, with trade reaching $70 billion in 2022. However, concerns remain over China's approach, including debt traps, human rights issues, and economic asymmetry, which has fueled growing phobias and anti-China sentiment in the region.

images.alt_text: Industrial output grew 5.6 per cent in April from a year earlier.
Many Chinese women are reluctant to have more than one or even any children due to the high costs of child-rearing and as the lack of childcare.
While there have been recent signs of stabilisation in China's property sector, there is uncertainty over the strength of the momentum.

site_title: Amazon plans to add ChatGPT-style search to its online store
summary: Amazon plans to introduce a chatGPT-style search feature to its online store, aiming to improve its search experience and rival Microsoft and Google's efforts in generative AI-powered search. The feature, designed to help users find products, compare them, and receive personalized suggestions, is part of Amazon's significant investment in generative AI. The company is seeking skilled engineers to develop this interactive conversational experience, which has the potential to transform its core retail business.

images.alt_text: The game will be set in Middle-earth, featuring stories from "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings" literary trilogy written by J R R Tolkien.

With Amazon Anywhere, introduced on Tuesday (May 9), the company will let people on gaming, mobile, web and augmented-reality (AR) applications buy related real-world items without leaving the experience.

site_title: This slow-burn financial crisis could still bring on a  recession
summary: A US financial crisis may lead to recession, as American banks continue to fall. The latest bank to drop is First Republic Bank, valued at $200 billion, following smaller banks like PacWest Bancorp, which saw a 10% deposit depletion in a week. Strategists warn that this wave of bank failures can only end in recession or government intervention, as the US bank run wave began with Silicon Valley Bank's digital customer deluge in March.

images.alt_text: Stubbornly high inflation and aggressive central bank action could lead to stagflation and erode the safety offered by long-term sovereign bonds.
“Clients recognise the fact that there are only a few institutions like ours that can make the investments to remain committed over the long term, and at a larger scale,” says BofA's Bernard Mensah.
The G7 finance leaders are expected to set a year-end deadline for launching a new scheme to diversify global supply chains.

epa10611267 A Pacific Western Bank branch is seen in Glendale, California, USA, 05 May 2023. Fears about the health of US financial instituions deepended this past week after reports that PacWest Bancorp is considering strategic options.  EPA-EFE/CAROLINE BREHMAN

site_title: China aims for better-skilled population, to improve childcare
summary: China aims to improve its population's skills and fertility rate by focusing on education, science, and technology. The country will strive for a "moderate fertility" level to support economic growth. China has doubled its childcare centre plans to 2025, increasing caregivers per 1,000 people to 4.5 from 2.5 in 2022. Financial incentives and boosting childcare facilities are part of the government's measures to lift the country's birth rate, which has declined for the first time in six decades. Authorities have proposed opening up fertility services to unmarried women to boost fertility.
