images.alt_text: While there have been recent signs of stabilisation in China's property sector, there is uncertainty over the strength of the momentum.

The so-called Swap Connect programme between mainland China and Hong Kong will provide overseas funds with easier access to the derivatives that will help hedge their exposure to the world’s second-biggest bond market.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 5.09 points to 3,219.81. Gainers outnumbered losers 66 to 62, driven by shares of Seatrium, ComfortDelGro, and CapitaLand Ascott Trust. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also traded higher. In contrast, US shares ended trading on Friday up, driven by optimism over US debt negotiations and the recovery of regional bank stocks.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit to acquire Seagate facility; proposes S$450 million private placement
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit plans to acquire a research and development facility and business park property in Singapore's one-north district for S$218.2 million. The acquisition is expected to be distribution per unit (DPU) accretive to unitholders, increasing DPU by 0.7% or 0.11 Singapore cents. The deal is valued at S$450 million, including a S$450 million private placement. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of 2023, pending regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: The property, which is located at 1 Buroh Lane, is the real estate investment trust’s (Reit) first cold storage facility investment in Singapore.

site_title: Vietnam PM approves US$135 billion power plan for 2030
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh has approved a US$134.7 billion power plan, known as PDP8, to ensure energy security and transition to carbon neutrality by 2050. The plan aims to increase power generation capacity to 158 GW by 2030, with a focus on renewable energy sources, including rooftop solar panels, green energy for exports, and offshore wind. The plan is crucial to unlock billions of dollars in foreign investment, including US$15.5 billion in green-transition funds pledged by the G7 nations, and is seen as an important step towards Vietnam's carbon neutrality goal.

images.alt_text: Vietnam aims to become a developed and high-income nation by 2050 with economic growth based on science, technology, innovation and digital transformation.
Sky Mavis’s office is located in downtown Ho Chi Minh City, where the entire game engineering and art teams are based.

site_title: Buffett exits TSMC while hedge funds Coatue, Tiger Global buy
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has exited its position in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC), slashing its holding by 86% in the first quarter. Meanwhile, hedge funds Coatue Management and Tiger Global Management added TSMC shares, citing concerns over geopolitical tensions between China and Taiwan. TSMC shares rose 1.7% after the news, as investors await signs of recovery amid weak global electronics demand and inventory glut. The company maintains its annual capital spending target, indicating its intention to shore up its lead in advanced semiconductors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) is pictured at its headquarters, in Hsinchu, Taiwan, Jan. 19, 2021. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks rise as banking shares advance
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 0.1% to 33,348.60. Regional bank shares, which had been beaten down following four bank failures earlier in the year, advanced by at least six percent. Analysts cited a more positive tone surrounding US debt limit negotiations between President Biden and Republican leaders as a factor in the market's upward trend.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 4, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: AT1 revival in Asia-Pacific picks up steam as CBA plans offering
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia plans to sell at least A$750 million of Additional Tier 1 (AT1) securities, rebounding from a global selloff sparked by the collapse of Credit Suisse Group. This follows a sale by Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group last month, and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group is also targeting a yen-denominated AT1 bond sale. The Asia-Pacific market for AT1 securities is slowly recovering, with banks returning to selling senior debt after a brief pause. Pricing for CBA's offering is expected to be around 3-3.2% above the bank bill swap rate.

site_title: Amid manpower crunch, SMEs should invest in upskilling to thrive: business leaders
summary: Singaporean business leaders stress the importance of upskilling for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) amid a manpower crunch. Technology continues to disrupt traditional business models, and SMEs must adapt to remain competitive. Experts, such as Koren Wines of Xero, note that the Covid-19 pandemic accelerated digital transformation and implementation of new solutions among SMEs. Investing in upskilling is crucial for SMEs to bridge the gap and thrive in a rapidly changing business landscape.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
One way for SMEs to cope with rising costs is to innovate by tapping existing government grants to adopt the digitalisation and subsequent automation of certain back-end functions.
SMEs can tap digitalisation, grants to mitigate rising costs: business leaders

site_title: The May art auctions will feature fewer works, bigger price tags
summary: May art auctions will feature fewer works with bigger price tags, following the unprecedented November sales. Sotheby's will sell a Gustav Klimt landscape for $45 million and an Henri Rousseau painting for $20-30 million. The May sales are expected to be a "comparatively subdued affair" after the November sales, which saw $3 billion spent on art in two weeks, with smaller overall volume of auctions across all houses. The market is expected to revert to a "normative level of strength".

images.alt_text: A 25.59-carat ruby ring from Cartier sold for 13 million Swiss francs, just missing its low estimate of 14 million Swiss francs
The Codex Sassoon is more than 1,000 years old and is one of only two codices containing all 24 books of the Hebrew Bible to have survived into the modern era.

site_title: Unilever, NVPC launch ‘purpose-driven’ growth programme for SMEs
summary: Unilever and the National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) have launched a "Purpose for Growth" programme for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, aiming to help them adopt corporate purpose and enhance their business competitiveness. The programme, to be run on Unilever's campus, includes two phases: an information session and structured learning with Unilever business leaders. The initiative aims to guide SMEs on aligning their businesses with environmental, social, and governance trends, and will provide resources from Unilever's network of suppliers and partners.

images.alt_text: Companies deliver value to all stakeholders by doing more in the people, society, governance, economic and environment areas.
Companies must work to make a difference in the society, and this begins with having a corporate purpose.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, ComfortDelGro, Penguin International
summary: Singapore Airlines' passenger volumes show signs of slowing recovery, with an 85.5% increase in April compared to the same month last year. CapitaLand Ascendas Reit plans to acquire a research facility for S$218.2 million through a private placement. ComfortDelGro posted a 56.9% drop in earnings due to inflationary cost pressures. Penguin International's consortium has raised its offer to take the company private to S$0.83 per share, a 16.9% premium.

site_title: Vietnam firms rank higher than global average in digitalisation: DBS
summary: Vietnam firms have ranked higher than the global average in digitalisation, according to a study by DBS. The country ranked second only to Singapore, with 63% of companies satisfied with digital transformation's impact on overall profitability. Gaps in talent and data privacy issues are the biggest challenges hindering digital transformation in Vietnam, as the country aims to become a developed and high-income nation by 2050.

images.alt_text: VNG's 12,400-square-meter data centre located Ho Chi Minh City in January is one of the three DCs in Vietnam that achieve both Tier-III certifications of design documents and constructed facility by Uptime Institute

site_title: Goldman to open Abu Dhabi office in sign of moving past 1MDB
summary: Goldman Sachs is opening an office in Abu Dhabi, marking a significant step in the bank's efforts to move past its involvement in the 1MDB scandal. The new office, located in Abu Dhabi Global Market, will focus on asset management and deepen relationships with clients. This move comes as the bank expands across the Middle East, following other major financial institutions. Goldman Sachs had previously been snubbed by Abu Dhabi for its role in the 1MDB scandal but has since been able to "draw a line under the scandal."

images.alt_text: Goldman's US$215 million settlement of the gender-discrimination class-action lawsuit against it means the juicy details of its culture and practices won’t be aired in court.
Currently, Canton Network can connect existing applications built using Daml – such as Goldman’s Digital Asset Platform.

site_title: Tanjong Pagar site up for en bloc sale again at unchanged S$216 million reserve price
summary: A 999-year leasehold commercial site in Singapore's Central Business District is up for collective sale via public tender at an unchanged reserve price of S$216 million. The site, comprising two five-storey buildings and remnant land, is zoned for commercial use and has a plot ratio of 5.6. The tender, which closes on May 31, is seen as an opportunity to take advantage of the absence of restrictions on strata subdivision in the CBD. Experts predict that the sale could attract interest from developers due to the site's prime location and potential for redevelopment into an iconic office building.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Wells Fargo to pay US$1 billion in class-action lawsuit
summary: Wells Fargo has agreed to pay US$1 billion to settle a shareholder lawsuit alleging the bank made misleading statements about its compliance with federal consent orders following the 2016 scandal involving unauthorized customer accounts. The settlement, one of the largest securities class-action settlements of the past decade, will go to investors who bought Wells Fargo stock from February 2018 to March 2020. The bank has previously agreed to pay US$3 billion to settle US investigations into widespread consumer abuses and US$480 million to settle another shareholder lawsuit.

images.alt_text: SAN BRUNO, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 14: A customer uses an ATM at a Wells Fargo Bank on April 14, 2023 in San Bruno, California. Wells Fargo reported better-than-expected first quarter earnings of $5 billion, a 32 percent increase from earnings of $3.8 billion one year ago.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Founder behind historic China bicycle bust starts over in New York City
summary: Dai Wei, the founder of the now-defunct Chinese bike-sharing startup Ofo, has started a new venture in New York City, About Time Coffee, which has raised over $10 million in funding. The coffee chain, backed by Chinese venture firms, has gained popularity with its affordable prices and trendy iced boba coffee. Dai, who stepped away from the public eye after Ofo's demise, is a minority shareholder and has helped build the team, but is not involved in day-to-day operations. About Time aims to expand its business model, which includes mobile payments and customer data collection, to woo New Yorkers.

images.alt_text: China's Luckin Coffee seeks US Chapter 15 bankruptcy protection

site_title: UBS poaches half dozen tech bankers from Barclays
summary: UBS has hired a half dozen technology, media, and telecommunications bankers from Barclays, including Richard Hardegree and Laurence Braham, in its push to expand US investment banking. The hires come as UBS prepares to integrate Credit Suisse, a deal orchestrated by the Swiss government. The talent reshuffling is part of a larger trend in the industry, with Credit Suisse rivals seeking new opportunities at other firms. UBS has already hired a trio of Barclays bankers in April, including Marco Valla, who will become co-head of global banking.

site_title: Locofy.ai raises US$4.3 million in seed II funding round
summary: Locofy.ai, a front-end development acceleration platform using AI to convert designs to code, has raised US$4.3 million in its Seed II funding round. The company, founded in 2021, helps developers build and manage front-end functions with a low-code development tool in public beta. The funding round includes participants Northstar Ventures, Golden Gate Ventures, Accel, and individual investors from Dropbox and Tinder. Locofy.ai's technology converts designs from Figma and Adobe XD into code for React, React Native, HTML-CSS, Gatsby, and Next.js platforms.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Flash Coffee has raised a further US$50 million amid fiercer competition and after a round of layoffs in November 2022.

site_title: Nasdaq-listed global wealth management group acquires AL Wealth Partners
summary: Global wealth management group AlTi Tiedemann Global has acquired AL Wealth Partners, a Singapore-based multifamily office with assets under management of close to S$1.5 billion. The merger is expected to enhance AlTi's advisory services for wealthy families, particularly in impact capital and philanthropic objectives. AL Wealth Partners' co-founders, Anthonia Hui and Leonardo Drago, will join AlTi, bringing their expertise in impact investing and philanthropy to the firm. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand AlTi's services and tap into Singapore's growing family office space.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Growth in Singapore’s AUM due mostly to institutional investors, not high-net-worth individuals
Setting up a family office is just the first step of a long journey for one that’s being built to last.

site_title: US banking regulators open to mergers, but vow tougher rules
summary: US banking regulators are open to future bank mergers, but vow to establish tougher rules after recent turmoil, including the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank. Acting Comptroller of the Currency Michael Hsu signaled the agency's willingness to consider merger proposals, while Federal Reserve Vice Chair Michael Barr and FDIC Chairman Martin Gruenberg emphasized the need for stricter oversight and regulations. The regulators aim to address concerns about bank consolidation and the impact on the financial system, particularly for large regional banks with over $100 billion in assets.

images.alt_text: The average age of battery electric vehicles (BEV) in the US actually fell to 3.6 years, down slightly from 3.7 years in 2022. That figure has hovered between 3 and 4 years since 2017, the group said.

site_title: Oil gains over 1%, ends losing streak on tightening supplies
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Monday, ending a three-session decline, due to tightening global crude supplies, particularly in Canada, where wildfires are shutting in large amounts of crude supply. Opec+ plans to implement additional output cuts in the second half, further contributing to the supply squeeze. Despite this, recession fears continue to pressure the market, with Brent crude futures settling at $75.23 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $71.11 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell 43 cents, or 0.6 per cent, to US$73.74 a barrel by 0130 GMT on Monday.

site_title: LNG exporters eye new Australia growth as profit boom fades
summary: Australia's LNG exporters aim to revive growth with multibillion-dollar projects, driven by increased competition for Asian buyers and the need for additional fossil fuel supplies to support the region's energy transition. The sector's investments have totaled around A$300 billion over the past 15 years, transforming Australia into the world's top LNG shipper. However, exports are forecast to decline, with the country expected to fall behind the US and Qatar as the industry's top exporter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A liquefied natural gas (LNG) tanker is tugged towards a thermal power station in Futtsu, east of Tokyo, Japan November 13, 2017. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
A flag seen at a climate protest near Songdo Convensia, where the Asian Development Bank was holding its annual business meeting on Thursday (May 4).

site_title: US consumers keep vehicles for a record 12.5 years on average: S&P
summary: US consumers are keeping their vehicles for a record 12.5 years on average, according to a study by S&P Global Mobility. This is partly due to supply constraints and reduced demand in 2022, leading to higher vehicle ages. However, the average age of battery electric vehicles (BEVs) in the US has fallen to 3.6 years, down from 3.7 years in 2022. This trend is expected to continue as BEV sales increase, with new vehicle sales projected to surpass 14.5 million in 2023.

images.alt_text: Electric car sales globally are expected to surge 35 per cent this year to 14 million, comprising 18 per cent of the passenger car market, up from just 4 per cent in 2020.

site_title: EU antitrust regulators clear US$69 billion Microsoft, Activision deal
summary: The European Commission has cleared Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision, citing significant improvements in cloud gaming. Microsoft offered 10-year free licensing deals to European consumers and cloud game streaming services, addressing the Commission's competition concerns. The EU competition watchdog stated that the commitments "fully address the competition concerns identified" and represent a significant improvement for cloud gaming.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Microsoft logo is seen on a smartphone placed on displayed Activision Blizzard logo in this illustration taken January 18, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: Vice Media files for bankruptcy as ad business suffers
summary: Vice Media Group, a popular digital media company, filed for bankruptcy protection on May 15, citing financial difficulties in a weak advertising market. The company will sell its assets to a lender consortium for approximately $225 million, assuming significant liabilities. This move comes after top-executive departures and a challenging period for technology and media companies. The bankruptcy filing is a sign of a broader crisis in digital-only media, with BuzzFeed also recently restructuring its news division.

images.alt_text: BuzzFeed announced in late April that it would shutter its news division.

site_title: Exxon settles Indonesia torture case that led to US SEC official’s ouster
summary: ExxonMobil has settled a long-running human rights lawsuit with Indonesian villagers who claimed soldiers hired by the company to guard a natural gas facility committed murder and torture. The 2001 case led to the 2021 resignation of Alex Oh, the US Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement director. The terms of the settlement are confidential, but a spokesperson for ExxonMobil said it "brings closure for all parties." The plaintiffs, 11 villagers, had been fighting the case for 20 years.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the trading information for ExxonMobil on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., December 9, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Saudi Arabia’s Biggest IPO of Year Covered on First Day
summary: Saudi Arabia's largest IPO of the year, Jamjoom Pharmaceuticals Factory Co, was oversubscribed on its first day, with demand exceeding the full deal size. The IPO aims to raise 1.26 billion riyals ($449 million), and shares are priced between 56-60 riyals apiece. The listing, valued at up to 4.2 billion riyals, is the largest in Saudi Arabia since Saudi Aramco's US$1.3 billion listing in December.

images.alt_text: SoftBank’s founder Masayoshi Son says he hopes the ARM IPO can be the largest ever by a chip company.

site_title: Thye Hua Kwan entities granted options to buy 2 office floors at Solitaire on Cecil for S$103.2m
summary: Three entities affiliated with the Thye Hua Kwan (THK) Group of Charities are purchasing two office floors at Solitaire on Cecil for about S$103.2 million. The THK entities, Thye Hua Kwan Moral Charities and Ang Mo Kio-Thye Hua Kwan Hospital, are buying Levels 10 and 14 of the 20-storey development, which is slated for completion in 2027. The purchases are subject to regulatory nods and are aimed at providing sustainable rental income to the charities.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Artist's impression of Solitaire On Cecil.

When completed in 2026, Solitaire on Cecil will rise to 127 metres and comprise predominantly office space, which will be on 15 levels ranging from 11,000 sq ft to 13,000 sq ft.




Source: Solitaire Cecil Pte Ltd
Singapore central office rents rise further in Q1 2023, up 5.1%: URA
28 Stanley Street (white building) is being sold with vacant possession.

site_title: Rate-cut bets are surfacing across emerging Asia on policy pivot
summary: Emerging Asian central banks are shifting from rate hikes to rate cuts amid slowing inflation, with traders betting on potential cuts as early as August and October. The Bank of Korea, Bank Negara Malaysia, and Reserve Bank of India have already pushed back against rate cut expectations, but market participants expect cuts in South Korea, India, and Indonesia this year. Rate cuts could support a rebound in sovereign debt, with a Bloomberg index of emerging Asia bonds gaining 3% this year.

images.alt_text: Apple did not say when it plans to open physical stores in Vietnam, which has a population of 100 million people.
ETFs that exclusively buy Chinese shares continued to fail to get new inflows last week.

site_title: ‘Bangkok Spring’ sets up a showdown over role of Thai monarchy
summary: Thailand's "Bangkok Spring" party, led by Pita Limjaroenrat, has won the most seats and votes in the general election, paving the way for a potential showdown with the royalist establishment over the "lèse-majesté" law, which can punish insulters with up to 15 years in prison. Pita vowed not to compromise on changing the law, which restricts criticism of the monarchy. The party's win marks a significant shift in Thai politics, with implications for democracy and the role of the monarchy in the country.

images.alt_text: Thai opposition leader Pita Limjaroenrat said he was ready to be prime minister after a stunning election result that left his upstart progressive party as the biggest in parliament.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise as investors assess politics, economic data
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% on Monday, hitting a two-week high, as investors assessed US debt ceiling talks and economic data. Banks gained, while shares of Spain's BBVA slumped 4.2% due to a potential Turkish presidential election runoff. Germany's wholesale price index fell for the first time in over a year, while Sweden's consumer prices eased. The European Central Bank signaled more rate hikes, despite the US Federal Reserve's openness to a pause in monetary tightening.

site_title: Sats should allay concerns following departure of WFS CEO
summary: Sats announced on May 3 that CEO Craig Smyth was leaving the organization, despite previously stating he would lead Worldwide Flight Services (WFS) post-acquisition. The company restructured its global leadership team, placing WFS members directly under CEO Kerry Mok. This move comes after Sats' Paris-based WFS takeover for €2.3 billion. The change in leadership structure aims to harness synergies and talent from the combined business, spanning over 20 countries.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Tackling the urgent manpower challenge in insurance
summary: The insurance industry is facing a critical manpower crunch, with a 4.1% job vacancy rate in 2022, the highest since 1998. To tackle this issue, CEO Andrew Yeo proposes three key pillars: building interest, initiating growth, and inspiring potential entrants. The industry must address the perception that insurance is just about sales, and showcase its sophisticated work behind the scenes, such as actuarial analyses and product development. Additionally, investing in data literacy and design thinking can help upgrade existing talent and attract new ones, while emphasizing the industry's social role and purpose can inspire potential entrants.

images.alt_text: Insurtech: Insurance reimagined in Asia
Job-switching hit a six-year high in 2022, with work-life balance being a common cited reason for this, noted industry players.
Singapore F&B sector braces for labour, cost squeeze from MCO

site_title: Sunak faces pressure from UK home secretary to cut immigration
summary: UK Home Secretary Suella Braverman is set to pressure Prime Minister Rishi Sunak to cut immigration, citing record net arrivals in the UK last year. Braverman will argue that Brexit enables the UK to build a high-skilled, high-wage economy less dependent on low-skilled foreign labor. This comes amid divisions within the Conservative Party, with some members calling for a crackdown on immigration. Sunak remains committed to reducing small boat crossings, a key pledge, despite criticism from some within his own party.

images.alt_text: Zelensky, making his European tour ahead of the planned counteroffensive, won major additional pledges of tanks, armoured vehicles and other weapons over the past two days from Germany and France.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on hopes of likely debt-ceiling deal
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, May 15, 2023, as investors became optimistic about a likely deal to raise the US debt limit, which is nearing its deadline. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 20.59 points, or 0.06%, to 33,321.21. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 2.57 and 16.42 points, respectively. The market sentiment is driven by anticipation of comments from Federal Reserve policymakers this week.

site_title: When hirers get fired – laid-off tech recruiters face a tough job market
summary: Tech recruiters, heavily impacted by layoffs, face a tough job market. Those laid off in November found relatively quick job opportunities, but those affected more recently are struggling. Jane, an in-house recruiter, notes that the current job market is less supportive, with companies being more blasé about layoffs. This trend is concerning for those in the field, as it may take longer to find new roles. The job market's response to recent layoffs highlights the challenges faced by tech recruiters and the evolving nature of the industry.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Benjamin Cher
There are more opportunities for fresh graduates and mid-career professionals to reskill and seek better-paying tech roles.
This will be a “strange year” for attracting, hiring and retaining staff, says a new report on South-east Asian tech talent.
Indeed is facing a rapidly cooling job market following a hiring boom during the pandemic.

site_title: What China’s new counter-espionage law means for foreign firms
summary: China's amended counter-espionage law broadens the scope of espionage activities, strengthening security protocols and enhancing administrative enforcement authority. The definition of espionage now includes theft, probing, bribery, or illegal provision of state secrets by non-spy organizations, individuals, and foreign firms. This amendment aims to combat espionage and regulate industries related to national security. The law change reflects China's proactive approach in ensuring national security, with enforcement becoming more active and companies facing increased scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Beijing is moving to tighten its grip on sensitive data as tensions with Washington mount.
The restriction highlights the more difficult environment facing investors operating in China despite Beijing’s push to improve ties globally.
The revised counterespionage law was approved during a Standing Committee meeting of the National People’s Congress (NPC) on Wednesday (Apr 26).

site_title: Singapore's HMI Group to buy healthcare tech platform MHC Asia
summary: HMI Group, a regional healthcare firm in Singapore, has signed a deal to fully acquire MHC Asia Group, a healthcare technology platform. The acquisition aims to deliver seamless patient journeys and improve health outcomes through technology. The combined group will serve over three million patients annually and expand its revenue base to over S$350 million, tapping into the estimated US$11 billion digital healthcare market in South-east Asia by 2027. HMI Group owns 45 primary care and health screening centres, 15 specialist centres, and two tertiary hospitals in Malaysia.

site_title: ThaiBev unit Sabeco, SP Group to install rooftop solar panels in 9 Vietnam breweries
summary: Sabeco, a Vietnamese beer manufacturer and distributor, and energy utilities group SP Group have partnered to install rooftop solar panels at nine of Sabeco's breweries. The 10.44 megawatt-peak solar panels will provide close to 25% of electricity consumed at the factories, generating 14,600 MWh of electricity annually. The project is expected to reduce Sabeco's carbon emissions by 10,000 tonnes annually, equivalent to taking 2,200 cars off the road. The installation is part of Sabeco's sustainable development model to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
ThaiBev's revenue for Q2 rose 2.4 per cent on higher sales from the company's spirits, non-alcoholic beverages and food businesses.

site_title: Foreign buying in private homes at five-year high in Q1, just before rollout of cooling measures
summary: Foreign buyers in Singapore's private homes reached a five-year high in Q1 2023, with 259 condo units purchased, a 14.6% increase from Q4 2022. This is the highest proportion since Q1 2018. Foreign buying momentum continued in April before the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates were hiked. Geopolitical tensions may have driven foreign buyers to seek safe havens like Singapore. Despite the ABSD increase, foreign buyers still accounted for 6.9% of private home transactions in Q1, with luxury condo sales reaching almost a decade high.

images.alt_text: Private residential properties in Singapore's prime areas are expected to be affected the most by the latest cooling measures due to the traditionally higher component of foreign buyers in these areas compared with the city-fringe and suburban locations.
At the recent launch of condominium Blossoms by the Park, four units were sold to US buyers and four to Chinese.
Singapore is mostly seeing higher prices for everything from condos to cars.

site_title: Biodiversity challenge gives clarion call for business
summary: The International Day for Biological Diversity on May 22 highlights the urgent need for radical change in human relationships with nature due to the sixth great extinction, where an estimated one million species are on the verge of extinction. The UN estimates we have three years to preserve the world's habitability and biodiversity. A recent global assessment report blames human activities for the massive loss of biodiversity, with monitored wildlife populations plummeting by 70% over the past half-century. Businesses are now recognizing the importance of healthy ecosystems, with the UN COP15 agreement in Montreal providing a framework for tackling biodiversity loss, including phasing out environmentally harmful subsidies and corporate reporting. However, implementation is crucial to make the treaty consequential in stemming biodiversity loss.

images.alt_text: While we have long quantified primary goods produced on the land, such as timber or wheat, we have fallen short on measuring less-tangible assets such as the state of biodiversity, air, water and soil health.
Giant forest trees in Singapore's Bukit Timah and Central Catchment nature reserves.

People stop and have their picture taken at the COP15 logo during the United the Nations Biodiversity Conference (COP15) at the Palais des congrès de Montréal in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on December 16, 2022. - Montreal is expected to have at least 10cm (4 inches) of snow throughout the day. (Photo by ANDREJ IVANOV / AFP)
Biodiversity is rising up the agenda

site_title: Amazon, Embracer strike deal to make Lord of the Rings video game
summary: Amazon and Embracer Group have agreed to develop and publish a massively multiplayer online (MMO) game based on J R R Tolkien's "The Lord of the Rings" series. The game will be set in Middle-earth, featuring stories from "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings" literary trilogy. The game will be published globally for PCs and consoles, with additional details to be shared at a later date. This marks the companies' first foray into developing a Lord of the Rings-based game, following Amazon's earlier cancellation of an online role-playing game in 2021.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Hobbiton Movie Set, a location for The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit film trilogy, is pictured in Matamata, New Zealand, December 27, 2020. REUTERS/Praveen Menon

site_title: Bitcoin bulls trip on a frog, as Pepe memecoin frenzy signals market top
summary: A new memecoin, Pepe, has sparked a frenzy in the cryptocurrency market, with trading reaching $1.6 billion in value before plummeting 70% in just a few days. This boom is reminiscent of previous memecoin crazes, which have often signaled market tops and subsequent multi-month drawdowns in Bitcoin and Ether. Experts warn that the hype may be a sign of an overextended market, and that traders who lost money in the Pepe frenzy may be hesitant to re-enter the market, leading to a potential drawdown in the prices of the two major coins.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Souvenir tokens representing cryptocurrency Bitcoin and the Ethereum network, with its native token ether, plunge into water in this illustration taken May 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
Canada has tightened regulations for crypto asset trading platforms in recent months, with the introduction of a pre-registration process.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies Bitcoin, Ethereum and DogeCoin are placed on PC motherboard in this illustration taken, June 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: ComfortDelGro Q1 earnings fall 56.9% to S$32.8 million despite revenue uptick
summary: ComfortDelGro's Q1 earnings fell 56.9% to S$32.8 million, despite a 2.1% revenue increase to S$906.4 million. The company attributed the decline to inflationary cost pressures on public transport services. Revenue rose 1.5% in the public transport segment, while the taxi division saw a 2.9% increase. Operating costs rose 4.9% due to driver shortages and inflation. The company maintains a net cash position and will monitor the situation.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Mark Greaves will replace outgoing chairman Lim Jit Poh starting Apr 28, 2023.
The Swedish capital is expanding its three-line metro network, with extensions as well as a fourth line being built, and these will come into service from 2025.
Analysts remain positive on ComfortDelGro despite the announcement that two of its competitors will be merging.

site_title: Default hits another Chinese builder that sold state-backed debt
summary: KWG Group Holdings, a Chinese developer, has defaulted on a US$119 million dollar bond, raising concerns about the government's support for the real estate sector. The default, which occurred on Sunday, has led to a 12% drop in the company's shares and a record low price. This is the second Chinese builder to default on dollar bonds, following CIFI Holdings Group, and highlights the ongoing difficulties in the sector. Authorities may prioritize project completion over debt repayment, with the company's cash under strict pre-sale escrow.

images.alt_text: Evergrande says the enforcement notice requires it to pay compensation of about 770 million yuan (S$148.1 million) to the claimant, among other required payments.

site_title: World number one Alcaraz knocked out of Italian Open
summary: World number one tennis player Carlos Alcaraz suffered a shock third-round defeat at the Italian Open, losing to Hungary's Fabian Marozsan 6-3, 7-6 (7/4). The 20-year-old Spaniard was outplayed by the 23-year-old Hungarian, who won the final six points of the second-set tiebreaker. This loss comes ahead of the French Open, which starts in less than two weeks. Marozsan, ranked 135th, had not won a match on the ATP Tour prior to the tournament.

images.alt_text: Spain's Carlos Alcaraz reacts after losing his third round match of the Men's ATP Rome Open tennis tournament against Hungary's Fabian Marozsan at Foro Italico in Rome on May 15, 2023. (Photo by Tiziana FABI / AFP)

Hungary's Fabian Marozsan celebrates after defeating Spain's Carlos Alcaraz during their third round match of the Men's ATP Rome Open tennis tournament at Foro Italico in Rome on May 15, 2023. (Photo by Tiziana FABI / AFP)

site_title: CapitaLand Malaysia Trust buys second logistics property in Malaysia for RM39.7m
summary: CapitaLand Malaysia Trust (CLMT) has acquired a logistics warehouse in Shah Alam, Selangor, Malaysia for RM39.7 million. The single-storey detached warehouse will be leased to a luxury fashion retailer for 10 years, generating a gross rental income of RM3.5 million annually. The acquisition is CLMT's second logistics property, following a similar deal in June last year. The trust expects the lease to commence in 2024, contributing positively to its income and portfolio diversification.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
CapitaLand Malaysia Trust is acquiring its first logistics property for RM80m in Penang.

site_title: US dollar slips from 5-week high; Turkish lira drops
summary: The US dollar slipped from a five-week high, falling 0.18% to 102.51, as concerns about American inflation and the debt ceiling stand-off led to a shift in investor sentiment. The Turkish lira dropped to a near record low, while the Thai baht rallied after a decisive election result. Analysts attribute the dollar's recent strength to safe-haven buying and concerns about global economic growth, with a possible Fed rate hike next month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A picture illustration shows U.S. 100-dollar bank notes taken in Tokyo August 2, 2011. REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao/File Photo

site_title: Private equity firm TPG to buy Angelo Gordon for US$2.7 billion
summary: US private equity firm TPG is acquiring Angelo Gordon for US$2.7 billion. The deal will allow TPG to expand into credit investing and provide Angelo Gordon with scale in the credit and real estate markets. Angelo Gordon's co-CEOs Josh Baumgarten and Adam Schwartz will become co-managing partners of the platform, reporting to TPG CEO Jon Winkelried. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2023.

site_title: IMF official says Sri Lanka reforms critical, evaluating progress
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is evaluating Sri Lanka's progress on reforms and will conduct a governance exercise to identify key weaknesses and corruption vulnerabilities in six key areas. The IMF mission, led by Director Krishna Srinivasan, will assess the country's economic reform program and provide recommendations to improve governance and reduce corruption. The report is expected to be completed by September, with the IMF currently forecasting a 3% contraction in 2023 and a modest growth of 1.5% in 2024, depending on the implementation of the economic reform program.

images.alt_text: The latest reading suggests the Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s efforts to reach single-digit inflation by the end of this year is bearing some fruit.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Developers sold 887 new units in April, a 80.3% increase from March, driven by the launches of Blossoms by the Park and Tembusu Grand. This marks the fourth consecutive month of rising new home sales, despite cooling measures aimed at curbing investment demand.

images.alt_text: Ravi Menon’s reappointment is effective from Jun 1, 2023.

site_title: STI inches up 0.2% amid US debt ceiling crisis, ahead of China data
summary: Singapore shares edged 0.2% higher, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,214.72, amid caution due to the US debt ceiling crisis and uncertainty over China's recovery. Key local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB reported record Q1 profits, while Genting Singapore slipped 7.2% after announcing a year-on-year trebling of Q1 net profit. China data release on Tuesday may influence market sentiment, with interest-rate pause and recession concerns driving investor caution.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Wellington were all down, though Tokyo and Jakarta edged up on Monday.
Genting Singapore which owns Resorts World Sentosa, announces on Friday that its net profit more than tripled to S$129.2 million for the first quarter ended Mar 31, 2023.

site_title: Bank Indonesia says too early to discuss rate cuts
summary: Bank Indonesia's deputy governor Juda Agung stated it's too early to discuss rate cuts, despite Indonesia's inflation easing to 4.33% last month and exports slowing. The central bank has kept policy rates unchanged since January and said its previous 225 basis point hikes were sufficient to guide inflation back to its 2-4% target range. Agung cited risks, including the impact of El Nino weather patterns, as reasons to remain vigilant and not consider rate cuts. The bank will continue to monitor inflation and economic trends before making any decisions.

images.alt_text: awtanker4 - An oil tanker is docked near fuel tanks at Tanjung Priok Port in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Tuesday, July 13, 2021. Indonesia will release trade figures on July 15. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Ukraine's Zelensky wins pledge of long range drones in Britain
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky received a pledge of long-range attack drones from Britain, alongside cruise missiles pledged last week, during his European tour. Zelensky met with British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak at Chequers country residence, further solidifying cooperation on expanding Ukraine's capabilities for a counteroffensive against Russia. This comes after Zelensky secured major additional pledges of tanks, armoured vehicles, and other weapons from Germany and France over the past two days.

images.alt_text: EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell has presented the union’s foreign ministers with a paper ahead of the meeting that sought to “define” and “re-calibrate our position towards China”.

site_title: SIA Group flies nearly 2.7 million passengers in April, almost matching March’s traffic
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported 2.7 million passengers in April, an 85.5% increase from the same period last year, with strong leisure demand during the Easter holiday. Passenger traffic and load factors were robust across all regions, with a 36.7% year-on-year increase in group passenger capacity. Cargo loads fell 11.2% due to weaker demand. SIA's passenger network covered 112 destinations in 36 countries, while its cargo network comprised 118 destinations in 38 countries.

site_title: India’s falling wholesale prices add room to spur growth
summary: India's wholesale prices declined 0.92% in April, the first contraction in nearly three years, due to softening global commodity prices. This decrease in wholesale prices is expected to ease input cost pressures for producers, potentially benefiting growth. Retail inflation slowed to 4.70%, the weakest in 18 months, and is within the Reserve Bank of India's target band, leading to speculation of a rate pause. The decline in wholesale prices may also help bring down output prices.

images.alt_text: Macron has been trying to reset his presidency amid protests and strikes.

site_title: When robots take over your portfolio (and hopefully make you rich)
summary: A recent article explores the potential impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on the financial industry, particularly in investment management. While AI can analyze data and identify patterns, it is unlikely to replace human financial advisers in the near future due to its limitations in providing personalized advice and understanding individual client situations. AI can, however, assist human advisers by automating tasks such as risk management and regulatory compliance, improving efficiency and accuracy. Despite AI's potential, human investment expertise remains essential for finding good investment opportunities and structuring resilient portfolios.

images.alt_text: Chinese search engine company Baidu unveiled its AI chatbot Ernie at an event in Beijing on Mar 16, 2023.
Google has previously tested new search features by introducing them to randomised groups of users.

site_title: Consortium of Penguin International executives raises privatisation offer to ‘final’ S$0.83 per share
summary: A consortium led by Penguin International's managing director James Tham has made a "final" offer of S$0.83 per share in cash to take the company private. The offer, a 4.1% increase from the initial S$0.82 per share, is non-negotiable unless a "competitive situation" arises. The consortium, which also includes a special purpose vehicle under Dymon Asia, is seeking to acquire Penguin International at a price that represents a 4.1% premium over the FY2022 dividend payout.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
James Tham, Managing Director of Penguin International

site_title: Cannes braces for stars and protests
summary: The Cannes Film Festival, featuring stars like Harrison Ford and Natalie Portman, kicked off on May 16 with heightened security measures due to past terror attacks in France. Around 1,000 police and security guards are on site, with 35,000 attendees expected over the 12-day festival. Premieres include "Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny," "Killers of the Flower Moon," and "Elemental." Protests by French unions are also expected, but the event is set to proceed as planned.

images.alt_text: Guardians had unseated Universal’s The Super Mario Bros Movie from the top spot the week before.

site_title: Elon Musk loses bid to end US SEC ‘muzzle’ over tweets
summary: Elon Musk's bid to modify or end his 2018 securities fraud settlement with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) was rejected by a federal appeals court on May 15. The 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals in Manhattan upheld the decree that requires a Tesla lawyer to approve some of Musk's tweets in advance, citing that the SEC did not exploit Musk's consent decree to conduct harassing investigations that violated his First Amendment free speech rights. The decision leaves Musk's settlement in place, which resolved an SEC lawsuit over a 2018 tweet that allegedly defrauded investors.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk’s running of Twitter has been criticised as taking the billionaire’s attention away from his jobs running Tesla and SpaceX.
Elon Musk on Tuesday announced that audio and video calls are coming to Twitter.

site_title: Foreigners resume offloading Chinese bonds as yield differentials widen
summary: Foreign investors have resumed reducing their holdings of Chinese yuan-denominated bonds, with foreign holdings declining to 3.17 trillion yuan (S$609.9 billion) at the end of April, down from 3.21 trillion yuan at end-March. This decline follows a marginal increase in March, when overseas institutional investors bought a net 10 billion yuan worth of yuan bonds. The widening yield differentials between China and the US have discouraged inflows, with China's onshore yuan bond yields outpacing those of US Treasuries.

images.alt_text: An executive at a real estate developer in Hong Kong said the difficulties of doing due diligence in China is deterring investors from buying assets in the mainland because of the risk of hidden debts.

site_title: Research shows carbon budget of listed firms to run out by Oct 2026
summary: Research by MSCI indicates that the world's listed firms will exceed their carbon budget, limiting global temperature rises to 1.5°C, by October 2026, two months earlier than previously estimated. Only 17% of listed firms have set targets that align with the 1.5°C target, while actual emissions are expected to reach 11.2 gigatons in 2023, putting the planet on track to warm by 2.7°C by the end of the century. Experts warn that public and private companies, and investors, must act urgently to meet the 1.5°C target.

images.alt_text: People wearing long clothing to protect themselves from the heat while riding motorcycles along a street in Hanoi. Extreme weather conditions in Vietnam saw temperatures exceed 44 deg C in some regions recently.

site_title: Macron wants to keep cutting taxes despite deficit warnings
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron plans to continue cutting taxes despite growing debt and budget deficit warnings. Macron stated that lowering taxes on the middle class is essential to boosting credibility and economic growth. However, Bank of France governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau warned that Macron's tax cuts must be offset by other revenue sources. The European Commission forecasts France's deficit to remain stable at 4.7% of GDP this year, with public debt expected to stabilize around 109.5% of GDP in 2024. Fitch Ratings recently cut France's credit rating to AA-, citing the country's high budget deficit.

images.alt_text: In the UK, more than a third of fixed-rate mortgages on rental properties – known as buy-to-let – are due to end in the next two years, leaving landlords vulnerable to the highest interest rates since 2008.

site_title: Philippines seeks sugar imports of up to 150,000 tonnes to avert shortfall
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has approved the importation of up to 150,000 tonnes of sugar to stabilize local prices and avert a domestic shortfall by the end of August. This plan comes three months after the government initially sought to import 440,000 tonnes of refined sugar. The country is expected to face a sugar shortage due to the local milling season, prompting the Sugar Regulatory Administration to recommend importing 100,000-150,000 tonnes to meet demand.

site_title: After The Continuum, weak take-up in any new launch will cast a pall on the private housing market
summary: Poor take-up in upcoming major private housing launches could halt the rise in private home prices in Singapore. Despite recent property cooling measures, new homes continue to be sold. The measures, which include higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) for foreigners and Singapore citizens/PRs, may not have the desired impact. Low mortgage rates also contribute to the market. Developers are launching new projects, and some have already secured top bids for sites. The economic outlook remains weak, and caution is advised for those pursuing condo dreams.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
The Continuum, a freehold development on Thiam Siew Avenue off Tanjong Katong Road.
博盛苑靠近住宅较少的纬壹科技城，附近买家对新私宅需求预料很大。（益民林发展公司提供）

site_title: Turning the corner on inequality?
summary: Economic policymakers face a challenge in stemming rising inequality, which hinders growth and threatens liberal democracy. However, despite fears, the impact of the Covid-19 crisis and energy-price shock on unskilled workers has been relatively benign. In the US, high gas prices have actually benefited the economy, while in Europe, they have led to a 2% income loss. Despite this, lower-income households tend to spend more on energy and have suffered a larger loss in purchasing power. However, other factors, such as homeownership and rent increases, have offset some of the effects, and wages are increasing faster at the bottom end of the income distribution.

images.alt_text: Rampant public-service strikes in Britain, Germany and France, which has also suffered eruptions of street chaos, may point to the most concerted fightback yet seen after decades when employees suffered declining proceeds from countries’ national incomes.
History shows that globalisation is largely driven by technological changes that reduce the importance of distance, and that will not change.
The Black unemployment rate plunged to 5 per cent last month, the lowest level in data going back to the early 1970s. It’s still 1.8 percentage points above the rate for White Americans

site_title: Hot stock: Genting Singapore down 7.2% after Q1 misses analyst expectations
summary: Genting Singapore's shares fell 7.2% after the company's Q1 results missed analyst expectations, with adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) down 25% to S$191.7 million. Revenue rose 54% to S$484.5 million, but the underperformance was attributed to a severe fall in non-gaming revenues at Resorts World Sentosa, with elevated airfares during the festive seasons potentially impacting visitor volume. Despite this, analysts maintain a "buy" call, with target prices ranging from S$1.18 to S$1.36, implying a potential upside of 12-20%.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Genting Singapore, which owns Resorts World Sentosa, said the integrated resort has benefited from the ongoing recovery of regional travel and gaming demand.
CGS-CIMB believes that Genting Singapore's profitability will continue to improve throughout the year, as flight capacities to and from China gradually increase with the country’s reopening.
Mass gaming revenue reaches a record US$549 million in Q1, parent company Las Vegas Sands says.

site_title: Indonesia April trade surplus beats forecast; exports, imports fall
summary: Indonesia's April trade surplus exceeded forecasts, driven by a larger-than-expected trade surplus of $3.94 billion, despite a 29.4% drop in exports to $19.29 billion and a 22.32% decline in imports to $15.35 billion. Coal and palm oil exports fell 40% yearly, while prices dropped. Analysts warn that declining commodity prices may lead to a shrinking trade surplus and slower economic growth. The central bank is expected to ease monetary policy, with some predicting interest rate cuts in August or September.

images.alt_text: Freeport is building a US$3 billion copper smelter in East Java to process 1.7 million tonnes of copper concentrate.

site_title: Gold prices firm as economic risks persist
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $22,018.76 per ounce as the US debt ceiling stalemate and concerns over an economic slowdown steered traders towards the safe-haven metal. Recent economic data downsides lifted recession fears, providing a cushion for gold. However, higher interest rates dim its appeal. Markets are pricing in an 83.4% chance of the US Federal Reserve holding interest rates steady in June.

images.alt_text: Safe-haven bullion tends to gain during times of economic or financial uncertainty, but higher interest rates tend to dim non-yielding gold’s appeal.

site_title: The unstoppable advance of the acronym
summary: The use of acronyms and abbreviations is on the rise, despite years of criticism about their potential to confuse and exclude. The trend has been fueled by advances in science and technology, as well as the need to simplify complex terms in various fields, such as climate change and finance. While some argue that abbreviations hinder communication, others see them as a way to achieve instant understanding and convey complex ideas. The phenomenon has even led to the creation of new words, such as "abkurzungsfimmel" in Germany, and the use of backronyms in legislation, which can be memorable and catchy.

images.alt_text: With the EIS, the government has made clear its intent to embed a culture of innovation and continuous learning across the entire innovation value chain.
Hybrid work will reshape cities, careers, family life and free time.
By last week, Apple was the only Big Tech name that had not underperformed the market this year, foretelling another collapse for acronym investing.

site_title: Blossoms by the Park, Tembusu Grand launches push new home sales up 80.3% in April
summary: Developers sold 887 new private residential units in April, excluding executive condominiums, a 80.3% increase from March. The launches of Blossoms by the Park and Tembusu Grand contributed to the surge in sales. However, some buyers were sidelined due to market cooling measures and high interest rates, putting pressure on developers to lower prices.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) data released on Monday (Apr 17) show that in March, developers sold 492 units, excluding ECs, up 13.6 per cent from the 433 units sold in February.

site_title: South Korean house prices fall in April for 11th straight month
summary: South Korean house prices fell 0.47% in April for the 11th consecutive month, marking the longest streak of declines in 11 years. The nationwide house price index dropped 8.53% over the past 11 months, the worst since 2003. The decline slowed for the fourth straight month, indicating the impact of aggressive interest rate hikes and cooling economic growth. The government responded by easing financial regulations for home buyers.

site_title: World Bank awards funds to suspected Huawei connected firms
summary: The World Bank has awarded funds to two contractors linked to Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications company under US sanctions, exposing a rift between Washington's national security priorities and the global development lender. A $9.9 million contract was awarded to Huawei Consortium for a regional government project in eastern and Southern Africa, and $61,000 to Huawei International for software maintenance in Rwanda. The US has restricted business with Huawei over security concerns, but the World Bank only prohibits firms from bidding on borrower contracts if they're under UN sanctions or banned for anti-corruption reasons.

images.alt_text: Huawei announced two years ago that it would begin charging “reasonable” fees for access to them.

site_title: Japanese investors turn net sellers of foreign bonds in April
summary: Japanese investors turned net sellers of foreign bonds in April, selling 1.35 trillion yen worth of overseas bonds after buying 10.9 trillion yen in the previous three months. The reversal came as US yields dropped, prompting concerns the Federal Reserve may pause rate hikes. Institutional investors believed US Treasury yields may have peaked, while Japan's bond yields had risen. Higher hedging costs were also cited as a factor. Domestic investors bought 356 billion yen worth of overseas equities in the same period.

images.alt_text: Market players expect new BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda to keep monetary settings ultra-loose at his debut policy meeting but they think a change in the BOJ’s yield curve control, which keeps the benchmark 10-year government bond yield below 0.5 per cent, is likely at the June policy meeting.

site_title: Saudi inflation steady at 2.7% in April, driven by housing
summary: Saudi Arabia's annual inflation rate remained steady at 2.7% in April, driven primarily by housing rental costs. Housing, water, electricity, gas, and other fuels rose 8.1% from the previous year, while the food and beverage sector increased 1%. Overall, housing rents grew 9.6% in April, with apartment rents rising 22.2% following a similar increase in March.
