site_title: How partnerships magnify the impact of philanthropy
summary: Singapore is launching the Impact Philanthropy Partnership (IPP) to connect donors with each other and with financial infrastructure to tackle societal challenges. The initiative, supported by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, aims to create opportunities for collaboration and innovation in philanthropy. A new tax incentive scheme has also been introduced, allowing qualifying donors to claim a 100% tax deduction for overseas donations made through local intermediaries. These moves are part of Singapore's efforts to develop a platform and network for philanthropy and impact investment, and to encourage more family offices and individuals to use the city-state as their wealth hub.

images.alt_text: The government wants to harness the best of organisations to address the needs of communities, by tapping their assets, expertise and networks, said Minister for Social and Family Development Masagos Zulkifli.
Social enterprises are rooted in the pursuit of the dual bottom line of profit and impact. They are testament to businesses' potential to be a force for good.

site_title: UK economy grows in Q1, but March drop underscores fragility
summary: The UK economy grew 0.1% in Q1 2023, but a 0.3% drop in March highlights its fragility. Widespread industrial action and low car sales also weighed on economic activity. The economy remains 0.5% smaller than in 2019, before the pandemic. Experts warn of vulnerabilities due to higher borrowing costs and tighter credit, potentially dampening business and household activity this year.

images.alt_text: The BOE now expects inflation to be slower to fall than it had hoped, mostly due to unexpectedly big and persistent rises in food prices.

site_title: Apple to open first online shop in Vietnam in a push to emerging market
summary: Apple to open its first online store in Vietnam, a move aimed at driving growth in emerging markets. The opening follows the company's recent expansion into India with its first Apple stores. Apple CEO Tim Cook believes emerging markets, with younger populations and fewer iPhones, offer opportunities for growth. The online store in Vietnam is set to launch on May 18.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Foxconn is seen outside the company's building in Taipei, Taiwan, Nov. 10, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo
While Apple may be the bigger company with a US$2.7 trillion market cap, Aramco’s shareholder payouts – excluding buybacks – dwarf all others.
Proceeds from Apple’s debt sale will be used for general corporate purposes.

site_title: Cartier maker Richemont’s profit gains as China rebounds
summary: Richemont, the Swiss luxury goods maker, reported a 14% sales increase in China following the end of Covid Zero policies, beating analysts' estimates. Operating profit was 5.03 billion euros, and the stock rose 5.9% to a record. Chairman Johann Rupert attributed the rebound to strong demand driven by Chinese customers traveling again, but noted that large group trips have not yet recovered due to high flight costs. Richemont plans to buy back up to 10 million shares and announced plans for a more diverse board, with a third of members expected to be women.

site_title: The nuts and bolts of private commercial real estate investing
summary: Private commercial real estate (CRE) investing has become more accessible with the availability of streamlined, tech-powered platforms and low minimums. CRE investing encompasses various property types, investment theses, and risk/return profiles, offering both solid cash flow and total return potential. Key benefits of private-market CRE investing include lower correlation to public equity and bond markets, higher illiquidity premium, and greater opportunity for passive investors to tap into alpha. Four main CRE investment styles are Core, Core Plus, Value Add, and Opportunistic, each with specific risk/return profiles. Investors should consider risk tolerance, time horizon, liquidity needs, and track record when selecting CRE investments, and diversification across platforms, operators, property types, markets, and risk/return profiles is crucial.

site_title: Binance.US explores ways to cut founder Zhao’s majority stake: report
summary: Binance.US is exploring ways to reduce the majority stake of founder and CEO Changpeng Zhao, amid a US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) lawsuit alleging an "illegal" exchange and "sham" compliance programme. Zhao has been trying to sell some of his stake since last summer. Reducing his stake may help improve the company's standing with US regulators, who may not grant licences to the company as long as he is majority owner. This move could address concerns raised by the CFTC lawsuit, which may have hindered Binance.US's ability to acquire regulatory licences in the US.

images.alt_text: Binance, the world’s largest crypto exchange, last year introduced zero-fee trading on a number of market pairs.
Binance on Sunday halted Bitcoin withdrawals for about 90 minutes, blaming congestion on the token’s blockchain.
Beijing cracked down on digital assets over concerns about money laundering, currency outflows and the environmental impact of Bitcoin mining.

The inquiry by the Justice Department’s national security division is looking at whether Binance or company officials ran afoul of sanctions related to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, according to five people familiar with the matter who asked not to be named discussing a confidential investigation.

site_title: China housing rebound fizzling shows risks to economic recovery
summary: China's housing market is regressing after a brief recovery, with high-frequency indicators showing a decline in home purchases and property investment. Despite Beijing's efforts to prop up the market with measures such as lower home loan rates and eased financing rules, the sector remains a concern for the country's economic growth outlook. The decline in prices of existing homes and a glut of unsold inventory also weigh on the global economy, affecting commodities like iron ore and copper. The property sector accounts for 20% of China's GDP and its decline could have significant implications for the country's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: The Hai Yue Cheng property project, developed by Languang, in Beijing. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Fake billionaire fund manager charged with running Ponzi scheme
summary: Phillip Galles, a 57-year-old former Chicago commodities trader, has been charged with wire fraud for running a $2 million Ponzi scheme since 2019. Galles allegedly stole from clients, claiming investments in commodity futures and luxury assets, while making grandiose claims about his firm, Tyche Asset Management. Prosecutors say Galles used the money to pay off early investors and fund his own expenses, and made false statements about his firm's operations and employees. Galles remains in custody and faces a single count of wire fraud.

images.alt_text: Unauthorised payments totalled £727 million, with more than half of those losses coming as a result of stolen card details being used for purchases.

A casino building shut down by police  in Sihanoukville in Preah Sihanouk province. Experts say the trafficked captives are held in large compounds in converted casinos in Cambodia, and in special economic zones in Myanmar and Laos.
Limitations in current laws make it difficult to take money mules to task, Second Minister for Home Affairs Josephine Teo said in Parliament on Monday.

site_title: AirAsia Superapp and Foodpanda to partner for more app offerings
summary: AirAsia Superapp and Foodpanda have partnered to expand their services. AirAsia Ride, the ride-hailing service from the super app, will be available on the Foodpanda app starting with a trial in Klang Valley, Malaysia. Foodpanda will connect users to its network of merchants and delivery partners, while AirAsia Superapp will offer ride-hailing services. The partnership aims to leverage each other's strengths and provide a wider range of services for users in South-east Asia and beyond.

images.alt_text: ADE, a subsidiary of Capital A, has inked a partnership agreement with OCP Asia to develop an MRO centre in Sepang, Selangor.
AirAsia's Fernandes taps Google for help with super-app push
The partnership will allow TADA to tap a larger community that uses ride-hailing and food delivery frequently, said the company’s chief executive Sean Kim.

site_title: With UK food price inflation at 46-year high, lawmakers launch probe
summary: UK lawmakers have launched an investigation into the fairness of the country's food supply chain amid a 46-year high of food price inflation, with prices 19.1% higher in March and 17.3% in April. The probe will examine how profits and risks are shared from "farm to fork" and the impact of external factors such as imported food and global commodity prices. The committee will gather evidence from various stakeholders and issue a report with recommendations, without the power to change legislation.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England is expected to raise borrowing costs for the 12th meeting in a row on Thursday, as it tries to tackle stubbornly high inflation.
A lack of housing supply in the UK is helping to prop up the property market and drive rental costs higher.
The highest number of super-prime deals took place in the borough of Kensington, with 26 properties sold.

The National Institute of Economic and Social Research estimated annual consumer price inflation will be 5.4 per cent in the final quarter of 2023 – well above forecasts from the Bank of England and the government’s budget watchdog.

site_title: Two Adani Group firms dropped from MSCI’s India gauge
summary: Two Adani Group firms, Adani Transmission and Adani Total Gas, will be dropped from MSCI's India gauge effective May 31, following changes in the calculation of freely tradable shares. The exclusion is part of MSCI's quarterly review and comes amid efforts by the conglomerate to recover from a stock rout triggered by a short-seller report in January. The move may impact investor confidence, as the Adani Group seeks to raise funds amid allegations of market manipulation and accounting fraud denied by the conglomerate.

images.alt_text: Adani Enterprises, Adani Green Energy and Adani Transmission may raise between US$3 billion and US$5 billion, according to Bloomberg News.
Adani's shares climbed 5.1 per cent after the earnings were announced which showed gross debt paring to 383.2 billion rupees from 410 billion rupees last year.

site_title: Thailand’s Kasikornbank halts plans to sell asset management stake
summary: Thailand's Kasikornbank has halted plans to sell a stake in its asset management business, citing stalled negotiations with potential bidders. The bank had initially sought a valuation of up to $2 billion, but talks with firms like Amundi, CVC Capital Partners, and TPG have stalled over terms. The decision marks a reversal for Kasikornbank, which had been weighing options for the sale since last year.

images.alt_text: The deal will give Kasikornbank, the kingdom's second-largest lender by assets, 67.5 per cent of Maspion's shares and is expected to be finalised by the end of the year, the Thai lender said in a message to the Stock Exchange of Thailand.

site_title:
Australian, New Zealand dollars take
turn for worse as global growth outlook darkens
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars slid to one-week lows due to concerns over a global economic slowdown, with the Aussie falling 1.1% overnight to US$0.6689 and the kiwi easing 0.6% to US$0.6256. Data from China showed a potential slowdown in its post-Covid rebound, while US jobless claims jumped to a 1½-year high, hinting at a potentially more abrupt slowing in the US economy. The decline in commodity prices also contributed to the downturn.

images.alt_text: Against a basket of currencies, the US dollar index edges up 0.14 per cent to 101.76.
The budget’s build-to-rent proposals apply to projects of 50 or more apartments or dwellings made available for rent to the general public.

site_title: New Zealand Q2 average 1-year inflation expectations ease to 4.28%: central bank survey
summary: New Zealand's business managers forecasted average annual inflation to ease to 4.28% in the coming year, down from 5.11% in the previous survey. This represents a decrease in near-term inflation expectations and falls within the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's target range of 1% to 3%. Two-year inflation expectations also decreased to 2.79%, within the central bank's target range. This suggests that New Zealand's near-term rate of inflation is expected to continue easing over the coming two years.

site_title: Malaysia’s Q1 GDP growth beats forecasts at 5.6%, but momentum could slow as exports weaken
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 5.6% in the first quarter, beating forecasts, driven by domestic demand. However, exports are expected to weaken due to external headwinds, leading economists to forecast moderation in growth. Bank Negara Malaysia governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus maintained the full-year growth forecast of 4-5% and is confident the country will achieve full employment by the end of the year. Despite the better-than-expected Q1 performance, economists expect growth to continue moderating due to shifting global consumption patterns and the global tech downcycle.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s central bank projects full-year inflation of 2.8 per cent to 3.8 per cent in 2023, compared to 3.3 per cent in 2022.

Many businesses in Malaysia are struggling to balance their accounts, after several new measures were implemented in 2022, such as an adjustment of the minimum wage and an increase in electricity prices.

site_title: Foxconn, Sharp shares slide after Japan firm’s surprise writedown
summary: Shares of Taiwan's Foxconn and its display affiliate Sharp fell after Japanese firm Sharp reported a surprise $1.9 billion loss due to writedowns on flat-screen assets. Sharp's shares dropped 8.7%, while Foxconn's shares fell 2.4% after reporting a $564 million hit related to the Japanese firm. Analysts downgraded their forecasts for Foxconn, citing a non-operational loss from Sharp.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Foxconn is seen outside the company's building in Taipei, Taiwan, Nov. 10, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo
Foxconn has manufactured Apple handsets in India since 2019 at its plant in the southern state of Tamil Nadu.

site_title: Without shared values and goals, tech regulation won’t work
summary: The European Union designated 19 online platforms, including Instagram, TikTok, and Twitter, as having significant user numbers, subjecting them to stricter content regulations. However, harmonization of values and goals among countries and tech companies is crucial for effective regulation, as differing priorities can hinder progress. The EU's regulatory approach highlights the challenges of harmonization in the tech realm, where technological advancements often conflict with restrictions imposed by various countries.

images.alt_text: Lawyers are to provide clients with effective legal representation, which often means they have to grapple with novel issues by coming up with arguments previously not advanced.
Stakeholder capitalism places attention on all private actors in society.

The US Department of Commerce put out a call for input from industry actors that would serve to inform the Biden administration in drafting regulation on AI.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS expects UMS order momentum to slow, lowers target to S$1.20
summary: DBS Group Research lowered its target price on UMS Holdings to S$1.20 from S$1.53, while maintaining a "buy" call. The research team cut earnings estimates due to slow order momentum and margin pressures, anticipating weak order momentum in the near term with a recovery in 2024. The company's semiconductor segment accounts for 90% of its revenue, and DBS believes UMS can benefit from global trade diversification amid US-China tensions, with its second plant expected to begin production in mid-2023.

site_title: Meta introduces AI tools to create ads and predict performance
summary: Meta introduced the "AI Sandbox" for advertisers to test AI-powered ad features, including generating different text for ads, creating alternate background images, and resizing ad images. The company is working with a small group of advertisers to test the tools, with plans to expand access in July. Meta also introduced Meta Lattice, an AI-based model that can predict ad performance using a larger data set, which showed increased performance for advertisers in early tests on Instagram. This move aims to help Meta's core digital advertising business grow amid pressure to rediscover revenue growth.

images.alt_text: China's artficial intelligence industry is dealing with a shortage of both talent and chips as companies seek to meet growing demand.

site_title: Europe: Shares run out of steam by close as Bayer, energy stocks weigh
summary: Europe's benchmark Stoxx 600 index closed flat on Thursday, weighed down by Germany's Bayer and energy stocks. Despite US economic data suggesting a pause in the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike campaign, investors remained cautious. Bayer fell 7.5% and energy stocks dropped 1.6% after lower oil prices. On the other hand, Swedish real estate company SBB rebounded 12.7% and Norwegian salmon farmer SalMar jumped 6.5% after reporting positive first-quarter results.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.7 per cent lower at 33,309.84, while the broad-based S&P 500 nudged down 0.2 per cent to 4,130.57 on Thursday.

site_title: Debt ceiling talks postponed until next week: White House
summary: US debt ceiling talks have been postponed until next week as staff continued working on a deal. Despite a meeting between President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, the two sides remain divided over the debt ceiling, with Republicans demanding significant budget cuts in exchange for support. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has warned of a potential default on June 1, which could have severe consequences for the global economy. The IMF has also expressed concern, stating that a US debt default would have "very serious repercussions" for the global economy.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen told a news conference prior to the start of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that a default “would spark a global downturn” and “would also risk undermining US global economic leadership.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Seatrium, Thai Beverage, OCBC, First Resources, StarHub, AEM, Bumitama Agri
summary: Stocks to watch include Seatrium, Thai Beverage, OCBC, First Resources, StarHub, AEM, and Bumitama Agri. Seatrium announced a net order book of S$20 billion for the year to date, while Thai Beverage reported a 3.4% rise in net profit. OCBC priced A$1 billion of senior floating-rate green notes, and First Resources fell 73.8% in net profit due to high base effect. StarHub rose 26% in net profit, and AEM Holdings dropped 61.8%. Bumitama Agri's shares fell 51% in net profit due to lower average selling price and higher fertiliser prices.

site_title: Elon Musk says new Twitter chief has been hired
summary: Elon Musk has announced the hiring of a new CEO for Twitter, which he has rebranded as X Corporation. This follows a promise to honour the results of a poll in which 57.5% of Twitter users voted for him to step down as CEO. Musk will transition into an executive chair and chief technology officer role, overseeing product, software, and system operations. The new CEO is expected to start in about six weeks, fulfilling Musk's earlier promise to step down.

images.alt_text: Google is racing to catch up with rival Microsoft, which has rushed to integrate ChatGPT-like powers in a wide array of its products, including the Bing search engine.
Elon Musk on Tuesday announced that audio and video calls are coming to Twitter.
Twitter’s billionaire owner Elon Musk in a separate tweet said inactive accounts will be archived, Musk did not add any details on when the process will begin.
Elon Musk’s policy changes since taking over Twitter, from firing half its staff to demanding users pay for once-coveted verified checkmarks, have disconcerted observers and users.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as regional banks fail to shake off fears
summary: US stocks ended mostly down on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing 0.7% lower and the S&P 500 down 0.2%. Regional banks faced pressure, with shares of PacWest slumping 22.7% after it reported a 9.5% drop in deposits and a 16.9% decline in total deposits in the first quarter. Concerns over a hard landing and deteriorating lending conditions fueled investor worries. The US debt ceiling talks and the Federal Reserve's next moves are also being closely watched.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Friday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell at the opening bell on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 0.4% to 3,217.41. Losers outnumbered gainers 68 to 49, and 92 million securities worth S$86.7 million were traded. Thai Beverage fell 3.3% after announcing a 3.4% rise in net profit, while Seatrium gained 1.6% after exceeding S$20 billion in net orders. Local banks DBS and UOB fell, while OCBC rose 0.2%. US stocks saw mixed trading, with the Dow Jones down 0.7% and the S&P 500 down 0.2%.

site_title: Bumitama Agri Q1 profit falls 51% to 429.1 billion rupiah
summary: Bumitama Agri, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 51% drop in net profit to 429.1 billion rupiah for its first quarter, primarily due to lower average selling prices and higher fertiliser costs. Revenue declined 8% to 3.6 trillion rupiah, with contributions from the palm kernel business falling 58%. However, the crude palm oil business saw a 3% increase in revenue due to higher sales volume. The company's shares closed 2.6% higher on the stock market.

site_title: Seatrium undertakes ‘holistic’ business review; net order book hits S$20 billion
summary: Seatrium, formerly Sembcorp Marine, has begun a "holistic" review of its business, focusing on its capital structure, growth opportunities, and sustainability amid the global green-energy transition. The review will assess the company's debt, asset holding structure, and cash flow sustainability. Seatrium's net order book has reached S$20 billion, with 39% comprising renewables and cleaner solutions. The company expects to execute its projects and tap growth areas in the renewables space, including offshore wind projects. A strategic review will guide the company's decisions on capital structure and share consolidation.

images.alt_text: Formerly known as Sembcorp Marine, Seatrium has won a S$500 million contract for the construction two offshore substation platforms for two offshore wind farms in the United States.

site_title: First class gets even fancier as airlines take luxury up a level
summary: Airlines are revamping first class to cater to deep-pocketed customers seeking luxury travel. Airlines such as Lufthansa, Qantas, and Cathay Pacific are investing heavily in upgraded cabins, including suites with private doors, heated/cooling seats, and personalized assistants. The investment comes despite economic slowdowns, as airlines aim to capitalize on the return of leisure travel. Premium travel is back to 86% of 2019 levels, with first class fares ranging from $15,000 to $18,000 for a round-trip ticket, making it a lucrative sector for airlines.

images.alt_text: The airline has made a “full recovery” since the hit to demand caused by the pandemic, says chairman and chief executive officer Sheikh Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum.

The first of the nine A350-1000s is slated to be delivered by the fourth quarter of 2025, with deliveries continuing until 2027, the airline said.

site_title: Asian Pay TV Trust Q1 net profit down 41% to S$7.1 million
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) reported a 41% decline in Q1 net profit to S$7.1 million due to 8.8% revenue drop and foreign exchange losses. Revenue fell to S$67.1 million, despite a 0.4% rise in constant Taiwan dollars boosted by broadband subscriptions. The company reaffirmed its full-year distribution guidance of S$0.0105 per unit. Basic cable TV revenue declined 12.4%, while broadband revenue increased 4.2%. APTT expects subscriptions for premium digital cable TV and broadband to rise, while basic cable TV subscriptions are expected to plateau due to a saturated market.

As travel recovers, these companies may face increased waste and emissions, potentially offsetting any environmental benefits. Meanwhile, sustainable bond issuance in Southeast Asia has slowed, indicating a potential decrease in investor interest in eco-friendly financing.

site_title: Revolut finance chief exits after two years
summary: Revolut's chief financial officer, Mikko Salovaara, is leaving the UK-headquartered fintech after two years for personal reasons. Salovaara had joined the firm in early 2021 and had expressed confidence in the company's future success despite facing obstacles, including concerns over its UK banking license. The company's CEO, Nik Storonsky, thanked Salovaara for his contribution and wished him well on his next steps.

site_title: IMF warns US default would have ‘serious repercussions’ globally
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that a US default on its debt would have "very serious repercussions" globally, including higher interest rates and broader instability. The IMF urges the US government to reach a consensus on the looming debt ceiling to avoid such consequences, which would add to the economic shocks of the past few years, including the Covid-19 pandemic and war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen told a news conference prior to the start of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that a default “would spark a global downturn” and “would also risk undermining US global economic leadership.

site_title: Geopolitics is driving Asean bank digitalisation
summary: Asean financial leaders are urging regional banks to accelerate digitalization and shift operations to the cloud to meet policymakers' expectations and the broader economy's needs. The push comes as digital wallets are already at the core of Asean spending, with smartphone ownership and the pandemic accelerating adoption. The goal is to reduce dependence on foreign currencies and boost local currency use for regional settlements, with the potential for cross-border digital payment systems. Leveraging software as a service (SaaS) can help regional banks keep up with consumers' digital trajectories and provide modern systems for identity verification, cybersecurity, and customer service.

images.alt_text: A customer using PayNow at a food stall in Whampoa on 30 November 2020.

site_title: Opec raises Chinese oil demand view, cites risk from US debt ceiling
summary: Opec raised its forecast for Chinese oil demand growth to 800,000 barrels per day, citing better-than-expected economic performance in China. The global oil demand growth figure remained unchanged at 2.33 million barrels per day, with Opec leaving its 2023 economic growth forecast at 2.6% due to potential risks such as the US debt ceiling and inflation. The organization cited geopolitical uncertainties and increasing debt payments from higher interest rates as key factors.

images.alt_text: Brent crude dropped US$1.03, or 1.3 per cent, to settle at US$76.41 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) fell US$1.15, or 1.6 per cent, to US$72.56 a barrel.

site_title: WHO declares end to mpox public health emergency
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the end of the global health emergency for mpox, a viral disease that caused flu-like symptoms and pus-filled skin lesions in over 100 countries. The declaration, made by WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, marks the end of a nearly year-long public health emergency. The decision is based on the recommendation of the WHO's emergency committee, which met on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: New name suggestions for monkeypox range from terms that remove the monkey imagery to ones that are farcical, such as "Poxy McPoxface".

site_title: Singapore Pools makes digital learning fun for seniors
summary: Singapore Pools' Community Day 2023, held on May 9, brought together 300 beneficiaries from 14 social service agencies, including a 77-year-old woman who received a pink balloon bracelet. The event, part of Singapore Pools' 55th anniversary celebrations, aimed to uplift disadvantaged communities through giving efforts. Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo attended the carnival at Gardens by the Bay, showcasing the organization's commitment to community upliftment.

images.alt_text: Singapore Pools CEO Lam Chee Weng in action at Tanah Merah Conutry Club during the BT Corporate Golf League 2023.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts lower Prime US Reit’s target price, expect earnings to stabilise
summary: Analysts from DBS and RHB have lowered their target prices for Prime US Reit to US$0.33 and US$0.57, respectively, citing a 30% year-on-year decline in estimated headline distribution per unit to US$0.0125. The decline is attributed to fluctuating occupancy and higher management fees paid in cash. Despite the lower target prices, both brokerages maintain a "buy" call on the counter.

images.alt_text: Comprising two freehold seven-storey Class A office towers, Sorrento Towers will be acquired by Prime US Reit at its valuation price of US$146 million.

site_title: Big banks with uninsured deposits to reimburse insurance fund, says US regulator
summary: The US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) has proposed a special assessment fee of 0.125% on uninsured deposits of US$5 billion or more to replenish the $16 billion hit to its deposit insurance fund due to the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank in March. The fee will be collected over eight quarters and primarily applies to banks with over $50 billion in assets, covering 95% of the cost. The extended timeline aims to minimize impact on bank liquidity.

images.alt_text: The DIF, as the fund is known, is a linchpin of the US financial system as it’s used to insure most accounts for up to US$250,000.

site_title: Oil falls 2% on weak US and Chinese economic data
summary: Oil prices fell 2% to a one-week low on Thursday due to recession jitters in the US and weak Chinese economic data. Brent crude futures dropped to $74.98 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $70.87. The US dollar rose against major currencies, making oil more expensive in other countries. Analysts at Ritterbusch and Associates attributed the decline to uncertainties over the US debt ceiling, banking issues, and a possible recession.

images.alt_text: World oil demand in 2023 will rise by 2.33 million barrels per day (bpd), or 2.3 per cent, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said in a monthly report.

site_title: Peony Jade: New premises at Tanjong Pagar serves modern dim sum and Cantonese cooking
summary: Peony Jade, a modern dim sum and Cantonese restaurant in Amara Singapore, has relocated to a more accessible location. The restaurant's chefs attempt to jazz up familiar dishes with mixed results. Standout items include brown sugar char siew pau, crispy pan-fried beancurd rolls, and lychee bonsai, which features dry ice and mini "lychees" made of prawn paste. The restaurant's menu is colorful and playful, with dishes named after kung fu stances and poetic phrases. While not a traditional Chinese restaurant, Peony Jade offers a unique twist on classic Cantonese cuisine with commendable effort and affable service.

images.alt_text: Hearth's dim but cosy, unpretentious interiors.

site_title: Chefs say Paris 2024 Olympians will have their cake, and eat it too
summary: Paris 2024 Olympics chefs have unveiled a menu featuring fresh baguettes, gourmet French dishes, and environmentally friendly options. The menu, created by renowned chefs, will include dishes such as crushed chickpeas with herbs, quinoa risotto, and chocolate mousse with raspberries. The Olympic Village's main restaurant will use reusable serving dishes, and all meals will be based on seasonal products, with plant-based food representing one-third of the offerings. The goal is to provide high-quality, healthy food that also aligns with the Olympic values of sustainability and environmental friendliness.

site_title: ThaiBev Q2 profit up 3.4% to 7.4 billion baht on higher sales revenue
summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) reported a 3.4% increase in net profit to 7.4 billion baht for the second quarter ended March 31, 2023, driven by higher sales revenue from spirits, non-alcoholic beverages, and food businesses. Revenue rose 2.4% to 67.4 billion baht, with the spirits segment contributing 31.4 billion baht and non-alcoholic beverages 4.8 billion baht. The company's interim dividend of 0.15 baht per share remains unchanged.

site_title: Venture Corp to install dual CEOs in restructuring
summary: Venture Corporation has announced the promotion of dual CEOs, Lee Ghai Keen and Wong Chee Kheong, to lead the company's two business groups, advanced manufacturing and design solutions (AMDS) and technology products and solutions (TPS), respectively. Lee will focus on the technology-driven transformation of life science and other businesses, while Wong will innovate and differentiate technology products underpinning Venture's organic electronic manufacturing services. The dual CEOs model is seen as an effective leadership approach to navigate the complexities of the technology industry.

Venture Corporation has made investment in advanced manufacturing systems and automation to drive efficiency, productivity and value creation.

site_title: Pakistan Supreme Court frees Imran Khan from custody
summary: Pakistan's Supreme Court ruled that former premier Imran Khan's arrest by the anti-graft agency was illegal, ordering his release from custody. The court's decision came after Khan was presented before the top court in an appeal against his arrest, which has fueled countrywide protests. The ruling comes as Pakistan's economy faces deep distress, with Moody's Investors Service warning of a potential default without an International Monetary Fund bailout.

site_title: Europe and the Indo-Pacific: Partners facing similar challenges
summary: The European Union is launching a new initiative to deepen partnerships with the Indo-Pacific region on sustainable prosperity, environment, digital connectivity, and security, including human security. EU High Representative Josep Borrell and Swedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billström will host a meeting in Stockholm on May 13, calling for action and cooperation in the face of global challenges such as aggression, economic turbulence, and climate change. The Indo-Pacific region is seen as strategically important, hosting a large portion of the world's population and economy, and stability in the region is crucial for global prosperity.

images.alt_text: Europe’s underlying goal of engagement with the Asia Pacific is to build competitive advantage vis-a-vis other world powers, including the US.

US President Joe Biden, India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida at the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) launch event in Tokyo, Japan, May 23, 2022.

site_title: Renault mulling attracting other strategic investors to Ampere, Alpine: CEO
summary: Renault is considering attracting new investors for its electric and software entity Ampere and sports brand Alpine, following its strategy to stay competitive in the electrification market. The company aims to list Ampere in Paris this year, with a potential valuation of up to 10 billion euros. Alpine listing is not currently on the agenda, according to CEO Luca de Meo. This move is part of Renault's efforts to raise capital and maintain its position in the rapidly evolving automotive industry.

site_title: Sweden to present law on blocking risky foreign investments
summary: Sweden's majority government plans to submit a bill to parliament next week allowing scrutiny of foreign direct investments in Swedish companies, with the aim of blocking those posing a national security risk. The legislation, set to take effect on Dec 1, follows a trend among Western nations seeking to prevent Chinese companies from making certain acquisitions. The Swedish government did not name specific countries that could pose a security risk, but the move is seen as a response to concerns over sensitive technological know-how flowing to China.

site_title: The cancer vaccine race is on
summary: BioNTech and Moderna are developing mRNA-based cancer vaccines targeting various types of cancer, including melanoma, prostate, and lung cancer. The vaccines aim to instruct the immune system to recognize and eliminate cancer cells. Clinical trials are underway, with 10,000 patients to be fast-tracked into trials in the UK. The World Health Organization estimates 10 million people die of cancer annually, and a successful cancer vaccine could potentially save millions of lives. By 2030, BioNTech co-founders predict that mRNA immunizations could become anti-cancer treatments.

images.alt_text: GSK has been trying to replenish its product pipeline in recent years as the company faces pressure to improve shareholder returns and keep up with UK rival AstraZeneca.
Beyond the vaccine race

site_title: Google, SAP team up to ease AI tasks for cloud clients
summary: Google's cloud computing unit and SAP have partnered to make it easier for clients to unite data from disparate sources and efficiently use artificial intelligence (AI) in their businesses. The partnership aims to help customers in various industries, including supply chain and marketing, by "harmonising" data sets. Google Cloud CEO Thomas Kurian said the partnership will bring together the power of data and AI to drive business transformation. SAP CEO Christian Klein noted that this partnership is the "front runner" for the company's cloud collaborations, allowing customers to leverage Google Cloud's AI tools.

images.alt_text: Google has previously tested new search features by introducing them to randomised groups of users.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine H1 profit falls 61% to S$4.2 million
summary: Marco Polo Marine reported a 61% drop in net profit to S$4.2 million for the first half of 2023, despite a 60.7% increase in revenue to S$55.9 million. The company's ship chartering and shipbuilding and repair operations improved from the previous year. No dividend was declared, citing capital expenditure requirements and cash conservation. The company remains focused on expanding its presence in renewable energy and offshore wind farm sectors.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Marco Polo Marine saw net profit and overall revenue skyrocket in Q1 2023.
Marco Polo Marine has shifted its focus from oil and gas companies to merchant vessels as shipping boomed amid the pandemic.

site_title: Three Adani firms weigh raising up to US$5 billion: Bloomberg News
summary: Three Adani Group firms, including Adani Enterprises, Adani Green Energy, and Adani Transmission, are considering raising up to $5 billion in funding, according to Bloomberg News. This comes after a failed $2.5 billion share sale in February due to a short-seller report. The companies are holding board meetings to consider proposals for the fundraising, but did not disclose the amount they plan to raise. The move is seen as an effort to recover from a significant loss of value, over $110 billion, since a scathing report by Hindenburg Research accused the group of unlawful use of offshore tax havens and stock manipulation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani group is seen on the facade of one of its buildings on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, April 13, 2021. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: Donald Trump has become more dangerous
summary: Donald Trump damaged himself in a CNN town hall on May 10, revealing his threat to the country. Unfiltered by his aides, Trump attacked his accuser, calling her a "whack job," and lied about the January 6, 2021, Capitol insurrection. He also expressed inclination to pardon rioters, despite laughter and applause from the audience. The CNN moderator attempted to fact-check him, but Trump responded with insults, showcasing his shamelessness. The incident highlights Trump's ability to present himself as a candidate despite his questionable behavior.

images.alt_text: Former US President Donald Trump with his defense team during his arraignment at court in New York, US, on Tuesday, April 4, 2023. Trump entered a not-guilty plea to 34 counts of falsifying business records in the first degree in a proceeding that took a little less than an hour. Photographer: Andrew Kelly/Reuters/Bloomberg

site_title: Volkswagen’s next-gen software platform to come towards 2027, 2028: CFO
summary: Volkswagen's next-generation software platform, Cariad, is expected to be released towards 2027 or 2028, about 2 years behind its initial target of 2026. The platform is designed to enable "Level 4" autonomous driving and will be implemented across the fleet. CFO Arno Antlitz cited delays in development and a focus on premium electric models as reasons for the delay. The company is also looking to rely more on outside partners to reduce cash burn and improve software expertise.

images.alt_text: Chief executive Oliver Blume acknowledges the fast pace of China’s electrification, and outlines Volkswagen’s strategy to hold on to its position as market leader.

site_title: Britain draws up blueprint for multi-billion fund to back startups
summary: Britain is planning a multi-billion pound investment fund, the "Future Growth Fund," to back UK startups and stem the flow of technology firms to New York. The fund aims to draw up to $63.11 billion from British pension pots to invest in fast-growing tech and biotech firms. The plan, proposed by London's lord mayor, Nicholas Lyons, could be finalized by the end of the year and would act as a giant UK-focused venture capital fund, specializing in backing unlisted startups.

images.alt_text: Investor confidence in the global banking sector has been shaken in recent weeks by the demise of Silicon Valley Bank, the collapse of a large US regional lender and the emergency rescue of Swiss giant Credit Suisse.

site_title: MOM imposes S$75,000 penalty on Japan Foods unit over payroll infringements
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has fined Japan Foods Holding a S$75,000 penalty for infringements under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act. The fine was due to erroneous Central Provident Fund contributions that inflated foreign employee entitlements for Japan Foods Enterprises. The company attributed the errors to an administrative oversight, stating no criminal offense was committed. JFE will pay the penalty and work with MOM to lift a suspension on new work pass applications, with the fine not expected to impact the company's financial results.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

site_title: Climate Impact X to roll out carbon credit price data with launch of spot exchange
summary: Climate Impact X, a Temasek-backed global carbon marketplace, will launch a suite of price assessments for carbon credits alongside its spot trading platform in July. The pricing intelligence aims to provide transparent and market-representative benchmarks for the growing voluntary carbon market. This move is seen as crucial for efficient market building, as CIX's pricing director Julien Hall stated that credible price signals are essential in this nascent market.

images.alt_text: The new pricing intelligence, Climate Impact X said, is meant to cater to growing demands from market participants for more transparent and market-representative benchmarks of carbon credits.
Wong Pei Ting

site_title: US producer prices increase at slowest pace since early 2021
summary: US producer prices rose 2.3% from a year ago in April, the slowest pace since early 2021, as inflation continued to moderate due to falling commodities costs and improved supply chains. The majority of the monthly increase, 80%, was attributed to services, including portfolio management, food wholesaling, and healthcare-related costs. The Federal Reserve closely monitors service prices for signs of abating inflationary pressures. Excluding food and energy, the core PPI increased 0.2% last month.

images.alt_text: An employee works at the BMW manufacturing plant in Greer, South Carolina, U.S., October 19, 2022.   REUTERS/Bob Strong

site_title: Vicom Q1 profit up 8% to S$6.9 million on higher operating profit, interest income
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection company, reported an 8% increase in after-tax profit to S$6.9 million in its first quarter ended March 31, 2023. This rise was driven by higher operating profit and interest income, despite higher operating costs. Revenue also rose 6.6% to S$27.8 million, primarily due to increased business volume in its non-vehicle testing business.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Vicom's vehicle testing business saw the periodic inspection for vehicles clocking a record number of 534,840 inspections in FY2022, up from 523,639 in FY2021.

site_title: Dyna-Mac secures new orders worth S$270 million
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings secured new orders worth S$270 million, bringing its net order book to S$608.1 million. The contracts include the construction of topside modules for a floating production storage offloading vessel and fabrication, installation, and integration work on-board vessels. The group's CEO, Lim Ah Cheng, attributed the wins to the company's ability to execute projects on time, on budget, and with strict safety and environmental standards. The new orders are expected to have a minimal impact on the group's earnings per share and net tangible assets for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Dyna-Mac's revenue for Q1 was up 29.3 per cent to S$87.3 million, from S$67.5 million a year ago.
In the long term, Maybank maintains a bullish outlook for Dyna-Mac as it believes the group is one of the key beneficiaries of the multi-year upcycle in the oil and gas sector.

site_title: EV maker Polestar lowers production guidance, cuts jobs
summary: Swedish electric vehicle maker Polestar has lowered its 2023 production guidance to 60,000-70,000 cars, down from 80,000 previously, due to a delayed production start for its Polestar 3 and a challenging industry environment. The company also announced a 10% reduction in headcount. The move comes as EV startups face increased competition from Chinese players and high interest rates, contributing to a tough quarter for the industry.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 open lower as Disney drags
summary: The US stock market opened lower on May 11, 2023, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 147.44 points, or 0.44%, to 33,383.89. The S&P 500 opened 5.40 points, or 0.13%, lower at 4,132.24, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 14.82 points, or 0.12%, to 12,321.26. The decline was driven by a drop in Disney shares after the company reported a fall in subscriber growth and a drop in PacWest's deposits, which sparked a rout in the regional banking sector.

site_title: Robinhood under investigation over communications compliance
summary: Robinhood is cooperating with probes by the US Securities and Exchange Commission and Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, investigating the firm's compliance with recordkeeping requirements, including employees' use of "off-channel communications." The SEC is also looking into trade reporting rules related to securities lending and fractional share trading.

site_title: Space startup partners with SpaceX to launch commercial space station
summary: Vast, a space startup backed by Jed McCaleb, plans to launch a school bus-sized space station, Haven-1, with SpaceX by late 2025. The cylindrical spacecraft is a replacement to the International Space Station (ISS), which is expected to retire in 2030. NASA aims to have commercial space stations replace the ISS, with Haven-1 being the latest platform in this effort.

images.alt_text: The consortium will be run by aerospace manufacturers Airbus and Thales Alenia Space along with satellite operators Eutelsat Communications, SES, and Hispasat.

site_title: Kimly H1 profit rises 0.7%, but revenue falls as food delivery demand tapers
summary: Kimly, a CATALIST-listed coffeeshop operator, reported a 0.7% rise in net profit to S$18.7 million for its first half-year ended March 31, despite a 0.9% revenue drop to S$155.5 million. The decline in revenue was attributed to a 5.7% drop in its food retail division, which generated S$91.2 million in revenue during the period.

images.alt_text: Kimly said the disposal will streamline business operations and better direct resources to the core business of operating coffeeshops, by opening more outlets and diversifying product offerings.
Industry players and market watchers said rising inflation, rental costs and the ongoing manpower crunch are pushing some F&B players to exit the market or seek out strategic partners for support.

site_title: Engineering service provider Ever Glory to raise over S$3 million in Catalist IPO
summary: Singapore-based mechanical and electrical engineering service provider Ever Glory United Holdings plans to raise over S$3 million through an initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company, which reported a profit of S$1.8 million in its latest financial year, aims to further strengthen its market position and broaden its income sources. It plans to scale its existing business, venture into property development and property investment, and potentially expand into other countries.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
SGX welcomed 11 new listings in 2022. The companies raised a total of S$580.3 million, according to bourse data.
BLA’s potential listing could be a boost for SGX, which has not had any mainboard listings for over a year.

site_title: Food Empire’s Q1 net profit up 50.9% to US$13.8 million on higher operating profits
summary: Food Empire, a manufacturer of proprietary brands, reported a 50.9% rise in Q1 net profit to US$13.8 million, driven by higher operating profits. Revenue rose 24.2% to US$102.6 million, with strong demand for branded products and lower sales in 2022 due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The company expects to benefit from favourable pricing in its South Asia segment, where revenue increased 29.6% to US$10.9 million. Despite a 10.4% decline in South-east Asia revenue, Food Empire plans to invest in its brands to gain market share and mitigate the effects of geopolitical uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Brokers’ take: RHB raises Food Empire target to S$1.39 after FY2022 earnings surprise
As the geopolitical situation still remains uncertain, Food Empire said it could face some margin pressure due to volatility in the foreign exchange rates and economic situation.

site_title: Return to Seoul digs deep into the roots of identity and belonging
summary: "Return to Seoul," a drama about a Korean-born French adoptee's search for her biological parents, has made its way to Singapore after wowing audiences at Cannes. The film follows Freddie, played by Park Ji-Min, as she navigates her identity and belonging in South Korea, struggling to connect with locals and confront her past. With a raw and unrefined performance by Park, the film strikes a balance between vulnerability and anger, ultimately leaving viewers with more questions than answers, but an emotionally resonant experience.

site_title: China's GEM to build a $500 million joint nickel project in Indonesia
summary: China's GEM Co is investing $500 million in a joint nickel project in Indonesia's Morowali Industrial Park. The project will produce 20,000 tonnes of nickel intermediate product annually for the new energy sector. GEM holds 51% of the project, while Singapore-based Cahaya Jaya Investment and Hong Kong-based Weiming International Holdings hold 26% and 18% shares, respectively. The project aims to support Indonesia's growing energy sector and China's increasing demand for nickel.

site_title: Sterling trims drop after BOE hike, China's data sends US dollar higher
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to 4.5% to curb inflation, while the US dollar rose following weak Chinese data showing consumer inflation almost flatlined. Sterling edged up 0.2% to $1.2597 after a 0.4% fall before the BOE decision. The US dollar index rose 0.4% to 101.81, with the euro slipping 0.5% to a three-week low of $1.0929. The BOE no longer predicts recession, but inflation is expected to be slower to fall than initially hoped.

images.alt_text: A shopkeeper (L) passes a customer their change in GBP pound sterling ten and twenty pound notes, at a shop in east London on March 31, 2023. (Photo by Susannah Ireland / AFP) / TO GO WITH AFP STORY BY Akshata KAPOOR

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower on Thursday despite Wall Street gains
summary: Singapore stocks ended lower on Thursday, despite a positive performance on Wall Street, due to softer inflation figures in the US. The Straits Times Index fell 0.4% to 3,229.55, with losers outnumbering gainers 287 to 246. Analysts attribute this to elevated sticky-price inflation growth in the US and heightened risk of global food price increases, potentially leading to a pause in the Fed funds rate hike. Regional indices also saw mixed performances, with the Nikkei 225 inching up 0.02%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Singapore stocks open little changed on Thursday; STI up 0.03%

site_title: 👋 Return of the boomerang employee
summary: A growing trend of "boomerang employees" is returning to their old workplaces after a period of time. However, it's essential to evaluate why they left initially and consider whether the workplace has changed for the better. Key questions to ask include whether the role is still interesting, the reporting structure has changed, and whether the company's long-term career plan aligns with their goals. Returning employees should be humble, open-minded, and willing to learn, bringing new skills and experiences to the table.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
If you're stuck in a work rut, delve into how and why you got there in order to work out how best to get out of it.
BT

site_title: The strange world of early video art
summary: National Gallery Singapore showcases "See Me, See You: Early Video Installation of Southeast Asia" featuring works from 1980s and 1990s artists from Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines. The exhibit highlights the region's unique aesthetic in early video art, with pieces such as Apinan Poshyananda's "How To Explain Art To A Bangkok Cock" and Chng Nai Wee's "Sin Of Apathy" that challenged audiences to question their apathy towards global issues. The show runs until September 17, offering a glimpse into the region's early experimentation with video art.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Thai artist Rirkrit Tiravanija's (right) latest show is curated by longtime friend and collaborator Hans Ulrich Obrist.
Brian Gothong Tan's stunning, surreal images were created using an AI tool. Like other artists in Singapore, Tan has been turning to AI for collaboration and inspiration.
Ghafir Akbar (left) and Julie Wee as the king and queen of fairies Oberon and Titania respectively.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims jump to the highest level since late 2021
summary: US jobless claims surged to 264,000 in the week ended May 6, the highest level since October 2021, amid rising interest rates weighing on the labor market. Economists had forecast 245,000 claims. Despite this, the labor market remains tight, with 1.6 job openings for every unemployed person. The Federal Reserve's interest rate increases are expected to continue affecting the labor market in the second half of the year, potentially leading to higher claims.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 16, 2022 a “Now Hiring” sign at T.J. Maxx in Annapolis, Maryland. - US job gains eased in March for a second straight month, government data showed March 7, 2023, adding to signs that the world's largest economy is cooling as policymakers push on in their fight against inflation. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)

site_title: Adidas to sell some Yeezy stock, donate proceeds: CEO
summary: Adidas plans to sell some Yeezy stock, with proceeds to be donated to international organizations that Kanye West harmed with his anti-Semitic comments. The company, which cut ties with West last year, has millions of Yeezy brand shoes worth 1.2 billion euros in storage. Selling the stock could minimize a $700 million loss this year, but the amount and proportion of proceeds to be donated are unclear. CEO Bjorn Gulden defended the company's 5-year collaboration with West, calling him "the most creative mind" in the industry.

images.alt_text: CHICAGO, ILLINOIS - FEBRUARY 10: Shoes are offered for sale at an Adidas store on February 10, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. Adidas is expecting to report a loss in 2023 after terminating a lucrative deal with rap artist Ye (formerly Kanye West) after he made a series of antisemitic and racist remarks. The company is now trying to decide what to do with $1.3 billion of the artist's unsold Yeezy branded merchandise.   Scott Olson/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SCOTT OLSON / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
“Their numbers there have been just abysmal. They’ve clearly lost market share, and that has a bigger impact in the long term than even Yeezy does,” says Morningstar analyst David Swartz.

site_title: Fitness studio Haus Athletics shuts outlets; operating company in liquidation
summary: Haus Athletics, a Singapore-based fitness studio chain, has been placed into creditors' voluntary liquidation after failing to meet financial obligations. The studio's two outlets at Cross Street Exchange and OUE Downtown Gallery were shut down on April 26 and April 19, respectively. The studio's owners, HAUS Lifestyle, owed approximately $1.8 million to 268 creditors, including studio members. The decision was made due to financial difficulties and changes in the market, despite efforts to adapt to the pandemic's aftermath.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Several users who bought packages ranging from about $200 to $600 from Kyklos Studio are unable to gain refunds.
The total amount of losses was a sharp increase of 24 per cent from S$520,000 in 2021, said the Consumers Association of Singapore.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore banks' CEOs pledge prudence ahead of rising credit quality risks. Capital Match, an invoice financing platform, is to liquidate after years of controversy. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has increased its gold reserves by 45% to 222 tonnes. Singapore stocks fell 0.4% despite Wall Street gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,229.55.

images.alt_text: Asia-Pacific is the top source for the increase in Singapore’s AUM, followed by Europe and the Americas.

site_title: Construction of JB-Singapore RTS Link on Singapore side has reached 50% mark: S Iswaran
summary: Construction on the Johor Bahru-Singapore Rapid Transit System Link has reached 50% on the Singapore side, with the project expected to start operations by end-2026. The 4km-long rail shuttle service, spanning 2.7km in Malaysia and 1.3km in Singapore, is on track despite challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic and government changes. The project aims to alleviate congestion on the Causeway and improve connectivity between Singapore and Johor Bahru, with affordable ticket fares expected to be finalized closer to completion.

site_title: StarHub Q1 net profit up 26% to S$37.5 million on higher service revenue
summary: StarHub reported a 26% rise in net profit to S$37.5 million in Q1, driven by higher service revenue growth of 11% and consolidation of MyRepublic broadband. All service segments showed growth, with mobile revenue up 13.5%, broadband revenue up 20.4%, and entertainment revenue up 21%. The company attributed topline growth to healthy operating metrics, including an increase in average revenue per user. StarHub plans to consolidate its Infinity Play products into an all-in-one app and position its enterprise business as a smart-city service provider.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The telecommunications company shed as much as 8.1 per cent or S$0.09 to S$1.02 in morning trading.
Excluding Dare+ provisions, non-operating items and its corresponding tax effects, StarHub's net profit after tax would have fallen by 34.6 per cent to S$53.2 million in the second half of the year.

site_title: Bank of England raises rates to 4.5% with inflation slow to fall
summary: The Bank of England raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to 4.5% on May 11, its 12th consecutive rate rise, to curb the fastest inflation of any major economy. The central bank now expects inflation to be slower to fall than initially thought, mainly due to persistently high food prices. The decision was in line with economists' expectations, but the BOE retains the same guidance on future actions, with inflation expected to remain above the 2% target until early 2025.

images.alt_text: The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) said its measure of new buyer enquiries fell to a net balance of -37 in last month from -30 in March, the lowest since January.

site_title: UK broadcaster ITV sees no quick relief for tough ad market
summary: UK broadcaster ITV reported a challenging advertising market for the April to June period due to persistently high inflation and economic uncertainty. The company expects total advertising revenue to be 12% lower than expected, with trading in line but behind analyst forecasts. ITV cited an improvement in the third quarter, driven by the return of popular shows like "Love Island" and the Rugby World Cup. The company's shares fell 5% following the update, but analysts expect a limited impact on full-year estimates.

images.alt_text: ITV said on Wednesday (Nov 9) that while the World Cup would help ad revenue in November and December, economic uncertainty could impact corporate ad spend.

site_title: China’s AI charge: Short on chips and talent
summary: China's AI industry is facing a significant challenge due to a shortage of high-performance graphics processing units (GPUs) from US chipmaker Nvidia. The US government has blocked Nvidia from exporting its A100 and H100 chips to China, limiting the country's ability to develop large language models and generative AI. Chinese companies are struggling to find domestic alternatives, and even if they could design competitive chips, they would face difficulties in manufacturing and packaging. Additionally, China is facing a shortage of top AI talent, with a deficit of 300,000 AI professionals, and its universities are not producing enough technical talent to meet industry demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Semiconductor chips are seen on a printed circuit board in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Invoice financing platform Capital Match to liquidate after years of controversy
summary: Capital Match, a Singapore-based invoice financing platform, will undergo liquidation after years of controversy over its operations. The company, which was on the Monetary Authority of Singapore's investor alert list, had allegedly misled investors into taking on more risk than they signed up for. At least four individuals have reported their grievances to the Singapore police, and Capital Match has been involved in numerous lawsuits. The company's liquidator, Perun Consultants, will manage operations and communicate with investors.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Bankruptcy applications up to 959 in Q1 and may rise further; property foreclosures yet to pick up

site_title: China warns brokerages not to spread sensitive information
summary: China has warned domestic brokerages not to spread sensitive information, as part of a campaign to safeguard national security. Regulators have told analysts to prevent leaks and false information that can influence the market, and staff must confirm the legality and accuracy of obtained information. This comes as Beijing cracks down on perceived threats to national security, including raids on foreign consulting firms and limited access to financial data. The move is part of a broader crackdown on perceived threats to national security, amid growing tensions between China and the West.

site_title: EU lawmakers take first step towards AI curbs
summary: European Parliament lawmakers have taken a crucial step towards regulating artificial intelligence (AI) systems, including ChatGPT, in the EU. They voted for a position text calling for curbs on AI usage while fostering innovation. The text will be put to the full parliament next month for adoption before negotiations with EU member states on a final law. This move aims to address the potential risks and benefits of AI, following the recent surge in public awareness since ChatGPT's release at the end of last year.

images.alt_text: US tech giants and others involved in the joint venture can only have a minority stake, and employees that have access to EU data would have to undergo specific screening and have to be located in the 27-country bloc, the document said.

site_title: Emirates airline reports record 10.9 billion dirham annual profit
summary: Emirates airline reported a record annual profit of 10.9 billion dirhams ($3.9 billion) for the 2022-2023 financial year, marking a full recovery from pandemic-related losses. The airline's group revenue increased by 81% and filled 79.5% of seats flown, up from 58.6% the previous year. Emirates also committed $200 million to a research fund to reduce the impact of fossil fuels in commercial aviation.

site_title: China cuts second batch of 2023 fuel export quotas
summary: China has cut its second batch of 2023 fuel export quotas, focusing on domestic demand during the refinery overhaul season and boosting sales amid poor export margins. The reduced quotas, primarily allocated to state-owned refiners, amount to 9 million tonnes of refined products and 3 million tonnes of marine fuel. This decrease is a result of strong demand expectations for petrol and diesel in the peak summer season, as refiners stockpile products and prioritize domestic sales.

images.alt_text: ForwardKeys data shows domestic Chinese travel bookings on Apr 28 are up 233 per cent from the same time in 2019, while international departures are at 79 per cent of the 2019 level.

site_title: China's JD.com beats estimates for quarterly revenue
summary: JD.com beats Wall Street estimates for first-quarter revenue, driven by resilient demand for its e-commerce platform. Despite the lifting of Covid-19 related curbs, customer spending on online platforms remains high, benefiting e-commerce firms like JD.com and Alibaba Group. The company's US-listed shares rose nearly 4% in trading before the bell, following the earnings release.

images.alt_text: The Beijing-based company spun off its logistics unit into a standalone entity in 2017 and then opened up its delivery and warehousing services to third-party companies.

site_title: OCBC to issue A$1 billion of senior floating-rate green notes due 2026
summary: OCBC Bank has priced A$1 billion of senior floating-rate green notes due 2026 under its US$30 billion global medium term note program. The notes will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on May 19, 2023, and are expected to be rated "Aa1" by Moody's, "AA-" by S&P Global Ratings, and "AA-" by Fitch Ratings. The net proceeds will go towards financing or refinancing new or existing qualifying assets as described under the OCBC Sustainability Bond Framework.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
OCBC to issue on Aug 12 A$500m floating-rate green notes due 2024
Mapletree Business City on April 21, 2022.
Sembcorp prices S$400m green bonds due 2031 at 2.45%

site_title: Singapore backs status quo on Asean approach to Myanmar; others call for review
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong supports maintaining the status quo of inviting Myanmar to participate in Asean meetings on a non-political level, citing both symbolic and practical benefits. This stance is shared by some other Asean countries, but others, including Indonesia, have called for a review of the "five-point consensus" (5PC) aimed at resolving the crisis. Lee emphasized the importance of patience and consistency in policy-making, and Asean's unity and cooperation with external partners to address the crisis and promote regional integration.

A chair for a Myanmar representative is left unoccupied during a retreat session of the 42nd Asean Summit in Labuan Bajo, East Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia, May 11, 2023.
