site_title: Australia's trade minister seeks end to trade curbs on visit to Beijing
summary: Australia's Trade Minister Don Farrell arrived in Beijing on May 11, seeking to remove trade curbs and stabilize diplomatic relations. Farrell met with Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao, advocating for the full resumption of Australian exports to China, worth A$287 billion in 2022. The visit aims to cement the "important consensus" reached between the two heads of state at a G20 meeting last year. Farrell also plans to discuss human rights cases, including the detention of Australian journalist Cheng Lei. The visit marks the first time an Australian trade minister has visited China since 2019.

images.alt_text: Australian trade data shows exports worth A$60.5 million (S$50.3 million) of copper ore and concentrate to China in January.

site_title: Honda Aircraft appoints new sales representatives for private jet customers in Asean
summary: Honda Aircraft has appointed two new sales representatives, WingsOverAsia for Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Brunei, and Forth for Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam, to serve private jet customers in South-east Asia. This marks the first sales representative appointment in the region since 2017. The move aims to expand Honda Aircraft's presence in the growing South-east Asian business jet market, following its wholly-owned US-based subsidiary's appointment in Thailand in 2017.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Shell's British power retailer draws bids from three rivals: sources
summary: Shell's British power retailer, under review since January, has drawn bids from three rivals: Octopus Energy, Ovo, and British Gas. Octopus Energy and Ovo have progressed to the second round of bidding, while British Gas's bid status is unclear. The review was triggered by "tough market conditions" and poor returns. Shell declined to comment, while the bidders did not respond to requests for comment. The outcome will determine the future of Shell's UK retail business.

images.alt_text: A view shows a logo of Shell petrol station in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James

site_title: Saudi Aramco to postpone mega IPO of energy trading unit
summary: Saudi Aramco is delaying its planned initial public offering of its energy-trading business, a deal expected to be one of the world's largest share sales this year. The company has slowed down preparatory work and hasn't set a new timeline for the listing, which may be postponed until next year unless the market improves. The energy-trading business was initially valued at over $30 billion.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco is considering an initial public offering of its trading arm amid a boom in oil prices in what could be one of the world's biggest listings this year.

site_title: Nissan full-year results beat estimates, forecast bullish
summary: Nissan reported a net profit of 221 billion yen for the year to March 2023, beating its prediction of 220 billion yen. The company projected 315 billion yen for the coming year, driven by sales improvements and cost-cutting. Despite challenges from raw material price increases and semiconductor shortages, Nissan's CEO, Makoto Uchida, expressed cautious optimism about the company's business in China, citing the end of zero-Covid policies. Nissan's global sales for the year to March 2023 stood at 3.16 million units, up 5.4% from the previous year.

images.alt_text: The Ariya is supposed to be the first of 19 new battery EVs that Nissan has said it plans to roll out by 2030.
Honda chief executive Toshihiro Mibe acknowledged the automaker lagged Chinese rivals in some software technologies.

site_title: Pushing the envelope on classic folklore
summary: A Singapore theatre troupe, Wild Rice, and Melbourne-based Victorian Opera have adapted the Chinese folktale "The Butterfly Lovers" into an East-meets-West musical, exploring the story's homoerotic undertones. The opera, set during the Eastern Jin dynasty, follows two scholars, Zhu Yingtai and Liang Shanbo, as they navigate forbidden desire and ultimately tragic separation. Director Ivan Heng has taken a more risqué approach, parsing the nature of desire, while the music fuses Chinese and Western operatic traditions.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Ghafir Akbar (left) and Julie Wee as the king and queen of fairies Oberon and Titania respectively.
Brian Gothong Tan's stunning, surreal images were created using an AI tool. Like other artists in Singapore, Tan has been turning to AI for collaboration and inspiration.

site_title: Yellen says debt default would hurt US international leadership
summary: US Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen warned that a federal government default would spark a global downturn and undermine US global economic leadership, posing a risk to national security. A default could occur as the US reaches its $31.4 trillion borrowing limit, prompting special accounting measures to run out by June 1. Yellen suggested a long-term fix could be to repeal the debt ceiling or change the rules around it, requiring a supermajority in Congress to block the president from unilaterally raising the ceiling.

images.alt_text: epa10620333 US Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference prior to the start of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting in Niigata, northern Japan, 11 May 2023. The meeting starts on 11 through 13 May 2023.  EPA-EFE/KIMIMASA MAYAMA

site_title: 10 boxed wines that are really good, seriously
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The bag-in-box method of packaging wine is gaining popularity, driven by environmental concerns. The packaging is more efficient, with less waste and a longer shelf life. Many producers are now using boxes for easy-drinking wines, rather than aging wines. The category faces resistance from consumers and producers, but attitudes are softening due to the climate crisis. A growing number of producers, including Communal Brands and Jenny & François, are offering high-quality boxed wines. The article highlights 10 boxed wines that are worth trying, including Ryme Cellars, Neleman Valencia, and Caspri & Co.

images.alt_text: As the wine industry flagged in its commitment to black and brown communities, Jermaine Stone forged his own path.

site_title: South Korea's Hyundai to invest US$2.45 billion in Indian state
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to invest US$2.45 billion in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu over 10 years, focusing on electric vehicle production. The investment will support the setup of a battery pack assembly unit with an annual capacity of 178,000 units and the installation of 100 EV charging stations across the state within five years.

images.alt_text: Negotiations to sell Hyundai’s factories in Russia are in the final stage, adding that the automaker has been waiting for a final approval from the Russian government, media reported.

site_title: London has its best year for super-prime property since Brexit vote
summary: London's super-prime property market saw its best year since the Brexit vote in 2016, with 161 deals valued at £3.1 billion. The borough of Kensington led the sales with 26 properties, followed by Belgravia and Mayfair. This marks a significant recovery from the post-Brexit slump, with the highest number of super-prime deals since 2016.

images.alt_text: Rows of houses stand on Egerton Crescent in the Kensington and Chelsea borough of London, U.K., on Friday, Dec. 28, 2012. Egerton Crescent, close to Harrods luxury department store in Knightsbridge, is the most expensive address in the borough, with an average property value of 8.14 million pounds ($13.2 million), Lloyds TSB said. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Keppel Corp, Keppel Infrastructure Trust commit 4.7 million euros to buy wind farm in Sweden
summary: Keppel Corp and Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) jointly invest 4.7 million euros (S$6.9 million) in a 17-megawatt Swedish onshore wind farm, Fäbodliden II. The 16.3% stake will be split between Keppel (2.9%) and KIT (13.4%), with the remaining 70% owned by Kommunal Landspensjonskasse (KLP) and MEAG MUNICH ERGO Asset Management GmbH (MEAG) and Fred. Olsen Renewables AS (FORAS). The acquisition supports Keppel's 2030 goal to grow its renewable assets and contributes to KIT's green infrastructure exposure.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

A German offshore wind farm that Keppel has invested in. The floating hybrid renewable energy system in Singapore consists of integrating offshore floating solar panels with other renewable energy technologies.
The Indonesian Investment Authority is working with the Asian Development bank to fund the shutting of a coal power plant 10 to 15 years ahead of the end of its useful life.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as traders unmoved by US inflation data
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday as investors remained cautious despite US inflation data showing a slight decrease. The consumer price index reading, the lowest in two years, provided the Federal Reserve with some room to reassess its interest rate hike campaign. The uncertainty surrounding the US debt ceiling and ongoing trade talks with the US also weighed on markets. Despite the mixed signals, key Asian markets, including Tokyo, Sydney, and Singapore, fell, with some closing in the red.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul and Taipei all dropped on Wednesday, though Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta squeezed out gains.
Singapore stocks open little changed on Thursday; STI up 0.03%

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn's Q1 profit slumps 56%
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, reported a 56% plunge in Q1 net profit to T$12.8 billion (S$553 million) from T$29.45 billion in the same period last year. This is Foxconn's biggest quarterly fall in three years, largely due to global economic woes hurting demand for smart consumer electronics. The result was worse than the average forecast of T$29.18 billion in profit from 13 analysts.

images.alt_text: Foxconn has manufactured Apple handsets in India since 2019 at its plant in the southern state of Tamil Nadu.

site_title: AEM Q1 net profit falls 62% to S$15.6 million amid semiconductor slowdown
summary: AEM Holdings, a semiconductor equipment maker, reported a 62% decline in Q1 net profit to S$15.6 million due to a slowdown in the semiconductor industry. Revenue fell 41.7% to S$152.7 million. CEO Chandran Nair accelerated development of Test 2.0 solutions, expected to drive growth in the coming years. The company's revenue was boosted by a volume ramp-up in the previous year but has since tapered off.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The brokerage has revised its forecast earnings estimates for AEM upwards by 30 per cent for FY2023 as the company’s inventories and visibility improve.

“Many semiconductor companies operating in Singapore have manufacturing processes and products that rely on US technology, which may be subject to export controls imposed by the US government,” said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan.
Semiconductor equipment maker AEM on Friday reported second half-year earnings of S$44 million, down 30 per cent from S$62.4 million the previous year.

site_title: The triumphant return of Shakespeare In The Park
summary: Singapore Repertory Theatre's (SRT) production of A Midsummer Night's Dream, part of Shakespeare In The Park, has returned after a five-year hiatus with a modern twist. The production, directed by Guy Unsworth, features a post-pandemic, go-woke celebration with a gender-fluid fairy cast, hip-hop music, and Instagram-worthy production designs. The play, set in a modern oil rig, retains the original's romantic comedy, farcical humor, and magical elements, but with a contemporary spin. Despite its nearly three-hour runtime, the production is enjoyable and engaging, making up for lost time after its hiatus.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: European gas slips as stronger wind forecast adds to low demand
summary: European natural gas prices slid to the lowest level in almost 22 months, dropping over 50% this year, due to strong imports of liquefied natural gas and high fuel stockpiles. However, the possibility of abnormal heat and drought this summer poses a short-term risk. Wind generation in the UK is forecast to increase, adding to the already sluggish demand outlook, and traders are watching weather forecasts closely. Storage sites are filling up rapidly, creating a buyer's market, and European gas prices declined 0.9% to 34.68 euros per megawatt-hour.

images.alt_text: Companies qualifying for the subsidy would be reimbursed for electricity costs above 6 US cents per kilowatt-hour.

For this first tender, which covers deliveries expected between June 2023 and May 2024, 77 European companies have clubbed together with applications for a total volume of around 11.6 billion cubic metres of gas.

site_title: Biden’s reelection battle is political – but also financial
summary: US President Joe Biden is embarking on a fundraising trip for his 2024 re-election campaign, aiming to raise over $2 billion. The trip includes events with wealthy donors, including a $25,000-per-person reception hosted by Tony James. Biden's campaign faces challenges, including a recent poll showing 68% of Americans believe he is too old for a second term. The 2024 presidential election is expected to be the most expensive in US history, with total spending potentially exceeding $5.7 billion.

images.alt_text: The US has tried to limit Beijing’s access to high-end semiconductors and blacklisted Chinese companies for their ties to the military or over accusations that they use forced labour.

Oversight Committee Chair James Comer said Romanian funds were part of more than US$10 million that Hunter Biden (pictured), his family and business associates had received from deals with foreigners in China, Ukraine, and elsewhere while Joe Biden was vice-president from 2009 to 2017.
US President Joe Biden, House of Representatives Speaker Kevin McCarthy and the three other top congressional leaders are set to meet again on Friday.

E. Jean Carroll leaves a federal court house after the jury found that former US president Donald J. Trump was liable for sexually abusing and defaming her but not liable for raping her, New York, May 9, 2023.

While Republicans seek to lift the US$31.4 trillion borrowing limit only in combination with drastic spending cuts, President Joe Biden has refused to agree to such reductions – raising fears of the first national debt default.

site_title: Gold rush: MAS leads central banks in precious metal buys in Q1
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) led central banks in the world in buying gold in the first quarter of 2023, with a total of 69 tonnes added to its reserves, bringing its total to 222 tonnes. This represents a 45% increase from end-2022 and the largest single buyer during the quarter. Central bank gold buying led to a "blistering" start to 2023, with demand hitting 228 tonnes, the strongest first quarter on record.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
China has raised its gold holdings by about 8.09 tonnes in April, according to data from the State Administration of Foreign Exchange on Sunday (May 7).
The dollar index was up 0.1 per cent, making bullion less affordable for overseas buyers.
Bullion prices initially rose on Wednesday after US inflation data was released, before turning negative on profit-taking.

site_title: Singapore’s ABSD hike won’t be hurting these foreign buyers
summary: Singapore has increased the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for foreigners, but US, Icelandic, and Norwegian nationals are exempt due to respective free trade agreements. Foreigners now face a 60% ABSD rate, while US, Icelandic, and Norwegian buyers pay the same stamp duty treatment as Singapore citizens. Despite the increase, four US and four Chinese buyers purchased units at a recent condominium launch, suggesting the exemption may not significantly impact foreign buyers.

images.alt_text: ABSD rate will be raised from 30% to 35% for SPRs purchasing their 3rd and subsequent residential property;

The rarity of shophouses make it a valuable tool in wealth preservation, especially for high-net-worth individuals and family offices, said Richard Tan, PropNex senior associate group district director.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund loses more money despite tech stock rebound
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund lost 297.5 billion yen (S$2.9 billion) in the March quarter, despite a 20% rebound in tech stocks, due to losses on private startups in its portfolio. The fund's full-year loss reached a record 4.3 trillion yen. SoftBank is divesting assets and promoting Arm's IPO to clean up its balance sheet and appease investors. The company is also offloading Alibaba shares and selling its startup incubator to reduce its financing burden.

images.alt_text: Coupang’s core delivery business grew exponentially during the pandemic as people bought everything from eggs and masks to home appliances through apps.
The IPO registration shows that Softbank is pressing ahead with the blockbuster offering despite adverse market conditions, after saying in March that it planned to list Arm in the US stock market.

site_title: Thai central bank to relax rules on use of yuan for trade this year
summary: Thailand's central bank plans to relax rules on using the Chinese yuan for trade this year to reduce the impact of dollar fluctuations against the baht. The move aims to encourage exporters to use local currencies, particularly the yuan, to mitigate risks. The Bank of Thailand is in talks with China's central bank to promote the use of yuan for trade settlements. The use of yuan is expected to be manageable due to a swap line between the two countries, and its impact on the US dollar is unlikely to be significant in the short term.

site_title: UK housing market shows signs of downturn ending
summary: The UK housing market shows signs of a potential turnaround, with year-ahead sales expectations rising to a net balance of 3% in April from 1% a month earlier, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' (RICS) report. A lack of housing supply is helping to prop up the property market and drive rental costs higher, but experts warn that soaring interest rates and inflation continue to squeeze consumer spending power. Delivering more supply is critical to addressing affordability concerns, and the government is under pressure to loosen planning rules and increase construction.

images.alt_text: UK unitied kingdom house housing rent Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: China rate cut bets mount, treasury yields fall below key threshold
summary: China's 10-year benchmark yield fell below 2.7% as treasuries rose to a 15-month high, driven by downbeat inflation data and banks' plans to cut deposit rates. Consumer prices rose at the slowest pace in over two years, suggesting further monetary easing may be needed. The People's Bank of China is set to announce its medium-term lending facility rate on Monday, with expectations of a policy rate cut. Analysts believe a cut is becoming more likely, but policymakers may take a "wait and see" stance to assess economic momentum.

images.alt_text: The Chinese leader says planning for the transfer of financial institutions, research institutes and public institutions should begin immediately.
The People’s Bank of China, however, maintains substantial sway by setting a ceiling and floor for rates through the interest rate self-disciplinary body.

site_title: Truffle experience dinner for BT subscribers
summary: BT subscribers can experience a four-course dinner featuring French Périgord Black Winter Truffles harvested in Western Australia on June 1. The menu, curated by Chef Steven Loo, includes truffle croquettes, butternut pumpkin soup, truffle wild mushroom ragu fettuccine, and osmanthus glaze apricot dessert. 15 subscribers will win a pair of seats worth S$296++ each. The dinner is held at Edition Rooftop Bar and Restaurant in Singapore from 7pm-10pm.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Editor Chen Huifen (left) hosting a table of subscribers at the Meet the BT Newsroom dinner on Wednesday evening.

site_title: Hong Kong political cartoon axed after government pressure, cartoonist says
summary: Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper is scrapping a decades-long comic strip by prominent political cartoonist Wong Kei-kwan, known as Zunzi, after authorities complained about its satirical take on Hong Kong and Chinese politics. The move is seen as the latest blow to media freedom in the China-ruled city, where authorities have raided and shut down liberal media outlets and public broadcaster RTHK has toned down its coverage. The Hong Kong Journalists Association condemned the decision, stating that critical voices cannot be tolerated and freedom of speech has been further narrowed.

images.alt_text: Protesters have been required to wear number tags.
Chief Justice Andrew Cheung inspects a Ceremonial Guard mounted by the Hong Kong Police Force at the opening of the Legal Year in Hong Kong.

site_title: Three Arrows co-founder Zhu Su gets restraining order against BitMEX co-founder for harassment
summary: Zhu Su, co-founder of failed crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital, has been granted a restraining order against BitMEX co-founder Arthur Hayes for harassment. The order, dated May 5, prohibits Hayes from using threatening or abusive language towards Zhu or publishing his identity information. This comes as Zhu Su has been battling liquidators trying to recover assets for 3AC's creditors after the fund's collapse last summer.

images.alt_text: Dubai’s Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority (Vara) issued a written reprimand to Su Zhu and Kyle Davies, both Three Arrows founders, as well as OPNX’s two other co-founders and its chief executive, on Apr 18, according to a statement from the regulator.
Auctions and private sales of non-fungible tokens ( NFTs  ) in the “GRAILS” collection will kick off next month in New York.

site_title: Lower Tokyo office vacancies give relief to market after Covid
summary: Tokyo's office vacancy rate fell to 6.11% in April, the lowest since May 2021, offering temporary relief to landlords. The drop is attributed to the expansion and refurbishment of buildings, which removed some available space from the market. However, experts warn that vacancies may resume rising due to new building completions and muted demand. The US office market is struggling, with vacancy rates reaching record highs in Manhattan and downtown Toronto. Japan's low interest rates and healthy commercial property financing are expected to mitigate risks, making its market more resilient.

images.alt_text: Japan's household spending fell 1.9 per cent in March from a year earlier, against economists’ median forecast for a 0.4 per cent rise and following a 1.6 per cent gain in February.

site_title: Flash Coffee raises US$50 million in extended Series B round
summary: Flash Coffee raises US$50 million in an extended Series B round led by White Star Capital, with existing investors including Delivery Hero, Geschwister Oetker, and Conny & Co. The funds will be used to accelerate profitability and fuel expansion across the Asia-Pacific region. Flash Coffee aims to focus on technology and product innovation while improving sales performance of existing stores, with plans to launch in Surabaya, Indonesia in July 2023. The coffee chain has over 200 stores across Singapore, Jakarta, Bandung, Surabaya, Bangkok, Hong Kong, and Seoul.

images.alt_text: Flash Coffee
Benjamin Cher

site_title: Thai consumer confidence at more than 3-year high in April
summary: Thai consumer confidence reached a 38-month high in April, with a 11th consecutive month of increase, driven by tourism recovery and election-related spending. The University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce's consumer index rose to 55.0, despite concerns over high living costs. Foreign arrivals, particularly from China, have boosted the tourism sector, with 8.6 million visitors recorded in January-April. The government expects up to 30 million foreign tourists for the year.

site_title: Manulife US Reit’s occupancy falls to 86.1% as top tenant gives up a quarter of leased space
summary: Manulife US Reit's portfolio occupancy fell to 86.1% in Q1, down from 88% at end-December, due to top tenant The William Carter Company giving up 69,000 sq ft of space in its Atlanta headquarters. The company renewed its lease for 209,000 sq ft, extending the lease expiry to 2035. Despite this, the Reit faces leasing challenges and increasing debt costs. Its manager expects positive rental reversion for 2023 and has "substantially completed" due diligence on a potential deal with Mirae Asset Global Investments.

images.alt_text: MAS should set out its expectations of troubled Reits' managers and sponsor groups
RHB lowered its target price for Manulife US Reit to US$0.40 while maintaining its "buy" call, after the Reit divested its Tanasbourne office campus.
Manulife US Reit says that despite challenges in the Reit’s submarkets, portfolio occupancy remained stable at 88 per cent as at end-Dec, which was above the US Class A average of 83.3 per cent.

site_title: Man Group appoints first female CEO in 240 years
summary: Man Group, the world's largest publicly listed hedge fund firm, has appointed its first female CEO in 240 years, Robyn Grew. Grew, who is currently the firm's president, will take over from Luke Ellis on September 1. The appointment follows the firm's appointment of Anne Wade as its first female chairman in February. Grew has over 14 years of experience at the firm and will split her time between the UK and the US. The move marks a significant milestone for the industry, which still lags behind in terms of female representation, with women making up just 21.3% of employees globally.

images.alt_text: The swaps this week had their biggest increase since UBS Group agreed to buy Credit Suisse in an emergency weekend deal in March.

site_title: Hong Kong overnight funding costs surge to highest since 2007
summary: Hong Kong's overnight funding costs surged to a 16-year high, reaching 4.81% as the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) drains liquidity to boost the local dollar and reduce interbank liquidity. The move comes after the HKMA spent $6.5 billion since February to defend the dollar's peg with the US dollar. Despite the climb in Hibor rates, some analysts see signs of relief in the HKD liquidity squeeze, with resilient demand in the months ahead expected to ease outflow pressures.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A security guard walks past a directory board of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) in Hong Kong December 20, 2012. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu (CHINA - Tags: BUSINESS)/File Photo

site_title: Singapore banks post robust Q1 results, but NIMs look to have peaked
summary: Singapore banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC posted robust Q1 results, with UOB's net profit rising 67% to S$1.5 billion, DBS's net profit reaching a record S$2.6 billion, and OCBC's net profit up 39% to S$1.9 billion. However, their net interest margins (NIMs) appear to have peaked, with UOB's NIM moderating eight basis points quarter-on-quarter and OCBC's NIM falling by one basis point. The banks remain prudent ahead of rising credit quality risks and cut their guidance for loan growth for the year.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The decline in Great Eastern's total weighted new sales was due to lower single premium sales from the Singapore market, the group said.
Jenn Ong, head of credit products at GXS, said that there are still individuals that are thinly served by banks.
Analysts expect limited upside for NIM growth ahead, while rising recession risks may result in weaker loan growth and rising asset quality risks.

site_title: ING’s beats Q1 profit forecasts, launches share buyback
summary: ING, the largest Dutch bank, reported a better-than-expected first-quarter profit of 1.59 billion euros, driven by rising interest rates and modest risk costs. The bank also launched a 1.5 billion euro share buyback program. This follows a similar trend seen in other lenders, as major central banks increased interest rates to combat inflation. The bank's stable and diversified deposit base grew by 1.3 billion euros in the quarter, with CEO Steven van Rijswijk attributing the growth to clients' trust in the bank.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ING Bank logo is seen in this illustration taken March 12, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Xi urges financial institutions to move to new flagship city
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has urged financial institutions, research institutes, and public institutions to relocate to the new flagship city in Xiong'an New Area, a high-tech hub in Hebei province, about 100km southwest of Beijing. Xi emphasized the need for immediate planning, stating that state-owned enterprises and financial institutions should be the first to move. The Xiong'an New Area aims to become a major hub for China's financial and technological development.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China, however, maintains substantial sway by setting a ceiling and floor for rates through the interest rate self-disciplinary body.
China's consumer price index for the month rose 0.1 per cent year-on-year, slower than the 0.7 per cent annual gain seen in March, the National Bureau of Statistics said.

site_title: ‘50 shades of green’ needed for Asia’s energy transition: IPCC chair
summary: Developing Asia needs to accept "50 shades of green" as it transitions to renewable energy, tolerating banks with "browner" portfolios and green industries with "yellower" solutions. The region cannot simply replace coal with renewable energy due to its reliance on cheap and steady access to power for economic growth. Experts, including the IPCC chair, emphasize the need for tolerance and flexibility in transition finance, citing concerns from investors and financial institutions about the risks of stranded assets.

images.alt_text: While much focus has been placed on reducing carbon emissions, other serious environmental problems such as deforestation, water shortages and soil erosion should not be overlooked.
ADB said financing the infrastructure gap has gotten more challenging than before the pandemic, as debt levels are up, tax revenues down and public spending has ballooned.

site_title: Myanmar makes no progress on peace; Asean needs unity: Indonesia
summary: Indonesia, chair of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), stated that Myanmar's ruling military has made no meaningful progress in implementing a peace plan agreed to two years ago. The 5-point consensus, or 5PC, aims to de-escalate violence in Myanmar, where the army has been fighting ethnic minority insurgents and pro-democracy fighters since 2021. Indonesia called for Asean unity to decide on the next steps, amid disagreement among member states on how to address the crisis.

site_title: Latest 6-month Singapore T-bill offers 3.78% cut-off yield
summary: Singapore's latest 6-month Treasury bill (T-bill) closed its auction with a cut-off yield of 3.78% on May 11, down from 3.83% in the previous auction. The latest tranche was 2.4 times subscribed, receiving S$12 billion in applications for the S$5 billion on offer, an increase from the previous tranche's S$11.1 billion. Non-competitive bids were fully allotted, while competitive bids at the cut-off yield were allotted around 23% of applications. Demand has fallen since Singapore's T-bills hit a 30-year high in December.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
For the 6-month T-bills’ yield to break past its glorious 4.4 per cent record, a sharp spike in inflation will be needed to drive interest rates higher.
Savvy investors have been applying to invest their CPF savings – particularly OA funds with lower yields – with many opting for Singapore Treasury bills.
The latest tranche of Singapore Savings Bond is offering a first-year interest rate of 2.81 per cent, and a 10-year average return of 2.82 per cent.
Demand for the latest six-month T-bill and Singapore Savings Bond fell, according to data released on Wednesday.

site_title: Italy's antitrust watchdog probes Apple over alleged app market abuse
summary: Italy's antitrust agency AGCM has opened a probe into Apple for alleged abuse of its dominant position in the app market. The watchdog claims Apple imposed more restrictive privacy policies on third-party app developers than on itself, giving them less data and visibility, which may harm non-Apple apps and drive competitors away. This could benefit Apple's internal apps, devices, and iOS operating system. The AGCM's investigation is under European Union competition law, which could result in a fine of up to 10% of Apple's annual turnover.

site_title: SingPost reviewing commercial sustainability of domestic postal business as FY2023 profit plunges 70.3%
summary: SingPost, Singapore's national postal service provider, is reviewing the commercial sustainability of its domestic postal business amid a 70.3% plunge in FY2023 profit to S$34.6 million. The company delivered 28% lower earnings for the second half of FY2023, with a S$3.8 million operating loss in the post and parcel business. A final dividend of S$0.004 per share is recommended, subject to shareholder approval. The move comes as delivery volumes fell and operational costs rose due to inflationary pressures.

Tay Peck Gek
Two electric motorbikes serving selected areas in Districts 9 and 10 will be used for three months during the trial, SingPost said.
SingPost Centre’s overall occupancy stands at 98.7 per cent as at end-2022.

site_title: China asks state banks to cut deposit rate ceilings from May 15
summary: China has asked state banks to lower deposit rate ceilings to 1.25-1.35% from May 15, a move aimed at reducing lenders' funding costs and supporting the country's economy. The move, which is a drop of 40-55 basis points, will benefit medium and small banks but have a limited impact on big lenders. The decision follows recent deposit rate cuts in early May and last year, and aims to alleviate pressure on banks to balance shrinking margins and government directives to boost lending support.

images.alt_text: More than 625,000 mainland Chinese arrived during the five-day “Golden Week”, though that was only two-thirds of the number of visitors during the same period before the pandemic closed down travel.

Residential and commercial buildings stand in the Pudong area of Shanghai, China, on Saturday, Feb. 2, 2013. site_title: UBS scrutinises Credit Suisse’s Asia loans in risk appraisal
summary: UBS is scrutinizing Credit Suisse's high-risk Asian loans, including those in Indonesia, Vietnam, Malaysia, and India, amid concerns about lending relationships and potential asset runoff or sale. The move comes after a series of scandals and risk management failures at Credit Suisse, including a failed investment in Luckin Coffee. UBS has sent a "clean team" to assess client rosters and talent, and is considering options to address the issues, including selling parts of the Asia credit book to private debt firms or unwinding the loans.

images.alt_text: Ulrich Koerner, chief executive officer of Credit Suisse Group AG, during a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Tuesday, March 14, 2023. UBS is studying plans to sell the Swiss banking business of Credit Suisse in an initial public offering (IPO) after taking over its smaller rival, the sources say.

site_title: Credit Suisse CDS surge as hedge funds see potential trigger
summary: Swaps insuring Credit Suisse debt have surged 85 basis points to 360 basis points, the largest increase since UBS Group's emergency acquisition in March. Hedge funds, including FourSixThree Capital and Diameter Capital Partners, are buying these swaps, arguing that Credit Suisse's subordinated bond write-down should trigger them. Despite no submissions to the Credit Derivatives Determinations Committee, traders at JPMorgan Chase have discussed the possibility of a trigger with clients, fueling trading in the swaps.

images.alt_text: UBS is in a race to understand the risk it’s taking on at Credit Suisse after a series of scandals and risk management failures in the years running up to the smaller firm’s collapse.

site_title: South Korea to drop mandatory 7-day quarantine for Covid-19 patients from June
summary: South Korea has lowered its crisis level for Covid-19 from 4 to 3, dropping mandatory 7-day quarantine requirements for infected individuals starting June. Health authorities will still recommend 5 days of self-isolation, while mask mandates at medical facilities and pharmacies will be dropped, except at hospitals with patient wards. President Suk Yeol Yoon expressed relief that people can resume normal life after three years and four months. The move comes after the World Health Organization declared an end to the global Covid-19 emergency status in January 2020.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment Q1 fee income-related business revenue down 3% to S$255 million
summary: CapitaLand Investment's fee income-related business revenue declined 3% to S$255 million in Q1 2023, driven by lower performance fees. Excluding these fees, revenue would have increased 10%. The lodging management segment saw a 42% rise in revenue per available unit, driven by the recovery of tourism. In contrast, revenue from its real estate investment business rose 11% to S$447 million. The company will continue to focus on launching new renminbi and US dollar funds.

The data centre development projects are expected to be completed in 2025 and will deliver over 100 megawatts (MW) of power.

site_title: China inflation grows at slowest rate in over two years
summary: China's inflation rate rose 0.1% year-on-year in April, the slowest rate since 2021, as food prices increased 0.4% and producer prices fell for the seventh consecutive month due to sluggish demand and lower commodity costs. This signals a weak recovery after lifting pandemic curbs. China's CPI is expected to remain soft in May, with analysts citing elevated unemployment and subdued fuel prices. In contrast, US consumer prices rose 4.9% in April, as the Federal Reserve hikes rates to tame escalating prices.

images.alt_text: The deficiencies are so great that auditors fail to obtain sufficient evidence to substantiate companies’ financial statements, PCAOB chair Erica Williams says.

site_title: Hot stock: Heavy trading in The Place Holdings amid talks to sell 11% stake in Realty Centre site
summary: The Place Holdings' shares surged 33.3% on Thursday after the group announced talks to sell up to 11% of its stake in New Vision Holding, the entity that owns the land and building formerly known as Realty Centre. The sale is expected to yield S$8.8 million, 13.6% of the company's market capitalization. The shares were trading at a near two-month high, and the counter was the most actively traded by volume. The proposed transaction is part of The Place Holdings' strategy to focus on its digital technology businesses.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

PROPERTY management and media company The Place Holdings has proposed to buy a 51 per cent stake each in 2 companies that are involved in the operations of an LED sky screen in Beijing, China, for an aggregate consideration of around S$47 million.

site_title: Robinhood beats revenue estimates as rate hikes bolster interest income
summary: Robinhood exceeded Wall Street estimates for first-quarter revenue, with net interest revenue nearly quadrupling to $208 million, driven by the US Federal Reserve's rapid rate hikes. The company reported a loss of 57 cents per share, beating analysts' average estimate, and plans to launch 24-hour trading for five days a week. Despite a decline in monthly active users to 11.8 million and a 5% decrease in transaction-based revenue, the company's revenue surpassed expectations at $441 million.

images.alt_text: Robinhood also agreed in principle last year to settle a proposed class action lawsuit filed by customers over the pandemic outages.
While Robinhood has been introducing new features, including retirement accounts and crypto wallets, it still earns roughly half of its revenue from trading.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange poised to propose trading during typhoons
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is preparing to propose allowing trading during typhoons and rainstorms, a move to ease concerns about the impact of extreme weather on the market. The proposal, which is still under discussion, aims to allow trading as normal despite the risks, with support from the Securities and Futures Commission and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. This would mark a departure from Hong Kong's traditional practice of suspending trading during extreme weather, which has been in place since the 1960s.

images.alt_text: HKEX’s profit increase comes as challenging macroeconomic conditions have continued to impact capital markets.
IPO applicants will also have to disclose material ESG information in their prospectuses.

site_title: Gold edges higher as dollar slips; US Fed outlook in focus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $2,032.48 per ounce, driven by a softer US dollar and slowing US inflation data, which may prompt the US Federal Reserve to pause interest rate hikes next month. The dollar index slipped 0.1%, making gold more affordable for overseas buyers. Markets now price in a 99% chance of the Fed holding rates steady in June.

images.alt_text: Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation, rising interest rates dull non-yielding bullion’s appeal.

site_title: Frasers Property H1 profit up 52.2% to S$197.2 million on residential development contributions
summary: Frasers Property's first-half earnings rose 52.2% to S$197.2 million, driven by higher contributions from residential developments. Group revenue increased 15.6% to S$1.9 billion, with Singapore's residential business benefiting from a buoyant market. The company will continue to manage its residential pipeline prudently, while monitoring older properties and optimizing its current portfolio. Despite a weak share price, the group remains positive on the long-term outlook for the residential sector, citing low inventory and strong credit profiles.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Chong Xin Wei

Frasers Property's recent purchase of a stake in Nex may not add value to its shareholders.

site_title: UK financial fraudsters made off with over £1.2 billion in 2022
summary: UK financial fraudsters stole over £1.2 billion in 2022, with authorised and unauthorised fraud totalling £1.8 billion. Unauthorised payments, primarily from stolen card details, totalled £727 million, while authorised fraud accounted for £485 million, including £114 million lost to investment scams. The ongoing cost-of-living crisis has led to increased use of fake investment opportunities and cheap deals to secure personal details. Online platforms are urged to do more to prevent fraudsters from operating on their platforms.

site_title: Philippine economic growth beats expectations amid inflation and rate hikes
summary: The Philippine economy expanded 6.4% in the first quarter, beating expectations, driven by strong post-pandemic demand. This growth supports the government's target of 6-7% full-year growth. Despite elevated inflation and monetary tightening, the economy defied expectations, with consumption growth slowing from a year ago. The growth is seen as a promising start to 2023, according to National Economic and Development Authority Secretary Arsenio Balisacan.

images.alt_text: Philippines' consumer price index rose 6.6 per cent in April from a year earlier, marking the slowest pace of increase since August, and was below the 7.0 per cent forecast in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Bank of England poised to raise rates again to tackle stubborn inflation
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise borrowing costs for the 12th consecutive meeting to tackle stubbornly high inflation, which stands at double the US level and much higher than the eurozone. The benchmark rate is expected to reach 4.5% and may continue to rise, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a peak of 5% in August. The central bank aims to curb inflation, which has been above 10% and pay growth far above its historical average, and will likely revise up its forecast for the economy in 2023.

images.alt_text: The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) said its measure of new buyer enquiries fell to a net balance of -37 in last month from -30 in March, the lowest since January.

The National Institute of Economic and Social Research estimated annual consumer price inflation will be 5.4 per cent in the final quarter of 2023 – well above forecasts from the Bank of England and the government’s budget watchdog.

site_title: Microsoft will not give employees salary raise this year: Insider
summary: Microsoft will not give employees a salary raise this year, citing "very different" economic conditions, according to CEO Satya Nadella. The tech giant has also reduced its budget for bonuses and stock awards. This decision comes after Microsoft laid off 10,000 workers in January, as the company focuses on generating revenue from its generative AI investments, including its collaboration with OpenAI.

site_title: British home-buyers, facing higher interest rates, retreat in April: RICS
summary: British homebuyers have retreated in April due to higher interest rates, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reporting a net balance of -37 for new buyer enquiries, the lowest since January. This drop in demand comes ahead of the Bank of England's expected interest rate increase, which is expected to take borrowing costs to 4.5% from 4.25%. Despite this, the RICS house price balance rose to -39 in April, slightly above economists' forecasts, and most surveyors noted an improvement in the market, with a pick-up in properties on the market.

images.alt_text: Shoppers and red London buses on Oxford Street in central London, UK, on Thursday, Feb. 16, 2023. The UK’s inflation rate slowed for a third month but remained stubbornly in double digits five times above the Bank of England’s targeted level. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg
The NHS remains plagued by strikes as health workers protest over wages that have failed to keep pace with rampant inflation

The Bank of England has forecast price rises will slow by the end of this year, but British households are currently contending with the highest inflation in western Europe, running at 10.1 per cent in March.

site_title: Singapore stocks open little changed on Thursday; STI up 0.03%
summary: Singapore stocks opened slightly up on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 0.03% to 3,423.11. Marine engineering group Seatrium was the top traded counter by volume, while gaming and resorts developer Genting Singapore saw its share price increase 0.9%. The US indices were mostly up after the release of US consumer price index data, which missed expectations slightly. The European Stoxx 600 closed 0.4% lower, but weathered expected losses due to US inflation.

site_title: Oil drops 1% after US data points to further rate hikes
summary: Oil prices fell by over 1% on Wednesday, with Brent crude dropping $1.03 to $76.41 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling $1.15 to $72.56 a barrel. The decline follows US economic data suggesting further interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, potentially impacting consumer prices and oil demand.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco cut its official selling prices for all crude grades to Asia for June-loading cargoes amid lower refining margins.
Brent crude settled 43 cents, or 0.6 per cent higher, at US$77.44 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude closed up 55 cents, or 0.8 per cent, at US$73.71.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust Q1 distributable income grows 2.5% to S$9.1 million
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust reported a 2.5% year-on-year increase in distributable income to S$9.1 million in Q1. Net property income rose 0.1% to S$11.3 million, while gross rental income gained 5.3%. The trust's weighted average lease expiry is 6.9 years, and portfolio occupancy remains at 98.6%. The manager plans to increase its supply of properties in Japan, particularly in Greater Tokyo, driven by demand from third-party logistics and e-commerce companies. Aggregate leverage rose slightly to 36.2%.

site_title: GIC seen as frontrunner for 2 billion euros stake in Germany’s Messer
summary: GIC is seen as the frontrunner to buy a 20% stake in German industrial gas maker Messer, with a deal potentially valuing the company at over $10 billion. GIC is in talks to inject $2 billion into Messer in exchange for the stake. EQT was also shortlisted but remains interested in the deal. The investment would be a significant move for GIC, and the deal's details are expected to be finalized in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: GIC is one of the top shareholders of Pagaya, which went public in June 2022.
Sovereign wealth fund GIC will acquire about half of Works Human’s shares, Nikkei said, with the rest held by Works Human executives and a new fund to be established by Bain Capital.
Stripe emphasised that it “does not need this capital to run its business”.

site_title: EU decision clearing US$69 billion Microsoft, Activision deal expected May 15, sources say
summary: EU antitrust regulators are expected to clear Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision on May 15, after the company agreed to licensing deals with cloud streaming rivals including Nvidia, Boosteroid, and Ubitus. This decision comes nearly three weeks after the UK competition authority blocked the deal due to concerns over competition in cloud gaming. The EU's clearance marks a significant milestone in the acquisition process.

site_title: Google to revamp search with generative AI tools, but gradually
summary: Google has introduced a new, experimental search engine in "Search Labs" that uses large language models and generative AI tools to answer users' queries conversationally. The update is being rolled out gradually to a waitlist of users, with certain features potentially graduating to the main search engine. Google aims to assess the impact on its search advertising business while addressing ethical concerns surrounding generative AI. The company is taking a risk-averse approach, insulating itself from potential harms and setting clear expectations for users.

Sonos alleges Google infringed two of its patents related to multi-room wireless audio, such as Google Home.

site_title: Disney shares slip as streaming losses narrow but some subscribers leave
summary: Disney's quarterly earnings met Wall Street expectations, with a narrowed streaming loss of $400 million and $21.82 billion in revenue. However, the company lost 4 million subscribers to reach 157.8 million, with most losses coming from Disney+ Hotstar in India. CEO Bob Iger announced plans to expand the streaming offerings with a new app combining Disney+ and Hulu, and an ad-supported option for Disney+ in Europe. The company's theme parks saw growth, with operating income increasing 23% to $2.2 billion.

Amazon MGM Studios Distribution will make the programming available to rent or buy on other services and on aeroplanes.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, CapitaLand Investment, Frasers Property, SingPost
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) plans to redeem half of its mandatory convertible bonds issued in 2021 as part of its balance sheet recalibration post-pandemic. CapitaLand Investment saw an 11% rise in Q1 revenue to S$447 million, while Frasers Property posted a 52.2% increase in net profit to S$197.2 million. Singapore Post declined 28% in its Q2 net profit, and UMS Holdings' Q1 profit fell 10% to S$17.4 million. Other companies reported mixed results, with Civmec and Daiwa House Logistics Trust flat, and Manulife US Reit and Prime US Reit experiencing declines.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall after sticky US inflation, upbeat earnings cap losses
summary: European stocks fell 0.4% on Wednesday as the US inflation data showed no signs of easing, indicating the Federal Reserve may keep interest rates high. Despite this, upbeat corporate earnings helped limit losses. The Stoxx 600 index briefly turned positive earlier in the day after the US CPI data showed a slight annual decrease in April. The market's reaction was largely driven by the mixed signals from the US economy.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.1 per cent lower at 33,531.33 on Thursday.

site_title: Digibank GXS entering consumer loans market at inopportune time
summary: Digibank GXS, a digital bank in Singapore, has launched its first credit product, a flexible loan offering with interest rates starting from 3.8% per annum. However, the margin on its offering is slim, with a spread of 32 basis points, compared to the 383 basis points of the country's largest bank, DBS. The digital bank's clean balance sheet may reassure depositors, but it faces challenges in building its asset base in the retail segment, and competition for deposits is returning, with interest rates expected to remain high.

Jenn Ong, head of credit products at GXS, said that there are still individuals that are thinly served by banks.
MariBank is only offering a savings account for now, with an interest rate of 2.5 per cent credited daily.

site_title: Just how good can China get at AI?
summary: China's AI advancements are rapidly closing the gap with the US, surpassing America in AI paper citations in 2019 and having 26% of global AI conference publications. However, China lags behind in "foundation models," the brainchild of OpenAI, which power generative AIs like ChatGPT. China's data, hardware, and expertise shortages are major hurdles, with the US imposing export controls on key technologies. Despite these challenges, Chinese AI labs have shown potential in developing their own models, and open-source models could provide a workaround. Ultimately, it's unclear whether China will be able to catch up, but the US's ability to diffuse cutting-edge innovation throughout its economy may give it an edge.

images.alt_text: Chatbots in China mostly focus on social interactions whereas ChatGPT, which learns from vast amounts of data how to answer prompts by users in a human-like manner, performs better at more professional tasks.
Microsoft has gone the furthest in pushing out generative AI to consumers and has pledged to pump billions of dollars into OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT.
Baidu is regarded as at the forefront of efforts to create a Chinese rival to the AI platform developed by OpenAI and backed by Microsoft.
The viral success of ChatGPT has turned the spotlight on artificial intelligence (AI) on Wall Street.

site_title: Republicans allege Biden family earned millions from shady overseas deals
summary: Republicans allege that the Biden family earned over $10 million from shady overseas deals while Joe Biden was vice-president from 2009 to 2017. Oversight Committee Chair James Comer claims that Romanian funds were part of these deals, totaling $1 million tied to a business deal with a Romanian tycoon in 2014-2015. The deal was allegedly orchestrated by Hunter Biden's business partner, Rob Walker.

images.alt_text: Against a basket of currencies, the US dollar index edges up 0.14 per cent to 101.76.
US President Joe Biden, House of Representatives Speaker Kevin McCarthy and the three other top congressional leaders are set to meet again on Friday.

E. Jean Carroll leaves a federal court house after the jury found that former US president Donald J. Trump was liable for sexually abusing and defaming her but not liable for raping her, New York, May 9, 2023.

site_title: OpenAI CEO to testify in US Senate next week amid questions about technology
summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman will testify before the US Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Privacy, Technology & the Law on May 16, addressing concerns about regulating artificial intelligence. This is Altman's first Congressional testimony, following a White House meeting on AI. Other witnesses include IBM's chief privacy officer, Christina Montgomery. The hearing aims to oversee and illuminate AI's advanced algorithms and powerful technology, with Sen. Richard Blumenthal stating that AI urgently needs rules and safeguards to address its immense promise and pitfalls.

site_title: US business lobby backs Biden China efforts while urging caution
summary: The US business lobby group, US Chamber of Commerce, urged the Biden administration to take "targeted and responsible steps" to restrict Chinese access to sensitive technologies while cautioning against viewing all interactions as a threat. The group supports efforts to strengthen national security, but also notes that many transactions between the US and China create opportunities for US small businesses and improve Americans' standard of living. The administration aims to "de-risk" and not "decouple" from Beijing, with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stating a full separation would be "disastrous" for both countries.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping has repeatedly stressed the need for self-reliance in technology to prune use of foreign technology.
Barring the Big Four could also hurt Chinese businesses, as an audit by a global firm lends credibility to their books on an international stage.

site_title: Global luxury home prices fall for first time since 2009
summary: Global luxury home prices fell 0.4% year-over-year in the first quarter, marking the first decline since 2009, according to Knight Frank. The biggest slump was seen in New Zealand's housing market, with luxury home prices in Wellington, Auckland, and Christchurch falling by double digits. Despite this, many cities, including Dubai and Miami, saw double-digit price increases. Experts attribute the slowdown to higher interest rates and global monetary policy tightening, but note that the decline is less severe than during the 2009 financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Miami is attracting plenty of wealthy investors, including Citadel’s Ken Griffin.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly rise as inflation cools slightly
summary: US stocks rose mostly on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 adding 0.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 1.0%, despite a 0.1% decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The consumer price index rose 4.9% in April, slightly lower than March's 5.0% figure, which may be enough to halt additional rate hikes. However, concerns over a US debt ceiling impasse and individual company performances, such as Alphabet's 4% gain and Airbnb's 10.9% drop, tempered gains.

site_title: Citigroup nears US$7 billion sale of Banamex unit to Grupo Mexico
summary: Citigroup is nearing a deal to sell most of its Banamex retail operations to Grupo Mexico for approximately US$7 billion. The Mexican conglomerate's shares dropped, while Citigroup will retain a portion of the unit with the option to later sell it or list it on public markets. This sale is part of Citigroup's efforts to dispose of its Mexican consumer, small-business, and middle-market banking divisions.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand also hired Hideto Yamada from Japan’s Government Pension Investment Fund, as a managing director in the country.

The number of new clients who joined Citi’s Private Bank in the region have doubled in the first quarter from a year ago, with new private banking assets growing 20 per cent year on year, according to a Citi spokesperson.

site_title: UK’s Sunak may fall short on 2023 inflation goal: NIESR
summary: The UK's inflation rate is expected to exceed 5.4% by the end of 2023, according to the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR), missing Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's goal to halve inflation this year. The forecast is higher than the Bank of England's 3.9% projection and the government's budget watchdog's 2.9% prediction. The NIESR predicts full-year consumer price inflation will be 7.4% in 2023 and 3.9% in 2024, with the Bank of England expected to raise interest rates to 4.5% later this week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A employee walks inside a Sainsbury’s supermarket in Richmond, west London, Britain, June 27, 2022. Picture taken June 27, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Binance’s crypto market share likely fell after zero-fee trading halt
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, has likely lost market share after removing zero-fee trading on certain pairs in March. Its spot market share has fallen to around 50%, the lowest since April 2022, according to senior research analyst Dessislava Ianeva. This decline is attributed to a regulatory crackdown on the cryptocurrency universe and institutions taking a wait-and-see approach, with some Korean exchanges seeing upticks in trading volumes. Binance's spot trading volume dropped 48% to $287 billion in April, its second-lowest monthly trading volume since 2021.

images.alt_text: Binance on Sunday halted Bitcoin withdrawals for about 90 minutes, blaming congestion on the token’s blockchain.

The inquiry by the Justice Department’s national security division is looking at whether Binance or company officials ran afoul of sanctions related to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, according to five people familiar with the matter who asked not to be named discussing a confidential investigation.

site_title: Google answers ChatGPT challenge with Bard expansion
summary: Google has expanded its Bard AI platform to 180 countries, aiming to compete with Microsoft's ChatGPT. The move is part of Google's efforts to integrate generative AI across its platform, including its leading search engine. CEO Sundar Pichai stated that Google has been applying AI for a while, but generative AI marks the next step. This expansion comes as Microsoft has rapidly integrated ChatGPT-like powers into various products, including the Bing search engine, in an attempt to catch up with Google.
