French startup Emobot has created a bot that uses AI to track the emotional state of the elderly to detect depression, anxiety and other mental health concerns.
Google describes Bard as an experiment allowing collaboration with generative AI, technology that relies on past data to create rather than identify content.

site_title: Blackstone, PNC, Apollo among 20 firms that bid for SVB assets
summary: At least 20 firms, including Blackstone, PNC Financial Services Group, and Apollo Global Management, bid for assets of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) after its collapse. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) disclosed the names of unsuccessful bidders and terms offered, but did not reveal which institution made each bid. The FDIC received 10 submissions for deposits, asset purchases, and pools of assets, as well as 10 additional bids for SVB's private bank. The high level of competition underscores the interest in acquiring SVB's assets.

images.alt_text: By seizing and selling First Republic Bank, the US government’s efforts may have stabilised the situation somewhat for now but it is far too early to declare victory.

Goldman Sachs has been criticised over its multiple roles with Silicon Valley Bank, in which it was both advising the California bank and purchasing distressed debt in a deal that ultimately played a central role in SVB’s collapse.

site_title: Telcos draw up proposal for charging Big Tech for EU 5G rollout
summary: European telecom operators have drafted a proposal requiring leading technology companies, such as Google, Apple, and Amazon, to contribute to funding 5G and broadband roll-out in the EU. The proposal, submitted to the European Commission, aims to address the issue of these companies' significant impact on internet traffic, accounting for over 50% of data internet traffic. The proposed threshold for companies to contribute is 5% of an operator's yearly average busy hour traffic, ensuring only large traffic generators are required to pay.

images.alt_text: Platforms like Amazon, Alibaba or Zalando would have to ensure goods sold online comply with all customs obligations.

site_title: Two-day conference to encourage SMEs to use AI and digital tools
summary: A two-day conference, Support SMB 2023, will be held in Singapore on May 16-17 to encourage small and medium businesses (SMBs) to adopt artificial intelligence (AI) and digital tools. The event will feature over 50 exhibitors, 20 breakout sessions, and 10 masterclasses, discussing ways to drive sustainable growth, ensure cyber and financial security, and harness AI for innovation. Organizers aim to provide SMBs with essential tools and insights to thrive in a digital-first environment, with about 5,000 participants expected to attend.

images.alt_text: One way for SMEs to cope with rising costs is to innovate by tapping existing government grants to adopt the digitalisation and subsequent automation of certain back-end functions.
Within Asean, Singapore ranks at the top of countries for businesses to venture into in their overseas expansion plans, while Thailand and Malaysia tie for second place.

site_title: Keong Hong narrows H1 net loss to S$3.7 million on pickup in construction activity
summary: Keong Hong Holdings reported a narrowed net loss of S$3.7 million for its half-year ended March 31, 2023, from S$10.8 million in the previous year. Revenue more than doubled to S$118.1 million, driven by progress in ongoing construction projects and increased productivity. Loss per share decreased to 1.58 Singapore cents, while no dividend was declared. Shares closed flat at S$0.35 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

site_title: Why the West’s revitalisation is well underway
summary: The West's revitalisation as a political and economic force has gained momentum, particularly since Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The G7's unified response has renewed confidence, despite the ongoing conflict's uncertain outcome. Western ministers have discussed various issues, including climate change and the world economy, but Ukraine remains the top priority. The West's revival is also driven by the need for transatlantic cooperation to address challenges from Russia and China. Key challenges include acknowledging the limitations of the old liberal order and exploring a new Western-led approach to global governance, including a revised international trade system.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Flags are pictured during the first working session of G-7 foreign ministers in Muenster, Germany, November 3, 2022.  REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/Pool/File Photo
Brokered by the United Nations (UN) and Turkey, the deal was signed in Istanbul last July, allowing Ukraine to export more than 27 million tonnes of grain from several of its Black Sea ports.

Japan's Economy, Trade and Industry minister Yasutoshi Nishimura (L) speaking in Tokyo at the Apr 4 meeting of the 2023 G7 trade ministers, during which economic security, including export controls, was raised.

site_title: Microsoft to buy power from nuclear fusion company Helion
summary: Microsoft has entered a deal with private US nuclear fusion company Helion Energy to purchase power from its plant, expected to be online by 2028. The agreement aims to advance the market for clean energy and demonstrate commercial-scale fusion. Helion's plant will generate 50 megawatts of power, enough to supply 1,000 US homes, and revenue will be used to develop more power plants and bring fusion to the grid faster. The deal is seen as a vote of confidence in Helion's technology, which could one day help slash emissions linked to climate change.

site_title: Citi acquisition to raise proportion of higher-margin unsecured lending in UOB’s consumer business
summary: UOB's acquisition of Citi's consumer portfolio is expected to double income contributions from its unsecured lending business by the end of 2023, growing to 27-30% of total income. The portfolio, valued at S$1 billion, will bring in revenue and increase the bank's presence in Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, and Vietnam. UOB aims to become the top foreign bank in each market and complement local banks. The acquisition will also enable the bank to roll out cross-regional offerings and partnerships.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
UOB attributed the strong Q1 performance to growth across its wholesale, global markets and retail businesses.
At UOB's annual general meeting, chief risk officer Chan Kok Seong said that ultimately, it is the level of trust and confidence in the bank that will ensure its long-term survival.
UOB declared a dividend of S$0.75 per share for the period, up from S$0.60 in H2 2021.

site_title: EU launches first tender for joint gas purchases
summary: The European Union launched its first international tender for joint gas purchases, covering deliveries from June 2023 to May 2024, with 77 European companies applying for a total volume of around 11.6 billion cubic meters of gas. This move aims to secure supplies amid Russia's war on Ukraine, with the EU seeking the best price to fill storage ahead of winter and avoid record price spikes.

images.alt_text: Russia is no longer the key supplier of liquefied natural gas and natural gas to Europe.

site_title: Manchester City owner risks EU scrutiny over Abu Dhabi money
summary: Manchester City's owner, Sheikh Mansour, risks EU scrutiny over Abu Dhabi's funding of City Football Group (CFG), which owns multiple clubs globally. CFG's business model aims to reduce costs and boost revenue by sharing resources. However, Belgian club Royal Excelsior Virton has filed a complaint with the European Commission, alleging that CFG's takeover of its rival gave it an unfair advantage. The complaint could be the first test of the EU's Foreign Subsidies Regulation, set to take effect on July 12.

site_title: Malaysia to lift export ban on renewable energy in accelerated transition plans
summary: Malaysia is lifting a ban on exports of renewable energy as part of its efforts to develop its clean-power industry and boost generation from non-fossil fuel sources. The ban, imposed in 2021, was intended to encourage local industry development. Minister of Economy Rafizi Ramli stated that lifting the ban will help firms build renewable-power generation capacity and capitalize on high demand from neighboring Singapore. This move aims to accelerate Malaysia's transition to a more sustainable energy sector.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo welcomes Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to the 42nd Asean Summit in Labuan Bajo, Indonesia.
With the US Senate’s 56-41 vote, the measure now heads to President Joe Biden, who has vowed to veto it and preserve the tariff moratorium he established that runs through early June 2024.
The Dalat Photovoltaic Base in Ordos city, China, April 2023.

site_title: China audits littered with deficiencies, US accounting watchdog finds
summary: A US accounting watchdog found significant deficiencies in audits of US-listed Chinese companies performed by KPMG in China and PricewaterhouseCoopers in Hong Kong. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) found that auditors failed to obtain enough evidence to substantiate companies' financial statements, citing a lack of quality controls. The PCAOB has given the two auditors a year to remediate the issues and will make referrals to its enforcement team if necessary, potentially leading to monetary penalties or exclusion from US exchanges.

site_title: Telkom sees 5 trillion rupiah in savings from Indihome-Telkomsel merger; will target higher-value customers
summary: Telkom Indonesia expects to save up to 5 trillion rupiah annually from the merger between its fixed broadband arm, Indihome, and mobile network operator Telkomsel. The merged entity aims to target higher-value customers, focusing on those who spend over 100,000 rupiah per month and have stayed with the company for more than a year. Telkom plans to increase revenue by offering bundle plans for fixed broadband and mobile services, while also reducing operational and personnel expenses. The company expects to grow revenue sustainably and increase the stickiness of its subscribers.

images.alt_text: Telkom CEO Ririek Adriansyah (left) and CFRO Heri Supriadi
Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Tackling nature’s demise as a key global business risk
summary: The world's most critical form of infrastructure is nature, with the UN's Food and Agriculture Organization warning that only 60 more harvests could be expected before it's "over." A new market for nature preservation and enhancement is emerging, with companies investing in ecosystem vitality and the private sector playing a key role in addressing the global business risk of nature's demise. To develop such markets, accurate measurement of natural capital is crucial, and technological advances in computer visualization, metagenomics, and machine learning can help quantify biodiversity, air, water, and soil health.

images.alt_text: Apart from global warming, there is a growing biodiversity crisis, with projections that as much as 42 per cent of all species in Southeast Asia could be lost by the turn of the century.
Ken Newcombe, chief executive officer (CEO) of C-Quest Capital
While much focus has been placed on reducing carbon emissions, other serious environmental problems such as deforestation, water shortages and soil erosion should not be overlooked.

site_title: US consumer prices increase solidly in April
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.4% in April, driven by higher petrol costs and rents, while underlying inflation remained strong due to a rebound in used motor vehicle prices. The core CPI increased 5.0% year-over-year, with used cars and trucks contributing to the growth for the first time since June 2022. This data is likely to keep interest rates elevated for a while, making it unlikely for the Federal Reserve to cut rates this year.

images.alt_text: New York Federal Reserve President John Williams also said he does not see “any reason to cut interest rates this year” in his baseline forecast, citing a need to lower stubborn inflation.

site_title: US dollar weakens, euro edges higher after inflation data
summary: The US dollar weakened 0.2% against a basket of currencies, falling to 101.38, after inflation data showed April inflation cooled to 4.9%, the smallest year-over-year increase in two years. Core inflation remained at 5.5%, suggesting interest rates may need to stay high to tame it. The euro rose 0.24% to $1.0987, while sterling was up 0.14% to $1.2640. Market analysts expect the Federal Reserve to pause interest rate hikes, citing a sigh of relief in the market, and believe it's too early to discuss rate cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar and euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Big US firms adopt cautious tone on China recovery
summary: US companies, including PepsiCo, Qualcomm, and Cummins, have expressed caution on China's growth prospects due to a slower-than-expected recovery after lifting Covid curbs. China's economy grew faster than expected in Q1, but demand remains below pre-pandemic levels. Weak domestic demand, a battered property market, and global economic uncertainty are contributing factors. This suggests that China's recovery is proceeding slowly, with imports contracting sharply in April and shoppers remaining wary.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping has repeatedly stressed the need for self-reliance in technology to prune use of foreign technology.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on signs of easing inflation
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.60% and 0.88% respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.43%. The increase follows US consumer prices rising at a slower-than-expected pace last month, suggesting the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are having a positive effect.

site_title: A-Plus Automation’s pivot to e-commerce leads to stellar growth
summary: A-Plus Automation, a Singapore-based company, experienced stellar growth after pivoting into e-commerce logistics in 2015. The company's managing director, Rodney Ham, recognized the need for change after the automotive industry's slow recovery from the 2008 global financial crisis. A-Plus leveraged its expertise in conveyor belt systems to partner with Lazada and began designing and manufacturing high-speed sortation systems for logistics providers. The company's focus on e-commerce has led to significant growth, including winning the Enterprise 50 Award in 2021 and being named among the SME100 Fast Moving Companies by SME Magazine.

images.alt_text:
smeplus - A-Plus Automation managing director Rodney Ham's decision to pivot into e-commerce logistics paid off.



Copyright/source: A-Plus Automation

site_title: New York Times misses revenue estimates as ad spending slows
summary: The New York Times reported revenue of $560.7 million for the first quarter, missing analyst estimates of $571 million. Ad spending slowed due to recession concerns, with digital ad revenue decreasing 9% to $61.3 million. The paper added 190,000 digital-only subscribers, aiming for 15 million by 2027. This decline follows a slowdown in consumer spending and a squeeze on marketing budgets.

images.alt_text: The reductions are “a necessary response” amid a “surge in interest rates and persistent inflation,” News Corp chief executive officer Robert Thomson said.

site_title: Roblox quarterly loss widens on higher expenses, shares tank
summary: Roblox posted a wider quarterly loss of $268.3 million, or 44 cents per share, due to increased expenses supporting platform expansion. The company's net bookings reached $773.8 million, surpassing analysts' expectations. Despite this, shares fell 12% in premarket trading. Roblox has been investing in collaborations with NFL, Fifa, and artists to expand its user base.

site_title: TikTok to delay launch of US shopping platform
summary: TikTok has delayed the launch of its US shopping platform due to growing pressure in Washington, including calls for a ban over concerns its US user data could fall into the hands of the Chinese government. The delay, initially set for early spring, is now expected to occur by June at the earliest. The move may prevent sellers from joining the platform, which had announced plans to let advertisers place ads alongside content made by premium publishers. The delay comes as TikTok faces increased scrutiny over its data handling practices.

site_title: Crypto firms call for global consensus instead of “fire hose” of rules
summary: The European Union has finalized the world's first comprehensive rules for cryptoasset markets, known as MiCA. However, other countries like Britain and the US are still behind in establishing regulatory frameworks. The lack of a global consensus on crypto regulations is hindering the maturation of the market, making it difficult to attract established investors. Experts, including US Securities and Exchange Commissioner Hester Peirce, emphasize the need for clearer rules and global standards to create a more mature market.

site_title: BRC Asia H1 net profit falls 34% on lower revenue
summary: BRC Asia, a steel solutions provider, reported a 34% year-on-year decline in net profit for its first half, due to lower revenue and a 10% decline in revenue. The company's net profit fell to $26.2 million, with a per-share earnings of $0.0961. Revenue fell to $717.1 million, primarily attributed to slower site progress in the domestic construction industry. Despite a "moderate recovery" in project contractual offtake in April, the company remains cautiously optimistic about the sector's recovery.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
BRC Asia noted that while Singapore’s construction industry grew by 6.5 per cent in 2022, its value-added remained 19.3 per cent below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: 50 public-service positions fulfil criteria to run for president, 1,200 companies meet the bar for shareholder equity: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's next presidential election is set to take place by September this year. About 50 public-service positions meet the public-sector service requirement, while over 1,200 companies have average shareholders' equity exceeding S$500 million. To qualify, candidates must be a Singapore citizen, 45 years or older, and have lived in the country for at least a decade. They must also meet public- or private-sector service requirements within the past two decades.

images.alt_text: News of Lee being investigated by the police has sparked speculation among some quarters, who questioned if it was being done to keep him out of the presidential race.

site_title: Private-credit firms see opportunity as banks tighten lending
summary: Private-credit firms see opportunities emerging as US banks tighten lending standards, citing a potential borrowing squeeze. About 46% of surveyed banks reported tightening lending standards in Q2 2023, slowing commercial and industrial lending to $2.76 trillion. Private lenders, including Blackstone, are eyeing commercial and residential real estate, particularly in sectors driven by smaller banks, as a result. With excess funds and potential for better loan terms, private-credit investors expect yields of at least 4% higher than a year earlier, making the sector attractive for continued investment in 2023.

images.alt_text: The new Citrix bonds will refinance most of a US$3.95 billion unsecured bridge loan.

site_title: Jewellery with Nazi links up for auction despite criticism
summary: A collection of 700 jewels, valued at over $150 million, is up for auction at Christie's in Geneva, despite criticism from Jewish groups over the jewelry's links to an Austrian billionaire's husband, who made his fortune under the Nazis. The sale aims to benefit charities, including a Holocaust research and education organization, but critics argue the proceeds do not adequately address the jewelry's Nazi past. The auction features pieces from renowned designers and includes the Sunrise Ruby, estimated at $15-20 million.

images.alt_text: Christie’s will offer 700 lots from Horten’s collection, including “unique and exceptional pieces” from 20th-century designers including Cartier, Harry Winston, Bulgari and Van Cleef & Arpels.

site_title: British pound no longer looks attractive after rally, Deutsche Bank says
summary: Deutsche Bank has downgraded its stance on the British pound, stating it no longer finds the currency attractive in the short-term due to a recent rally. The pound has risen 22% since its record low in September last year, with sterling trading near a one-year high at $1.262. Deutsche is closing its bet on the pound versus the dollar, citing that domestic UK news is now priced in. The bank also expects a "dovish surprise" from Thursday's Bank of England meeting, potentially leading to a rate cut.

site_title: Centurion Q1 revenue up 4.6% to S$47.1 million on higher occupancies, raised rents
summary: Centurion Corp's Q1 revenue rose 4.6% to S$47.1 million driven by increased occupancies and rents in its purpose-built dormitories and student accommodations in Singapore, Malaysia, and Australia. Financial occupancies in Singapore's dormitories reached 98%, with revenue from the PBSA segment growing 6.9% to S$11.7 million. Despite a slight decline in revenue from Singapore assets, the group reported positive rental revisions and growth in Malaysia and Australia.

images.alt_text: duplicate image
Tessa Oh

site_title: Far East Organization to launch The Reserve Residences at prices from S$2,300 psf
summary: Far East Organization will launch The Reserve Residences in Bukit Timah on May 27, with prices starting from S$2,300 per square foot (psf). The 99-year leasehold development will feature 732 residential units, ranging from one-bedroom to five-bedroom units, and is located above a retail mall with direct access to Beauty World MRT station. The project is expected to attract a "mixed group" of buyers, including investors and families, with the majority of units priced between S$1.11 million and S$3.5 million.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
The retail component of the 99-year leasehold mixed-use development has also attained 82 per cent expected occupancy, ahead of its launch by the end of this year.

site_title: Civmec Q3 net profit rises 20% to A$14.6 million
summary: Civmec, a construction and engineering services provider, reported a 20.2% year-on-year increase in net profit for its third quarter to A$14.6 million, despite a 2.7% fall in revenue to A$187.8 million. The company secured new contracts and maintained a strong order book of nearly A$1.2 billion. Revenue for the nine-month period grew 4.2% to A$606.6 million, with net profit rising 23.4% to A$42.9 million.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The package of work will utilise most of Civmec's in-house capabilities.

site_title: US dollar teeters on unresolved debt-ceiling crisis, upcoming inflation data
summary: The US dollar seesawed on Wednesday, edging up 0.14% to 101.76, amidst the unresolved debt-ceiling crisis and upcoming inflation data. US President Joe Biden and top lawmakers remained divided over raising the US debt limit, while speculators have built up the biggest bullish position in the euro in over two years. Economists expect core consumer prices to rise 5.5% year-on-year, potentially influencing the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

site_title: US debt ceiling standoff talks look at Covid clawbacks, energy permits
summary: US debt ceiling talks resume after a White House meeting, with President Joe Biden signaling openness to clawing back unused Covid relief funds ($80 billion) and speeding up energy project permits. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy has expressed willingness to negotiate, with a two-week deadline to reach a deal. The Treasury Department warns of a potential default as soon as June 1, which could destabilize the economy. Biden is prepared to cancel a trip to a G7 meeting if a deal is not reached, but lawmakers face time-consuming procedures to advance legislation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The U.S. Capitol building is seen in Washington, U.S., April 5, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo

site_title: Volkswagen defends China record at turbulent shareholder meeting
summary: Volkswagen defended its record in China and its joint ownership of a plant in the Xinjiang region despite criticism from activists and investors over potential human rights abuses. The UN has reported arbitrary detention of Uyghurs and other Muslims in the region, and rights groups have documented forced labor in detention camps. Volkswagen's CEO, Oliver Blume, acknowledged the fast pace of China's electrification and outlined the company's strategy to hold its position as market leader. Investors called for an independent audit of the Xinjiang plant, but the company's China chief, Ralf Brandstaetter, denied evidence of human rights abuses.

images.alt_text: Oliver Blume, chief executive officer of Volkswagen AG (VW), speaks at the Volkswagen AG annual general meeting (AGM) in the CityCube Berlin conference centre in Berlin, Germany, on Wednesday, May 10, 2023. Volkswagen will amp up partnerships and using external expertise to tackle the challenges of keeping up in China and rectifying software struggles that have pushed Europe’s biggest carmaker off course. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: Branded Lifestyle Asia lodges preliminary prospectus for mainboard IPO
summary: Branded Lifestyle Asia (BLA) has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a mainboard IPO on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), potentially boosting the exchange which has not had a mainboard IPO in over a year. BLA operates over 300 stores in South Korea and 100 stores in Taiwan, with a subsidiary holding a 15.6% market share in the South Korean children's fashion market. The company aims to list on the SGX and raise funds to further expand its business.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Singapore Exchange Centre at 2 Shenton Way, taken on 15 Feb 2019.

site_title: Singapore tech startups Krosslinker and Luminis win awards at US pitching competition
summary: Singapore tech startups Krosslinker and Luminis Water Technologies won awards at the 2023 SelectUSA Investment Summit startup pitching competition in Maryland. Krosslinker took the top prize in the Cleantech category, while Luminis Water Technologies won in the Regional category. The competition, attended by a Singapore delegation of over 25 companies, featured 79 international startups.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Hainan Jones has had to adapt and improvise, to get the taste of its chicken rice in New York as close as possible to the original from Singapore.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's assets under management (AUM) have increased, with the Asia-Pacific region being the top source of growth. Institutional investors account for the majority of this growth, not high-net-worth individuals. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan stated this in Parliament, highlighting the shift in wealth inflows into Singapore.

site_title: Temasek-backed STT GDC said to mull US$1 billion pre-IPO round
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC), a digital infrastructure provider backed by Temasek Holdings, is considering a US$1 billion pre-IPO funding round to set a valuation benchmark for a potential initial public offering (IPO) as early as next year. The funding round would be led by potential advisers and strategic investors, with deliberations preliminary and subject to change.

images.alt_text: Temasek fully owns Singapore Technologies Telemedia, the parent of STT GDC.

site_title: DBS considering expansion in Dubai, says Piyush Gupta
summary: DBS Group Holdings is considering an expansion in Dubai, with CEO Piyush Gupta stating the region offers "real opportunity" for growth. The bank's presence in the Middle East is currently limited, and its infrastructure is being reviewed to improve recovery capabilities after recent disruptions. Dubai's ease of doing business, tax-free status, and global travel appeal are drawing hedge funds and financial firms to the city. This move aligns with other financial firms, such as GoldenTree Asset Management, expanding in the region.

images.alt_text: DBS' Q1 2023 earnings beat the S$2.3 billion consensus forecast in a Bloomberg survey of three analysts.

site_title: UMS Holdings Q1 net profit slips 10% to S$17.4 million
summary: UMS Holdings reported a 10% year-on-year decline in Q1 net profit to S$17.4 million, primarily affected by higher expenses and a foreign exchange loss of S$200,000 due to the weaker US dollar. Revenue was slightly lower, and the company declared an unchanged interim dividend of S$0.01 per share.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
UMS said its order book remains healthy, and the group will continue to expand capacity to meet customer demands.
Venture helps companies design and produce high-tech products. Its margins have been consistently been around 10 per cent in the last five years.

site_title:
After seizures, the Met sets a plan to 
scour collections for looted art
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has announced a plan to review its collections for looted art, hiring four new provenance researchers to study the history of its holdings. The move comes amid increasing calls to repatriate works with problematic histories, following scrutiny from law enforcement officials, academics, and the media. The museum aims to return items found to have problematic histories, seeking to address concerns over its collection's provenance.

images.alt_text: Stolen gods - Nepal seeks to bring home lost treasures

site_title: Hong Kong passes tax concession bill to woo global family offices
summary: Hong Kong passed a tax concession bill to attract global family offices, offering a tax exemption for eligible family-owned investment vehicles with a minimum asset threshold of $240 million. The move aims to restore the city's position as a premier financial hub, competing with Singapore. The bill, effective May 19, will exempt profits from qualified transactions starting from April 1, 2022. The city has been rolling out other measures to attract talent and capital amid rising geopolitical tensions. This move is expected to foster Hong Kong's position as a premier family office hub and international asset management center.

site_title: SIA to redeem half its 2021 mandatory convertible bonds with cash reserves
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) plans to redeem 50% of its 2021 mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) with cash reserves, totaling approximately S$3.4 billion. The redemption, to be paid on June 26, will be funded by the airline's cash reserves, which stood at S$15.4 billion as of December 2022. This move aims to reduce the risk of potential dilution of shareholders and align with the airline's post-pandemic review of its long-term liquidity strategy.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The presence of independent directors alone does not address the sometimes divergent interests of controlling shareholders and minority investors
Singapore Airlines is calling its 2020 MCBs and the airline group is the sponsor of Formula One Singapore Grand Prix.
Singapore Airlines is expected by analysts to be profitable from FY2023.
Singapore Airlines' S$6.2b MCB rights issue undersubscribed
MCBs may be better play on SIA's recovery than shares: Phillip
SIA said its quarterly revenue per available seat-kilometre hit a record high for the three months to Sep 30

site_title: Prime US Reit Q1 net property income down 7.2% to US$23.6 million
summary: Prime US Reit reported a 7.2% decline in net property income to US$23.6 million for its first quarter, down from US$25.4 million the previous year. Gross revenue dropped 1.7% to US$40.2 million, and distributable income fell 22.5% to US$14.9 million. Despite a negative rental reversion of 2.6%, the Reit's portfolio has a weighted average lease expiry of 3.9 years and a debt headroom of US$200 million. The Reit's shares closed at US$0.235, down 2.1% from the previous day.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
For the second half of FY2022, distributable income fell 10.8 per cent to US$35.8 million, while net NPI dropped 13.3 per cent to US$47.1 million.

site_title: Hong Kong interbank rates jump, pull HKD off band extreme
summary: The Hong Kong dollar rose to its strongest since mid-February at 7.8325 per US dollar due to a surge in interbank rates. The overnight Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate jumped 92 basis points to 4.4381%, its highest since December 2019. One-week and one-month Hibor rates also increased, leading to an unwinding of short positions in the pegged Hong Kong dollar. This suggests expectations of tightening monetary settings and a potential end to the dollar's band.

images.alt_text: It remains profitable for the traders to borrow the Hong Kong dollar cheaply and buy the higher-yielding greenback, pocketing the rate difference.

site_title: ECB still has ‘more ground to cover,’ Lagarde tells Nikkei
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) still needs to take further action to combat inflation, according to President Christine Lagarde. Despite inflation rates decreasing from their peak, Lagarde warned of "significant upside risks" and emphasized the need to monitor wage pressures. The ECB plans to raise interest rates twice more, with a peak rate of 3.75%, before pausing rate increases. Officials stress that a concrete turnaround in core inflation is required before pausing rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Signage for the European Central Bank (ECB) outside the bank's headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, on Monday, May 23, 2022. While ECB policy makers have increasingly coalesced around the prospect of a first hike at their July 21 meeting in recent weeks, they have barely mentioned the possibility of a more aggressive half-point move such as the US Federal Reserve delivered this month. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: China urges giant state firms to be tech ‘pillars’ in self-reliance drive
summary: China has urged its state-owned enterprises to play a key role in its drive for self-reliance in technology, with President Xi Jinping stressing the need to prune use of foreign technology. The science and technology ministry said state firms should become leading tech companies with global influence by boosting investment in basic research, attracting talent, and strengthening technological innovation. Analysts say China's private firms are more innovative, but the government aims to turn some state giants into tech leaders to counter the US in the race for technological dominance.

images.alt_text: China already has the world’s largest fleet of renewable generation and plans to boost that with about 455 gigawatts of wind and solar in mainly desert areas.

site_title: Chinese company earnings reveal lopsided economic recovery
summary: Chinese companies' first-quarter earnings show a mixed recovery, with travel and dining sectors surging 155% and 18% respectively, while home furnishings and apparel firms' earnings declined 9%. Consumer caution and global growth concerns have limited overall demand, with the materials sector posting the worst results. Analysts expect earnings to rebound in the coming quarters, driven by policymakers' fiscal and monetary measures to support the economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Inbound shipments to China fell by 7.9 per cent year on year, while exports grew by 8.5 per cent in the same period after an unexpected surge of 14.8 per cent in March.

Residential and commercial buildings stand in the Pudong area of Shanghai, China, on Saturday, Feb. 2, 2013. China's economic growth accelerated for the first time in two years as government efforts to revive demand drove a rebound in industrial output, retail sales and the housing market. Photographer: Tomohiro Ohsumi/Bloomberg

site_title: Philippine Airlines to buy nine Airbus A350-1000 wide-body jets
summary: Philippine Airlines has ordered nine Airbus A350-1000 wide-body jets to expand its fleet and route network, with deliveries expected to begin by the fourth quarter of 2025 and continue until 2027. The new aircraft will operate non-stop services from Manila to North America, including the US east coast and Canada. The airline has secured purchase rights on three additional A350-1000s for future expansion to new destinations. This move comes as air travel recovers from the pandemic, with the airline having previously filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the US in 2021.

images.alt_text: Airbus is hoping to deliver 720 aircraft this year – a target it initially had set for 2022.

site_title: South-east Asian leaders pledge crackdown on human traffickers online scams
summary: Southeast Asian leaders pledged to combat human traffickers' online scams, particularly targeting vulnerable jobseekers. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) leaders issued a declaration to address the increasing use of technology in human trafficking, citing social media and online platforms. More than 1,000 victims have been rescued in recent days, with 20 Indonesian citizens repatriated from Myanmar and over 1,000 people rescued in the Philippines. The Asean leaders agreed to enhance law enforcement capacity and conduct joint exercises to combat human trafficking.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo welcomes Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to the 42nd Asean Summit in Labuan Bajo, Indonesia.

site_title: Taiwan’s banks cut China exposure to record low as tensions rise
summary: Taiwanese banks have significantly reduced their exposure to China, cutting back lending, investments, and interbank transactions to $34.6 billion as of March, a 18% decline from the same period last year. This marks the lowest level of exposure in at least a decade, as tensions between Taiwan and China deter lenders from expanding in the world's second-largest economy. Investments in China have shrunk 28.3% over the past year, with banks focusing on diversifying their exposure.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's central bank, in a unanimous decision, raised the benchmark discount rate by 12.5 basis points (bps) to 1.875 per cent.

site_title: Chinese tech IPOs’ complicated comeback
summary: Chinese tech companies are poised for a comeback in the market, with Alibaba's logistics arm Cainiao Network Technology reportedly eyeing a Hong Kong IPO of up to $2 billion. Other companies, including ByteDance, Shein, and Xiaohongshu, may also pursue listings. This marks a stark contrast to the turmoil of recent years, when Chinese tech IPOs were marred by government crackdowns and US-China tensions. However, market observers remain cautious, citing geopolitical and economic volatility, including US-China tensions and weak domestic demand in China.

images.alt_text: There’s a slim chance an Ant listing would make it onto this year’s slate — global economic uncertainty and continuing US-China tensions shouldn’t be discounted.
Cainiao, which has started work on the IPO, is looking to raise between US$1 billion and US$2 billion in Hong Kong, according to three sources.
Shein and Temu have taken the world by storm, with a potent combination of ultra-low prices and personalised recommendations.

site_title: Capital markets can lead the way in transition finance
summary: Capital markets can facilitate sustainable transition finance by providing capital to carbon-intensive businesses that invest in renewables. However, defining "significant harm" criteria is crucial to ensure the integrity of transition finance. Investors, governments, and other stakeholders must work together to develop common approaches and avoid "transition washing" fears. To achieve this, stock exchanges can play a key role in promoting sustainability by developing tools and platforms for sustainability-themed financial services and products, and creating an SDG index to report impact.

images.alt_text: (From left) Morgan Davis, editor of IFR Asia Bonds, moderating a panel comprising Green Climate Fund's Kavita Sinha, Adani Group's Robbie Singh, MUFG's Fumitaka Nakahama, and Sustainable Fitch's Aurelia Britsch.
Transition finance has been slow to address the coal challenge, but there are good reasons to be cautious.

site_title: Panasonic sees record profit on robust battery demand, US tax credit
summary: Panasonic predicts a 32% increase in net profit to a record 350 billion yen (S$3.4 billion) due to robust auto battery sales and a US tax credit under the Inflation Reduction Act. The company expects operating profit of 430 billion yen for the year ending March 2024, beating analyst estimates. This growth is driven by increased demand for electric vehicle batteries, with Tesla being one of Panasonic's key customers. The tax credit is expected to boost Panasonic's bottom line by 100 billion yen.

site_title: Singapore stocks flat amid cautious trading on inflation concerns
summary: Singapore stocks ended flat on Wednesday, May 10, amid cautious trading due to inflation concerns. The Straits Times Index (STI) inched down 0.02% to 3,242.29. Gainers outnumbered losers 273 to 255, with 1.2 billion securities worth S$815.1 million changing hands. Investors remained cautious ahead of US inflation data, with risk markets moving cautiously.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
ST20230303_202311925234 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on March 3, 2023.

site_title: Australian firms correct claims after regulator’s greenwashing crackdown
summary: Australian regulators have cracked down on "greenwashing" by public companies, managed funds, and superannuation funds, securing 23 corrective disclosure outcomes and issuing 11 infringement notices between July 2022 and March 2023. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (Asic) investigated claims about environmental, social, and governance (ESG) credentials, leading to corrections and penalties for firms such as Mercer Superannuation, Black Mountain Energy, and Tlou Energy. The crackdown aims to ensure transparency and accuracy in ESG claims.

images.alt_text: investors are asking ESG-related questions relating to businesses – referring to sustainability ratings and metrics when assessing an organisation’s suitability for inclusion in their investment portfolios.

site_title: Indonesia tax cut drives electric car sales for Hyundai, Wuling
summary: Indonesia's tax cut on electric cars has driven sales of Hyundai's IONIQ 5 and Wuling Air EV, with Hyundai's sales tripling to over 600 units and Wuling's surging 80% to over 740 units in April. The tax cut, which applies to electric cars with at least 40% local content, aims to increase demand for electric vehicles. Hyundai aims to sell 10,000 units of IONIQ 5 in Indonesia this year, while Fitch Ratings expects sales of four-wheeled EVs to exceed 50,000 units in 2023.

site_title: Australia exports first copper to China since 2020, industry hopes end to ban near
summary: Australia has exported copper ore and concentrate to China for the first time since December 2020, with January exports valued at A$60.5 million (S$50.3 million). The exports, worth around US$40 million, are seen as a positive sign for the industry as diplomatic relations between the two countries improve. China has lifted unofficial restrictions on Australian imports, including coal, and trade talks are set to resume, with the Australian Trade Minister planning to visit Beijing soon. Resumed copper imports could meet demand for the raw material in a tight global market.

images.alt_text: Australian inflation sits at near 30-year highs of 7.0 per cent, forcing the government to announce relief measures aimed at lowering power bills and easing pressure on consumer prices.

site_title: Mongolia's building boom traps capital residents in concrete jungle
summary: Mongolia's capital, Ulaanbaatar, is experiencing a rapid construction boom fueled by a decade-long mining windfall, but it's coming at a cost. The city is becoming increasingly congested, with high-rises replacing traditional yurts, leaving little room for public services like hospitals, schools, and playgrounds. Experts blame antiquated city planning strategies, while locals say the boom has trapped their children in a concrete jungle, with many forced to spend hours commuting to work due to massive traffic jams. The city's mayor has announced a ban on construction permits until 2040, but the impact of the boom remains a pressing issue.

images.alt_text: Mongolia seeking pact with Rio Tinto to end copper mine expansion: FT

site_title: India's Go First airline gains bankruptcy protection, lessors' woes deepen
summary: India's Go First airline has gained bankruptcy protection, which could bolster its chances of getting back on its feet after being grounded by faulty Pratt & Whitney engines. The airline has staff of around 7,000 and has suspended all flights. Bankruptcy protection supersedes lessors' repossession requests, but they may challenge the decision. Go First's lessors, including Jackson Square Aviation and Bank of China Aviation, are expected to mount a prolonged legal battle. The airline's woes may lead to higher lease premiums for Indian airlines, complicating the country's emergence as an aviation powerhouse.

site_title: Cisco to begin manufacturing from India in diversification move
summary: Cisco Systems plans to manufacture from India, diversifying its global supply chain. CEO Chuck Robbins announced the move, aiming for $1 billion in domestic production and exports over the next few years. The decision follows a meeting between Robbins and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has been working to establish India as a global electronics hub. This marks a significant milestone for Cisco, which sees India as a strategic location for growth. The investment size was not disclosed, but the company plans to support growing demand from Indian customers and expand its supply chain capabilities.

images.alt_text: The Cisco logo is displayed, during the GSMA's 2023 Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona, Spain March 1, 2023. REUTERS/Nacho Doce

site_title: Hong Kong passes law barring foreign lawyers from security cases
summary: Hong Kong's legislature has passed a law that requires the Chief Executive's approval for foreign lawyers to participate in national security cases. The amendment to the Legal Practitioners bill, which was approved by an opposition-free legislature, effectively bars foreign lawyers from these cases. The bill now heads to Chief Executive John Lee's desk for signing, limiting the ability of foreign lawyers to practice in Hong Kong's courts.

site_title: Myanmar shadow government welcomes Asean peace talks but distrusts junta
summary: Myanmar's shadow government, the National Unity Government, has welcomed Asean's efforts to kickstart peace talks, but remains distrustful of the military junta that took power in 2021. The junta has failed to implement a five-point peace "consensus" agreed by its top general with Asean, and has been accused of trying to mislead the international community. The junta has intensified attacks and air strikes, seeking to consolidate power ahead of a planned election, amidst ongoing resistance from fighters and ethnic armed groups.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo welcomes Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to the 42nd Asean Summit in Labuan Bajo, Indonesia.

site_title: Vietnam’s SBV tackling multiple challenges to steady economy
summary: Vietnam's central bank, the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV), is facing challenges in managing interest rates, currency, and credit policies amid a slowing domestic economy and global turbulence. The bank has shifted its policy to support lower lending rates, loan moratoriums, and debt recast for struggling firms to boost economic recovery and control inflation. Despite a low inflation rate of 2.81%, policymakers must balance supporting the local currency, boosting credit demand, and stimulating economic growth, which the government targets at 6.5% this year.

images.alt_text: Vietnam’s growth slowed from 5.92 per cent in late 2022 to 3.32 per cent in the first quarter of 2023, prompting the SBV to cut its benchmark rates twice this year.

Well-managed monetary policies and stable exchange rate have enabled the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) to continue to buy foreign currency to boost foreign reserves, Investment Minister Nguyen Chi Dung says.

site_title: China names Li Yunze top financial regulator in surprise move
summary: China has appointed Li Yunze, a former banker, as party secretary of the newly formed national financial supervision and management bureau, overseeing the country's $61 trillion financial sector. The 52-year-old, who has served as a vice-governor of Sichuan province since 2018, was unexpectedly chosen to tackle financial risks amid Beijing's efforts to shore up its economy. The move contrasts with previous leadership changes, which focused on continuity and international experience, and is seen as a way for President Xi Jinping to consolidate power and control over the sector.

images.alt_text: Restaurants and tourism businesses recover, with travel-related consumer services sector earnings surging 155 per cent.

site_title: Saudi Aramco to supply full oil volumes to Asia in June, but some seek less
summary: Saudi Aramco will supply full volumes of crude oil to Asian customers in June, despite some refiners requesting lower volumes. The company cut official selling prices for all crude grades to Asia due to lower refining margins. This decision comes as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies announced output cuts of 1.16 million barrels per day for the rest of the year, with Saudi Arabia reducing production by 500,000 barrels per day.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Saudi Aramco logo is pictured at the oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: US urges WHO to invite Taiwan to observe May meeting
summary: The US has urged the World Health Organization (WHO) to invite Taiwan as an observer at its annual meeting in May, citing the WHO's commitment to an inclusive approach to international health cooperation. This move is in line with the US one-China policy, which considers Taiwan a part of China. China, however, has blocked Taiwan's participation in the WHO's annual assembly since 2017, labeling it as a province. Taiwan's foreign ministry thanked the US for its support, saying exclusion would harm global health cooperation. China urged the US to abide by the one-China principle.

images.alt_text: Taiwan slams WHO's 'indifference' after failing to get into key meeting

site_title: Mothers in business
summary: A spotlight is on mumpreneurs, women who balance raising families and building businesses. Three entrepreneurs share their experiences, prioritizing work and family. They offer tips on mastering the art of give and take. Meanwhile, arts enthusiasts can look forward to performances and exhibitions, including a new National Art Gallery show. Additionally, a Chinese restaurant has opened a new premises with creative dim sum options.

site_title: Timor-Leste PM says country taking ‘necessary steps’ towards full Asean membership
summary: Timor-Leste Prime Minister Taur Matan Ruak announced the country is taking "necessary steps" to meet Asean membership criteria, focusing on infrastructure development, including a submarine fibre-optic cable and airport expansion. The country aims to fulfill milestones on a formalized road map and support Asean's goals of being "open, transparent, inclusive and rules-based". Timor-Leste has committed to joining Asean's efforts in promoting peace and stability in Myanmar, where ongoing violence has sparked international concern.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Indonesian President Joko Widodo welcomes Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to the 42nd Asean Summit in Labuan Bajo, Indonesia.

Better known as a gateway to the famed Komodo Island, the normally idyllic Labuan Bajo has been abuzz with activity in the lead-up to the Asean Summit, which will be held at Meruorah Komodo Labuan Bajo
Timor-Leste made its debut as an observer at the Asean Coordinating Council meeting in February, after receiving in-principle approval to join Asean in November 2022.

site_title: China’s shift away from Big Four auditors has EY most exposed
summary: China's crackdown on US-linked auditors, including Big Four firms, may expose EY to significant revenue loss. EY stands to lose about one-tenth of its China revenue, primarily from central state-owned enterprises (SOEs), which earned 12% of the company's China revenue in 2021. The move may also have a cascading effect on global businesses operating with these companies. Beijing's nationwide anti-espionage crackdown on consulting firms further adds to the uncertainty in the professional services sector.

images.alt_text: China already has the world’s largest fleet of renewable generation and plans to boost that with about 455 gigawatts of wind and solar in mainly desert areas.
Inbound shipments to China fell by 7.9 per cent year on year, while exports grew by 8.5 per cent in the same period after an unexpected surge of 14.8 per cent in March.
People walk by office towers in the Lujiazui financial district of Shanghai, China. More than 80 listed companies in Shanghai and Shenzhen have changed auditors since December.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank raises Dyna-Mac target price to S$0.40 on strong Q1 results
summary: Maybank Securities raised its target price for Dyna-Mac to S$0.40, citing strong Q1 results with a net profit of S$3.9 million, more than double the previous year. The brokerage maintains a "buy" call and revised forecasts for FY2023 and FY2024 net profit, expecting better quarters ahead due to operational improvements. Maybank believes Dyna-Mac's margins will rise due to better contract utilization and pricing, and sees potential for mergers and acquisitions to provide stability for shareholders.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of Dyna-Mac’s Holdings' main yard in Gul Road.
The company is expected to secure larger orders with potentially higher margins, including another estimated S$600 million worth of orders by the fourth quarter of 2023, says Maybank KE.
Office workers walking past the SGX logo outside the SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on 17 January 2020.

site_title: China’s BYD launches lower-priced versions of Seal EV; aims to extend lead
summary: China's BYD launches five lower-priced versions of its Seal EV sedan, aiming to extend its lead in the world's largest new-energy car market. The rear-wheel drive Seal Champion Edition starts at 189,800 yuan (S$36,359), 10% lower than a previous version and 18% cheaper than Tesla's Model 3 in China. The move seeks to compete with Tesla's Model 3 in China, where BYD aims to maintain its market lead.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A BYD Seal electric vehicle (EV) is displayed at a car dealership in Shanghai, China, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: ABN Amro Q1 net profit jumps 77% on higher rates and lower costs
summary: ABN Amro, a Dutch bank largely state-owned, reported a 77% jump in first-quarter net profit to 523 million euros, beating analyst expectations. The bank attributed the increase to rising interest rates and lower costs, with deposit margins driving net interest income up 24%. Total costs dropped 2.5%, partly due to job cuts. The lender maintains its expectation of reduced operating expenses for the year.

images.alt_text: Online and mobile shopping payments will be added later on, along with subscription instalments, and services such as buy now, pay later, over time.

site_title: Virgin Australia says IPO planning advanced, finalising capital return
summary: Virgin Australia is days away from finalizing a capital return, with investors led by US private equity firm Bain Capital set to receive A$730 million. The capital return will be structured as a capital reduction, with Bain Capital taking around 90% and Richard Branson's Virgin Group with 5%. The airline had sought up to A$450 million in loans for the return. The move comes as the airline prepares for its upcoming initial public offering (IPO), which is likely to be one of the country's biggest listings this year.

images.alt_text: The reopening of premium lounge at Hong Kong is part of a A$100 million investment by Qantas into its global lounge network.

The Australian competition regulator said in its review that Alliance’s integration with Qantas could substantially lessen competition in the charter services sector in Queensland and Western Australia.

site_title: Buddy Holly wins best in show at Westminster
summary: Buddy Holly, a 2-year-old Petit Basset Griffon Vendeen, won the best in show competition at the 147th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York. The dog, owned by Janice Hayes, defeated last year's runner-up Winston the French bulldog. Buddy Holly performed flawlessly, doing exactly what Hayes wanted him to do, and was described by Hayes as "the epitome of a show dog." This is Hayes' third attempt at Westminster, and she has been watching the show with her father since she was a child.

images.alt_text: Live sheep exports fell to below 500,000 in 2022, down from a peak of 6.5 million 20 years ago.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift lower as US inflation data looms
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday as investors awaited US inflation data, amid concerns over the debt ceiling standoff and banking sector uncertainty. The Federal Reserve hinted at a possible pause in interest rate hikes, but warned of potential further tightening if inflation rises. The US economy shows resilience but growth is slowing, with several indicators suggesting a possible recession. The debt ceiling talks between President Biden and lawmakers yielded no breakthrough, and market reactions are expected to be muted until a deal is reached.

images.alt_text: Losers outnumbered gainers 315 to 250, after 1.3 billion securities worth S$925.5 million changed hands.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta markets were all in the green on Monday.

site_title: Cybersecurity outfit SquareX raises US$6 million in seed capital from Sequoia
summary: SquareX, a cybersecurity startup led by Vivek Ramachandran, has raised US$6 million in seed capital from Sequoia Capital South-east Asia. The funds will be used for research and development and go-to-market strategy for its browser extension-based cybersecurity solution. The solution monitors users and ensures their security, integrating cloud services to guard against phishing and identity theft. Anandamoy Roychowdhary, partner at Surge, Sequoia South-east Asia, described SquareX as the first solution to take a 100% protection approach, with no chance to infect users.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

ST20221117-202282731354-Lim Yaohui-pixgenseric/
Generic photograph of Singapore skyline as viewed from Capella Singapore, Sentosa on Nov 17, 2022.
Can be used for stories on money, property, building, housing, company, land, shop, office, tourist, greenery, population, commercial, invest, budget, income, finance, financial, CBD, URA, economy, and development.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)
Founded by Dr Joe Fitzsimons, Horizon is developing tools that will make it easier to construct complex quantum algorithms.
Zilingo, a once high-flying company, pitched into a downward spiral after complaints of financial irregularities.

site_title: Chinese tycoon’s luxury Hong Kong home put up for sale by receiver
summary: Embattled Chinese tycoon Chen Hongtian's luxury Hong Kong home, Opus Hong Kong, has been put up for sale by its receiver. The 5,154 sq ft apartment, designed by Frank Gehry, is valued at HK$680 million (S$115 million) and includes five bedrooms. This is the latest in a series of seized assets, following a US$271 million mansion and a commercial building. The tender for the property ends on August 8.

images.alt_text: Opus Hong Kong, designed by architect Frank Gehry, on Stubbs Road in Hong Kong. Photographer: Jerome Favre/Bloomberg

site_title: Thais expected to deliver heavy poll blow to military parties
summary: Thailand is set to hold its first election since 2019, with the opposition-led Pheu Thai party expected to win the most seats, rejecting nearly a decade of military-backed rule. The party, led by 36-year-old Paetongtarn Shinawatra, is polling ahead of the United Thai Nation party and Palang Pracharath Party, led by former Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha. The election aims to address economic stagnation and human rights concerns, with voters demanding change from the military-backed government. Pheu Thai needs 376 seats to secure power, and an alliance with the radical Move Forward Party may be necessary.

images.alt_text: epa10424388 A Thai clothing rental vendor assists Chinese tourists dressing in Thai traditional costumes, during a visit to Wat Arun or Temple of Dawn in Bangkok, Thailand, 23 January 2023. Thailand's tourism and business related activities are in recovery stimulated by the influx of Chinese tourists after China lifted COVID-19 travel restrictions. Thailand is projected to welcome five million Chinese visitors in 2023 with 29,4000 tourists from mainland China expected to arrive during Lunar New Year, according to the Tourism Authority of Thailand.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT
Former Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra was convicted in absentia on corruption charges – and faces numerous other cases as well – but on Tuesday said he was ready to face the courts.

Thai voters lining up to cast ballots during the general election advance voting at a polling station in Bangkok on Sunday. More than 2.3 million eligible voters nationwide have registered to cast their early-votes.

site_title: Growth in Singapore’s AUM due mostly to institutional investors, not high-net-worth individuals
summary: Singapore's assets under management (AUM) grew by about S$470 billion from 2017 to 2021, with institutional investors accounting for the bulk of the increase, not high-net-worth individuals. Non-retail individual clients, including family offices, accounted for about 20% of the growth. Asia-Pacific was the top foreign source for the increase in AUM for high-end individual investors, followed by Europe and the Americas. The influx of foreign funds managed in Singapore has little to no impact on the local economy, including the Singapore dollar exchange rate, inflation, or the private housing market.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

MAS-co-chaired private banking industry group PBIG says it noted at a recent meeting that sources of Singapore overall inflows remain diversified, despite public commentary's tendency to focus on inflows from China.

site_title: HSBC gains assets from former Credit Suisse clients in Asia
summary: HSBC has acquired assets from former Credit Suisse clients in Asia, attracting US$22 billion in net new money globally, with nearly two-thirds coming from the region. The bank expects strong growth in China, driven by President Xi Jinping's common prosperity drive, and has been expanding its wealth management business and hiring talent from Credit Suisse and other banks. Despite fierce competition, HSBC's wealth and personal banking division saw a 82% increase in net operating income in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: HSBC announced a dividend of US$0.10 per share, its first quarterly dividend since 2019, following calls of shareholders to increase the dividend payout.
FILE PHOTO: The HSBC bank logo is seen in the Canary Wharf financial district in London, Britain, March 3, 2016.  REUTERS/Reinhard Krause/File Photo

site_title: Coupang’s sales beat estimates after big spending pays off
summary: Coupang, a South Korean e-commerce giant backed by SoftBank Group, reported a 13% revenue growth to $5.8 billion in the quarter ended March, beating analyst estimates. The company's core delivery business expanded exponentially during the pandemic, and active customers grew 5% to 19 million. Coupang posted an operating profit of $106.8 million, despite spending hundreds of millions of dollars on expansion and new offerings. The company's CEO, Bom Kim, attributed the success to its focus on operational excellence and long-term strategy.

images.alt_text: The salary hike marked a milestone for the Singapore-based e-commerce and gaming company, which had previously announced several rounds of layoffs and salary freezes.
Amazon late last year hiked the price of its annual Prime subscription that includes free shipping benefits by US$20 to US$139.

site_title: Musk says video and audio calls coming to Twitter
summary: Elon Musk announced on Twitter that audio and video calls are coming to the platform, allowing users to communicate with others worldwide without sharing their phone number. The feature is expected to compete with other messaging services like WhatsApp and Signal. Additionally, Twitter will start encrypting direct messages to safeguard user privacy. Musk also discussed his vision for an all-purpose "X" application combining messages, payments, and more, as part of his plans for the rebranded company.

images.alt_text: Twitter’s billionaire owner Elon Musk in a separate tweet said inactive accounts will be archived, Musk did not add any details on when the process will begin.
Elon Musk’s policy changes since taking over Twitter, from firing half its staff to demanding users pay for once-coveted verified checkmarks, have disconcerted observers and users.
The US Department of Commerce put out a call for input from industry actors that would serve to inform the Biden administration in drafting regulation on AI.

site_title: Trudeau slams Facebook for threatening to block Canadian news
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau criticized Meta for threatening to block news for Canadian Facebook and Instagram users in response to a proposed law requiring digital giants to pay for local journalism content. The move comes as Google also announced plans to restrict Canadians' access to news in preparation for the passage of the Online News Act. Trudeau described the tech giants' arguments as "dangerous to our democracy and economy," emphasizing the importance of independent journalism.

images.alt_text: US tech giants and others involved in the joint venture can only have a minority stake, and employees that have access to EU data would have to undergo specific screening and have to be located in the 27-country bloc, the document said.

Startups don’t need to build models and should instead focus on developing applications, where “brand new entrepreneurial opportunities that are 10 times greater than WeChat and Douyin will emerge,” says Baidu CEO Robin Li.
Sonos alleges Google infringed two of its patents related to multi-room wireless audio, such as Google Home.

site_title: China to boost policy support for large renewable power projects
summary: China plans to boost policy support for large renewable power projects to meet its climate targets. The country aims to expand its renewable energy fleet with 455 gigawatts of wind and solar capacity in desert areas. Despite already having the world's largest renewable generation fleet, the government warns of slow grid connection and energy storage infrastructure construction. The authorities urge relevant parties to ensure projects start generating on time, with about 100 gigawatts under construction. China's renewable capacity stood at 426 gigawatts of solar and 376 gigawatts of wind at the end of March.

site_title: Gold flat as US inflation test looms
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged at $2,035.39 per ounce as traders awaited US inflation data that could impact the Federal Reserve's policy stance. The US consumer price index (CPI) data is due, with markets pricing in an 83% chance of the central bank holding rates steady in June. Rising interest rates dull the appeal of non-yielding bullion, despite gold's inflation-hedging properties.

images.alt_text: The dollar index was up 0.1 per cent, making bullion less affordable for overseas buyers.

site_title: India renews call for chipmakers as billionaire’s effort drags
summary: India is reviving its efforts to lure chipmakers, including billionaire Anil Agarwal's $19 billion plan, amid concerns over dependence on expensive imports and Taiwan/China. The government is reopening the application process for $10 billion in incentives, removing a previous 45-day deadline, and keeping it open-ended. Despite initial efforts attracting only three applicants, India's chip market is expected to reach $64 billion by 2026, driven by electronics manufacturers relocating assembly operations to the country.

images.alt_text: Rising price pressures, alongside an improving economic outlook, mean the Reserve Bank of India will likely lean towards keeping its key interest rate on hold rather than easing it anytime soon.

site_title: New York’s empty office buildings lure rich families hunting bargains
summary: Wealthy families and individual investors are buying Manhattan office buildings at discounted prices due to the city's commercial real estate slump. With rising interest rates threatening defaults, institutional buyers are pulling back, allowing high-net-worth individuals to snap up properties. Since last year, 46% of private bankers and wealth advisers see real estate as a top opportunity to increase wealth, and offices are a top target sector for ultra-high-net-worth individuals. Investors are taking advantage of the downturn, with some buying buildings at 7% discounts, and others planning to convert them into residential buildings or luxury apartments.

images.alt_text: An office building at 1330 Avenue of Americas in New York, US, on Sunday, April 30, 2023. With large institutional buyers pulling back on deals, high-net-worth families and little-known developers are bargain-hunting for Manhattan office buildings. Photographer: Amir Hamja/Bloomberg

The roughly US$150 million conversion of the Hilton will show how such projects – quicker and cheaper than building new apartment buildings – can be an effective way of adding more affordable housing in New York.

site_title: Emerging market investors ditch China stocks to pile into TSMC, Reliance
summary: Emerging market investors are favoring non-China stocks, with the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ex China ETF receiving $148 million in new inflows last week. This is the fifth consecutive week of net deposits for the fund, which includes holdings in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC), Reliance Industries, and Vale. In contrast, ETFs that exclusively buy Chinese shares have failed to attract new investors, driven by concerns over China's economic recovery, regulatory risks, and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping has taken steps to promote the country’s reputation abroad, even as he focuses on implementing reforms and bolstering growth at home.

site_title: Sembcorp says no definitive deal to sell waste management unit; stock hits 8-year high
summary: Sembcorp Industries' shares surged 3.1% to an 8-year high, reaching S$4.73, after the company denied reports of a definitive deal to sell its waste management unit SembWaste. The company stated there's no certainty a transaction will materialize, despite Reuters reporting potential bidders KKR, Macquarie Asset Management, and I Squared Capital. Sembcorp will review its portfolio for strategic fit and maximize shareholder value, with no immediate announcement planned.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The company is working with a financial adviser on the potential divestment of SembWaste and could seek as much as US$700 million for the unit.
Sembcorp opens solar-powered EV charging hub; to be available for public use by 2022

site_title: UK firms turn to temporary staff as wages keep rising
summary: UK firms are turning to temporary staff as wages continue to rise, with permanent staff hiring declining at the sharpest pace in over two years in April. Job vacancies are still increasing but growth is losing steam due to economic uncertainty and rising costs. Starting wages rose in April, partly due to firms compensating new workers for higher living costs and struggling to attract skilled candidates for permanent positions. Labour supply grew for a second month, with most job-seekers looking for permanent roles.

Some lenders are starting to edge up the price of home loans again, in anticipation of higher BOE rates.

Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is under pressure to make good on his pledge to grow the economy this year, as he prepares for a general election that must before held no later than January 2025.

site_title: Australia seeks to calm rental crisis with investor tax breaks
summary: Australia is introducing tax breaks for investors to build rental properties, aiming to ease the country's worsening housing crisis. The government will halve tax levies for foreign investors, potentially leading to 150,000 new homes built over the next decade. However, experts warn that the measures may not significantly improve housing affordability, as the supply shortage intensifies due to high immigration levels. The government has also announced rent assistance for lower-income households and loans for social and affordable housing projects.

images.alt_text: Australian inflation sits at near 30-year highs of 7.0 per cent, forcing the government to announce relief measures aimed at lowering power bills and easing pressure on consumer prices.
The centrepiece of the budget is A$14.6 billion worth of measures over four years that include relief from high energy costs for households and small businesses.

site_title: Hebrew Bible, rare Rousseau to star at New York spring auctions
summary: A rare Codex Sassoon, over 1,000 years old and one of only two surviving Hebrew Bibles, is expected to fetch up to $50 million at Sotheby's auction on May 17. A Gustav Klimt waterscape, "Island in the Attersee," is also set to debut, with an estimated sale price of $45 million. Meanwhile, Henri Rousseau's "Les Flamants" is predicted to sell for up to $30 million, smashing the record price for the French post-impressionist painter. Other notable works include Jean-Michel Basquiat's "Now's the Time" and Louise Bourgeois's monumental sculpture "Spider."

site_title: Property developers brace for surge in compliance work with new anti-money laundering rules
summary: Singapore property developers face a surge in compliance work ahead of June 28, when they must conduct customer due diligence checks on all transactions of uncompleted residential and non-residential properties. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has provided guidelines, but developers are grappling with clarity on criteria and boundaries. Approximately 10 developers, including major players, have sought assistance from property data analytics company Amicus, while lawyers and professional services firms have also received requests for help. The new rules aim to combat money laundering and terrorism financing in the real estate sector, with penalties of up to S$100,000 for non-compliance.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
MAS said the new platform, named Cosmic, will allow financial institutions to share information on customers who show suspicious behaviour.

site_title: OCBC profit up 39% for Q1 to record S$1.9 billion
summary: OCBC Bank's net profit for the first quarter rose 39% to a record S$1.9 billion, beating the S$1.6 billion consensus forecast. Strong net interest income growth, driven by a 56% increase to S$2.3 billion, supported by a 75 basis point rise in net interest margin, contributed to the earnings. Despite global volatility, the bank expects limited potential to reprice its loan book upwards and funding costs will continue to catch up. OCBC's NIM guidance was raised to 2.2%, the highest among local banks.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Vivienne Tay

The decline in Great Eastern's total weighted new sales was due to lower single premium sales from the Singapore market, the group said.

site_title: Robert De Niro becomes father again at 79
summary: Robert De Niro, 79, has become a father again with the birth of his seventh child. The actor revealed the news in a recent interview, stating he just had a baby without revealing the mother's identity. De Niro already has five children from previous relationships, including his wife Diahnne Abbott and socialite Grace Hightower. The news comes as he promotes his new comedy film "About My Father," set to be released in US theatres on May 26.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MAY 09: Robert De Niro attends the "About My Father" premiere at SVA Theater on May 09, 2023 in New York City.   Dia Dipasupil/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Dia Dipasupil / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) climbing 6.83 points to 3,249.78. Despite overnight losses on Wall Street and in Europe, the local market saw gains from three local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB. Losers outnumbered gainers 57 to 56 in the broader market, with Seatrium and Thai Beverage being the most traded stocks by volume.

images.alt_text: People waiting outside the OCBC bank outlet in Compass One shopping mall on 17 February 2022.

site_title: Metaverse could contribute up to 2.4% of US GDP by 2035: study
summary: A study commissioned by Meta Platforms forecasts that the metaverse could contribute up to 2.4% of the US GDP by 2035, with an estimated value of $760 billion. The metaverse, which includes augmented and virtual reality technologies, may generate economic gains in sectors such as defense, healthcare, and manufacturing, as well as entertainment use cases like video games and communication.

images.alt_text: ByteDance is sharpening its focus on e-commerce and platforms such as TikTok and its Chinese sibling Douyin – implying a deemphasis on VR, gaming, and education.

site_title: Biden, McCarthy divided over debt ceiling but talks continue
summary: US President Joe Biden and House of Representatives Speaker Kevin McCarthy agreed to further talks on raising the $31.4 trillion US debt limit, with a deadline of June 1 for a possible default. The talks, set to resume on Friday, aim to break a deadlock between Democrats and Republicans over government spending. Biden offered possible compromises, including clawing back unspent coronavirus relief funds, but reiterated that Republicans must take the threat of default off the table. Economists warn that a default could lead to a deep recession and destabilize the global financial system.

images.alt_text: While Republicans seek to lift the US$31.4 trillion borrowing limit only in combination with drastic spending cuts, President Joe Biden has refused to agree to such reductions – raising fears of the first national debt default.
Although he has not yet announced his candidacy, Ron DeSantis is expected to be among the top contenders vying for the Republican presidential nomination next year.

American Airlines planes are seen at Ronald Reagan National Airport (DCA) in Arlington, Virginia, U.S., on Wednesday, Nov. 25, 2020.
