site_title: Hurdles in requisitioning EGMs point to need for changes to law, say experts
summary: Singapore's Companies Act (CA) needs legislative changes to smooth the path for shareholders requisitioning an extraordinary general meeting (EGM), experts say. A recent High Court ruling in the USP Group case found that beneficial owners of around 11% of the company, who held shares through nominee accounts, did not have standing to requisition an EGM. This decision highlights a gap in the law and has sparked calls for amendments to the CA and Securities Futures Act (SFA) to allow indirect investors to requisition meetings.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Recent boardroom tussles involving SGX-listed companies have seen varying degrees of success for requisitioning parties, and not all cases are straightforward.

While the requisition of a general meeting may be unwelcomed, boards should consider the merits of the proposals from the perspective of the issuer and its shareholders as a whole, said Tan Boon Gin, CEO of SGX RegCo.

If USP Group does not appoint auditors for an audit of its most recent financial year, release the statements, and either move to exit the watch-list or seek an extension of its cure period, the SGX RegCo will direct it to delist.
SGX has directed ASTI to hold its FY2021 and FY2022 AGM by 30 July 2023.

site_title: Investment bankers bonuses forecast to drop as much as 20% this year: report
summary: Investment bankers' bonuses are forecast to drop 10-20% this year due to dwindling deals. This is the largest proportion of decline on Wall Street. The decline is attributed to rising interest rates, economic uncertainty, and bank collapses. However, larger banks and those in debt capital markets are expected to raise bonuses by 10-20% and 5-10%, respectively. Asset management firms are expected to cut bonuses by 5-10%, while private equity and hedge funds' compensation remains unchanged.

site_title: Australian government rejects concerns budget may worsen inflation
summary: Australia's Labor government has announced a cost-of-living relief plan worth A$14.6 billion, aiming to lower power bills and ease pressure on consumer prices. Despite concerns it may worsen inflation, the government says the measures will not add to inflationary pressures. The budget includes direct energy bill relief for low-income families and small businesses, as well as increased unemployment allowances and income support payments. The government believes the relief will "take some of the sting out of inflation" and relieve pressure on the central bank to lift interest rates.

images.alt_text: The centrepiece of the budget is A$14.6 billion worth of measures over four years that include relief from high energy costs for households and small businesses.
Superannuation or retirement funds in Australia raised their investment to more than A$34 billion (S$31 billion) in companies most responsible for expanding fossil fuels, Market Forces said.
The Australian government is set to unveil in the budget financial assistance for more than 5 million low-income families, small businesses and pensioners struggling with high power bills.

site_title: Paramount cuts 25% of domestic cable staff, ends MTV News
summary: Paramount Global is reducing costs by cutting 25% of domestic cable staff and shutting down MTV News after 4 decades. The company is combining 9 teams into one and has already announced plans to merge its Showtime and MTV studios. Despite subscriber growth and new hit shows, Paramount cited economic headwinds as the reason for the cost-cutting measures. The move is part of the company's efforts to adapt to a shift away from traditional TV viewers.

site_title: EU draft rules propose tougher  cybersecurity labelling rules for Amazon, Google, Microsoft
summary: The European Union has proposed draft rules requiring US tech giants, such as Amazon, Google, and Microsoft, to establish a joint venture with an EU-based company to obtain a cybersecurity label for handling sensitive data. The joint venture must be operated and maintained from the EU, with employees accessing EU data undergoing specific screening and located within the bloc. The rules aim to mitigate interference from non-EU states and protect EU data rights and privacy, but are likely to spark criticism from US tech giants worried about being shut out from the European market.

images.alt_text: VNG's 12,400-square-meter data centre located Ho Chi Minh City in January is one of the three DCs in Vietnam that achieve both Tier-III certifications of design documents and constructed facility by Uptime Institute
The Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) pushed through new rules requiring data exports to undergo security reviews last year.
MAS and Treasury also reviewed the lessons gleaned from the exercise and discussed possible enhancements and the involvement of other international partners in future exercises.
Teamwork is crucial in modern cybersecurity and allows for true organisational resilience.
In today’s hurried digital world, younger, tech-savvier people are making up a larger proportion of victims.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Sasseur Reit, Sembcorp, Olam, Best World, Grand Venture
summary: OCBC announced a record S$1.9 billion net profit for its first quarter of 2023, a 39% increase. Sasseur Reit posted a 1.5% increase in distribution per unit to S$0.01849, driven by strong sales growth. Sembcorp Industries is a potential bidder for SembWaste, with a possible valuation of US$500 million. Olam Group plans a dual IPO in Singapore and Saudi Arabia, while Best World's net profit fell 25.7% to S$20.5 million.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Top US Federal Reserve official does not rule out further rate hike
summary: US Federal Reserve President John Williams left open the possibility of further interest rate hikes to combat stubborn inflation, despite citing "incredible progress" over the past year. Williams stated that the Fed will be data-dependent in its future decisions and does not see a need to cut interest rates this year. He also emphasized the need to keep a restrictive stance of policy to bring inflation down, suggesting that interest rates may remain high for some time.

images.alt_text: Against a basket of currencies, the US dollar index edges up 0.1 per cent to 101.5, but remains near recent low as traders eye a peak in US interest rates.

The US Treasury Department in Washington, DC, on May 8, 2023. - US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned on May 7, 2023, that unless Congress acts soon to raise the nation's debt ceiling, "financial and economic chaos would ensue." US President Joe Biden will meet with the top Republicans and Democrats from Congress to breach the impasse. (Photo by Mandel NGAN / AFP)
The central bank has raised interest rates at the fastest pace since the 1980s as it tried to catch up to surging inflation that it was slow to forecast and respond to.

A shopper at the Shein pop-up store in New York, US, on Friday, Oct. 28, 2022. Shein, the online retailer that has turbocharged the global fast-fashion industry, is planning to deepen its foothold in the US as its sales to American shoppers continue to soar, the Wall Street Journal reports. site_title: Asean must press on with regional integration in increasingly troubled world: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of regional integration in the face of an increasingly troubled global environment. During the 42nd Asean Summit in Labuan Bajo, Indonesia, Lee called for deeper cooperation on transnational issues, such as human trafficking and cybersecurity. He also welcomed two key statements on Asean's post-2025 vision and strengthening the bloc's institutional effectiveness. Lee highlighted the need to upgrade core agreements and strengthen energy interconnectivity, as well as support the development of the Asean Digital Economy Framework Agreement.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Better known as a gateway to the famed Komodo Island, the normally idyllic Labuan Bajo has been abuzz with activity in the lead-up to the Asean Summit, which will be held at Meruorah Komodo Labuan Bajo
Timor-Leste made its debut as an observer at the Asean Coordinating Council meeting in February, after receiving in-principle approval to join Asean in November 2022.

site_title: Airbnb slides as muted outlook shows cracks in travel demand
summary: Airbnb's shares plummeted 10% to $114.25 after the company reported a cautious forecast for revenue in the second quarter, citing rising prices and economic uncertainty. The San Francisco-based home-sharing company expects revenue of $2.35-$2.45 billion, a 12-16% increase from last year, but slower than expected. This comes amid a post-Covid rush to travel losing steam, and consumers reining in leisure budgets due to inflation and an unsteady economy.

images.alt_text: Airbnb currently partners with 250 buildings that allow renters to lease their apartments part-time on the home-sharing platform.
Airbnb has been one of the few tech firms to avoid mass layoffs, while many peers have cut their growth expectations amid higher interest rates and a sector-wide slowdown.

site_title: Sasseur Reit Q1 DPU up 1.5% to S$0.01849 after retention
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Chinese outlet mall REIT, reported a 1.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01849 for Q1 2023, its highest since listing. Strong sales performance, driven by pent-up consumer spending, contributed to the increase. However, distributable income fell 4% to S$23.7 million and rental income fell 2.1% to S$33.1 million. The REIT maintained a prudent aggregate leverage of 25.7%.

images.alt_text: Analysts believe that the rebounding Chinese economy would continue to benefit CLCT and Sasseur Reit, even though challenges from rising interest rates could still weigh on the broader Reits segment.
An outlet mall in Chongqing which is part of Sasseur Reit’s portfolio.
New Tech Park in Lorong Chuan is among the portfolio properties of Sabana Industrial Reit, which is among the 10 trusts with the lowest gearing ratios reported.
Dasin Retail Trust is the only China-focused S-Reit to register a gain in unit price after China on Dec 7 announced the nationwide loosening of Covid restrictions.
An outlet mall in Chongqing, which is part of Sasseur Reit’s portfolio. The Reit manager's CFO is under investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: US: Stocks close lower ahead of inflation data
summary: US stocks closed 0.2% lower on Tuesday ahead of key inflation data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing at 33,561.81. Investors were cautious, awaiting the Federal Reserve's upcoming monetary policy decisions, which will be influenced by the consumer price data. The market is also watching talks between President Biden and Republican leaders on fiscal issues. Market analysts expressed a "wait and see" approach, with one stating, "It's a wait and see."

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 4, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Apple may be bigger but Aramco’s soaring dividend is unmatched
summary: Saudi Aramco, the world's largest publicly traded oil company, is set to increase its dividend payouts by over $20 billion in 2023, exceeding those of the next five largest global payers combined. The firm's shareholder payouts, excluding buybacks, already surpass those of Apple, despite Apple's larger market cap. The increased dividend payout will be closely monitored by Aramco shareholders, with analysts forecasting a 10-20% increase in the dividend stream at current oil prices.

site_title: Trump found liable for sexually abusing writer
summary: A New York jury found Donald Trump liable for sexually abusing and defaming writer E. Jean Carroll, ordering him to pay $5 million in damages. The jury rejected her accusation of rape but upheld other complaints, including defaming her after she went public with the allegation in 2019. Trump immediately rejected the verdict, calling it a "disgrace" and a "hoax." The verdict marks the first time Trump has faced legal consequences over a string of sexual assault allegations dating back decades.

images.alt_text: Although he has not yet announced his candidacy, Ron DeSantis is expected to be among the top contenders vying for the Republican presidential nomination next year.

Trump is also being investigated over his efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss in the southern state of Georgia, his alleged mishandling of classified documents taken from the White House and his involvement in the storming of the US Capitol by his supporters on January 6, 2021.
Former US president Donald Trump (left) takes the stage with New Hampshire Republican leaders, before addressing a crowd during a rally in Manchester, New Hampshire, USA, April 27, 2023.

site_title: Uncertainties remain about the return of the haze this year
summary: Malaysia is experiencing haze from open burning, with air pollution indicators briefly spiking into the unhealthy range in parts of the country. The situation remains under control, but health authorities caution residents to limit their time outdoors and mask up if the haze worsens. Weather forecasts are uncertain, with increasing heat and dry spells expected to worsen by May or June, potentially affecting neighboring countries in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Bangkok and other Thai cities have grappled with poor air quality in recent years, with pollution tending to get worse in the dry season around December to April due largely to agricultural burning, forest fires and higher vehicular emission.

site_title: FLCT’s Robert Wallace to stay on until Aug 1
summary: FLCT's manager has agreed with Robert Wallace to extend his effective date of cessation as CEO from June 1 to August 1. Wallace was initially set to step down due to family reasons, with a successor to be announced. The Reit manager is in an advanced stage of recruiting Wallace's replacement, and FLCT units closed at S$1.31, down 2.2% on the day.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: SMEs can start small, tap available grants when adopting sustainable practices
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can start adopting sustainable practices by tapping available grants and reducing business costs. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong said SMEs can install energy-efficient appliances to contribute to the country's sustainability efforts. This move can ease their transition to more sustainable practices, now that climate change is a pressing issue that won't wait for economic recovery. The initiative encourages SMEs to start small and make a positive impact on the environment.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
BT Sustainability Dialogue 2023: Linus Goh (left), head of global commercial banking, OCBC Bank; Gan Kim Yong, Minister for Trade and Industry.

From left: Prof Leo Tan, chairman of Garden City Fund,  Kenneth Er, CEO of NParks, Helen Wong, group CEO of OCBC and Desmond Lee, Minister for National Development & Minister-in-charge of Social Services Integration.

Iris Ng, the business head of middle market for global commercial banking at OCBC, said the bank has in the past two years accorded green loans to more than 500 SMEs. Only one of three of them provided the bank with a green certificate to validate the green criteria.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall on downbeat earnings, SBB hits five-year low
summary: European shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday due to weak corporate earnings, with the Stoxx 600 index hitting a five-year low. The real estate sector was particularly affected, with SBB falling 24.2% after halting dividend payments and scrapping a share issue. Investors await US economic data for clarity on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy plans, with policymakers suggesting interest rates may need to be raised for longer than anticipated.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.2 per cent lower at 33,561.81 on Tuesday.

site_title: Catalysing a shift to sustainability among SMEs
summary: Singaporean Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong and OCBC Bank's Head of Global Commercial Banking Linus Goh emphasized the importance of SMEs adopting sustainable practices. The pressure points are coming from consumers, regulations, and emerging industries, with investors and banks increasingly demanding sustainable businesses. Gan noted that if SMEs don't embark on sustainability, they will be left behind, and green financing may become the default. Linus Goh highlighted the OCBC SME financing framework and the growing availability of green financing, which will become more prevalent in the future.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
BT Sustainability Dialogue 2023: Anita Gabriel, Senior Correspondent, The Business Times

site_title: Occidental buys back 6.5% of Warren Buffett’s preferred stock
summary: Occidental Petroleum redeemed US$647 million, or 6.5% of Warren Buffett's preferred stock, four years after he helped finance its acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum. The redemption includes a 10% premium to Buffett and matches distributions to common shareholders. Occidental's adjusted earnings were US$1.09 a share in the first quarter, missing the consensus, and the stock dropped 1.6% in after-market trading. Berkshire Hathaway, Buffett's conglomerate, owns a 24% stake in Occidental common stock and is willing to buy more, but ruled out buying the oil producer outright.

site_title: Rivian reports better-than-expected loss, affirms EV output plan
summary: Rivian Automotive reported a narrower-than-expected loss of $1.25 per share in the first quarter, with revenue of $661 million matching Wall Street projections. The company reaffirmed plans to build 50,000 vehicles this year, despite supply-chain snags and operational challenges. Efforts to cut costs and simplify production plans have buoyed the electric vehicle maker. Rivian also reiterated a forecast for a $4.3 billion loss for 2023, excluding certain items, and aims to reach profitability in 2024.

images.alt_text: Rivian R1T electric vehicle pickup trucks at the company's manufacturing facility in Normal, Illinois. Photographer: Jamie Kelter Davis/Bloomberg

site_title: Price war squeezes Chinese carmakers with no relief in sight
summary: China's car price war is squeezing automakers, with steep discounts failing to boost sales. Most top-listed Chinese carmakers suffered a decline in profits, with only BYD and Changan Automobile Group posting increases. Electric vehicle (EV) upstarts Xpeng and Zhejiang Leapmotor Technologies saw sales plummet 50% year-over-year. Revenue and profit margins are under pressure, with only three companies posting an increase in profits. The industry is shifting towards EVs, but traditional carmakers face profitability challenges. Changan Automobile may be a bright spot, gaining market share and setting a deadline to phase out petrol cars by 2025.

images.alt_text: China’s crowded auto market is getting even more congested, with nearly 300 models displayed at the Shanghai auto show in April.
BYD, China’s biggest EV brand, is building its first overseas production facility in Thailand.

site_title: EA sales, profit top estimates on results from soccer title
summary: Electronic Arts (EA) reported record revenue for its fiscal fourth quarter, beating analysts' estimates with $1.95 billion in quarterly bookings, a 11% increase. Adjusted earnings rose to $1.77 per share, surpassing estimates of $1.31. The company attributed the success to its popular soccer title, FIFA 23, which achieved the most successful launch in the franchise's history. EA is retiring the FIFA brand and launching EA Sports FC later this year, while revenue from live-services games, including FIFA, Apex Legends, and The Sims, increased nearly 10% to $5.49 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People play Electronic Arts' "FIFA" video game at the Microsoft Xbox booth at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, in Los Angeles, California, United States, June 16, 2015. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo

site_title: Virgin Galactic earnings miss as it plans new flights
summary: Virgin Galactic reported Q1 revenue of $0.39 million, missing estimates of $1.37 million, and lost 57 cents per share, exceeding expectations of a 52 cents-per-share loss. The company expects to begin commercial spaceflights in June, with its first mission for the Italian Air Force. Shares fell 1.7% after the announcement, despite a 18% climb in the year to date. The company's first full passenger flight is set for the end of May, marking the first powered trip of its VSS Unity spaceplane since July 2021.

images.alt_text: Oita prefecture had estimated the spaceport, similar to Virgin Orbit’s Cornwall, England facility, would produce economic benefits worth about 10.2 billion yen (S$101 million) in the region over the five years from the initial launch.

site_title: ISS backs all 4 ValueAct director candidates in Seven & I boardroom fight
summary: ISS backs ValueAct's director candidates for Seven & i Holdings, recommending shareholders elect all four US investment firm's nominees. ValueAct, which owns 4.4% of the company, has criticized Seven & i's conglomerate structure and called for a strategic review, including spinning off its 7-Eleven chain or selling the entire company. ISS cited poor performance, capital allocation, and a lack of urgency in reforms, stating that ValueAct's nominees bring board experience and executive experience, and would add a shareholder perspective.

images.alt_text: ValueAct said Seven & i should narrow its business focus to 7-Eleven, which it said could become a global champion as a convenience store franchise and boost the company’s value.

site_title: Indonesia became second largest cobalt producer in 2022
summary: Indonesia became the world's second-largest cobalt supplier in 2022, accounting for nearly 5% of global production. The country's cobalt production surged to 9,500 tonnes, surpassing Australia and the Philippines. Global demand rose 13% to 187,000 tonnes, with electric vehicles accounting for 40% of total demand. Indonesia has the potential to increase cobalt production by 10 times by 2030, according to the Cobalt Institute.

images.alt_text: An excavator loads raw nickel ore into a dump truck at a nickel mining site of Vale in Sorowako, South Sulawesi province, Indonesia, March 29, 2023.

site_title: Greenwashing by association – the new threat facing corporates
summary: Companies can be accused of greenwashing even if they don't make false or misleading claims, due to associations with parties guilty of greenwashing. A new report by the Asia Investor Group on Climate Change and ClientEarth highlights examples, including intermediaries representing green portfolios, companies not meeting net-zero alliance commitments, and funding organizations opposing Paris Agreement-aligned goals. To avoid this, companies should conduct due diligence, verify green claims, and be transparent about issues. Strengthening regulation against greenwashing and familiarizing individuals within the company with their obligations are also crucial.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Industrial.
Is your ‘eco-friendly’ shirt really ‘green’?

The desire to save the planet has spurred more and more consumers and investors to be more conscious of where they put their money in recent years, but their enthusiasm to do so can be easily exploited by corporates that want to maximise earnings.

site_title: UK unveils pharmacies plan to ease NHS pressure
summary: The UK government has unveiled plans to allow pharmacies to prescribe certain medications, aiming to ease pressure on the NHS and reduce waiting lists. The move, which will be introduced this winter, will enable pharmacists to prescribe treatments for seven common conditions, including earaches and sore throats. The plan is part of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's efforts to address the NHS's staffing shortages and rising costs, following recent strikes by health workers protesting over stagnant wages. The measure is expected to help free up millions of appointments for those in need.

site_title: Vietnam’s renewable power output under strain amid  record heatwave
summary: Vietnam is facing a strain on its renewable power output due to record-breaking heatwaves, which have lowered hydropower output and put pressure on the country's energy supply. The majority of Vietnam's wind and solar energy capacity remains uncommercialized, exacerbating the issue. State-owned power company Vietnam Electricity has warned of potential power shortages in northern Vietnam, citing reduced hydropower output and rising coal prices. The country aims to increase its renewable energy capacity to 158GW by 2030, but the current strain on renewable power sources poses significant challenges to meeting this goal.

images.alt_text: Wind turbines, including some from RWE's new Kaskasi offshore wind farm, are pictured during the opening of the RWE-Offshore-Windpark Kaskasi, north of Helgoland, Germany, March 23, 2023.    Christian Charisius/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Goldman, Microsoft, Cboe and others team up to launch blockchain network
summary: A group of financial institutions, including Goldman Sachs, Microsoft, and Cboe Global Markets, are launching the Canton Network, a blockchain system aiming to connect disparate institutional applications. The network, which will start testing in July, promises better privacy and controls than existing systems, and will enable the linking of blockchain apps created using Daml. With over 30 firms participating, the initiative aims to facilitate broader adoption of distributed ledger technology in financial markets and simplify complex processes.

site_title: US small business sentiment slumps to more than 10-year low
summary: US small business confidence dropped to a 10-year low in April, with a 1.1-point decline in the National Federation of Independent Business's Small Business Optimism Index to 89.0, the lowest since January 2013. Concerns about the near-term economic outlook and worker shortages are contributing to the decline. However, economists note that credit conditions for small businesses remain accessible, with 30% reporting that all their credit needs were met. The decline in sentiment may be a sign of an economic slowdown, but economists caution against reading too much into the drop.

images.alt_text: Owners of small businesses are worried that sharp rent increases and a lack of protections for commercial tenants could shut down their stores, just as the economy is gaining momentum.

site_title: Amazon is bringing its online store to gaming, mobile apps
summary: Amazon has introduced "Amazon Anywhere," a service allowing users to buy related real-world items within gaming, mobile, web, and augmented-reality applications without leaving the experience. The service debuts with Peridot, an AR game featuring virtual pets, and lets users link their Amazon accounts to purchase items, which are delivered from Amazon warehouses. This move aims to extend Amazon's reach beyond its online marketplace, competing with Shopify and other e-commerce software sellers.

site_title: Tackle the decline in the local stock market
summary: The Singapore stock market has declined significantly over the past five years, from S$1.1 trillion in 2017 to approximately S$815 billion in 2023. This decline is attributed to low liquidity, poor valuations, and a lack of confidence among investors, resulting in more companies delisting than going public. As of April 2023, there are only 630 listed entities compared to 752 in 2017.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said on May 3 that no decision on a pause had been made yet, but highlighted the change in rhetoric in the Fed's statement
Slowing global growth on top of rising interest rates had been a concern for the equity market, resulting in a generally flat market in April, said Paul Chew, head of Phillips Securities Research.

site_title: Grand Venture Q1 net profit after tax falls 58.3% on weaker semiconductor activity
summary: Grand Venture Technology reported a 58.3% fall in net profit after tax to S$1.5 million for Q1, driven by a 37.1% decline in semiconductor revenue to S$13.7 million. Revenue from the electronics, aerospace, medical, and others segment rose 48.9% to S$8.5 million. The company plans to diversify its revenue and onboard new back-end semiconductor customers. Despite a muted semiconductor industry outlook for Q1, Grand Venture expects industry momentum to pick up in the latter half of the year.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Grand Venture Tech in talks with third party for potential share subscription

site_title: Fox beats estimates for quarterly revenue
summary: Fox Corp reported quarterly revenue of $4.08 billion, beating estimates of $4.03 billion. The company's shares rose over 3% in premarket trading. This upbeat result underscores the cautious approach of advertisers buying ad slots on dominant networks amid economic conditions. The revenue growth is attributed to a range of sports channels operated by Fox.

site_title: US homebuyers persevere despite high rates, prices
summary: US homebuyers remain committed to purchasing properties despite rising interest rates, high inflation, and slowing growth. According to a Bank of America survey, 54% of respondents plan to speed up or stick to their original home purchase plans. Buying a home is a priority for Gen Z and millennials, who show "extreme resilience" in the competitive market. The dream of home ownership remains alive, despite the challenges.

images.alt_text: Homebuying remains muted, particularly in the newly-built luxury condo towers in downtown San Francisco, where half-empty office buildings were left behind by remote workers now living in less expensive locations.

site_title: Transforming capitalism for the common good?
summary: Stakeholder capitalism, a system prioritizing all private actors in society, seeks to balance economic development with the greater good. This approach contrasts with shareholder capitalism, focusing solely on shareholder interests, and state capitalism, where the state controls resource distribution. Proponents, including the Business Roundtable, argue that stakeholder capitalism enables corporations to manage for the benefit of customers, employees, suppliers, communities, and shareholders. The concept has evolved from earlier ideas, such as the Modern Corporation and Private Property, and is increasingly relevant in addressing challenges like climate change, where corporations must consider transition risks and balance competing interests.

images.alt_text: As the apex body, the board sets the tone for corporate morality by encouraging and reinforcing moral reasoning and behaviour. PHOTO:
No need for Asia to be woke - Responsible Capitalism through an Asian lens
For CEOs in Asia, purpose matters now, more than ever

site_title: Indonesia confirms outbreak of African swine fever, WOAH says
summary: Indonesia has confirmed an outbreak of African swine fever on a farm in the Riau Islands, near Singapore, according to the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH). The outbreak, detected on April 1, killed 35,297 pigs out of a herd of 285,034 on Bulan island. The disease, fatal to pigs but not to humans, has plagued China in recent years, causing significant declines in meat output and global market disruptions.

site_title: After US$1.8 billion of outflows, Asia’s worst-performing stock market is set for election boost
summary: Thailand's stock market, Asia's worst-performing this year, is expected to receive a boost from the upcoming general election on May 14. Despite a macro backdrop unfavorable to stocks, with foreign investors withdrawing nearly $1.8 billion, optimism is high with opposition parties projected to win a majority, promising economic stimulus. Analysts expect the SET Index to rally, with domestic-oriented sectors like banking, commerce, and healthcare historically outperforming during election periods.

images.alt_text: epa10424388 A Thai clothing rental vendor assists Chinese tourists dressing in Thai traditional costumes, during a visit to Wat Arun or Temple of Dawn in Bangkok, Thailand, 23 January 2023. Thailand's tourism and business related activities are in recovery stimulated by the influx of Chinese tourists after China lifted COVID-19 travel restrictions. Thailand is projected to welcome five million Chinese visitors in 2023 with 29,4000 tourists from mainland China expected to arrive during Lunar New Year, according to the Tourism Authority of Thailand.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT
Daniel Bian, a Chinese potential property buyer from Shanghai, visits a luxury condominium in Bangkok, Thailand, April 20, 2023.
Sunday’s voters are among more than 52 million who will elect 500 candidates to Thailand’s House of Representatives.

site_title: Oil recoups losses on plans for SPR refill, higher seasonal demand
summary: Oil prices rose 0.6-0.8% on Tuesday, reversing a 2.5% drop earlier in the session, as the US government plans to refill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve and anticipated higher seasonal demand. Brent crude settled at $77.44 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude closed at $73.71 a barrel. The Energy Information Administration also forecast higher seasonal demand and lower-than-expected output, supporting prices.

images.alt_text: An oil pump jack at the New Harmony Oil Field in Grayville, Illinois, US, on Sunday, June 19, 2022. Top Biden administration officials are weighing limits on exports of fuel as the White House struggles to contain gasoline prices that have topped $5 per gallon. Photographer: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 28.84 points, or 0.09%, to 33,589.85. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with declines of 13.87 points, or 0.34%, and 61.14 points, or 0.50%, respectively. The falls were attributed to dour earnings forecasts and a debt-ceiling deadlock, with investors focusing on a fresh tariff salvo by Donald Trump on Canada.

site_title: G7 to discuss strengthening global banking system
summary: G7 finance leaders will discuss strengthening the global banking system amid recent US bank failures and concerns over digital bank runs. The meeting, chaired by Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki, will also address the US debt ceiling woes and steps to prevent Russia from circumventing sanctions. Japan aims to issue a joint statement stressing the need for authorities to remain vigilant to banking sector woes, building on a previous G7 statement in April that emphasized the need for stability and resilience.

images.alt_text: Brokered by the United Nations (UN) and Turkey, the deal was signed in Istanbul last July, allowing Ukraine to export more than 27 million tonnes of grain from several of its Black Sea ports.

site_title: Goldman to pay US$215 million to end case on underpaying women
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay US$215 million to settle a class-action lawsuit alleging the bank systemically underpaid women. The deal, reached with lawyers representing about 2,800 female associates and vice-presidents, includes US$150 million in direct compensation and US$65 million in attorney fees. The settlement follows a long-running case that could have provided insight into inequality in the financial industry, with the trial set to examine pay and promotion statistics and workplace culture.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A Goldman Sachs sign is seen above their booth on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, January 19, 2011. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid (UNITED STATES - Tags: BUSINESS)/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s ex-leader arrested
summary: Pakistan's ousted Prime Minister Imran Khan was arrested on May 9 by paramilitary troops at a court hearing in Islamabad, amid a growing political crisis. The arrest escalates tensions between the current government and Khan, who has openly challenged the military and government, and faces dozens of court cases on charges including terrorism and corruption. Khan's popularity has remained high, with analysts suggesting his arrest may further escalate the turmoil, potentially leading to mass unrest.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Police officers walk past the Supreme Court of Pakistan building, in Islamabad, Pakistan April 6, 2022. REUTERS/Akhtar Soomro/File Photo

site_title: China to implement stricter vehicle emissions standards from Jul 1
summary: China will implement stricter vehicle emissions standards nationwide from July 1, banning the production, imports, and sales of vehicles that do not meet the National VI B emission standards. The new standards include stricter requirements on pollutants and require Real-Driving Emission tests on the road. Automakers and dealers are under pressure to clear inventories of old models, leading to aggressive discounts. A six-month grace period has been granted for light vehicles that do not meet the RDE test requirements.

site_title: Best World Q1 net profit falls 25.7 per cent to S$20.5 million
summary: Best World International reported a 25.7% decline in Q1 net profit to S$20.5 million, down from S$27.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 30.8% to S$80 million due to lower contributions from its franchise segment. Management attributed the decline to factors such as increased travel during the festive season, lower consumer sentiment, and strong headwinds from macroeconomic challenges. The company maintains a cautious outlook for the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Best World International reported a 7.1 per cent year on year dip in net profit to S$47.7 million.

site_title: Lionel Messi: The ‘greatest’ leaves PSG on low note
summary: Lionel Messi's two-year stint at Paris Saint-Germain is ending with a move to Saudi Arabia, where he will join Cristiano Ronaldo at Al Nassr. The move, which is reportedly a "done deal," marks a low note in Messi's career, coming after a suspension for making an unauthorized trip to Saudi Arabia. Messi has won numerous titles and accolades throughout his career, including seven Ballon d'Or awards, and is widely regarded as one of the greatest footballers of all time. His departure from PSG and potential retirement are seen as a significant end to his European career.

images.alt_text: The deal would far exceed the more than US$200 million deal Cristiano Ronaldo signed to play in Saudi Arabia until the summer of 2025.
“He cannot train, cannot play, and will not be paid while disciplinary measures are in place,” a source says Lionel Messi would be sidelined for “several days”.

site_title: Ryanair orders 300 Boeing 737 MAX jets worth US$40 billion
summary: Ryanair has ordered 300 Boeing 737 MAX jets worth over $40 billion, the largest order by an Irish company for US-manufactured goods. The deal, comprising 150 firm orders and 150 options, is subject to shareholder approval at Ryanair's annual general meeting in September. The jets, set for delivery between 2027 and 2033, are expected to significantly boost Boeing's sales as the aviation sector recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Ryanair to begin 737 MAX roll-out with UK market

site_title: Tesco chairman accused of inappropriate behaviour
summary: Tesco chairman John Allan is facing allegations of inappropriate behavior, including a claim that he touched a senior female employee's bottom at a 2022 shareholder meeting. Allan "strongly denies" the allegation, and Tesco stated there have been no complaints about his conduct during his eight-year tenure as chairman. The allegations, made by four women, also relate to Allan's time as president of the Confederation of British Industry from 2018-2020.

images.alt_text: The CBI said Danker “is dismissed with immediate effect, following the independent investigation into specific complaints of workplace misconduct against him”.

site_title: Acra hauls USP Group to court for not holding AGM
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) is taking action against USP Group for failing to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) within four months after the end of its financial year. USP Group will appear at the State Courts on May 24, facing a charge under Section 175(4)(a) of the Companies Act for defaulting on the AGM. The company is seeking legal advice and will provide updates to shareholders. This comes after a group of shareholders attempted to requisition an EGM to remove the existing board of directors.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Judicial Commissioner Goh Yihan declared the requisition notice for USP Group's upcoming EGM invalid, as the requisitioning shareholders were not deemed as “members” of USP under the Companies Act.
Minority shareholders of watch-listed USP Group are looking to take the company out of the watchlist by gaining control of its board and injecting it with new projects.

site_title: Porsche to incorporate Mobileye automated driving and navigation software
summary: Porsche is set to integrate Mobileye's "SuperVision" technology platform into its future models, providing automated assistance and navigation functions. This marks the technology provider's second major partnership with a large automotive group, following Geely in China. Mobileye's "SuperVision" system enables drivers to take their hands off the wheel, following navigation routes, changing lanes, and overtaking slower vehicles. The collaboration comes as Volkswagen's software unit Cariad expands its partnership base, following a leadership overhaul. The move aims to boost Porsche's autonomous driving capabilities.

site_title: IBM unveils new watsonx, AI and data platform
summary: IBM unveiled its new AI and data platform, watsonx, to help companies integrate AI into their business. The platform, launched after a decade since IBM's Watson software won the Jeopardy game show, offers lower costs for implementing large language AI models. IBM CEO Arvind Krishna stated that AI could reduce certain back office jobs, but not total employment, allowing for more investment in value-creating activities. The platform enables companies to train and deploy AI models, generate code, and use various large language models for different purposes, such as chemical creation or climate change modeling.

images.alt_text: Arvind Krishna in an interview in New York on May 1.

site_title: Vietnam trade falls sharply as economy faces slowdown
summary: Vietnam's exports and imports fell sharply in the first four months of the year, with exports declining 13% to US$107.1 billion and imports falling 17.7% to US$99.6 billion. This is despite a trade surplus of US$7.5 billion. The decline in exports, particularly in the smartphone sector, has raised concerns about the country's growth target of 6.5% this year. Lawmakers have urged the central bank to cut policy rates further to support the economy, and the government is planning to cut its value-added tax to boost consumption.

images.alt_text: Vietnam’s growth slowed from 5.92 per cent in late 2022 to 3.32 per cent in the first quarter of 2023, prompting the SBV to cut its benchmark rates twice this year.

site_title: US dollar edges up as market looks to US debt ceiling talks, inflation data
summary: The US dollar edged up 0.1% to 101.5 against a basket of currencies, awaiting US debt ceiling talks and new inflation data for a clearer economic outlook. Traders eye a peak in US interest rates, while the euro dipped 0.2% and the Japanese yen rose 0.3% amid Bank of Japan comments on yield curve control. The closely watched US inflation data due on Wednesday will set the tone for markets, with the Federal Reserve's policy tweaks weighed against a backdrop of US banking turmoil and a debt ceiling impasse.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are displayed in this illustration taken, February 14, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Dyna-Mac’s Q1 net profit more than doubles to S$3.9 million
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings reported a net profit of S$3.9 million for the first quarter of 2023, more than doubling from S$1.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 29.3% to S$87.3 million, driven by higher gross profit from projects carried out during the period. The company aims to execute projects successfully and expand its production capacities to meet growing demand, with a net order book of S$338.1 million as of March 31.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The company is expected to secure larger orders with potentially higher margins, including another estimated S$600 million worth of orders by the fourth quarter of 2023, says Maybank KE.

site_title: Sri Lanka Supreme Court clears path for decriminalisation of homosexuality
summary: Sri Lanka's Supreme Court has cleared the path for the decriminalization of homosexuality, ruling that a proposed bill is not unconstitutional. The decision, made after hearing over a dozen petitions, allows for the bill to proceed through Parliament, where it still needs support from 225 lawmakers. Activists hail the ruling as a "historic development" and a major step forward for LGBTQ+ rights in the country. The next steps for the bill to become legislation are unclear, with neither the government nor opposition making a comment on their support.

images.alt_text: Army cadets patrol in a boat in front of Sri Lankan parliament building in Colombo on July 16, 2022. - Sri Lanka's ousted president did his "utmost" to avoid an economic catastrophe but the coronavirus pandemic derailed his efforts, he said in his resignation letter read out to parliament on July 16. (Photo by Arun SANKAR / AFP)

While Sri Lanka president Ranil Wickremesinghe has been credited with bringing about some normalcy to the country, he has been criticised for aligning with the Rajapaksas, and clamping down on protests.

site_title: How to build a giant? Sauropod dinosaurs did it 36 different ways
summary: A new study has calculated that 36 different sauropod dinosaur lineages evolved to achieve massive proportions over 100 million years, reaching lengths of 100-120 feet and weighing up to 76 tonnes. These massive land animals, including Argentinosaurus and Brachiosaurus, varied in size, diet, growth rates, and metabolism, with some having hollow bones and air-filled cavities to save weight. Contrary to a 19th-century hypothesis, size offered advantages such as reduced predation, access to food, and wider geographic range.

images.alt_text: Scientific and popular culture depictions of Tyrannosaurus and other meat-eating dinosaurs - think of the T rex in the 1993 movie Jurassic Park - often have shown their teeth as exposed like those of crocodiles.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Tuesday amid mixed regional trading; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,242.95, down 14.71 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 315 to 250, with 1.3 billion securities worth S$925.5 million changing hands. The decline follows mixed regional trading, with key indices in the region tracking Monday's mixed close on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.4%

site_title: Novavax lays off 25% of workforce, releases 2023 outlook
summary: Novavax is laying off 25% of its workforce, approximately 498 jobs, as part of its cost-reduction measures. The biotech company expects total annual revenue of $1.4-$1.6 billion and aims to slash expenses by 20-25%. The layoffs come after the company reported a net loss of $293.9 million in the first quarter, despite a successful trial for its Covid/flu combination vaccine candidate. Novavax hopes its cost controls and successful trial will help it stay afloat amid tepid demand for its Covid-19 vaccines.

site_title: Timor-Leste’s path to Asean membership
summary: East Timor, also known as Timor-Leste, is set to make its debut as an observer at the 42nd Asean Summit in Indonesia, following in-principle approval to join the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) last November. The country, which was a Portuguese colony for nearly 300 years and gained independence in 2002, has been on a decade-long journey to join the bloc, with the first of three fact-finding missions conducted in 2019. An "objective criteria-based roadmap" for Timor-Leste's full membership will be formalized and tabled at the summit, with potential benefits including expanded diplomatic relations, increased foreign investment, and improved education and employment opportunities.

images.alt_text: The half-island nation will also be granted observer status at high-level Asean meetings, the bloc said after regional leaders met in Phnom Penh to discuss the issue.
Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan says amid global political fragmentation, Singapore must continue to support and uphold the rule of international law.

site_title: High-tech solutions for a net-zero world will come from Asia
summary: Asia is poised to lead the transition to a net-zero world with growing momentum behind global clean energy investment. The International Energy Agency predicts a total annual clean energy investment of $5 trillion by 2030, creating millions of jobs in renewables, energy efficiency, and related industries. Key countries like China are driving innovation, with leading companies in renewable energy components, EV batteries, and energy-efficient data centers. This shift is expected to boost global GDP and transform Asia from a predominantly coal-powered region into a climate leader.

images.alt_text: If-Cap financing will contribute to ADB’s raised ambition for US$100 billion from its own resources for climate change from 2019 to 2030.
Transition finance has been slow to address the coal challenge, but there are good reasons to be cautious.

site_title: Those who improve crew welfare deserve recognition
summary: The Seafarers Happiness Index's latest report shows a decline in overall satisfaction levels among vessel crews, falling to 7.1 out of 10 in Q1 2023 from 7.69/10 in Q4 2022. The report highlights the need for recognition of those who improve crew welfare. Nominations for the sixth annual Seafarers Awards 2023 are now open, recognizing individuals and organizations that contribute to seafarer welfare.

images.alt_text: Three sub-themes for the maritime industry were present during Singapore Maritime Week: ensuring steady progress for decarbonisation, aligning international standards in the move towards greater digitalisation, and redoubling efforts to attract and nurture talent.

site_title: StanChart to hire 100 staff for new China investment banking unit
summary: Standard Chartered plans to hire at least 100 staff in China for its new investment banking unit, targeting niche bond deals, by the end of this year. The unit, launched in January, aims to help local companies raise capital through exchange-traded fixed-income issuance, focusing on bonds and asset-backed securities worth over $3.8 trillion. The hiring comes as foreign entrants expand their onshore investment banking units in China, amid heightened competition and growing demand for China's fixed income market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Standard Chartered bank logo is seen at their headquarters in London, Britain, July 26, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Elon Musk and Tesla break ground on massive Texas lithium refinery
summary: Elon Musk and Tesla broke ground on a massive Texas lithium refinery, aiming to produce enough battery metal to build about 1 million electric vehicles by 2025. The facility, the largest North American processor of lithium, will push Tesla outside its core focus and make it the only major automaker in North America to refine its own lithium. Musk said the move is necessary to meet Tesla's ambitious EV sales targets and make Texas self-reliant in lithium production.

images.alt_text: Tesla has cut prices globally since January, including in the United States, seeking to drive volume, especially for its mass-market cars, the Model Y crossover and the Model 3 sedan.
Telsa has posted record deliveries in the January-March quarter, but deliveries of higher-priced Model X and Model S vehicles have slumped by 38 per cent.

site_title: Britons will get poorer faster than their wealthy peers, survey shows
summary: The UK is poised to experience a faster decline in living standards compared to other developed economies, according to a Bloomberg poll. Wages adjusted for price growth are falling by over 3% due to inflation outpacing pay raises, with essentials like energy bills and groceries rising even faster. The UK's housing market is also expected to decline, with prices down around 3% from their peak, and investors favoring the FTSE 100 index over other UK investments. A majority of respondents also called for a new government to address the country's economic prospects.

images.alt_text: The final S&P Global-CIPS UK services PMI rose to 55.9 from 52.9 in March, above the 50 threshold for growth and higher than a provisional reading of 54.9.

site_title: Swedish home construction set to plummet this year, Nordea says
summary: Sweden's housing market is expected to plummet this year, with new-home construction likely to start on 22,500 dwellings, down 67% from 2021. This contraction is forecasted to contribute to a 1.2% economic output decline in 2023, as falling housing prices and lower household spending weigh on the economy. The housing market's rapid price decline after rising interest rates has made it a global example of the effects of inflation on housing markets.

site_title: SIA Engineering CEO says aviation recovery uncertain as economy wobbles
summary: SIA Engineering Company's CEO, Ng Chin Hwee, expressed uncertainty over the aviation recovery due to economic wobbles. Despite handling 78.7% of pre-pandemic flight volumes in March, the next 20% of recovery is uncertain. Airlines face aircraft availability constraints and difficulties recruiting crew, partly due to inflation and a tight labour market. Ng noted that macroeconomic factors could weigh on further growth, indicating a cautious outlook for the aviation industry.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The recovery of flight activities has led to a pick up in demand for maintenance and overhaul, said SIA Engineering.

site_title: Olam Agri's Singapore-Saudi US$1 billion dual listing may launch as early as June: sources
summary: Olam Agri's dual IPO on the Singapore and Saudi Arabian stock exchanges may launch as early as June, with the potential to raise up to US$1 billion. This would make Olam Agri the first company to list in both countries and the first non-Gulf Cooperation Council incorporated business to list in Saudi Arabia. The IPO is subject to regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: Agri-business group Olam proposed a final dividend of 4.5 cents per share, the same as what was declared in the year-ago period.

site_title: KKR, Macquarie eyeing Singapore’s waste management firm SembWaste: sources
summary: KKR and Macquarie Asset Management are potential bidders for SembCorp's waste and recycling management arm, SembWaste, in a deal valued at around $500 million. SembCorp, 49.3% owned by Temasek, has hired HSBC to run the sale. The first round of non-binding bids is due by early June. This move could mark a significant change in Singapore's waste management sector, with SembWaste being one of three public waste collectors appointed by the National Environment Agency.

site_title: Thailand says Chinese tourists on track to reach pre-Covid level
summary: Thailand expects Chinese tourists to reach pre-Covid levels, with arrivals projected to hit one million per month from October, according to the Tourism Authority of Thailand. Following the relaxation of China's zero-Covid policy, Chinese tourists jumped to 270,000 in March from less than 100,000 in January. This is seen as a boon for Thailand's economy, which is expected to reach 29.5 million international arrivals this year, more than twice last year's tally.

site_title: China arrests ChatGPT user who faked deadly train crash story
summary: Chinese authorities have detained a man, surnamed Hong, for using ChatGPT to write and spread fake news articles, including a fabricated train crash story that left nine people dead. The article was viewed over 15,000 times before being removed. This appears to be one of the first instances of an arrest related to misuse of artificial intelligence in China, highlighting concerns over the technology's use within the country's strictly-controlled internet realm. Authorities are now seeking to introduce rules governing the technology's use.

site_title: WhatsApp launches payment feature for Singapore-based businesses
summary: WhatsApp is launching a payment feature for Singapore-based businesses, allowing users to pay local businesses directly on WhatsApp. The feature, supported by Stripe, enables secure payments using credit, debit cards, or PayNow. Initial businesses to use the feature include plant-based butcher Love Handle and lifestyle boutique Tye Tye. WhatsApp will roll out the feature to more businesses over the coming months, expanding revenue streams for businesses and offering customers a convenient payment experience.

images.alt_text: WhatsApp has now agreed to explain changes to EU users’ contracts and how these could affect their rights.
The payments tool in Brazil would allow WhatsApp users to find a company’s account through a directory service and make in-app transactions with credit or debit cards.
Despite WhatsApp’s popularity and its eye-popping US$22 billion acquisition price tag in 2014, to date, it has contributed only a sliver to Meta’s total revenue.

site_title: India extends US$1 billion credit line for Sri Lanka by a year
summary: India has extended a US$1 billion credit line for Sri Lanka by one year, until March 2024, as part of its US$4 billion emergency assistance package. The move gives Sri Lanka backup funds to pay for essential imports amid improved foreign exchange reserves and a nearly US$3 billion IMF bailout package. The country's reserves have risen to US$2.7 billion, reducing the need for the credit line, which was initially set to expire in March.

images.alt_text: The latest reading suggests the Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s efforts to reach single-digit inflation by the end of this year is bearing some fruit.

site_title: SM Prime’s planned US$1 billion Reit listing will give Philippines market a much-needed fillip
summary: SM Prime Holdings, a major developer of malls and offices in the Philippines, plans to list its real estate investment trust (Reit) unit later this year, aiming to raise up to $1 billion. The listing is expected to boost the Philippines market, with analysts predicting a positive impact on the property and stock markets. The Reit's portfolio will include 12-15 malls, and the proceeds will be used to support SM Prime's capital-spending budget and a $100 billion Manila Bay reclamation project. A successful listing is seen as a sign of investor confidence and a boost to the sector's valuations.

images.alt_text: Philippines' consumer price index rose 6.6 per cent in April from a year earlier, marking the slowest pace of increase since August, and was below the 7.0 per cent forecast in a Reuters poll.
Avril de Torres (right) of the Center for Energy, Ecology and Development says the shift from loans to bonds is what facilitates continued fossil fuel investments.
Bonds from sovereign and quasi sovereign names, such as Indofood and Pertamina, have seen greater investor interest.
The Ninoy Aquino International Airport has been ranked among the world’s worst international travel hubs, thanks to regular flight delays and crumbling facilities.

site_title: Ridership excluded in new public transport fare formula but could be reconsidered in future: Iswaran
summary: Minister for Transport S Iswaran announced a new capacity adjustment factor in the public transport fare formula, replacing the existing network capacity factor, to reduce fare variability due to uncertain post-pandemic ridership. The new factor excludes ridership from its calculation, but ridership may be reconsidered in future fare reviews when it fully recovers.

images.alt_text: The updated formula will help reduce volatility for both public transport operators and commuters, said Transport Minister S Iswaran.
COE prices will continue to rise as incomes grow and supply remains limited, says Iswaran.

site_title: 4 in 5 businesses in Asia want to expand overseas but face challenges: UOB study
summary: More than 80% of Asian businesses are seeking to expand internationally for revenue and profit growth, but face challenges in finding overseas partners, legal and tax support. The top two markets for expansion are Asean and China, with Singapore, Thailand, and Malaysia ranking second. However, difficulties in finding partners, lack of talent, and regulatory compliance hold businesses back. Most businesses cite the need for support in connecting with overseas partners and clients, as well as tax incentives.

images.alt_text: The Asean SME Transformation Study 2022 found that SMEs in Indonesia are the most optimistic, with 75 per cent expressing confidence in the economy.

Iris Ng, the business head of middle market for global commercial banking at OCBC, said the bank has in the past two years accorded green loans to more than 500 SMEs. Only one of three of them provided the bank with a green certificate to validate the green criteria.

site_title: China’s April new yuan loans seen as retreating: Reuters poll
summary: China's new yuan loans are expected to have dropped in April after reaching an all-time high in the first quarter, according to a Reuters poll. Banks issued 1.40 trillion yuan in net new loans, about one-third of the 3.89 trillion yuan issued in March. Despite this, loans are still expected to be more than double the 645.4 billion yuan issued in April last year. The central bank has pledged to maintain support for the economy, focusing on domestic demand, and keep money supply and total social financing growth in line with nominal economic growth.

site_title: Nintendo warns of big slowdown in Switch console sales this year
summary: Nintendo expects to sell 15 million units of its Switch console this fiscal year, a slowdown from its previous forecast of 15.7 million. The company's operating income is forecasted at 450 billion yen, slightly lower than the average estimate. Nintendo's president, Shuntaro Furukawa, noted that sustaining the Switch's sales momentum will be difficult in its seventh year, and there are no imminent plans for a successor console. The company faces rising competitive pressure from Sony's PlayStation 5, which is expected to sell over 25 million units this year.

site_title: How Wall Street is preparing for a US debt default
summary: Wall Street is preparing for a potential US debt default, with some experts warning that even a brief default could cause significant economic damage. The Treasury Department has developed a contingency plan, which includes extending the maturity date of Treasury securities and having the Fedwire Securities Service change its practice to allow for one more day to sell or borrow against the security. However, experts, including Goldman Sachs' Beth Hammack, say that the plan is not a complete fix and that the damage could be severe, potentially even more so if it lulls Washington into a false sense of security.

images.alt_text: While Republicans seek to lift the US$31.4 trillion borrowing limit only in combination with drastic spending cuts, President Joe Biden has refused to agree to such reductions – raising fears of the first national debt default.
Pedestrians at Union Square shopping district, San Francisco, April 27, 2023. US economic growth slowed in the first quarter to 1.1 per cent.

site_title: China's car sales rise 2.1% in April as price war effect fades
summary: China's passenger vehicle sales rose 2.1% in April to 1.65 million units, driven by a 54.5% increase from the same period last year. However, this growth is slower than expected as the stimulus effect of price cuts and incentives fades. Sales of new energy vehicles (NEVs) declined 3.6% in April, accounting for 32% of total car sales, with BYD holding 37% market share and Tesla 7.6%. The crowded auto market is expected to continue, with nearly 300 models displayed at the Shanghai auto show in April.

images.alt_text: Chery’s mid-size Omoda 5 is selling across Australia for as little as A$32,000 (S$28,789) for the base model.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Stem cell biologists Sandhya Sriram and Ling Ka Yi founded Shiok Meats to develop lab-grown crustacean meat, but the startup faces scale-up issues and employee allegations that its core technology does not work. Meanwhile, bankruptcy applications rose to 959 in Q1 2023, and PM Lee Hsien Loong is leading a Singapore delegation to the Asean Summit in Labuan Bajo, Indonesia. A digital platform for banks to share data on fishy transactions is set to launch in H2 2024, and 80% of Asian businesses want to expand overseas but face challenges.

site_title: Launching in H2 2024: Digital platform for banks to share data on fishy transactions
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) plans to launch a digital platform, Cosmic, in H2 2024, allowing banks to share information on suspicious transactions. Initially, sharing will be voluntary, but MAS aims to make it mandatory in higher-risk situations. The platform will enable banks to detect and prevent money laundering, terrorism financing, and proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Participating banks will be granted immunity from liability for sharing information, and MAS will ensure data security through cybersecurity measures and audits. The platform will be open to six major banks initially, with potential expansion to other financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Limitations in current laws make it difficult to take money mules to task, Second Minister for Home Affairs Josephine Teo said in Parliament on Monday.
MAS said the new platform, named Cosmic, will allow financial institutions to share information on customers who show suspicious behaviour.

site_title: Indicted FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried urges court to toss charges
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the now-bankrupt FTX cryptocurrency exchange, has asked a US judge to dismiss criminal charges against him, citing that several of the charges failed to properly state an offense. Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have accused him of stealing billions of dollars in customer funds to plug losses at Alameda, buy real estate, and make political contributions through an illegal straw-donor scheme. Bankman-Fried, a 31-year-old former billionaire, has been confined to his parents' home since his December arrest in the Bahamas.

images.alt_text: FTX filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States on Nov 11 in the biggest crypto firm failure.
. In September, FTX US won an auction for Voyager assets in an agreement valued at about US$1.4 billion.
Genesis is seeking mediation to take place over a two-day period prior to May 9, and ahead of a mid-May due date on US$630 million of debt owed to Genesis by DCG.
flag, america, usa
Bankrupt crypto exchange FTX has recovered US$7.3 billion in assets

site_title: Partnering for impact: institutional investors and the net-zero transition
summary: Institutional investors can drive the global transition to net zero by partnering with other investors, governments, and companies to support sustainable solutions and reduce emissions. This collaboration can help build confidence, resilience, and competitiveness in the wider economy. By working together, investors can share expertise, leverage resources, and amplify their influence to create systemic change and fulfill their fiduciary duty. Through collective advocacy, investors can encourage rules and frameworks that support the interests of their beneficiaries and create conditions for a well-managed climate transition.

images.alt_text: Transition finance has been slow to address the coal challenge, but there are good reasons to be cautious.

The uptake of loans that link borrowing costs to agreed sustainability targets shows that companies are growing more aware of the financial benefits of improving their sustainability practices over time, says Sustainable Fitch.  PHOTO:

site_title: Where will Singapore Treasury bills go from here?
summary: Singapore Treasury bills (T-bills) have diverged from the US interest rate path, with yields declining this year despite the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes. The decline is attributed to the stability of Singapore's financial system, appreciation of the SGD, and softening inflation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has chosen not to tighten monetary policy, and T-bill yields are unlikely to see an upward trend from here. Instead, the optimal case is for yields to hover at the current level or gradually taper off, with a sharp spike in inflation needed to break the 4.4% record.

images.alt_text: The total value of applications in this six-month T-bill auction was S$12.3 billion, representing a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.6.
Demand for the latest six-month T-bill and Singapore Savings Bond fell, according to data released on Wednesday.

site_title: UBS replaces CFO, keeps Credit Suisse’s Koerner in top team
summary: UBS has announced a new leadership team after taking over Credit Suisse, with Ulrich Koerner staying on as part of the top team to oversee operational continuity and client focus. Todd Tuckner has been promoted to group CFO, replacing Sarah Youngwood. The combined group will manage two separate parent companies, with each institution maintaining its own subsidiaries and branches. The integration process is expected to take 3-4 years. UBS will evaluate options for Credit Suisse's Swiss business, with a decision potentially made by the end of the summer.

images.alt_text: UBS is studying plans to sell the Swiss banking business of Credit Suisse in an initial public offering (IPO) after taking over its smaller rival, the sources say.

site_title: DBS Foundation partners MSF, New Hope to teach displaced individuals digital skills
summary: DBS Foundation, in partnership with MSF and New Hope Community Services, has launched a digital literacy program for displaced individuals in Singapore. The pilot project, "Let's Go Digital," aimed to teach participants basic digital skills, including how to use banking apps like DBS PayLah! and citizen e-services. The event featured guided learning and hands-on activities, and beneficiaries received S$28 in PayLah! credit to use for cashless payments. The program's success will be assessed on the participants' digital literacy and confidence in using these applications. DBS Foundation plans to scale the program to more beneficiaries and collaborate with other agencies to address the digital divide.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
BT BAF believes that every child or youth with interest and potential in the arts should have the opportunity to develop their talents, regardless of their financial resources.

site_title: Aramco Q1 profit falls 19% to US$31.9 billion
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a 19% drop in first-quarter net profit to US$31.88 billion, mainly due to lower crude prices. Despite this, the company's dividend payment of US$19.5 billion remained unchanged from the previous quarter. CEO Amin Nasser stated that Aramco is considering introducing performance-linked dividends, targeting 50-70% of annual free cash flow. The company also announced expansions in its downstream business and capacity expansion projects, with initial production expected in 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Saudi Aramco logo is pictured at the oil facility in Abqaiq, Saudi Arabia October 12, 2019. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo

site_title: BT Budding Artists Fund marks 18 years of empowering young artists
summary: The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) celebrated its 18th anniversary with a performance titled "The Light Within" featuring 85 students from various art forms. The event, held at 10 Square's auditorium, aimed to empower financially disadvantaged children and youth to pursue the arts. The performance incorporated puppetry and dance, highlighting the challenges faced during the Covid-19 pandemic. BT BAF believes every child with interest in the arts should have equal opportunities, regardless of financial resources, and aims to nurture creativity and collaboration among its participants.

site_title: Identifying winners in the gems of China and India
summary: China and India, two Asian giants, are poised to continue their economic growth in the decade ahead. China's digital economy, consumer discretionary, and banking sectors are expected to shine bright due to its innovation, consumption, and robust capital structure. India, with its thriving tech talent, growing middle class, and offshoring powerhouse, will benefit from its IT services, banking sector, consumer staples, and pharmaceutical industry. These sectors are expected to drive growth and provide attractive investment opportunities. As the world shifts towards a multipolar order, investors are encouraged to look into these markets for sectoral opportunities.

images.alt_text: The reopening of China’s economy will be pivotal for the region with the spillover to Asia seen focused on consumption and service-sector demand rather than investment, the IMF said.

site_title: Indonesia, Singapore alarmed as shots fired in Myanmar at diplomats, aid group
summary: Indonesia and Singapore condemned an attack on a convoy of their diplomats and a humanitarian aid group in Myanmar, calling for an end to violence and dialogue between warring groups. The incident, which occurred on May 7, targeted staff from the Indonesian and Singaporean embassies and a Asean humanitarian assistance centre in northern Myanmar. No group claimed responsibility, but Myanmar state media described it as an attack by "terrorists" with small arms, resulting in minor damage. Indonesian President Joko Widodo and Singapore's foreign ministry called for a peaceful solution, while the US also condemned the attack and urged the military to implement a peace consensus.

images.alt_text: Myanmar has been in turmoil since the military putsch ousted Aung San Suu Kyi’s government in February 2021, with the junta’s bloody crackdown on dissent sparking social unrest and an economic disaster.

site_title: Swiss watch CEO triples sales with focus on red hot Tonda line
summary: Parmigiani Fleurier, a Swiss luxury watch brand, has tripled its sales under the leadership of CEO Guido Terreni, who refocused the brand on its Tonda PF line. Sales now account for 98% of the brand's sales, with the Tonda PF producing "a few thousand" watches annually. The brand has doubled its production and has a waiting list of over a year for its most complex models, priced up to 163,000 francs. Terreni credits the brand's independence for allowing him to move quickly to change its focus and appeal to a wider audience.

images.alt_text: Exports climbed 13.8 per cent by value to 2.4 billion Swiss francs (S$3.6 billion), with shipments increasing by almost 62 per cent to Hong Kong, the Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry said.
Demand for Patek’s timepieces, which start at around US$30,000, still far outstrips supply.

site_title: Vietnam lawmakers call for further rate cut to prop up growth
summary: Vietnam's economic growth slowed to 3.32% in Q1 2023, prompting the State Bank of Vietnam to cut benchmark rates twice this year. Lawmakers are urging further rate cuts to support the economy and meet the 6.5% GDP growth target for the year. The country's growth slowdown was attributed to various factors, including global economic uncertainty and the impact of US trade policies. The central bank's decision to cut rates is seen as a sign of growth jitters, as Malaysia also takes measures to shield its economy from tariff threats.

images.alt_text: VNG's 12,400-square-meter data centre located Ho Chi Minh City in January is one of the three DCs in Vietnam that achieve both Tier-III certifications of design documents and constructed facility by Uptime Institute

site_title: Self-exiled ex-PM Thaksin seeks return to Thailand by July
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, 73, announced his intention to return to Thailand by July 26, his birthday, despite facing corruption charges. Thaksin, who has been in self-exile for 15 years, stated he is ready to face justice and will enter the legal process upon his return. This comes as his daughter Paetongtarn's party, Pheu Thai, is leading in most opinion polls ahead of the general election on Sunday. Thaksin's return has sparked speculation that he may finally fulfill his repeated promises to return to Thailand.

images.alt_text: Pita Limjaroenrat, the Move Forward Party's candidate for prime minister, greets supporters during a general election campaign in Bangkok, Thailand, 04 May 2023. 'Move Forward' party leader is still the top choice for prime minister among Bangkok's residents in opinion polls for the general elections which will be held on 14 May 2023.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

Thai voters lining up to cast ballots during the general election advance voting at a polling station in Bangkok on Sunday. More than 2.3 million eligible voters nationwide have registered to cast their early-votes.
Green Party supporters canvass for votes in Bangkok, April 30, 2023. For the past three months, much of Thailand has been blanketed with record-breaking air pollution.
Sunday’s voters are among more than 52 million who will elect 500 candidates to Thailand’s House of Representatives.

site_title: Spain may end or curb controversial ‘golden visa’ real estate scheme
summary: Spain is considering ending its "golden visa" scheme, which grants residency rights to foreign investors who buy property worth at least 500,000 euros. The scheme has been criticized for allowing millionaires to obtain residency with little to no job creation, leading to rising housing prices and displacement of locals. The European Commission has urged EU countries to end such programs due to security and money-laundering risks. A preliminary agreement has been reached to put an end to the scheme, but no official confirmation has been made by the government.

images.alt_text: Pandemic drives Spain's real estate companies online

site_title: UK mortgage costs risk heading higher again with BOE rate hikes
summary: UK mortgage costs are expected to rise again as the Bank of England signals higher interest rates to combat double-digit inflation. Lenders are increasing mortgage rates, with the big six lenders lifting the average two-year fixed-rate mortgage by 0.16 percentage points to 4.65% and the five-year deal by 0.11 percentage points to 4.21%. Experts warn that mortgage rates could rise further if the BOE hikes interest rates to 5%, which would strain households already dealing with a cost-of-living squeeze.

images.alt_text: UK unitied kingdom house housing rent Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg
