Among the writers’ demands is that studios will not let artificial intelligence encroach on writers’ credit or compensation. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

site_title: The AI age will be disruptive but not necessarily dystopian for workers
summary: The AI age may bring disruption to workers, but it's unlikely to be a dystopian future. Analytical, interpersonal, and technological skills will remain crucial for students, while AI-generated tools may displace some white-collar jobs. A green transformation is also expected to create new opportunities in emerging fields. Forecasts can help workers prepare for multiple futures, rather than predicting a specific outcome. Companies are struggling to navigate layoffs, and the global economy is facing uncertainty due to the pandemic, war, and climate change. A shift towards emerging green jobs is expected.

images.alt_text: Members of the Writers Guild of America and supporters picket outside a sound stage at Brooklyn Stages where the "FBI" television show was filming in New York, May 5, 2023. Among the writers’ demands is that studios will not let artificial intelligence encroach on writers’ credit or compensation.
“We want to give them this opportunity to earn money with the AI. We want to give people new (jobs),” Mubert’s CEO, Paul Zgordan, who is also a DJ and musician, said.
FILE PHOTO: Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken March 31, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The IT Literacy programme conducted by Daughters of Tomorrow is one of several projects  supported by StanChart's contribution to IMDA's Digital for Life fund.

site_title: New butterflies are named after Sauron, ‘Lord of the Rings’ villain
summary: Scientists have named two new butterfly species, Saurona triangula and Saurona aurigera, after JRR Tolkien's 'Lord of the Rings' villain Sauron due to their dark, eye-like spots on orange wings. Found in the southwestern Amazon rainforest, the butterflies are part of the Euptychiina group, which are difficult to distinguish by physical characteristics. Genetic sequencing helped identify the new species, and the naming aims to draw attention to this underappreciated group of butterflies, some of which are threatened with extinction.

images.alt_text: The 3.9-metre skeleton has been mounted on a red carpet and under crystal chandeliers in a Zurich concert hall, where it will be on public display before going under the hammer on April 18.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as banks tighten lending standards
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% at 33,618.6, ahead of key inflation data. A survey of lenders showed greater caution among banks, with tightened lending standards expected to continue over 2023, following four bank failures since March. Regional banks were mixed, while tech stocks rose 0.2%. The S&P 500 edged up 0.1% and Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.2%. The market is watching inflation data and interest rate reports due to be released this week.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., May 4, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Pound hits one-year high against struggling US dollar
summary: The pound reached a one-year high against the US dollar, trading at US$1.2668, due to expectations of a potential peak in US interest rates and looming inflation data. The euro also strengthened, supported by the European Central Bank's interest rate hikes, while the US dollar index fell 0.25% due to market expectations of a potential interest rate cut. The pound is expected to remain under scrutiny ahead of the Bank of England's rate increase on Thursday.

site_title: Amazon to offer its original movies and films on other sites
summary: Amazon is launching Amazon MGM Studios Distribution, a unit that will make its 4,000 films and 17,000 TV episodes available to rent or buy on other services and on planes. The originals, including "Borat Subsequent Moviefilm" and "The Marvellous Mrs Maisel," will be offered on other outlets after their initial run on Prime Video. This move follows Amazon's US$8.5 billion acquisition of MGM last year and its commitment to releasing films in theatres with a US$1 billion budget. The distribution will generate additional revenue for Amazon.

site_title: Taiwan in talks for US$500 million weapons package from US
summary: Taiwan's Defence Minister Chiu Kuo-cheng confirmed that the US has been discussing a fast-tracked $500 million weapons package with Taipei, aiming to make up for delays in arms procurements. The package, expected to be implemented this year, will prioritize immediate delivery of spot goods over delayed deliveries. The move comes as tensions with China escalate, and Taiwan is awaiting a $4.5 billion security assistance package approved by the US in September.

images.alt_text: Thunder Tiger, a maker of unmanned vehicle systems including drones, and Hocheng, a ceramics producer for bulletproof materials, have climbed more than 23 per cent during the period.

site_title: Riverstone Q1 net profit falls 57% to RM46.7 million on higher cost of sales
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a Malaysian glove maker, reported a 57% drop in net profit to RM46.7 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2023, due to higher cost of sales and lower average selling prices of healthcare gloves. The company plans to increase its exposure in customized products. Earnings per share fell to 3.15 sen, down from 7.34 sen in the previous year.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

Riverstone executive chairman and chief executive Wong Teek Soon said the poor performance reflected “typical cyclical weakness” for the medical glove industry, with demand and average selling prices normalising from Covid-19 peaks.

site_title: China, Singapore in talks on bilateral visa-free travel
summary: China and Singapore are in talks to establish a bilateral visa-free travel arrangement, which is expected to boost visitor numbers from China, Singapore's largest pre-pandemic tourism market. In 2019, China had 3.6 million visitors to Singapore, spending a combined $4.1 billion. The visa-free travel arrangement aims to increase economic ties and attract more Chinese investment, relocation, and tourism.

images.alt_text: Haneda Airport in Japan (pictured) is expected to see a full resumption of international capacity this year.

site_title: Baidu’s smart speaker unit to launch a phone next week
summary: Baidu's smart speaker unit, Xiaodu, will launch its first smartphone next week, marking the first major Chinese entrant in the mobile market in years. The move follows years of investment in artificial intelligence and comes as the company embeds its AI tools into various business lines. The launch of a handset under the Baidu umbrella is seen as a significant step in building a hardware ecosystem to complement its internet services.

site_title: Streaming broke the career ladder, striking Hollywood writers say
summary: Hollywood writers are striking due to the changing landscape of the industry, citing reduced opportunities and lower pay. The Writers Guild of America (WGA) is seeking changes to the contract, including a requirement for at least six writers per series and stipends for early-career writers. The strike has shut down late-night television and threatens the fall TV season. Writers claim that streaming services' "mini rooms" with fewer writers limit their experience and pay, while studios propose alternatives such as showrunner-identified writers and wage increases.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng said industries must show clear plans to develop local talents in jobs to be added to the "shortage occupation list" for employment passes. 89% of Singapore's depositors are fully insured under the Deposit Insurance Scheme, and the LTA will redistribute 6,000 COE certificates. Sea is giving a 5% salary bump to most employees, while Singapore stocks ended lower with the STI losing 0.3%. Minority shareholders of Global Palm Resources should reject an offer to take the company private.

site_title: India's Go Airlines seeks urgent bankruptcy order, told to stop issuing tickets
summary: Go Airlines, also known as Go First, has filed for bankruptcy protection, citing faulty Pratt & Whitney engines as the reason for grounding about half its 54 Airbus A320neo planes. The airline, with 57 planes, has asked India's company law tribunal to urgently grant its request for bankruptcy protection. The aviation regulator has stepped up pressure on the carrier to stop issuing new tickets, and lessors have sought to repossess planes. A decision on the bankruptcy plea is pending.

images.alt_text: Some lessors opposed Go Airlines’ plea at the first hearing of the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) on Thursday, after the airline had blamed “faulty” Pratt & Whitney engines this week for the grounding of about half of its fleet.

site_title: MUFG to launch venture debt funds worth US$400 million for Japan, Europe
summary: MUFG is launching two venture debt funds worth US$400 million for Japanese and European startups. The funds, worth US$250 million for Europe and 20 billion yen (S$196.3 million) for Japan, will be created through a joint venture with Liquidity Capital. This move reflects strong funding demand as the market for initial public offerings remains dull due to rising interest rates and market volatility.

images.alt_text: The wipeout suffered by MUFG clients who bought the AT1 bonds make up the bulk of losses in Japan, where investors bought about 140 billion yen (S$1.4 billion) of these products.

site_title: Singapore TV licensing startup Allrites to merge with Aura SPAC
summary: Allrites Holdings, a Singaporean TV licensing startup, has agreed to merge with US-listed blank cheque firm Aura FAT Projects Acquisition, valued at $92 million on a pro forma basis. The deal includes a potential $18 million earnout over two years, subject to revenue targets. Allrites, founded by Australian TV producer Riaz Mehta, generates over half its revenue in the US. The agreement allows Aura FAT Projects to seek private investment before closing the transaction, and the companies intend to focus on new emerging technology companies in South-east Asia and Australia.

site_title: Germany’s industrial plunge makes winter recession a possibility
summary: Germany's industrial production dropped 3.4% in March, the largest decline in a year, raising the risk of a winter recession. The automotive sector was particularly affected, with a significant decline in factory orders. This unexpected data may lead to a downward revision of first-quarter GDP growth, which had previously been predicted to be stagnant. The decline in manufacturing performance follows a 10% slump in March factory orders and weak retail sales and exports.

images.alt_text: Sentiment among German exporters has rebounded to the highest point seen since the outbreak of war in Ukraine, on hopes of increased demand following China’s reopening and thanks to the resilience of the US economy.

site_title: Swedish housing market extends rebound in realtor data
summary: Sweden's housing market shows signs of recovery, with average apartment prices increasing 1% in April, marking a third consecutive month of stable or rising prices. Detached houses remained unchanged. Despite this, other data indicates the market is far from recovery, with a 1% decline in April according to an index published by state-owned lender SBAB. The Riksbank's benchmark rate has risen to 3.5%, with another hike expected in June or September.

images.alt_text: Swedish home prices declined a seasonally adjusted 1 per cent in April, led by a drop in the value of detached houses, data by SBAB shows.

site_title: StanChart’s Winters says too big to fail must be reviewed after US crisis
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters says the concept of "too big to fail" banks needs to be reviewed after the collapse of four US lenders, including Silicon Valley Bank. Winters notes that even JPMorgan, with a 12% deposit share, is manageable in a competitive US market. He suggests regulators should focus on concentrated deposit market shares in specific regions, rather than overall bank size. Winters believes the ideal response to the crisis would have been to provide liquidity to the challenged banks before their collapse, potentially preventing a broader system undermining of confidence.

images.alt_text: Bill Winters, Group Chief Executive, Standard Chartered,

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower on Monday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks ended lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 0.3% or 8.97 points to 3,257.66. Despite US stocks' gains on Friday, anxiety over US default led to a decline. Regional markets were mixed, with the Hang Seng Index up 1.2%, while the Nikkei 225 index slid 0.7%. Local banks ended mixed, with DBS and UOB rising, while OCBC declined 3.2%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Across the market, gainers outnumbered losers 90 to 43 after 81.2 million securities worth S$66.5 million changed hands.

site_title: Chinese property brokers need to reduce fees, regulator says
summary: China's housing regulator has ordered real estate brokers to reduce fees for housing transactions and leasing services to promote a healthy sector development. The regulator stated that some brokers have charged excessive, unclear, and unfair fees, misusing clients' personal information and abusing their dominant market position. Brokerage agencies must implement reasonable fee reductions and apply different pricing based on transaction size. The move aims to reduce the burden on parties to transactions and protect clients' legal rights.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past a property model at a sales office of Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China November 10, 2021. REUTERS/David Kirton/File Photo

site_title: HSBC reaches deal to buy out China fund partner: sources
summary: HSBC has agreed to buy out its 51% stake in the China fund management joint venture, HSBC Jintrust Fund Management, from its partner Shanxi Trust. The deal, subject to a public auction and regulatory review, will expand HSBC's presence in China's $3.8 trillion fund management market, its main banking market. The acquisition is part of HSBC's push for expansion in the Asian market.

site_title: KKR earnings sink 26% in first quarter as asset sales slow
summary: KKR's earnings dropped 26% in the first quarter to US$719.3 million, driven by a decline in its capital markets business and slower asset sales. Despite this, the firm took in US$12 billion of new capital and assets under management grew 6% to US$510 billion. Traditional private equity portfolio declined 9% over the past 12 months, while infrastructure assets gained 9%. Realised investment income fell 43% and carried interest dropped 71%. KKR's shares have gained about 3.3% over the past year.

site_title: COE quotas get one-time redistribution boost; long-term price uptrend likely to continue: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) will redistribute about 6,000 non-extendable COEs due to expire, increasing quota supply by 24% in Category A and 15% in Category B. This move aims to smoothen supply and reduce volatility, despite expected long-term price uptrend due to rising incomes and limited supply. COE prices are expected to continue rising, with Transport Minister S Iswaran stating that prices will be "upwards" as demand outpaces supply.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Derryn Wong
Government studying COE market, ready to refine it if needed: Iswaran

site_title: China’s debt-to-GDP ratio rises to record 279.7% on credit boom
summary: China's debt-to-GDP ratio has reached a record high of 279.7% in the first quarter of 2023, driven by a surge in bank loans to companies. The macro leverage ratio increased by 7.7 percentage points from the previous quarter, with non-financial corporate debt rising 5.8 percentage points. Leverage ratios for households and governments also rose, with the household sector up by around 1 percentage point and the government sector by around 1 percentage point. The record debt ratio is attributed to China's economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Under solvency regulations applied by the People’s Bank of China, the G-SIBs are required to have a minimum TLAC of 16 per cent of their risk-weighted assets by 2025, and 18 per cent by 2028.

site_title: Why the fight for ‘critical minerals’ is heating up
summary: China dominates the critical minerals used in electric vehicle (EV) batteries, solar panels, and wind-turbine magnets, accounting for over half of global production of battery metals and rare earths. The US and Europe need to catch up fast to reduce their dependence on Chinese supplies, which can be costly and technically challenging to extract and refine. The US and EU are working on ad hoc trade pacts and supply deals to boost domestic production, with a total of $13 billion committed to fund new mining projects. However, China is consolidating its grip on key metals and may restrict exports of technology and equipment to forestall Western efforts to build new mining and processing capacity.

images.alt_text: Rare earths have long been a pain point for automakers and the clean-energy sector, because of unpredictable prices and China’s tight grip on the supply chain.
Global investment in the green transition is set to triple by 2030 from US$1 trillion last year, President Ursula von der Leyen told the European Parliament on Wednesday, declaring “the race is on”.

site_title: The fast-growing kingdom of Jamie Dimon
summary: Jamie Dimon's JPMorgan Chase has cemented its position as a dominant force in finance with the takeover of First Republic, increasing its asset base to nearly $4 trillion, three times its size before the 2008 financial crisis. This deal, reminiscent of previous crisis-triggered rescue deals, has raised concerns about JPMorgan's size and potential impact on the banking system. Critics argue that JPMorgan's growing scale poses a risk to the financial system, and the FDIC's "least-cost" approach may not consider the long-term implications. Dimon's ability to manage the bank's increasing complexity and size remains a subject of debate.

images.alt_text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) announced on May 1 that it sold the failing First Republic Bank to JP Morgan Chase & Co. First Republic Bank is the second-largest bank failure in US history.
FILE PHOTO: A First Republic Bank branch is pictured in Midtown Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: Japan PM applauds trust with South Korea after landmark summit
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida concluded a landmark visit to Seoul, marking the first formal summit in the South Korean capital in a dozen years. Kishida and President Yoon Suk-yeol pledged cooperation on high-tech goods, including semiconductors, and reaffirmed a renewed reliance between the two countries crucial to US security policies. The visit came after a proposal by Yoon to mend a rift over compensation for Koreans conscripted to work in Japanese factories during colonial rule. Kishida expressed his commitment to strengthening the relationship of trust with Yoon, with a planned meeting in Hiroshima this month to discuss the US-Japan-South Korea trilateral summit.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol (right) with Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, who was in Seoul for the first visit to the South Korean capital by a Japanese leader in 12 years.

site_title: China automakers flood Australia with budget-priced luxury cars
summary: Chinese carmaker Chery Automobile is flooding the Australian market with budget-priced luxury cars, with its mid-size Omoda 5 available for as little as A$32,000. The Omoda 5 boasts features like heated steering wheels and exterior puddle lights, rivaling luxury cars at a lower price point. Chery joins Chinese rivals Great Wall Motor and SAIC Motor in targeting the Australian market, which has seen a 69% increase in sales of vehicles sourced from China. The move is seen as a test of Australia's willingness to switch to electric vehicles, with EVs accounting for 8% of new car sales in April, up from 1.1% a year earlier.

site_title: Chinese militia boats cross Indian, Asean warships exercising in South China Sea
summary: Chinese militia boats approached and crossed paths with Indian and Asean warships exercising in the South China Sea, according to two Indian sources. The incident occurred during the two-day Asean-India Maritime Exercise (AIME 2023), where naval ships from India, Vietnam, Thailand, and others participated. Chinese boats, believed to be part of the Qiong Sansha Yu militia fleet, moved towards the participating vessels without a face-off, prompting concerns of intimidation and disruption. The incident is the latest in a series of incidents involving Chinese vessels in the region.

images.alt_text: An aerial view taken on March 9, 2023 shows vessels identified by the Philippine Coast Guard as a Chinese maritime militia vessel near Thitu Island in the South China Sea. - As a Philippine Coast Guard plane carrying journalists flew over the Spratly Islands in the hotly disputed South China Sea, a Chinese voice issued a stern command over the radio: "Leave immediately." (Photo by JAM STA ROSA / AFP)

site_title: Jokowi condemns ‘shootout’ involving Asean officials in Myanmar
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo condemned a "shootout" involving Asean officials delivering humanitarian aid in Myanmar, calling for an end to violence in the strife-torn country. The incident occurred in Hsi Hseng township in the western Shan State, targeting Asean officials from the humanitarian assistance centre. Widodo stated that the violence would not deter efforts to push for peace in Myanmar, urging all stakeholders to engage in dialogue and find solutions. The Myanmar junta and shadow government have not commented on the incident.

images.alt_text: Myanmar has been in turmoil since the military putsch ousted Aung San Suu Kyi’s government in February 2021, with the junta’s bloody crackdown on dissent sparking social unrest and an economic disaster.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange Fund Q1 investment income HK$97.9 billion: HKMA
summary: Hong Kong's Exchange Fund posted investment income of HK$97.9 billion (S$16.5 billion) in Q1 2023, a second consecutive quarter gain. This compared to a HK$48.8 billion loss in the same period a year earlier and an adjusted HK$73.4 billion in investment income in Q4 2022. The fund's holdings of Hong Kong equities, bonds, and other securities generated significant income, with gains of HK$3.3 billion, HK$25.5 billion, and HK$43.9 billion, respectively. The chief executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority expressed uncertainty about the quarters to come due to global economic changes and US inflation.

images.alt_text: The programme will begin with Northbound Trading, allowing overseas investors to participate in mainland China’s interbank financial derivatives market through a connection between the two markets, HKMA said in a statement.
While rents in Singapore's central business district remains cheaper than Hong Kong's, the latter offers more cost-effective decentralised nodes.

site_title: Thai election agency criticised after snags in early voting
summary: Thailand's election commission faced criticism after receiving 300 complaints during early voting, including issues with voter registration, ballots, and polling station lists. The complaints sparked concerns about the commission's competence, given its appointment under military rule. The complaints were made by the People's Network to Monitor Elections, an alliance of non-governmental organizations. The criticism comes ahead of the general election on May 14, which could potentially mark the end of nine years of military-backed government.

images.alt_text: Former protest leader Panusaya “Rung” Sithijirawattanakul posing for a photo in front of the Democracy Monument in Bangkok, Thailand, April 6, 2023.

site_title: Chinese premier urges IOC to oppose politicisation of sports
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang urged the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to oppose the politicization of sports, amid pressure from 35 governments to exclude Russian and Belarusian athletes from the Olympics due to the war. Li made the comments during a meeting with IOC head Thomas Bach in Beijing, expressing China's willingness to work together to prevent politicization. The IOC has been under pressure to exclude athletes from Russia and Belarus, but has suggested including them as neutrals or through alternative qualifying pathways.

images.alt_text: Saccage and other critics of the Paris Olympics say the event will negatively impact the environment and benefit big businesses and elites, rather than locals.

site_title: Australia’s big  pension funds boost fossil fuel investments, activist group says
summary: Australia's 30 largest pension funds increased investments in fossil fuel companies by 50% in 2022, reaching over A$34 billion, despite long-term commitments to net-zero carbon emissions. Environmental activist group Market Forces criticized the funds for "making a mockery" of their climate goals, saying they are "buying up wholesale" in companies expanding fossil fuels.

images.alt_text: The Australian government is set to unveil in the budget financial assistance for more than 5 million low-income families, small businesses and pensioners struggling with high power bills.

site_title: Toyota suspends sales of Yaris model after safety test problem
summary: Toyota Motor has suspended sales of its Yaris Ativ model after an affiliate, Daihatsu, rigged part of the door in side-collision safety tests. The decision was made due to pressure during the development of the Ativ model, according to Toyota's CEO for the Asia region, Masahiko Maeda. The vehicles in use by customers are deemed safe, but the issue highlights the importance of proper development conditions.

site_title: Sias: Minority shareholders should reject offer for Global Palm shares
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Sias) advises minority shareholders of Global Palm Resources (GPR) to reject the offer to take the company private at S$0.25 per share, deeming it "clearly wholly unsatisfactory." The watchdog group urges the offerer to raise the offer price, citing concerns that the current price does not provide adequate margin for extraction of value and may leave shareholders feeling short-changed. The offer price is also below the mean price-to-earnings ratio of recent going-private transactions on the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Malaysia says the EU law is a “deliberate effort” to increase costs and barriers for its palm oil sector.
The world’s top palm oil producer tightened exports earlier this year in anticipation of higher domestic demand for cooking oil ahead of the holy Islamic month of Ramadan.

site_title: China’s export seen rising in April but at slower pace, outlook challenging: poll
summary: China's exports are expected to rise 8.0% year-on-year in April, following a 14.8% surge in March, but at a slower pace. Imports are forecast to show no growth, similar to April 2022. Analysts are cautious due to a slowing global economy and rising geopolitical tensions, with factory output lagging. China's economy grew faster than expected in the first quarter, but property market weakness and surging bank savings raise doubts about demand, and the government's GDP growth target of 5% for this year is considered modest.

images.alt_text: Beijing is moving to tighten its grip on sensitive data as tensions with Washington mount.

The semi-annual event is known as the Canton Fair kicked off on Apr 15, just as Chinese officials embarked on a charm offensive to lure foreign investors back after three years of Covid Zero policies that prevented in-person visits.

site_title: Alibaba logistics arm eyes up to US$2 billion Hong Kong IPO: sources
summary: Alibaba's logistics arm, Cainiao Network Technology, is planning to raise up to $2 billion through an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, likely in early 2024. The IPO is part of Alibaba's plan to split its business into six units and explore capital raisings or market debuts to fund future growth. Cainiao has started work on the IPO, which would be its first listing, and the exact size of the offering has not been reported before.

images.alt_text: Shein and Temu have taken the world by storm, with a potent combination of ultra-low prices and personalised recommendations.
Alibaba’s international online shopping unit is in the early stages of consideration and the IPO’s size has yet to be determined
Signage atop the the Ant Group Co. headquarters in Hangzhou, China, on Monday, Feb. 20, 2023. Ant Group is scheduled to release earnings results on Feb. 24. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Nurturing US-Indo-Pacific commerce through digital trade
summary: US trade negotiators meet in Singapore for the next round of Indo-Pacific Economic Framework (IPEF) talks, aiming to secure clear signals on trade and economic liberalization. The IPEF framework should build on existing digital trade agreements, such as the US-Japan Digital Trade Agreement, to promote near-term positive trade outcomes and establish policy certainty for US businesses and trading partners. Securing progressive digital trade provisions is crucial to avoid data localization and mandates, which could harm innovation and global supply chains.

images.alt_text: US trade policy agenda being scuttled by politics
While the shipping industry has begun to explore and embrace automation and digitalisation, it still relies on many manual and paper-based processes and practices.

The Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity can be a valuable
platform for the US to exercise economic diplomacy in the region, and it
clearly signals the US’ continued commitment to engage with its partners in
Asia, and deepen ties across the Pacific, said Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen  says strong trade and investment, and people-to-people ties make the bilateral economic and financial relationship a critical element to the partnership between the two countries.

site_title: Thai election raises hopes for stability, economic reforms
summary: Thailand's general election on May 14 has raised hopes for stability and economic reforms. The election features over 70 parties and 500 seats in Parliament's Lower House, with a group of 250 senators appointed by the military regime playing a significant role in the outcome. Former prime minister Prayut Chan-o-cha's appeal has diminished, and the focus has shifted to addressing economic growth and competitiveness. The Move Forward Party, led by Pita Limjaroenrat, has gained popularity with its reform platform, while the Pheu Thai Party, backed by former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, has emphasized populist policies. Analysts predict a coalition government, with potential scenarios including an anti-military coalition or a Pheu Thai-Palang Pracharath Party coalition, which could bring about reforms and promote economic growth.

images.alt_text: epa10589239 Thai property tycoon-turned-politician and one of the three Pheu Thai Party's Prime Ministerial candidate Srettha Thavisin greets supporters during an election campaign in Bangkok, Thailand, 24 April 2023. The Pheu Thai Party linked to former coup ousted leader Thaksin Shinawatra announced the party will not join to form a government with the two pro-military parties led by the two generals who were involved behind the 2014 military coup after the general election on 14 May 2023. The Pheu Thai Party leads ahead of all other parties in all of the survey polls for the upcoming general election.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT

Adverse weather events have affected food prices, which means the trajectory of inflation should not be practically taken as "one straight line" even amid slowing global demand, said UOB head of research Suan Teck Kin.
Pita Limjaroenrat, 42, the charismatic leader of the Move Forward party, is most-preferred PM candidate.
Former protest leader Panusaya “Rung” Sithijirawattanakul posing for a photo in front of the Democracy Monument in Bangkok, Thailand, April 6, 2023.

site_title: 89% of depositors fully insured under Deposit Insurance Scheme; MAS to seek public consultation on scheme by end June
summary: The Deposit Insurance Scheme in Singapore covers 89% of depositors, with the remaining 11% either not insured or outside the scheme. Minister of State Alvin Tan stated that while deposit insurance is important, it's not the primary way to safeguard depositors' interests. Instead, a safe and resilient banking system relies on pre-emptive safeguards. The Singapore Deposit Insurance Corporation (SDIC) insures up to S$75,000 per depositor per financial institution.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan speaking in Parliament on 4 April 2022.
Generic picture of Singapore financial buildings landscape
Shares of PacWest slumped more than 40 per cent in Thursday afternoon trading – a record low – after the lender confirmed a Reuters report that it was exploring strategic options.
The DIF, as the fund is known, is a linchpin of the US financial system as it’s used to insure most accounts for up to US$250,000.

site_title: Saudi Arabia budget slips into deficit as spending accelerates
summary: Saudi Arabia reported a 2.91 billion riyal deficit in the first quarter, driven by increased spending on salaries and economic diversification projects. Non-oil revenues rose 9% while oil revenues fell 3% to 179 billion riyals. The government maintains an ability to continue expansionary fiscal policy, despite predictions of a budget deficit by the International Monetary Fund, forecasting a 1.1% GDP deficit.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's gross domestic product grew an annual 3.9 per cent in the opening three months of the year, according to preliminary data released by the General Authority for Statistics.
The kingdom is the world’s largest oil exporter and leads the Opec+ group of producers along with Russia.

site_title: Chinese bank stocks soar, adding US$159 billion in trading frenzy
summary: Chinese bank stocks surged on Monday, adding $159 billion to the market value of the CSI 300 Financials Index, its fifth consecutive gain. State-owned lenders such as China Citic Bank Corp and Bank of China posted significant gains, with Bank of China hitting a 10% limit-up for the first time since 2015. The rally followed deposit rate cuts by three nationwide lenders and progress on state-owned enterprise reform, boosting investor sentiment. Analysts attribute the gains to cheap valuations and attractive dividend yields, with some seeing value in bank stocks despite shrinking net interest margins.

site_title: Chinese tycoon’s HK$7 billion Hong Kong tower put on sale by creditors
summary: A commercial property valued at HK$7 billion (S$1.18 billion) in Hong Kong, owned by Chinese tycoon Chen Hongtian, has been put up for sale by its creditors amid a liquidity crunch in the mainland real estate market. The property, comprising an office building and retail villa, was previously valued at HK$7 billion. The tender, managed by Savills, will close on August 28. This sale follows other Chinese developers' properties going on the market in recent months, as the market continues to face challenges.

images.alt_text: Jiayuan, which has fallen out of the top 100 builders in China based on contracted sales, in August first proposed to exchange its dollar notes in order to extend maturities.

site_title: China limits data after US research spurred alarm: WSJ
summary: China has curtailed access to sensitive data from overseas firms, partly due to reports by US research institutions that alarmed officials. The Cyberspace Administration of China notified data providers in March to restrict access to information such as patents and statistics. This move comes as tensions with the US continue to rise, with US think tanks like the Center for Security and Emerging Technology and the Center for a New American Security facing scrutiny. The restrictions are expected to limit public discourse on China and make the US-China relationship worse.

images.alt_text: The semi-annual event is known as the Canton Fair kicked off on Apr 15, just as Chinese officials embarked on a charm offensive to lure foreign investors back after three years of Covid Zero policies that prevented in-person visits.
Jiayuan, which has fallen out of the top 100 builders in China based on contracted sales, in August first proposed to exchange its dollar notes in order to extend maturities.

site_title: China’s main trade fair struggles to lure buyers as global growth slows
summary: China's largest trade fair, the Canton Fair, saw a disappointing turnout with only $25.1 billion in transactions agreed, down from $38 billion in 2008 and $30 billion in 2019. The fair, which kicked off in April, was expected to attract foreign buyers but was largely attended by local trading firms and vendors. The decline is attributed to a slowing global economy, high inventory levels, and rising interest rates, which have led to decreased consumer demand in the US and Europe. Sellers are also concerned about buyers moving to other regions, exacerbating the situation amid intensifying geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: The benchmark CSI 300 Index has continued its downtrend as mainland markets reopened after the Labour Day holiday, suggesting traders are unimpressed by the surge in tourism spending as they worry more about the surprise weakness in the manufacturing sector.
China has raised its gold holdings by about 8.09 tonnes in April, according to data from the State Administration of Foreign Exchange on Sunday (May 7).

site_title: Thailand chokes on pollution but greens struggle to be heard in election
summary: Thailand's election is approaching, with record-breaking air pollution affecting the country for the past three months. Despite growing awareness of environmental issues, green movements have struggled to gain traction with Thai voters. Green Party leader Phongsa Choonaem says the public's understanding of environmental issues is improving, but the party is fielding only a handful of candidates. Critics argue that Thailand's system of political patronage hampers substantive change, and politicians' promises are often "loosey-goosey" in detail. Voters' growing awareness of air pollution is encouraging, but it remains a side issue in the election.

images.alt_text: Daniel Bian, a Chinese potential property buyer from Shanghai, visits a luxury condominium in Bangkok, Thailand, April 20, 2023.
Sunday’s voters are among more than 52 million who will elect 500 candidates to Thailand’s House of Representatives.

Pita Limjaroenrat, the Move Forward Party's candidate for prime minister, greets supporters during a general election campaign in Bangkok, Thailand, 04 May 2023. site_title: Binance again pauses Bitcoin withdrawals, cites congestion
summary: Binance, the largest crypto exchange, temporarily paused Bitcoin withdrawals for about 90 minutes, citing congestion on the token's blockchain. The pause, which occurred for the second time in less than 12 hours, led to a 2.9% decline in Bitcoin's price. The move comes as Bitcoin developer Casey Rodarmor's Ordinals protocol, which allows for minting non-fungible tokens (NFTs) on the network, boosted transactions on the blockchain, causing congestion. Binance assured customers that funds are safe.

images.alt_text: Beijing cracked down on digital assets over concerns about money laundering, currency outflows and the environmental impact of Bitcoin mining.
NFTs were once one of the hottest tokens around, with celebrities like Paris Hilton creating collections and Justin Bieber buying the digital images.

site_title: Australian government pledges A$15b in budget to ease cost of living
summary: The Australian government has pledged A$14.6 billion in budget funding over four years to ease the cost of living for low-income families, small businesses, and pensioners. This move aims to directly alleviate price pressures and inflation, which remains near 30-year highs of 7.0%. The budget plan, unveiled by Treasurer Jim Chalmers, will provide financial assistance for over 5 million households and businesses struggling with high power bills, without adding to inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: A shopper browses products at a Wesfarmers Ltd. Coles supermarket in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, July 28, 2011. Wesfarmers Ltd., Australia's second-largest retailer, said fourth-quarter sales from its Coles supermarkets rose 7.2 percent as cheaper milk and bread lured customers. site_title: Despite low yields and high taxes, Singapore properties still a draw for foreigners
summary: Foreigners continue to buy properties in Singapore despite high taxes and low yields, accounting for 4.3% and 7.3% of new private apartment and condominium sales in 2021 and 2022 respectively. The Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rate for foreigners doubled from 30% to 60% in 2023, but still attracted buyers. Non-PR foreigners, mainly from China, Malaysia, India, and the US, accounted for 15.1% and 11.3% of new sales in Q1 2023. Foreigners add to overall demand and upward pressure on prices, making it challenging for locals to buy private homes.

site_title: Industries must support local training efforts for jobs to be added to shortage occupation list: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng emphasized that industries must support local training efforts for jobs to be added to the shortage occupation list. The list requires industry sectors to demonstrate a commitment to develop local talents in such jobs. The Ministry of Manpower and Ministry of Trade and Industry will monitor indicators of shortage and track local graduates who can take on these roles. Extra points will be granted to EP applicants for jobs on the list, and the list will be reviewed annually to adjust occupations and ensure a responsive labor market.

The bonus criteria award bonus points to EP applicants who possess skills in shortage and firms that contribute to the country's strategic economic priorities.

site_title: Ex-Trek executive given 2 months’ jail for cheating and falsifying accounts
summary: Foo Kok Wah, former divisional president of Trek 2000 International, was sentenced to two months in jail for cheating and falsifying accounts. This conviction marks the end of four prosecutions that began in 2019. Foo was previously convicted of two charges and had falsified the company's books in 2015 by recording a fictitious sale worth US$3.2 million to Unimicron Technology. The sentence follows convictions of Trek 2000 founder Henn Tan, former executive director Poo Teng Pin, and former CFO Gurcharan Singh, who were sentenced to between nine and 16 months in jail for related conspiracies.

images.alt_text: Founder of Trek 2000
Henn Tan has been in remand for 1.5 months, according to the court system.
Trek 2000 is better-known as the company that invented the ubiquitous thumb drive.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise after strong US jobs, rebound in banks
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, tracking a US jobs report and rebound in regional banks, easing recession fears. Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other markets rose, while Tokyo fell due to a retreat in banks. The US economy showed resilience despite higher rates and inflation, but investors remain wary of US financial system upheaval and a possible debt crisis. The Federal Reserve may pause interest rate hikes, providing a boost to markets, but concerns persist.

images.alt_text: Asia, meanwhile, got off to a similarly uneven start on Friday, with Hong Kong up more than one per cent at one point, but Shanghai down.

site_title: Most Sea employees to get 5% raise, now that company is profitable: Bloomberg
summary: SEA, a Singapore-based e-commerce and gaming company, is giving a 5% salary bump to most employees starting July, following a decline in cash balance the previous year and achieving "self-sufficiency". The raise applies to employees who joined on or before March 31. This marks a milestone for the company, which had previously announced several rounds of layoffs and salary freezes. The move comes as the company's cash balance is now on a growth trajectory.

site_title: Japan’s service activity grows at record pace in April: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector grew at a record pace in April, with the final au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers' index (PMI) reaching 55.4, surpassing the 50-mark for the seventh consecutive month. This follows a surge in consumer spending and international tourist arrivals after the end of Covid-19 pandemic restrictions. New orders expanded at the fastest pace on record, and business confidence for the coming year hit a record high, with 80% of service providers expecting an increase in activity.

images.alt_text: The Rothschild firm is seeing more Japan companies seek acquisition and investment opportunities in the US and Europe, and vice versa.

site_title: How ethics, vision, empathy and rewards help fix business culture
summary: A business culture can be improved by assessing its ethics, vision, empathy, and rewards. Leaders should ask sincere questions, check their biases, and demonstrate empathy to understand their employees' needs. Ethics should be prioritized, with a focus on visionary commercial ethics that align with societal expectations. Rewards, including material benefits and recognition, should be tied to employee performance and satisfaction. By implementing these strategies, businesses can foster a positive work environment, increase employee engagement, and drive long-term success.

site_title: Hot stock: Venture shares fall on Monday after Q1 results release
summary: Venture Corporation's shares fell 6.1% to S$16.02 on Monday after reporting a 12.4% year-on-year decline in Q1 net profit to S$73.6 million. The stock had initially shed S$1.04 before recovering to S$16.10, down 5.6%. The decline followed the company's Q1 results release, which also included a dividend of S$0.50 per share.

site_title: Singapore’s soaring rents are becoming a political problem
summary: Singapore's housing market is experiencing a severe shortage, with high-end properties seeing the world's fastest rental growth. Young singles, like 33-year-old Sonam, are being priced out of the nation's subsidized housing program, leading to growing concerns among expats and locals alike. The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) is under pressure to address the issue, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong acknowledging soaring prices but claiming incomes keep pace. The government has announced measures to curb foreign property purchases, but opposition lawmakers argue these steps will only drive up prices.

site_title: Chinese users of the Binance and FTX exchanges show holes in Beijing’s crypto ban
summary: Chinese citizens continue to buy and sell digital assets despite Beijing's 19-month-old crypto ban, with 8% of FTX users identified as Chinese and over 9 million customer accounts held by the exchange. Chinese investors have found workarounds to comply with the ban, using virtual private networks and digital identities in countries like Dominica. Experts say the ban has been ineffective or loosely enforced, and that legalization of crypto in China could lead to a surge in demand. The ban's difficulty in eliminating crypto trading is attributed to its decentralized nature and global exchanges.

site_title: Gold prices flat as traders gear up for US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Monday, holding at $2,016.29 per ounce, ahead of US inflation data due this week. Global demand for gold fell in the first quarter as central banks and Chinese consumers offset reduced investor buying. Investors maintained a cautious stance following stronger-than-expected US job growth and wage gains, which tempered expectations of interest rate cuts. The US consumer price index (CPI) data is due on Wednesday, with traders also monitoring the US banking sector amid economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: China has raised its gold holdings by about 8.09 tonnes in April, according to data from the State Administration of Foreign Exchange on Sunday (May 7).

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 7.44 points to 3274.07, a 0.2% gain. Gainers outnumbered losers 90 to 43 after 81.2 million securities worth S$66.5 million changed hands. Seatrium and MarcoPolo Marine led the gains, while Singapore's big three banks recorded mixed results. The gains followed a rally in US stocks, which rose on Friday due to upbeat results and a resilient labour market.

site_title: China builders with upcoming lawsuits just got a ‘wake-up call’
summary: Chinese developers facing winding-up lawsuits must now present a detailed restructuring plan and material creditor support to avoid liquidation. Jiayuan International Group, a residential and commercial builder, became the first to face court-ordered liquidation despite launching a debt exchange offer. The ruling marks a shift in approach, where public efforts to restructure debt are no longer enough to buy time in the courts. Other developers, including Logan Group, will face similar tests in the coming weeks.

site_title: Richest man in Vietnam reinforces risky US$8 billion wager on EVs
summary: Vietnam's richest man, Pham Nhat Vuong, is betting heavily on electric vehicles (EVs) with a US$8 billion wager, mirroring Elon Musk's approach. However, the odds of success are uncertain, with several high-profile EV ventures struggling or failing, including James Dyson's, Jia Yueting's, and Hui Ka Yan's companies. Despite this, Vuong remains committed to the EV market, a move that could either pay off or leave him facing significant losses.

The next few months could be a challenging time for markets, and investors should exercise caution.

site_title: Singapore e-commerce firm Mdada hit by complaints of late deliveries, defective goods
summary: Singapore-based e-commerce firm Mdada has faced complaints from customers about late deliveries and defective products. Among them, housewife XY Wu reported that her two orders, including a luxury leather bag and a skincare product, took over three months to arrive and were of poor quality. The company has received 44 complaints between Jan 1, 2022, and Apr 30, 2023, with issues including delayed deliveries, incomplete deliveries, and defective products. Mdada's co-founder Michelle Chia acknowledged the complaints and stated that the company aims to resolve all outstanding orders by June, attributing delays to supply-chain issues.

site_title: Digital Core Reit bullish on tight supply, strong demand for data centres
summary: Digital Core Reit's manager John Stewart believes the company can see positive rental reversions due to tight supply and growing demand for data centres. Rental rates are rising in the US and Europe as companies adopt AI and digitalize. Constrained supply in key markets is driving up pricing, with Stewart stating that the trend is expected to continue. This positive outlook is attributed to the growing demand from digitalizing companies, which Digital Core Reit sees as a net positive for its portfolio.

site_title: Australia’s Westpac flags H2 margin pressure, drops cost target
summary: Westpac, Australia's third-largest bank, has announced plans to shift its focus from an absolute expense target to a relative expense-to-income ratio, citing high inflation and intense mortgage competition. The bank has also dropped its cost target to A$8.6 billion by fiscal 2024. Despite a 22% jump in net profit to A$4 billion for the six months ended March 31, Westpac warned of margin pressure in the current half. The bank's expense-to-income ratio has improved to 45.9%, and it declared an interim dividend of 70 Australian cents per share.

images.alt_text: ANZ Banking Group, which reported a 23 per cent jump in cash profit on Friday (May 5), signalled it will look to diversify beyond mortgages, which have become increasingly competitive.

site_title: Australian budget near surplus as Chalmers joins inflation fight
summary: Australia's budget is expected to show a slim surplus of A$5.35 billion, or 0.25% of GDP, in the 12 months to June 30, driven by high export prices and low unemployment. The Reserve Bank of Australia has raised interest rates to combat inflation, which is running at 7%. The government aims to balance its budget with monetary policy, with Treasurer Jim Chalmers signaling a willingness to keep spending in check. A surplus this year is seen as a political victory for the centre-left government, but economists predict large deficits in the following years.

images.alt_text: Australia’s central bank is part of a worldwide wave of tightening as monetary authorities try to bring inflation under control, though most are nearing the end of the cycle following aggressive moves.

site_title: Oil prices inch up as recession fears begin to fade
summary: Oil prices rose slightly in early Asian trade on Monday, with Brent crude futures up 6 cents at US$75.36 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 8 cents at US$71.42. Fears of a US recession began to recede, contributing to the price increase, as a strong US jobs report, a weaker dollar, and expected supply cuts by Opec+ helped stabilize prices. The rebound follows a decline last week, with oil prices expected to continue rising as the US Federal Reserve is expected to pause rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Brent crude closes US$2.80, or 3.9 per cent higher, at US$75.30 a barrel. US West Texas Intermediate settles up US$2.78, or 4.1 per cent, at US$71.34 after four days of declines.

site_title: Arab League to readmit Syria after more than a decade of isolation
summary: The Arab League has unanimously decided to reinstate Syria, ending President Bashar Al-Assad's decade-long regional isolation despite US reservations. The decision, made at an Arab foreign ministers meeting in Cairo, caps months of diplomatic efforts and may be formalized at an Arab League heads of state summit in Saudi Arabia on May 19. The move reflects a broader shift in the Middle East, with Saudi Arabia increasing its influence and seeking to cement its role as regional power broker, while also supporting Assad diplomatically and economically.

Seatrium secured a contract worth over S$500 million to develop offshore wind farms. F&N posted a 19.8% decrease in net profit to S$55 million, while Venture's net profit fell 12.4% to S$73.6 million. Far East Orchard saw a 67.9% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$4.7 million.

site_title: Sustainability-linked loans’ targets increasingly sophisticated, science-based
summary: Sustainability-linked loans (SLLs) in Singapore are becoming increasingly sophisticated, incorporating more science-based targets and dynamic goals. Industry players say companies are recognizing the financial benefits of improving their sustainability practices, leading to a growing demand for SLLs. The loans are tied to key performance indicators such as green buildings, energy efficiency, and direct and energy-related greenhouse gas emissions, with indirect emissions from supply chains also being explored. Regulators are pushing for transparency, and the Climate Bonds Initiative suggests that mandatory transition plans are needed, with Singapore remaining the clear leader in SLL issuance volumes.

site_title: Over 26% of The Continuum’s units sold on launch day at average of S$2,732 psf
summary: The Continuum, a freehold development in District 15, saw over 26% of its 816 units sold on launch day at an average price of S$2,732 psf. A total of 216 units were sold, with "healthy demand" across all unit types. The development's strong showing defies recent cooling measures and a cloudy economic outlook, with buyers predominantly locals and first-timers. Experts attribute the slow sales to the price being "too aggressive" compared to comparable projects in the vicinity.

site_title: Chinese scour Thailand for homes, looking to offset risks after pandemic
summary: Mainland Chinese residents, seeking a safety net and hedge against economic risks, are flooding Thailand with property buys. Since China reopened its borders, Thailand has become a popular destination for Chinese tourists, with nearly 270,000 visiting in March, a three-year high. Many Chinese buyers are investing in luxury apartments in cities like Bangkok, seeking freedom and a better quality of life. Thai real estate agents are catering to Chinese buyers, despite rules limiting foreign ownership to 49%.

site_title: Malaysia gives Lynas extension to keep rare earths unit open
summary: Malaysian authorities granted Lynas Rare Earths a six-month extension to meet environmental requirements for its rare earths refinery in Pahang, extending the deadline to January 2024. The refinery, the largest outside China, has been plagued by environmental concerns and community opposition. The government issued a three-year licence to the plant with conditions requiring the relocation of radioactive waste and cracking and leaching processes. The decision was made after an appeal hearing in April.

summary: Marvel's Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 opened to a US$114 million in ticket sales in North American theatres, exceeding expectations despite concerns of superhero fatigue. The film's opening is considered "strong business" by analyst David Gross, who notes it's an excellent opening for a Marvel episode 3 sequel. The movie's success marks a positive trend for the superhero genre, defying predictions of fatigue among moviegoers.

summary: BT Podcasts is set to grow its reach and revenue with new facilities and an expanded team. The new facilities, built with a team of experts from various departments, will enable the production of more podcasts, while the expanded team will allow for better content creation and distribution. The move is aimed at serving BT consumers better and moving the needle on reach and revenue. site_title: Rothschild taps ex-Daiwa banker to bolster Japan expansion
summary: Rothschild & Co has hired Yuichi Akai, former co-head of investment banking at Daiwa Securities Group, as vice-chair for Japan to strengthen its business in the country. The move is part of a plan to accelerate Rothschild's ambitions in Asia, amid slowing business activity globally. The bank is adding staff in Japan and plans to continue hiring for investment-banking roles, with a focus on cross-border deals. Rothschild sees strong potential in the Japan market and is investing for the long term, driven by the country's merger activities.

site_title: ABSD hikes may push more wealth to Singapore commercial real estate
summary: High-net-worth individuals and family offices may shift wealth to commercial real estate in Singapore due to the government's 60% hike in Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for residential properties. Despite this, wealthy foreigners who have relocated to Singapore will continue to look for homes, with shophouses being a valuable tool for wealth preservation due to their rarity. Market watchers predict a pause in the high-end residential market, but commercial property remains unaffected by ABSD.

site_title: Inflation in Asean easing, seen converging towards central-bank targets by end-2023
summary: Inflation in Southeast Asian economies, known as Asean, appears to be easing, with cost pressures receding and monetary policy tightening helping to cool aggregate demand. The latest available data shows a decline in the headline consumer price index (CPI) across the Asean-6 countries, including Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam. Economists attribute this decline to adverse weather events affecting food prices, which are not directly correlated to slowing global demand. By end-2023, inflation is expected to converge towards central-bank targets.

site_title: Private-market assets are all the rage, but are they worth the bragging rights?
summary: Private-market assets, such as hedge funds and private debt, are increasingly being pitched to individuals with smaller portfolios, despite higher risks and illiquidity. Research by Laurence Siegel suggests that these assets are more suitable for ultra-high-net-worth individuals, but may not be worth the risks for those with less than $10 million. High hurdle rates and illiquidity make it challenging for individuals to justify the costs, with fees ranging from 2.22% to 4.5%. Experts advise caution and recommend keeping allocations small, with Siegel suggesting that a "very modest" allocation can provide "psychic benefits" without incurring significant costs.
