site_title: World food prices rise for first time in a year
summary: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's (FAO) world price index rose 0.7 points in April, marking the first increase in a year, due to higher prices for sugar, meat, and rice. The rise in sugar prices, 17.6% from March, was attributed to concerns over reduced supplies in India and China. Despite this, the FAO forecast world wheat production in 2023 at 785 million tonnes, slightly below last year's levels, and cereal stocks are expected to ease by 0.2% from their opening levels.

images.alt_text: China buys more than 60 per cent of the world’s traded soybeans, well over 90 million tonnes a year, largely from the US and Brazil.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Ant weighs introducing investor in Hong Kong bank unit
summary: Ant Group, backed by Jack Ma, is considering selling a stake in its Hong Kong virtual banking unit, Ant Bank (Hong Kong), to bolster operations. The move comes as the fintech giant overhauls operations to appease regulatory demands. Ant Bank recorded significant losses in 2021 and has been talking to potential investors. The plan is preliminary and subject to change. This latest move is part of Ant Group's restructuring efforts following its halted initial public offering in 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong should reduce fiscal deficit gradually: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) advises Hong Kong to reduce its fiscal deficit gradually to ensure a balanced recovery, rather than over two years, as its economy returns to normal after the pandemic. Hong Kong's real GDP is projected to grow by 3.5% in 2023 and 3.1% in 2024. The IMF notes that despite a strong recovery, the economy still has large slack and urges targeted household support to promote inclusive growth.

images.alt_text: “The recovery of inbound tourism and private consumption should continue to benefit the retail sector,” a government spokesperson says.
The HKMA has been intervening in the foreign exchange market to protect its currency peg, draining liquidity from the financial system and, in turn, pushing up short-term interbank rates.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Macroeconomic data dominates the week (Ep 42)
summary: Macroeconomic data dominated markets this week, with uncertain global conditions affecting performance. Claressa Monteiro, host of BT Market Focus, discussed SGX's wrap, insights from The Business Times' newsdesk, and notable corporate news for investors. The podcast also touched on the impact of macroeconomic data and inflation on the market.

images.alt_text: Find out how inflation and the ABSD hike affected markets this week.
Markets were pulled this way and that this week.

site_title: UK PM Sunak’s Conservatives rebuffed by voters at local elections
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's Conservative Party suffered a significant loss in local elections, with voters punishing the party for scandals, inflation, and stagnant economic growth. Labour added 193 seats and the Liberal Democrats gained 87, while the Conservatives lost 324 seats. A Sky News projection suggests Labour could garner 36-38% of the vote at the next national election, making them the biggest party, with the Conservatives at 28-30%. Labour leader Keir Starmer said the party is on track to win the next general election with an eight-point lead over the Conservatives.

images.alt_text: Barring a major calamity in coming months, it is most likely that Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will lead the Conservatives into the next general election next year. But he has a massive political hill to climb.

site_title: Slower US job growth expected in April; unemployment rate seen rising to 3.6%
summary: The US unemployment rate is forecast to rise to 3.6% in April, the highest since 2001, due to employers hiring the fewest workers in nearly 2.5 years. Higher interest rates are impacting the economy, but wage growth is expected to remain strong. The Labor Department's employment report will provide little relief to Federal Reserve officials battling high inflation.

images.alt_text: A Walmart in Atlanta, Georgia, US, on Sunday, Feb. 19, 2023. Walmart Inc.'s profit forecast for this year fell short of analyst estimates, signaling more struggles for the world’s largest retailer after it was hammered by a surge in inventory. Photographer: Dustin Chambers/Bloomberg
Markets are still hoping the US Fed will start to cut rates this year.

site_title: The Japan opportunity: Potential for attractive long-term returns
summary: Japanese equities are considered a compelling long-term investment opportunity, with potential for mid-teens annual percentage compound total returns over the next 5-10 years. Earnings growth is expected to drive this, with a 8% annual compound rate, and dividends could add to the potential return. The country's economic and corporate reform efforts, including "Abenomics," have led to respectable earnings growth and a strong institutional framework. However, short-term considerations, such as currency impact and a widening yield curve control range, may impact investor confidence. Despite this, the author believes the stock market will be driven by earnings, not currency fluctuations, and Japan is forecast to be one of the fastest-growing developed economies in 2023.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc
Even after their rally over the past year, the main Japanese stock indices are still well below their historical peaks.

A Tokyo Stock Exchange analysis shows that about half of the 1,800 companies on the exchange’s prime section were trading below their book value in January, meaning that the market is under-pricing the shares.

site_title: Great Eastern Q1 total weighted new sales down 22% to S$390.9 million
summary: Great Eastern's Q1 total weighted new sales fell 22% to S$390.9 million, due to lower single-premium sales in Singapore and partially offset by better performance in regular premium sales. The company attributed the decline to strong competition in the market. Despite the fall in new business embedded value, margins were higher in Q1 across all markets due to a shift in product mix. Profit attributable to shareholders stood at S$244 million, with shares closing up 1.1% on the day.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

INSURANCE company Great Eastern Holdings said its profit attributable to shareholders fell to S$220 million for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, 50 per cent lower than the S$437.6 million in the same period a year ago.

site_title: US can’t use Philippine bases for China offensive, Marcos says
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. stated that the US cannot use military bases in the Philippines as staging areas for an offensive action against China, amid tensions over Taiwan. Marcos said the Biden administration has never raised such a possibility, and he has reassured Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang on this matter. Marcos also expressed his country's commitment to strengthening US-Philippine defense ties while maintaining a balance with Beijing's increasing pressure. Joint patrols with the US and other nations in the South China Sea could begin this year, and Manila is in talks for a trilateral defense treaty with Washington and Tokyo.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. discusses "the modernization of the U.S.-Philippines alliance," during an event at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, U.S., May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Nathan Howard

Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr’s official visit to Washington is the first by a Philippine president in more than 10 years, and the latest in a series of high-level meetings that the Philippines has held with leaders of the US and China, which are jostling for strategic advantage in the region.

site_title: Australia-UK free trade accord to begin as EU deal nears finish
summary: The UK and Australia have agreed on a free trade accord, set to take effect on May 31, marking the first full deal negotiated from start to finish since the UK's 2016 EU exit. The agreement eliminates tariffs on 99% of Australian exports to the UK, including agricultural products, and streamlines visa and business licensing. The deal is seen as a "win-win" for both countries, reducing costs for consumers, and comes ahead of a similar agreement with the EU, which is nearing completion.

images.alt_text: Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers is expected to announce a slim surplus for the fiscal year through June when the 2023 budget is released next Tuesday.
Export volumes of iron ore lumps and iron ore fines to China jumped 24.3 per cent and 17.7 per cent respectively from a month earlier.

site_title: IAG boost outlook after swinging to profit in Q1
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways and Iberia, raised its full-year earnings outlook after reporting a surprise profit in Q1. The airline industry has rapidly recovered from the pandemic slump, with operating profit exceeding the upper end of its previous guidance of 1.8-2.3 billion euros. IAG now expects operating profit to exceed this range, and net debt is expected to decrease by the end of the year. The company attributed the positive results to lower fuel prices and strong demand for air travel, with leisure demand particularly strong and business travel recovering more slowly.

images.alt_text: British Airways planes sit on the tarmac at London Heathrow airport on Tuesday, November 5, 2002.  British Airways is leading European carriers in cutting costs, planning to reduce its workforce 23 percent to 43,500 employees and save 650 million pounds a year by 2004. Photographer: DD/Bloomberg News.

site_title: Indonesia Q1 GDP growth beats expectation at 5.03% year on year
summary: Indonesia's economy grew 5.03% in Q1, beating expectations, driven by a commodities-led export boom. This marks the country's recovery from the pandemic. However, analysts predict a slowdown in growth as commodity prices ease and global demand is impacted by monetary policy tightening. Indonesia's central bank has paused interest rate hikes, with some expecting no further changes this year. The transportation, warehousing, and hospitality sectors recorded the fastest year-on-year growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Trucks are seen near a palm oil plantation at a village in Sepaku, East Kalimantan province, Indonesia, March 8 2023. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo
Bahlil Lahadalia says the government will seek the cheapest pricing possible to increase its stake from 51 per cent to 61 per cent in Freeport-McMoRan’s Indonesian unit.

The global nickel market is facing a massive oversupply this year due to surging Indonesian output.

site_title: Pressure grows for regulatory intervention as US bank rout deepens
summary: US regulators face pressure to intervene in the banking sector amid a renewed rout in regional lenders' shares, with PacWest Bancorp exploring strategic options and Western Alliance's shares plummeting 60% after a report denying strategic options. Major US banks lost ground, and deposit insurance is being called for to prevent further bank failures, with some experts warning of potential risks and others advocating for government backstops. The US Treasury and Fed have yet to step in, but regulators are closely monitoring market developments and considering options to support the banking system.

images.alt_text: PacWest has about 70 branches, primarily in California, as well as about US$44 billion in assets.

site_title: Federal Reserve data shows failed bank First Republic was key central bank borrower
summary: The US Federal Reserve's emergency lending activities have shifted from banks to "other credit" as First Republic Bank, a key borrower, shut down. Discount window borrowing declined to $5.3 billion, while Bank Term Funding Program loans fell to $75.8 billion. "Other credit," which includes loans associated with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's work on high-profile bank failures, increased to $228.2 billion. The Fed's leader, Jerome Powell, stressed that conditions in the banking sector have improved, and the US banking system is resilient.

images.alt_text: Markets are still hoping the US Fed will start to cut rates this year.
S&P cut First Republic Bank's credit rating to ‘CC’ and said it expects default to be a “virtual certainty.”

site_title: Adidas ‘optimistic’ as first-quarter sales beat expectations
summary: Adidas reported a small operating profit of 60 million euros in its first-quarter results, beating analyst expectations, despite sales falling 1% and a 400 million euro loss from the Yeezy partnership. CEO Bjorn Gulden forecast a "bumpy year" and a potential 700 million euro operating loss if the Yeezy stock is completely written off. The company's gross margin fell to 44.8% due to higher supply chain costs and discounts, but the "terrace" style shoes are doing well.

images.alt_text: Adidas is considering selling Yeezy products and donating the profit to charity, as it tries to offset the financial hit from the collapse of the alliance with Ye
An Adidas spokesman told AFP that “we are already in the process of withdrawing our opposition to the Black Lives Matter Global Network Foundation’s trademark application”.

site_title: A house that is as green as it gets
summary: A California couple, Sally and Bay Liu, built a 7,477-square-foot eco-friendly home in suburban Hillsborough, California, with the goal of achieving net-zero energy. The "House of Earth and Sky" features rammed earth, glass walls, and blackened wood cladding, and incorporates water- and energy-conservation features. The home, designed by Aidlin Darling Design, received the highest Leed certification: platinum. The home's design allows for abundant connection to the outdoors, and its passive- and engineered-solar power systems work as planned, meeting the couple's goal of net-zero energy.

images.alt_text: The roughly US$150 million conversion of the Hilton will show how such projects – quicker and cheaper than building new apartment buildings – can be an effective way of adding more affordable housing in New York.

site_title: HSBC faces shareholder vote on splitting bank
summary: HSBC is set to face a shareholder vote on a proposal by its largest stakeholder, Ping An, to split the bank into a separately listed entity headquartered in Hong Kong. Ping An is seeking better returns, while HSBC has urged shareholders to vote down the proposal. The bank's quarterly net profit surged in the previous week, boosted by rising interest rates and its rescue of the UK arm of Silicon Valley Bank. The outcome of the vote will determine the bank's future restructuring plans.

images.alt_text: Relatively newer sustainable bond markets around the globe are increasingly complementing sustained growth in more seasoned markets such as China, according to Moody's ESG Solutions.

Hang Seng Index inched up 0.2 per cent, while Hang Seng China Enterprises Index dipped 0.33 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia PM in talks with countries to bring Jho Low back
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is in talks with other countries to bring fugitive financier Jho Low back to face charges related to the 1MDB scandal. Low was first charged in absentia in 2018 with eight counts of money laundering. The process involves international cooperation and intelligence services. Anwar reiterated his government's commitment to bringing Low back, despite the complexity of the process. This comes after Low struck a deal with US prosecutors to recoup assets worth over $1 billion. Low is wanted for his role in stealing $1.42 billion from 1MDB.

images.alt_text: Grammy Award-winning rapper Prakazrel "Pras" Michel of the hip hop group "The Fugees" leaves US federal court with his attorneys after being convicted on criminal charges that he conspired with Jho Low to orchestrate a series of foreign lobbying campaigns aimed at influencing the US government, in Washington, April 26, 2023.

site_title: What happens when a story loses a main character?
summary: The article discusses how the death of a main character can significantly impact a story. The author cites examples from various TV shows, including Succession, Game of Thrones, Homeland, and The Wire, where main characters are killed off early in the series. The author argues that such deaths can be a narrative risk, but also a profound one, as it forces the story to adapt and explore the aftermath of the character's demise. The article concludes that the death of a main character can lead to a shift in the story's dynamics, much like real-life bereavement, and can ultimately lead to the emergence of new heroes and plotlines.

images.alt_text: The financial world's favourite TV drama Succession is now in its 4th and final season.

site_title: Go Air may have planes repossessed, complicating rescue efforts
summary: Go Air, an Indian airline, may have its planes repossessed by lessors, complicating its rescue efforts. At least 20 Airbus jets operated by the airline are at risk of being de-registered by the Directorate General of Civil Aviation, including brand new A320neo jets. The move could further hinder the airline's attempts to start flying again, as it is controlled by billionaire Nusli Wadia's group and is insolvent. India's enforcement of the Cape Town Convention, which defines aircraft ownership rights during payment defaults, has been slow in the past, leading to increased lease rates and court cases.

site_title: Vietnam to more than double power generation by 2030, lower offshore wind target
summary: Vietnam aims to more than double its power generation capacity to 158 gigawatts by 2030, with coal remaining a dominant source of electricity until the end of the decade. The country plans to increase coal-fired power capacity to 30.1 GW by 2030, while offshore wind capacity will reach 6 GW, slightly lower than initially estimated. Vietnam's overall energy mix is expected to be dominated by hydropower, liquefied natural gas, and onshore wind by 2030. The government's power plan is crucial for unlocking $15.5 billion in green-transition funds and supporting an average annual economic growth of 7% this decade.

CapitaLand was reported in talks to buy Vietnam property assets from Vinhomes against the backdrop of a cash crunch in local property market

site_title: China’s services activity expands as consumers return: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector expanded for a fourth consecutive month in April, with the Caixin/S&P Global services PMI falling to 56.4, above the 50-point mark. The economy grew faster than expected in the first quarter, driven by a return to pre-pandemic demand levels. However, the world's second-largest economy faces an uneven recovery, with strong services activity and manufacturing contraction. China's tourism rebounded during the May Day holidays, but the economic rebound's sustainability remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Shein and Temu have taken the world by storm, with a potent combination of ultra-low prices and personalised recommendations.
China’s property sector, which accounts for a quarter of the economy, has shown some signs of stabilising in recent weeks with home prices rising.
China’s economy expanded at the fastest pace in a year last quarter, largely driven by consumer spending as the nation ended its Covid curbs.

site_title: China to enhance credit support to private investment projects
summary: China's state planner plans to enhance credit support for private investment projects to encourage more private capital investment in major projects. Despite better-than-expected economic growth in the first quarter, public investment outpaced sluggish private investment by a big margin, with private sector fixed-asset investment growing only 0.6% and state sector investment jumping 10.0%. This move aims to rebalance the economy and promote more private sector investment.

images.alt_text: People cross a street near office towers in the Lujiazui financial district, ahead of the National People's Congress (NPC), in Shanghai, China, February 28, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song
China’s economy grew at a faster-than-expected pace in the first quarter, as businesses and consumers shook off the chill of strict Covid-19 curbs that were lifted in December.
China’s property sector, which accounts for a quarter of the economy, has shown some signs of stabilising in recent weeks with home prices rising.

site_title: BMW warns owners ‘do not drive’ 90,000 cars recalled over defective airbag
summary: BMW has issued a "do not drive" alert for 90,000 affected vehicles with Takata airbags, citing risks of explosion after long-term exposure to high heat and humidity. The recalled vehicles include models from the 2000-2006 3 Series, 2000-2003 5 Series, and 2000-2004 X5s. The crisis has linked at least 25 US deaths and over 400 injuries to the defective equipment, prompting recalls from multiple carmakers. Owners are advised to check their vehicles' eligibility for a free repair and contact a BMW service centre for assistance.

site_title: Philippine inflation slows in April, builds case for a rate pause
summary: The Philippine consumer price index rose 6.6% in April, the slowest pace of increase since August, below the 7.0% forecast. This eased inflation, building a case for the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas to pause interest rate hikes, with the central bank raising rates by 425 basis points since last May. Officials say inflation may settle within the 2-4% target in the fourth quarter, and analysts expect the BSP to keep rates on hold this month, with a possible pause in interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Avril de Torres (right) of the Center for Energy, Ecology and Development says the shift from loans to bonds is what facilitates continued fossil fuel investments.

site_title: Gold set for weekly gain on bets of US Fed pause
summary: Gold prices rose, poised for its biggest weekly gain in nearly two months, amid uncertainty and lower interest rates. The US Federal Reserve signaled a likely pause in interest rate hikes, boosting demand for the safe-haven metal. Economic uncertainty and a weakening dollar also made gold more attractive for overseas buyers. Spot gold was flat but set for a 3% weekly gain, while US gold futures rose 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016. Gold advanced to the highest level in a year after the European Central Bank indicated it wouldnÕt cut interest rates further, boosting the euro and making dollar-denominated bullion less expensive for investors. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

site_title: E-commerce 2.0: Shein and Temu fight for the global market
summary: Shein and Temu, two Chinese e-commerce companies, are vying for the global market with their ultra-low prices and personalized recommendations. Shein, founded in 2012, has become one of the world's largest fast-fashion retailers, while Temu, launched in 2022, has already become the top downloaded app in the US. Both companies are in stiff competition for consumer wallets, challenging e-commerce stalwarts like Amazon and Alibaba. Despite their success, they face challenges such as supply chain transparency, geopolitical tensions, and ESG concerns. Shein plans for a US IPO and aims for $58.5 billion in revenue by 2025, while Temu seeks to expand into European markets. The companies' business fundamentals, including cash burn and profit margins, will be crucial to their long-term success.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Shein taps on technology across its operations, giving it cost savings and lower overheads said Leonard Lin, country general manager, Singapore, Shein.
Temu has made a big splash since launching in the US last September, selling shoes, jewelry, beauty accessories and home goods directly from Chinese merchants for very low prices.
“Consumers these days are no longer looking just at price: in the next phase to continue to grow you need to have ESG in mind,” Shein executive vice chairman Donald Tang said.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed after slide on Wall Street
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Friday, following a slide on Wall Street driven by renewed fears of banking sector turmoil. US regional bank shares plummeted, with PacWest, First Horizon, and Western Alliance losing 50.6%, 33.6%, and 38.5%, respectively. Despite this, Hong Kong rose over 1% and Sydney and Taipei also increased. European markets also saw a cautious rebound. Experts warn that the acute phase of bank turmoil may not be over, and policymakers need to address financial stability concerns.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass an electronic board showing the numbers for the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong on December 5, 2022. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)
