The Federal Reserve begins two days of meetings today to determine its next steps in relation to interest rates in an ongoing battle against reigning in inflation.   Win McNamee/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by WIN MCNAMEE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Sydney, Seoul, Wellington and Singapore were down, while Taipei, Jakarta and Manila were up.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 4.5% in March, easing from February’s double-digit growth
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 4.5% year-over-year in March, slowing from February's 12.6% growth. On a month-on-month basis, sales increased 2.2% from February. Online sales accounted for 13% of the estimated total retail sales value of S$4.1 billion.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Brothers Ang Eng Guan (left) and Ang Eng Hwa set up Soon Lee Heng (SLH) Fresh Fruits Trading in 2014.

site_title: Indirect stakeholder’s winding-up petition of no material impact: Dasin Retail Trust
summary: Sino-Ocean Capital, an indirect stakeholder in Dasin Retail Trust and its trustee-manager, is facing a winding-up petition in Hong Kong. The trustee-manager stated that the petition has no material impact on the trust's day-to-day operations. Sino-Ocean Capital holds 70% interest in the trustee-manager and 11.988% of the trust's units. The trustee-manager will make further announcements if material developments occur, and Dasin Retail Trust's units traded 0.8% lower following the news.

images.alt_text: Ocean Metro Mall, one of seven malls in Dasin Retail Trust's portfolio.
The Carrefour lease in Ocean Metro Mall was originally for a term of 20 years, commencing from Dec 28, 2014, for a total leased area of 17,770 square metres (sq m).
Luso Bank on Jan 10 issued a letter of demand to Dasin’s trustee-manager, declaring an event of default and demanding payment.
The trustee-manager is negotiating to extend the loan maturity date of its offshore facilities.

site_title: Expedia Group beats Street estimates on record lodging bookings
summary: Expedia Group reported a record first-quarter lodging bookings, beating Street estimates, with total gross bookings rising 20% year-over-year to $29.4 billion. The company posted an adjusted loss of 20 US cents per share, missing expectations. Travel demand remains elevated despite economic concerns, driven by increasing international travel and major city travel. Shares rose 4.3% after the announcement, with CEO Peter Kern citing strong travel demand and shifting travel preferences towards traditional travel.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of global online travel brand Expedia is pictured at the International Tourism Trade Fair  in Berlin, Germany, March 9, 2016.          REUTERS/Fabrizio Bensch/File Photo

site_title: Macquarie rides commodities volatility to post record profit
summary: Macquarie Group posted a 10% jump in annual profit, reaching A$5.18 billion, driven by a 54% surge in profit from its commodities and global markets unit. The bank's return on equity slipped to 16.9% due to a downturn in dealmaking. Macquarie's investment banking advisory business saw a 50% decline in profit, while the bank will pay a final dividend of A$4.50 per share. CEO Shemara Wikramanayake's compensation rose 27% to A$32.8 million, while commodities head Nick O'Kane's earnings surged 59% to A$57.6 million.

site_title: Booking Holdings beats profit estimates on strong travel demand
summary: Booking Holdings reported a better-than-expected profit for the first quarter, driven by strong travel demand despite recession concerns. Revenues rose 40% to $3.78 billion, beating estimates. Shares rose 1% to $2,630.5. The company's success is attributed to flexible work arrangements and a strong US dollar, which helped offset high labor and maintenance costs.

images.alt_text: The company posted an adjusted first-quarter loss of 20 US cents per share, missing analysts’ expectations for a loss of 4 US cents a share.

site_title: RBA cuts GDP, inflation forecasts as rate hikes cool activity
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) lowered its forecasts for inflation, wages, and GDP growth, citing the impact of interest rate hikes. The RBA estimated trimmed mean inflation at 6% for the year-ended June, down from 6.25%, and expects it to ease to 4% by December. The central bank also lowered its forecasts for wages, GDP growth, and unemployment, citing a tightening labor market and stabilizing wages growth. The RBA's decision reflects a global trend of monetary authorities tightening to control inflation.

images.alt_text: Retail sales have been seasonally weak in December in recent times, suggesting further evidence of slowing demand is needed before the RBA pauses tightening.
The Reserve Bank of Australia lifted the key interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.85 per cent, wrong-footing many economists who predicted there would be no change.

site_title: Icahn Enterprises issues dividend after Hindenburg attack
summary: Icahn Enterprises, under pressure from short-seller Hindenburg Research, announced a dividend of $2.00 per unit to investors, sending shares higher. The move comes after Hindenburg disclosed a short call against Icahn's investment firm. Unitholders can opt for cash or additional units for the distribution, which is Icahn Enterprises' typical quarterly dividend.

images.alt_text: All told, Icahn’s fortune sank by an unprecedented 41 per cent to US$14.6 billion, according to the wealth index, dropping him from the world’s 58th-richest person to the 119th.
Hindenburg also claimed Carl Icahn was operating a “ponzi-like economic structure,” selling units to new investors to support its dividend payouts.

site_title: DoorDash rides on delivery demand to raise 2023 core profit forecast
summary: DoorDash raised its annual core profit forecast after beating quarterly revenue expectations, driven by a surge in food, grocery, and convenience orders despite high inflation. Revenue rose 40% to $2.04 billion, and the company now projects annual adjusted Ebitda between $600 million and $900 million. Total orders surged 27% to 512 million in the first quarter, and gross order value is expected to reach $63 billion to $64.5 billion for 2023.

images.alt_text: Consumers are spending on food delivery even though inflation is squeezing budgets and the economic outlook has soured.

In a tentative ruling Friday (Sep 24), Superior Court Judge Richard Ulmer rejected the San Francisco-based company’s request to dismiss the wrongful death lawsuit, which DoorDash said shouldn’t have been brought in California.

site_title: US new home listings plunge 21% with higher rates spooking sellers
summary: US new home listings have plummeted 21% in April compared to last year, with 31% fewer listings than in 2019, according to Realtor.com. Higher mortgage rates, above 6% since September 2022, are deterring both buyers and sellers, with many potential sellers feeling "locked in" to their current mortgages and unwilling to take on higher rates. This has led to slower price growth, with the national median listing price increasing just 2.5% year-over-year and the number of homes under contract declining by 23%.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip slightly at Friday’s open; STI down 0.1 %
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% at the open on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping to 3,267.32. The decline follows the US Federal Reserve's latest rate hike, which saw global markets react negatively. Marine engineering group Seatrium and beverage group Thai Beverage were among the most actively traded stocks, with Seatrium's share price falling 0.8% and Thai Beverage's gaining 0.8%. Local bank UOB was the only local bank to rise, with its share price increasing 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: US authorities probe Goldman Sachs over Silicon Valley Bank collapse
summary: US authorities are investigating Goldman Sachs over its role in Silicon Valley Bank's collapse. The probe centers on Goldman's multiple roles with SVB, including advising the bank and purchasing distressed debt, which contributed to the bank's demise. Goldman is cooperating with government bodies and providing information on its activities. The investigation follows a request from House Democrats to investigate whether Goldman operated at "arm's length" in its role as advisor for SVB. The government probes focus on the deal in which Goldman purchased distressed debt from SVB, which was announced just before the bank's collapse on March 10.

images.alt_text: The lender’s muni holdings were mostly long-dated bonds with low coupons.
Goldman Sachs added the lawsuit, filed on Apr 7 in the US District Court for the Northern District of California, seeks compensatory damages in unspecified amounts.

site_title: Google gives early look at Pixel fold phone before debut next week
summary: Google has given an early look at its foldable Pixel smartphone, the Pixel Fold, featuring a large external display and an even bigger internal screen that can close like a clamshell. The company will provide more information at its I/O conference on May 10. This move signals Google's entry into the competitive smartphone market, where it has struggled to gain a significant foothold. Foldable smartphones, though accounting for only 1% of shipments, contribute a larger share of revenue due to their higher prices.

site_title: Saudi Arabia cuts Asia oil prices as energy market weakens
summary: Saudi Arabia lowered oil prices for Asia, cutting the price of its Arab Light grade by 25 US cents to US$2.55 a barrel, amid a weakening global energy market. The move follows a slump in Brent and WTI futures due to a softening US economy, fragile banks, and weak manufacturing data in China. The price cut is a precautionary measure to stabilize the market, and the kingdom may opt for another supply reduction at the next Opec+ meeting on June 3-4.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco sets its crude prices based on recommendations from customers and after calculating the change in the value of its oil over the past month, based on yields and product prices.

site_title: UBS weighs options for sale of Credit Suisse’s Swiss unit: sources
summary: UBS is reviewing options for selling Credit Suisse's Swiss banking business, including an initial public offering (IPO), as part of a state-backed rescue takeover. The Swiss banking business reported pre-tax income of 1.5 billion Swiss francs in 2022 and is seen as the jewel in Credit Suisse's crown. UBS may keep investment banking operations while selling the rest, and a sale could create a dominant position in the Swiss loan market. The future of Credit Suisse's business in Switzerland is closely watched due to concerns over reduced competition.

images.alt_text: Bondholders in Asia are joining more than a thousand others in Europe and the US in seeking damages from the Swiss authorities.
The deal is expected to close by early June.

site_title: FDIC plans to hit big banks with fees to refill Deposit Insurance Fund
summary: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) plans to exempt smaller lenders from contributing to the Deposit Insurance Fund (DIF) and instead impose fees on larger banks to refill the fund. The proposal, set to be released next week, would exempt institutions with less than $10 billion in assets, affecting over 4,000 smaller lenders. Larger banks would bear the majority of the cost, aiming to replenish the DIF, which was partly depleted by the failures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve data on Thursday showed a large part of the central bank’s emergency lending activities in recent weeks were tied up with the now-shuttered First Republic Bank.
The FDIC said in its report that switching to a “targeted coverage” approach, where business accounts get more coverage than the current cap, would be the best option for financial stability.

site_title: Geely’s London black cab unit unveils new large EV platform
summary: Geely's London Electric Vehicle Company (LEVC) unveiled a new large electric-vehicle (EV) platform, dubbed Space Oriented Architecture (SOA), designed for vehicles ranging from people movers to commercial vans. Developed over two-and-a-half years in multiple countries, the platform offers longer range, fast-charging capabilities, and advanced driver-assistance features. It can be used for various EVs, including pickup trucks, large SUVs, and mobile homes, and is expected to provide a competitive edge for LEVC and potentially other Geely units.

images.alt_text: Zeekr’s shift to the gigapress technique comes at the same time Chinese rival Xpeng has adopted a new vehicle platform technology that also mimics the way Tesla designs and manufactures electric cars.

Renault and Geely want the JV to become a leading combustion engine and hybrid engine supplier for the car industry by the end of 2023, with a workforce of 19,000 and 15 billion euros in annual revenue.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit H2 DPU up 11.3% to S$0.05244
summary: AIMS Apac Reit posted an 11.3% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.05244 for the second half of 2023, driven by a 9.1% increase in gross revenue to S$84.2 million. Net property income rose 10.6% to S$61.4 million, and distributable income grew 12.7% to S$37.9 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy reached a record high of 98% and owns 29 properties valued at S$2.2 billion.

images.alt_text: AIMS APAC Reit will divest its Yishun property above for S$12.9 million at an 8.2 per cent premium .
Yu has more than 20 years of experience in leadership and management roles within the banking and financial services sector in Australia and Asia, the Reit manager says.
Higher gross revenue and net property income result in an increase in distribution per unit for Aims Apac Reit.

site_title: ‘Very happy’ Ed Sheeran wins US copyright trial
summary: Ed Sheeran won a US copyright trial, with a jury ruling that he "independently" created his 2014 hit song "Thinking Out Loud" and did not plagiarize Marvin Gaye's "Let's Get It On." Sheeran was "very happy" with the decision, calling it a "devastating and insulting" accusation that threatened songwriters' creative freedom. The trial was the second in a year for Sheeran, who previously successfully defended himself against a similar lawsuit in a London court.

images.alt_text: Actress Billie Lourd (left) and her husband Austen Rydell at a ceremony honouring Carrie Fisher who was posthumously awarded a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, Hollywood, California, May 4, 2023.
A first-time nominee for the rock honor, Nelson joins country legends Dolly Parton, who was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 2022, Hank Williams and Johnny Cash.
Paul Anka will perform in Singapore for the first time in 9 years.

site_title: The crowning of King Charles: A new start for the British monarchy?
summary: King Charles III's coronation marks a new start for the British monarchy, with a rise in his personal approval rating to 55% despite a decline in overall support for the institution. The event is expected to deliver a show of public support, with 65,000 events planned across the UK. However, a shift in the king's conduct and relationship with the public has raised concerns about the monarchy's ability to adapt. The institution is being held to account, with a greater emphasis on transparency and public service. The monarchy's future will be evaluated in public service terms, and modernization is expected to be a key aspect of Charles's reign.

images.alt_text: Oxford Street is decorated with British flags, ahead of the coronation of Britain's King Charles and Camilla, Queen Consort, in London, Britain.
During the ceremony, the glove is placed onto the right hand of the monarch during the ceremony as a reminder that the sovereign should exercise gentleness in raising taxes.

site_title: Microsoft is helping finance AMD’s expansion into AI chips
summary: Microsoft is providing financial support to AMD's expansion into AI chips, working together on a homegrown Microsoft processor for AI workloads called Athena. This move aims to offer an alternative to Nvidia, which dominates the market for AI-capable chips. AMD's CEO Lisa Su has stated that AI is the company's No 1 strategic priority, and Microsoft's chip division is developing a graphics processing unit for training and running AI models. The collaboration is part of a broader rush to augment AI processing power, driven by the demand for AI technology.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 02, 2022 a Microsoft logo is displayed at the MWC (Mobile World Congress) in Barcelona. - Wall Street stocks opened higher on April 26, 2023, lifted by strong earnings from Microsoft and other large companies, although shares of First Republic Bank tumbled again. (Photo by Josep LAGO / AFP)
The agreement  with Nware marks the latest effort by Microsoft to ease fears its purchase of Activision would hinder competition in cloud gaming

site_title: Apple’s iPhone bounces back, helping sales top estimates
summary: Apple's iPhone sales rebounded in the second quarter, exceeding analyst estimates with $51.3 billion in sales, up 1.5% from the same period last year. The company's overall revenue reached $94.8 billion, surpassing predictions of $92.6 billion. Despite a 2.5% decline in iPhone sales, Apple's performance marked a recovery from a slump affecting the tech industry. The company also announced plans for $90 billion in stock repurchases and raised its quarterly dividend by 4%.

images.alt_text: The Apple Inc. logo at the new Apple store in Mumbai, India, on Tuesday, April 18, 2023. Chief Executive Officer Tim Cook officially opened Apple Inc.’s first company-owned store in India, betting the iPhone maker’s retail outlets will help accelerate sales growth. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg
Small location devices intended as a way for people to find backpacks, laptops, keys, handbags or other items have been used by stalkers to secretly track people such as ex-romantic partners.

site_title: Carrie Fisher’s Walk of Fame star ceremony overshadowed by family squabble
summary: Carrie Fisher was posthumously awarded a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, but her family ceremony was marred by a bitter feud. Actress Billie Lourd, Fisher's daughter, oversaw the ceremony, which was held on May the Fourth, an unofficial Star Wars holiday. Fisher's brother Todd and half-sisters Joely and Tricia Leigh were absent, accusing Lourd of not inviting them, while Lourd accused them of cashing in on her mother's death. Mark Hamill paid tribute to Fisher, saying she was "our princess, dammit."

images.alt_text: Cast member Michael Douglas poses at a premiere for the film "Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania" in Los Angeles, California, U.S., February 6, 2023. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni
The video game-based film earned an estimated US$40 million for the Friday-through-Sunday period in the United States and Canada, for a domestic total so far of US$490 million.
The film, which stars Joaquin Phoenix as Napoleon Bonaparte, will first be shown exclusively in theatres this November.

site_title: Pacific West Bancorp tries to avoid a case of mistaken identity
summary: Pacific West Bancorp, a small Oregon-based bank, is seeking to distance itself from a California-based bank, PacWest Bancorp, amid concerns about a case of mistaken identity. Following a similar bank's recent financial difficulties, Pacific West Bancorp stated it is a separate entity with no affiliation. The smaller Oregon-based bank's shares have declined 3.6% this year, while PacWest's shares have plummeted 85% this year due to its own financial challenges and recent stock rout.

site_title: Qualcomm amplifies chip gloom with ‘sobering report’
summary: Qualcomm's shares dropped 7% after the chip designer reported a weaker-than-expected quarterly revenue outlook, citing a customer's delayed purchases and China's slow post-Covid recovery. The company's smartphone market is expected to take longer to rebound, potentially costing it $10 billion in market valuation. Despite this, Qualcomm's automotive revenue jumped 20% and its Internet-of-things unit reported in-line sales, indicating diversification efforts are on track.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Qualcomm is seen during the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain February 27, 2018. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo
Qualcomm faces stiffer competition, especially for high end smartphone chips, from Taiwan’s MediaTek.

site_title: Crypto exchange Coinbase posts smaller first-quarter loss
summary: Coinbase Global reported a smaller-than-expected first-quarter loss of $78.9 million, down from $429.7 million in the same period last year. The company's shares rose nearly 7% in extended trading after investors returned to the cryptocurrency market to hedge against economic concerns. Despite trading volumes more than halving to $145 million, CEO Brian Armstrong said Coinbase has emerged stronger after previous crypto cycles. The company's shares have risen nearly 40% this year, ending a brutal 85% decline in 2022.

images.alt_text: The new platform, Coinbase International Exchange, will list Bitcoin and Ether perpetual futures starting this week after it received a licence last month from the Bermuda Monetary Authority.

Coinbase said that it’s particularly interested in these so-called “flatcoins,” adding that exploring the potential of stablecoins is “more important than ever” given the recent woes of the banking system.

site_title: ECB raises rates by 25 bps in inflation fight
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 3.25% as expected, marking its fastest pace of tightening since last July. This decision aims to combat inflation, with ECB President Christine Lagarde signaling that more rate hikes may be necessary. The ECB's Asset Purchase Programme will also stop reinvesting cash from maturing debt in July, further restricting economic growth. Despite a slowdown in loan demand, Lagarde stated that more tightening is needed to tame inflation, and the bank's written statement hinted at future rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ An outdoor market in Paris on May 28, 2022. The euroÕs slide makes imports more expensive for people and businesses in the 19 countries that use the currency, adding to the regionÕs inflationary woes. (Dmitry Kostyukov/The New York Times)

site_title: NYSE-parent ICE tops profit views as market volatility spurs trading
summary: ICE, the parent company of the NYSE, reported first-quarter profit slightly above Wall Street views, driven by a 1% revenue growth in its exchanges segment to a record $1.09 billion. This was largely due to increased market volatility, which boosted trading activity. However, its mortgage technology business saw a slump due to interest rate hikes and the recent banking crisis. Despite this, the company's fixed income and data services segment revenue rose 11% to a record $563 million.

site_title: Credit Suisse AT1 holders in Asia add to claims
summary: Credit Suisse AT1 holders in Asia have joined over 1,000 European and US investors in seeking damages from the Swiss authorities for a 16 billion Swiss franc write-down of the bank's riskiest debt. The investors, representing over 60 in Asia, are seeking to "revoke the Finma order to write off the bonds" and compensation. This move comes after a similar suit filed by a US law firm, Quinn Emanuel, representing over 400 institutional investors. The case appeals Finma's decision to prioritize shareholders over AT1 bondholders, who lost billions in the bank's restructuring.

images.alt_text: The deal is expected to close by early June.

This was an abuse of process and the resolution procedure should not be used by Switzerland to enable UBS to take over Credit Suisse to the detriment of AT1 holders,” Law firm Pallas founder and managing partner Natasha Harrison said in a statement.

site_title: Volkswagen, Bosch give up joint venture plans for battery cells
summary: Volkswagen and Bosch have cancelled plans to create a joint venture to equip battery cell factories, despite initial intentions to digitize battery factories. The partnership, announced in 2022, aimed to deliver battery production systems and assist manufacturers in scaling up production. Bosch's CEO Stefan Hartung stated that the partnership will continue, with Volkswagen seeking new partners to equip battery cell factories.

site_title: Oil up slightly after smaller ECB hike; demand concerns linger
summary: Oil prices rose 0.44% to $72.65 a barrel after the European Central Bank slowed interest rate hikes, but demand concerns in major consuming countries, including China, limited gains. WTI crude rose 0.17% to $68.72, falling to a session low of $63.64 a barrel. This week's decline of over 9% was driven by US economy and manufacturing growth concerns, and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has implemented voluntary output cuts, but demand concerns remain.

images.alt_text: A Rosneft worker walks near a nodding donkey at the Yuganskneftegaz oil production station near the Siberian town of Nefteyugansk, some 3,000 km (1,863 miles) east of Moscow April 26, 2006. Russian state oil giant Rosneft and private major Surgutneftegaz won auctions on Tuesday for large oilfields in East Siberia as they prepare to be the key shippers via a pipeline to Asia.  REUTERS/Sergei Karpukhin

site_title: BuzzFeed, Vice woes signal crisis in digital-only media
summary: The digital-only media industry is facing a crisis, with BuzzFeed shutting down its news division and Vice on the verge of bankruptcy. Both companies relied heavily on advertising dollars, which have decreased significantly due to tech giants accounting for 70% of digital ad revenues. Experts attribute the failure to the "free model" not working as expected, and the difficulty in transitioning to a paywall model, as news consumers often prefer free content. This trend has also affected other media outlets, with many resorting to layoffs or debt to stay afloat.

images.alt_text: BuzzFeed shares plunged more than 20 per cent on Wall Street following the news it was shutting its news division.
Reached by phone Friday,  declined to comment further.
Verizon nears deal to sell media arm to Apollo

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE C-Reit, AA Reit, Great Eastern, Aztech, LHN
summary:
Key developments in the Singapore stock market on May 5, 2023, include:

- AA Reit announced an 11.3% increase in distribution per unit for the second half of FY2023, driven by higher rental and recoveries from its assets.
- OUE C-Reit reported a 1.5% rise in its unit price after announcing a 18% increase in net property income for the first quarter of 2023.
- Great Eastern Holdings posted a 22% decline in total weighted new sales for its first fiscal quarter, while Aztech Global reported a 3.6% decline in net profits.
- LHN issued a profit warning announcement, expecting a 47% year-on-year decline in net profit for the first half of its financial year.
- Trading halted for Penguin International pending an announcement about a potential takeover bid.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered decliners 290 to 272 on Thursday after 1.2 billion securities worth S$890.5 million were traded.

site_title: Moderna's surprise profit powered by deferred Covid orders
summary: Moderna reported a surprise profit of 19 cents per share in the first quarter, driven by higher-than-expected sales of its Covid-19 vaccine Spikevax, which reached $1.83 billion. The company expects an additional $3 billion in deferred vaccine revenue in the second half of 2023, with total Covid vaccine sales expected to reach $5 billion for the year. Moderna continues to expect the US annual Covid-19 market to be 100 million doses.

images.alt_text: Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine Comirnaty and virus pill Paxlovid have been transformative for the company, contributing more than half of the company’s US$100 billion in sales last year.

site_title: US productivity drops in Q1; labour costs jump
summary: US productivity declined 2.7% in Q1, missing economists' expectations, as unit labour costs surged 6.3% and hourly compensation rose 3.4%. This increase in labour costs may lead the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates higher for longer, potentially impacting the economy. The decline in productivity, the fifth consecutive year-on-year drop, is attributed to shifts in the workforce following the Covid-19 pandemic, making it challenging to assess productivity accurately.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in the SoHo neighborhood of New York, US, on Saturday, Jan. 21, 2023. The Bureau of Economic Analysis is scheduled to release personal spending figures on January 27. Photographer: Jordana Bermudez/Bloomberg

site_title: FedEx plans to move Asia headquarters, executives to Singapore from Hong Kong
summary: FedEx plans to consolidate its Asia Pacific, Middle East and Africa (AMEA) headquarters functions in Singapore, aiming to connect operations with greater speed and agility. The company will relocate some of its Hong Kong-based executives, including regional president Kawal Preet, to Singapore. FedEx will retain a significant presence and leadership roles in Hong Kong, with 35,000 workers in the region and services to over 100 countries. The relocation is expected to take place in September.

site_title: Concerns mount over retirement adequacy after RM145b pulled from Malaysia’s EPF
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) has seen a significant withdrawal of RM145 billion due to the pandemic, leaving low-income groups with depleted retirement savings. The EPF now has 51.5% of its members with less than RM10,000 in their accounts. Economists suggest raising the retirement age or addressing income inequality to rebuild retirement savings. The government has offered an alternative to struggling households by allowing personal loans backed by EPF savings, but experts warn of the strain on public healthcare if retirees rely on the underfunded system.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is under pressure to let citizens dip into their retirement savings once again, with the opposition clamouring that he allow for another round of “targeted withdrawals” to help struggling Malaysians.

Bank Negara Malaysia said in the article that Malaysians could run out of savings by the age of 58 due to low wages, high debt, and premature withdrawals from their retirement funds during the pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower as ECB slows rate hikes but signals more to come
summary: European shares ended lower on Thursday, closing 0.5% lower near one-month lows, as the European Central Bank eased interest rate hikes but signaled more tightening to come. The ECB raised rates by 25 basis points to 3.25%, with President Christine Lagarde stating the bank remains on its path to fight stubborn inflation. Analysts expect further rate hikes, with a peak of 3.75% possible, and predict the ECB will leave rates at that level until well into 2024.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.9 per cent to 33,127.74 on Thursday.

site_title: Penguin’s chairman, MD along with Dymon Asia SPV in second attempt to take firm private
summary: Penguin International, a Singaporean aluminium high-speed craft builder, is being taken private for the second time by a consortium led by its executive chairman and managing director, along with a special purpose vehicle under private equity firm Dymon Asia. The new offer price is S$0.82 per share, a 15.5% premium over the last transacted price. The consortium, called Aleph Tav, aims to delist the company from the mainboard and provide shareholders with a clean cash exit opportunity.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Penguin International posts 16% drop in net profit for H2 FY20
Penguin chairman, MD tie up with Dymon Asia fund to take firm private
Mandatory offer for Penguin turns unconditional; closing date extended
Offer for Penguin closes; offeror, concert parties to hold 80.05% stake
James Tham, managing director of Penguin International, is prepared to accept lower margins as part of the group's diversification efforts.
Offeror holds 75.68% stake in Penguin International after market acquisition

site_title: Sports events organisers encouraged to secure injunctions against online piracy
summary: The European Commission has issued a non-binding recommendation to sports event organisers to secure injunctions against online piracy of live events, aiming to curb a problem costing billions of euros annually. The recommendation encourages the use of blocking injunctions, cross-border cooperation, and measures to boost commercial offers. Despite this, lobbying groups have expressed disappointment, calling for binding legislation, and warning that the current recommendation may not be enough to tackle the issue. The Commission plans to set key performance indicators to monitor the impact of its suggestion.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower as regional banks dive again
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.9% to 33,127.74, the S&P 500 shedding 0.7% to 4,061.22, and the Nasdaq Composite Index losing 0.5% to 11,966.40. The decline followed another brutal sell-off in regional banking shares, with four bank failures since early March. The market downturn was driven by concerns over the stability of the US banking system and the potential impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY 02: The Federal Reserve building is shown May 2, 2023 in Washington, DC. The Federal Reserve begins two days of meetings today to determine its next steps in relation to interest rates in an ongoing battle against reigning in inflation.   Win McNamee/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by WIN MCNAMEE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 19, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: China tech : Unleash the private sector to spur  innovation
summary: China's private sector plays a crucial role in driving technological innovation, contributing over 70% of the country's technological achievements. Private enterprises have emerged as leaders in fields such as 5G, new-energy vehicles, and artificial intelligence. However, they face constraints, weak representation, and systemic barriers that limit their innovation. To overcome these challenges, the government has emphasized fair treatment and equal opportunities for private enterprises, and has implemented policies to improve their access to innovation resources. Restoring confidence in private enterprises' development and expectations for stability is also crucial to stimulating their innovative momentum.

images.alt_text: SenseTime CEO Xu Li took to the stage on Monday (Apr 10) to show the capabilities of its large AI model SenseNova and a user-facing chatbot called SenseChat.
Huawei's net income dived to 3 billion yuan in Q1 2023, following its first annual profit decline in more than a decade.
ByteDance is sharpening its focus on e-commerce and platforms such as TikTok and its Chinese sibling Douyin – implying a deemphasis on VR, gaming, and education.

site_title: Embraer posts net loss in seasonally weaker Q1
summary: Embraer reported a quarterly adjusted net loss of US$88.9 million, larger than the US$75.3 million loss seen a year ago, as it prepares to increase deliveries in the next quarters. Despite the loss, the company's results came in within management expectations for a seasonally weaker period and reaffirmed full-year forecasts. Shares fell 7% in morning trading, making it the biggest faller on Brazil's Bovespa stock index.

images.alt_text: Any deal remains distant as negotiations have yet to start, Airbus’ head of defense and space in Latin America, Victor De La Vela, said in an interview.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit Q1 NPI rises 18% to S$56.6 million
summary: OUE Commercial Reit reported a 18% increase in net property income (NPI) to S$56.6 million in Q1 2023, driven by higher contributions from its Hilton Singapore Orchard and Singapore commercial properties. However, higher interim interest expense due to steep interest rate hikes is expected to impact upcoming distributions in 2023. The Reit's manager is in advanced discussions with banks to refinance S$263 million of borrowings, which is expected to lengthen the average term of debt to 3.2 years.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

Han Khim Siew, the CEO of OUE Commercial Reit said the second half of 2022 was characterised by “continued operating challenges posed by geopolitical tensions, inflationary pressures, interest rate hikes and macroeconomic headwinds”.
Net property income in Q3 rose to S$48.3 million, due mainly to lower property expenses, while revenue increased 1.7 per cent to S$59.5 million, OUE C-Reit's manager said in an exchange filing.
OUE Commercial REIT  has reported a 1.2. 2 per cent fall in DPU on lower net property income arising from the 50 per cent divestment of OUE Bayfront

site_title: Bill Gates-backed startup plans plant for machine key to hydrogen future
summary: Bill Gates-backed startup Electric Hydrogen plans to build its first electrolyzer factory in Massachusetts, backed by a $90 million private investment. The plant, expected to be commissioned late this year, will produce large-scale electrolyzers for customers seeking to produce green hydrogen. Powered by renewable energy, electrolyzers split water into hydrogen and oxygen without emitting greenhouse gases. The move is part of a growing wave of clean-tech manufacturing projects in the US, as governments worldwide bet on green hydrogen to cut emissions in industries.

site_title: Directors need social media strategies
summary: Directors are urged to develop social media strategies to better represent their companies and engage with stakeholders. A 2022 survey found that 63% of people believe CEOs with online social profiles are better representatives for their companies. However, many CEOs lack familiarity with social media or prefer to maintain a low profile due to cultural and reputational risks. To mitigate these risks, companies should establish clear policies, monitor social media activity, and conduct scenario planning. Effective social media management can help companies gain a competitive advantage and build trust with employees, investors, and other stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Under pressure in a dynamic environment, management may, however, seek to portray a different financial image of the company beyond what strict accounting rules might allow.
Hybrid work is a flexible arrangement that supports a blend of in-office, remote and on-the-go employment.

site_title: WHO experts mull Covid emergency status
summary: The World Health Organization's emergency committee is meeting to discuss whether Covid-19 remains a global health emergency. The 15th meeting comes over three years after the initial emergency declaration and follows a recent drop in Covid-19 deaths by 95%. A decision on the emergency status is expected to be made by WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, who may lift the international emergency status, but it remains unclear which way the experts will lean.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A medical worker in a protective suit registers information for a patient at the entrance to the fever clinic of the Central Hospital of Wuhan, amid of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Wuhan, Hubei province, China December 31, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Goldman Sachs named as defendant in SVB-related class action lawsuit
summary: Goldman Sachs has been named as a defendant in a securities class action lawsuit related to SVB Financial Group's share offerings in 2021 and 2022. The lawsuit, filed on April 7, alleges material misstatements and omissions in the offer documents, seeking compensatory damages. Goldman Sachs booked a $1.8 billion loss on a bond portfolio acquired by SVB, which contributed to the bank's attempted stock sale and subsequent bankruptcy filing under Chapter 11 protection. The lawsuit is part of the broader fallout from the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and other financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Goldman has one of the biggest pools of veteran talent in Asia for equities, which has made it a prime poaching ground for rivals.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise as higher borrowing costs cool demand
summary: US initial jobless claims rose 13,000 to 242,000 for the week ended April 29, exceeding economists' forecast of 240,000. Higher interest rates are cooling demand, leading to a gradual softening of the labor market. Despite rising layoffs, the labor market remains tight, with 1.6 job openings for every unemployed person in March. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points and signaled a possible pause in further increases, citing a tight labor market and signs of supply and demand balance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for a job fair is seen on 5th Avenue after the release of the jobs report in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., September 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Aztech Global Q1 net profit falls 3.6% to S$13.4 million
summary: Aztech Global's net profit fell 3.6% to S$13.4 million in Q1 2023 due to higher operating expenses. Revenue rose 26.3% to S$161.6 million, driven by increased sales of IoT devices and data communication products. The company's order book remains strong at S$661.9 million, with most deals scheduled for completion in FY2023. Despite this, Aztech Global remains cautiously optimistic about its business outlook, citing supply chain challenges, inflation, and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Maybank Securities and DBS Group Research have raised their target prices on Aztech Global on its positive outlook, while UOB Kay Hian maintains its "buy" call with an unchanged target price.
Aztech Global's net profit in H2 2022 fell 45.9 per cent to S$24.3 million on foreign exchange loss, said the group on Friday.
The acquisition will expand the group’s manufacturing capacity for Internet of Things (IoT) devices and data-communication products in Malaysia.
Michael Mun, chairman and CEO of Aztech Global (right) says the group will continue to stay vigilant and nimble to manage the myriad of headwinds ahead.

site_title: US trade deficit falls in March on rise in exports
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed to $64.2 billion in March, a decrease of $6.4 billion from February, driven by a rise in exports to $256.2 billion, a $5.3 billion increase. Exports of industrial supplies, crude oil, and autos contributed to the growth. Imports fell to $320.4 billion, with a decline in semiconductor and petroleum product imports. The US goods deficit with China and the European Union also decreased. This narrowing trade gap may indicate some softening in trade as the US economy shows signs of cooling.

images.alt_text: Gold is a favoured trade in a stagflationary environment, as well as high quality bonds and companies with prcing power.

site_title: Majority of Sunac China creditors back debt restructuring plan
summary: Sunac China Holding, a major Chinese property developer, has received approval from 85% of its existing bondholders for a debt restructuring plan. The proposal, which was met in late April, involves exchanging part of the debt into convertible bonds backed by Hong Kong-listed shares and new notes with maturities of 2-9 years. This follows a similar agreement reached with offshore creditors in March to restructure US$9 billion of debt. The company's stock has lost more than half of its market value in recent months.

site_title: Ferrari Q1 core earnings up 27% as sportscar maker reopens Purosangue orders
summary: Ferrari's first quarter core earnings rose 27% to 537 million euros, beating forecasts, as demand for its cars extends into 2025. The company reopened orders for its Purosangue four-door, which was initially suspended due to high demand. Ferrari plans to deliver the petrol-powered car this quarter and has pledged to keep sales below 20% of total shipments to maintain exclusivity. The company also confirmed its full-year forecasts and expects to launch four new models this year.

images.alt_text: Ferrari Classiche cars in a garage at the Ferrari factory in Maranello, Italy; Ferraris are the most prized vintage autos, according to Adolfo Orsi, founder of the Classic Car Auction Yearbook, which has been tracking auction sales data since 1990, who described them as “absolutely the blue-chips of this sector”.

site_title: 👊 Grindset is out, quiet quitting is in
summary: Quiet quitting, a concept introduced by Zaid Khan on TikTok in August 2022, refers to doing one's job without going above and beyond, rejecting the hustle culture that values long hours with little self-care. The movement has been linked to the pandemic's effect on attitudes towards work, with many Gen Z respondents citing salary dissatisfaction and burnout. While some view quiet quitting as a healthy boundary, critics argue it can harm one's career if done for the wrong reasons. Experts suggest taking ownership of one's career growth and addressing underlying issues with managers before resorting to quiet quitting.

images.alt_text: Daryl Choo

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as PacWest woes offset Fed optimism
summary: US stocks opened lower on May 4, as the Dow Jones fell 66.46 points, or 0.20%, to 33,347.78, amid concerns over PacWest Bancorp's strategic options. This countered optimism from the Federal Reserve's potential pause in interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 falling 8.20 points, or 0.20%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 27.99 points, or 0.23%.

site_title: Covid rise tests Malaysia hospitals as Philippines reopens wards
summary: Malaysia's crowded hospitals are struggling to cope with a surge in Covid-19 cases, with over 70% of government hospital beds occupied. The jump in cases is fueled by recent gatherings during the Hari Raya Aidilfitri holiday, resulting in 20 deaths in two weeks. In response, the Philippines has reopened Covid treatment wards, while Vietnam and Singapore have reimposed pandemic-era restrictions. The surge highlights the need for governments to adjust to the disease's ebb and flow in a world living with Covid-19.

site_title: Interpol says 11,000 stolen artefacts seized in Europe crackdown
summary: Interpol reported that 60 people were arrested and over 11,000 trafficked artworks and artefacts were seized in a European crackdown codenamed Pandora VII, led by Spain's Guardia Civil police from September 13 to 24 last year. The items recovered included ancient books, sculptures, and coins from Italy, Poland, and Portugal, with investigations ongoing in 130 cases. Police from 15 countries participated, with coordination provided by Interpol and Europol. The operation aims to recover stolen cultural heritage and prevent further destruction.

site_title: UK businesses raise prices to pass on higher wage costs: PMI
summary: The UK services sector experienced its fastest growth in a year, driven by new orders and improved demand, with the S&P Global-CIPS UK services PMI rising to 55.9 in May, above the 50 threshold for growth. However, businesses passed on higher wage costs to consumers, adding pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates. Official data showed average private-sector wages were 6.1% higher than a year earlier, while consumer price inflation in March was 10.1%.

images.alt_text: UK unitied kingdom house housing rent Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England (BoE) building in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo

site_title: Shopify cuts jobs for the second time in less than a year
summary: Shopify cuts jobs for the second time in less than a year, reducing its workforce by about 20% after a challenging climb back from last year's slump. The company agreed to sell its logistics business to Flexport, with CEO Tobi Lütke stating the decision was not made lightly and acknowledges the impact on affected employees. Despite this, Shopify reported revenue of US$1.51 billion and gross merchandise volume of US$49.6 billion, beating analyst estimates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Shopify is seen outside its headquarters in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, September 28, 2018. REUTERS/Chris Wattie/  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD/File Photo

site_title: Stock market hits brick wall of Powell’s Fed policy
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate to a 16-year high of 5-5.25%, sparking a sharp decline in stock markets. Despite the rate hike, investors remain hopeful for a rate cut this year, with some speculating that the Fed may pause rate hikes in June. The market's expectation of a rate cut has been a driving force behind its recent performance, and the recent rate hike has brought the market to a "brick wall."

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY 02: The Federal Reserve building is shown May 2, 2023 in Washington, DC. The Federal Reserve begins two days of meetings today to determine its next steps in relation to interest rates in an ongoing battle against reigning in inflation.   Win McNamee/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by WIN MCNAMEE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended up 0.3 per cent, after closing at its lowest level in one-month on Tuesday.
US inflation has been falling only slowly, leaving some Fed officials unconvinced that interest rates have moved high enough to truly control it; yet the economy itself appears to be weakening.

site_title: Euro falls after dovish ECB
summary: The euro fell 0.35% to $1.10260 after the European Central Bank eased its interest rate hikes by 25 basis points, its smallest increase since last summer. The move followed the US Federal Reserve's decision to raise its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point. The ECB's cautious tone and focus on past effects of tightening have led to a depreciation of the euro and reduced expectations of future rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 20 and 50 Euro bank note are seen in front of a cash drawer with Swiss francs in Bern January 16, 2015. REUTERS/Thomas Hodel
The US dollar index falls by 0.3 per cent to 101.56, dropping for a second day in a row.

site_title: Asean’s sustainable debt sees first full-year decline in 2022 with a 32% contraction: report
summary: Asean's sustainable debt saw its first full-year decline in 2022, with a 32% contraction, due to rising inflation and interest rates. Despite this, issuances remained robust at US$36 billion, with loans being the most popular debt instrument. Sovereign issuers entered the market, and the average amount per issuer increased. Green bonds and green loans fell the least, while sustainability-linked bonds declined by almost 90%. The report calls for further development of the sustainable debt market, recommending the establishment of guidelines and frameworks for entity transition plans and mandatory transition plan disclosure.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Rising rates drag SE-Asian ESG bond volumes down 36% in Q1 2023, but sustainable loans grow
In February, BIDV issued a Sustainable Loan Framework in consultation with global climate consultancy Carbon Trust
ADB said financing the infrastructure gap has gotten more challenging than before the pandemic, as debt levels are up, tax revenues down and public spending has ballooned.

site_title: How Succession became the must-watch for corporates
summary: The hit TV show Succession has become a must-watch for corporate leaders and finance professionals, with its authentic portrayal of high-stakes business dealings and family dynamics. The show's fourth and final season is generating significant buzz, with viewers tuning in to dissect the intricate plot twists and character interactions. Creator Jesse Armstrong drew inspiration from real-life stories of powerful American families, including the Murdochs and Redstones, to craft a narrative that highlights the fragility of power and the importance of succession planning. The show's attention to detail and nuanced performances have made it a favorite among corporate leaders, who see parallels between the Roy family's struggles and their own industry challenges.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
The Korean drama earned 14 nominations, competing against the eventual best drama winner HBO’s Succession.

A pricing strategy for JioCinema is still under discussion internally, an industry source said, but Ambani has a reputation of disrupting rivals in the price-sensitive Indian market with cheap offers.

site_title: New Mercedes GLC offers plug-in and play option
summary: Mercedes-Benz Singapore has launched the new GLC-Class, a redesigned five-seat SUV that offers a plug-in hybrid option. The move aims to push plug-in hybrid technology into the mainstream, particularly for consumers interested in electric cars but uncertain about making the switch. The GLC 300e is the latest addition to the popular model, which is the single best-selling Mercedes model worldwide.

images.alt_text: “Never before has a Golf been so progressive, digitalised, connected, and intuitive to operate,” says Ricky Tay, the managing director of Volkswagen Group Singapore.

site_title: BlackRock, LGIM pick Europe credit over US as bank woes deepen
summary: Major asset managers BlackRock and LGIM are shifting their focus to European corporate bonds, preferring them over similar US debt due to the turmoil in the US regional banking sector. The preference is attributed to lower event risk in Europe, stricter regulation, and a relatively cheap credit market. European corporate bond spreads are converging with US counterparts, with a 20-basis-point spread differential down from 71 in October, and some expect Europe to revert to historically tighter spreads.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs added the lawsuit, filed on Apr 7 in the US District Court for the Northern District of California, seeks compensatory damages in unspecified amounts.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Resale volumes of Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats in Singapore fell 4.3% month-on-month in April, with 2,188 flats changing hands. Despite this decline, resale prices continued to rise, according to flash figures from SRX and 99.co. This marks a trend of rising resale prices despite falling volumes, indicating a shift in the HDB resale market.

site_title: Singapore and Hong Kong neck and neck in wooing MNCs: CBRE
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong are neck and neck in competing to attract multinational corporations (MNCs) for regional headquarters in Asia-Pacific. Despite Singapore's cheaper rents in the central business district (CBD), Hong Kong offers more cost-effective decentralized nodes. Both cities excel in influence, scalability, talent availability, and residential and office rents. The competition is particularly intense in the residential and office segments, highlighting the ongoing rivalry between the two cities in the region.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
In Singapore, an acute supply crunch and an influx of wealth has pushed up rents.

Lunar new year shopping in Suzhou, Jiangsu province, China. Travel, airlines, hospitality, F&B are among the sectors expected to recover following the easing of zero-Covid measures.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Thursday following Fed rate hike; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Thursday, following the US Federal Reserve's 25 basis point interest rate hike, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,269.18. Asian indices, including the Shanghai Composite and Hong Kong's Hang Seng, also rose, while major US indices declined overnight. Gainers outnumbered decliners 290 to 272, with Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust leading the index gainers, and shares of Jardine Matheson slipping 1%.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
All three major indices retreated, with the S&P 500 finishing down 0.7 per cent.

site_title: Alibaba’s global online commerce arm weighs a US IPO
summary: Alibaba's international online shopping unit is exploring a US IPO, with the IPO's size yet to be determined. The unit, which includes major e-commerce brands Lazada and AliExpress, is in the early stages of consideration and is in talks with banks to prepare for the IPO next year. Valuations for the international business units vary, with Morgan Stanley pricing them at around $29 billion and a CICC analyst report valuing the firm's international division at around $39 billion.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) logo is displayed atop a gong at the HKEX Connect Hall in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Most Hong Kong people were caught off-guard by Beijing's proposal of the national security bill. site_title: What if you could juice up an electric vehicle in seconds?
summary: A Taiwanese company, Gogoro, is testing its electric scooters in Singapore through a partnership with Cycle & Carriage. The scooters feature hot-swappable batteries, which can be quickly replaced at designated GoStations, adding about 100km of range. This technology could make electric two-wheelers more viable for businesses and individuals, addressing the challenge of limited battery space. The trial aims to assess operational viability and costs, with the goal of commercializing battery swapping in the region.

images.alt_text: “Never before has a Golf been so progressive, digitalised, connected, and intuitive to operate,” says Ricky Tay, the managing director of Volkswagen Group Singapore.

site_title: Adani flagship profit jumps 138% as it moves past Hindenburg hit
summary: Adani Enterprises' flagship firm has reported a 138% jump in quarterly profit to 7.22 billion rupees, rebounding from a short seller attack that wiped off over US$100 billion in market value earlier this year. The company's gross debt has decreased to 383.2 billion rupees from 410 billion rupees last year. This positive earnings report is expected to bolster Adani's growth and fundraising plans, as the conglomerate focuses on strengthening operations after being slammed by a Hindenburg Research report. The company's shares have risen 5.1% following the announcement.

site_title: Australia to deliver first budget surplus in 15 years, Sky News reports
summary: Australia is set to deliver its first budget surplus in 15 years, according to Sky News. The federal budget is expected to report a slim surplus for the fiscal year through June, driven by strong export prices and record-low unemployment. Treasurer Jim Chalmers will announce the surplus in his second budget, but future years are expected to slip back into deficit due to large spending pressures.

site_title: Amazon damage could cost Brazil US$184 billion, World Bank says
summary: A new World Bank report warns that the Amazon rainforest is moving towards an inflection point where it won't receive enough rain to support itself, potentially costing Brazil's economy $184 billion by 2050. Climate change, deforestation, and cattle pastures are at risk of jeopardizing agriculture production, water supply, and hydroelectric energy. The report suggests Brazil consider a carbon levy, boost green hydrogen production, and increase renewable energy to mitigate the damage. The country needs to tap into private and international funds to meet its sustainable infrastructure investment needs, estimated at 3.7% of GDP per year.

images.alt_text: Brazil deforestation 94% illegal: report

site_title: US Senate votes to restore tariffs by up to 254% on South-east Asian solar panels
summary: The US Senate voted 56-41 to reinstate tariffs up to 254% on solar panels from South-east Asia, which now heads to President Joe Biden for a likely veto. The move aims to insulate US renewable development from trade risks, but 9 Democrats joined Republicans in voting to end the tariff moratorium. The moratorium runs through early June 2024.

images.alt_text: The Dalat Photovoltaic Base in Ordos city, China, April 2023.
In June, Biden waived tariffs on solar panels from Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam in an effort to create a “bridge” while US manufacturing ramped up.

site_title: Hyflux independent director charged over neglect in failure to disclose material information on Tuaspring
summary: Hyflux independent director Lee Joo Hai, 67, has been charged with neglect for allegedly failing to disclose material information about the Tuaspring Integrated Water and Power Project, which was an expansion into selling electricity. This resulted in Hyflux intentionally not notifying the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and failing to disclose the plant's profitability was contingent on electricity sales revenue. Lee faces up to 7 years in jail and a fine of up to S$250,000 if convicted.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Olivia Lum has been sued for claims of at least S$690.6 million over alleged negligence and breach of fiduciary duty when she was helming the listed water treatment firm, which is in liquidation.
Many investors in Credit Suisse's AT1 bonds apparently were not aware of the write-down clauses in the issue documents.
Hyflux was placed under judicial management in November 2020, and the High Court in July 2021 approved its winding up.
Lum is being sued by Hyflux for claims of at least S$690.6 million over alleged negligence and breach of fiduciary duty.
Hyflux's liquidators say they have received total proof of debt amounting to around S$1.5 billion, but the realisations from the asset sales are unlikely to exceed S$100 million.
The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority is finalising the outcome of its inspection on the audits by KPMG in its role as Hyflux’s external auditors.
Hyflux announced the Tuaspring project in 2011, and issued S$400 million worth of preference shares that year
Besides the criminal charges, Olivia Lum, founder and former chief of water treatment firm Hyflux, is also being sued by the liquidators and the Hyflux group.

site_title: China’s holiday home sales fall sharply against pre-Covid level: survey
summary: China's holiday home sales plummeted 22% compared to pre-Covid levels, according to a private survey. Demand remains subdued in small and medium-sized cities, with sales down 28% in tier-two cities and 42% in tier-three and tier-four cities. Despite recent stabilizing home prices, the recovery is uneven, and the property sector, accounting for a quarter of China's economy, is expected to stabilize in the second quarter with slight nationwide home sales increases.

site_title: Two art world superstars come together for STPI show
summary: Thai artist Rirkrit Tiravanija and curator Hans Ulrich Obrist have collaborated on the exhibition "We Don’t Recognise What We Don’t See" at STPI, tackling animal extinction and humanity's destruction of the natural world. The show features 40 artworks that incorporate human participation, including a conceptual graveyard with tombstones for extinct animals and origami pieces that "undo" the animal forms. The exhibition aims to raise awareness of the impact of the Enlightenment on the natural world and the importance of coexisting with the environment.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
The financial world's favourite TV drama Succession is now in its 4th and final season.
Brian Gothong Tan's stunning, surreal images were created using an AI tool. Like other artists in Singapore, Tan has been turning to AI for collaboration and inspiration.
Gallerists manning one of the over 170 booths at Art Basel Hong Kong selling modern and contemporary art.

site_title: LNG should be phased out like coal, civil society groups say in protest at ADB meet
summary: Civil society groups protested near the Asian Development Bank's annual governors' business session, calling for an end to the promotion of liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a transitional fuel in Asia's green energy transition. The groups, led by Lydinyda Nacpil, criticized the bank's support for LNG, citing its potential to hinder the transition to clean energy. In response, the ADB said it would support LNG projects under strict criteria, ensuring overall emissions reductions and the use of cleaner alternatives. Energy expert Victor Nian argued that gas is a necessary transitional fuel, citing practical challenges to integrating renewables into the grid.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Australia last week passed legislation targeting 4.9 per cent annual cuts in emissions from its most-polluting industrial facilities, including from the massive LNG plants.

From left: Germany’s Parliamentary State Secretary Niels Annen, Indonesia Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati, ADB president Masatsugu Asakawa, moderator Zeinab Badawi, Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong, India Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman at a governors’ seminar discussing policies to support Asia’s rebound on the second day of the 56th ADB Annual Meeting.

(From left) Morgan Davis, editor of IFR Asia Bonds, moderating a panel comprising Green Climate Fund's Kavita Sinha, Adani Group's Robbie Singh, MUFG's Fumitaka Nakahama, and Sustainable Fitch's Aurelia Britsch.

site_title: UK mortgage lending stalls for first time since pandemic in 2021
summary: The UK's mortgage lending activity ground to a halt in March for the first time since the pandemic in 2021, with net lending for residential property purchases remaining unchanged at £700 million. However, mortgage approvals surged to 52,000, exceeding expectations. Consumer borrowing also rose £1.6 billion in March, driven by car loans, credit cards, and personal lines of credit. The figures suggest an improving housing market, with homebuyer demand rebounding to a six-month high.

site_title: Newest Golf is less powerful but still popular
summary: Volkswagen's newest Golf, the Golf Life, has been launched in Singapore with a detuned engine, producing 129 horsepower, making it eligible for the Certificate of Entitlement (COE) system's Category A, where premiums are lower. The car lists for S$175,900 with COE, S$12,500 cheaper than the next model up. Despite having less power, the Golf Life is still a fun-to-drive hatchback with a lively engine and a mild hybrid system. Its affordability and features, including a 7-speed dual-clutch gearbox and 8.25-inch touchscreen, make it an appealing option for those prioritizing money over power.

images.alt_text: The Flying Spur Hybrid's 8.5 kilowatt-hour lithium-ion pack delivers roughly 40 kilometres of emissions-free travel

site_title: HSBC, StanChart hike Hong Kong prime rates as liquidity shrinks
summary: HSBC and Standard Chartered, Hong Kong's two largest banks, raised their prime lending rates by 12.5 basis points to 5.75% and 6%, respectively, as liquidity shrinks in the financial hub. The move follows the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's 25 basis point hike and US Federal Reserve's rate hike. The banks aim to increase funding costs as short-term interbank borrowing costs, Hibor, rise. The HKMA has intervened to defend the currency peg with the US dollar, spending HK$4.7 billion, and liquidity has decreased to its lowest level since 2008, potentially leading to higher interest rates and increased pressure on the economy.

images.alt_text: The HKMA has been intervening in the foreign exchange market to protect its currency peg, draining liquidity from the financial system and, in turn, pushing up short-term interbank rates.

site_title: Hong Kong March retail sales jump 40.9% in fourth month of growth
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales surged 40.9% in March, marking a fourth consecutive month of growth, driven by improved consumer and visitor spending. The sales increase came after the reopening of border checkpoints and the lifting of Covid-19 mask mandates in early February. The government attributes the growth to the recovery of inbound tourism and private consumption, with plans to disburse a new round of consumption vouchers to further support the retail sector.

images.alt_text: Customers wearing face masks queue up to pay at a supermarket, ahead of mass coronavirus disease (COVID-19) testing, in Hong Kong, China March 2, 2022. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu
The HKMA has been intervening in the foreign exchange market to protect its currency peg, draining liquidity from the financial system and, in turn, pushing up short-term interbank rates.

site_title: German exports fall significantly more than expected in March
summary: Germany's exports fell 5.2% in March, more than expected, with declines in US (10.9%), China (9.3%), and EU countries (6.2%) reported. This contrasts with a Reuters poll predicting a 2.4% decline. Sentiment among exporters has rebounded to its highest point since the Ukraine war, driven by hopes of increased demand following China's reopening and a resilient US economy. Despite this, the global economy faces challenges such as sticky inflation and geopolitical uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Germany's consumer prices, harmonised to compare with other European Union countries, rose by 7.6 per cent on the year in April, preliminary data from the federal statistics office showed on Friday (Apr 28).

The Federal Labour Office said the number of people out of work increased by 24,000 in seasonally adjusted terms to 2.567 million. Analysts polled by Reuters had expected that figure to rise by 10,000.

site_title: From Hermes lamps to Dior chairs, luxury brands are pushing into furniture and home decor
summary: Luxury fashion brands, such as Hermes, Fendi, and Dior, are expanding into the furniture and home decor market, with many debuting new collections at Milan Design Week 2023. The market is estimated to be worth $727.6 billion in 2022 and expected to reach $939.7 billion by 2028, with a compounded annual growth rate of 6.8%. Brands are leveraging their strong visual identities and codes to create homeware and furniture, with a focus on organic materials, craftsmanship, and exclusivity. While some brands face challenges in maintaining the discipline and quality of their core products, those with strong brand universes and codes are well-positioned to penetrate the market.

images.alt_text: In three years, SG Interiors KJ has grown into a team of 34 interior designers,.

site_title: Don’t rush to sign that renovation contract
summary: Kelvin Tan, a viral comedian and serial entrepreneur, has started an interior design company, SG Interior KJ, to address the industry's shady reputation and high complaints rate. The company, which has grown to 34 designers, prioritizes transparent practices, providing clients with detailed quotations and project progress updates. Tan advises homeowners to research, compare, and find a designer with whom they connect, and to carefully review quotations to avoid hidden costs. He also warns of the risks of low-priced renovation packages and the importance of setting aside a 10% contingency fund.

images.alt_text: Nissi Gicalde transformed a rundown property into a desirable home.

site_title: BMW sticks to guidance despite first-quarter earnings beat
summary: BMW reported a 12.1% automotive earnings margin in Q1, beating analyst estimates, despite a 1% decline in shares. The company's sales of high-end models, such as its M-badged cars, rose significantly. BMW maintained its 2023 outlook, citing uncertain global demand, but announced a new 2 billion euros share buyback program to boost earnings per share. The company's premium car sales and electric vehicle shift are seen as key factors in its resilience, but downward price pressures and weakening global demand remain concerns.

site_title: Epstein’s islands sell to finance buyer planning luxury resort
summary: Jeffrey Epstein's Caribbean islands, Great St James and Little St James, have sold to finance buyer Stephen Deckoff for a combined $60 million. The sale comes with a discount from the 2022 listing price of $125 million. The US Virgin Islands will receive half the proceeds from the sale of Little St James, where Epstein lived, as part of a settlement with the government. Deckoff plans to develop a 25-room luxury resort on the islands, which he expects to open in 2025, aiming to boost tourism and create jobs.

images.alt_text: Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan mansion sold for US$51m after judge lifts asset freeze

site_title: Analysts positive about Keppel’s asset monetisation targets, see positive share catalysts
summary: CGS-CIMB analysts are optimistic about Keppel Corporation's asset monetisation targets, predicting the company will reach its Vision 2030 goal of S$17.5 billion by 2029. The analysts believe Keppel will meet its new targets and maintain its annual monetisation pace of S$1.8 billion. CGS-CIMB maintains its "add" call on Keppel, with a target price of S$8.70.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation CEO Loh Chin Hua briefing media and analysts on the conglomerate's major reorganisation to become a global asset manager and operator.

site_title: COE premiums end mostly lower, motorcycle COE falls to S$5,002 with new measures to curb speculation
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has seen a decrease in COE premiums, with motorcycle COE falling to S$5,002, a 58.9% drop. New measures to curb speculation have been implemented, including increasing the bid deposit for motorcycle COEs and requiring them to be used within a month. COE premiums for smaller cars and electric vehicles also ended mostly lower, with decreases ranging from 0.3% to 2.6%. The new measures aim to stabilize the market and reduce speculation.

images.alt_text: There are ways to achieve the goals of the certificate of entitlement without having to use a regressive auction-based pricing mechanism.

site_title: Iron ore hits five-month low on weak China factory activity data, demand worries
summary: Iron ore futures in Dalian and Singapore hit a five-month low due to weaker-than-expected China factory activity data and concerns over near-term downstream demand. The Caixin/S&P Global manufacturing PMI fell to 49.5 in April, marking the first contraction since January. Analysts at National Australia Bank had previously expected the reopening and building season to boost steel consumption, but hopes have faded. The decline in iron ore prices is attributed to a 10% drop in the past month, further weighing on sentiment.

images.alt_text: Some mills in top steel producer China now hurting from lacklustre steel demand and a slump in prices “have started to actively limit production”, Sinosteel Futures analysts said in a note.

site_title: Indonesia cuts tax breaks to discourage low-quality nickel investment
summary: Indonesia has cut tax incentives to discourage investment in lower-quality nickel products, aiming to extract value from its rich reserves and push for higher-valued downstream investments. The country's largest nickel reserves are being saved for electric vehicle battery materials, while most current output is used in stainless steel production. Indonesia aims for around $95 billion in investment this year, focusing on natural resources processing industries.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati says the country is on  a strong recovery path as the boost from China’s reopening and robust domestic sectors offset downside factors relating to the advanced economies.
Exports from the resource-rich country rose to a record high last year on soaring global commodity prices.

site_title: China urges 'high vigilance' over Nato expansion in Asia
summary: China has urged "high vigilance" over NATO's planned expansion into Asia, with the alliance reportedly set to open its first liaison office in Japan. The move is seen as a response to China's geopolitical challenges from Russia and NATO's eastward expansion. China's foreign ministry spokesperson, Mao Ning, stated that Asia should not be a "battle arena for geopolitics" and warned of the need for vigilance due to NATO's influence in the region.

images.alt_text: Finland's and Nato's flags fly in front of the Finnish Foreign Ministry building in Helsinki, Finland after the country became the 31st Nato member on 4 Apr 2023.

site_title: China takes the yuan global in bid to repel a weaponised dollar
summary: China is promoting the yuan globally in an effort to counter the US dollar's dominance. President Xi Jinping's government has signed agreements with countries such as Russia, Saudi Arabia, and Brazil to expand the yuan's use in international finance. The yuan's share of global trade finance has tripled since 2019, and it is being used in transactions with countries like Russia and Bangladesh. China aims to demonstrate its currency as an alternative to the dollar, but limitations on the yuan's use, such as restrictions on cross-border loans and portfolio investments, hinder its growth.

images.alt_text: The yuan’s share of global payments is merely 2.5 per cent, and tiny compared with US dollar’s 39.4 per cent and euro’s 35.8 per cent.

site_title: Volvo Cars axes 1,300 jobs as it steps up cost cuts
summary: Volvo Cars is cutting around 1,300 office-based jobs in Sweden as part of its cost-cutting efforts. The move, aimed at improving efficiency, is attributed to economic headwinds, increased raw material prices, and increased competition. The company's main global operating unit, Volvo Personvagnar, will lose approximately 1,100 jobs, while 200 positions will be identified after a review of the company's entities across Sweden. This move follows the company's initial cost-cutting efforts, with CEO Jim Rowan stating that more needs to be done to address the challenges facing the industry.

site_title: Maersk’s profit slumps more than half as global trade slows
summary: Maersk, a global shipping company, reported a 56% decline in first-quarter operating profit to $3.97 billion, citing weaker trade and freight rates. Transport volumes fell 9.4% and freight rates dropped 37% from the same period in 2022. Maersk expects global container transport volumes to shrink 2.5% this year and maintains its full-year financial forecast of $8-11 billion. The company attributed the decline to a cooling world economy and reduced demand for consumer goods.

site_title: Chinese banks to drive Apac banks’ debt issuance in coming months: S&P
summary: Major Chinese banks are expected to drive debt issuance in the Asia-Pacific in the coming months due to regulatory requirements and lower capital accumulation from profits. The four largest Chinese banks must raise total loss-absorbing capacity (TLAC) securities to meet the People's Bank of China's 16% minimum by 2025 and 18% by 2028. Chinese banks have already dominated debt issuance, with over half of the $21.11 billion raised by Asian Pacific banks in March coming from two major Chinese lenders. This trend is expected to continue as banks tap the onshore market to meet their funding needs.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The shrinking margins were due to the effects of prime rate reductions and the “continuously increasing proportion of time deposits,” ICBC said in a statement.
The People’s Bank of China has maintained its benchmark deposit rate artificially low at 1.5 per cent since 2015.
President Xi Jinping has taken steps to promote the country’s reputation abroad, even as he focuses on implementing reforms and bolstering growth at home.
