site_title: Shell posts Q1 profit of US$9.65 billion, lifted by fuel trading
summary: Shell reported a first-quarter net profit of US$9.65 billion, exceeding analyst forecasts, driven by strong fuel trading earnings. The company's adjusted earnings were US$9.65 billion, surpassing the forecast of US$8 billion. Fuel trading profits jumped 139%, while natural gas profits slumped 18% due to lower prices. Shell maintained its dividend and share repurchase program unchanged.

site_title: Australia’s exports to China hit record highs as barriers ease
summary: Australia's exports to China reached record highs in March, driven by increased iron ore shipments and lowered barriers to thermal coal exports. Export volumes of iron ore lumps and fines rose 24.3% and 17.7% respectively, while thermal coal shipments surged 125% by volume. This boost lifted Australia's trade surplus to its second-highest on record, benefiting mining profits and tax receipts. The surge in exports comes as China and Australia resolve a World Trade Organization dispute over Chinese barley tariffs.

images.alt_text: China’s economy expanded at the fastest pace in a year last quarter, largely driven by consumer spending as the nation ended its Covid curbs.
The figures from this year’s May Day holiday – the first travel season since the pandemic without restrictions – are being monitored as a gauge of China’s economic health.

site_title: Apac stock markets respond better than Wall Street to Fed’s possible pause in rate hikes
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its funds rate by 25 basis points, marking the highest level since June 2006, with the funds rate now at 5.25%. Asian markets generally responded positively, while Wall Street indices declined. Analysts, including DBS and Bank of Singapore, suggest that the Fed may pause rate hikes, citing a shift towards data-dependent decision-making and a possible end to the rate hike cycle. However, concerns remain about banking system stress and the potential for future rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Sydney, Seoul, Wellington and Singapore were down, while Taipei, Jakarta and Manila were up.
Earlier in the session, bullion prices rose to US$2,072.19 per ounce and hovered close to an all-time high of US$2,072.49 scaled in 2020.
The HKMA has been intervening in the foreign exchange market to protect its currency peg, draining liquidity from the financial system and, in turn, pushing up short-term interbank rates.
The US central bank raised its benchmark overnight interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to the 5.00-5.25 per cent range, as expected by financial markets.
In China, data over the weekend showed April manufacturing activity fell unexpectedly in the world’s largest energy consumer and top buyer of crude oil.
All three major indices retreated, with the S&P 500 finishing down 0.7 per cent.

site_title: Stock bulls won’t find much to celebrate in Fed’s pause
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision to pause interest rate hikes has been met with skepticism by stock bulls, who traditionally benefit from such moves. The Fed's language and Chairman Jerome Powell's comments suggest a hawkish bias, indicating the central bank is unlikely to cut rates soon. Despite a pause in rate hikes, inflation remains a priority, and the Fed's dual mandates suggest further rate increases may be necessary. The market's reaction to the pause is uncertain, with yields on 10-year Treasury notes already below the Fed funds rate and an earnings recession in the US, making a short-term rally unlikely.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY 02: The Federal Reserve building is shown May 2, 2023 in Washington, DC. The Federal Reserve begins two days of meetings today to determine its next steps in relation to interest rates in an ongoing battle against reigning in inflation.   Win McNamee/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by WIN MCNAMEE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The US central bank raised its benchmark overnight interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to the 5.00-5.25 per cent range, as expected by financial markets.

site_title: US homeowners hold near-record equity even after price declines
summary: US homeowners maintained near-record equity levels despite a decline in home prices, with 47.2% of mortgaged homes holding at least half the equity in the first quarter. This marks a slight drop from the previous quarter, but remains close to historic highs. Higher equity levels shield homeowners from foreclosure risks and could protect the economy from a severe housing downturn. The largest declines in equity positions occurred in the West, particularly in Arizona, Nevada, and Idaho, while states like South Carolina and Florida saw increases in equity-rich homes, with Florida ranking second in the nation.

images.alt_text: The US central bank raised its benchmark overnight interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to the 5.00-5.25 per cent range, as expected by financial markets.
The PMI remains above the 49.9 level, which the ISM says over time indicates growth in the overall economy.

site_title: China’s factories struggle in further sign of economic imbalance
summary: China's factories experienced a contraction in April, with the Caixin manufacturing PMI dropping to 49.5, marking the first time since January. This follows a slower-than-expected expansion in the official PMI, which fell to 49.2. The decline in factory output suggests a slowdown in China's economic recovery, with domestic demand and the job market also deteriorating. Despite this, consumer spending remains strong, and several major banks expect annual GDP growth to outperform Beijing's target of 5%.

images.alt_text: The figures from this year’s May Day holiday – the first travel season since the pandemic without restrictions – are being monitored as a gauge of China’s economic health.
Thailand posted a region’s best PMI reading of 54.8 last month as it ramped up manufacturing production and output.
While factory activity has been improving, it’s been tough for companies to pull themselves out of last year’s deep, Covid-induced slump.

site_title: EV ride-hailing startup raises US$42 million from BP, others
summary: Indian EV ride-hailing startup BluSmart Mobility has raised $42 million from investors including BP Ventures, valuing the company at $250 million. Founded in 2019, BluSmart aims to provide a greener alternative to Uber and Ola, focusing on electric vehicles to generate better income for drivers and offer clean rides to users. The startup has seen revenue triple over the last three quarters and plans to double its fleet to 10,000 over the next year.

images.alt_text: A man charges an electric vehicle at  a BluSmart Electric Mobility charging hub in Gurugram, India, Dec 9, 2022.

site_title: Man charged over alleged hydroponics, aquaponics farming investment scam
summary: A Singaporean man, Oommen Mathews, has been charged with 55 counts of offences related to a hydroponics and aquaponics farming investment scam. Mathews, director and shareholder of Reign Gainers and Capital Nation, allegedly offered investments promising up to 20% returns per annum to over 60 people. However, the police found no business activities to generate these returns, and Mathews used the companies for a "fraudulent purpose" between 2015 and 2017. He faces up to 7 years in jail and a fine of up to S$15,000.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
In today’s hurried digital world, younger, tech-savvier people are making up a larger proportion of victims.

site_title: New York City will finally turn a hotel into housing
summary: New York City is set to convert a hotel into housing, with a $150 million project expected to provide over 300 affordable units. The conversion, which includes 318 units, will be funded by a combination of state and private investment. The project is the first under a 2021 state program aimed at repurposing hotels into housing, and its success could pave the way for similar conversions in the city. The development aims to address the city's housing crisis, with 60% of the units targeting individuals struggling with homelessness and the remaining 40% targeting lower-income households.

images.alt_text: This is the second year in a row that the board has endorsed significant hikes, presenting another challenge for people struggling to afford living in the city.

site_title: Volkswagen revenue jumps on growth in Europe, North America
summary: Volkswagen reported a 22% increase in revenue to 76 billion euros in the first quarter, driven by strong growth in Europe and North America. Deliveries rose 7.5% from the previous year, in line with BMW. Despite a drop in operating profit, the company's earnings beat analyst expectations of 5.48 billion euros. Deliveries in China were down 14.5% but the company remains confident in its ability to recover throughout the year. Volkswagen confirmed its 2023 outlook.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Volkswagen logo is seen during the New York International Auto Show, in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., April 5, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Pinduoduo owner PDD moves headquarters to Ireland from China
summary: PDD Holdings, the parent company of discount e-commerce platforms Pinduoduo and Temu, has moved its headquarters from China to Ireland, according to recent filings. The company reported revenue of 39.82 billion yuan in the fourth quarter, falling short of estimates. The move comes as China's post-reopening consumer recovery remains patchy. The company did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment on the relocation.

site_title: ARA H-Trust Q1 net property income rises 19% to US$6.4 million as recovery continues
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust posted a 19% increase in net property income to US$6.4 million for its Q1, driven by a 10% rise in gross revenue. Portfolio occupancy rose to 61.7%, and revenue per available room increased 24.4%. The trust expects the US lodging market to remain optimistic, despite economic uncertainty, with RevPar growth projected to be positive for the next three years.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
ARA US Hospitality Trust - which owns a total of 38 properties comprising Hyatt Place and Hyatt House hotels - attributes its improved H2 FY2022 performance to pent-up travel demand.
CapitaLand India Trust announced a proposed acquisition of International Tech Park Pune in India for S$221.9 million.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after US Fed hikes rates again
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday, May 4, following the US Federal Reserve's rate hike and indication that it won't cut rates soon. The Fed's decision weighed on Wall Street, with the dollar and US oil prices declining. However, Hong Kong's stocks rose 1% driven by commerce and industry stocks. Taipei, Jakarta, and Manila saw gains, while Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, and Singapore fell. The attention now shifts to the European Central Bank's meeting, expected to deliver another rate increase. Oil prices remained below $70 a barrel due to recession worries and weaker demand.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong was down nearly 1.5 per cent in early trade, with tech shares among the biggest losers.

site_title: Freeport Indonesia must divest additional 10% stake to government: minister
summary: Indonesia's Investment Minister Bahlil Lahadalia has stated that Freeport Indonesia must sell an additional 10% stake to the government to extend its permit to operate in the country. The government will seek the cheapest pricing possible to increase its stake from 51% to 61% in Freeport-McMoRan's Indonesian unit, which controls the world's largest copper mine. The deal also requires Freeport to build a smelter in Papua and meet environmental standards. The negotiations aim to avoid job losses and economic impacts in 2041 when the current permit expires.

images.alt_text: The global nickel market is facing a massive oversupply this year due to surging Indonesian output.
Freeport is building a US$3 billion copper smelter in East Java to process 1.7 million tonnes of copper concentrate.

Freeport Indonesia have started construction of $3 billion processing facility in Gresik, East Java, that will have capacity of 1.7 million tonnes of copper concentrate and is expected to start operations gradually in 2024.

site_title: Gold advances as US Fed hints rate-hike pause
summary: Gold prices rose 0.8% to $2,055.54 per ounce, hovering near a record high, after the US Federal Reserve hinted it may pause further interest rate hikes, raising the benchmark rate by 25 basis points. The Fed's statement suggested it will watch incoming data to determine if more hikes are necessary, boosting demand for the zero-yielding asset. The dollar index fell 0.2%, making gold more affordable for overseas buyers.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect gold prices to hover around US$1,950 an ounce in the coming months.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise further in April amid falling volume: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale prices rose 1.1% month-on-month in April, with overall prices up 8.4% year-on-year. Prices for mature estates increased 1% and non-mature estates saw a 0.8% rise. Five-room flats saw the largest price increase at 1.9%, while executive flats rose 1%. Resale volumes fell 4.3% month-on-month, with 2,188 flats changing hands. Experts attribute the rise in prices to high rent prices and the revised Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty rates, which may prompt tenants to buy resale flats instead.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
XX

site_title: Convincing workers and foreign employers of the value of Singapore’s tripartism
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong highlighted Singapore's cooperative tripartism as its "secret formula" for success. This model, which maintains harmonious relations between the government, labour movement, and employers, is a key competitive advantage. However, proving its value to ordinary workers and foreign investors remains a challenge. Wong emphasized the need to guard this advantage.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warned of greater competition as advanced economies roll out subsidies for investment.
Singapore must adapt to the changing economic environment and support those who are affected, says PM Lee.

site_title: Biden administration OKs boost in Chinese airline flights to US
summary: The US Transportation Department has approved a boost in Chinese airline flights to the US, increasing services to 12 weekly round-trips, matching the number of flights Beijing has permitted for American carriers. This is a significant increase from the current eight weekly round-trip flights and aims for a gradual reopening of the US-China air services market. The move comes after China reopened its borders to foreign tourists in March.

images.alt_text: Air France is seeking to increase the number of flights to 14 a week in July pending Chinese government approval, up from the 6 weekly flights to China as of this month.
Haneda Airport in Japan (pictured) is expected to see a full resumption of international capacity this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks open muted on Thursday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened muted on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% to 3,257.8, as the US Federal Reserve confirmed a 25 basis point rate hike. Losers outnumbered gainers 55 to 42, with 55.3 million securities worth S$62 million traded. Notable movers included Singtel, which rose 0.8% to S$2.59, and Lian Beng Group, which rose 4.6% after the Ong family revised its privatisation deal.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: National Australia Bank slides after profit misses estimates
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) reported its first-half profit fell short of analyst estimates, with cash earnings rising 17% to A$4.07 billion. The bank's profit missed the A$4.18 billion estimate, and the stock opened 6% lower. Higher interest rates boosted margins, but caution on the economic trajectory and market expectations of a pivot to rate cuts later this year may impact earnings growth.

images.alt_text: Signage at a National Australia Bank Ltd. (NAB) branch in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, May 2, 2023. NAB is scheduled to release earnings results on May 4. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg
UniCredit has a presence in 13 countries and is one of the few true cross-border European banks.

site_title: US Fed raises rates, opens door to pause in tightening cycle
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 5.00-5.25%, marking the end of its historic series of interest rate hikes. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that the rate-hike cycle may be nearing its end, citing signs of a slowdown in the economy and high inflation. However, Powell also emphasized that inflation remains the top concern and that further rate hikes are possible if necessary. The Fed's policy-setting committee will continue to monitor economic risks, including credit tightening by banks, before making future policy decisions.

site_title: Qualcomm outlook grim as smartphone sales stay weak
summary: Qualcomm forecasted third-quarter revenue and profit below Wall Street estimates due to weak smartphone sales and stiffer competition from MediaTek. The company expects a larger-than-normal decline in chip revenue and has not seen evidence of a meaningful recovery in the smartphone market. Qualcomm's total revenue is forecasted to be $8.1 billion to $8.9 billion, lower than analysts' expectations of $9.14 billion. The company faces challenges from declining demand and competition in the high-end smartphone chip market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed Qualcomm logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: SK Innovation sees ‘solid’ Q2 refining margin on China’s reopening
summary: SK Innovation expects a "solid" refining margin in Q2, driven by China's reopening and the summer driving season. The company operated facilities at 80% capacity in Q1, up from 77% in 2022, and posted an operating profit of 375 billion won. Revenue rose 18% to 19.1 trillion won. No specific margin target was given, but the company plans routine maintenance in Q2. This supports peer S-Oil's expectation of regional refining margins being supported by summer demand.

images.alt_text: The company is boosting its exposure to the EV battery market as it bets on a faster-than-expected electrification of cars.

site_title: Barclays names Zhang as sole head of macro trading for Apac
summary: Barclays has appointed Yun Zhang as the sole head of macro trading for Asia-Pacific, a move aimed at bolstering revenue from structured products sales. Zhang, who leads the bank's structured rates business in the region, will continue to hold existing roles. The personnel change is part of Barclays' effort to enhance female leadership across its global markets business in Asia-Pacific, following recent appointments including Angela Liu and Shella Wang. The bank's goal is to drive growth and stay ahead in the macro business across the region.

site_title: NFT sales pick up after launch of peer-to-peer lending site
summary: NFT sales have seen a significant increase after the launch of Blend, a peer-to-peer perpetual lending platform for NFTs. The platform, which debuted on May 1, allows users to borrow against their digital pictures within seconds and buy valuable NFTs at a fraction of their price. Since its launch, Blend has made 1,338 loans worth $26 million, leading to a 30% increase in NFT sales over the past week, and a 19% decrease in sales in April.

images.alt_text: Artist Robness with his piece "Brute Trash Can"; he donated to the Pompidou a 3D “portrait” of Satoshi Nakamoto, the possibly fictional creator of bitcoin.
Global NFT sales were US$736 million in March.
Auctions and private sales of non-fungible tokens ( NFTs  ) in the “GRAILS” collection will kick off next month in New York.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, ARA US Hospitality Trust, Lian Beng
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) announced a distribution per unit of S$0.0352 for the first half of FY2023, a 8.6% year-on-year decline. ARA US Hospitality Trust posted a 19% increase in net property income to US$6.4 million in its first quarter. Lian Beng Group raised its privatisation offer to S$0.68 per share, with valid acceptances totaling 0.01% of issued shares.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: UniCredit CEO has quietly axed 7,700 jobs in two years
summary: UniCredit CEO Andrea Orcel has quietly axed 7,700 jobs, a 10% reduction in full-time equivalent employees, over the past two years. The cuts, mainly made in Italy, Germany, and Austria, aim to slim down the workforce and reduce costs while protecting revenue growth. Orcel has implemented cost-cutting measures, including reducing bureaucracy and back-office duplication, and investing in front-line staff. Despite inflationary pressure, UniCredit's operating costs decreased, while revenue increased 18% in Q1, with improved cost and revenue guidance for 2023.

images.alt_text: While UniCredit has signalled its intention to redeem the bond, it has until early May to make a final decision.

site_title: Airbus piles pressure on engine maker Pratt as profits fall
summary: Airbus reported a 39% fall in first-quarter core earnings to 773 million euros, due to fewer airplane deliveries and negative currency effects. The company reaffirmed production and financial targets but warned of supply chain disruptions. Airbus singled out Pratt & Whitney, citing engine durability issues, particularly with its GTF engines, which have affected airlines such as Go First. The company predicted "persistent tensions" in the supply chain, but still expects to meet annual delivery targets.

images.alt_text: Boeing has paused deliveries of some 737 MAXs due to a problem involving two fittings that join the aft fuselage made by Spirit to the vertical tail, which were not attached correctly.
The airline’s total liabilities to all creditors stand at 114.63 billion rupees and this includes dues to banks, financial institutions, vendors and aircraft lessors.

site_title: IMF warns of ‘uncertainty’ in Japan’s monetary policy, flags potential global spillover
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned of uncertainty in Japan's monetary policy, citing the risk of a shift from ultra-low interest rates and potential global spillover. Japan's inflation exceeds the 2% target, prompting speculation about a possible change in monetary policy. The IMF also highlighted risks to Asia's economic outlook, including a slowdown in productivity and investment in China, and a fragmentation of global trade. Changes in Japan's monetary policy could have significant global implications, particularly for export-reliant countries.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk in front of the Bank of Japan (BoJ) head office building (C) in Tokyo on April 27, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: PacWest is weighing strategic options, including possible sale
summary: PacWest Bancorp, a regional bank in California, is weighing strategic options including a sale, following the collapse of three rival California-based lenders. The bank, which has about 70 branches and $44 billion in assets, has explored a break-up, capital raise, and sale of its lender finance business. A potential buyer would face hurdles, including a large loss on some loans. PacWest's shares have plummeted 85% since March, and the bank has stabilized deposits after a rush of withdrawals.

images.alt_text: The deal is expected to close by early June.

site_title: UBS viewed buying Credit Suisse as ‘not desirable’ in February
summary: UBS Group's board of directors deemed buying Credit Suisse "not desirable" in February, just weeks before agreeing to a government-brokered deal to purchase the struggling bank. The UBS board considered challenges in valuing Credit Suisse, risks, and possible liabilities, but ultimately decided to proceed with the acquisition, which is expected to close by early June. The deal includes extensive government guarantees and liquidity provisions, marking a 99% decline in price from Credit Suisse's peak in 2007.

site_title: Etsy rises as revenue beat, user growth buck e-commerce slowdown
summary: Etsy reported a revenue beat in the first quarter, rising to $640.9 million, driven by improved buyer engagement and a 20% take rate, the highest since its history. Active buyers in the US marketplaces grew for the first time since 2021. The company issued second-quarter guidance, which was in line with analyst expectations. Shares jumped 11% before paring gains, despite being down 17% this year. Etsy attributes the growth to platform improvements, including personalization and generative AI.

images.alt_text: Approximately 0.5 per cent of Etsy’s active sellers -or around 2,700 merchants- had their payments delayed on Friday related to SVB’s collapse, according to Etsy.

site_title: TikTok to launch ad product that will give premium content creators 50% cut
summary: TikTok is launching Pulse Premiere, an ad product allowing brands to place ads alongside content from premium publishers, with 50% of ad revenue shared with those publishers. The first brands to join include Buzzfeed, DotDash Meredith, NBCUniversal, UFC, and WWE. The move aims to address tightening ad spending by brands, while also addressing concerns about US user data falling into Chinese hands. Pulse Premiere is an extension of TikTok's existing Pulse programme, which lets marketers place ads alongside top content creators.

site_title: Ford CEO sees leaner, lower investment in China’s auto market
summary: Ford plans to scale back investment in China's auto market, shifting focus to commercial vehicles, exports, and its Lincoln luxury line. CEO Jim Farley aims to achieve higher returns with a "leaner, more focused business" in the country. This comes after Ford reported a 2.1% market share and $572 million losses in China last year. By concentrating on profitable areas, Ford hopes to improve profitability in the country.

images.alt_text: For the first time, Ford reported results by business unit, rather than geography, after chief executive officer Jim Farley radically restructured the 120-year-old company to increase focus on electric vehicles (EVs).

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts mixed on Sheng Siong as Q1 sales normalise
summary: Analysts at DBS, RHB, and OCBC have mixed views on Sheng Siong's growth prospects after the retailer reported a 0.4% fall in revenue to S$356.5 million in Q1, with sales normalizing following pandemic restrictions. DBS downgraded to "hold" while retaining its target price of S$1.82, while RHB maintained its "buy" call and target price at S$2. OCBC raised its fair value estimate to S$1.94 and called the counter a "defensive play" amid inflationary pressures. The analysts expect Sheng Siong to benefit from new store openings and a better product mix, but note limited upside to the counter.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong said competition in the supermarket industry is expected to remain keen among both brick-and-mortar stores and online markets
Groceries packed in FairPrice's signature white-blue-red plastic bags at an NTUC FairPrice Xtra outlet.

site_title: Messi in talks for US$400 million Saudi deal: Telegraph
summary: Lionel Messi is in talks for a US$400 million annual contract with Saudi Arabia's Saudi Pro League, surpassing Cristiano Ronaldo's US$200 million deal. The deal, negotiated by Messi's father, comes after he was suspended by Paris Saint-Germain for two weeks for traveling to Saudi Arabia without permission. The potential signing is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to boost its sports image and investment in various leagues and events, despite criticism of "sports washing" and its human rights record.

site_title: Cannes Film Festival to honour Michael Douglas with honorary Palme d’Or
summary: The Cannes Film Festival will pay tribute to actor Michael Douglas at its opening ceremony on May 16 with an honorary Palme d'Or award, recognizing his "brilliant career and engagement for cinema." This honor comes after a career spanning films like "The China Syndrome," "Basic Instinct," and "Behind the Candelabra." Past recipients of the award include Agnes Varda and Jodie Foster, and this marks Douglas' addition to the festival's esteemed list of honorees.

site_title: US: Stocks fall after latest Fed rate hike as oil prices slide
summary: US stocks fell 0.7% as the Federal Reserve's latest interest rate hike was met with skepticism, with investors expecting more hikes in the future. Oil prices slid below $70 a barrel amid recession worries. The dollar also pulled back against other major currencies. Analysts characterized the Fed's decision as "moderately dovish," but some saw it as more hawkish. The market is now awaiting the European Central Bank's decision on interest rates, expected to deliver another hike. Regional US banking shares declined, and investors remain concerned about the US debt ceiling crisis.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 14, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Oil falls 4%, extending losses after Fed rate hike
summary: Oil prices fell 4% on Wednesday, extending losses after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates, as investors worried about slower economic growth hitting energy demand. Brent futures settled at $72.33 a barrel, the lowest close since December 2021, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 4.3% to $68.60. The Fed signaled a possible pause in further rate hikes, giving officials time to assess the banking sector's fallout and monitor inflation.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell US$3.99, or 5.0 per cent, to settle at US$75.32 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) fell US$4.00, or 5.3 per cent, to end at US$71.66.

site_title: Should there be a broader pool of investment options under CPFIS?
summary: Savvy investors are shifting their CPF savings, particularly from Ordinary Account (OA) funds with low yields, to Singapore Treasury bills and fixed deposits. Over $4 billion was invested in these options in the first two months of 2023. The CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) offers limited investment options, mainly stocks and ETFs listed on the Singapore Exchange, but experts suggest broadening or simplifying options to cater to the growing desire for higher returns and diversification. A long-term, diversified approach could help ensure better risk-adjusted returns, but current options may not be suitable for retirement savings.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Investors can use funds within their CPF OA to purchase T-bills, by opening a CPF investment account with either DBS, UOB or OCBC.
CPF ordinary savings for fixed deposits at OCBC at 3.4 per cent per annum.
DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.
Gerard Lee, former CEO of Lion Global, has just retired and is now exploring projects harnessing fintech to boost Asian fund managers.

site_title: UK economists see one more rate hike from Bank of England
summary: UK economists predict the Bank of England will raise interest rates by just one quarter-point to 4.5% on May 11, with most expecting a pause after that, despite double-digit inflation. About 60% of forecasters predict the rate will peak at 4.5%, while a third expect two more increases to 4.75%. This diverges from market expectations, which expect rates to reach 5% by September, following US Federal Reserve decisions later this week.

images.alt_text: Shoppers and red London buses on Oxford Street in central London, UK, on Thursday, Feb. 16, 2023. The UK’s inflation rate slowed for a third month but remained stubbornly in double digits five times above the Bank of England’s targeted level. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

site_title: Upcoming longer training contracts could hurt law firms’ bottom lines
summary: Singapore's law firms may face reduced revenue and increased costs due to a longer practice training period for law graduates, which will double from 6 to 12 months starting 2024. The extended period may lead to firms paying more for trainees and taking fewer trainees, but most firms expect to maintain or increase trainee intake. The change aims to bring Singapore's training period closer to international norms, allowing for more robust training programs and better prepared lawyers.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Chong Xin Wei
The structural changes to the professional training and admission regime of lawyers were first announced in 2018.

site_title: Carlsberg agrees to pay 50 million euro fine in German price-fixing case
summary: Carlsberg has agreed to pay a 50 million-euro fine to German authorities over alleged price-fixing in 2012. The Danish brewer refutes the allegations but settled to focus on its core business. The company confirmed the settlement through a statement, citing an "enormous amount of time and financial resources" spent on the case.

site_title: US services sector grows steadily in April: ISM survey
summary: The US services sector experienced steady growth in April, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing PMI reaching 51.9, indicating growth. New orders increased amid a surge in exports, but businesses faced higher prices for inputs, suggesting inflation could remain elevated. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points, amid rising risks to the economy, including a potential government debt crisis and a slowing labour market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for a job fair is seen on 5th Avenue after the release of the jobs report in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., September 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo/File Photo

NOVATO, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 07: A customer walks by a now hiring sign posted in front of a Ross Dress For Less store on April 07, 2023 in Novato, California. The U.S. labor market added 236,000 jobs in March bringing the national unemployment rate down to 3.5 percent. (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Biden’s World Bank pick wins top job, signals climate-change shift
summary: The World Bank has ratified the nomination of Ajay Banga as its next head, marking a shift towards a greater focus on climate change. Banga, a former Mastercard CEO, will take over at a pivotal time for the lender, which gives out about $100 billion annually. His election was largely a formality, as he was unopposed, and his five-year term starts June 2. The move is seen as a step towards addressing global challenges like climate change and poverty, as the US seeks to reform multilateral development banks to unlock more climate financing for the developing world.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A participant stands near a logo of World Bank at the International Monetary Fund - World Bank Annual Meeting 2018 in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, October 12, 2018. REUTERS/Johannes P. Christo/File Photo

site_title: US becomes first country to approve RSV vaccine
summary: The US has become the first country to approve a vaccine for the Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV), a common illness that can be life-threatening, particularly for vulnerable individuals. GSK's Arexvy vaccine, approved for adults aged 60 and older, contains a "subunit" of the virus to train the immune system. Similar shots from Pfizer and Moderna are expected to follow soon, marking a significant public health achievement in preventing a disease that can be life-threatening.

images.alt_text: A visitor leaves GlaxoSmithKline Plc's headquarters in London, U.K., on Wednesday, Feb. 5, 2014. GlaxoSmithKline, the U.K.'s biggest drugmaker, forecast that revenue will rise by about 2 percent this year as it introduces new medicines. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
GSK has been trying to replenish its product pipeline in recent years as the company faces pressure to improve shareholder returns and keep up with UK rival AstraZeneca.

site_title: G20 Turkey at pivot point as elections approach
summary: Turkey's presidential and legislative elections on May 7 are expected to have significant implications for the country's international relations, economy, and politics. The outcome could lead to a shift in Turkey's foreign policy, potentially renewing the Black Sea grain deal with Russia and Ukraine, or exacerbating tensions with the US and EU. The election could also mark the end of President Recep Erdogan's 20-year rule, leading to a more orthodox economic stance and a potential return to a parliamentary system. Alternatively, Erdogan's narrow loss to opposition candidate Kemal Kilicdaroglu could lead to economic instability and polarization, with Erdogan disputing the outcome. The outcome of the election will frame Turkey's future for years to come.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - The destroyed Greek Orthodox Church of the historic southern city of Antakya is pictured on February 12, 2023, after a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck the border region of Turkey and Syria earlier in the week. (Photo by Yasin AKGUL / AFP)
The destroyed Greek Orthodox Church in Antakya. In the city, Arab-speaking Muslim and Christian communities lived in harmony with Turks, Kurds, Armenians, Greeks and Jews.

Turkey's main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP) leader Kemal Kilicdaroglu greets his supporters at the party's headquarters after a six-party alliance announced him as its presidential candidate, in Ankara, Turkey March 6, 2023.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher with eyes on Fed, oil stocks fall for second day
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, ending a one-month low, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with speculation it may be the final hike of the cycle. The Stoxx 600 index closed at its lowest level in a month on Tuesday. Oil stocks fell for the second day, while energy prices continued to decline due to concerns over the US economy. The European Central Bank is expected to raise rates by 25 basis points on Thursday.

site_title: US Treasury flags bigger sales as soon as August, buybacks in 2024
summary: The US Treasury announced plans to issue $96 billion in debt in May and August, with a new buyback program to be launched in 2024. The buyback, initially sized conservatively, aims to bolster liquidity in the Treasuries market and smooth out volatility in issuance. The Treasury faces a risk of running out of cash to make good on federal obligations by June 1, prompting a high-stakes summit with congressional leaders on the debt limit. The debt ceiling is currently at $31.4 trillion, and the Treasury plans to keep benchmark bill issuance below 20% of total debt.

images.alt_text: State Street's indicators found that investors’ actions over April were much more cautious and that risky asset pricing was overly complacent.

site_title: Boeing supplier Spirit Aero flags US$31 million hit from 737 fuselage defect
summary: Spirit AeroSystems, a Boeing supplier, expects a $31 million hit to full-year gross profit due to a 737 MAX fuselage production problem. The issue involves two fittings not attached correctly, causing deliveries of some 737 MAXs to be paused. The company projects repair work will be complete by the end of July, and has started building and delivering production-conforming 737 fuselages under a revised process. Spirit also reported a first-quarter adjusted loss per share of $1.69, wider than analyst expectations.

images.alt_text: Boeing’s jet deliveries and free cash flow are being closely watched as the company tries to recover from a series of crises since two fatal MAX crashes in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Big hedge funds face new 72-hour deadline to report losses
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is set to approve a new rule requiring large hedge funds to report extraordinary investment losses and major margin events within 72 hours. The rule, aimed at increasing oversight of the private funds industry, would give regulators a more real-time look at major events at managers overseeing at least $1.5 billion in assets. The changes are part of a push by SEC Chair Gary Gensler to clamp down on the fast-growing private funds industry and mitigate systemic risks. The regulation is expected to be adopted on May 3.

site_title: Changi Airport’s March 2023 passenger traffic crosses 80% of pre-pandemic levels
summary: Changi Airport's March 2023 passenger traffic reached 82% of pre-Covid levels, surpassing 80% for the first time. The airport handled 4.63 million passengers, with aircraft movements at 81% of pre-Covid levels. The top five traffic markets were Australia, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. Air cargo movements remained steady, with 152,000 tonnes in March 2023 and 417,000 tonnes over the first quarter. The airport expects continued growth in key source markets and passenger flows to mainland China and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The full reopening of T2 comes amid anticipation of a full travel recovery in 2024, or earlier.
Changi Airport is the world’s 9th busiest, with a total of 31.9 million travellers passing through in 2022.
The awards were given out based on a global survey conducted by Skytrax between August 2022 and February 2023.
The exterior of Sats Coolport, a purpose-built airfreight terminal that can handle commodities with different temperature requirements on 21 Dec 2020.
In 2022, some 54 new tenants opened in Jewel Changi Airport, translating to more than a new store every week, according to chief executive officer of Jewel Changi Airport Development James Fong.
The airport handled 32.2 million passengers in 2022, or about half of the traffic in 2019, Changi Airport Group (CAG) said.

site_title: China tourism rebounds to pre-Covid levels during May Day holiday
summary: China's tourism sector rebounded to pre-Covid levels during the May Day holiday, with 274 million domestic trips taken, a 70.8% increase from last year and 19% more than in 2019. Total spending was 148 billion yuan, a 128.9% increase from last year. The rebound is seen as a gauge of China's economic health and a potential turning point for the tourism sector. This could ease concerns about the country's post-pandemic economic recovery, which has been affected by a soft property market and exports facing headwinds.

images.alt_text: Passenger traffic on the railways alone hit 53.5 million, with national operator China Railway Group earlier saying it expects the figure to hit a record 120 million between Apr 27 to May 4.

site_title: Despite portents of doom, San Francisco remains a US powerhouse in many aspects
summary: San Francisco, despite its high-tech industry, is recovering more slowly than other US cities from the post-pandemic era, with scores of people working remotely. The city's economy, the sixth-largest in the US, is facing challenges such as rising office vacancy, shuttered small businesses, and declining tax revenues. Office attendance has stalled at around 40%, leading to a $780 million government projected shortfall. However, the city remains a powerhouse in many aspects, including venture capital deals, low unemployment, and new business formation. Experts anticipate a challenging road ahead for the city's recovery.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co agreed to acquire First Republic from the FDIC which seized the bank after a tumultuous period in which its stock had cratered and depositors had pulled almost half their money.
New York City rents in April were up 4.4 per cent from a year earlier.
Real estate agent Emily Young at the Hanover Republic Square, one of the most luxurious apartment buildings in Austin.
Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) and Marina Bay Financial Centre along the Singapore River at night, 29 October 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong raises base rate as US Fed tightens, hints at final move
summary: Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 5.5% on May 4, following the US Federal Reserve's move to tighten monetary policy. This may be the final rate hike in the HKMA's campaign to protect the local currency peg to the US dollar. The move is expected to push up short-term interbank rates and influence lending rates announced by major banks, including HSBC Holdings and Standard Chartered.

images.alt_text: The US central bank raised its benchmark overnight interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to the 5.00-5.25 per cent range, as expected by financial markets.
Hong Kong dollar banknotes

site_title: Dilemmas of deterrence
summary: The article discusses the challenges of deterrence in international relations, particularly in the context of the ongoing war in Europe and the tensions between the US and North Korea. Credibility is a crucial factor in successful deterrence, and the US has struggled to maintain its credibility in recent years, as seen in its failed attempts to deter North Korea's nuclear ambitions. The article cites historical examples, such as the US-extended deterrence in Europe during the Cold War, and the US's policy towards Taiwan, which has been characterized as "strategic ambiguity" or "double deterrence". The author argues that studying the limits of deterrence is essential to finding an effective strategy that works.

images.alt_text: Joseph S Nye
People watch a TV broadcasting a news report on North Korea firing a ballistic missile of intermediate range or longer, at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, April 13, 2023.

US President Joe Biden and his South Korean counterpart Yoon Suk Yeol said the US security shield for South Korea was being strengthened in the face of the nuclear-armed North’s aggressive missile tests.
History shows that globalisation is largely driven by technological changes that reduce the importance of distance, and that will not change.
US Navy sailors recover the downed Chinese surveillance balloon off the coast of South Carolina, US, on Feb 5, 2023.
US and China must avoid exaggerated fears that could create conflict

site_title: UBS aims to close Credit Suisse deal by end of May, early June: CEO
summary: UBS aims to close its merger deal with Credit Suisse by the end of May or early June, according to CEO Sergio Ermotti. The deal, agreed in March, includes a 3 billion Swiss franc takeover and assumption of up to 5 billion francs in losses. A spin-off of Credit Suisse's domestic unit is being considered, with current head Andre Helfenstein expected to run it. Ermotti acknowledged job cuts would not be avoidable, but did not provide a figure. The merger's outcome is subject to growing public and political pressure.

site_title: TSMC plans for first German chip fab with cost up to 10 billion euro
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) is in talks to build a chip fabrication plant in Saxony, Germany, with a potential budget of 10 billion euros, including state subsidies. The plant, which could be approved by August, will focus on producing 28-nanometre chips for the automotive sector. The project, involving TSMC, NXP Semiconductors, Robert Bosch, and Infineon Technologies, aims to boost EU semiconductor production and support the EU's Chips Act, which aims to double global production by 2030.

images.alt_text: TSMC is the world’s biggest contract manufacturer of semiconductors.

site_title: Eli Lilly’s ‘remarkable’ Alzheimer drug reduces cognitive decline
summary: Eli Lilly announced its experimental Alzheimer's drug, donanemab, significantly slowed cognitive and functional decline by 35% in a 18-month trial of nearly 1,200 people with early Alzheimer's disease. This reduction is comparable to a 27% decline found in another Alzheimer's drug, lecanemab. The results, hailed as "remarkable" by experts, target amyloid beta, a key protein in Alzheimer's disease. Donanemab also showed a 31% microhemorrhage rate, a side effect seen in 31% of treated patients and 14% in the placebo group.

images.alt_text: Eli Lilly invests US$30m in health-equity focused venture fund

site_title: UOB launches 42nd Painting of the Year award featuring artists with disabilities
summary: UOB launched its 42nd Painting of the Year award, featuring 36 art wearables co-designed by UOB artists and artists with disabilities from Journey. The limited-edition wearables will be sold for charity, with proceeds supporting Journey's art and education efforts. The award has expanded to Vietnam and includes a competition for Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam winners, with a grand prize of S$13,000 and a residency program in Japan. The competition is open to Singapore citizens and permanent residents, with submissions closing on July 31.

images.alt_text: President Halimah Yacob (fourth from left) at Monday's May Day Charity event with the top sponsors of this year's benefit.

site_title: Qantas’ Hong Kong lounge reopens as international flights return
summary: Qantas' Hong Kong lounge reopened on May 3 after a three-year closure, marking a return to international travel hub status. The A$100 million investment is part of Qantas' global lounge network expansion. The spruced-up lounge features new furniture, colors, and local dishes. Daily return flights between Sydney and Hong Kong resumed in January, with the Melbourne-Hong Kong route to be reinstated from June. Qantas' new CEO, Vanessa Hudson, has expressed strong demand for flights to Hong Kong.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher ahead of Fed decision
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 42.11 points, or 0.13%, to 33,726.64. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 opening 2.67 points, or 0.06%, higher to 4,122.25, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 16.53 points, or 0.14%, to 12,097.04. The market awaits the Fed's decision, which may influence investor sentiment.

site_title: EU pledges 500 million euros to boost ammunition output in Europe
summary: The European Union has pledged 500 million euros to boost ammunition production in Europe, with a focus on supporting Ukraine's defense needs and strengthening the bloc's defense industry. The funding will be used to co-finance projects with EU governments, with around half of the funds allocated to companies to increase output capacity or refit old ammunition stocks. The move aims to speed up production and address the urgent need for artillery ammunition in the region.

images.alt_text: Europe spent 13 per cent more on its armies in 2022 than in the previous 12 months, in a year marked by the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Singapore Tourism Board appoints new chief executive
summary: Melissa Ow, executive vice-president at the Economic Development Board, will become the new chief executive of the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) on June 1, 2023, succeeding Keith Tan. Tan, who led the tourism sector during the Covid-19 pandemic, will leave his post after steering the sector's recovery and reopening. Under Tan's leadership, Singapore became the first country certified as a sustainable destination by the Global Sustainable Tourism Council in 2023.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

On top of resuming travel and recovering flight and airport capacities, Singapore must redefine our destination, reconnect with our fans, and reinvent our industry to secure the future of tourism, says STB chief executive Keith Tan.
As part of Orchard Road’s rejuvenation plans, Tanglin’s identity as a neighbourhood with a strong artisanal flavour will be strengthened.

site_title: Indonesia finance minister calls for cautious approach towards easing inflation
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati advises a cautious approach to easing inflation, citing rapid price changes last year. Despite cooling inflation, policymakers must consider diverse factors driving price changes. Indonesia's central bank kept interest rates unchanged, but policymakers remain wary of persistent price pressures, as seen in unexpected rate hikes in Australia and Malaysia. Consumer inflation eased to 4.33% in April, approaching the central bank's target band of 2-4%. A carbon tax plan, delayed from last year, is still being considered, with no clear timeline announced.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati speaks during an interview with Reuters, on the sidelines of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) annual meeting in Incheon, South Korea, May 3, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: AI ‘will cause real damage,’ Microsoft chief economist warns
summary: Microsoft's chief economist Michael Schwarz warns that artificial intelligence will cause real damage if used by unscrupulous individuals, citing potential harm from spammers and election interference. He advocates for regulation, but cautions against over-regulation, stating that the benefits of regulation should outweigh the costs. Schwarz emphasizes that AI can be a powerful tool for productivity, but notes that policymakers should be cautious and wait until harm is seen before implementing regulations, saying "the benefits from the regulation to our society should be greater than the cost to our society."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken March 31, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The big question, as we lift the lids simultaneously on two giant Pandora's boxes, is: What kind of regulations and ethics must we put in place to manage what comes screaming out?

site_title: Singapore’s April PMI contracts for second month in a row
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced a decline in activity for the second consecutive month in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping 0.2 points to 49.7. This marks a downward trajectory echoing regional trends, where external demand remains weak. A reading below 50 indicates a decline in the manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Dyson's new battery plant in Tuas - the size of 53 basketball courts - is the company's "most significant investment in advanced manufacturing" in its history, it said.

Following three quarters of pessimism, a net weighted balance of 2 per cent of manufacturing firms are now anticipating a favourable business situation from April to September, a survey by the Singapore Economic Development Board showed on Friday (Apr 28).

site_title: Ancient DNA shows who wore this 20,000-year-old pendant
summary: Scientists have successfully extracted DNA from a 20,000-year-old elk's canine tooth pendant found in a Siberian cave, identifying the owner as a Stone Age woman closely related to hunter-gatherer populations in the region. A new non-destructive technique allowed researchers to isolate DNA from skin cells and bodily fluids absorbed by the pendant, providing insight into past behavior and culture. The discovery, published in the journal Nature, marks the first time a prehistoric artifact has been linked to a specific person, offering new opportunities to reconstruct past social roles and division of labor.

images.alt_text: The discovery suggests “detailed knowledge of limb anatomy and muscular and vascular systems,” the research team wrote in a paper published Wednesday in the journal Nature.

site_title: Chinese data provider tightens some information access for offshore users: sources
summary: China's data provider Wind Information has blocked some offshore users from accessing certain business and economic data, citing new security reviews. The move follows the Cyberspace Administration of China's push for data exports to undergo security reviews last year. The company, which aggregates financial data, has made part of its data inaccessible to users outside the Chinese mainland. The decision has raised concerns about information access in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Messi’s PSG future in doubt after suspension over Saudi trip
summary: Lionel Messi's future at Paris Saint-Germain is uncertain after he was suspended by the club for travelling to Saudi Arabia without permission. Messi, out of contract at the end of the season, will be sidelined for "several days" and may miss upcoming league matches, including a game against Troyes on Sunday. The suspension raises doubts about Messi's potential to stay with the club beyond his current deal, following recent reports that he is "much more likely" to depart.

site_title: SICC raises S$1.7 million at May Day Charity event
summary: The Singapore Island Country Club (SICC) successfully raised S$1.7 million at its May Day Charity event, exceeding its goal. The event, now in its 51st year, has raised over S$25 million for social service programs since its inception. The charity will benefit 14 organizations supporting causes such as health, community, and the elderly. President Halimah Yacob praised the SICC for its "club with a heart" spirit, encouraging continued charitable efforts throughout the month of May.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, UBS pick bonds over stocks on recession risk
summary: Fund managers at JPMorgan, UBS, and Morgan Stanley are shifting their focus to bonds over stocks due to rising recession risk. The threat of an economic slowdown has made debt securities a safer bet, with yields of high-grade dollar bonds exceeding dividend yields of companies in the MSCI ACWI Index by nearly 90 basis points. This trend has led to a flight to safety, with bonds experiencing a surge in popularity and stocks sinking. Despite some analysts predicting opportunities in emerging markets, the majority agree that fixed-income instruments are currently a more attractive option due to valuations and earnings expectations.

images.alt_text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) announced on May 1 that it sold the failing First Republic Bank to JP Morgan Chase & Co. First Republic Bank is the second-largest bank failure in US history.

site_title: Businesses keen on UK’s planned investment zones; sceptics see administrative challenges
summary: The UK government has announced plans to launch 12 new investment zones across the country, with £960 million in funding over the next five years. The zones, focusing on digital and tech, green industries, life sciences, and creative industries, aim to boost UK innovation and competitiveness. Local businesses and foreign investors, including Singapore, are enthusiastic about the move, with the UK Treasury seeking to attract £12 billion in new investment from Singapore alone. However, some sceptics raise concerns about administrative challenges, including a shortage of planning officers and poor communication from local authorities.

images.alt_text: Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran and UK Secretary of State for Business and Trade Kemi Badenoch at a virtual meeting where they announced the launch of negotiations on a new UK-Singapore Bilateral Investment Treaty.
Hunt says that although headline corporate tax will increase, most companies will be able to offset this with tax breaks for investments.

site_title: Changi Airport Terminal 2 to reopen fully in October, months ahead of schedule
summary: Changi Airport Terminal 2's northern wing is set to reopen fully in October 2023, several months ahead of schedule, with an increased handling capacity of 28 million passengers per year. The upgrade will bring the airport's total capacity to 90 million passengers annually. The full reopening comes as passenger traffic at Changi Airport continues to grow, with 82% of pre-Covid-19 passenger levels reached in March. The upgraded terminal will feature new amenities and retail offerings, enhancing the distinctive Changi travel experience.

images.alt_text: Changi Airport is the world’s 9th busiest, with a total of 31.9 million travellers passing through in 2022.

site_title: Development no longer possible without effective climate action: ADB president
summary: Asian Development Bank (ADB) President Masatsugu Asakawa stated that development is "no longer possible without effective climate action." At the 56th ADB Annual Meeting, Asakawa emphasized the importance of structural reform and not relying on fiscal policy in the face of banking stress. Finance ministers and central bank governors discussed policies to support Asia's rebound, with a focus on climate action, energy transition, and structural costs. Indonesia Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati stressed the need for a clear plan to lift fiscal consolidation without jeopardizing the economy's recovery.

images.alt_text: Exports from the resource-rich country rose to a record high last year on soaring global commodity prices.

Indonesia’s Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati says the country is on  a strong recovery path as the boost from China’s reopening and robust domestic sectors offset downside factors relating to the advanced economies.

site_title: Country legend Willie Nelson, at 90, among 2023 Rock Hall inductees
summary: Willie Nelson, 90, and country legends Dolly Parton, Hank Williams, and Johnny Cash will be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame this year, marking Nelson's first-time nomination. The 38th induction ceremony will take place on November 3 at Barclays Center in Brooklyn, coinciding with Nelson's 90th birthday and the 50th anniversary of hip-hop. Other inductees include late pop singer George Michael, rapper Missy Elliott, singer Sheryl Crow, and rock band Rage Against the Machine.

images.alt_text: Paul Anka will perform in Singapore for the first time in 9 years.

site_title: WWE quarterly revenue falls on delay in key event
summary: WWE reported a 11% decline in first-quarter revenue to $297.6 million, mainly due to a delayed large-scale international event. Operating income dropped 43% to $53.1 million, and net income fell to $36.7 million. Despite this, the company maintained its full-year earnings forecast of $395-410 million in adjusted OIBDA. The merger with Endeavor-owned UFC is expected to close in the second half of this year, with Endeavor owning a 51% stake in the new company. WWE's shares rose about 2% following the report.

images.alt_text: WWE executive chairman Vince McMahon will retain his role in the new company, which will be majority owned by Endeavor with a 51 per cent stake, while WWE investors will own the rest.

site_title: Toronto housing market roars back with sales and prices surging
summary: The Toronto housing market saw a significant surge in sales and prices in April, with 27% more homes trading hands than in March on a seasonally adjusted basis. The benchmark price of a Toronto home rose 2.4% to C$1.11 million, erasing earlier declines and marking the largest monthly increase in two decades. The rebound comes after last year's record price decline, driven by the Bank of Canada's interest rate hikes, and is attributed to a shortage of housing stock and increased demand.

site_title: Lian Beng makes final offer of S$0.68 per share in privatisation bid
summary: Lian Beng Group's controlling Ong family, through investment holding company OSC Capital, has made a final offer of S$0.68 per share to take the company private. The offer, made after a previous offer of S$0.62 per share, is less than half the group's net asset value of S$1.54 per share as of November last year. OSC Capital, 51% owned by Ong Pang Aik, does not intend to revise its final offer, which is expected to be considered by Lian Beng's shareholders.

images.alt_text: Ong Pang Aik, Executive Chairman, Lian Beng Group Ltd.

“Sias will not stand by and allow companies, which can afford to pay, to get away with lowball offers that are not fair and reasonable," says the association's founder, president and chief executive David Gerald.
Listed companies appear to be trying to make use of the compulsory acquisition loophole before it is closed?
Ong Pang Aik  is a director of both OSC Capital and Lian Beng.

site_title: Commercial real estate market faces next wave of financial stress, says Apollo CEO
summary: Apollo Global Management's CEO Marc Rowan warns that the commercial real estate market is facing a "next wave of financial stress" due to the rise of remote and hybrid work, limited office fill rates, and rising borrowing costs. The US vacancy rate for office buildings is nearly 19%, and some landlords have defaulted on debt. While some high-quality offices are seeing better rents, others are expected to face significant pain, particularly commodity office buildings and those in central business districts.

images.alt_text: Commercial real estate prices are a major concern for investors globally, as public markets price the impact of a slowing economy and the growth of remote work, while owners, especially unlisted players, resist major changes.
The Singapore Central Business District (CBD) skyline at night on 27 January 2014, showing the skyscrapers which house offices and banks.

site_title: Working together to bridge the digital divide
summary: Standard Chartered Bank's contribution to the Digital for Life fund has supported several digital inclusion projects in Singapore, including the IT Literacy programme by Daughters of Tomorrow, which aims to bridge the digital divide for low-income women. The programme provides digital skills training and mentorship, enabling participants like Aishah to access administrative and office-based roles. The bank's contribution has helped 7 projects so far, aiming to make technology a key enabler for social and economic inclusion.

images.alt_text: (From left) United Women Singapore's president Georgette Tan, Senior Minister of State Sim Ann and Standard Chartered cluster CEO Patrick Lee speak on a panel discussion at the Sneak Peak programme launch.
The festive bags, or fu dais, are packed by more than 1,300 volunteers over two days.

site_title: You don’t want to know how banks make their sausage
summary: The Federal Reserve and FDIC have released post-mortem reports on the failed Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), revealing a haphazardly run institution that prioritized appearances over professionalism. The reports show SVB's technology and risk management systems were lacking, with the bank's CEO Greg Becker stating that risk-management systems needed to be robust during a period of rapid growth. Despite these issues, management was informed of "foundational shortcomings" just days before the stock hit its all-time high, and the bank's executives kept shareholders in the dark about problems.

images.alt_text: The Blackstone real estate fund limits investor withdrawals to 2 per cent of net asset value in any month and 5 per cent in a calendar quarter; the limits prevented a run from taking hold.
A HSBC bank branch on King Street, London. The global ambitions of both HSBC and Citigroup have been pared back, replaced by a narrower focus on core markets.

site_title: US dollar takes a knock as jobs data muddies Fed outlook
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.3% to 101.56, marking a second consecutive day of decline, ahead of an expected interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve and amid concerns over the US debt ceiling and banking collapses. Jobs data showed a slowing labor market, which may speed up the Fed's fight against inflation. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, with investors awaiting policymakers' signals on future actions.

site_title: Mad about Succession
summary: The article discusses the popularity of the HBO series Succession, which has become a sensation among corporate professionals and business leaders. Viewers and financial experts alike dissect the show's realistic portrayal of power struggles and business dealings, drawing parallels with real-life American families. The show's influence extends beyond entertainment, with some even using it as a reference for business strategies and networking. The article also touches on related topics, including entrepreneurship, home renovation, and corporate purpose.

images.alt_text: Television still: Succession 3 starring Brian Cox

site_title: China restricts overseas access to corporate registry databases
summary: China has restricted overseas access to its corporate registry databases, affecting financial data providers Wind Information and Qichacha, as well as TianYanCha. The move is due to regulatory requirements and highlights the growing difficulty foreign firms face when trying to obtain sensitive information in China. The restriction comes amid increased pressure on foreign companies operating in the country, with authorities targeting US consultancy firms and imposing a new counter-espionage law. This move is seen as counter to Beijing's efforts to improve diplomatic ties globally, and has raised concerns about transparency in China's economy.

images.alt_text: The administration is preparing to solicit bids from chip companies that want to build semiconductor manufacturing plants in the US under President Joe Biden’s Chips and Science Act.

site_title: Fifa responsible for undervaluing Women’s World Cup, says ex-council member
summary: Former Fifa Council member Moya Dodd criticizes the governing body for undervaluing the Women's World Cup, saying the industry was trained to pay more for the men's tournament. Broadcasters in Europe offered $1-10 million for the women's rights, compared to $100-200 million for the men's. Dodd argues that Fifa should review bundled deals to attribute a fair proportion to the women's game, which could result in billions of dollars in revenue.

images.alt_text: The offers from broadcasters in the “Big 5” European nations – Italy, Germany, France, the UK and Spain  – “are still very disappointing and simply not acceptable,” President Gianni Infantino said in a statement on Fifa’s website.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip alongside other Asian markets ahead of Fed rate decision; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.6% on Wednesday, mirroring regional markets, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,262.01, with losers outnumbering gainers 321 to 257. Key losers included Genting Singapore, UOB, and DBS, while Sembcorp Industries surged 5.5%. Investors remain cautious due to regional banking concerns and the Fed's interest rate decision, with analysts expecting a 25 basis-point rate hike.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.1 per cent lower at 33,684.46 on Tuesday.

site_title: Advance Intelligence Group raises US$80 million from investor group
summary: Advance Intelligence Group, a Singapore-based AI startup, raised US$80 million from an investor consortium, including Warburg Pincus and Northstar Group. The funds will be used to accelerate AI technology adoption to streamline consumer transactions and improve financial inclusion in South-east Asia. This latest round follows the group's US$400 million Series D round in 2021, bringing total funding to over US$700 million. Advance Intelligence owns several AI-powered financial platforms, including Atome and Advance.AI.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts cut DBS targets amid expectations of NIM moderating
summary: Analysts have lowered their target prices on DBS Group Holdings due to a softer outlook, citing a moderation in net interest margins (NIM) and loan growth. RHB cut its target price to S$35.70, while CGS-CIMB trimmed its target to S$35.30. The implementation of Basel IV, starting January 2024, is expected to improve DBS' CET-1 CAR by two percentage points, providing a short-term boost, but the improvement will be eroded over time. DBS shares fell 2.2% or S$0.71 after the announcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of DBS is pictured outside an office in Singapore January 5, 2016.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD
Analysts expect limited upside for NIM growth ahead, while rising recession risks may result in weaker loan growth and rising asset quality risks.
DBS' Q1 2023 earnings beat the S$2.3 billion consensus forecast in a Bloomberg survey of three analysts.

site_title: India's Go First Airways owes financial creditors US$798 million
summary: India's Go First Airways, a budget airline, has filed for bankruptcy with total liabilities of 114.63 billion rupees (US$798 million) to financial creditors, including banks and vendors. The airline owes financial creditors US$798 million, with Central Bank of India, Bank of Baroda, and IDBI Bank among the major creditors. Go First has defaulted on payments to operational creditors, including vendors and aircraft lessors, and has received notices for termination of aircraft lease agreements. The airline's assets are insufficient to meet its liabilities, and lenders will meet soon to discuss the situation.

images.alt_text: Go First’s filing comes after Pratt & Whitney, the exclusive engine supplier for the airline’s Airbus A320neo aircraft fleet, refused to comply with an order to release engines to the airline that would have allowed it to return to full operations.

site_title: Hong Kong interbank rates jump ahead of Fed decision
summary: Hong Kong interbank rates jumped 18.9 basis points to 3.89929% and 14 basis points to 3.55333% on May 3, as the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) intervened to defend the peg, causing cash levels to decline and upward pressure on interbank rates. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise the benchmark Fed funds rate by 25 basis points, contributing to the market's anticipation of a rate hike.

images.alt_text: It remains profitable for the traders to borrow the Hong Kong dollar cheaply and buy the higher-yielding greenback, pocketing the rate difference.

site_title: Rent in New York City could soon increase by 2% to 5%
summary: The Rent Guidelines Board in New York City voted to approve rent increases of 2-5% for one-year leases and 4-7% for two-year leases, marking the second consecutive year of significant hikes. The increases, tracking inflation, will affect nearly one million rent-stabilized apartments, where the median rent is $1,400. Landlords argue they need the increases to cover rising costs, while tenant advocates call for a rent decrease, citing the ongoing housing crisis. The final vote is expected in June.

images.alt_text: New York City rents in April were up 4.4 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Keppel Corp CEO Loh Chin Hua appealed to analysts to reassess the company's valuation amid plans to simplify its organizational structure into a new "horizontally integrated operating model". Dyson is setting up a next-generation battery plant in Singapore, doubling its advanced manufacturing footprint in 2023. Lian Beng Group made a final offer of S$0.68 per share to take the company private. Meanwhile, Advance Intelligence Group raised US$80 million from an investor group, and Heartland shops underwent a visual makeover under a government-backed programme. Singapore stocks slipped 0.6% ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

site_title: Jewellery maker Pandora raises guidance after Q1 revenue beat; slow down brand relaunch in China
summary: Pandora, a Danish jewellery maker, raised its full-year revenue outlook after Q1 results slightly exceeded analyst forecasts. The company expects organic sales growth between -2% and 3% this year, better than its earlier estimate of -3% to 3%. Despite this, Pandora will slow down its planned country-wide relaunch in China due to slow customer demand recovery from Covid-19 curbs. The company aims to launch a brand relaunch in one city at a time, starting in the third quarter.

site_title: World's tallest 'hemp hotel' trails South Africa's green credentials
summary: South Africa's Cape Town is set to welcome the world's tallest building constructed from industrial hemp, the 12-storey Hemp Hotel, due to be completed in June. The 54-room hotel features wood-finished hempcrete walls that provide insulation, fire resistance, and a negative carbon footprint. The hemp used for the project was imported from Britain, but the company plans to produce its own blocks using South African hemp once permits are issued. The hotel's carbon footprint is three tonnes lower than a conventional building, making it a sustainable landmark in the construction sector.

images.alt_text: Climate change has spurred renewed interest in the ancient technique which sees polluting concrete swapped where possible for earth.

site_title: India’s April services activity hits near 13-year high, inflation accelerates
summary: India's services sector expanded at its fastest pace in nearly 13 years in April, with the S&P Global India services PMI jumping to 62.0 from 57.8 in March. Strong demand, including robust domestic and international demand, drove the growth. However, employment generation was only marginally higher, and input prices rose to a three-month high, leading to price pressures. The Reserve Bank of India is likely to keep its key interest rate on hold, citing an improving economic outlook and rising price pressures.

images.alt_text: The reopening of China’s economy will be pivotal for the region with the spillover to Asia seen focused on consumption and service-sector demand rather than investment, the IMF said.
A man stands outside an IDBI Bank branch next to its ATM kiosk in Mumbai. After a record-breaking year in 2021, PE and VC investments totalled US$61.6 billion in 2022.

site_title: Malaysia to move to dual network model for 5G after expanding coverage
summary: Malaysia plans to transition to a dual network model for its 5G rollout after achieving 80% coverage, following concerns over pricing and competition. Currently, Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB) has 57.8% coverage and aims to reach 80% by the end of the year. The move comes after Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced a review of the plan, citing a lack of transparency. A new entity will be established after 80% coverage is reached, addressing industry concerns about a single government-run network.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s central bank projects full-year inflation of 2.8 per cent to 3.8 per cent in 2023, compared to 3.3 per cent in 2022.

site_title: Former Audi boss agrees deal to make confession in diesel emissions scandal
summary: Former Audi CEO Rupert Stadler is set to make a confession in two weeks regarding his role in the diesel emissions scandal in exchange for a suspended sentence and a payment of 1.1 million euros. Stadler has been on trial since 2020, having previously rejected the allegations. His defense team stated that the upcoming statement will be a complete confession, which the judge will then decide upon.

site_title: Musk threatens to reassign NPR’s Twitter handle in ongoing feud
summary: Elon Musk threatens to reassign NPR's Twitter handle (@npr) due to the organization's decision to stop tweeting after he labeled it "state-affiliated media" along with other publicly funded outlets. Musk suggested transferring the handle to another company, "National Pumpkin Radio," and asked if NPR should reassign the handle. The move has raised concerns about misinformation on the platform, as reassigning Twitter handles could be misleading for users.

site_title: World should prepare for El Nino, new record temperatures: UN
