summary: The UN's World Meteorological Organization (WMO) estimates a 60% chance of El Nino developing by the end of July, with an 80% chance by the end of September. This climate pattern is associated with increased heat worldwide, drought in some areas, and heavy rains elsewhere, potentially leading to new heat records. El Nino last occurred in 2018-19 and its development could fuel global temperatures.

site_title: Australia’s retail sales gain in March driven by food inflation
summary: Australia's retail sales rose 0.4% in March, driven by food inflation, marking a third consecutive month of gains. This slowdown in spending reflects the impact of the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest-rate increases and increased cost of living pressures. Consumer electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi reported a slowdown in same-store sales, and economists predict a cooling in spending, with consumption growth expected to be 1.7% by end-2023, down from a 7.5% gain in 2022.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia lifted the key interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.85 per cent, wrong-footing many economists who predicted there would be no change.

site_title: UK's Lloyds beats profit forecasts, signals stresses ahead
summary: UK's Lloyds reports pretax profit of £2.3 billion for the first quarter of 2023, beating analyst forecasts, but indicating potential stress among borrowers due to rising interest rates and high inflation. The bank made a provision of £243 million to cover potential losses after reporting "modest" rises in arrears. Despite exceeding expectations, Lloyds kept full-year profit forecasts flat, signaling caution about the outlook for profit-boosting rates and rising defaults.

images.alt_text: Canary Wharf in the financial district of the City of London. Commercial real estate has been roiled by the dramatic shift in interest rates over the past year, which has begun to hit pricing.

site_title: Thailand’s April headline inflation lowest in 16 months, to drop further
summary: Thailand's headline inflation dropped to its lowest in 16 months in April, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising 2.67% from a year earlier, close to forecast. Lower energy and food prices contributed to the decline, while a high base in 2022 also played a role. The core CPI index, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, rose 1.66% from a year ago, its slowest increase in 15 months.

images.alt_text: Exports, a key driver of Thai growth, are expected to drop 0.5 per cent this year.

site_title: S&P slashes First Republic Bank’s ratings to ‘CC’
summary: S&P Global has slashed First Republic Bank's credit rating to 'CC' due to a "virtual certainty" of default. The US lender was previously closed by California banking regulators. This move puts First Republic's credit rating deeper into junk territory, indicating a high risk of default. The downgrade is a significant blow to the bank's financial stability and may impact its ability to raise capital or access credit markets.

site_title: Global rate hike push slows to a trickle in April ahead of busy May
summary: Global interest rate hikes slowed to a trickle in April, with only two hikes across five meetings by central banks overseeing the 10 most heavily traded currencies. Policymakers in developed markets, such as the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, are still expected to deliver more hikes in May. In emerging markets, 11 out of 18 central banks decided not to hike rates, with only Israel and Colombia increasing by a cumulative 50 basis points, a significant slowdown from March. Analysts expect a pivot towards rate cuts in emerging markets, but inflation concerns remain.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia lifted the key interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.85 per cent, wrong-footing many economists who predicted there would be no change.

site_title: Porsche profit rises on stronger sales, pricing power
summary: Porsche reported a 25% increase in first-quarter operating profit to 1.84 billion euros (S$2.7 billion) and revenue rose to 10.1 billion euros, driven by stronger sales and pricing power. The luxury carmaker's return on carmaking was 18.2% in the first quarter, exceeding its 2023 guidance of 17% to 19%. Despite a slowing global economy, high-end carmakers like Porsche, Mercedes-Benz, and BMW have shown resilience, with Porsche's operating profit and revenue outperforming last year's figures.

images.alt_text: 22-year-old Oskar (R) and his brother, 19-year-old Jakob Flyman, work in their garage, specializing in converting regular cars into A Traktors, on February 28, 2023, in Balsta, northwest of Stockholm, Sweden. - Too young for a driver's licence at 15, Evelina Christiansen is already cruising in a sleek BMW in Sweden, where teens can drive any car modified to roll no faster than a golf cart. An almost century-old regulation originally applied to agricultural vehicles allows kids 15 and older to drive without a proper driver's licence, providing the vehicle has been altered to have a maximum speed of 30 kilometres per hour (18.6 miles per hour). Called an "A-traktor" -- with Swedes often using the older designation EPA -- these cars and trucks have become so popular in recent years that authorities are now concerned about a rise in road accidents. (Photo by Jonathan NACKSTRAND / AFP)

site_title: Institutional investors to prolong defensive play on debt ceiling, rate volatility woes: State Street
summary: Institutional investors are taking a defensive stance, with cautious actions over April and overly complacent risky asset pricing, according to State Street's indicators. The Institutional Investor Holdings Indicator and Institutional Investor Risk Appetite Indicator showed that investors' actions are broadening defensive behavior across all asset classes. Cash holdings are below long-term averages, suggesting potential for further defensive behavior if debt ceiling concerns, interest rate volatility, or stagflation fears flare up. The indicators will be made available on State Street's research platform, Insights.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
SVB was neither conservative nor prudent, but in the absence of a run on its deposits, it did not have to crash.
Dark trading isn't all secretive and risky; what's "hidden" aren't the prices but the buy and sell orders.

site_title: Federal Reserve likely to hike rates, hint at pause in tightening cycle
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates and signal a pause in its 14-month tightening cycle at its Wednesday meeting. Policymakers aim to balance slowing inflation with weakening economy risks, including bank failures and a possible US debt default. The Fed may adopt a less forward-leaning tone on future rate hikes, indicating a potential shift towards prioritizing financial stability over inflation control.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect gold prices to hover around US$1,950 an ounce in the coming months.
JPMorgan Chase & Co agreed to acquire First Republic from the FDIC which seized the bank after a tumultuous period in which its stock had cratered and depositors had pulled almost half their money.

FILE PHOTO: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell testifies before a U.S. Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee hearing on "The Semiannual Monetary Policy Report to the Congress" on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., March 7, 2023. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque//File Photo/File Photo
Morgan Stanley in December cut roughly 1,600 jobs.

site_title: Heartland shops get a visual makeover
summary: Heartland shops in Singapore have undergone a visual makeover under the Heartland Enterprise Centre Singapore and Enterprise Singapore's Visual Merchandising programme. Since August 2021, over 200 stores have benefited from the transformation, resulting in a 20% increase in footfall and sales. The programme, which also includes digital marketing and brand upkeep, aims to enhance the overall shopping experience and support local businesses.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Mr Loh Chee Liue hand his retail store M S Color which participated in the Visual Merchandising Programme.

Under the Heartland Innovation and Transformation (HIT) Programme, more modular temporary spaces in mature heartland precincts will be constructed and made available for enterprises to use these spots to test out new business ideas.
Shoppers participating in a hawker-themed gameshow organised as part of this year's Heartlands Festival.

site_title: Thailand in talks with CATL, others on potential battery plants, government official says
summary: Thailand is in talks with Chinese battery maker CATL and other companies to build production facilities in the country, aiming to become a regional electric vehicle (EV) production hub. The government is offering tax cuts and subsidies to drive EV adoption and production. According to Narit Therdsteerasukdi, Secretary General of Thailand Board of Investment, multiple companies are being approached, not just CATL. This move is part of Thailand's efforts to push into the global EV supply chain outside of China.

images.alt_text: CATL battery sales volume could grow 40-50 per cent in 2023 on China’s economic reopening and zero purchase tax to bolster EV sales.

site_title: With AI, let’s not move fast and break things
summary: Thomas Friedman discusses the risks and benefits of artificial intelligence (AI) and climate change, comparing them to the two Pandora's boxes. He warns that if we don't put in place regulations and ethics, AI could lead to unpredictable and harmful consequences, similar to social networks' impact on society. Experts, including James Manyika and Dov Seidman, emphasize the need for responsible AI development and use, while also acknowledging its potential to help humanity. Friedman concludes that the faster AI and climate change evolve, the more crucial it is to scale ethics and regulations, lest we "break things" and lose our way.

images.alt_text: The UN’s World Meteorological Organization (WMO) says it now estimates a 60-per cent chance that El Nino would develop by the end of July.
The rapid development and increasingly pervasive use of generative AI systems has alarmed many.
ChatGPT, which has wowed some users with quick responses to questions and caused distress for others with inaccuracies, is made by California-based OpenAI and backed by Microsoft Corp.
WHO details steps to ensure human gene editing is safe, ethical

site_title: Singapore stocks drop at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking overnight losses on Wall Street and Europe, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.7% to 3,260.77. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell 1.5%, 0.7%, and 0.5% respectively, while Seatrium, Genting Singapore, and Singtel also experienced losses. The decline follows overnight losses in the US and Europe, with regional bank stocks declining on expectations of another Fed rate hike.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Stocks to watch: Keppel, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, Unusual

site_title: TikTok’s head of US trust and safety will leave the company
summary: TikTok's head of US trust and safety, Eric Han, will leave the company on May 12, amid concerns over a potential US ban. Han, who oversaw content moderation and election misinformation efforts, departed after a four-year tenure. The move comes as TikTok prepares to present to advertisers in New York and faces ongoing security concerns. Han's departure is the latest in a series of changes at the company, which has already been banned in countries such as Canada and Australia due to data security concerns.

site_title: Apax, Canada Pension weigh buyout of US$2 billion IT firm Thoughtworks
summary: Apax Partners and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board are considering a potential $2 billion buyout of US technology consultancy Thoughtworks. The consortium, led by Apax, has teamed up with CPPIB to explore a possible joint offer for Thoughtworks' shares. The company's stock jumped 25% on Tuesday after the news, valuing it at $2.3 billion. Apax acquired Thoughtworks in 2017 and listed the company through a Nasdaq IPO in 2021. Deliberations are ongoing, with no certainty of a formal offer, and the company remains focused on executing its business plan.

images.alt_text: The move expands the Singapore state investor’s exposure to logistics assets.

site_title: Air France wants level playing field with Chinese carriers
summary: Air France is seeking increased flights to China, aiming for 14 weekly flights in July pending Chinese government approval. The airline wants a "level playing field" with Chinese carriers, citing unfair advantages from flying over Russian airspace. Avoiding Russian airspace adds 2-3 hours and extra costs, but also saves on overflight fees. The move comes as China's tourism market recovers, and France's government considers introducing taxes or measures to balance competition between Air France and Chinese airlines.

images.alt_text: An Airbus SE A318-111 passenger aircraft, operated by Air France-KLM. The company said it was on track to fully pay back French state aid by April 2023, reporting a net debt of 6.3 billion euros, down 1.9 billion euros from the previous year.

site_title: Tech industry allowing ‘deluge’ of misinformation: RSF
summary: Reporters Without Borders (RSF) criticizes the tech industry for allowing a "deluge" of misinformation, citing Twitter's paid verification system as an example. The organization's annual report rates journalism as "bad" in 70% of 180 countries, with Norway and North Korea being the best and worst, respectively. RSF secretary-general Christophe Deloire attributes the problem to the rapid evolution of artificial intelligence, which "drowns out" trustworthy news. The report also highlights the involvement of disinformation industries in many countries, including Russia, India, and China.

images.alt_text: Musk made his prediction on the eve of Twitter’s Apr 1 ultimatum that verified accounts with the cherished blue tick that had not forked over cash would lose it.

FILE PHOTO: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Director-General of the World Health Organization (WHO), speaks during a news conference in Geneva, Switzerland, December 20, 2021. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo/File Photo
YouGov data shows that about 41 per cent of people in Singapore aged between 18 and 24 have used TikTok in October 2022.

FILE PHOTO: Rupert Murdoch, Executive Chairman of News Corp and 21st Century Fox, takes part as a judge during a global start up showcase at the Wall Street Journal Digital Live (WSJDLive) conference at the Montage hotel in Laguna Beach, California, October 20, 2015. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

Smartmatic is seeking US$2.7 billion in damages, saying Fox News knowingly lied about its technology and how it was used in order to boost ratings, and keep Trump supporters from defecting to the right-wing networks Newsmax and One America News.

site_title: Keppel seeks stronger valuations with reorganisation
summary: Keppel Corp plans to reorganize into a global alternative real asset manager, simplifying its structure and focusing on recurring fee income. The company aims to scale its assets under management to S$200 billion by 2030 and S$100 billion by 2026. Analysts were invited to reassess the company's valuation, with a focus on price-to-earnings multiples for income-generating components. The reorganization will also lead to S$60 million to S$70 million in annual savings by 2026. Keppel expects to monetize its assets, including its land bank, and invest in new growth engines.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Vivienne Tay
While the company did not specify its net profit figures for the quarter, it noted that net profit was significantly higher year-on-year.

site_title: Jewellery with Nazi links set to fetch US$150 million at auction
summary: Christie's is set to auction off a collection of 700 jewels worth an estimated US$150 million, including pieces from renowned designers Cartier, Harry Winston, and Bulgari. The collection, which belonged to Austrian billionaire Heidi Horten, has a complex history tied to her husband Helmut Horten, a former Nazi party member. Despite this, Christie's has chosen to proceed with the sale, with proceeds going to support philanthropic activities and Holocaust research. The auction will take place from May 10-12 in Geneva, with online sales also available.

site_title: White House calls in tech firms to talk AI risks
summary: The US White House plans to meet with top tech executives from Google, Microsoft, OpenAI, and Anthropic to discuss AI risks and benefits. The meeting aims to ensure consumers are protected from AI harms while benefiting from its promise. The US Department of Commerce has issued a call for input on AI regulation, following a step towards drafting rules that could impact new technologies like ChatGPT. The meeting comes as the US lags behind international regulation of the tech industry.

site_title: China still a ‘huge market’ for US chip companies despite risks
summary: US semiconductor companies are seeking access to China's market despite national security concerns, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association. The Biden administration is preparing to solicit bids for chip manufacturing plants in the US under the Chips and Science Act, with rules to be proposed on investments in China. Industry leaders want clear rules to ensure the program's success and predictability, citing uncertainty and challenges in planning for the next five years. They aim to balance national security priorities with commercial interests in the China market, the industry's largest.

site_title: Ronaldo tops Forbes’ highest-paid athletes list in 2023 after Saudi move
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo topped Forbes' highest-paid athletes list in 2023 after signing with Saudi Arabian club Al-Nassr, nearly doubling his annual playing salary to an estimated $75 million. His contract, valued at over $200 million euros, surpassed previous records. Lionel Messi and Kylian Mbappe rounded out the top three, with Paris St Germain duo earning an estimated $110 million and $85 million respectively. Ronaldo's move to Al-Nassr marked a significant shift in his career and finances.

site_title: AMD shares sink on forecast miss as PC market remains weak
summary: AMD shares dropped 6% after missing quarterly sales estimates due to a weak PC market, contrary to expectations for a chip market recovery in the second half of 2023. The company forecast $5.3 billion in revenue for the quarter, below analyst estimates. This underperformed Intel's 3% rise in extended trading, as the rival chipmaker predicted a PC market rebound in the second half.

site_title: Indonesian cold-chain solutions provider Coldspace bags US$3.8 million in seed funding
summary: Indonesian cold-chain solutions provider Coldspace secured US$3.8 million in seed funding led by Intudo Ventures, logistics firm ASSA, and agricultural conglomerate Triputra Group. The funding will be used to expand capacity, launch management solutions, and increase geographic coverage. Founded in December 2022, Coldspace aims to address high food waste and spoilage in Indonesia's tropical climate, targeting emerging demand for temperature-controlled infrastructure.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, Unusual
summary: Keppel Corporation will reorganize to focus on fund management, investment, and operating platforms, aiming to become a global alternative real asset manager by 2030. CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's average rental rates rose 11.1% for leases renewed in Q1 2023, with Australian assets seeing a 14.3% increase. Unusual's shares surged 13.6% after a strong response to ticket sales for an upcoming concert by Jacky Cheung.

site_title: Gold prices steady with market focus on US Federal Reserve rate decision
summary: Gold prices remain steady above $2,000 per ounce, holding at $2,015.25 per ounce, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Analysts expect gold prices to hover around $1,950 an ounce in the coming months due to a potential decrease in demand with higher interest rates. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, which could impact the demand for gold as a hedge against inflation and economic turbulence.

images.alt_text: While gold is known as an inflation hedge, rising rates tend to lower demand for zero-yielding asset.

site_title: 5 Questions with Leslie Teo, economist-turned-techie
summary: Leslie Teo, former chief economist at GIC, quit his job at 50 to pursue a career in tech. He now leads data science at AI Singapore and is a senior director for AI products. Teo believes the convergence of Big Data, networks, and computing power will be the next disruptive force in the world. He has made a successful career transition, leveraging his analytical skills to drive innovation in AI. Teo shares insights on the impact of AI and data analysis on various industries, including transportation and safety.

site_title: Indonesia economy likely grew 4.95% on year in Q1, contracted vs quarter: poll
summary: Indonesia's economy likely grew 4.95% in Q1, its weakest in over a year, as lower commodity prices hit exports and higher interest rates restricted domestic demand. Exports dropped 11.33% in March from a year earlier, and GDP growth forecasts ranged from 4.23% to 5.20%. The economy is also forecast to have contracted quarter-on-quarter for the first time in a year, by 1.0%. This slowdown is attributed to weak external demand and tighter monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Indonesian Muslims typically increase their spending during the festivities and millions travel home to celebrate Eid al-Fitr.

site_title: France’s BNP Paribas doubles profits in Q1 with Bank of the West sale
summary: France's BNP Paribas reported a 2.4-fold increase in first-quarter profits, driven by the sale of its US retail division, Bank of the West, which generated 2.95 billion euros in capital gains. Revenue exceeded expectations at 12.03 billion euros, with net interest income rising and fixed-income trading performing better than peers. The bank's capital and liquidity buffers were bolstered, and it confirmed its 2025 targets, including a return on tangible equity of around 12% and an average annual growth in net income of over 9%.

images.alt_text: Online and mobile shopping payments will be added later on, along with subscription instalments, and services such as buy now, pay later, over time.
The new wealth management unit will provide clients access to international capital markets by using BNP Paribas’ platform in Singapore.

site_title: Why Chinese banks aren’t worried about depositors fleeing
summary: Chinese banks remain unfazed by depositors fleeing to higher-yielding investments, as they maintain artificially low benchmark deposit rates since 2015. Despite the challenges, Chinese banks are not starved for funding due to consumers' past experiences with failed investments. Household deposits now account for 70% of total deposits, up from pre-pandemic levels. In contrast, US money-market funds are unlikely to "break the buck" due to regulatory changes and government backing, but vulnerabilities remain, including the debt ceiling crisis.

images.alt_text: The yuan’s share of global payments is merely 2.5 per cent, and tiny compared with US dollar’s 39.4 per cent and euro’s 35.8 per cent.

site_title: Asia: Stocks down after Wall Street losses
summary: Asian stocks fell on Wednesday following Wall Street losses due to concerns over banking sector turmoil and interest rate hikes. Hong Kong dropped 1.5% in early trade, with tech shares among the biggest losers. The Australian central bank raised interest rates to an 11-year high, and investors positioned themselves ahead of expected rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Seoul, Taipei, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore and Manila were all up, while Sydney, Wellington, Jakarta and Bangkok were down on Tuesday.

site_title: Young Thai protesters hope for ‘game changer’ election
summary: Young Thai protesters, who led a democracy movement three years ago, are now preparing to vote for the first time in Thailand's May 14 election. They hope the election will be a "game changer" for reform, with demands including monarchy reform and changes to the country's strict laws. The protesters, who are mostly millennials and Gen Z, are not naive about the challenges they face, but are optimistic about the potential for change. They will be voting against the current prime minister, Prayut Chan-O-Cha, and are supporting pro-democracy parties like the Move Forward Party.

site_title: Malaysia raises key policy rate to 3% as domestic growth prospects stay ‘resilient’
summary: Malaysia's central bank raised its overnight policy rate (OPR) by 25 basis points to 3% on May 3, its first hike since November. The decision was unexpected, surprising economists who had anticipated a continued pause. Despite the hike, the bank maintains its monetary policy stance as "slightly accommodative and supportive of the economy." Economists expect the central bank to keep policy accommodative for the rest of the year, citing resilient domestic growth prospects.

images.alt_text: FILE — The Federal Reserve Building in Washington, Aug. 6, 2022. Yields on government debt have been sent higher as the Fed and other central banks continue their campaigns to raise interest rates and bring prices under control. (Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times)

site_title: BlackRock favours shorter bonds to hedge volatility, higher rates
summary: BlackRock's research arm advises favouring shorter bonds to hedge volatility and higher interest rates due to sticky inflation. The firm expects the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank to hike interest rates this week, increasing the appeal of short-dated debt over longer-term bonds. This shift is driven by concerns about inflation and the potential for further losses in longer-maturity bonds. BlackRock strategists also warn that investors will increasingly demand higher compensation for holding long-term government bonds amid high debt levels and rising inflation.

images.alt_text: The government hired BlackRock to sell the collapsed banks’ securities earlier in April, highlighting the firm’s role as an adviser to regulators in times of financial peril.
The world’s top asset manager has already seen a boost amid the recent turmoil in the US banking sector, following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March.

site_title: Dyson to set up next-gen battery plant in Singapore, double advanced manufacturing footprint in 2023
summary: Dyson is setting up a next-generation battery plant in Singapore, its first proprietary new technology battery plant, with a production capacity equivalent to 53 basketball courts. The plant is expected to be completed in 2023 and become operational by 2025, producing battery cells with proprietary technology for new products. The investment is part of Dyson's five-year £2.75 billion (S$4.58 billion) roadmap, with plans to double its advanced manufacturing footprint. The company has also set up new R&D campuses in the Philippines and the UK, with investments totaling £166 million and £100 million respectively.

site_title: Oil slumps 5% to five-week low amid US debt default fears
summary: Oil prices plummeted 5% to a five-week low amid concerns over the US economy, with Brent futures falling to $75.32 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude falling to $71.66 a barrel. The US Treasury Secretary warned of a possible debt default, while investors prepare for potential interest rate hikes. Analysts at Barclays predicted a recession in the US later this year, citing a contracting manufacturing sector and struggling consumer.

images.alt_text: Brent crude fell US$1.02, or 1.3 per cent, to settle at US$78.45 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude slid US$1.12, or 1.5 per cent, to settle at US$75.66 on Monday.

site_title: Carl Icahn’s wealth plunges US$10 billion on Hindenburg ‘ponzi-like’ accusation
summary: Carl Icahn's wealth plummeted by 41% to $14.6 billion after Hindenburg Research accused him of a "ponzi-like" economic structure at his investment company, Icahn Enterprises. The company's stock fell 20%, erasing $3.1 billion from Icahn's fortune. Hindenburg criticized Icahn for not disclosing margin loan details, which added $7.3 billion to the net worth calculation. Icahn's stake in the company, worth $15.7 billion, was boosted by dividend payments in units, making it attractive to retail investors.

images.alt_text: Hindenburg, founded by short-seller Nathan Anderson, describes itself as a forensic-research outfit operating with its own capital.

site_title: Sats adds three Worldwide Flight Services executives to board; WFS CEO leaves
summary: SATS added three Worldwide Flight Services executives to its global management board, including Francois Mirallie as deputy CEO and Michael Simpson as CEO of Americas WFS. Craig Smyth, WFS CEO, will leave the company due to new reporting lines. The move is seen as a recognition of talent development across the global organisation to unlock insights from diverse regions and enable expansion. The WFS leadership team's future strategy and responsibilities remain unchanged.

site_title: 'Bring it on': Emirates airline boss welcomes Saudi competition
summary: Emirates airline president Tim Clark welcomes Saudi Arabia's expansion plans, including the launch of new national carrier Riyadh Air and a major airport, as "bring it on." Clark believes Saudi airlines and other competitors, such as Air India, need time to develop and improve their services to be profitable. He notes that Emirates has built its brand over 35 years and sees no threat to its dominance, but is open to increased competition. The airline reported record half-year profits of $1.2 billion in November, and expects to regain its pre-pandemic network of destinations by summer next year.

images.alt_text: The launch of Riyadh Air is part of Saudi Arabia’s strategy to help kickstart its tourism industry and make it one of the world’s most popular destinations.

site_title: US job openings fall, layoffs jump, indicating softer labour market
summary: US job openings fell to 9.59 million in March, down from nearly 10 million a month earlier, and layoffs jumped to the highest level since December 2020, indicating a gradual moderation in labor demand. The labor market remains resilient, but the data suggests a shift towards better balance and alleviating upward pressure on wages. The quits rate eased to 2.5%, and the ratio of openings to unemployed people ticked down to 1.6, the lowest since October 2021.

images.alt_text: The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index fell to 101.3 – the lowest since July 2022 – from a revised 104.0 in March.

site_title: Apple and Google aim to expose Bluetooth tracker abuse
summary: Apple and Google have proposed a tech standard to alert users when their Bluetooth devices are being tracked by stalkers or unwanted individuals, following the misuse of devices like AirTags and Tile. The proposed standard, backed by Samsung and other companies, aims to make Bluetooth tracking devices compatible with detection and alert systems in iOS and Android mobile software. If adopted, the standard would give device makers the option to build tracking prevention capabilities into their products, helping to combat unwanted tracking.

site_title: AI disruption deepens with Chegg plunge, IBM hiring halt, Samsung chatbot ban
summary: Artificial intelligence is causing widespread disruption, with companies like Chegg and IBM halting hiring for jobs that can be replaced by AI. Chegg's shares plummeted 48% after the company cited OpenAI's ChatGPT as a threat to its homework-help services. IBM will slow hiring for 30% of its non-customer facing workers, while Samsung has banned employees from using ChatGPT due to concerns over data security. The technology's impact on industries and economies is expected to be massive, with Goldman Sachs predicting 7% global GDP growth in the next decade.

site_title: Britain’s housing slowdown leaves more homes on the market
summary: Britain's housing market is experiencing a slowdown due to higher borrowing costs and possible drop in house prices, leaving more homes on the market. As of last month, there were 66% more properties available to buy compared to a year ago, with an average of 25 homes per estate agency branch. Sellers are accepting lower valuations, and first-time buyers are opting for smaller properties, with 30% of interest in one- and two-bed flats. Prospective buyers may find relief in announcements from the Conservatives and Labour Party to stimulate the housing market.

images.alt_text: London has already lost its crown as the top European trading hub following Britain’s departure from the European Union in early 2021, despite earlier post-Brexit reforms.

site_title: Divestment from oil & gas will slow clean-energy transition: State Street CEO
summary: State Street CEO Ron O'Hanley stated that divestment from oil and gas companies will slow the transition to cleaner energy. He argued that investments in polluting industries are necessary for them to change, rather than divestment. O'Hanley claims that divestment efforts will not significantly reduce carbon emissions, sparking a debate between green energy advocates and Republican politicians over "woke" policies and environmental investments.

site_title: Greater collaboration within Asia-Pacific the answer to forthcoming EU carbon tax?
summary: The European Union's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) is set to be enacted in October, requiring countries exporting to the EU to demonstrate they've paid a carbon price to cover production costs. Asian-Pacific businesses are weighing the implications, with some economies ill-prepared for the regulation. To address this, regional collaboration and integration through renewable energy exchange, such as Malaysia-Thailand-Vietnam power trade, could be key. Existing grid networks in the region, like those connecting Malaysia, Thailand, and Laos, could also facilitate cross-border collaboration and help balance carbon costs.

images.alt_text: Global investment in the green transition is set to triple by 2030 from US$1 trillion last year, President Ursula von der Leyen told the European Parliament on Wednesday, declaring “the race is on”.
Leaders from nine countries including Germany, France and Britain are set to gather in Ostend, Belgium on Monday, to pledge to more than quadruple offshore wind capacity in the North Sea by 2030.
The Liddell power station, about three hours’ drive north of Sydney, is one in a series of ageing coal-fired plants slated to close in coming years.

site_title: New Zealand jobless rate holds steady as wage inflation climbs
summary: New Zealand's jobless rate remains steady at 3.4% in the first quarter, while employment rose 0.8% and wage inflation accelerated to 4.5%. The tight labour market is fueling price pressures, prompting the Reserve Bank of New Zealand to raise interest rates at a record pace. The RBNZ predicts a recession this year, which should soften the labour market, and is expected to deliver a final 25 basis-point hike at its next policy meeting on May 24, bringing the Official Cash Rate to 5.5%.

images.alt_text: THE Reserve Bank of New Zealand said it was not seeing widespread financial distress among households or businesses but warned more borrowers could fall behind on their payments this year.

site_title: Reducing US tensions with China
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen proposes a "constructive disengagement" approach to address growing tensions with China, suggesting a balanced perspective on the issue. This approach aims to maintain economic ties and cooperation on issues of common interest, despite differences over core geostrategic concerns. Yellen's comments aim to counter the notion of a potential cold war between the US and China, potentially preventing a hot war, particularly over Taiwan.

images.alt_text: China and economic security will be main topics when G7 leaders meet in Japan next month, according to an official familiar with the discussions.
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and France's President Emmanuel Macron, meeting with China’s President Xi Jinping, in Beijing, China, April 6, 2023.

site_title: Starbucks sales top estimates, buoyed by strength in US and China
summary: Starbucks posted sales that beat estimates, with 6% growth in the US and 11% comparable sales globally. The company's quarterly performance was driven by consumers' resilience in paying higher menu prices and a return to dining out. However, shares slid 5.2% after CEO Laxman Narasimhan reaffirmed the company's full-year guidance, disappointing investors who had hoped for a boost. Despite this, Starbucks' year-to-date gain is more than double that of the S&P 500 Index.

images.alt_text: While China has largely abandoned its zero-Covid policy and began reopening in early December, customer traffic at Starbucks remained weak owing to widespread Covid-19 outbreaks in the country.

site_title: Jacky Cheung’s concert cited as possible reason behind Unusual’s unusual trading activity
summary: Unusual Limited's shares rose 13.6% after citing overwhelming response to ticket sales for a Jacky Cheung concert as a possible reason for unusual trading activity. The company's shares had also steadily risen over the past week, with a 14.1% increase between April 26 and 28. Prior to this, trading activity was generally muted, with prices usually hovering at S$0.14.

site_title: Ford beats on first-quarter profit, maintains 2023 outlook
summary: Ford Motor Company beat first-quarter profit estimates with adjusted earnings per share of 63 US cents, exceeding analyst expectations. The company reported higher vehicle pricing and increased sales volumes, contributing to a 4.5% increase in adjusted earnings before interest and taxes to $3.4 billion. Ford maintained its full-year outlook, despite the strong quarterly results. The company's restructuring efforts, led by CEO Jim Farley, focus on electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: The Ford Mustang Mach-E. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: US factory orders for March rebound on aircraft bookings
summary: US factory orders rebounded 0.9% in March, boosted by a 78.3% surge in civilian aircraft bookings. The rebound was short-lived, as the overall manufacturing industry continued to struggle under the weight of higher interest rates. Factory orders increased 2.4% on a year-over-year basis, but the sector accounts for only 11.3% of the economy. Economists attribute the decline to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and shifting spending towards services.

site_title: SVB’s US$7 billion municipal bond portfolio could pose challenge for liquidators
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) $7 billion municipal bond portfolio may pose a challenge for liquidators, including BlackRock, as investors remain wary of the bonds' low coupons and high risk of tax provision. The bonds, mostly long-dated with low coupons, have lost 15.6% in value last year and are still deep underwater, triggering a tax provision. BlackRock kicked off sales of the muni portfolio, starting with a $50 million sale of taxable securities, and may spread the sales over a two-week span.

site_title: Apple fights US$2 billion London lawsuit for 'throttling' millions of iPhones
summary: Apple is facing a US$2 billion lawsuit in a London tribunal, accusing the company of "throttling" millions of iPhones by limiting performance through software updates. Consumer champion Justin Gutmann claims Apple concealed issues with batteries in certain phone models and installed a power management tool to reduce performance. Apple urged the tribunal to block the lawsuit, arguing that it did not hide defective batteries. The case centers on iPhone models with the issue, but the exact models have not been specified.

images.alt_text: Apple is dismissing its suit against Gerard Williams III, who left his job as lead chip architect at Apple in 2019 and co-founded Nuvia.

site_title: UK regulator looks to simplify London listing rules
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has proposed simplifying London's listing rules to attract more companies and improve investor choice. The proposed changes aim to simplify the rulebook, making it more accessible for companies and reducing the burden of regulation. The FCA's goal is to rebalance the regulation to benefit listed companies and investors. The proposals will be consulted on until June and new IPO rules are expected to be published in late 2023 or early 2024.

images.alt_text: Tech and miners are the top two monthly decliners for April.

site_title: People are numb to big numbers
summary: A recent article highlights the issue of people being numb to big numbers, making it difficult to comprehend and understand large-scale information. The human brain is wired to struggle with numbers beyond a million, and politicians often use big numbers to impress rather than to convey meaningful information. To combat this, experts suggest making big numbers smaller by dividing them by population size or using percentages to provide context. Additionally, adding more numbers to provide context and comparison can also help. By making these adjustments, the public can better understand and engage with large-scale information, promoting more informed participatory democracy.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England in London. Photographer: Carlos Jasso/Bloomberg
The post-pandemic economy is like the Mona Lisa. Each time you look, you see something different.

site_title: Ford cuts prices of Mustang Mach-E after Tesla moves
summary: Ford Motor is cutting prices on its Mustang Mach-E electric vehicle by $3,000 or $4,000, depending on the version, after rival Tesla raised prices on its top-selling models. The move comes after the federal EV tax credit for the Mach-E fell in half to $3,750. Ford also plans to increase production in the second half of the year and expand the range for standard range battery models. The price cuts follow a 20% drop in US sales of the Mach-E in the first three months of the year.

site_title: Renaissance United no longer being investigated for role in 2013 penny stock crash
summary: Renaissance United, formerly Ipco International, has ended investigations by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) regarding its involvement in the 2013 penny stock crash. CAD confirmed that there are no ongoing investigations, and current directors are not being probed, following a request from the company. Ex-chief executive Quah Su-Ling and her accomplice John Soh Chee Wen were found guilty in December of masterminding the scheme, leading to significant market losses and convictions for some parties involved.

Renaissance United issues Q3 result warning due to gas shortages

site_title: Nurses urged to end strikes after UK unions accept pay deal
summary: The UK government's pay deal for health workers, including nurses, has been accepted by labour groups representing staff in the National Health Service (NHS). The 5% raise and additional bonus were accepted after a meeting of the NHS Staff Council. However, the Royal College of Nursing has vowed to ballot its 280,000 members for further strikes between June and December. Despite this, Health Secretary Steve Barclay hopes workers who rejected the offer will end their industrial action.

images.alt_text: Britain sought to end months of walk-outs in the healthcare sector by offering a 5 per cent wage increase for the coming year for 1 million nurses, paramedics, midwives and other workers in England.

site_title: Europe: Shares close at one-month low as oil stocks slide, Pearson plummets
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed at its lowest level in nearly a month, falling 1.2% as energy stocks plummeted 4.5% amid concerns about a US bond default and interest rate hikes. Pearson led media company falls, while HSBC Holdings gained 3.5% on better-than-expected quarterly profit. The European Central Bank is expected to hike interest rates by 25 basis points on Thursday, and investors are cautious ahead of the decision.

images.alt_text: Across the broader Singapore market, gainers outnumber losers 305 to 263 after 2.1 billion securities worth S$1.1 billion change hands.

site_title: Pakistan inflation hits record-high 36.42%
summary: Pakistan's inflation has reached a record-high of 36.42% in April, following the introduction of new taxes and fuel price hikes to meet IMF conditions. This is the highest-ever level of inflation in the country. Rising food prices and transport costs are affecting poor Pakistanis, with food prices up by nearly 50% and transport costs 57% higher. Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif is battling to revive the next tranche of a $6.5 billion loan deal, but analysts predict inflation will rise even after a deal is reached.

site_title: Reit managers, take note: General mandate to issue new units is least popular resolution at S-Reit AGMs
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit's manager lost its general mandate to issue new units at its AGM, with 57.86% of unitholders voting against the resolution. This trend is rare in Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits), where resolutions typically pass with high voting shares. The low unitholder support may indicate investors' skepticism about Reit managers' motivations, particularly in uncertain times. The general mandate allows managers to issue new units and make or grant convertible instruments without unitholder approval.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The manager's decision to spend S$20 million to enhance the Reit’s 1 Tuas Avenue 4 asset is among concerns flagged by activist investor Quarz.
The Reit manager is now unable to fundraise by issuing new units to support asset enhancement initiatives or have flexibility in capital management.

site_title: Tim Hortons, Burger King lift Restaurant Brands earnings
summary: Restaurant Brands International, the parent company of Tim Hortons and Burger King, reported a 75-cent-per-share earnings beat in the first quarter, driven by higher traffic and prices at Tim Hortons restaurants in Canada and Burger King's 12% global comparable sales growth. Despite Burger King's US struggles, the company's "Reclaim the Flame" turnaround plan may be working, with US comparable sales rising 8.7%. Total revenue rose to $1.59 billion, beating estimates of $1.56 billion.

site_title: Marriott beats Wall Street estimates on China recovery
summary: Marriott International reported a 34% revenue increase in its first quarter, beating Wall Street estimates, as China's travel demand recovered. The company's shares rose 3% following the announcement. Despite a worsening US economic outlook, Marriott's international revenue and solid booking trends boosted its full-year guidance for RevPAR. In China, RevPAR rebounded to 95% of pre-pandemic levels, with business and leisure segments recovering in line with each other. The company's CEO attributed the strong results to pent-up demand in the Asia Pacific region.

site_title: Neoliberalism’s final stronghold
summary: A recent essay in The Economist celebrates America's economic success, attributing it to its "astonishing record" and the principles of laissez-faire capitalism. The author argues that Americans should not blame the government for the economy's problems, instead, it is the market that giveth and taketh away. However, the essay's conclusion misrepresents US history, downplaying the role of a developmental state in addressing challenges like climate change and global warming. The author suggests that recognizing the scale and urgency of these challenges requires governments to act, rather than denying their ability to address them.

images.alt_text: Can anything be done to improve the world's ability to imagine a desirable future?
The perils of paradigm economics

site_title: US: Stocks fall as regional banking concerns return
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.1% to 33,684.46, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropping 1.2% and 1.1% respectively. Regional bank stocks plummeted ahead of an expected rate hike by the Federal Reserve, with the KBW Nasdaq Regional Banking Index falling over 5.5%. Shares in midsize banks such as PacWest and Western Alliance fell by nearly 28% and 15% respectively. Analysts say financial markets often move in a "big direction" before an interest rate decision.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Wall Street sign is pictured outside the New York Stock Exchange in New York, October 28, 2013. REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: Leadership changes at Mandarin Oriental, DFI Retail
summary: Mandarin Oriental announced that Laurent Kleitman will take over as group chief executive from James Riley on Sep 1, 2023. Kleitman, previously president and CEO of Parfums Christian Dior, will replace Riley, who will step down on Jul 31. Meanwhile, DFI Retail Group announced Scott Price as new group chief executive from Aug 1, 2023, replacing Ian McLeod.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Mandarin Oriental trims full-year loss to US$141.4m
The fall in sales in the grocery retail segment was primarily driven by the easing of movement restrictions in South-east Asia, said DFI Retail Group.

site_title: Police detain man after ‘shotgun cartridges’ thrown into Buckingham Palace
summary: A man was arrested in London after allegedly throwing suspected shotgun cartridges into the grounds of Buckingham Palace, just days before King Charles III's coronation. The incident occurred at around 7 pm on May 2, 2023, and a controlled explosion was conducted on a suspicious bag the man was carrying. The man was found to be armed with a knife and has been taken into police custody on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon. No injuries or shots were reported, and the palace's occupants were not present at the time of the incident.

images.alt_text: Oxford Street is decorated with British flags, ahead of the coronation of Britain's King Charles and Camilla, Queen Consort, in London, Britain.
During the ceremony, the glove is placed onto the right hand of the monarch during the ceremony as a reminder that the sovereign should exercise gentleness in raising taxes.

site_title: EU chief von der Leyen hails Infineon factory as chip production milestone for Europe
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen hailed the construction of Infineon's new factory in Dresden, Germany, as a milestone in mass chip production, marking a step towards Europe's goal of doubling its global chip production to 20% by 2030. The factory, which will quadruple current capacity, aims to reduce Europe's dependence on individual suppliers, particularly China, which holds a 76% share of silicon metal production. The EU has agreed a 43-billion-euro chip subsidies plan to secure supplies and strengthen supply chains.

site_title: Remove artificial barriers to allow transition finance to flourish: Adani CFO
summary: Adani Group's CFO, Robbie Singh, criticized European banks for lacking courage to fund energy transition projects that don't completely phase out coal. He argued that such projects, which can reduce coal usage, are ready to take off but face bankability issues due to coal involvement. Singh emphasized the need for a mechanism to transition to lower fossil fuel usage, saying it's essential for resolving bankability issues and addressing climate change. He also highlighted the importance of public finance in supporting the energy transition, particularly in countries like India.

images.alt_text: The criteria for qualifying coal projects were laid out in the second version of Asean taxonomy for sustainable finance, released by the Asean Taxonomy Board after the market closed on Monday (Mar 27).

(FILES) In this file photo taken on September 28, 2021 a smokestack of the Wujing Coal-Electricity Power Station spots smoke in Shanghai. - Long-term exposure to air pollution raises the risk of depression, according to a pair of new studies published in the JAMA network of scientific journals. A study published on February 10, 2023 in JAMA Network Open found that long-term exposure to elevated levels of air pollution increases the risk of late-onset depression among the elderly. (Photo by Hector RETAMAL / AFP)

Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the launch of NUS Sustainable and Green Finance Institute on Thursday (April 20) with Hsieh Fu Hua, chairman of NUS board of trustees, Professor Tan Eng Chye, NUS President and Professor Sumit Agarwal, managing director of the institute.
Avril de Torres (right) of the Center for Energy, Ecology and Development says the shift from loans to bonds is what facilitates continued fossil fuel investments.
The green transition is correctly being billed as a growth and jobs story. But if it entails a massive real appreciation, it can also destroy jobs.
A spokesperson for Standard Chartered says the London-based bank “isn’t involved in the financing” of the East Africa Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP) project.
FILE PHOTO: The Sinopec logo is seen at one of its gas stations in Hong Kong April 26, 2010.  REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo

site_title: Coinbase launches international exchange as tensions with US regulators grow
summary: Coinbase is launching an international derivatives exchange, Coinbase International Exchange, to diversify its business amid strained relations with US regulators. The platform, which received a licence from the Bermuda Monetary Authority, will list Bitcoin and Ether perpetual futures starting this week. The move comes after Coinbase received a Wells Notice from the US Securities and Exchange Commission, signaling a potential lawsuit. The exchange will cater to non-US institutional clients, with trading settled in USD Coin, and offers up to five times leverage. Coinbase remains committed to the US but criticizes its "regulation by enforcement" approach.

site_title: SGX and AWWA team up to engage children with autism
summary: SGX Cares and AWWA School @ Bedok collaborated on a sports activity for primary school-aged children with autism, marking the second year of their partnership. The event aimed to help students with autism develop recreational and social skills, while volunteers gained experience in interacting with individuals with differing abilities. The partnership, which includes the Lion City Sailors Women's Team, seeks to create positive social impact through resources and time. Both parties expressed interest in continuing the collaboration, believing it can benefit both students and volunteers.

site_title: MLT manager turns cautious on forex, interest rate impact
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) manager Ng Kiat expressed caution on the company's performance due to higher interest rate costs and foreign exchange fluctuations. Despite a 7.7% increase in gross revenue to S$730.6 million for FY22/23, the company warned of more uncertainty ahead. Ng highlighted the impact of forex losses and borrowing costs, which accounted for S$10 million of the gross revenue decline in Q4. The company's total debt stood at S$4.9 billion with an aggregate leverage ratio of 36.8%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Maybank Securities upgrades the real estate investment trust (Reit) to “buy” from “hold"
MLT's DPU for 4Q FY22/23 remained flat at S$0.02268.

site_title: Global sugar surplus shrinks to 1.1 million tons after poor harvest
summary: The global sugar market is expected to have a smaller supply surplus of 1.1 million tonnes in 2022/23, down from a March estimate of 2.5 million tonnes, due to poor harvests in India, Mexico, and the European Union. India's sugar production projection was cut to 32.8 million tonnes, with the country's new crop seen as stable at 32.5 million tonnes. The situation is expected to improve only slightly in the new season to a global supply surplus of 1.3 million tonnes.

images.alt_text: The market has also been driven higher by a lack of deliverable sugar ahead of the expiry of the May white-sugar contract on Friday (Apr 14).

site_title: Temasek refutes claim of US$10m investment into crypto company Array
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean investment company, has denied investing US$10 million in algorithmic currency system Array, contrary to a claim made by Array on its website. Temasek stated that the news is incorrect and they have no relationship with Array. An investigation by The Straits Times found no evidence of Temasek's involvement, and Yahoo News removed the press release from its platform after being approached by Temasek. The incident raises questions about the accuracy of information shared by companies and the need for verification.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit posts 11.1% positive rental reversion in Q1 2023
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit reported an 11.1% positive rental reversion in Q1 2023, with average rental rates increasing by 11.1% for leases renewed in the quarter. The Reit's portfolio occupancy fell to 94.4% and lease expiry is spread out, with 3.8 years remaining. Despite facing challenges from high interest rates and inflation, the Reit manager expects rental reversion to be in the positive mid-single-digit range for the full financial year.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Clar is divesting KA Place (above) for S$35.4 million, in line with its manager's proactive asset management strategy.
S-Reits lead Singapore stocks higher amid US recession fears; STI up 0.3%
Cromwell European Reit (CEReit) is a pure-play Pan-European Reit with light industrial/logistics and office assets.
Amid banking-led uncertainties, market watchers say S-Reits with strong sponsors are favoured to outperform their peers.

site_title: Aramco in talks with Sinopec and Total on US$10 billion Saudi gas deal
summary: Saudi Aramco is in talks with Sinopec and TotalEnergies to invest up to $10 billion in its Jafurah gas development in Saudi Arabia. The project, valued at over $100 billion, aims to exploit one of the world's largest untapped gas fields. The deal would help fund midstream and downstream projects, including the construction of facilities to export the fuel as liquefied natural gas. The talks are ongoing, with no final decisions made, and would mark a significant shift in Saudi Arabia's energy strategy, diversifying exports beyond oil.

images.alt_text: Oil demand is expected to be weak as several refiners in Asia, such as Sinopec, S-Oil, Fuji Oil and Idemitsu, have planned maintenance in May.

site_title: Hindenburg takes on billionaire Icahn with latest short position
summary: Research firm Hindenburg has taken a short position in Icahn Enterprises, a conglomerate controlled by billionaire Carl Icahn, alleging the company's valuation is inflated by over 75% and that it operates a "ponzi-like economic structure" to support dividend payouts. The company's shares fell 10% in premarket trading. Hindenburg claims Icahn is selling units to new investors to pay out dividends to old investors, a practice it describes as "using money from new investors to pay out dividends to old investors."

images.alt_text: The buyback would mark another effort by the Adani group to regain investor confidence, including trimming capital spending, after a Hindenburg Research report pounded its bonds and shares.

site_title: Many losers from 2022 financial turmoil still unknown: Norway wealth fund CEO
summary: Norway's $1.4 trillion sovereign wealth fund CEO, Nicolai Tangen, says many institutions still unknown have incurred significant losses from last year's global financial market turmoil. The fund, which owns 1.5% of all globally listed shares, has yet to disclose the identities of institutions that suffered losses. Tangen notes that financial markets lost $30 trillion in value in 2022, and losses will "pop up" despite his skepticism about a new financial crisis. The fund has stress-tested its portfolio against various scenarios, including a 40% loss due to an unspecified geopolitical event.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the building of Norway’s central bank (Norges Bank) in Oslo, Norway, June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Victoria Klesty/File Photo

site_title: Sinopec strikes oil and gas at extra-deep well in China's Tarim basin
summary: Sinopec, a Chinese state oil major, announced that its Shunbei-10X well in the Tarim basin has struck a daily oil and gas flow of 600,000 cubic meters, exceeding 8,000 meters in depth. This marks the 50th well to achieve this milestone, with an average well depth of over 7,300 meters, making it one of the world's deepest oil and gas fields being commercially developed.

site_title: India's Go First Airways files for insolvency, blames Pratt & Whitney engines
summary: Indian airline Go First Airways filed for insolvency on May 2, 2023, citing Pratt & Whitney engines as the reason for grounding about half its fleet. The airline blamed Pratt & Whitney for refusing to release engines that would have allowed it to return to full operations. This marks the first major airline collapse in India since Jet Airways filed for bankruptcy in 2019, highlighting the intense competition in the sector.

images.alt_text: The International Civil Aviation Organization expects passenger demand to recover to pre-Covid levels on most routes this quarter and then to about 3 per cent higher than 2019 levels by year-end.

site_title: Fifa threatens TV blackout for Women’s World Cup in Europe
summary: FIFA is threatening to not televise the Women's World Cup in five major European countries, including Italy, Germany, France, the UK, and Spain, unless broadcasters pay more for media rights. FIFA President Gianni Infantino stated that the current offers from broadcasters in the "Big 5" European nations are "disappointing and not acceptable." The tournament, being held in Australia and New Zealand, requires universal access, and FIFA aims to reinvest revenue in women's football. Despite women's football gaining popularity, broadcast payments for the women's games are significantly lower than for the men's games.

site_title: UK luxury watchmaker Bremont finds CEO in exec who relaunched Tudor
summary: Bremont, the UK luxury watchmaker backed by billionaire Bill Ackman, has appointed Davide Cerrato as its new CEO. Cerrato, credited with relaunching Tudor's Black Bay, will join the board and oversee the brand's growth ambitions. The move aims to bolster Bremont's competitiveness in the Swiss watch industry and revive UK watchmaking. Bremont, which produces around 10,000 watches a year, is currently unprofitable but has secured a £48.4 million investment to expand its US market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has reported that financing the infrastructure gap has become more challenging due to rising debt levels, declining tax revenues, and increased public spending. The ADB advises ASEAN governments to aim for a "double-digit" return on private and institutional sector financing for every public dollar invested in infrastructure development. Meanwhile, Singapore's OCBC Bank and RHB Banking Group have entered into sustainability-linked loan and swap transactions. Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Tuesday, tracking regional gains, while DBS posted a 43% rise in Q1 profit to a record S$2.6 billion.

site_title: Sweden’s housing downturn deepens, with more declines forecast
summary: Sweden's housing market experienced a 1% decline in April, led by a drop in detached house values, according to data by SBAB Bank. This follows a 0.8% decline in March and marks one of the world's worst housing downturns. The Riksbank's recent interest-rate hike is expected to further fuel the decline, with mortgage costs rising and potentially leading to a 16% average decline in detached house values. The housing market weakness weighs on the Swedish economy, particularly the construction sector, which contributes 11% of the country's economic output.

site_title: BT Explains: Why the latest property cooling measures may not lower new home prices
summary: Singapore has introduced higher additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rates for residential properties, effective April 27, in an effort to dampen investment demand and curb housing prices. The new rates include a 20% increase for Singapore citizens buying their second property, a 30% increase for their third and subsequent properties, and a doubling of the foreigner rate to 60%. However, property analysts suggest that the measures may not be effective in lowering new home prices, as developers could counter by regulating supply and withholding properties from the market.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
For Singapore citizens, ABSD will be raised to 20 per cent from 17 per cent for the purchase of their second property, and to 30 per cent from 25 per cent for their third and subsequent properties.

Minister for National Development speaking to reporters on Thursday (Apr 27) at HDB MyLearningSpace after the Singapore government announced on Wednesday that it will be stepping up ABSD rates for residential properties, in fresh cooling measures.
ABSD rate will be raised from 30% to 35% for SPRs purchasing their 3rd and subsequent residential property;
The Singapore government first started enacting property cooling measures in 1996.

site_title: Pfizer beats profit estimates on demand for new drugs, Covid products
summary: Pfizer reported a stronger-than-expected first-quarter profit, driven by high demand for its newly acquired drugs and steady sales of Covid-19 products. The company's Covid-19 vaccine and antiviral treatment sales exceeded estimates, with Comirnaty and Paxlovid generating $3.06 billion and $4.07 billion, respectively. However, Pfizer expects lower sales contributions from Covid products in the second quarter. The company reaffirmed its annual profit forecast and maintained its annual Covid products revenue forecast of $21.5 billion. Its shares rose nearly 3% before the bell.

site_title: Dubai reprimands Three Arrows founders over new crypto project
summary: Dubai's Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority (Vara) issued a written reprimand to Su Zhu and Kyle Davies, co-founders of Three Arrows Capital, and the co-founders and CEO of OPNX, for operating and promoting their digital-asset exchange without a required local licence. Vara will continue to investigate OPNX's activity, taking a stricter approach towards crypto in the emirate. The reprimand follows a cease and desist order and a second notice from Vara in February, with OPNX launching despite the warnings.

site_title: Stagflation risk eludes investors, threatens to expose market mispricings
summary: Investors are bracing for a potential "stagflation-lite" scenario, characterized by slowing economic growth and persistent inflation, which could dash hopes for a pause in the Fed's rate hikes and expose market mispricings. The risk of stagflation has grown due to a slowing economy, with the Bureau of Economic Analysis reporting a 1.1% annualized GDP growth rate in the first quarter, and a Fed-preferred core inflation gauge reaching 4.9%. As a result, investors are turning to safe-haven assets like gold, high-quality bonds, and companies with pricing power, while hedge funds are betting against US stocks and Treasuries.

images.alt_text: We are walking into a world unlike any we have seen, and there is a possibility that economists won't be able to turn things around.

FILE PHOTO: Marked ingots of 99.99 percent pure gold are placed in a cart at the Krastsvetmet non-ferrous metals plant in the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, Russia March 10, 2022. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk/File Photo

site_title: Singapore Savings Bond interest rate curve flattens further; 10-year average return at 2.81%
summary: Singapore's latest tranche of Savings Bonds (SSB) offers a first-year interest rate of 2.81% and a 10-year average return of 2.81%. This is a decrease from the May issuance, which had a first-year interest rate of 3.03% and a 10-year average return of 3.07%. The SSB interest rate curve has flattened further, following a decline in investor interest. The SSB issuance, which includes S$700 million, closes on May 26 and will be allotted on May 29.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Demand for the latest six-month T-bill and Singapore Savings Bond fell, according to data released on Wednesday.

The image of Yusof Ishak, former president of Singapore, is displayed on various denominations of Singapore dollar banknotes in an arranged photograph in Bangkok, Thailand, on Friday, Sept. 18, 2015. Singapore's challenge is to find a way to keep its economy energized and sustainable for the next 10 to 15 years, with low single-digit growth expected to be considered a good performance in the future, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Saturday. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

Recently released statistics from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) showed the overall non-bank loan-to-deposit ratio had fallen to 73.3 per cent in February 2023, from 81.2 per cent in February 2022.
The big question now is how much longer it will take the Fed and other major central banks to get inflation under control

site_title: Credit Suisse AT1 bondholders who lost US$1.7 billion in UBS deal file lawsuits
summary: Credit Suisse AT1 bondholders who lost $1.7 billion in a government-brokered takeover by UBS have filed lawsuits against Switzerland's banking regulator, Finma. Law firm Pallas Partners claims the regulator had no right to order the writedown and is seeking full compensation for its clients. This lawsuit is the latest in a series of claims from investors who represent over a third of the $17 billion in AT1 bonds issued by Credit Suisse, with some seeking up to five cents on the euro in recent weeks.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Saudi National Bank (SNB) can be seen at the banks' headquarters in Riyadh on March 27, 2023, after the chairman of SNB, the main shareholder of troubled lender Credit Suisse which was bought out this month, resigned. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)
UBS reappointed Sergio Ermotti as CEO in April to oversee the historic acquisition of Credit Suisse after its rival collapsed.

Credit Suisse, in consultation with UBS, has identified a list of employees seen as crucial to both preserving businesses until the deal is done, but also for a smooth combination once they are able to begin integration.

site_title: Thomson Reuters reports higher first-quarter sales, profit
summary: Thomson Reuters reported higher sales and operating profit in the first quarter, driven by divestitures and high customer retention rates. The company's adjusted earnings were 82 cents per share, beating expectations. Total revenue rose 4% to $1.738 billion, with organic revenue up 7% in its "Big 3" segments. Thomson Reuters reaffirmed its full-year financial forecasts, but trimmed its revenue growth forecast to 3-3.5% due to elevated macroeconomic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Thomson Reuters logo is seen on the company building in Times Square, New York October 29, 2013.    REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: Core inflation slows in eurozone, supporting smaller ECB rate hike
summary: The eurozone's core inflation rate slowed to 5.6% in April, down from 5.7% in March, supporting a smaller interest rate hike by the European Central Bank (ECB). Headline inflation rose to 7%, still above the 2% target, but the decrease in core inflation suggests policymakers may opt for a quarter-point rate hike instead of the previously considered half-point. The ECB has been focusing on underlying pressures, driven by robust demand for services and profit margins, as it seeks to curb the eurozone's severe bout of inflation.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank vice-president Luis de Guindos on Wednesday (Apr 26) said: "Growth in the first quarter of the year, according to the leading indicators, is going to be possible."

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on debt ceiling jitters
summary: US stocks opened lower on May 2, 2023, amid concerns over the US government's debt ceiling. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that the US could run out of money within a month. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 34.08 points, or 0.10%, to 34,017.62. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 opening 3.77 points lower, or 0.09%, to 4,164.10, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 14.58 points, or 0.12%, to 12,198.02.

site_title: Samsung bans use of ChatGPT for mobile, appliances staff
summary: Samsung Electronics has banned employees in its mobile and appliances division from using generative AI services like ChatGPT due to instances of "misuse." The ban applies to company-owned computers and advises staff to refrain from uploading work-related information to such platforms when using personal computers outside the premises. The move comes after a global trend of major financial firms and companies restricting employee use of ChatGPT-like platforms due to data collection and processing concerns. Samsung aims to find alternative, secure ways to utilize generative AI services in the future.

images.alt_text: A Samsung flag flutters outside the company's Seocho building in Seoul on April 27, 2023. - Samsung Electronics on April 27, reported its worst quarterly profits in 14 years, blaming slowing consumer spending on electronics and a global microchip glut that hit its core memory business. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks track regional gains on Tuesday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Tuesday, tracking regional gains, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,281.99. Local banks OCBC, DBS, and UOB led the gains, while Thai Beverage fell 2.3%. The market saw 2.1 billion securities worth S$1.1 billion traded, with Seatrium gaining 4.8% after 731 million shares were traded. Traders are focusing on macro events, particularly the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate decision on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.1 per cent lower at 34,051.70 on Monday.

site_title: Pouring good oil on bad banks
summary: The US banking sector is experiencing a fragile state due to interest rate pressure, with poorly managed banks reeling from the effects. Despite the decline in oil prices since mid-2022, inflation remains a concern. The Federal Reserve's tightening of monetary policy is exacerbating the issue, with the collapses of Silicon Valley Bank and First Republic Bank serving as cautionary tales. The US banking sector's fragility is a unique response to domestic factors, and while it may have some international implications, the global impact is limited.

images.alt_text: The gold trading chart suggests more interest rate rises are to come, along with an economic slowdown.

site_title: UK factory activity shrinks in April but cost pressures ease: PMI
summary: The UK manufacturing sector contracted in April, with the S&P Global/CIPS UK manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 47.8, its lowest in three months. Output and new orders declined, but input costs rose at the weakest rate since May 2020, indicating easing cost pressures. Despite this, manufacturers remain cautious due to client uncertainty and a worsening export trend, with 61% expecting production to rise in the coming year.

images.alt_text: Soaring inflation and interest rates have strained affordability of new homes, but a lack of supply of properties coming to market has helped keep prices buoyant.
It was only the second month of cooling shop price inflation since the start of 2022.

Shoppers and red London buses on Oxford Street in central London, UK, on Thursday, Feb. 16, 2023. The UK’s inflation rate slowed for a third month but remained stubbornly in double digits five times above the Bank of England’s targeted level. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

site_title: UK shop price inflation cools for first time in 2023: BRC
summary: UK shop price inflation cooled to 8.8% in April, marking the first time in 2023, due to heavy discounting on clothing and furniture. However, grocery prices rose to a fresh all-time high of 15.7% as ready meals and fresh produce became more expensive. Retailers expect food prices to decrease in the coming months, easing pricing pressure. This development may influence the Bank of England's decision on further interest rate increases to curb inflation.

images.alt_text: Shoppers and red London buses on Oxford Street in central London, UK, on Thursday, Feb. 16, 2023. The UK’s inflation rate slowed for a third month but remained stubbornly in double digits five times above the Bank of England’s targeted level. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan, South Korea revive stalled economic talks as global risks grow
summary: Japan and South Korea have revived stalled economic talks, agreeing to resume regular dialogue amid growing global risks. The resumption comes ahead of Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's visit to South Korea for talks with President Yoon Suk Yeol. The talks aim to increase cooperation and mend strained relations as policymakers discuss regional economic challenges and buffers against various shocks. The move is seen as a positive step to address slowing growth and tensions in the region.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is said to be visiting South Korea before he hosts a G7 summit from May 19.

site_title: Uber confident on profit as ride-sharing makes strong start to 2023
summary: Uber reports strong start to 2023, with Q1 revenue jumping 29% to $8.83 billion, beating estimates, driven by a 72% growth in ride-hailing. The company expects adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) in the range of $800 million to $850 million, higher than analysts' projection. Gross bookings are forecast between $33 billion and $34 billion. The ride-sharing giant attributes its success to its dominant position in key global markets and a surge in demand for travel and food delivery.

images.alt_text: Uber launched the freight division in 2017, pairing trucking companies with those seeking to transport loads in a similar model to the company’s ride-hailing business.

site_title: Space rivals join up to bid for EU’s US$6.6 billion satellite plan
summary: European satellite companies Airbus, Thales Alenia Space, Eutelsat Communications, SES, and Hispasat have formed a consortium to bid for the EU's $6.6 billion Iris² satellite project, aiming to beam internet across the continent. The project, set to start providing service in 2024, will include hundreds of satellites in multiple orbits, providing critical infrastructure and reinforcing the EU's technological sovereignty. The consortium, led by Airbus and Thales Alenia Space, will work with telecom companies to deliver the project, which is seen as a key step in the EU's efforts to compete with other countries and private companies in the space industry.

images.alt_text: EU looks to drones, space communication to get ahead in tech race

site_title: High ambitions on show at Singapore Maritime Week
summary: Singapore Maritime Week 2023 showcased ambition and action in the maritime industry, focusing on decarbonization, digitalization, and talent attraction.
