images.alt_text: The "Longest Putt to LIV Golf" challenge is now on at Resorts World Sentosa, where fans can putt on this 32-metre surface.

Golf - The Masters - Augusta National Golf Club - Augusta, Georgia, U.S. - April 6, 2023
Spain's Sergio Garcia hits his tee shot on the 10th hole during the first round REUTERS/Mike Blake

The arbitration panel concluded the players had committed “serious breaches of the code of behaviour of the DPWT regulations” by playing in LIV’s London and Portland events, despite their release requests having been refused.

site_title: Wanted: More skills for workers as green jobs grow
summary: The global economy is shifting towards a green economy, driven by the need to reduce climate change and nature loss. However, a lack of skills in key sectors such as agriculture, forestry, infrastructure, and energy hinders progress. Experts estimate that tens of millions of green jobs can be created this decade with the right policies and investments. The field of green jobs is broader than commonly perceived, with skills such as solar consultant, sustainability manager, and wind turbine technician in demand. To address the gap, governments, companies, and educational institutions must prioritize training for the green workforce, particularly women and those in developing countries.

images.alt_text: Lego, which will explore using e-methanol in some types of its building bricks and aims to bring new prototype bricks to the market in the future.

site_title: Singapore’s market cap down 0.5% in April amid slowing global growth
summary: Singapore's market capitalization fell 0.5% in April to S$814.8 billion, driven by slowing global growth and rising interest rates. The finance sector was the biggest loser, with UOB and DBS experiencing declines of S$2.6 billion and S$464.7 million, respectively. The manufacturing sector also declined, led by electric vehicle maker Nio and agribusiness group Wilmar International. The real estate investment trust sector was a notable gainer, with its market cap rising S$800 million to S$64.3 billion. Experts expect the Singapore market to struggle to find direction due to uncertainty over interest rate hikes and economic growth outlook.

images.alt_text: SGX centre along Shenton Way. For stories xon finance, share market, stocks, economy, shares, finance, Singapore.
Tan Nai Lun

site_title: China reopening party over as emerging markets slip back to void
summary: Emerging markets have experienced significant losses, with the MSCI Emerging Markets Index down 7% since January, driven largely by China's stock market decline. Despite China's economy expanding faster than forecast, investors remain skeptical due to idiosyncratic risks, including its stance on Taiwan and regulation of the private sector. The MSCI World Index of developed-market equities is up 4 times more, leading to a 5.6% decline in the emerging markets-to-rich nations ratio this year.

images.alt_text: The MSCI China is trading at about 10.1 times forward earnings – 10 per cent cheaper than averages going back two decades.

site_title: Amid rising protectionism, Singapore must refresh, strengthen compact with workers: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warned Singapore must refresh and strengthen its social compact with workers amid rising protectionism in trade and investment. Advanced economies are rolling out massive subsidies to build domestic production in strategic industries, making competition tougher for Singapore. To counter this, Wong emphasized the need for ingenuity and innovation, investing in connectivity infrastructure, and deepening capabilities for innovation. The government will also focus on addressing inequality and supporting workers in vocational and technical roles, as well as those who lose their jobs. Wong highlighted Singapore's tripartite structure as a strength, but acknowledged the need for continuous improvement.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
One new initiative in response to feedback is a "career trial" intiative, details of which NTUC secretary general Ng Chee Meng earlier shared with the media.
Singapore must adapt to the changing economic environment and support those who are affected, says PM Lee.

site_title: India’s private equity, venture capital investments cross US$60b mark for third year in a row
summary: India's private equity and venture capital investments reached a record $61.6 billion in 2022, marking the third consecutive year to exceed $60 billion. Despite a funding winter, smaller and mid-sized deals drove the growth, with over 2,000 deals made last year. Analysts attribute the slowdown to rising interest rates, inflation, and geopolitical conflicts affecting IPOs. Startups are exploring alternative funding options, such as credit investments and asset-based financing, to manage working capital requirements. Experts expect a shift in deal flow, with a focus on portfolio company profitability, and predict a return to late-stage funding in the second half of this year.

images.alt_text: Clement Schwebig, president for India, South-east Asia and Korea for Warner Bros said the agreement was part of its commitment to the South Asia market, as it looks to further strengthen the scale of its regional business.
Freddy Ong , head, Client Coverage, Singapore, Corporate, Commercial & Institutional Banking, Standard Chartered.

site_title: Super Mario is year’s first film to pass US$1 billion globally
summary: Super Mario has become the year's first film to surpass US$1 billion globally, with an estimated US$1.02 billion in worldwide earnings. The video game-based film held its first-place position on North American movie screens, earning an estimated US$40 million for the Friday-through-Sunday period in the US and Canada. The film's domestic total now stands at US$490 million, while its overseas earnings total US$532 million.

images.alt_text: "The Super Mario Bros. Movie" ranks as the year’s top movie so far, taking in an accumulated US$434.3 million domestically and US$437 million internationally.

site_title: China new home prices up slightly in April; fewer cities post gains: survey
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.02% in April, marking a slight extension of modest gains seen in March, according to a private survey. This represents a decrease in cities posting gains, with 30 cities reporting increases compared to 41 in March. The government has pledged to support housing demand, ensure home delivery, and promote stable property market development. The property sector, accounting for a quarter of China's economy, was severely impacted last year due to unfinished projects and mortgage boycotts. Consumer confidence remains fickle despite recent sales rebounds in major cities.

site_title: Leading Thai opposition PM candidate gives birth two weeks from polling day
summary: Thai opposition Prime Minister candidate Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of billionaire former leader Thaksin Shinawatra, gave birth to a baby boy two weeks before the May 14 general election. Despite her health, she is expected to attend Pheu Thai's final rally in Bangkok on May 12. Thaksin, who lives in Dubai to avoid corruption charges, has promised to return to care for his seventh grandchild. Paetongtarn's health status and her participation in the election are unclear, but her party is still polling strongly ahead of the election.

images.alt_text: Pheu Thai supporters attending an election campaign rally in Bangkok last week; the party has won the backing of 41.37 per cent of roughly 162,000 eligible voters surveyed.

site_title: NTUC must scale up, do more for underserved workers and innovate: Ng Chee Meng
summary: NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng emphasized the need for the labour movement to scale up existing initiatives, prioritize underserved worker segments, and foster a culture of innovation. The NTUC has engaged over 40,000 workers in the #EveryWorkerMatters Conversation, sharing key findings with tripartite partners to co-create an economically vibrant and inclusive Singapore. Ng highlighted the need to expand company training committees, better support young workers, and drive industry transformation through innovation, aiming to achieve 2,500 CTCs by 2025 and 1,000 Career Starter Lab pilots.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Mar 02, 2023. site_title: Navigating an uncertain world
summary: Business leaders worldwide face a "polycrisis" of geopolitical and macroeconomic pressures, making it impossible to plan for a single high-probability scenario. Executives must navigate uncertainty by considering multiple, interconnected crises, such as inflation, recession, and the energy transition. To adapt, leaders should focus on long-term themes and opportunities, rather than trying to isolate the impact of individual crises. This requires a more holistic approach to leadership, prioritizing flexibility and resilience in the face of extreme uncertainty. Authentic leadership is key to thriving in such complex environments.

site_title: US debt ceiling: Playing chicken games again?
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a bill raising the $31.4 trillion borrowing limit, passing 217-215 with all Democrats opposing and four Republicans voting against it. This vote, seen as a victory for new House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, averts concern about a US financial default and reduces uncertainty in the markets.

US Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy after the House passed the debt limit bill at the Capitol in Washington on April 26, 2023.

site_title: Asia: Stocks to rise as earnings outweigh bank woes
summary: Asia's stocks are poised to rise on Monday as robust corporate earnings boosted Wall Street, despite concerns over First Republic Bank's future. US stocks rose 0.8% on Friday, with the S&P 500 posting back-to-back monthly gains for the first time in five months. Regulators have asked banks to submit bids for First Republic Bank by Sunday, with the US authorities having the option to take ownership if none materialize. The Federal Reserve is expected to increase borrowing costs 25 basis points this week, while the European Central Bank and Reserve Bank of Australia are also expected to raise interest rates.

images.alt_text: China’s blue-chip CSI300 Index closed up 1 per cent, while the Shanghai Composite Index finished 1.1 per cent higher.

site_title: Thailand parties’ populist policies pit fiscal stimuli against economic stability
summary: Thailand's general election on May 14 will feature populist policies, raising concerns about fiscal stability. The Pheu Thai Party, led by Srettha Thavisin, has proposed a 10,000 baht monthly stipend for citizens aged 16 and above, requiring a massive 560 billion baht budget. Economists question the scheme's sustainability, citing Thailand's already high public debt and need for fiscal stability. Experts argue that stimulus measures won't reverse the country's declining competitiveness and aging population. The Election Commission may disband the Pheu Thai Party if it fails to disclose the budget source, sparking debate on stimulus versus welfare schemes.

images.alt_text: Economic activity is expected to have improved in April and exports should gradually get better along with a recovery in the economies of trading partners, the Bank of Thailand (BOT) said in a statement.
Bonds from sovereign and quasi sovereign names, such as Indofood and Pertamina, have seen greater investor interest.
“Despite the export fall, it’s still considered very good,” Poonpong Naiyanapakorn, head of the ministry’s Trade Policy and Strategy Office, told a news conference.
Exports, a key driver of Thai growth, are expected to drop 0.5 per cent this year.

site_title: Japan's Astellas to buy Iveric Bio for US$5.9 billion to expand eyesight treatments
summary: Astellas Pharma agreed to buy US-based Iveric Bio for $5.9 billion, gaining access to ophthalmology treatments for 160 million people worldwide, particularly in Japan's aging population. Iveric's key asset, avacincaptad pegol (ACP), is in trials for treating geographic atrophy, a common cause of vision loss. The deal, Astellas' second-largest cross-border acquisition in five years, will fund via short-term loans and commercial paper, and is expected to bolster Astellas' pipeline as its main sellers lose patent protection.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Astellas Pharma's logo is pictured at its headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, December 3, 2019.   REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: Manila airport cancels 40 domestic flights after power outage
summary: Manila's Ninoy Aquino International Airport has canceled 40 domestic Cebu Pacific flights due to an unexplained power outage at Terminal 3. The airport's standby power systems enabled partial functioning of airline and immigration computers, allowing for processing of passengers. Cebu Pacific has offered passengers departing from or to Terminal 3 the option to rebook or request refunds to be put in a travel fund for future use. The cause of the power failure remains unknown.

site_title: Bitcoin sags after its longest streak of monthly gains since 2021
summary: Bitcoin's 73% rebound from last year's crypto rout stalled around the US$30,000 level, marking the end of its four-month winning streak since April. The token slid 3.2% and was trading at US$28,580. Traders await further catalysts, including a potential Federal Reserve pivot to looser monetary policy, as the rally was fueled by bets on the erosion of confidence in fiat currency. The decline follows a year of significant gains for Bitcoin.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin could gain from factors including recent turmoil in the banking sector, a stabilisation of risk assets as the US Federal Reserve ends its interest rate-hiking cycle and improved profitability of crypto mining, says Standard Chartered’s Geoff Kendrick.

site_title: Global Palm Resources privatisation offer closes with 93.1% valid acceptances
summary: Global Palm Resources' voluntary unconditional cash offer closed on May 31 with 93.1% of shares accepted, allowing the offeror to compulsorily acquire dissenting shareholders and delist the company. The offeror, led by Suparno Adijanto, received S$0.25 per share for all issued shares. Minority shareholders had initially rejected the offer, citing it as "clearly wholly unsatisfactory," but the offeror is now entitled to acquire the remaining shares.

site_title: Can sales commissions of agents be squeezed to benefit consumers?
summary: Singapore's largest real estate agency, PropNex, posted a 7.5% increase in revenue and 3.9% increase in net profit for 2022, with a return on equity of nearly 50%. The company's success has led to a question about the potential cost savings for consumers if they relied less on real estate agents. With PropNex's high profit margins, some argue that consumers could benefit from reduced commission fees, but the article does not provide a conclusive answer to this question.

site_title: Chinese tourists flock to gambling hub Macau for Labour Day holiday
summary: Macau, the world's biggest gambling hub, experienced a surge in visitors from mainland China for the Labour Day holiday, with over 100,000 visitors arriving daily, up from 60,000 previously. The relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions in January allowed visitors to return to Macau for the first time in over three years. The city is now the top destination for Chinese travelers in Asia, with bookings up 11% from pre-pandemic levels in 2019. The influx of visitors is expected to reach 90% hotel occupancy, with some hotels fully booked, as the city aims to diversify its economy beyond casinos.

images.alt_text: The UAE, whose population is 90 per cent foreign, has made a series of liberalising moves as it faces increased regional competition for talent and tourism, notably from neighbouring Saudi Arabia and Qatar.
With China just emerging, they are looking for safe destinations to service their hospitality needs, and Singapore can do that very well," says MBS chief operating officer Paul Town.

site_title: SIA investing to up its game; to offer free unlimited inflight Wi-Fi to all KrisFlyer members
summary: Singapore Airlines is investing to enhance customer experience with free unlimited inflight Wi-Fi for KrisFlyer members in economy and premium economy classes starting July. The move follows the restoration of appetizers in economy class and heavier main courses. CEO Goh Choon Phong emphasized that these investments are aimed at improving customer experience, despite potential increased costs. The airline's budget for inflight meals is 20% higher than pre-pandemic levels, but Goh noted that the focus is on maintaining customer satisfaction rather than cutting costs.

site_title: Gold slips on firmer greenback as focus turns to Fed meet
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,986.15 per ounce on May 1, as the US dollar strengthened and traders awaited the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The meeting, scheduled for May 2-3, is expected to see a 89.1% chance of a 25 basis point interest rate hike, which tends to dull the appeal of gold as an inflation hedge. Spot silver and platinum also declined, while palladium inched lower. The dollar index rose 0.1%, making gold more expensive for overseas buyers.

site_title: DBS donates S$3.5 million to Esplanade
summary: DBS Bank donated S$3.5 million to Esplanade, supporting its free Outdoor Theatre programmes for five years. The bank's "DBS Perspectives @ Esplanade" series will bring diverse community segments together to explore societal themes, starting May 3. The partnership aims to uplift the community and promote inclusivity, aligning with DBS's common vision. The Esplanade's Outdoor Theatre has become a key part of Singapore's civic life, providing opportunities for artists and community engagement.

Guest of Honour Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam described the fund as having a “simple but powerful (idea), about partnerships”.

site_title: AI kingpins have global rulemakers over a barrel
summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has threatened to "cease operating" in European markets if the European Commission's proposed AI Act is implemented, citing potential regulatory costs. The AI kingpin's comments have been met with criticism, with European Commissioner Thierry Breton calling them "blackmail." Altman's comments come as ChatGPT, OpenAI's revolutionary technology, has become widely adopted, with 44% of US workers using it in their workplaces. The potential economic impact of shutting down the technology is significant, with a global economic boost estimated at $15.7 trillion.

images.alt_text: In March, more than 1,100 industry leaders advocated for a six-month pause on training powerful AI models.
“Agile companies will take advantage of AI and boost their position. Companies less so will perish,” the Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang says.

site_title: ChatGPT’s riskiness splits Biden administration on EU AI rules
summary: The Biden administration is divided on how to regulate artificial intelligence (AI) tools, with some officials supporting the European Union's plan to subject generative AI to additional rules, while others argue that aggressive regulation could put the US at a competitive disadvantage. The EU's proposed rules would require developers to document copyrighted material used to train AI products and track how that information is used. The US is unlikely to pass binding rules, leaving the EU as the first to dictate how tech giants develop foundation models that underpin the next frontier of AI.

images.alt_text: In March, more than 1,100 industry leaders advocated for a six-month pause on training powerful AI models.

site_title: What's in wine? Campaigners want ingredients on the bottle
summary: The European Union has introduced new rules requiring wine producers to reveal their ingredients, but the labels will be linked to a website via QR codes, not printed on the bottles. The wine industry has opted for this method, citing the need for flexibility and automatic translation into all EU languages. Environmental campaigners, such as the Transparency for Organic World Association, are opposed, arguing that QR codes are unworkable and do not provide sufficient transparency. The new rules come into effect on December 8, and organic and natural winemakers are warning consumers to avoid wines that require QR codes.

images.alt_text: Since 2003, the top winemakers have learned what to do and not do in hot, dry conditions. For example, planting cover crops between the vine rows, which you now see all over Bordeaux, trains roots to go deep to obtain water.

site_title: Singapore stocks’ market cap down 2.8% in May on global macro uncertainty
summary: Singapore's total market capitalization fell 2.8% in May, reaching S$792 billion, amid global macroeconomic uncertainty. The Straits Times Index (STI) also declined 2.9% to S$523.8 billion. Flag carrier Singapore Airlines (SIA) booked the biggest gain in value, adding S$1.7 billion, while top decliners included DBS and OCBC. Analysts expect the STI to hold at 3,180 points over the next few months, citing a possible rebound in June or July.

site_title: Warren Buffett will beat the market in recession times, say investors
summary: Investors believe Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway will outperform the US market, especially during a recession, with 67% of respondents expecting a return of 10% or more. Over half of 352 respondents are confident the company's returns will beat the S&P 500 Index over the next five years, citing a "Buffett premium" embedded in its shares. This confidence comes ahead of Berkshire's shareholder meeting, which is seen as a significant indicator of the company's future performance.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc

site_title: Temasek cuts employee compensation after failed FTX investment
summary: Temasek, a Singaporean investment firm, has cut the compensation of its senior management and investment team involved in a failed US$275 million investment in cryptocurrency exchange FTX. The move comes after an internal review found no misconduct in the investment team's decision-making process, but the firm took collective accountability for the reputational damage suffered by Temasek. The investment was made in 2021 and 2022, with Temasek holding a 1.5% stake in FTX. The firm aims to strengthen its investment evaluation process and enhance due diligence on founders and management teams.

images.alt_text: FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried speaks at the Crypto Bahamas conference in Nassau on April 27, 2022. FTX's collapse has left an estimated 1 million creditors facing losses totaling billions of dollars.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo and decreasing stock graph in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said Sam Bankman-Fried stole billions of dollars in FTX customer funds to plug losses at Alameda, buy real estate, and make political contributions through an illegal straw-donor scheme. They have also charged him with bribing Chinese officials.
Technology like these food dispensers are what eFishery offers to fish and shrimp farmers in Indonesia.
Temasek fully owns Singapore Technologies Telemedia, the parent of STT GDC.
The potential deal could boost BlueStone’s plans to expand aggressively in India, the second-largest jewellery consuming nation behind China, as demand surges after the pandemic.
The Temasek logo at the Temasek Holdings office at The Atrium@Orchard on 9 February 2021.

site_title: Cortina posts 11% fall in H2 net profit; proposes 16-cent dividend
summary: Cortina, a luxury watch retailer, reported an 11% fall in its H2 net profit to S$38.6 million due to a one-off write-back. Revenue rose 7% to S$419.7 million, driven by a better sales mix and new brand introductions. The company proposed a final dividend of 2 cents and a special dividend of 14 cents per share. Despite a challenging global economic outlook, Cortina expects to remain profitable in the coming year, barring unforeseen circumstances.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Analysts expect that small-cap property plays such as Propnex could do well in 2023.

site_title: Oil extends second weekly drop on new China recovery concerns
summary: Oil prices extended a two-week decline as concerns about China's economic recovery reignited. West Texas Intermediate futures fell 0.7% after China's manufacturing activity unexpectedly contracted in April. This data raised concerns about a patchy recovery in the world's largest crude importer, leading hedge funds and money managers to turn bearish on crude. Despite a rally in US company earnings on Friday, the losses continued, with prices swinging sharply in April.

site_title: UK Labour vows to restore housing targets to boost homeownership
summary: Labour Party leader Keir Starmer vowed to restore UK's mandatory home-building targets to 300,000 new houses per year to boost homeownership to 70%. A Labour government would give local authorities more power to build new homes, prioritizing first-time buyers in their areas. This comes as the Conservative government dropped mandatory targets in December. National elections are set to take place before January 2025, with Labour leading in polls, and could make gains in local elections.

site_title: South Korea detains passenger after Asiana plane door opened mid-air
summary: South Korean authorities detained a man after he opened a door of an Asiana Airlines Airbus A321-200 plane minutes before it landed in Daegu, causing panic among passengers. The incident occurred on May 26, with the plane landing safely. Nine teenagers, all passengers, were sent to hospital with breathing issues. The transport ministry is investigating violations of aviation safety laws, with the detained man being held by police.

images.alt_text: Asiana Airlines' Airbus A321 plane, of which a passenger opened a door on a flight shortly before the aircraft landed, is pictured at an airport in Daegu, South Korea May 26, 2023.  Yonhap via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. SOUTH KOREA OUT. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES.

site_title: Modern art thrives in historic Istanbul
summary: Istanbul has seen a thriving modern art scene despite the country's political and economic conditions. The city is home to notable institutions such as Istanbul Modern, Salt Galata, and Borusan Contemporary, which feature works by top Turkish and international artists. The new Istanbul Modern building, designed by Pritzker laureate Renzo Piano, is a temple of modernism that houses a spectacular collection of contemporary art. This development is a testament to the city's ability to adapt and flourish amidst challenging circumstances.

site_title: Dubai’s luxury real estate sales drive global rebound
summary: Dubai's luxury real estate market has driven a global rebound, with 88 homes sold for over $10 million in the first quarter, surpassing Hong Kong and New York. The city now accounts for 17% of global luxury sales, up from 2% in 2019. Global luxury sales rose 11% in the first quarter, but the value of properties purchased slipped 4% to $7.2 billion. Knight Frank estimates luxury purchases will total up to $27 billion this year, down from $33 billion in 2022.

site_title: Brookfield cedes defaulted Los Angeles office tower to receiver
summary: Brookfield has handed over control of the EY Plaza office tower in downtown Los Angeles to a receiver after stopping payments on the building's $305 million debt. The 41-floor tower, which opened in 1985, is now being managed by Colliers after Brookfield's debt burden exceeded the market value of the building. This is the second Brookfield building in the city to enter receivership, following the Gas Company Tower. The office vacancy rate in downtown Los Angeles reached a record 30% in the first quarter, and office prices are forecast to fall 55% by 2030.

site_title: Malaysia’s inflation eases to 3.3% in April, lowest in 11 months
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate decreased to 3.3% in April, the lowest in 11 months, according to the Department of Statistics Malaysia. This moderation was largely due to slower price growth in the transport segment. The inflation rate was in line with economist median forecasts. On a monthly basis, the consumer price index (CPI) increased marginally by 0.1% from March to April.

images.alt_text: Asia is in the midst of a blistering heatwave, in line with predictions from climate scientists that 2023 could be the world’s hottest year.

site_title: China’s home-grown C919 completes first commercial flight
summary: China's state-backed Commercial Aviation Corp of China (Comac) has completed the country's first commercial flight on the C919, a home-grown narrow-body jet. The C919 took off from Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport on May 28 and landed at Beijing Capital Airport two hours later. The aircraft, which began development 15 years ago, marks a milestone in China's effort to become more self-reliant in aviation. President Xi Jinping hailed the project as a triumph of Chinese innovation, and Comac has won 1,035 orders from 32 customers.

site_title: Economic development in Asia still faces many challenges: China minister
summary: Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao acknowledged the challenges facing economic and trade development in the Asia-Pacific region, but emphasized China's willingness to contribute as a major developing country. Despite China's own economic struggles, Wang urged APEC countries to promote open regionalism, deepen trade and investment cooperation, and support sustainable and inclusive trade development. He also called for policy exchanges, industrial cooperation, and infrastructure investment to fortify global supply chains.

images.alt_text: Closing out two days of talks in Detroit, the Apec host, US Trade Representative Katherine Tai,  issued a chair’s statement summarising the discussions, with an emphasis on inclusiveness, fighting climate change and sustainability.
Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao’s trip to the US comes after G7 leaders met in Hiroshima, at which US President Joe Biden and other G7 leaders took aim at China over “economic coercion”
UAW president Shawn Fain noted the UAW has lost 1 million members since 1980 – a decline he blamed on trade policy.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher on optimism of debt ceiling deal
summary: US stocks closed higher on Friday, with the S&P 500 rising 1.3% to 4,205.45, the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.0% to 33,093.34, and the Nasdaq soaring 2.2% to 12,975.69. The optimism comes as Democrats and Republicans inch towards a deal to avert a potentially catastrophic US debt default, with the Treasury Department warning the US could run out of money to pay all existing spending obligations as early as June 5.

site_title: Franck Muller makes a splash with colourful new collection
summary: Franck Muller has unveiled a new collection featuring colourful and sporty timepieces, including the Grand Central Tourbillon Flash CX 36, Skafander 43, and Vanguard Damas. The Grand Central Tourbillon Flash CX 36 boasts multiple colour options and a neon strap, while the Skafander 43 is available in various colours with matching rubber straps. The Vanguard Damas features Damascus steel, inspired by samurai sword fighting, and is available in a steely grey tone. The collection also includes four other watches, ranging from S$15,800 to S$188,600.

images.alt_text: The #FR2NCK Muller Vanguard is a limited edition of 800 pieces.

site_title: Europe: Shares log worst day in two months on UK inflation shock, debt ceiling concerns
summary: European stocks logged their worst day in two months, falling 1.8% as the US debt ceiling negotiations stalled, UK core inflation surged to a 31-year high, and luxury stocks hit a seven-week low. Real estate and travel stocks took the biggest hits, with UK homebuilders dropping after interest rate hike bets intensified. The Stoxx 600 index slid, with European markets in the red, as risk sentiment deteriorated amid concerns over inflation and economic headwinds.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.6 per cent lower on Tuesday, logging its steepest one-day percentage fall in three weeks.

site_title: The Singapore luxury handbag label that’s been quietly gaining fans among royalty and high society
summary: Singapore luxury handbag label Llora, founded by Ling Fu in 2015, has gained popularity among royalty and high-society women. Fu, who was frustrated with the buying process of coveted handbags, started her own label after learning leather working and handbag-making from craftsmen in Italy. Llora's handbags are designed with attention to detail and timeless designs, featuring materials like crocodile skin and semi-precious stones. The brand is now available at Harrods and the Raffles Hotel shopping arcade, and Fu has built a fan base through word-of-mouth, with clients appreciating the brand's honesty and commitment to quality.

images.alt_text: Francoise Bettencourt Meyers, vice-chairwoman of the L’Oreal’s board, the wealthiest woman on the planet, is the latest French billionaire to benefit from the spending spree.

site_title: Crypto startup co-founded by OpenAI’s Sam Altman raises US$115 million
summary: Crypto startup Tools for Humanity, co-founded by OpenAI's Sam Altman, has raised US$115 million in funding from investors, including Blockchain Capital and Andreessen Horowitz. The startup aims to create a digital ID for every living person using blockchain and iris scanning technology. The new funding will be used for product expansion and hiring new employees. The company's identity technology is seen as crucial in a world where AI raises questions of human identity online.

site_title: BT Explains: US debt default? Here’s why Singaporeans should worry
summary: The US debt ceiling is set to expire on June 1, potentially leading to a historic default, which would hurt the US economy and rattle global markets. A default would cause job losses, tank imports, and lead to a decline in global growth. The US credit rating, currently AAA, is under threat of downgrade, which would have significant repercussions on global financial markets. Analysts predict that the US dollar may strengthen and the Singdollar may weaken in the near term due to flight to quality, potentially affecting Singapore's economy.

images.alt_text: Analysts believe that a default on US debt would be unprecendented and unpredictable.

US President Joe Biden, left, confers with House Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) during a St. Patrick's Day luncheon at the Capitol in Washington on March 17, 2023. The US Treasury is running out of cash, leaving little time to resolve a debt ceiling standoff that could result in default.

site_title: Cathay CEO says Hong Kong’s image damaged by cabin crew incident
summary: Cathay Pacific's CEO, Ronald Lam, stated that a recent incident involving cabin crew making "inappropriate comments" about customers on a flight has damaged the airline's image and Hong Kong's, causing significant backlash from the public and media. The incident, which was recorded and shared online, led to the firing of the three crew members. Lam acknowledged that the incident reinforced a long-held perception that Cathay has not provided high-quality services to customers from diverse backgrounds, prompting him to call for a deeper examination of the airline's culture to address these concerns.

images.alt_text: “We have suspended the flight attendants concerned and launched an internal investigation,” the Cathay says.
Covid-related disruption had such an impact on Hong Kong air travel that on one day in March last year, Cathay flew just 58 passengers.

site_title: Citi to pursue IPO for Mexico retail unit after sale fails
summary: Citigroup plans to pursue an initial public offering (IPO) of its Banamex unit in Mexico, which consists of consumer, small business, and middle-market banking operations. The move follows a strategic overhaul by CEO Jane Fraser to exit 14 consumer banking markets in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and Mexico. The IPO is expected to be completed in 2025, with Mexico's Grupo Mexico having previously expressed interest in acquiring the unit. Citi's shares fell 1.7% in pre-market trading following the announcement.

site_title: Some capital ideas for profit-sharing
summary: Singapore's shophouse market saw a $37 million sale with a $16 million profit for its owner in just five years, indicating potential for capital appreciation. Despite a dip in sales in 2022, February data shows a return to the condominium market with rising prices in all regions except the Core Central Region. Experts propose alternative investment options such as Reits, joint ownership, and fractionalisation to make high-value assets more accessible to average citizens. New commercial projects, including the record-breaking sale of Solitaire on Cecil, and a surge in art sales in Hong Kong, suggest a rising tide in luxury property investments.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low

site_title: New restaurants showcase chefs’ personal takes on heritage cooking
summary: Four new restaurants in Singapore showcase chefs' personal takes on heritage cooking from Malay, Indian, Indonesian, Singaporean, and Korean cultures. Chef Hafizzul Hashim's Restaurant Fiz celebrates the diversity of South-east Asia, blending ancient techniques with contemporary sensibilities. Chef Nurl Asyraffie Mohamed Shukor's Arang offers modern Malay cooking influenced by the flavors of the archipelago, while chefs Dillon Ng and Lusiana Hendrika's Foliage highlights local dishes with a refined approach. Meanwhile, chefs Mano Thevar and Sun Kim's Tambi combines Indian and Korean flavors in a joint effort.

images.alt_text: The interiors of Cloudstreet restaurant.

site_title: UK companies watchdog proposes tougher disclosures on internal controls
summary: The UK's corporate governance watchdog, the Financial Reporting Council, has proposed tougher disclosures on internal controls for listed companies starting January 2025. This follows collapses at retailers BHS and builder Carillion, which led to recommendations for stronger internal controls to improve audit quality. The proposed updates to the British Corporate Governance Code will require boards to state if internal controls have been kept effective during the reporting period and explain why. The changes aim to ensure accurate financial reports and avoid a one-off review of effectiveness.

images.alt_text: ESGpedia 2.0 will have greater data coverage, enhanced solutions and analytics, and assessment tools, said Benjamin Soh, founder and managing director of Stacs, which is behind the platform. PHOTO:
A survey conducted by Schneider Electric found that linking executive remuneration to decarbonisation progress could drive companies’ green plans.
Generative AI models have become well known for making mistakes, or “hallucinations”, spewing up misinformation with uncanny certainty.

site_title: The R word
summary: Singapore's first-quarter GDP numbers showed a weaker-than-expected economic slowdown, prompting economists to cut forecasts and ease off on monetary tightening. The property market responded cautiously, with new home sales rising for a third consecutive month but down 25% year-over-year. Despite a flood of new launches, market dynamics are expected to differ from last year's new launch drought. Outbound investment deals surged 76.7% in Q1, with S$19.3 billion in total value, as developers turn to overseas opportunities. Analysts predict Reit managers may shift focus to asset enhancements due to high financing costs.
