site_title: Biden to nominate Democrat for key seat on US telecom regulator: sources
summary: President Joe Biden plans to nominate attorney Anna Gomez for a key seat on the US Federal Communications Commission (FCC), ending a 2-2 deadlock since January 2021. Gomez, a Democratic telecommunications attorney, will replace a vacant seat, and Biden will also renominate Democratic commissioner Geoffrey Starks and Republican commissioner Brendan Carr for new five-year terms. This move aims to reinstate landmark net neutrality rules revoked under former President Donald Trump, a goal Biden signed an executive order for in 2021.

site_title: Gender pay gap: how new EU pay transparency laws will make men and women’s wages more equal
summary: The European Union has adopted a new pay transparency directive to help reduce the gender pay gap, which remains close to 13% despite efforts to improve equality over the past decade. The directive includes measures to ensure employers share aggregated pay data by gender, and workers have the right to obtain pay information about other workers doing equal work. While pay transparency alone cannot address all causes of the gap, evidence suggests it can help reduce information asymmetries and make it easier for workers to identify and act against pay discrimination. The EU hopes the directive will help close the gap further, but it will be a challenging task due to drivers of wage inequality such as unconscious bias and stereotyping.

images.alt_text: Goldman's US$215 million settlement of the gender-discrimination class-action lawsuit against it means the juicy details of its culture and practices won’t be aired in court.
Setting an expectation that it’s OK (or even necessary) to work beyond your contracted hours disadvantages those that need more flexibility, such as carers, who are typically women.
It has never been made clear how a menstrual leave policy will deliver the positive outcomes they're intended for.
Recent research shows men are 19 per cent more likely to assess their abilities higher than they really are, which can affect career outcomes for men and women.

site_title: Tomb Raider games firm Embracer tumbles after partnership talks collapse
summary: Embracer, a Swedish games group, reported a 40% drop in shares after a large strategic partnership fell through unexpectedly. The deal, worth over $2 billion, would have improved profit and cash flow predictability. Embracer had lowered its profit guidance due to game delays, weaker demand, and negative reception for some new games. The company also postponed game releases, cutting its adjusted profit forecast for the current year to 7-9 billion krona. The deal's collapse and lowered outlook led to Embracer's shares hitting an all-time low.

images.alt_text: In Shadow Of The Tomb Raider, gamers can explore underwater tombs, among other things.

site_title: TSMC executive says talks on possible plant in Germany continue
summary: TSMC executive Kevin Zhang confirmed talks with partners to invest up to 10 billion euros to build a chip fabrication plant in Germany, citing the need for a diverse supply to serve European customers. The project's earliest decision is expected in August, but Zhang did not disclose the size of the subsidy or cost. The move aims to capitalize on Europe's significant customer base and demand for semiconductors.

site_title: SoftBank exploring offering credit funds to tech startups: sources
summary: SoftBank Investment Advisers is exploring a private credit strategy to provide debt or debt-like financing for late-stage tech startups, targeting mid-teens returns. The plan aims to offer liquidity options to tech startups amid a slow venture funding environment and weak IPO exits. This move comes as several major firms have stepped in to fill the funding gap created by Silicon Valley Bank's collapse. SoftBank's Vision Funds have seen significant losses due to underperformance of major investments, prompting the company to seek alternative funding sources.

images.alt_text: The Korean company, founded in 2005, is betting on growth in software services for customers such as hotels and hospitality providers.

Signage displayed outside a SoftBank Corp. store in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, May 11, 2022. SoftBank Group Corp. is scheduled to release its full-year results on May 12. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: US criticises China restriction on Micron chips
summary: The US has criticized China for restricting the sale of chips from American giant Micron, citing national security concerns. China's cybersecurity watchdog instructed operators to stop buying from Micron due to potential network security issues. This move comes amid a feud between the two powers on semiconductors, with the US imposing sweeping restrictions on China's access to high-end chips last year. The US Commerce Department is addressing concerns with China, while Micron has products with "relatively serious potential network security issues".

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden has previously voiced optimism about holding a long-anticipated phone conversation with Xi, though he didn’t give any indication on how soon that might take place.
Micron, which has previously said it stood by the security of its products and commitments to customers, is evaluating the conclusion of the review.
The probe is the latest escalation in the ongoing chip war between the United States and China.
Dram chips are memory chips that lose the memory when the power is off.

site_title: Alibaba’s cloud arm to cut 7% of staff in overhaul, sources say
summary: Alibaba's cloud division is undergoing a significant overhaul, with plans to cut approximately 7% of its staff, sources claim. The move is part of a broader restructuring aimed at preparing the unit for a potential spinoff and initial public offering (IPO). Alibaba aims to fully separate its cloud business within a year, with analysts valuing the business at over $30 billion. The company plans to streamline its operations and attract external financing to drive growth, with a standalone cloud platform potentially surpassing Alibaba in size.

site_title: Sri Lanka eyes Chinese tourism to help ease debt crisis
summary: Sri Lanka is targeting 500,000 Chinese tourists in 2024, nearly doubling pre-Covid visitor levels, to alleviate its debt crisis. The country aims to raise US$2.5 billion from Chinese tourism, comparable to the recent IMF bailout. Sri Lanka clinched a US$3 billion IMF bailout loan in March and is seeking debt restructuring to release next round of funds. To attract tourists, the government plans to offer free visas for Chinese travellers until November and increase flights to Sri Lanka, operated by Chinese carriers.

images.alt_text: Krishna Srinivasan, Director of the Asia and Pacific Department at the IMF says the governance exercise will identify key weaknesses and corruption vulnerabilities across six key areas including central bank governance, financial sector oversight, market regulations among others.

site_title: Hedge funds’ ultra-bearish oil bets signal US recession angst
summary: Hedge funds' trading positions are near the most bearish levels since 2011, indicating a high risk of US recession. Speculators are bracing for a market downturn, particularly in diesel and gasoil, which power the economy. The Federal Reserve's rate hikes, China's economic slowdown, and a potential US debt default are contributing to the bearish outlook. This suggests that oil prices could plummet, exacerbating the economic concerns.

images.alt_text: The Paris-based agency raised its forecast for global oil demand by 200,000 bpd to 102 million bpd, noting that China’s recovery after the lifting of Covid-19 curbs had surpassed expectations, with demand reaching a record 16 million bpd in March.

site_title: Private sector R&D crucial to Singapore’s energy efficiency: Amy Khor
summary: Senior Minister of State for the Ministry of Sustainability and Environment Amy Khor emphasized the importance of private sector involvement in researching and developing green solutions to improve Singapore's energy efficiency. She highlighted the need for innovative solutions such as cost-efficient cooling and ventilation, smart-energy management strategies, and smart building management to meet the country's "80-80-80 in 2030" targets. The private sector is encouraged through incentives and grants, and Dr. Khor also discussed the decarbonization of Singapore's energy mix by introducing more renewable energy sources and researching low-carbon alternatives.

images.alt_text: Solar panels on the roof of Blk 278A Compassvale Bow in Sengkang. To date, about 3,300 HDB blocks have been equipped with solar panels.
Large oil storage tanks seen against the waters of the Singapore Strait.

site_title: Even at record prices, gold continues to retain allure over silver and platinum
summary: Gold prices reached an all-time high of US$2,081 an ounce in early May, outperforming silver, platinum, and palladium this year. Despite a recent drop below the US$2,000 threshold, gold remains 14.8% higher than its January value. Silver, which peaked at US$26.12 an ounce, has fallen to US$23.75, 52% below its 1980 record. Platinum and palladium have also underperformed, with platinum trading at US$1,074 an ounce and palladium at US$1,491, 25% cheaper than gold. Economists predict silver will rise sharply towards the end of 2023 and remain buoyant in 2024 due to growing demand for solar power.

images.alt_text: Good gold returns require impeccable market timing — otherwise, long-term pain ensues.
While gold is considered a hedge against inflation, rising interest rates dull non-yielding bullion’s appeal.

site_title: Wings v tenders: the choice says more about you than you think
summary: A choice between chicken wings and tenders at a bar reveals more about a person's preferences than they might think. Chicken wings, with their uneven cooking and messy texture, appeal to those who enjoy a challenge. In contrast, chicken tenders, a single piece of meat formed from tenderloin, satisfy the desire for consistency and convenience. The preference between the two reflects a desire for either mental stimulation or comfort food, with wings representing a more adventurous and hands-on experience, while tenders embody a more straightforward and uniform approach.

images.alt_text: Hiromi Matsumoto serving a plate of karaage, a Japanese style fried chicken at an izakaya bar in Tokyo, March 1, 2023.

site_title: Modern heritage cooking
summary: Chefs from Malay, Chinese, Indian, and Korean backgrounds are reinterpreting traditional heritage food to create personal narratives. This new approach to heritage cooking is showcased in various dining concepts, such as Restaurant Fiz, Thevar 2.0, and Tinto. Meanwhile, the Singapore International Festival of the Arts kicked off with exciting events, and two local designers have launched their own leather lines.

images.alt_text:
jecover25 - restaurant fiz Bafun Uni & Ikura

Credit Restaurant Fiz

site_title: 4 years’ jail for ex-independent director convicted of cheating after failing to declare S$1.5m fee
summary: Former lead independent director Christopher Chong Meng Tak, 64, was sentenced to 4 years' jail for failing to declare a S$1.5 million fee for his role in acquiring several companies in 2015. Chong had concealed his interest in the acquisition from the board and seller, inducing the healthcare firm SOG to proceed with the deal at a lower price. He was convicted in February and had intended to appeal, but the court handed down the sentence on May 17.

site_title: Laid-off tech workers still in demand elsewhere – but may not be in jobs they prefer
summary: Tech workers in Singapore laid off by large multinational corporations may still find employment, but often in lower-paying jobs. Many have landed new jobs within three to six months, with 72.8% re-entering employment within six months. However, 64.1% of those who landed new jobs did so in a different industry. While top tech talent remains in demand, the layoffs have freed up positions in smaller firms, and companies are now more conservative in hiring. The market correction may lead to downward mobility, with redundant workers taking less preferred jobs.

images.alt_text: 80,000 high-paying jobs in infocomms sector by 2025 under updated industry map
This will be a “strange year” for attracting, hiring and retaining staff, says a new report on South-east Asian tech talent.
Hiring weakness has been spotted in sectors like manufacturing and infrastructure, said recruiters.

site_title: Rushdie says 'struggle continues' in first public appearance since attack
summary: Salman Rushdie, the 75-year-old author, made his first public appearance since a knife attack in August 2022, delivering an emotional address at a PEN America Literary Gala in New York City. Rushdie, who lost sight in one eye after the attack, received an honorary award and proclaimed that "the struggle continues" in the face of terrorism and violence. The attack, which occurred at a literary conference in New York, was carried out by a 24-year-old man from New Jersey who pleaded not guilty to assault charges.

images.alt_text: The changes include making Oompa-Loompas in Charlie and the Chocolate Factory gender neutral.

site_title: Hatten Land refutes claim its unit is under probe for Melaka project Harbour City
summary: Hatten Land, a Singapore-listed developer, has refuted claims that its subsidiary Gold Mart Sdn Bhd (GMSB) is under investigation by Malaysian authorities over the Harbour City project in Melaka. GMSB allegedly failed to apply for a housing developer licence, but Hatten Land stated that the units sold were commercial, not residential, and buyers were aware of this. The project, which includes a mall, theme park, and three hotel blocks, has been delayed due to a legal dispute and the Covid-19 pandemic. Hatten Land aims to complete the project as soon as possible.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Hatten Land said it has in Q3 prioritised securing anchor tenants to its malls.

site_title: Millennium hires equity special situations experts in Singapore
summary: Millennium Management, a global alternative investment firm, has hired two equity special situations specialists, Justin Tang and Jin Rui Oh, in Singapore. Both were former directors at United First Partners and have expertise in corporate actions such as mergers and acquisitions, special dividends, and buybacks. This move is seen as a boost to Millennium's equity special situations strategy, which is based on corporate actions and has gained popularity in Asia amid rising activist investor campaigns.

site_title: Cardboard, construction nets and coffee pods go couture
summary: The Lendlease Trash to Couture fashion design competition in Singapore showcased eco-friendly designs created from waste materials, promoting sustainability in the fashion industry. The top prize was awarded to Jamela Law, whose garment made from 200 Tetra Pak drink cartons impressed the judges. Other standout designs included Gini Ika Jayanti's coffee pod and gunny sack ensemble, and Andrea Karundeng's jute sack and cardboard box dress. The competition aimed to raise awareness of waste reduction and circularity, with the winning designs to be showcased in a roving exhibition. Industry experts emphasized the need for businesses to incorporate sustainable practices and educate consumers about environmental issues to drive change.

images.alt_text: A worker walks through the wastewater treatment plant at textiles manufacturer Ghim Li Group's fabric mill.
Alternative materials with a sustainable twist are no longer a novelty, and are now mainstream in fashion.
Hermès emphasised its use of organic materials at Milan Design Week 2023.

site_title: GuocoLand appoints new managing director for Malaysia unit
summary: GuocoLand appoints Noorbaizura Hermeyney, 43, as the new managing director of its Malaysia unit, effective May 18. Hermeyney replaces Tan Wee Bee, who is leaving for personal interests, and brings nearly 20 years of experience in investment and asset management. The appointment is seen as a strategic move to take GuocoLand (Malaysia) into its next phase of development and growth. Financial controller Yeap Yen Yen will also step up as chief financial officer on the same day.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
DBS was optimistic about GuocoLand’s strategy and its appeal to buyers, citing the example of Lentor Modern.
An artist's impression of Lentor Hills Estate highlighting the two sites currently on the market.
Singapore's government estimates the new round of cooling measures to impact about 10 per cent of all residential property transactions.

site_title: US: Stocks drop on worries about consumers, debt ceiling talks
summary: US stocks dropped on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.0% to 33,012.14, amid concerns about consumer health and debt ceiling talks. Home Depot's downcast earnings report, which included a drop in quarterly sales and a cut to its 2023 forecast, weighed on the Dow. The S&P 500 fell 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index dipped 0.2%. Markets are watching for talks between President Biden and House Republican leaders to avert a US debt default.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 73.23 points, or 0.22 per cent, at the open to 33,275.37.

site_title: Sea’s path to profit paved with layoffs, single-ply toilet paper
summary: Forrest Li, CEO of Sea Ltd, implemented a series of drastic measures to turn the company profitable, including laying off 10% of its workforce, freezing pay, and cutting expenses. The company reported its first quarterly profit in 14 years, $427 million in March, and its stock soared 22%. Li argues that Sea's unique opportunity lies in bringing e-commerce to emerging markets, where Amazon may be at a disadvantage. The company's path to profit is seen as a challenge to rivals, including Grab Holdings and GoTo Group, and a model for other tech companies to follow.

images.alt_text: Despite their recent doubling, the rally in Sea’s shares still looks like just a tiny blip on a longer-term price chart.
The salary hike marked a milestone for the Singapore-based e-commerce and gaming company, which had previously announced several rounds of layoffs and salary freezes.

site_title: US single-family housing starts rise in April; March revised down
summary: US single-family housing starts rose 1.6% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 846,000 units in April, despite a revised downward revision of March data. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market index increased to 50 in May, the first time since July 2022, due to a surge in previously owned homes. The housing market has been impacted by the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening, with average 30-year fixed mortgage rates dropping from 7.08% in November to 6.35% last week.

site_title: Chinese foreign minister to visit Australia: SCMP
summary: Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang is expected to visit Australia in July, as diplomatic relations between the two trading partners stabilize. This visit comes after tensions eased following Australia's change in government in 2022. Qin Gang's visit is seen as part of the restored normal course of bilateral diplomacy, including the annual Foreign and Strategic Dialogue. The visit aims to further improve relations and remove trade barriers on Australian exports.

images.alt_text: A shopkeeper (L) passes a customer their change in GBP pound sterling ten and twenty pound notes, at a shop in east London on March 31, 2023. (Photo by Susannah Ireland / AFP) / TO GO WITH AFP STORY BY Akshata KAPOOR
The budget’s build-to-rent proposals apply to projects of 50 or more apartments or dwellings made available for rent to the general public.
Australian trade data shows exports worth A$60.5 million (S$50.3 million) of copper ore and concentrate to China in January.

ASIC says it secured 23 corrective disclosure outcomes and issued 11 infringement notices between July 2022 and March 2023 as part of its investigation into public companies, managed funds and superannuation funds’ claims about their ESG credentials.

site_title: The long wait is over: New ‘Zelda’ hits shelves
summary: Nintendo has released the highly anticipated next installment in its 40-year-old gaming saga, "The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom." The game, which features Princess Zelda and elf-like warrior Link, has sold 125 million copies worldwide since its first edition in 1986. With its release, Nintendo aims to boost sales and prolong the life of its Switch console, which experts say is in its dotage after seven years on the shelves. The game is expected to be a major contributor to Nintendo's sales this year, potentially becoming the best-selling game in history.

images.alt_text: The EU antitrust enforcer is expected to clear the acquisition after Microsoft agreed to licensing deals with cloud streaming rivals.
“We try to not only put one system in every home, but several in every home, or even one for every person,” Nintendo said in a statement accompanying its earnings report on Tuesday (May 9). T
The video game-based film earned an estimated US$40 million for the Friday-through-Sunday period in the United States and Canada, for a domestic total so far of US$490 million.

site_title: Fintech lender Jenfi raises US$6.6 million in pre-series B funding round
summary: Fintech startup Jenfi has raised US$6.6 million in a pre-series B funding round led by Headline Asia. The funding will accelerate technological development and enhance credit underwriting capabilities. Jenfi, which offers revenue-based financing to digital businesses in South-east Asia, has deployed over US$25 million to 600 companies. The company plans to expand its offerings to more customers across the region, with CEO Jeffrey Liu aiming to enhance speed and accuracy of credit assessments. This funding round follows a previous US$6.3 million Series A round led by Monk's Hill Venture in 2021.

images.alt_text: The company offers loans of up at US$1 million as non-dilutive capital to businesses in areas like consumer-tech and e-commerce.
Former Guavapass CEO snags US$6.3m for new Singapore-based financing startup Jenfi

site_title: Biden and McCarthy plan to resume debt ceiling talks on Tuesday
summary: US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy plan to resume debt ceiling talks on Tuesday, May 16. The meeting comes ahead of Biden's foreign trip, including the Group of Seven and Quad summits. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that the US risks default as early as June 1 if the debt limit isn't suspended or raised. Biden expressed optimism about reaching a deal, saying he believes there's a desire from both parties to reach an agreement.

images.alt_text: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office forecast on Friday that the country could default on its debts by June 15 if lawmakers fail to agree on a deal with Biden to raise current limits on government spending.

The new numbers from the CBO show an even worse fiscal outlook than the agency presented in February, and may be seized on by Republican negotiators attempting to use the current debt-limit showdown with Democrats to slash federal spending.

site_title: PacWest claims US$15 billion of immediately available liquidity
summary: PacWest Bancorp reported having US$15 billion of immediately available liquidity, sufficient to fund cash flow needs over the next 12 months. Despite this reassurance, shares plummeted 7% in pre-market trade due to investor concerns about the stability of mid-sized banks. The bank's deposit outflows of 9.5% over the week ended May 5, mainly on May 4 and 5, following news reports of exploration options. Regulatory protection for bank deposits and additional backstops are urged by Wall Street executives and analysts to alleviate the crisis.

site_title: From trash to couture
summary: The 'You Won't Believe it's Trash: Trash to Couture' fashion design contest, organized by Lendlease, showcased finalists' creative use of waste materials to create avant-garde apparel. The contest aimed to promote sustainability in the fashion industry, with a goal to halve greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. Contestants transformed materials such as hard hats, fishing nets, and other unconventional waste into stunning designs, demonstrating the potential for eco-designers to make a positive impact on the industry.

images.alt_text: Selected finalists from the second "You Won't Believe it's Trash: Trash to Couture" design competition, organised by Lendlease, the 313@Somerset on May 11, 2023. Collage by BT.

site_title: Catalonia tells landlords use or lose empty housing in affordable property drive
summary: The Catalan government has told landlords to find occupants for their empty properties or risk expropriation. The move aims to address the region's affordable housing shortage, with up to 70 empty houses set to be repurposed in 14 towns. The plan, which comes ahead of Spain's local elections, allows property owners one month to explain their empty properties, after which the government can expropriate them. The government has budgeted 5 million euros for potential expropriations, estimating it could cover the cost of buying 50-70 houses for half their market value.

images.alt_text: The European Commission has urged EU countries to end programmes allowing investors to obtain citizenship, and to tighten checks when issuing residency permits, describing them as a security and money-laundering risk.

site_title: Hard to justify low carbon prices in Asia-Pacific’s developed markets: BMI
summary: A new report from BMI finds that low carbon prices in Asia-Pacific's developed markets, such as South Korea and Japan, are hard to justify compared to those in the European Union, United States, and Canada. The report cites that carbon prices in Tokyo and Japan are significantly lower than the recommended levels of $75 per tonne by 2030 for developed markets. BMI notes that introducing carbon-pricing instruments could alleviate the region's reliance on imported fossil fuels, improve macroeconomic resilience, and aid efforts at fiscal consolidation, but faces challenges such as political opposition and asset-stranding risks.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Developing Asia – which relies on steady and cheap access to power, currently coal generated for the most part, for economic growth – cannot simply replace coal with renewable energy.

site_title: From LED lights to reverse osmosis, Ghim Li stays ahead of the sustainability curve, Sustainability Impact Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A car dealership has pledged to support the transition to sustainable transportation by investing in electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure and promoting eco-friendly options. The dealership plans to install EV charging stations across its locations, making it easier for customers to switch to greener vehicles. By doing so, the dealership aims to reduce its carbon footprint and contribute to a more environmentally friendly transportation system. This move is seen as a step towards a faster transition to green highways and a more sustainable future for the automotive industry.

site_title: Australian consumer mood bleak in May after surprise rate hike, budget
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment index fell 7.9% in May, with pessimists outnumbering optimists, after a surprise interest rate hike by the Reserve Bank of Australia and a "mildly disappointing" federal budget. The index reading of 79.0 was the lowest since March 2020. Higher living costs led to consumers holding off on buying major household items, with the index dipping 0.4%. Despite a surge in confidence in house prices, 70% of consumers expect mortgage rates to rise over the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: A shopper holds items and looks at others on sale at a clothing retail store in central Sydney, Australia, March 19, 2017. REUTERS/Steven Saphore

site_title: Raising Malaysia’s EPF employer rate to 20% will hurt competitiveness, business leaders say
summary: Malaysian business leaders oppose a proposed increase in the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) employer contribution rate to 20%, citing concerns it would hurt the country's competitiveness and attract foreign investments. The proposed rate hike, which would rank Malaysia the highest in South-east Asia, has been met with resistance from business associations, who argue that it would lead to higher operating costs and potentially cause businesses to fold or move abroad. The Malaysian government has received the proposal from the Union Network International-Malaysia Labour Centre, but has yet to announce a decision.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Economists said extending the retirement age may be an inevitable option for low income groups in Malaysia to rebuild their retirement savings.

Bank Negara Malaysia said in the article that Malaysians could run out of savings by the age of 58 due to low wages, high debt, and premature withdrawals from their retirement funds during the pandemic.

Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is under pressure to let citizens dip into their retirement savings once again, with the opposition clamouring that he allow for another round of “targeted withdrawals” to help struggling Malaysians.

site_title: Toyota sees 10% rise in annual profit after bumper Q4; shares jump
summary: Toyota forecasts a 10% rise in annual operating income to 3.0 trillion yen, following a 35% surge in Q4 operating profit to 626.9 billion yen. The company expects higher sales in major markets and improved semiconductor supply, boosting vehicle production to 10.1 million units. Toyota shares jumped 2.2% after the announcement, despite facing challenges in China's rapidly shifting EV market and problems at affiliate Daihatsu. The company aims to introduce 10 new battery-powered vehicles by 2026.

images.alt_text: Masahiko Maeda, Toyota CEO, Asia Region, says  the vehicles customers are using were safe and the vehicle is a quality car.

A worker installs a radiator car parts in the trimming area on the assembly line of the Daihatsu assembly plant in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Friday, September 21, 2012.  Photographer: Dadang Tri/Bloomberg

site_title: Connections that threaten Asian growth
summary: Asian economies' growth may be threatened by the "connections world," where business and politics are intertwined, fostering cronyism and limiting competition. This arrangement has driven growth but also created market concentration, limited job creation, and rising income inequality. The "connections world" breeds inefficiency, as business groups focus on short-term profits and restrict innovation. To overcome these challenges, Asian economies must transform business groups into more transparent organizations and weaken the links between politicians and business, requiring policies such as corporate governance reforms, inheritance taxes, and competition policy changes.

site_title: Apple tapping US high-grade bond market with US$5 billion deal
summary: Apple is selling $5 billion in US high-grade bonds, with the longest portion expected to yield 135 basis points over comparable Treasuries. The proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including stock repurchases and dividend payments. The deal is part of a larger trend in corporate debt markets, with up to 15 borrowers expected to sell debt this week ahead of key inflation readings. This is Apple's first bond sale since August, and the company aims to maintain its net-cash-neutral goal.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 23, 2020 the Apple logo is seen on the window of the newly opened company store in Bangkok. - Germany's anti-cartel watchdog said April 5, 2023 it had placed US computing giant Apple under closer surveillance for any possible abuse of its market position. (Photo by Mladen ANTONOV / AFP)
The rally in Apple’s shares buoyed optimism across Wall Street, after CEO Tim Cook’s results late on Thursday that so far has been less bad than expected.
Apple CEO Tim Cook is betting that the emerging markets like India will provide more opportunities for growth, with their youthful populations and relatively few iPhones.

site_title: Entrepreneurial mothers: Not having it all, but making the most of what they have
summary: Entrepreneurial mothers share their secrets to success. Amanda Ong, founder of babysitting app Aunty SG, emphasizes the importance of having an appreciative mindset. Jasmin Tay, founder of Perky Lash, sets boundaries between her personal and professional life. Despite the challenges, these mumpreneurs find joy in their careers and prioritize their well-being. By focusing on what they have, rather than what they don't have, they are able to thrive as business owners and mothers.

images.alt_text: The 75-year-old has painted the portraits of 2,765 of women in recognition of their sacrifice during the war that ended in 1975.
Abolishing the motherhood penalty

site_title: Bank Indonesia to bide its time before cutting policy rate
summary: Bank Indonesia is expected to wait until definitive signs of declining inflation before cutting its benchmark interest rate, according to nine out of 15 economists surveyed. The central bank's Governor Perry Warjiyo said inflation is falling but still above target, and the bank will evaluate monthly. Analysts expect a potential rate cut as early as September or not until 2024, with some predicting a pause in rate hikes throughout 2023 due to a dry spell and ample harvest. The decision will be made on May 25, with policymakers seeking to keep inflation within the 2-4% target range.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati says the country is on  a strong recovery path as the boost from China’s reopening and robust domestic sectors offset downside factors relating to the advanced economies.

site_title: Government studying COE market, ready to refine it if needed: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister S Iswaran stated that the government is studying the certificate of entitlement (COE) system and is prepared to refine it if needed. The recent adjustments to motorcycle COE prices have resulted in a "correction" in their prices, but predicting the future trajectory is difficult due to various factors. The government aims to ensure the market functions smoothly, with measures to curb speculation. The study comes as COE prices continue to rise, with premiums for smaller cars and electric vehicles breaking records.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Traffic condition at Bartley Road on April 28, 2023. Can be used for stories on cars, COE price, traffic accident, highway, expressway, heavy traffic, inflation.

The COE premium for smaller cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp, as well as for electric vehicles (EVs) with up to 110 kilowatts of power, finished at S$101,001, down 2.6 per cent from the previous high of S$103,721 at the April 19 tender.
THE Additional Registration Fee (ARF) will be adjusted to better differentiate between higher-end cars. Luxury cars will also be taxed at a higher rate.

site_title: Silver lining for Julius Baer Group from Credit Suisse collapse
summary: Julius Baer Group's chief executive, Philipp Rickenbacher, views the Credit Suisse crisis as a silver lining for the Swiss banking system, highlighting its strength and ability to resolve the crisis quickly. The crisis led to Julius Baer becoming the second-largest listed Swiss bank by market capitalization. Rickenbacher emphasizes the need for a "convergence of terms" around bank AT1 perpetuals and expresses confidence in the bank's capital position and controlled risk profile. Julius Baer aims to achieve sustainable profit growth through organic growth and mergers and acquisitions, investing in innovation and technology, with a focus on value services for clients.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

“We are definitely going to grow,” said Jimmy Lee, member of the executive board and head of Asia Pacific. “Not only will we hire people from outside, we will also grow our own young, talented relationship managers.”

The logo of Credit Suisse is pictured on a building near the Hallenstadion where took place the Annual General Meeting, two weeks after being bought by rival UBS in a government-brokered rescue, in Zurich, Switzerland, April 4, 2023. REUTERS/Pierre Albouy
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse is seen in front of a branch office in Bern, Switzerland November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
Bondholders in Asia are joining more than a thousand others in Europe and the US in seeking damages from the Swiss authorities.

This was an abuse of process and the resolution procedure should not be used by Switzerland to enable UBS to take over Credit Suisse to the detriment of AT1 holders,” Law firm Pallas founder and managing partner Natasha Harrison said in a statement.
FILE PHOTO: A logo is pictured on the Credit Suisse bank in Geneva, Switzerland, March 15, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: China property crisis sees new casualty with Languang delisting
summary: Sichuan Languang Development, a Chinese property developer, is likely to delist from the Shanghai Stock Exchange after its shares traded below one yuan each for 20 consecutive sessions. This marks the first delisting of a Chinese property developer since last June. The move highlights the challenges facing weaker developers in accessing funds, as investors have lost faith in the recovery and debt restructuring of smaller private developers. The delisting will suspend trading and the Shanghai Stock Exchange will make the final decision within 15 trading days.

images.alt_text: Jiayuan, which has fallen out of the top 100 builders in China based on contracted sales, in August first proposed to exchange its dollar notes in order to extend maturities.

site_title: Seatrium secures S$500 million contract to build substation platforms at two offshore wind farms
summary: Seatrium, a subsidiary of Sembcorp Marine, has secured a S$500 million contract to build substation platforms for two offshore wind farms, Empire Wind 1 and 2, off the coast of Long Island, US. The platforms will be built at Seatrium's Singapore and Indonesia yards and are expected to power over one million homes in New York. Construction is set to begin in the fourth quarter of this year and the second half of next year, respectively.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Seatrium, formerly Sembmarine, announced that the proceedings in Brazil into its subsidiary there has been suspended.

Seatrium is a combination of the words “sea” and “atrium”, which reflects the business and its aspiration to be a premier global player providing innovative engineering solutions for the offshore, marine and energy industries, said Sembmarine.

Sembcorp Marine's increased market cap of S$8.2 billion makes it the largest counter on the Straits Times Index (STI) reserve list, which means it has a chance of being added to the benchmark index – depending on how it and other index counters trade in the coming months.

site_title: Australia’s top banks look to diversify from mortgages as rates peak
summary: Australia's top banks, including ANZ and Commonwealth Bank, may diversify beyond mortgages as interest rates peak and competition intensifies. ANZ CEO Shayne Elliott stated that mortgage margins have been declining for 30 years and are expected to resume. The housing market is struggling due to high interest rates, and some banks are offering cash payments to lure borrowers. The Reserve Bank of Australia's inflation rate remains above target, indicating potential further interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Australian banks have been reaping the rewards of aggressive interest-rate hikes over the past year that fuelled banks’ revenue from lending.

Commercial real estate prices are a major concern for investors globally, as public markets price the impact of a slowing economy and the growth of remote work, while owners, especially unlisted players, resist major changes.
The Reserve Bank of Australia lifted the key interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.85 per cent, wrong-footing many economists who predicted there would be no change.

site_title: BYD to make electric vehicles in Vietnam in South-east Asia push
summary: BYD, China's largest electric vehicle (EV) brand, plans to establish its first overseas production facility in Vietnam. Following a meeting between Deputy Premier Tran Hong Ha and BYD's chairman and founder Wang Chuanfu, the company expects Vietnam to create favorable conditions for its investment. BYD aims to form a local supply chain and produce EVs for sale in Vietnam and other South-east Asian countries. This move comes after the company sold 210,295 vehicles in April, with exports accounting for about 6% of its EV sales.

images.alt_text: BYD has unveiled its Seagull electric hatchback at the recent Shanghai car show, stunning visitors with a price from just 78,000 yuan – around half the level of the cheapest new energy vehicles available elsewhere.
The BYD Seagull hatchback attracted significant attention at the Shanghai auto show at a price starting from 78,800 yuan – half the price of the cheapest new energy vehicles available elsewhere.

site_title: iPhone maker Foxconn buys huge site in India tech hub
summary: Taiwanese electronics giant Foxconn has acquired a 1.2 million-square-metre site in Bengaluru, India, to diversify its production away from China. The company, a principal assembler of Apple iPhones, aims to shift manufacturing due to strict Covid policies, industrial unrest, and diplomatic tensions with the US. Foxconn has already manufactured Apple handsets in India since 2019 at its plant in Tamil Nadu. The acquisition is part of Apple's push into India, where the company is expanding its manufacturing footprint and opening its first retail stores.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Foxconn logo is seen in this illustration taken, May 2, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US retailers cut most number of jobs in April
summary: US retailers cut the most number of jobs in April, with 67,000 positions eliminated, according to a report by Challenger, Gray & Christmas. This is a 25% decrease from the previous month. The sector has cut 337,000 jobs since the start of the year, below the 114,000 jobs cut by technology companies. The job cuts are attributed to the uncertain economy and the impact of higher interest rates on consumer spending. Retailers and consumer goods manufacturers are preparing for a tightening in consumer spending, particularly with the Fed's hike to interest rates to control inflation.

site_title: UK antitrust watchdog launches review into AI market
summary: The UK's antitrust watchdog, the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), has launched a review of the artificial intelligence (AI) market to assess how companies develop AI products with suitable consumer protections. The review aims to ensure open, competitive markets and effective consumer protection while the technology continues to evolve. The CMA will publish its full report in September, following similar efforts by the US and EU to regulate the rapidly evolving technology.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 02, 2022 a Microsoft logo is displayed at the MWC (Mobile World Congress) in Barcelona. - Wall Street stocks opened higher on April 26, 2023, lifted by strong earnings from Microsoft and other large companies, although shares of First Republic Bank tumbled again. (Photo by Josep LAGO / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken March 31, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The US Department of Commerce put out a call for input from industry actors that would serve to inform the Biden administration in drafting regulation on AI.

site_title: Another US bank under pressure. How worried should we be about a financial crisis?
summary: The US banking system is at a critical juncture, with several high-profile banks collapsing in recent months, including Silicon Valley Bank, Signature Bank, and First Republic Bank. The recent fragility and collapse may not be an isolated phenomenon, and a damaging combination of rising interest rates, changes in work patterns, and the potential of a recession could prompt a credit crunch not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. A looming concern is the commercial real estate sector, with millions of dollars in loans coming due in the next few years, increasing the risk of default.

images.alt_text: What the post-mortem reports from the Fed and FDIC reveal is, among other things, how haphazardly the failed banks were run, compared with the super-professional show they put on for investors.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) announced on May 1 that it sold the failing First Republic Bank to JP Morgan Chase & Co. First Republic Bank is the second-largest bank failure in US history.
FILE PHOTO: A First Republic Bank branch is pictured in Midtown Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., March 13, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: LHN warns profit decline of 47% for H1 2023
summary: LHN Limited, a real estate management services provider, expects a net profit before tax of at least S$19 million for the first half of its financial year ended Mar 31, 2023, a decline of over 47% compared to the same period last year. The decline is mainly due to a fair value loss on investment properties, but is partially offset by a one-off gain on the disposal of an associate. Despite this, LHN's share price rose 7.7% to close at S$0.28 on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

site_title: Integra Partners raises US$90 million for Fund II; targets fintech, digital health startups
summary: Integra Partners has raised US$90 million for its Fund II, bringing total committed capital to over US$140 million. The fund targets fintech, insurtech, and digital health startups in South-east and South Asia, aiming to make responsible financial services and healthcare more accessible and affordable. Fund II is anchored by global institutional investors and will expand Integra's regional presence, with plans for further growth in Singapore, the Philippines, India, and Pakistan.

images.alt_text: The startup was established in December 2019 by Jaggi and four others with the idea of bringing a new, greener ride-hailing option to the massive Indian market.

site_title: Malaysia’s dual wholesale 5G network could be boon for telcos, but questions remain: Analysts
summary: Malaysia's plan to introduce a second wholesale 5G network has been confirmed, which could benefit mobile network operators by allowing for network and service differentiation. Analysts, including Citi's Luis Hilado and Arthur Pineda, believe the announcement will lead to share price rebounds for MNOs. However, questions remain about the type of spectrum available, ownership model, and how the government will reduce uncertainty for telcos during the transition. The second network is expected to be rolled out after the first wholesale network reaches 80% coverage of populated areas, currently at 57.8%.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Malaysia's Communications Minister Fahmi Fadzil says DNB has achieved 57.8 per cent coverage of populated areas currently and is on track to hit 80 per cent by the end of the year.
Telcos appear to be working more closely together to better serve customers and save costs.
Malaysia's single wholesale network has reached 33.2 per cent of populated areas as at Sep 30 this year.

site_title: FLCT posts 8.6% lower H1 DPU of S$0.0352 on foreign exchange weakness
summary: FRASERS Logistics and Commercial Trust (FLCT) reported an 8.6% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0352 for its first half ended Mar 31, due to foreign exchange weakness and divestment of Cross Street Exchange in Singapore. Revenue fell 11.7% to S$208 million, with net property income (NPI) and distributable income also decreasing. Despite the lower figures, FLCT's manager remains optimistic about its logistics and industrial-focused portfolio, as well as its healthy balance sheet, with a 95.9% occupancy rate and 27.8% aggregate leverage.

images.alt_text: Alexandra Technopark accounted for 9.8 per cent of FLCT’s portfolio value as at end December.
Robert Wallace, CEO of the manager of Frasers Logistics Commercial Trust, will remain at his post until May 31 before returning to Australia to be with his family.
FLCT's property of Blythe Valley Park, a business park located in Birmingham, the United Kingdom.  Its overall occupancy for Q1 FY 2023 came in at 95.9 per cent.

site_title: Only 9 of 120 suspected money mules in OCBC phishing scam could be charged; 790 victims lost S$13.7m
summary: Singapore authorities have identified 120 suspected money mules involved in phishing scams targeting OCBC Bank customers between December 2021 and January 2022. However, due to limitations in current laws, only 9 can be charged. As a result, 790 victims lost a total of S$13.7 million. Second Minister for Home Affairs Josephine Teo stated that current laws make it difficult to take money mules to task, highlighting the need for legislative changes.

site_title: Fed pause is no reason to turn less bearish
summary: The US Federal Reserve has signaled a pause in its rapid tightening of monetary policy, with Chairman Jerome Powell stating that no decision has been made yet. However, the Fed's statement highlighted a change in rhetoric, indicating a more dovish stance. Despite this, the author remains bearish on the market, citing the lagged effect of previous rate hikes and the recent bank failures in the US. The author also notes that the US labor market remains resilient, raising the risk of further rate hikes. Meanwhile, in Singapore, the government has doubled the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) for foreigners buying residential properties, sparking concerns about the impact on the market.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul

Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, on May 3, 2023. - The Fed has been on an aggressive campaign of interest-rate hikes since March last year, rapidly raising rates to help target high inflation, which remains above its long-term target of two percent. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)
URA's flash estimate has shown a 3.2 per cent quarter-on-quarter rise for its overall private home price index in Q1 2023.

Private residential properties in Singapore's prime areas are expected to be affected the most by the latest cooling measures due to the traditionally higher component of foreign buyers in these areas compared with the city-fringe and suburban locations.
The US central bank raised its benchmark overnight interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to the 5.00-5.25 per cent range, as expected by financial markets.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on May 16, 2022 a “Now Hiring” sign at T.J. Maxx in Annapolis, Maryland. - US job gains eased in March for a second straight month, government data showed March 7, 2023, adding to signs that the world's largest economy is cooling as policymakers push on in their fight against inflation. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)

site_title: Microsoft expands AI access to public
summary: Microsoft has expanded public access to its generative artificial intelligence (AI) programs, allowing users to access AI-enhanced features of its Bing search engine and Edge internet browser without a Microsoft Account. The enhanced features can now work with images and text, and Microsoft plans to add video capabilities. Despite concerns about the risks of AI, including its potential use for fraud, Microsoft believes innovating and learning in the open is a responsible approach to developing the technology.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 02, 2022 a Microsoft logo is displayed at the MWC (Mobile World Congress) in Barcelona. - Wall Street stocks opened higher on April 26, 2023, lifted by strong earnings from Microsoft and other large companies, although shares of First Republic Bank tumbled again. (Photo by Josep LAGO / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken March 31, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Ex-Kamoshita chef serves up simple grill & oden style food at Hearth on Craig Road
summary: Chef Koki Miyoshi, formerly of Kamoshita, opens Hearth, a grill-centric izakaya in Singapore, shifting from traditional oden to irori cooking. The restaurant features a dim, cosy interior and simple, pre-prepped dishes grilled over charcoal. Highlights include a whole roasted sardine, koji-marinated pork shoulder, and fluffy fish cake in clear broth. Oden ingredients, such as carp and yolked eggs, also make an appearance. The menu balances warm and cool options, including whisky highballs and a honey pudding dessert. With a focus on fireside cooking and sincere hospitality, Hearth offers good-enough sustenance without pretension.

site_title: Recovery of Chinese air travel bodes well for Asean airport operators: analysts
summary: Chinese air travel demand is recovering rapidly, with analysts predicting a full resumption of international capacity at airports in the region this year. Historically popular destinations such as Singapore, Thailand, and Malaysia are expected to benefit from demand, while Japan and South Korea may experience a slower recovery due to earlier political spats. China's residents are taking to the skies again, with domestic demand underpinning the recovery of China's airports. Analysts expect airport operators to raise fees as they adjust to pre-pandemic profitability levels, but regulatory constraints may limit rate increases.

site_title: US private payrolls beat expectations in April
summary: US private payrolls increased by 296,000 jobs in April, beating expectations of 148,000. However, hiring could be eroded by higher interest rates cooling demand for workers and a tightening in bank lending. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise its benchmark interest rate to 5.00-5.25%. Despite this, the labor market remains tight, with 9.6 million job openings at the end of March, and economists warn of a slowdown amid recent financial market turmoil.

site_title: Euro dips below US$1.10 after eurozone data, eyes turn to US
summary: The euro dropped below the US$1.10 level to US$1.0973, flat on the day, after data showed eurozone banks are reducing credit and inflation is falling. The Australian dollar surged 1% against the US dollar after a surprise rate hike. Investors are focusing on upcoming US data, including job openings and payrolls figures, and the Federal Reserve meeting, which could influence interest rates. Expectations of US rate cuts later this year may support European currencies.

site_title: IMF raises Asia’s economic forecast on China recovery, warns of risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised Asia's economic forecast due to China's recovery, citing a focus on consumption and service-sector demand rather than investment. The IMF expects Asia to be the most dynamic region in 2023, driven by China's and India's buoyant outlooks. However, the IMF warns of risks from persistent inflation and global market volatility, particularly driven by Western banking-sector woes.

images.alt_text:
awshanghai - At the Bund, boisterous crowds jostle on a regular Monday night, excitedly snapping and posing for photos along Shanghai’s famed waterfront promenade that overlooks the financial hub’s dazzling skyline. A year since China’s most open and cosmopolitan city was ordered into a two-month lockdown that forced its 26 million residents to be confined to their homes without food and medicine in the early days, Shanghai appears to have bounced back. But signs have also emerged in China’s richest top city by gross domestic product to show that its recovery has been slow and soft.

site_title: Moving light, but with strength: Joe Green sees potential in hi-tech recycled building materials, Sustainability Impact Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A car dealership has announced its support for a green highway initiative, aiming to transition its customers to sustainable transport. The dealership, which sells electric and hybrid vehicles, will be installing solar panels and EV charging points along its premises. The move is expected to reduce the dealership's carbon footprint and encourage customers to switch to eco-friendly vehicles. The initiative is part of a larger effort to promote sustainable transportation in the region, with the goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and mitigating climate change. The dealership plans to expand its green initiatives in the coming years.

site_title: Pakistan calls out army to quell riots over ex-PM Khan’s arrest
summary: Pakistan has deployed its military to quell nationwide riots following the arrest of former Prime Minister Imran Khan on fresh corruption charges. The arrest, which came after months of political turmoil, has sparked violent protests, with at least six deaths reported. The government has approved the deployment of troops in two provinces and the capital to restore peace, amid criticism from Western powers and human rights groups. Khan's supporters have vowed to continue protesting, with many expressing concern about his treatment in custody.

images.alt_text: Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party activists and supporters of former Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan clash with policemen during a protest against the arrest of their leader, in Islamabad on May 10, 2023. Khan will appear in a special court at the capital's police headquarters to answer graft charges on May 10, a day after his shock arrest prompted violent nationwide protests.
